title: BUSINESS AND THE LAW ; S.E.C. POSITION ON TAKEOVERS
description: WASHINGTON

title: 'IDEOLOGICAL BLINDERS'
description: Recently I urged a Court of Appeals to declare unconstitutional the ''loyalty'' screenings of Americans working for the World Health Organization. The screenings, ordered by President Harry S. Truman in 1953, consist of an extensive questionnaire about applicants' political history and friends and a possible intensive field study by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A Circuit Judge, Hugh H. Bownes, listening to the argument, Leonard B. Boudin, a constitutional lawyer and professor, appears frequently before the Supreme Court, most recently in Regan against Wald, on the right to travel to Cuba. leaned back and said reflectively: ''I have a sense of dej a vu.'' His remark has more general application in today's legal-political scene. The Executive Order reminded me of those Cold War days of our domestic loyalty-security program. Thousands of good citizens were hounded from government employment by loyalty boards, Congressional committees and illegal grand jury reports, not to mention unfounded perjury prosecutions of people such as Owen Lattimore, the eminent Far Eastern scholar. Only a few writers, like I. F. Stone, Henry Steele Commager and the late Alan Barth, and only a few judges, like Hugo L. Black and William O. Douglas, raised their voices in eloquent opposition. I thought, too, of those Americans driven out of United Nations employment by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Investigations Subcommitte, the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee and other Congressional Committees. All this despite decisions in the citizens' favor by the United Nations' Administrative Tribunal and the International Court of Justice.

He is a member of the Chase Manhattan Bank's international advisory committee and a director of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

This will be held at the student center, North Campus Road and East 27th Street.

title:

 U.S. Auction Plan Awaited
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday when professional dealers sold Government securities in advance of the Treasury's refunding announcement. Analysts said the lack of institutional buying support and the high Federal funds rate also helped weaken market prices.

title: ANDOVER CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
A YEAR OF NOT MUCH ADO ON ANYTHING
description: The Senate spent last week doing nothing much about the budget, and this week started out just as slowly. When Senator Steven D. Symms, an Idaho Republican, offered a cost-cutting amendment, only 68 senators showed up for the roll-call vote, which meant that almost one-third of the lawmakers had better things to do.

title: L J N TOYS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''My young friends, history is a river that may take us as it will.

title: Bridge: Novices Are Inclined to Miss Chances to Get a High Score
description: One of the major weaknesses of inexperienced players is their failure to take advantage of opportunities for low-level penalty doubles. As a result they collect small numbers that could have been big numbers, or settle for a game when a penalty would have been more lucrative.

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Venture Of Capital
description: WHEN the exceedingly rich John Hay Whitney came home from World War II, he thought the free-enterprise economy needed a new dimension. He wanted a place where an entrepreneur with a risky dream beyond the standards of banks or more conventional underwriters could go for start-up money and business know-how. He put up $10 million to create it. And in 1946, J.H. Whitney & Company was born. The trouble was that nobody quite understood its role.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DUARTE VOWS TO CRUSH DEATH SQUADS
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democrats' candidate for President of El Salavdor, said today that if elected he would set up a special commission to investigate slayings by the death squads.

description: To the Editor:

Mrs. Kirkpatrick Says NATO Is Greatest Postwar Success
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, said yesterday that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ''is a colossal success, the greatest single success of the post-World War II years.''

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Danger From Raccoons
description: A common intestinal worm in raccoons can infect people, sometimes with fatal results, the American Veterinary Medical Association has warned.

title: AN IMPROVED HOT LINE: HOW THE 2 SIDES DIFFER
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Soviet and American negotiators were near agreement on technical aspects of upgrading existing crisis hot-line communications, but that Moscow seemed hesitant to reach final agreement for broader political reasons.

title: PARLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OSSINING VS. OSSINING: TOWN FACING EVICTION BY VILLAGE
description: The Village of Ossining (population 22,000) has served an eviction notice on the Town of Ossining (population 32,000, including the village's 22,000), ordering it to move its offices out of the Municipal Building by May 31.

title: TAUBMAN TO BUY WOODWARD CHAIN
description: Woodward & Lothrop Inc., a leading department store chain in the Washington area, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Taubman Holdings, which is owned by A. Alfred Taubman, a Detroit developer who runs one of the nation's major shopping mall enterprises.

title: M. L. Vasanthakumari Sings Carnatic Songs
description: To celebrate the 500th birthday of the Indian saint Purandara Dasa, who wrote songs and systematized the teaching of Carnatic (South Indian) classical music, the Hindu Temple Society and the Carnatic Music Association presented a concert Saturday at McMillin Auditorium by the Carnatic singer M. L. Vasanthakumari.

title: Case Not Closed
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn , asserting that an arbitrator's decision had undercut his power to deal with players' drug problems, said yesterday that he would try to take further action in the case of the Atlanta Braves pitcher Pascual Perez. Kuhn suspended Perez without pay for one month, until May 16, after the player was convicted of a cocaine possession charge in the Dominican Republic.

title: WALBAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN ENDS TRIP AS THOUSANDS JAM SHANGHAI STREETS
description: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese jammed the streets of this old commercial city to greet President Reagan Monday as he completed his six-day visit to China.

title: LEVITT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $190,000 for the latest quarter and $171,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: FRIDAY'S (TGI) INC (N) reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Reported Crimes Decline by 5.7%
description: The number of reported crimes in the city declined 5.7 percent during the first three months of this year, compared with the same period last year, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: CEASARS WORLD
description: Caesars World Inc. said it had filed to offer $100 million of subordinated debentures to finance an $86 million expansion of its Atlantic City hotel and casino already under way. The company said the lead underwriter was Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MONDALE TELLS CAROLINA FARMERS HE BACKS TOBACCO ACREAGE PLAN
description: Charles McLawhorn, who is 79 years old, unhitched his plow this morning, put on a white shirt and his best gray suit, drove over to the feed store and delivered a modest lesson to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: FRUITS OF THE TRIP
description: President Reagan's six-day trip to China produced no diplomatic breakthroughs and no visible shifts in either side's well-established foreign policy positions. But, authorities on both sides agreed, it was primarily important for bringing together the leader of American conservatism with Peking's Communist leadership.

title: THE RAINS IN AFRICA: A MIXED BLESSING
description: ABIDJAN, IVORY COAST THROUGHOUT much of tropical Africa, the monotony of sun-parched days and starry nights is now beginning to be relieved by sudden bursts of sound and light and swiftly moving walls of water. The approach of the rainy season is a hopeful time here and in the two dozen other African nations that have been devastated by a prolonged and serious drought.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 1, 1984 International
description: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese jammed the streets of Shanghai to greet President Reagan as he completed his six-day visit to China. Workers in the old commercial city, many apparently given time off, gave Mr. Reagan the biggest reception of his career. (Page A1, Column 6.) Rashid Karami, Lebanon's Prime Minister-designate, announced the formation of a new national unity government that for the first time would bring the leaders of all warring militias into one cabinet. However, the Shiite militia leader, Nabih Berri, rejected any participation, (A6:3-5.)

title: The U.N. Today May 1, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Chase Seeks More Non-Bank Banks
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said it had filed applications with the Comptroller of the Currency to open nine ''non-bank banks'' in nine states.

title: Solidarity Urges Boycott Of May Day Ceremonies
description: The Solidarity underground distributed leaflets in factories and the streets today urging Poles to boycott Government May Day ceremonies on Tuesday. The Government responded by mobilizing extra policemen, setting up summary courts and banning the sale of alcohol.

title: INMATE RELEASED ON LOW BAIL CLEARED OF LATER RAPE CHARGE
description: A man accused of raping a Bronx woman two days after his release from Rikers Island under a program to relieve jail overcrowding has been found not guilty, the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: BASIE: IN HIS FRIENDS' WORDS
description: ''The words I have heard were not so much about Count Basie the musician but Count Basie the man. The first word I heard was 'gentleman.'

title: Steve Turre Conducts Brass and Seashells
description: Steve Turre led something more than a brass band Saturday at Soundscape. Although his septet included four trombonists, a trumpeter and a tuba player, plus a percussionist, Mr. Turre's arrangements also called for didjeridoos (tree-trunk trombones from Australia) and up to six end- blown seashells.

CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Auto-Air Industries, which was acquired Jan. 31, and reflect the consummation of Cade Industries' public offering made in January.

title: Leonard Passes Exam
description: Sugar Ray Leonard has passed his Massachusetts State Athletic Commission eye examination and has been cleared to begin his boxing comeback against Kevin Howard on May 11 in Worchester. The 27-year- old Leonard, who retired as the undisputed welterweight champion in November 1982, was examined by Dr. Edward Ryan . Dr. Ryan's findings were passed on to the athletic commission's chairman, Tommy Rawson , who issued the go-ahead.

Citicorp to Form Bank in Maryland The Federal Reserve Board gave Citicorp permission to form a limited- purpose national bank in Maryland. Citicorp plans to use the proposed bank, Citibank Maryland, to provide consumer-banking services elsewhere in the United States.
description: -of-state institutions to establish banks in Maryland, but does not permit them to conduct banking business in the state. The Maryland bank would be similar to one Citicorp established in South Dakota several years ago.

title: CREUSOT FACES STIFF CUTBACKS
description: By refusing a plea for emergency aid, the French Government has decided to let Creusot-Loire, the big steel and heavy engineering group, slip into bankruptcy as a way of forcing the privately owned company to restructure its loss-making activities. The decision, at a time when unemployment is rising rapidly, is expected to cost thousands of jobs.

title: NEUTRAL SETTING FOR BOY ORDERED IN CUSTODY CASE
description: Aiming for a Solomonlike compromise, Judge Harold Reed of District Court today kept 12-year-old Brian Batey temporarily from the custody of both his father, a homosexual, and his mother, a Pentacostalist whose church holds that homosexuality is sinful.

title: SEARS PLANS TO SELL PREFERRED STOCK
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had filed a registration statement covering a proposed offering of 2.5 million shares, at $100 a share, of adjustable rate preferred stock.

description: For all the controversy over the earlier censorship of some of his televised remarks, President Reagan appears to have created a positive impression among many Chinese.

title: Core-Mark Deal
description: Core-Mark International Inc. said it had agreed to acquire 90 percent of Mid-Continent Distributors Inc. Mid- Continent, a tobacco and confectionery distributor based in Denver, has annual sales of nearly $80 milllion. Mid-Continent's president, David Bershof, will retain a 10 percent interest in the company. In addition, Core- Mark said it had acquired Royal Wholesale Cigar of Los Angeles, which has annual sales of about $95 million.

title: Gunmen in Speedboats Rob Venice Casino
description: Masked gunmen stole about $1.5 million from Venice's beachside Municipal Casino today, hauling away the money in speedboats, the police said.

title: Drug Use Cited
description: A number of players in the Los Angeles Dodgers' minor league system - including members of the Albuquerque Dukes - have been found to be using drugs, a physician said yesterday. ''There has been found to be drug use throughout the minor league system,'' Dr. Forrest Tennant , a Los Angeles-area physician commissioned by the Dodger organization to deal with drug problems, told The Albuquerque Tribune. Dr. Tennant said Albuquerque players were involved.

title: IDAHO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
United May Seek Takeover of Bank
description: United Banks of Colorado Inc., a Denver bank holding company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it may seek control of Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc. United Banks said recent purchases of Affiliated common and preferred stock, as well as options, give it the equivalent of 1,846,628 common shares of Affiliated, or 17.77 percent of the total outstanding.

title: NEW-HOME SALES OFF BY 4.9%
description: Sales of new homes dropped by 4.9 percent in March from February as a sharp decline in home buying in the South more than offset a big jump in the Northeast, the Government reported today.

title: Dome Continues Debt Negotiations
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had not yet fully satisfied all the terms in letters of understanding with its Citibank lender group and four Canadian banks on rescheduling its debt.

title: CANADIAN TORY SEEKS TO EASE RIFTS WITH U.S.
description: The leader of the Progressive Conservative Party called today for a new approach to resolve disputes between Canada and the United States. His proposal involved ''secretariats'' on the part of both countries and a permanent staff of experts.

description: Year-ago share earnings figure reflects a 4-for-3 stock split paid Oct. 13, 1983.

description: The leader of a drug ring that the Federal Bureau of Investigation said was responsible for 15 percent of the heroin sold in New York City was sentenced yesterday to 40 years in prison with no chance for parole.

title: ACCORD REPORTED IN SUIT ON HOUSING
description: New York State and civil rights groups have reached an agreement to set goals for integration at the huge Starrett City project in Brooklyn and other state-subsidized private housing in New York City, sources close to the negotiations said last night.

title: April's Toll Put at 130 In Peruvian Violence
description: About 130 people were killed in April in a surge of violence by Peruvian Maoist guerrillas, an army commander said today.

title: U.S. Industries Reverses Position on Stock Sale
description: In an apparent move to protect itself against stockholder suits, U. S. Industries reversed itself yesterday and said that it was no longer advising stockholders not to sell their shares to a unit of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London.

Reliance Adds Disney Shares
description: Saul P. Steinberg, a New York financier, increased his stake today in Walt Disney Productions by nearly one-third, to 12.1 percent, buying a block of one million shares of the entertainment company. Disney's shares were among the most active on the Big Board, and closed at $66, up $3.125.

title: AIDES DEFEND ARGENTINE LOAN
description: Although American banks benefited from a $500 million loan that the Treasury organized recently for Argentina, senior Treasury and Federal Reserve officials testified in Congress today that this had not been their main objective.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll on the prospects of a woman as Vice President incorrectly tallied political shifts among some population groups in response to such a possibility. Those shifting toward Democrats included unmarried women, by 11 percentage points, and Republican women, by 9 points. Shifts toward Republicans included Democratic men and Middle Western men, each by 14 points.

title: STAGE: 'BRECHT'S ASHES 2,'A MAN'S ART
description: ''BRECHT'S ASHES 2,'' which represents the American debut at La Mama Annex of Eugenio Barba's Odin Teatret, is a critical examination of the world of Brecht through the work of Brecht. As produced by this Danish-based troupe, the evening is a provocative crossbreeding of theater, politics and biography, and it is also a demonstration of collective performance art.

BILL TO MAKE DEFENSE PROVE INSANITY PASSES KEY OBSTACLE IN ALBANY
description: The last major obstacle to changing New York State's law on the use of insanity as a defense in criminal trials was removed today when a key lawmaker said he would not block legislation on the issue.

title: OF CONCERNS FOR FELONS AND FOR THE UNBORN
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO GROUP DEMANDS BLACK MAYOR HEED WHITES' CONCERN
description: About 1,000 white Chicagoans are demanding that the city's first black Mayor pay attention to their ''white ethnic agenda,'' which they say is meant to enable them ''to enjoy what we have struggled so hard to achieve.''

title: Power of Television
description: The Philadelphia Stars and the Birmingham Stallions, whose 9-1 records are the best in the United States Football League, had been scheduled to play in Birmingham, Ala., Friday night, but the ABC network, invoking a clause in its contract with the U.S.F.L., has switched the game to Sunday afternoon to attract a bigger audience. That was not good news for officials at the Alabama International Motor Speedway, 45 miles east of Birmingham.

title: Bridge: Regional Tourneys Dwindle From 3 to 1 in New York City
description: Serious tournament players seek out regional championships, which offer tough competition and, for those who need them, the red points that lead to life master rank.

title: Maree a U.S. Citizen
description: It took him only six months in the United States to realize that he could never live in his homeland again, and yesterday, six years after he left his native South Africa to attend Villanova, Sydney Maree , the star distance runner, finally got a homeland he is proud to call home. He was sworn in as a citizen of the United States, a step that comes in time to allow him to try out for the United States Olympic team.

title: BRITAIN REJECTS A FORMAL INQUIRY INTO LIBYAN CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, rejecting opposition calls for an independent inquiry into the Government's handling of the crisis over the Libyan Embassy, said today that she had ordered an internal review to be carried out by established security agencies.

title: Seoul's Exports Soar
description: South Korea's exports totaled $2.3 billion in April, the highest in four months and up 24.3 percent from April 1983, the Commerce and Industry Ministry said today. This brought exports since January to $8.65 billion, up 29.8 percent from the 1983 period.

title: 30 ARE WOUNDED IN CHILE PROTEST
description: Riot policemen fired shotgun pellets, tear gas and water cannon at stone- throwing demonstrators during a May Day rally by foes of Chile's military Government. At least 30 people were wounded and 80 arrested.

title: MONDALE IS VICTORIN TENNESSEE VOTE
description: Walter F. Mondale won a decisive victory today in the Tennessee primary, setting back Gary Hart's hope of rebounding as the Democratic Presidential campaign entered a crucial eight-day period.

title: FILM: 'HOME FREE ALL,' A RADICAL GROWS OLD
description: THINGS are not going at all well for Barry, the middle- aged hero of Stewart Bird's ''Home Free All.'' He'd like to be a writer, but for the time being he is selling kitchen gadgets on a street corner near Macy's. His therapist has canceled his treatment for lack of payment. His girlfriend finds him sexually disappointing, and says so. His past as a radical doesn't seem to have much place in his present. ''I'm tired of being far-out and broke,'' he says.

title: GuiltyPleaUpheld In Lennon Slaying
description: An appeals court yesterday let stand the guilty plea of Mark David Chapman, the confessed killer of John Lennon, as it rejected arguments that Mr. Chapman was mentally incompetent when he admitted the slaying.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INGLIS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings do not reflect a 4-for-1 stock split effective May 18.

title: CONCERT: MOZARTEAN PLAYERS
description: THE Mozartean Players Classical Orchestra is an admirable and much-needed addition to New York musical life, offering small-scaled performances of music by Mozart, Handel and their contemporaries on original period instruments. Its Friday evening concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, under the direction of Steve Lubin, was both musically and historically rewarding.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A FEW years ago, a pop song, ''Short People,'' drew angry protests throughout the country. The reaction to the song (written by Randy Newman as a parody of prejudice) highlighted the difficulties faced by short-statured people, including the nearly two million American children with serious growth deficiencies. These are the children whose final height without treatment will fall below 5 feet 4 inches for boys and 4 feet 10 inches for girls.

title: CUBA SAYS ITS MILTIA FORCES NOW EXCEED A MILLION
description: The Cuban Government said today that it had doubled the size of its militia forces to more than a million men and women.

description: 3 Agencies Receive Additional Business

title: Jersey Crime Falls By 9% in a Year
description: Reported crime in New Jersey fell 9 percent from 1982 to 1983 for the third consecutive annual decline and the largest since statewide crime statistics have been kept, the state police said today.

Court Says Employees Can Sue Congressmen
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that members of Congress were not protected from lawsuits when they dismissed a Capitol Hill employee, even though lawmakers cannot be sued for official actions they take in office.

title: Curb on Pornography Enacted in Indianapolis
description: An ordinance seeking to ban pornography by classifying it as a civil rights violation was signed into law here today by Mayor William H. Hudnut 3d.

SCREEN: 'MISSION,' IRANIANS
description: ''The Mission'' was shown as part of the 1983 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 30, 1983. The film opens today at the Cinema 3, 59th Street at Fifth Avenue.

title: Follower of Charles Manson Denied Parole in '69 Killings
description: The man who once called himself Charles Manson's ''lieutenant for killing'' and played a key part in the Tate-La Bianca murders 15 years ago today was denied parole.

title: DOMINICANS IGNORE UNIONS' CALLS FOR PROTESTS
description: International Workers Day passed today without incident and with few signs that people were heeding union leaders' calls to stay off the streets and display black symbols to mourn those killed in food riots last week.

title: FRESH MORELS: UNIQUE FLAVOR
description: THAT unmistakably bosky odor drifting under the noses of shoppers in some of the city's more elaborate vegetable markets these days comes from morels, curious-looking fungi with spongy, corklike caps and a sweetly nutty flavor that many enthusiasts consider the finest of all eating mushrooms.

title: Jewel Holds Talks With American
description: Executives of Jewel Companies and American Stores, both with large retail food and drug operations, met last week to discuss a possible combination, a Jewel spokesman said.

title: Excel Layoffs Follow Ruling
description: The Excel Corporation said it was laying off 1,000 workers at a meatpacking plant in Oakland, Iowa, as a result of a court decision returning the plant to its original owner, the Land O' Lakes Company. Last Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver refused to lift a lower court injunction that blocked Excel and its parent company, the Cargill Corporation, from purchasing the Oakland plant from Land O' Lakes.

title: VOLUME AT 6-WEEK HIGH
description: The stock market scored an impressive advance yesterday in the heaviest trading in six weeks. The blue-chip, technology and transportation issues were the biggest gainers.

title: UPWARD PRESSURE ON INTEREST RATES
description: Interest rates remained under upward pressure yesterday as the markets awaited today's announcement by the Treasury of its mid-quarter refunding.

title: A CENTER FOR F.D.R.
description: To the Editor:

SOUTH AFRICA BLOCKS COURT ACTION AIMED AT FREEING NAMIBIA REBELS
description: The South African Government has blocked a court action that was focused on obtaining the release of 37 members of a guerrilla organization fighting for the independence of South-West Africa.

title: Game Off, Wind
description: On Monday night in Toronto, as the Blue Jays prepared to face the Texas Rangers at Exhibition Stadium, the temperature was 48 degrees and there was no precipitation in the air.

FOILED PENALTY SHOT A KEY FOR ISLANDERS
description: The puck rested at center ice as Billy Smith stood in front of the Islander goal and Mats Naslund waited to begin his penalty shot. A Montreal goal would break a 1-1 tie in the Stanley Cup semifinal game. An Islander victory would create a 2-2 tie in the 4-of-7 series.

title: CONCERT: MIJA KANG, SOPRANO
description: SOMETIMES the rudeness of an audience can come close to ruining an otherwise effective concert. Such was the case with the Monday evening program of the soprano Mija Kang at the Abraham Goodman House.

SCHOLARS DEBATE NEED TO AID ARTS
description: ''Just why do you and I when we visit a museum or attend a performance of modern dance deserve to have our enjoyment subsidized?'' William J. Baumol, professor of economics at Princeton and New York University, asked yesterday. ''Do we really have such special merits that we deserve to be fed at the public trough when others who consume only more worldly goods deserve to be turned away?''

W. RADFORD BASCOME JR.
description: -relations consultant, died of a stroke Monday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, L.I. He was 70 years old and lived on Shelter Island.

title: Out of Bounds For the Raiders
description: The National Football League's next Super Bowl game, which will be played in Stanford Stadium in Palo Alto, Calif., is still nine months away, but already the league has chosen the headquarters hotels and practice sites for the competing teams.

title: HART PRESSES TO DISCREDIT MONDALE RECORD IN OHIO
description: Dennis Wineburg, an unemployed factory worker whose wife expects twins next month, eagerly raised his hand this morning in a question-and-answer session with Senator Gary Hart at a local health clinic.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: Bahrain Getting University
description: The Emir of Bahrain laid the cornerstone of Gulf University today, the first university in this island state. It is to serve the Persian Gulf region. The six countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council and Iraq are financing the $540 million university, which is to open regular classes in September 1986.

title: Union Reaches Supermarket Pact
description: -TROY HILLS, N.J. (UPI) - A union representing 21,000 supermarket clerks and cashiers reached a tentative contract agreement today with four supermarket chains in New Jersey and New York State.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Horner , the Atlanta Brave third baseman who suffered a minor shoulder separation in a collision at home plate last Friday, will miss at least five games, the club announced. . . . Bum Phillips , the coach of the New Orleans Saints, was given a three-year contract extension that will keep him with the team through 1988. . . . Stuart Gray , a 7-foot center who never lived up to expectations at U.C.L.A., said he would pass up his senior year and make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft June 19.

title: BIG LAW FIRMS STEPPING UP VOLUNTEER SERVICES IN THE CITY
description: A group of New York's largest law firms and corporate legal departments announced yesterday that they would devote substantially more of their time to supplying legal services to the poor.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 2, 1984 International
description: Thousands of Solidarity backers led by Lech Walesa slipped into an official May Day parade in Poland's port city of Gdansk and shouted slogans of the outlawed independent union as they marched past a reviewing stand. Cheers and shouts of ''Solidarity!'' rose from the crowd, and officials on the the stand appeared stunned. Protests were reported to have developed into street clashes in at least six cities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Konstantin U. Chernenko presided over the May Day parade in Red Square a year after his absence from the march prompted some students of Soviet affairs to begin writing him off as a force in Kremlin politics. A theme of yesterday's parade seemed to be the ascendancy of the 72-year- old Mr. Chernenko as the Soviet party leader and head of state. (A12:3-6.)

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WELCOME to Sue City. You are standing in an office of the New York City Law Department at 100 Church Street. The mountain of legal briefs on your right represents one day's worth of litigation. The Kafkaesque figure beneath the mountain is a proofreader named Erik La Prade. The cases he proofs are not the sort that make the 6 o'clock news: A former patient is suing the Health and Hospitals Corporation. The city is rescinding this or that contract. An inmate is suing the Department of Correction. ''Not Corrections,'' the proofreader reminds us.

title: BUCKS DOWN NETS AND TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: With time running out on the Nets tonight, Micheal Ray Richardson was trying to cap a furious rally by attempting a potentional game-tying shot. But faced by the Milwaukee Bucks' burly center, Bob Lanier, blocking his path, Richardson chose to pass instead.

title: THE REVISED 'ST. ELSEWHERE,' HOSPITAL DRAMA
description: ALREADY renewed by NBC for next season, ''St. Elsewhere'' is one of those weekly series that seem unable to rise above the comfortable but rather frustrating category of being promising. On one level, it is just another hospital show, crammed with the medical jargon and paraphernalia that have been exploited in everything from soap operas to such series as ''Dr. Kildare'' and ''Nurse.'' On another level, that of form and style, it is the medical equivalent of ''Hill Street Blues,'' wrapped in overlapping dialogue, hand-held camera shots and meandering plot lines.

title: 1-ACT PLAYS BY GILBERT, SULLIVAN
description: NEITHER ''Trial by Jury'' nor ''Cox and Box'' represent Arthur Sullivan and W. S. Gilbert at their most inventive and assured, but if Public Television's ''Complete Gilbert and Sullivan'' series is to be complete, then indeed they must be seen and counted.

title: MUSIC: MISHA DICHTER PLAYS BRAHMS
description: YEARS ago, before science discovered how to keep people alive indefinitely, it used to be said that life began at 40. In music, whether for good reasons or not, this was often taken as a watershed time, a point at which a performer could be expected to show signs of significant growth, if ever that were going to happen. Now, perhaps, we should be content to wait a couple of decades for the onset of artistic maturity. Take Misha Dichter, for instance. The pianist, who now stands at the brink of age 40, first made a dent in the public consciousness by taking a silver medal at the 1966 Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow and quickly established a reputation as a virtuoso for whom nothing was too difficult. Along with his ability to burn up the keyboard in the big, flashy pieces, he also showed an inclination to play the classical literature with patrician poise. For nearly 20 years, Mr. Dichter has played with just this blend of technical brilliance and stylistic elegance, content to refine his achievements rather than to rush off in new directions.

title: China Grain Output Up
description: Chinese grain production had its largest increase ever last year, both in terms of total production and production per acre, the official New China News Agency said today. Overall output increased to 426 million tons last year, from 389 million tons in 1982 and 357 million tons in 1981, the agency said. The yield rose by 247 pounds an acre, to 3,026 pounds.

First it was Japan. Then the 10-nation European Economic Community. Now it is Brazil and Mexico, with South Africa, South Korea and Taiwan in the wings.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Heating Oil Price Rise Higher Than Gasoline's
description: The energy futures market took an unusual turn yesterday when prices of heating oil futures rose more than those for gasoline. This threw the ''crack spreads'' of both commercial hedgers and speculators into disarray.

title: SOUFFLES: EASY TO MAKE IN A NEW WAY
description: MAKING souffles is a little bit like dancing the samba: from the sidelines it appears more difficult than it actually is, so a good many people hesitate to try for fear of falling flat in front of an audience. Traditional souffles, which are made by mixing a roux, a combination of butter and flour, and then adding milk, egg yolks, a primary ingredient (vegetables, meat, fish, fruit, etc.) and beaten egg whites, take time and patience to prepare successfully. However, a shortcut method that eliminates the roux yields a quicker, lighter souffle that works exceptionally well with fresh spring vegetables and fruits.

title: Israel Foils Its Own Extremists
description: From the six-day war to Entebbe, the Israelis have brought off so many exceptional feats of self- defense against Arabs that the rest of the world has come to take their skill for granted. The world may thus fail to appreciate the comparable feat last week when the Israelis foiled a terrorist plot, apparently concocted by Jews, against Jerusalem Arabs.

title: ARGENTINA COURTS FARMERS

title: Football Series Off
description: Auburn's football coach, Pat Dye , said that Penn State had canceled plans to play Auburn in 1986 and 1987. ''We wanted to keep the Penn State series, but they felt otherwise,'' said Dye, noting that Penn State had agreed to the series in a letter of intent several years ago but had never signed a formal contract. Penn State's coach, Joe Paterno , could not be reached, but Dye said that Penn State, already committed to a home- and-home series with Alabama, decided that it would not be a good idea to schedule two games a season with teams from the Southeastern Conference.

title: SEOUL TIGHTENS SECURITY FOR THE VISIT BY JOHN PAUL

title: HART'S FATAL BLUNDER
description: Senator Gary Hart has just made what seems like a major and maybe even fatal blunder in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Instead of sticking to his appeal for ''new ideas,'' which are badly needed, he has reverted to the oldest idea of all: attacking Walter Mondale personally and even running against the record of his own party.

title: CONCERT: ASHKENAZY PERFORMS PIANO SOLO
description: THE greatest musical works provide the interpreter, understandably, with the most diving room. Schubert's posthumous Sonata in B flat, for instance, is one of those endlessly-astonishing pieces that a pianist can play throughout life without ever touching bottom. What is that first movement about, really, with its deep and somehow disturbing trills in the left hand and the gentle song that keeps coming back to chase away the suggestion of menace? This is the mighty Schubert, capable not only of achingly lovely melody but of a kind of gentle nobility that no other composer quite matches.

title: HERS
description: MY mother has always said: ''The daughters come back to you eventually. When the sons go they're gone.'' She has other favorite sayings - ''A father's not a mother,'' ''The beginning is the half of all things,'' and ''De gustibus non disputandum est,'' which she translated as ''That's what makes horse races'' - all of which have become increasingly meaningful to me with time. Recently I told her that she was right in a fight we had 27 years ago about which language I should study in high school. This came up because I had just had the same discussion with my son and took the side my mother took then (French). She laughed when I told her that she was right 27 years ago. There have been more and more nice moments like that with my mother as we both grow older.

The action in effect is a 50 percent stock dividend, which will be delivered July 2 to owners of record June 11.

title: MASS-MARKETING OF EYE CARE
description: Manhattan Eyeland, on the corner of 59th Street and Second Avenue, describes itself as an optical department store, the first in Manhattan. Within its 20,000 square feet are housed a computerized eye-examination center, offices for eye doctors, a lens-making laboratory and display areas. A showroom, called Sutton Place, boasts a sofa, a piano and vaults for eyeglasses that range in price from $200 a pair to an eye-popping $32,000.

title: Mellon, Heritage
description: The Mellon National Corporation and Heritage Bancorp said they had asked for an appeals court review of the Federal Reserve Board's assertion of jurisdiction over the proposed merger of the Girard and Heritage banks. The Comptroller of the Currency has approved the transaction and concluded that the Federal Reserve does not have jurisdiction over it, the bank companies said.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $9 million. c-Including a capital gain of $16.8 million. Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Gulf United Corp., which was acquired effective Jan. 5, 1984.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings figure has been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January 1984.

title: BEFORE THE STORM
description: ''Everybody doesn't have to agree with us,'' Shimon Peres said. ''We only need to shift 5 or 10 percent, and we are confident of that.''

title: D.D.B. Profits Rise
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International said its net income increased 18.2 percent in the first quarter, to $1.3 million, or 21 cents a share, from $1.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 5.9 percent, to $46.7 million, from $44.1 million a year ago.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $450,000, or 34 cents a share, from a partial resolution of litigation in connection with the Delamar silver mine in which the company owns a 7.5 percent net profits interest.

title: G.M. Request On Price Cuts
description: The General Motors Corporation acknowledged that it had asked parts suppliers to cut their prices. The suppliers said the auto maker sent out letters several months ago, saying G.M. needed the cuts to compete with foreign companies, which can produce parts at a cheaper rate because of lower labor costs.

title: CONCERT: DA CAPO PLAYERS, THREE WORLD PREMIERS
description: THE Da Capo Chamber Players, those seemingly tireless performers of new music, introduced yet another half-dozen pieces to New York in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. Three of these were world premieres - Alvin Brehm's ''Bocca della Verit a,'' Stephen Jaffe's ''Nonesuch Serenade'' and James Greeson's ''Fantasy for Five Players.'' The other works were Stephen Albert's ''I Am Leafy Speafing,'' Judith Shatin Allen's ''Werther'' and Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's ''Intrada.''

title: CAMFLO MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $3,352,000 on the reversal of an unrealized loss on coal operations.

title: A BLIND SPOT IN THE SCENARIOS OF DEFICIT CUTTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGETARY TRAILMARKS
description: President Reagan says he is proposing to cut military spending by $40 billion in the next fiscal year. The Congressional Budget Office says that the Reagan proposals actually amount to a $4 billion increase. The House Budget Committee proposes a $95 billion defense cut, which amounts to 3.5 percent increase (after inflation) in defense spending. Meanwhile, the General Accounting Office reports that cost overruns in defense production averaged 32 percent over the last 20 years.

title: DECORATIVE IDEAS FOR THE WELL-DRESSED WINDOW
description: ''Americans have never really understood curtains,'' said Mario Buatta, the interior decorator. ''In the old days,'' he continued, ''there would be layers of fabric - draperies as well as curtains over the windows to control light and heat, but recently they have been out of fashion.''

title: QUEBEC TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THURSDAY, MAY 3, 1984 International
description: The Pope was welcomed to the United States by President Reagan in Fairbanks, Alaska. Mr. Reagan wished John Paul II well on his forthcoming trip to South Korea, Thailand, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Syria confirmed seizing three Israelis in Lebanon and said they had been taken to Syria. Israel demanded their release. Damascus said the Israelis were saboteurs trying to infiltrate Syrian-controlled territory, but an Israeli Government spokesman said they were diplomats who had strayed into the Syrian area while on a sightseeing tour. (A1:3-4.)

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IT WAS A BIG NIGHT OF SPRING PARTIES FOR MANHATTAN
description: IT was one of those nights. The

title: JAMES MANNO
description: James Manno, owner of the Astorian Manor, a catering hall in Astoria, Queens, died of a heart attack yesterday at the home of a friend in Astoria. Mr. Manno was 70 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: O'NEILL TO DELAY DEBATE ON ALIENS
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., agreed today to postpone debate on a comprehensive immigration bill until after the California Democratic primary June 5.

title: STOCK SURGE: THE OBSTACLES
description: -tuning time for Wall Street opinion. The first trading day in May seemed like

title: SENATE COMMITTEE FAVORS LAND PLAN
description: A Senate committee, breaking a logjam that has stalled Congress for more than three years, approved bills today designating more than 3 million acres of Federal land as protected wilderness and releasing millions more to logging, mining and other development.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
STREAMLINED FAUCETS
description: VERSATILE designs in kitchen faucets have been introduced. Ladylux, manufactured by Grohe, a German concern, is a faucet-sprayer combination. When the water is turned on by the single lever the faucet operates like any swiveling kitchen faucet.

title: E.E.C. Steel Output Off
description: Production of crude steel in the European Economic Community fell to 11.8 million tons in March, down a seasonally adjusted 2.8 percent from February, Eurostat, the trade bloc's statistical agency, said today. The March output was 10.5 percent higher than in March 1983, but 3.9 percent below production in March 1982, the agency added. Greek output was not included.

title: Joe Cocker Arrested Over Fee in Vienna
description: The British rock singer Joe Cocker was arrested here today on charges of trying to make off with a concert fee of $12,500 without giving a performance, the police said.

title: By Eva Hoffman;
description: ASSAULT ON MOUNT HELICON: A

title: J. DAVID'S CHIEF IS HELD ON COAST FOR CONTEMPT
description: J. David Dominelli, whose investment firm collapsed in bankruptcy, was cited for contempt today for fleeing the country and was ordered held in lieu of $5 million bond on fraud and conspiracy charges.

title: ISLANDERS FIND THEIR ATTACK AND GO FOR TIEBREAKER
description: The Canadiens have seen the Islanders at their worst and best. They saw the four-time champions slinking out of Montreal after two straight losses. Then they saw them at Uniondale, L.I., confident and almost swashbuckling, envisioning a fifth straight Stanley Cup.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aloha Airlines Inc. common stock totaling 5.6 percent is held by Sheridan Ing, a Honolulu real estate developer, according to an S.E.C. filing.

title: GREAT WESTERN ADDS A BROKERAGE PRESIDENT
description: Glen E. McIlvaine, with 18 years of varied experience in securities trading, has been named president of a new discount stock and bond brokerage subsidiary wholly owned by the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: THE DANCE: JOHANNA BOYCE
description: LAWS of chance and behavior predicated on them are the subject of ''Facing the Odds,'' a richly textured, funny and poignant performance piece by Johanna Boyce, a leading young post- modernist, that was presented at the Kitchen on Tuesday. Here, for once, was the kind of seamless weave of elements - dance, drama, visual effects and personal history - that performance art is said to be meant to be, and a considered articulation of a whole.

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 OFFICERS OF SHELL TO SELL STOCK
description: The Shell Oil Company, in a surprise move, announced late yesterday that its top five executives, including John F. Bookout, president and chief executive, had decided to sell their stock in Shell Oil to the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.

title: Uncle Sam's Campus Bargain
description: Last fall Charles Bender, a sophomore at the University of Minnesota, lost $5,000 because he refused to register for the draft. As an opponent of ''war in any form,'' Mr. Bender felt he could not sign up. Because he had not done so, he could not submit a signed ''statement of compliance'' to the university that would have enabled him to receive Federal grants and loans. Without them, he had to become a part-time student and find off-campus housing.

title: ISSUES RAISED BY S.E.C. IN CARTER SUIT
description: In its suit against Carter Hawley Hale Stores, the Securities and Exchange Commission has raised several relatively narrow legal issues, among them whether the retailer violated securities law by buying its own shares on the open market without giving shareholders the prior notice the commission says was required by law.

title: Suffolk Judge Sees Bias on Jury Pool
description: A Suffolk County Court judge has found that the county's method of choosing its pool of jurors discriminates against young blacks, and has urged that the system be changed.

title: FELMONT OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $1,008.

title: Computervision
description: The Computervision Corporation said it had added two new series of integrated, distributed systems for computer-aided engineering, design and manufacturing. The company also announced the first major enhancement of its CDS 4000 system. In addition, Computervision announced a major restructuring of its pricing policies to more accurately reflect ''the additive value of its applications software.''

title: CENTER BANC SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Idlers, in the Senate
description: A hundred thousand jobless young people are being held hostage on Capitol Hill. Or at least their jobs are. It's been a year since the House voted to create an American Conservation Corps - a new version of the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps. But the Senate dawdles and the Reagan Administration gives no help.

title: Tigers Lose, 5-4; Now 19-3
description: Dwight Evans and Jim Rice hit two-run home runs to help the Boston Red Sox deal Detroit Tigers only their third defeat in 22 games tonight, 5-4.

title: Seed Concern Acquired
description: Orsan, a joint subsidiary of the Lafarge Coppee cement group and of the Credit Agricole banking group, said today that it had acquired all the shares outstanding in Wilson Hybrids Inc., an Iowa company specializing in production of corn and soya seeds. Terms were not disclosed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., insurance brokers, named Peter M. Densen senior vice president-finance and chief financial officer.

title: GRAMMY-WINNING ARRANGER
description: Gordon Jenkins, a composer, pianist, conductor and Grammy-winning arranger, who wrote ''Manhattan Tower'' and the pop hit ''This Is All I Ask,'' died of Lou Gehrig's disease Tuesday in Malibu, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: Steel Quotas Opposed
description: Reagan Administration officials voiced opposition today to the domestic steel industry's demand for quotas on imported steel, saying the quotas would harm the domestic recovery. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige; Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, and J. Paul McGrath, head of the antitrust division of the Justice Department, testified before the House Ways and Means trade subcommittee.

title: LEGAL GAMBLING GROWS TO $24 BILLION ANNUALLY
description: Dorothy Parks came straight from her job at a local store. Her husband, Bill, came straight from work, too, as manager of new car sales at an automobile dealer. They met at The Lott, a new cabin-style structure in the downtown area of this middle-class suburb of Omaha.

title: ACCORD IN MINORITY SUIT PROVIDES FOR MORE SUBSIDIZED APARTMENTS
description: The state has agreed to provide more apartments for members of minority groups in government-subsidized private housing projects in New York City.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PULLMAN TRANSPORTATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company did not report revenues. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $834,000 and an extraordinary credit of $26,000. d-Net loss. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of $978,000 and an extraordinary credit of $26,000. The latest quarter and 6 months results reflect the acquisition on Jan. 1 of Trailmobile and UOP Aerospace for about $28 million in cash and common stock from the Signal Companies. This transaction has been treated as a purchase for accounting purposes. The results of discontinued operations in the year-ago quarter and 6 months reflect discontinuance of the company's railroad freight car manufacturing and related business.

title: ; SUPERVISING TEACHERS' LONG RUN FOR TENURE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Composers at Discoth eque

title: Senior Golfers Win in a Walk
description: Ben Crenshaw, the 32-year-old Masters champion, and Lanny Wadkins, the 34-year-old winner of the 1982 and 1983 MONY Tournament of Champions, are not easily taken on a golf course by sharpies, hustlers or other golfers.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter figures include the results of Dynaport Electronics Inc., acquired by Metex on Jan. 18, 1984, in a purchase transaction.

title: TOP EFFIES TO SSC&B AND ALLY & GARGANO
description: At the Effies last night at the New York Hilton, two Grand Effies were handed out in addition to the medals in 34 product categories. The top awards, sort of Best of Show, went to Ally & Gargano, for its frequently honored Federal Express campaign, and to SSC&B, for the Diet Coke campaign.

title: GENERAL MOTORS ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Space Museum Gets a Gift
description: The most popular museum in the nation is getting a new acquisition that is guaranteed to become its least-visited exhibit.

title: CHINA'S SIGNING OF ATOM PACT SEEN AS A MAJOR POLICY CHANGE
description: Administration officials said today that in agreeing to a nuclear cooperation accord with the United States, China had moved significantly toward joining other nuclear powers in curbing the spread of atomic weapons to countries without them.

title: SOVIET SCHOLAR CENTER OF DISPUTE
description: A Soviet mathematician whose behavior seemed so unusual that American and Soviet psychiatrists were summoned to nearby Dulles International Airport to examine him Monday night became the center of a new Soviet-American dispute today.

title: STATE PLANS TO ISSUE LICENSES FOR DRIVERS WITH PHOTOS IN JULY
description: New York plans to begin issuing drivers' licenses with photographs on them this summer, becoming the last state in the country to do so, the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles announced today.

title: Arbitrage Trading Examined
description: Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company, a New York securities firm that has been questioned about the possibility of manipulation of stock-index options, said yesterday that it was engaged in ''bona fide arbitrage activities'' when it purchased large blocks of stock and traded options on April 19.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $132,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,411,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: GRAY & CO PUBLIC COMMUNUNICATION reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Nuclear Projects Backed at Rally
description: Thousands of cheering and chanting construction workers demonstrated at the Capitol steps today in favor of nuclear and hydroelectric power plants.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BROKEN or torn window and door screens are as bad as having no screens at all, so it makes sense to inspect them before the insect season advances any further.

title: S.E.C. SUES CARTER ON STOCK ACTIONS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a suit filed yesterday in Federal court in Los Angeles, charged that Carter Hawley Hale Stores had applied pressure on its shareholders to sell shares back to the company under what amounted to an illegal tender offer.

title: A New President At Hanna Mining
description: Carl E. Nickels Jr. has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Hanna Mining Company, the Cleveland-based company announced yesterday. Since 1979, Mr. Nickels, a 53-year-old Cleveland native, has been executive vice president with responsiblity for operations, finance, law, taxes and governmental affairs.

title: Market Gains Again; Dow Up 3.56
description: A continuing surge of buying by many institutional accounts sent stock prices moderately higher yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Bridge: Kaplan's Team Is Favored In Playoffs Over Weekend
description: The right to represent the United States in the 1984 World Team Olympiad, scheduled for October in Seattle, is at stake in Memphis this weekend.

title: Inflation Dips In the E.E.C.
description: The average inflation rate in the European Economic Community fell to 7.9 percent for the 12-month period that ended in March, Eurostat, the Common Market's statistics agency, said today.

title: No Headline
description: The Democrats:

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: German Trade Surplus
description: West Germany's trade surplus narrowed in March to the equivalent of $1.68 billion, from $2.29 billion in February and $2.02 billion in March 1983, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: A BLIND SPOT IN THE SCENARIOS OF DEFICIT CUTTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 72-STORY TOWER PROPOSED NEXT TO THE CITY CENTER
description: A 72-story commercial and residential tower was proposed yesterday for a site next to the City Center of Music and Drama, on West 55th Street.

title: REGIS DEBRAY: AT HOME IN THE REALM OF REALPOLITIK
description: Hide out with Che Guevara in Bolivia and people will persist in asking you questions about Latin America. Pose for photographs back then, hand on cartridge belt, and embassy functionaries will flinch when your name comes up on cocktail party invitation lists 20 years later.

title: HOUSE DELAYS ACTION ON AID UNTIL AFTER EL SALVADOR'S VOTE SUNDAY
description: House Democratic leaders agreed today to delay consideration of emergency military aid to El Salvador until after Sunday's runoff presidential election, while a House committee assured a floor vote that enhanced the prospects for Congressional approval of the aid.

title: GALVESTON HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROLE IN 'JAZZ SINGER'
description: -screen actress with a wide-eyed innocent look who was Al Jolson's leading lady in the landmark 1927 talking picture ''The Jazz Singer,'' and who was once described as a ''star-eyed goddess'' by Carl Sandburg while the Chicago poet was a newspaper film reviewer, died April 26 in Los Angeles. She suffered a heart attack last year. Miss McAvoy was 83 years old.

title: ON EXHIBIT: POTTERY, CERAMICS AND CRAFTS
description: Fragments , Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, 212-242-4106. An exhibition and sale of large ceramic wall hangings with rugged surfaces, some measuring 24 inches high and 14 inches wide, by Bob Barry will run through May 19.

title: Perez Retires 9 in 3 Innings
description: It won't officially count, but Pascual Perez of the Atlanta Braves indicated tonight that he's ready to pitch again in the major leagues. ''If I keep throwing like I did today, I think I'll win a lot of games,'' Perez said after he retired all nine San Diego Padres he faced before the scoreless game was rained out after three innings.

title: Tests in Kennedy Death To Go to Florida Judge
description: Laboratory tests that may reveal the cause of David A. Kennedy's death will be turned over Thursday to a judge who will rule whether they will be made public, officials said today.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LETTER: ON DISCRIMINATION
description: TO CRY FOUL UNDER FAIR HOUSING LAW

title: Key Atari Scientist Switches to Apple
description: Alan Kay, the chief scientist at Atari Inc. and the key figure in Atari's effort to regain prominence in the home computer market, resigned to take a top research post at Apple Computer Inc., Apple said yesterday.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES PISANI USED $20,000 IN STATE FUNDS TO BUY SUMMER HOUSE
description: A prosecution witness testified yesterday that State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle had used $20,000 of state money to buy a summer house.

title: International Debt Talks Set
description: High-ranking officials from some 20 central banks around the world will meet for three days in New York next week to discuss possible solutions to the international debt crisis, a spokesman from the New York Federal Reserve Bank said yesterday.

title: CBS OFFERS TWO HOURS OF COUNTRY
description: ''COUNTRY COMES HOME,'' a two-hour hodgepodge of music, corn and commercialism shown tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS, tries to be all things to all country fans. It is likely to please no one for long, because, like the ''country'' category of the music business, it tries to lump together two increasingly incompatible styles - conventional pop that has a vaguely Southern accent and the traditional country amalgam of bluegrass and honky-tonk.

title: HOYT'S ONE-HITTER TOPS YANKS
description: The wind, rattling through Comiskey Park tonight, took a perfect game away from LaMarr Hoyt.

title: PULLOUT BY TOWER SETS OFF WIDENING RIPPLES IN TEXAS
description: When John Tower decided last August that he would not run again after 22 years in the United States Senate, he not only sent shock waves through the renascent Republican Party in Texas; he also set in motion a game of musical chairs.

title: Bristol-Myers Directors
description: The Bristol-Myers Company has elected to its board Andrew C. Sigler, chairman and chief executive of the Champion International Corporation. The company has also named to its board Bruce S. Gelb, executive vice president and president of Bristol- Myers's consumer products group, and William R. Miller, executive vice president and president of the company's pharmaceutical and nutritional group.

title: A FLOWER SHOW IN GRAMERCY PARK
description: THERE was little question in Carmen Miranda's mind which category of flower arrangement she would enter in the 38th Annual Gramercy Park Flower Show. Its theme was ''Hats Off to Flowers: A Salute to Fashionable Headgear Through the Years.''

title: 2 Jailed in Plot To Oust Tenants
description: Two men accused of directing a gang that terrorized tenants into leaving their Manhattan apartments were ordered held without bail yesterday.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Learning Goes On and On

CARUSCAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: STANFORD REVIVES INQUIRY ON OUSTED CHINA SCHOLAR
description: Stanford University's president, Donald Kennedy, has asked for more information from Steven W. Mosher, a graduate student who was expelled last year after a school investigation into charges of ''illegal and seriously unethical conduct'' while doing research in a Chinese village.

title: Arts Club to Admit Women
description: The Cliff Dwellers, an all-male club from which Adlai E. Stevenson 3d resigned when his membership became an issue in the the 1982 gubernatorial campaign, has agreed to admit women for the first time in its 75-year history, officials announced Tuesday.

title: KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $600,000 from discontinued operations. In the latest quarter operating results include the March acquisition of Moran Energy Inc. on a pooling-of-interests basis. The net was reduced by $373,000 reflecting an appeals court reversal of a federal energy regulatory commission ruling regarding gas pricing from 1980 to 1983 and was also reduced by $351,000 from the writeoff of two obsolete drilling rigs. The operating results in both quarters restated to reflect a change to the full cost accounting method.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bargain

title: G.M.'S SILICON VALLEY STAKE
description: For the first time since the early days of the auto industry, the General Motors Corporation has bought a minority interest in a small company rather than swallowing it whole.

title: MARSH LIFTS LOSS ESTIMATE
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies told its shareholders in a letter yesterday that it now believes its after-tax losses from bond trading and related expenses will be 50 percent higher than first estimated.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: The share earnings for the year- earlier period were adjusted for 2-for- 1 stock split paid in September 1983.

title: Credit-Card Shift by Bank
description: First City Bancorp of Texas Inc., one of the state's largest issuers of Visa and Mastercards, said it would move its credit-card operations to South Dakota to escape Texas's restrictions on interest rates and fees. Mike Gatewood, a First City senior vice president, said that Texas laws do not allow it to be competitive with out-of-state institutions that market credit cards in Texas.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: INDONESIA, UNDER SUHARTO, ALLOWS FEW DISSENTING VOICES TO BE HEARD
description: A sales clerk chatting with a customer complained about Indonesia's press censorship and other authoritarian measures of the Government of President Suharto, who has ruled for 17 years.

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, the first five words of a sentence in the theater review of ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' were omitted yesterday from some copies. The passage should have read: ''Perhaps critics will debate forever whether this lyrical work matches its two major predecessors in the canon, 'The Iceman Cometh' and 'Long Day's Journey Into Night.' At times, 'Moon' surpasses those other giants because O'Neill seems to have distilled its theme to its purest form and then transcended it.''

title: Accounts
description: * Talking Textbooks Inc. to B. A. Margan & Associates.

title: Atlantic Resignation
description: David Auchincloss, the 41-year-old president of The Atlantic magazine, has resigned to work on a new magazine project. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, The Atlantic's chairman, has appointed two associate publishers: Susannah Pask, 32, who will be the New York ad director, and James Sheridan, 57, who will be the national ad director. Mr. Auchincloss, formerly a publisher of Newsweek, will be available to The Atlantic as a consultant for two months. Miss Pask was formerly with Penthouse and Mr. Sheridan with Reader's Digest.

title: BRITISH TIE CITED IN DELOREAN TRIAL
description: The British Government knew that John Z. DeLorean was being investigated by the American authorities a month before he was arrested on cocaine-trafficking charges, and simultaneously the British permanently closed his automobile factory in Belfast, Northern Ireland, according to statements made in court today.

title: PIONEER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sudanese President Dismisses 6 in Cabinet
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry dismissed 6 of 21 Cabinet members today.

title: State of Emergency In Brasilia Cut Short
description: Gen. Joao Figueiredo, the President of Brazil, today suspended a 60-day limited state of emergency that had been imposed to halt demonstrations for direct presidential elections.

title: STANFORD TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Year to March 31
Comings and Goings
description: Denny Walling , batting .286 for the Houston Astros, sprained his back while fielding during batting practice before the game in Cincinnati last night. . . . Alfrederick Hughes of Loyola of Illinois, the nation's fourth- leading scorer last season averaging 27.6 points, has changed his mind and will stay in school for his senior year.

title: TAPED FILMS MAKE GAIN, STUDY FINDS
description: The use of prerecorded video cassettes has grown markedly among owners of video-cassette recorders, according to a survey released yesterday by the A.C. Nielsen Company. The machines are still used most often, however, to tape television programs for viewing at a later time, the survey showed.

THE BUREAUCRATIC MANEUVERERS' OUTMANEUVERER
description: It was the fiercest Pentagon turf battle in years. When the smoke had cleared last February, Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security policy, had Pentagon Directive 2040.2 safely tucked in his pocket.

title: KODAK HAS SHARP RISE IN QUARTER
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that earnings in the the first quarter of 1984 - after the inclusion of a substantial extraordinary charge in the 1983 first quarter - more than tripled as sales edged up one-half of 1 percent.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: RIVALS IN DEBATE CRITICIZE JACKSON ON BACKER'S ACTS
description: In a debate here tonight, Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart condemned the Rev. Jesse Jackson for refusing to repudiate the support of Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader who threatened a reporter for disclosing Mr. Jackson's use of anti-Semitic language.

title: Greyhound Down 22.9%
description: The Greyhound Corporation said today that its net income declined 22.9 percent, to $12.1 million, or 24 cents a share, in the first quarter from $15.7 million, or 35 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues fell 6.8 percent, to $493.4 million, from $529.2 million, John W. Teets, chairman and chief executive officer, said.

title: ENCHANTED VILLAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-The company reported it had no sales and only minimal activity for the year-ago periods.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Tidewater Tides, at Norfolk, Va., exhibition. Braves vs San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, cable, 7:35 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs.

title: SOME PROBLEMS BETWEEN SCIENCE AND LITERATURE
description: COMMUNICATION between what Lord C. P. Snow called ''the two cultures'' has not been flourishing of late. As usual, it seems to be a case of the rest of us not quite understanding what the scientists know. For example, the conclusions reached by Jonathan Schell in his book ''The Fate of the Earth,'' an account of the catastrophic effects of nuclear war, have recently been challenged by Freeman Dyson, the weapons expert and professor of physics at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.

title: THE HOCKEY FAN IN GLEN FALLS
description: Bill Dineen was watching the hockey game on a big screen in a bar in upstate Glens Falls. The former National Hockey League forward saw the play developing, saw the swift Mats Naslund get behind Denis Potvin, saw the Islanders' other defender try to keep up with Naslund, prodding him with his stick. The other defender was Bill Dineen's son Gord.

description: The Senate today defeated a one-year feeze on nearly all military and domestic spending, possibly opening the way for approval of President Reagan's deficit-reducing plan. The vote was 65 to 33.

Senate Subcommittee Blocks Acid Rain Plan
description: Legislation to curb acid rain was effectively killed by a House subcommittee today. The panel's chairman called the 10-to-9 vote ''a likely death knell'' for stronger air pollution controls.

title: 18-Year-Olds Reduce Fatal Auto Accidents
description: The number of fatal car accidents involving 18-year- old drinking drivers fell to 26 from 45 last year after the state raised its legal drinking age to 19, according to a report released today.

title: LINEBACKERS DOMINATE DRAFT
description: The trend toward designing defenses capable of offsetting more sophisticated passing offenses was dramatically reflected in the National Football League draft Tuesday. More linebackers, 56, were taken than players in any other position.

A SERVANT HAMPERED BY GHOSTS
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S ''Mystery!'' series has been dabbling in ghost stories for the last several weeks, and the results have not been especially thrilling. More often than not, ghosts do not take well to the small screen. The insistent realistic demands of the medium do not treat ethereal creatures kindly.

title: Southwestern Bell Criticizes Rate Rise
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said today that it had received an annual rate increase of $822 million, which it termed ''unsatisfactory,'' from the Texas Public Utility Commission.

description: A Federal appeals court, ruling in favor of two major newspapers, has affirmed the constitutional right of the public to attend civil court hearings.

title: GENERAL KILLED IN NEVADA CRASH FLEW SOVIET JET
description: The Air Force general who was killed in a plane crash last Thursday in Nevada was flying a Soviet MIG-23 jet that has been used in tests against American planes equipped with radar-evading technology, according to Air Force sources.

title: NATIONALISTS URGE A NEW IRISH STATE
description: Nationalist leaders from both parts of Ireland called on Britain today to work with them to find a lasting political solution to halt the drift of Northern Ireland ''into more violence, anarchy and chaos.''

description: The Central Maine Power Company, a 6 percent owner of the Seabrook nuclear project, has borrowed $40 million from a consortium of five banks because it fears it might be unable to borrow on Wall Street if Seabrook were canceled or if the project's lead owner, Public Service of New Hampshire, were forced into bankruptcy, the company said yesterday.

description: Although the rape charge filed in New York City against Dean Craig was not particularly remarkable, his arrest last November produced huge headlines. That was because he was one of the first prisoners released a few days earlier from the Rikers Island jail to comply with a controversial Federal court order to reduce its overcrowding.

description: An article Tuesday about the new president of NBC News misstated the experience of Van Gordon Sauter of CBS, misidentified his current position and omitted the name and credentials of his successor. Mr. Sauter has not been president of CBS News since September 1983, when he became executive vice president of the CBS/ Broadcast Group. He has had extensive newspaper, radio and television news experience. Edward M. Joyce succeeded him as president last September after serving as executive vice president since 1981. Mr. Joyce also has a long background in radio and television news.

He was a local hero and he won the support of underdog fanciers elsewhere when he charged down the stretch at Aqueduct to miss winning the Wood Memorial by a nose.

description: Alan Schneider, the Broadway director, remained in ''very critical'' condition in a London hospital today, two days after receiving severe head injuries in a street accident.

title: Robertson Sued
description: Andre Robertson , the Yankee shortstop, New York City and an erecting company were sued for $25 million yesterday by the female passenger who was paralyzed from the waist down when a car driven by Robertson crashed into a barrier on the West Side Highway last Aug. 18. Shenikwa Dawn Nowlin , 25 years old, said in papers filed in New York State Supreme Court that Robertson was ''careless and negligent'' when he tried to negotiate an ''S'' curve on the highway. Because Robertson was driving ''at a greater rate of speed than care and caution would permit under the circumstances,'' the car crashed into the guardrail, overturned and caused her ''grievous and paralyzing injuries,'' the suit said.

title: In Battle of Singers,Coke Signs Up Iglesias
description: The soft-drink battle of the singers moved into Coke's court yesterday as the Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Company announced at a news conference that it had signed Julio Iglesias, whom Coke described as ''the world's most popular entertainer.''

Actually, it is about love deepening, a theme that Gelsey Kirkland and Kevin McKenzie made rapturously clear as never before Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: VIEWS OF LONG ISLAND Diane Gorodnitzki studied photography at the Maryland Institute of Fine Arts. Her idols were the pro- preservationists Ansel Adams and Eliot Porter, and landscapes and seascapes are her favorite subjects. In her current exhibit, ''The Land That Water Made: Photographs of Eastern Long Island,'' Miss Gorodnitzki displays her preferences and her philosophy in 100 color prints showing farmlands, forests and the orchids that are found in bogs. The exhibit is on view at the Community Gallery, 30 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: Pepsico Considers Sale of Lee Way
description: Pepsico Inc. said it was ''actively negotiating'' the sale of its Lee Way Motor Freight subsidiary with ''several prospective purchasers.'' The company also said its board had approved a definitive agreement for the previously announced sale of its North American Van Lines Inc. subsidiary to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $315 million.

Immediately on Thursday morning, some of the White House staff will have to rush into the details of the next Presidential trip, the one to Britain, Ireland and France four weeks hence, planning like circus managers for each day of shelter, food, locomotion and photo angles to be required.

title: Bush Adds Indonesia to Trip
description: Vice President Bush is scheduled to visit Indonesia May 10-12 for talks with President Suharto as part of a tour that will also take him to Japan, India, Pakistan and Oman, the White House said today. According to a tentative schedule, Mr. Bush is scheduled to leave for Japan on Monday and travel to Jakarta on May 10, going on to New Delhi May 12, Islamabad on May 15 and Muscat on May 18. He will return to Washington May 20.

title: TRUDEAU URGES U.S. TO RESIST PROTECTIONISM

description: ON the eve of its 50th anniversary, the Village Light Opera Group has revived ''Engaged!,'' a three-act comic opera based on an 1877 play by W. S. Gilbert. Using lyrics and music from four little-known Gilbert & Sullivan operas, as well as Arthur Sullivan's scores for other librettists and Gilbert's librettos for other composers, it was constructed into a Gilbert & Sullivan opera in 1962 by the Englishmen George Rowell and Kenneth Mobbs. The Village Light Opera Group first presented the work in 1965.

title: U.S.-CHINA RELATIONS MATURING
description: Both Peking and Washington can be reasonably satisfied with the results of President Reagan's recent trip to China. The Chinese can take comfort in the fact that their visitor, who came into office proclaiming his attachment to Taiwan, has now joined a growing consensus in the United States on the necessity for stable Sino-American relations. The President has largely repaired the damage that his earlier statements did to our relations with Peking.
