description: Syria confirmed today that it captured three Israeli officials in Lebanon Tuesday and said they had been taken to Syria. Israel demanded their release.

title: A BLAZE OF NEON-BRIGHT COLORS MARKS FALL FASHION SHOWS
description: DESIGNERS have dipped deeply into the strong color palette this season, probably in reaction to the sober blacks and grays of the last few collections. But no one on this side of the Atlantic has been as enamored of vivid tones as Oscar de la Renta.

title: CITY'S PLAN TO BUILD 8 INCINERATORS IS DEBATED AT FIRST PUBLIC HEARING
description: The Sanitation Department's plan for building eight garbage-burning incinerators around the city by 1996 was faulted yesterday before the Board of Estimate as being premature and incomplete. It was also welcomed as a response to the growing problem of waste disposal.

title: Only A Rogue
description: Britain has broken relations with Libya, after the shooting in London and the ultrapolite siege of the ''Libyan People's Bureau,'' alias Libyan Embassy. The U.S. did about the same after the burning of the American Embassy in Tripoli in 1979.

title: SPRING'S PLEASURES: MAY HOUSE TOURS
description: SPRING is high season for touring historic houses and districts and decorator show houses. The fun of looking at other people's houses and apartments, of exploring a new neighborhood or seeing a mansion temporarily refurbished by expert designers is one of the pleasures of May.

title: Article 164921 -- No Title
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said that it had completed seven separate transactions this week covering the sale of about $637 million of producing properties, and that it is conducting ''serious negotiations'' regarding the sale of an additional $192 million of producing properties.

title: John L. Barrett, 71, the Voice Of the Lone Ranger on Radio
description: John L. Barrett, who played the Lone Ranger when that radio drama began in Buffalo in the early 1930's, died at his home Tuesday.

title: People
description: * Kathryn Feakins, Jane Fitzgibbon, Robert Neuman, F. Paul Pracilio and Mark Shap elected senior vice presidents at Ogilvy & Mather.

title: MAYOR REVERSES 1982 DEMOTION OF WELFARE AID
description: Reversing an earlier decision, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he would reinstate a city social worker who was demoted after he publicized the mishandling of abuse cases in which nine Brooklyn children died.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $23,500. c-Net loss.

title: Panel Rejects Plan On Yankee Doodle
description: A plan to build a replica of a house where some people believe Yankee Doodle once lived was rejected here Tuesday night.

title: METS DOWN CUBS ON RUN IN NINTH
description: The comeback Mets did it again last night, staking the Chicago Cubs to a 3-0 lead before beating them, 4-3, on a sacrifice fly by Keith Hernandez in the ninth inning.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $77,179. c-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $212,460.

title: ROCK: THE PRETENDERS PERFORM AT RADIO CITY
description: THE PRETENDERS, who played the first of three shows at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday, retain only half their original personnel. But while the current Pretenders tour is the first for the guitarist Robbie MacIntosh and the bassist Malcolm Foster, the music has not changed a great deal. Chrissie Hynde, the singer, songwriter and guitarist from Ohio who assembled the original Pretenders in England, still dominates the band. And Martin Chambers is still the Pretenders's backbone, and one of rock's most exact and powerful drummers.

title: Races Canceled At Meadowlands
description: A transformer fire caused a blackout at the Meadowlands Race Track tonight, forcing track officials to cancel the remainder of the card after the opening race. The fire, described by a Meadowlands spokesman as ''quite small and contained,'' and affecting only the offices, apparently damaged electrical connections shortly after the first race at 8 P.M. Patrons at the track will receive refunds on any of the canceled races and get a free program for Thursday.

title: Required Reading Democrats in Trouble
description: Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, in remarks on the Senate floor, May 1, 1984:

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOP GIANT PICK LOOKS BACK
description: Carl Banks, the Michigan State linebacker and the Giants' No. 1 choice in National Football League draft, remembers the lessons he learned growing up in Flint, Mich.

title: Natchezsippi to Play
description: The cornetist Olu Dara will lead his group, Natchezsippi, tonight and tomorrow at at Sweet Basil (242- 1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. There is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: REAGAN MAY PRESS FOR SALVADOR AID
description: White House officials, alarmed about the military situation in El Salvador, expect President Reagan to give a televised address this month charging that Congress will be to blame if the Salvadoran Government is not given the military aid he says it needs.

title: LATE-APRIL AUTO SALES ROSE 36.6%
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's major manufacturers rose 36.6 percent in the last 10 days of April from a year earlier, the companies reported today.

title: Debt Issues ;  Preferred Stock
description: E. F. Hutton Group Inc. , a holding company, said it had filed for up to $200 million aggregate principal amount of its senior debt securities, which will be sold directly or through a group of underwriters. The securities may be offered in one or more series at terms to be determined at the time of the sales. American Exploration Co., an oil and gas company in Houston, announced the conversion of all of the 26,777 outstanding shares of its series A 12 percent cumulative convertible preferred stock into shares of its common stock. As a condition, American closed a private offering of one million shares of common at $5 a share.

title: Article 166647 -- No Title
description: Esmark Inc., the big Chicago company that bought Norton Simon Inc. last year for $1 billion, said yesterday that it had just received a takeover bid of its own for $2.3 billion in cash. It has yet to respond to the offer, but Esmark is widely known to be interested in making a deal, if an acceptable price can be struck.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Althea, Filly, Is Derby Choice
description: For the first time in 49 years, a filly is the favorite to win the Kentucky Derby.

title: Democrat's Chief Sees Gain in Anderson Move
description: Charles T. Masnatt, the Democratic national chairman, said today he expected the Democrats to gain as many as four million votes from John B. Anderson's decision not to run for President in 1984.

title: JACKSON, IN A CONCESSION, SUGGESTS STUDY OF RUNOFF PRIMARIES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has made enforcement of the Voting Rights Act a key issue of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, today backed away from insisting that the party's Presidential nominee must share his views on that issue to receive his support.

title: Merger Rumors Advance Pioneer
description: The Pioneer Corporation's share s advanced $2.625 a share, to $31, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in the company's biggest one-day volume ever, amid rumors of a takeover move. Analysts said two likely suitors are the Coastal Corporation and the Pennzoil Company, both of which declined comment.

title: SOLIDARITY RALLY STAGED IN WARSAW
description: Thousands of riot policemen and hundreds of armored vehicles surrounded the capital's Old Town today, but protesters nevertheless managed to stage an impromptu Solidarity demonstration.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ISLANDERS TOP CANADIENS AND TAKE 3-2 SERIES LEAD
description: The Islanders found still another tactic tonight to help win a playoff game: Throwing their bodies in front of hard-driven pucks.

title: Bayer's Profits Surged in 1983
description: Bayer A.G. said today that a strong rebound for the worldwide chemical industry helped its 1983 profits soar more than 10 times from 1982's figures.

description: An obituary on April 15 of Carl K. Erpf, chairman of the Manhattan brokerage firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, misidentified Mr. Erpf's late father. He was Carl Erpf; Armand G. Erpf was the younger Mr. Erpf's uncle.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $15.7 million from the company's investment in Houston Natural Gas Corp.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kodak Has New Ektaprint Copier
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a multi-featured Ektaprint 225 copier-duplicator, which it said was designed to challenge the Xerox Corporation's hot-selling 1075 copier. Kodak also announced improvements in its Ektaprint 200.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCREEN: 'BUDDY SYSTEM'
description: ''THE BUDDY SYSTEM,'' based on an original screenplay by Mary Agnes Donoghue, looks and sounds like a lesser Neil Simon comedy. Miss Donoghue has studied the master carefully, but without learning how to turn out the abrasive one- liners that sometimes can make this kind of movie fun in spite of itself.

title: Continental Narrows Loss
description: Continental Air Lines reported yesterday that it had narrowed its net loss to $4.9 million for the first quarter, from $57.6 million in the quarter a year earlier when it was a much larger airline. Revenues fell 31.6 percent, to $217.7 million, from $318.2 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late Edition yesterday omitted page C11 and carried page C18 twice. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: No Headline
description: William Platt Is Dead; M

title: Mayor of Augusta, Ga., Quits After Conviction
description: Edward M. McIntyre, Mayor of Augusta, resigned today, five days after being convicted of extortion.

title: CENTENNIAL FOR THE MAN FROM INDEPENDENCE
description: One hundred years ago next Tuesday, John Truman nailed a mule shoe over the door of his house in Lamar, Mo., to celebrate the birth of his first son.

title: Klezmer Orchestra
description: The clarinetist Andy Statman will lead his four-piece Klezmer Orchestra in a two-hour concert Sunday at 8 P.M. at the WBAI Free Music Store, broadcasting live (on 99.5 FM) from P.S. 41 at 116 West 11th Street. The suggested donation is $3 at the door.

title: CITY'S SCHOOLS IN SEARCH FOR STABILITY
description: New York city's school system is so enormous, its bureaucracy so entrenched, that for a while - maybe a long while - it can almost run itself.

title: IT'S SEASON FOR MUSIC OF MIDDLE EAST
description: For the last eight and a half years, the Alternative Museum at 17 White Street has been presenting musicians from around the world, exposing New Yorkers to folk and classical styles rarely heard in the United States. The next two months will see its most ambitious program yet - a survey of the full sweep of the Middle Eastern musical tradition, which extends from Andalusia to western China and from Africa to central Asia.

title: Standex Buyout Talks Are Cited
description: The Standex International Corporation said it understood that Boston Ventures Management Inc. and some members of Standex were considering a leveraged buyout of Standex for a total of $21 a share, including cash and debentures. Based on the company's 13.8 million shares outstanding, the deal would be valued at nearly $290 million.

title: Hunt Seeks 10 Debates With Helms in Contest
description: Gov. James Hunt Jr., seeking to unseat Senator Jesse Helms, wants 10 debates with Mr. Helms later this year.

title: KATHY BOUDIN GIVEN 20 YEARS TO LIFE IN PRISON
description: Kathy Boudin was sentenced today to 20 years to life in prison for her role in the 1981 Brink's holdup in which a guard and two police officers were slain.

title: Advertising; The Art Of Selling A Concept
description: WHEN you saw those two new American Greetings TV commercials this week, did you marvel at the softness of the sell that characterizes that genre of advertising?

title: 'CAFETERIA' PLANS FACE I.R.S. CURB
description: The Internal Revenue Service is proposing to ban a popular new type of fringe benefit plan that allows workers to use pretax wages to pay for medical and other personal expenses and take back in cash any unused portion.

title: DOW OFF 5.03, TO 1,181.53
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in slower trading after posting impressive advances in the previous two sessions. The biggest gainers yesterday were issues responding to takeover news or rumors.

MOSCOW ASSAILS PEKING'S STANCE TOWARD REAGAN
description: A commentary distributed by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency, accused China today of taking only scant notice of the United States' ''militarist course'' while seeking improved relations with Washington.

title: NEW DESIGNER MAKES MARK
description: Tuesday night, before a packed house of 1,700 people at the Ritz nightclub, Stephen Sprouse, the 30-year-old fashion designer from Indiana, muscled his way into the ranks of American fashion with an outstanding collection of men's and women's fall clothes.

title: Export Bill Unresolved
description: House- Senate conferees today failed to narrow any of the major differences separating the two chambers on legislation that would set new ground rules for controlling exports, but they did make some progress on minor issues.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about allegations that gangs had forced tenants out of some Manhattan apartment buildings included a list, provided by the District Attorney, that cited one building erroneously. The building, 336 West 19th Street, should not have been on the list.

title: Waiting 9 Days For Playoff Game
description: The Edmonton Oilers may have to pay a price for their four-game sweep of the Minnesota North Stars for the championship of the National Hockey League's Clarence Campbell Conference.

title: POPE, IN SEOUL, CALLS FOR 'A MORE HUMAN SOCIETY'
description: Pope John Paul II began a four-day visit here today by expressing the hope that South Korea's economic progress would lead to ''a more human society of true justice and peace.''

title: CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Co-produced by KTCA-TV of Minneapolis-St. Paul and MGW Productions of Washington, the new, seven- part documentary series ''Your Children, Our Children,'' is being billed as ''the first to focus on America's 67 million young people.''

title: CENTRAL PARK ACTIVITIES
description: Central Park in the spring offers something for everyone: the athletic and the sedentary, the naturalist and the culture lover, parents and children. The diversity will be especially evident in the events that will be available this Sunday.

title: SYRIAN ASSERTS 3 CAPTURED ISRAELIS CONFESSED TO SPYING
description: A senior Syrian official said today that three Israelis captured by Syrian troops in Lebanon on Tuesday had confessed that they had been on a ''spying mission.''

description: USA Today, Gannett's national newspaper, with about 1.3 million daily circulation, begins a $2.5 million print advertising campaign Monday to explain itself to advertisers, agencies and the business community.

title: 2 Journalists Receive Prize For Reporting on Diplomacy
description: The Edward Weintal Prize for diplomatic reporting was awarded today to Dusko Doder, Moscow correspondent for The Washington Post, and Bernard Gwertzman of the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS ASKS ETHICS INQUIRY
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation has asked the Justice Department to look into bringing criminal charges against its former president for asking an oilman seeking Federal subsidies to invest in his bank.

title: HALL, FRANK B. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $901,000, or 7 cents a share, gain from change in accounting method for adjusting fee income. The year-ago results restated for a pooling of interests.

title: BALLET: 'MOVES' BY JEROME ROBBINS
description: ''MOVES,'' a ballet without music choreographed by Jerome Robbins in 1959 for his short-lived company, Ballets: U.S.A., was obviously an experiment from the start. And it has remained an experiment of a different sort in its transfer to the New York City Ballet 25 years after its creation.

title: Tribute for Niekro
description: Ted Turner may rue the day he released Phil Niekro , the longtime Atlanta pitcher who won 268 games and lost 230 before he joined the Yankees, for whom he has won four games without losing this season. But Turner is not one to hide his mistakes.

description: The Gary Hart Presidential campaign has come to resemble a pushmi-pullyu. That fictional beast, created by Hugh Lofting in ''The Story of Dr. Dolittle,'' had no tail but had a head at each end.

title: Pop and Rock
description: In its bedrock simplicity, the blues is one of the toughest kinds of music to play well, depending on such factors as the musicianship of the performers, the response of the audience and the intangible feeling on the bandstand. Tonight at 8 at the Beacon Theater (874-1717), Broadway at 74th Street, there will be a triple bill of blues bands, which, with any luck, will spur all the players' competitive instincts. The headliner is Johnny Winter, the Texas blues-rock guitarist with a slashing, flamboyant style and a roar of a singing voice.

title: CHAIRMAN OF AIR FLORIDA IN SUDDEN RESIGNATION
description: Citing unspecified ''policy differences,'' Donald Lloyd-Jones resigned abruptly yesterday as chairman, president and chief executive officer of Air Florida.

description: ONE of the most remarkable images that we have seen in New York lately is the variant after ''Oedipus and the Sphinx'' by Jean-Dominique Ingres that is included in the exhibition of recent paintings by Francis Bacon at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street.

title: ROTHKO FOUNDATION GIVES 1,000 WORKS TO 19 ART MUSEUMS
description: The Mark Rothko Foundation yesterday announced that it was giving most of its collection of about 1,000 works by Rothko, one of the leading artists of the 20th century, to 19 museums in the United States and abroad.

description: One of the most pleasant surprises of the season for Pat Corrales, the manager of the Cleveland Indians, has been the relief work of a rookie, Tom Waddell, a 1981 graduate of Manhattan College.

description: Orin R. Smith was elected president and chief executive officer yesterday of the Engelhard Corporation by its board of directors.

description: Blue Bell Inc., a maker of jeans and other apparel based in Greensboro, N.C., said yesterday that it was holding talks on a proposed leveraged buyout at $50 a share.

title: Net at MCI Tumbles 89%
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, a long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that net income for its fiscal fourth quarter dropped 89 percent, to $5.9 million, or 3 cents a share, from $53.1 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier.

description: A Spanish Basque exile was shot dead and another was seriously wounded by gunmen near here in the French border village of St.-Martin- d'Arrosa today, the police said.

title: BONUS FOR ATTENDENCE LEAVES SCHOOL BIG BILL
description: Hoping to improve attendance, Richmond High School last year offered $100 to any student who was in school every day. But school officials hardly expected 200 students to qualify, and now they are trying to find $20,000 for the payoff.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THERE'S a monumental Henry Moore on the sidewalk at Sotheby's and two Alexander Calders on its roof - all part of the auction house's exhibition of art works that it will sell over the next two weeks. Moore's bronze ''Reclining Figure,'' executed in the late 1960's, was shipped in by helicopter and flatbed truck Monday from somewhere in the New York area (the site and the collector have not been disclosed) to the galleries, York Avenue at 72d Street. Then, because of the sculpture's size and weight - it's more than 11 feet long and 8 feet tall and weighs 3,000 pounds - David J. Nash, Sotheby's director of fine arts, decided it should remain out front until it is auctioned May 15. Mr. Nash had Sotheby's carpenters build a wedge-shape base so that the figure is level on the sloping sidewalk. ''I just hope someone buys it and takes it away,'' Mr. Nash commented, adding that to do so may cost a buyer about $500,000.

title: ALAN SCHNEIDER, PIONEERINGDIRECTOR, IS DEAD
description: Alan Schneider, one of the most important American directors of contemporary theater, died yesterday in London from head injuries suffered when he was hit by a motorcycle Monday. He was 66 years old.

description: Thomas R. Pickering had no previous experience in Latin Ameria when he was chosen last July to be United States Ambassador to El Salvador.

title: FILM: 'RENT CONTROL,' NEW YORK CAST
description: SCENE: an Upper West Side bar, on a Saturday afternoon. Leonard Junger, an aspiring young television writer, runs into an acquaintance named Milton Goeller, a disagreeably egotistical, successful, free-lance writer of expose pieces. As Milton proceeds to get thoroughly drunk, he tells Leonard about his latest bit of scandal- mongering, a book that will finger a prominent United States Senator as a murderer.

title: FRANCE BANS GROUP SEEKING GUADELOUPE'S INDEPENDENCE
description: The Government today outlawed the Caribbean Revolutionary Alliance, a pro-independence group based in Guadeloupe that has taken responsibility for bombing French Government installations and other so-called symbols of colonialism in France's Caribbean territories.

title: WEINBERGER GIVES PLAN TO CUT BACK PENTAGON BUDGET
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today gave Congress the Reagan Administration's plan to cut the military budget. It bows to bipartisan pressure to shrink the Federal deficit but saves the scope of the military buildup by stretching out purchases of conventional weapon programs.

title: 6,000 Are Detained At Protest Rally in India
description: The police briefly arrested 6,000 opposition members here today for violating a ban on rallies in the capital to protest what they called Government failure to curb terrorism in the Punjab.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $797,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN WEST TEXAS, THE TOPIC IS DUST STORMS, NOT POLITICAL WINDS
description: Three times this spring Howard Applegate has planted his tomatoes, and three times they have been sand-blasted away. And the unripe green fruit on his plum tree have been prematurely harvested by the wind. ''Now I have a green- plumb carpet outside the house,'' said Professor Applegate, an expert in pollution along the Mexican-American border who works at the University of Texas campus here.

title: NETS LOSE AND TRAIL PLAYOFF SERIES BY 2-1
description: The Nets were executing their offense with such chaos that it looked as if they learned the plays last week. Albert King, one of their best outside shooters, was tentative and missing. Buck Williams was missing free throws as well as anything he shot farther than 2 feet from the basket. Darryl Dawkins was in foul trouble. His backup, Mike Gminski, was being muscled.

title: A.J.C. PONDERS THE GULF BETWEEN BLACKS AND JEWS
description: Concern over the growing gulf between blacks and Jews was a recurring theme at the 78th annual meeting of the American Jewish Committee, held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 4, 1984 International
description: President Reagan defended the American Ambassador to El Salvador, Thomas R. Pickering, against sharp criticism made Wednesday by Senator Jesse Helms. The Republican Senator from North Carolina accused Mr. Pickering of interfering in the Salvadoran presidential runoff election and demanded his immediate recall. Congressional leaders of both parties joined Mr. Reagan in expressing their confidence in the Ambassador. (Page A1, Column 1.) The President may blame Congress in an address this month if the Salvadoran Government is not given the military aid he says it needs, White House officials said. (A5:1.)

title: Southwold, SGS In Enterra Bid
description: Southwold N.V. and SGS Associates have offered to buy all the shares outstanding of the Enterra Corporation for $21 a share, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Southwold and SGS now hold 1.01 million of Enterra's common shares, or 11.3 percent of the total outstanding.

title: HOT DOGS CALLED A CHOKING THREAT

title: 'LAST DAYS OF POMPEII,' WITH LAURENCE OLIVIER
description: -hour, three-night mini-series ''The Last Days of Pompeii,'' which begins on Channel 7 Sunday night at 8, positively cries for the word colossal. Five years in the planning, costing $19 million, featuring an international cast that includes Laurence Olivier, partly filmed in the ruins of Italy's Pompeii, the production is colossal in many ways. But basically, it is a colossal failure, or, at the very least, the kind of colossal hoot that will be treasured by entertainment buffs.

Tatiana Troyanos
description: Tatiana Troyanos, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, will give a song recital Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y. Her program will include music by Rossini, Mozart, Berlioz, Berg and Mahler and Ravel's Greek folk-song arrangements, which are usually sung in French, in their original tongue. Tickets are $11 to $15 and are available at the Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue. The information number is 427-4410.

title: Title Vacated
description: Roberto Duran has vacated his World Boxing Association junior middleweight title in order to fight Thomas Hearns for the World Boxing Council's version of the 154-pound title June 15 in the Bahamas. The W.B.A. had mandated that Duran must fight its top junior middleweight challenger, Mike McCallum, before meeting any other opponent, or Duran would be stripped of the title.

description: Sarah Bradley Gamble, honorary chairman of the Pathfinder Fund of Boston, a foundation that provides money for family planning services and population programs in developing countries, died April 27 at her home in Milton, Mass. She was 86 years old.

description: Armed guards patrol the quiet, nearly deserted streets of this capital at night, occupying the intersections or crouching, automatic weapons in hand, in the shadows of shopping arcades.

title: ART: JOAN MIRO EXHIBIT, SCULPTURE AND CERAMICS
description: ''ACT from the conviction that all these pure devisings of my mind will magically and miraculously find an echo in the minds of other men,'' the Spanish artist Joan Miro advised himself in a notebook entry of 1941. By that time, his Surrealist-inspired painting, recognized as one of the great contributions to 20th-century art, had already found its echo, but still to come were other magical ''devisings,'' among them sculpture and ceramics.

title: WHO NEEDS DEREGULATED BANKS?
description: Are we better off with a deregulated banking industry? The answer depends on who the ''we'' is.

description: Britain today ordered the deportation of two Libyan students, one reputed to be the head of the Libyan student movement, and the police ended their search of the vacant Libyan Embassy.

PARIBAS SETS FUNDS FOR BECKER
description: A. G. Becker Paribas Inc., the Wall Street investment-banking and brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it would get a new infusion of capital from Paribas, the big French nationalized bank that is its major shareholder.

title: ART: HIROSHIGE PRINTS AT I.B.M. GALLERY
description: AS far as curatorial pomp and circumstance goes, the Hiroshige print show at the I.B.M. Gallery, 590 Madison Avenue at 56th Street, is no blockbuster. The catalogue weighs in at a mere 2 1/4 pounds, most of its illustrations are black and white, and its essay, by Edythe Polster, is little more than a chronology. Still, at around 700 works, the exhibition is huge and, for this observer, the largest retrospective since Picasso's in 1980, a Museum of Modern Art production of which, by the way, I.B.M. was the chief sponsor.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds tumbled $1.24 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $170.07 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the previous week, the assets declined $357 million, to $171.3 billion.

title: Grey Earnings Up
description: Grey Advertising released its first- quarter financial statement yesterday and, like the other public agencies that have reported, it showed healthy earnings gains. Net income rose 57.7 percent, to $1 million, or $1.59 a share, from $634,000, or $1.12 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 27 percent, to $40.4 million, from $31.8 million.

title: GRAHAM LEADS BY 3 ON A 64
description: David Graham got rolling with an eagle 3 at the second hole today and went on to tie the La Costa Country Club course record with an eight-under-par 64 in the opening round of the 32d annual MONY Tournament of Champions. His 64 gave Graham, the 1981 United States Open champion, a 3-shot lead over Fuzzy Zoeller (67) and 4-shot lead over Ben Crenshaw (68), who won the Masters Tournament three weeks ago.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net income for the fourth quarter and year includes a writeoff of $49.8 million for a decline in the value of telex-related equipment.

title: A LESSON FROM WHIPSAWING 101
description: For Dennis E. Eckart, a second-term Democratic Congressman from Ohio, it came down to a choice, a tough choice, between the economic burdens of his constituents and his longstanding concern about the environment. In the end, the local issues proved more important, causing him to cast a vote that may well have doomed any prospect for adoption of legislation this year to reauthorize the Clean Air Act and control acid rain.

title: JERSEY SUING FOR $1.27 BILLION IN FEDERAL SUPERFUND CLAIMS
description: New Jersey has filed suit against the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to obtain $1.27 billion to help alleviate the damage done by hazardous waste to the state's waterways, woodlands and wildlife.

title: A PAPAL VISIT FOR THE LEPERS OF KOREA
description: Pope John Paul II, visiting South Korea, was scheduled to make a brief stop of more than an hour Friday on Sorok Island, off the southern Korean coast. It is a pine-covered patch of land whose pleasant beaches belie the fact that they ring the country's biggest leper colony.

Budget Group Pressing For Pledges on Deficit
description: In its efforts to cut spending and raise taxes to reduce the Federal budget deficit, the Bipartisan Budget Appeal has recruited a number of former public officials, more than 400 chief executive officers and numerous educators, economists and lawyers. The bipartisan group is headed by former Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson and five other former Cabinet officials, W. Michael Blumenthal, John B. Connally, C. Douglas Dillon, Henry H. Fowler and William E. Simon.

title: COURT BARS DATA ON KENNEDY DEATH
description: A state court judge today barred the release of any information about how David Anthony Kennedy died, asserting that to do so would ''hamper'' a police investigation into the death.

title: RED SOX STOP TIGERS BY 1-0
description: An eighth-inning home run by Dwight Evans broke up a pitchers' duel between Jack Morris and Bob Ojeda and gave the Red Sox a 1-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

description: Twelve Metro-North conductors and assistant conductors were indicted yesterday in Manhattan on charges of having stolen $7,000 by falsely claiming to have worked weekends or on overtime.

description: The smile grew on Guy Lafleur's face, lips together. He was asked about the late 1970's, when the Montreal Canadiens were winning four straight Stanley Cups and ''the Flower'' was their most precious rose.

description: The Federal Election Commission said today that Presidential candidates raised more than $40 million, including Federal matching funds, and spent $36.6 million through January.

title: Relief for Yonkers
description: Local pride has its place, but nearly bankrupt Yonkers, N.Y., deserved better than the long resistance of its City Council to state supervision in return for state aid. Did no one care that the delay jeopardized the education of 20,000 schoolchildren?

title: HOUSE, AFTER STIFF DEBATE, BACKS CHEAP POWER FOR 3 WESTERN STATES
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved a 30- year renewal of an arrangement giving utilities in three Western states low- cost electric power generated by the Hoover Dam.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE: WHAT'S BEST IN ALL THE ARTS THIS WEEKEND ; STAGE
description: Nine New York Times critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead just to make sure everything is on schedule.

title: SCREEN: '16 CANDLES,' A TEEN-AGE COMEDY
description: JOHN HUGHES'S ''16 Candles'' is a cuter and better-natured teen comedy than most, with the kinds of occasional lapses in taste that probably can't hurt it in the circles for which it is intended. The middle of the film wastes time on a bit more house-wrecking and car-crashing than is absolutely necessary, and there are some notably unfunny ethnic jokes. But most of the the movie is cheerful and light, showcasing Mr. Hughes's knack for remembering all those aspects of middle-class American adolescent behavior that anyone else might want to forget.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''IT is,'' whispered Bando Tamasaburo, ''a stepping up in my career. It is wonderful to be seen and appreciated by an audience other than Japanese.''

title: Doctor of Art
description: Boxing fans know Ferdie Pacheco as a medical doctor who, as a hobby, became a cornerman for fighters trained by Angelo Dundee. Pacheco served from 1963 to 1977 as Muhammad Ali's personal physician and then moved into television as a boxing consultant and analyst for NBC Sports.

title: Chico Freeman Group
description: The saxophonist Chico Freeman will perform with Steve Coleman on alto saxophone, Mark Thompson on piano, Frederick Waits on drums and Cecil McBee on bass tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7459), 154 West 57th Street. Tickets are $8.50.

title: RIVALS PRESS HUNT FOR VOTES IN TEXAS
description: All three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination pressed their hunt for delegates in the critical state of Texas today, but Senator Gary Hart cut short his effort and concentrated instead on Louisiana and Ohio.

title: Z & Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Breaking the Wilderness Logjam
description: The three-year deadlock over adding Forest Service lands to the national wilderness system has finally been broken. Senator James McClure of Idaho has agreed to a procedure that will allow some forests ''under review'' to be developed and others to be maintained in pristine natural state. Thus resumes a process that could permanently preserve some 10 million acres of land - an area twice the size of New Jersey.

title: A PRODUCER AND STAR OF TV GAME SHOWS
description: Jack Barry, the producer and star of such popular television game shows as ''The Joker's Wild'' and ''21,'' collapsed and died of a heart attack Wednesday while jogging in Central Park. He was 66 years old.

title: New Charges Returned In Philadelphia Inquiry
description: James Martin, the city's former Deputy Police Commissioner, and 14 officers were indicted today on charges of obstructing justice in a reported conspiracy to protect illegal gambling.

The Editorial Notebook; From Nemesis to Noah
description: Like skirt lengths, though not so unabashedly, scientific theories are subject to the iron whims of fashion. Theories of global catastrophe, after a century's eclipse, are enjoying a lightning comeback. Nineteenth-century scientists repudiated deus ex machina catastrophes like Noah's flood as acceptable explanations for events in the earth's geological history. Catastrophes are now back in vogue, though in the form of astronomical influences, not divine intervention. But the new catastrophism may be headed for a crash landing.

title: U.S. ACTS LAWFULLY
description: We are often told that we can bring the rule of law to bear on an unruly world if we but set an example by unilateral compliance. And when it appears that we choose not to do so, we are accused, in the words of one former high-ranking United States official, of trying ''to match the Russians in deviousness or the Libyans in irresponsibility or the Iranians in brutality.'' This is pious nonsense.

title: ART: APOCALYPTIC POP IN MIXED-MEDIA SHOW
description: WITH his new work, Robert Longo emerges, unquestionably, as one of the leading artists of his generation. In his exhibition at Metro Pictures, 150 Greene Street, through May 19, Longo's generosity, directorial skill and feeling for cultural contradiction have been put in the service of works that seem freer of sentimentality, more sustained and more appropriate to their large scale than anything he has done before.

title: OPTIONS INQUIRY CONTINUES
description: The chief executive of Bear, Stearns & Company, Alan C. Greenberg, said yesterday that his firm was ''not involved in any way, shape or form'' in options trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange on April 19.

title: GREAT WEST STEEL CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $6.3 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $1.4 million from other charges. c-After a loss of $3.8 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $900,000 from other charges.

title: Scott to direct 'Design for Living' at Circle in Square.
description: NOEL COWARD wrote ''Design for Living'' in 1933 as a get-together for Lynn Fontanne, Alfred Lunt and himself. He called it ''all our own,'' and people apparently took him at his word: the play has not had a major Broadway production since. Circle in the Square, inspired by both the historical curiosity of the play and the success of its revival of Coward's ''Present Laughter'' two years ago, has picked ''Design for Living'' as its next production. Jill Clayburgh, Raul Julia and Frank Langella will star in Coward's romantic triangle, and George C. Scott, who both starred in and staged ''Present Laughter,'' will be the director. Rehearsals began today. The first performance will be June 1.

title: Sonat Aide Is Promoted
description: Sonat Inc.'s directors yesterday elected Ronald L. Kuehn Jr. chief executive officer. Mr. Kuehn, a 49-year-old lawyer who has been the company's president and chief operating officer since 1982, will assume his new post on June 1.

title: No Headline
description: HISPANICS

title: PAYMENTS ORDERED OVER MINORITY HIRING
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Government should compensate white municipal employees who are laid off while minority workers with less seniority keep their jobs under affirmative-action programs.

description: A Federal agent in the undercover investigation of John Z. DeLorean said today that the Government had planned to arrest Mr. DeLorean no matter how he reacted to being presented with a suitcase of cocaine, short of his threatening to ''call the F.B.I.'' to arrest the undercover agents.

''I said a long time ago that I was not interested in football,'' said the track star, who showed no interest in changing his mind after learning that the Cowboys had selected him on the 12th and final round of the National Football League draft Wednesday.

''No more soccer for me, 20 years as a pro is enough,'' said the 39- year-old Beckenbauer, who helped the Cosmos win three championships after he helped Bayern Munich win three European titles and West Germany capture the 1974 World Cup.

RESTAURANTS
description: THE CAPTAIN'S TABLE, a small, frenetically busy restaurant at the corner of Second Avenue and 46th Street, has specialized in American- and Mediterranean-accented fish dishes since it opened six years ago. While the wondrous variety of local and imported fish is still impressive, some of it tantalizingly displayed at the entrance, the details that make the difference between an excellent restaurant and a very good one have been lost. This is surprising because the owners, Gino and Sabine Musso, have sold the original Captain's Table in Greenwich Village and should be able to give full attention to their uptown establishment.

title: Unhappiness over the final 'Swing Shift.'
description: ''SWING SHIFT,'' starring Goldie Hawn, is not the film that at least two of its makers expected it to be. Jonathan Demme, the director, described himself as ''deeply disappointed'' with the final version, and added, ''I finished the picture one way and then saw it in a new form that I didn't even recognize.'' Mr. Demme said that he finished shooting the film but left before it was edited into its current version. He said that he and Craig McKay, who had been his editor on ''Melvin and Howard,'' left of their own volition ''rather than participate in work we didn't believe in.''

title: U.S. IS SAID TO SUPPORT FRENCHMAN AT O.E.C.D.
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to support a senior French diplomat for the key international economic post of Secretary General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, according to diplomatic sources.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE: WHAT'S BEST IN ALL THE ARTS THIS WEEKEND ; Dance
description: Nine New York Times critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead just to make sure everything is on schedule.

title: Jackson Aide Is Linked To Insurance Conflict
description: Arnold R. Pinkney, the national manager of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, sold a $2 million insurance policy to a port agency of which he is an officer, The Plain Dealer said today.

title: HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Clark Griffith , last Monday night. ''Calvin has said he wants $35 million for his shares,'' Dick Pomerantz , a spokesman for the Minneapolis Chamber of Commerce, said. . . . Leathem (Tim) Stearn has been named skipper of Courageous II, one of nine United States yachts that will vie for a chance to win back the America's Cup from Australia in 1987. . . . Joe Scannella , whose ties to football coaching go back to high school teams and C.W. Post College on Long Island, has been promoted to offensive coordinator of the Cleveland Browns after serving as running-back coach there the last two seasons. . . . Danny (Little Red) Lopez has decided to attempt a ring comeback June 14 against an opponent to be named. Lopez, 31, has not fought since June 1980, when Salvador Sanchez stopped him in the 14th round of their rematch for the World Boxing Council featherweight championship.

description: A major fire engulfed several buildings in the heart of a downtown shopping district today, forcing the evacuation of two department stores and scores of smaller shops.

title: RECITAL: COLORADO QUARTET
description: THE great composers have always learned from one another. Mozart's ''Dissonant'' Quartet, which opened the Colorado Quartet's Naumburg Award recital at Tully Hall Wednesday, is one of those dedicated to Haydn, and one of the things Mozart learned from Haydn was the drama of sudden silence.

Wainoco to Swap For Partnerships
description: The Wainoco Oil Corporation said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an exchange offer of its common stock and cash for all limited interests in three oil and gas partnerships. The three limited partnerships were sponsored by Wainoco from 1970 through 1972.

description: EDISTO. By Padgett Powell. 183 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $11.95. THE DEER AT THE RIVER. By Joseph Caldwell. 240 pages. Little, Brown. $15.95.

title: SOVIET SAID TO STEP UP AFGHAN DRIVE
description: The scope and tempo of the Soviet offensive in Afghanistan against insurgents in a key valley north of the capital have reportedly increased significantly in the last 24 hours.

title: INDAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
APATHY WIDESPREAD AS OHIO PRIMARY APPROACHES
description: The item on the ballot next Tuesday that has generated the most interest here does not involve the Democratic Presidential contest. It is a referendum on whether the city should issue $150 million in bonds to finance a domed stadium.

title: Binney & Smith Views Options
description: Binney & Smith Inc.

title: BASEBALL SETS UP DRUG PROGRAM
description: Baseball's player-owner drug committee, working quietly while current drug-related suspensions were being argued in spotlighted arbitration, has reached agreement on a program under which future cases will be handled.

title: 'PURPLE HEARTS,' SET IN VIETNAM
description: SELDOM has the long arm of coincidence received the workout that it gets in Sidney J. Furie's ''Purple Hearts,'' as it flings together Dr. Don Jardian and Nurse Deborah Solomon against the backdrop of war-torn Vietnam. The film begins with a dedication to the Vietnam War's 347,304 Purple- Heart recipients, though it also seems aimed at the nation's millions of soap- opera fans. Whenever the film's war scenes verge on becoming believable, which is often enough, the love story is allowed to take over.

title: DISPUTED MEETING ON U.S. BENEFITS IS CANCELED BY THE CENSUS BUREAU
description: The Census Bureau, under pressure from Democratic members of Congress, today canceled plans for a private meeting with eight economists who were to suggest new ways of measuring the value of noncash benefits such as food stamps, Medicaid and housing subsidies.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a realized investment gain of $5,190,000. c-Including a realized investment gain of $1,540,000.

TALES OF TRAVAIL ON THE WASHINGTON AIR SHUTTLE
description: A lawyer who is an experienced traveler between New York and Washington spends a lot of time cocooned in the silver jets of Eastern Airlines and the red ones of New York Air.

title: Circus Poster Sale
description: An exhibition and sale of American circus posters will be held Sunday at 1 P.M. at Phillips, Son & Neale, 79th Street east of Second Avenue. The sale will benefit the Circus World Museum of Baraboo, Wis., the town where the Ringling Brothers Circus began 100 years ago this month. The museum owns the 287 posters up for bidding, all of which are duplicates.

title: For the Grieving, and Other Consumers
description: After seven years of investigation and five of procedural delay, the Federal Trade Commission has finally put forward rules to protect grieving survivors against the hard-sell practices of the funeral industry. Thus the country gains standards similar to those already in effect in New York City.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a credit of $2,935,099 from an accounting change.

title: Olympic Flame To Arrive by Air
description: Greek officials have discarded plans to relay the Olympic Torch to the United States for the Los Angeles Games by telecommunications satellite after the traditional flame-kindling ceremony in the ruins of ancient Olympia Monday.

title: COSTA RICAN CIVIL GUARD TRADES FIRE WITH SANDINISTA SOLDIERS
description: Costa Rican security forces clashed with Nicaraguan troops today in fighting that spilled over onto the Costa Rican side of the border, the Government announced.

title: Gary Stindt, an Ex-Reporter, Is Dead at 64 in West Berlin
description: Gary Stindt, a longtime reporter for NBC News, died today at his home here, his wife reported. He was 64 years old.

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid May 18 and a 10 percent stock dividend to be paid June 25.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BRITTEN AND BRUCKNER
description: ZUBIN MEHTA'S elbow operation, which caused him to cancel the last weeks of his New York Philharmonic season, has brought a series of emergency guests to the Avery Fisher Hall podium. The latest of these helpful substitutes, Gunther Herbig, conducted a Britten and Bruckner program last night that allowed us to take his measure at least somewhat.

title: EXECUTIVE BONUSES DRAW UNION'S FIRE
description: The large bonuses paid to top automobile executives will make it more difficult to negotiate a new labor contract this fall without a strike, the head of the United Automobile Workers said today.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Argentina's foreign debt misstated the percentage effect on earnings that would have been reported by some banks for the first quarter of 1984 if they had declared their Argentine loans nonaccruing. The percentages by which the banks would have had to reduce their earnings were: Manufacturers Hanover, 23; J. P. Morgan, 8.4; Citicorp, 2.5; Bank of America, 4; Chemical Bank, 3.8; Bankers Trust, 1.3, and Bank of Boston, 3.6. The dollar figures in the article were correct.

title: MODERN PROBLEMS FOR AN OLD LIQUEUR
description: Behind the walls of the 900-year-old Monastery of La Grande Chartreuse high in the French Alps, a community of Carthusian monks guards one of the best-kept business secrets in the world: the formula for making Chartreuse.

title: THE MANNISH LOOK TAKES OVER
description: Not since the days of Courr eges and the miniskirt has an idea taken such a firm hold on the fashion world. The idea - for fall and winter - is men's clothes for women, and it looks like one whose time has come. It emerged full blown in the collection of Calvin Klein early in the week, and subsequent showings have proved how suitable it is for sportswear today.

title: Jury Indicts Georgian As 'Stocking Strangler'
description: A prison escapee who spent his boyhood here was indicted today for three of seven ''stocking strangler'' murders of elderly women that terrorized this city for eight months in 1977 and 1978.

title: Festival to Honor Basie; New June 30 Program
description: A Kool Jazz Festival program featuring Count Basie and his orchestra and scheduled for June 30 has been changed as a result of Mr. Basie's death last week.

title: STATE WITNESS TO TELL 'INSIDE STORY' IN '82 KILLINGS
description: A prosecutor told a jury in Manhattan yesterday that a diamond company owner had paid $2,000 to a gunman to kill his company's accountant and $5,000 more after ''complications'' caused the gunman to kill three CBS employees who tried to help the dying accountant.

title: HEARING OPENS ON DRUG TIED TO DEATHS OF BABIES
description: A physician from Spokane, Wash., said today that he warned the distributor of an intravenous vitamin E solution last January that the drug was thought to have contributed to the deaths of four babies in his city. But a hospital director from another city said that when he inquired about the vitamin two months later the company said there had been no reports of problems.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can see a strong coalition to reduce defense.'' - Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. (1:3.)

title: 6 Tourists Die in Mexico
description: A bus carrying a group of French tourists plunged into a ravine, reportedly killing six people and injuring 26, including the driver, the French Embassy said today.

title: Atlas Attracts Wesray Group
description: Wesray Resources Inc. has been holding discussions with the Atlas Corporation of Princeton, N.J., a uranium mining and manufacturing company, on acquiring or merging with Atlas, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Police Seek Giants End
description: The New Orleans police said they had issued a warrant for the arrest of Malcolm Scott , the Giants' tight end, after finding cocaine and marijuana in his motel room. They said the drugs had been discovered Wednesday night after the police were called by Scott's friend, Jerry Reese , who said he had been unable to get into the room and feared that an intruder was inside.

title: No Headline
description: Interfering in El Salvador El Salvador's Marxist guerrillas acquired a new if unlikely ally when Senator Jesse Helms complained about American interference in that nation's presidential election. Like the guerrillas, North Carolina's hard-shell conservative said President Reagan's Ambassador was ''guilty of unwarranted interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.''

title: OTHER VOICES
description: A column I wrote recently about Jesse Jackson prompted a great deal of mail from readers, some of which was instructive and worth sharing here. The column expressed support for the social themes sounded by Reverend Jackson but criticism for his ''Hymie'' references to Jews - arguing that one can believe in black aspirations while deploring the polarizing effect of such ethnic remarks.

description: Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today announced his intention to form a ''party unity task force'' to resolve disputes among the three Democratic Presidential candidates.

description: The Reagan Administration is confident that Jose Napoleon Duarte, the leader of El Salvador's Christian Democrats, will win the presidential runoff election Sunday and is planning to invite him to Washington later this month, State Department officials said today.

The Blitz has been for sale ever since Dr. James Hoffman , a Milwaukee heart surgeon, decided he had got in over his head when he bought the team from Dr. Ted Diethrich last September.

title: Nursing Home Worker Convicted of Killing 6
description: A jury today convicted Anthony Joyner, 22 years old, of raping and murdering six elderly women who lived at the nation's oldest nursing home.

title: Bid for Frantz
description: Snyder, McAlaine & Castle Capital Partnership told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was seeking to acquire the Frantz Manufacturing Company of Sterling, Ill., through a leveraged buyout. S.M.C., which holds 55,800 common shares, or 6.9 percent of Frantz's shares outstanding, said it had also asked Frantz management to consider transactions that would reduce the number of shares outstanding. Frantz rose $1.50, to $30.75, today on the New York Stock Exchange. It has 810,000 shares outstanding.

title: 250,000 NEW OPENINGS HOLD JOBLESSNESS AT 7.7%
description: The expanding economy created another quarter-million jobs last month while the average factory workweek rose to its highest level in nearly 20 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NORANDA MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss including an unusual gain of $22.4 million from the sale of an office building and a gain on the sale of shares by an affiliate. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: TOUCH OF GLAMOUR IN SATIN AND FURS
description: Sandwiched between the tweed and flannel men's-wear-inspired clothes that dominated the week's fall and winter fashion shows were some pockets of old-time glamour. It's the unabashed seductiveness of, say, the clothes in 1930's movies or 1950's French couture collections - updated, of course.

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: EXPERTS IN CONGRESS SEE MORE CUTS IN ARMS BUDGET REAGAN TRIMMED
description: Congressional experts on military matters generally said today that President Reagan's latest plan to trim the Pentagon budget did not go far enough. They predicted Congress would make additional cuts as it grappled with reducing the budget deficit in the months ahead.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Voters Give Mrs. Thatcher a Setback
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher suffered a sharp political reversal Thursday on the fifth anniversary of her move to 10 Downing Street. The Conservative party was turned out of office in several important cities and barely managed to hold onto two seats in the House of Commons that it has always won by hefty margins.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday, with an article on the Pentagon budget, misidentified the second man from the left. He was Vincent Puritano, comptroller of the Defense Department.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in January 1984.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * DMG Inc., a West Palm Beach, Fla., company involved in real estate finance and development, said it had decided to cancel its proposed tender offer for all shares of Aegis Corp., a Coral Gables, Fla., holding company, at $5.75 a share following Minstar Inc.'s decision to increase its offer to $6 a share.

title: HILTON PACT AIDS SUSPECT UNION FUND
description: The two Hilton hotels here agreed Thursday night, in a contract accord marking the first major break in a 32-day strike of resorts here, to double their contributions to a nearly insolvent union welfare fund that a Senate subcommittee is investigating for a suspected diversion of money to organized crime figures.

title: Kuhn Accepts Decision
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has decided to take no additional action against Pascual Perez , the Atlanta pitcher whose suspension for a cocaine-possession conviction in the Dominican Republic was overturned last week by Richard Bloch , baseball's arbitrator. Kuhn, upset over Bloch's decision, had threatened further action based on what he said was Perez's obstruction of his investigation. But yesterday Kuhn said that Bloch's full decision ''has now precluded even that course.''

title: NEW YORK CITY JOBLESS RATE, AT 7.7% IS LOWEST IN 4 YEARS
description: New York City's unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent last month, the lowest since December 1980, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The rate was 8.4 percent in March and 9.2 percent in April 1983.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIR AGE ENCOUNTERS
description: The annals of great airport meetings were enriched Tuesday when President Reagan and Pope John Paul II met for slightly less than half an hour at the airport in Fairbanks, Alaska. The Holy Father was headed for South Korea and the President was coming home from China, and they took the opportunity to discuss Asia, arms control, East-West relations, Poland, the Middle East and Central America.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS U.S. DECISION TO PULL OUT OF UNESCO
description: The Soviet Union's representative to Unesco today sharply criticized the United States' decision to leave the organization, saying it reflected a deliberate attempt to undermine the organizations of the United Nations.

title: PORTRAITS OF NEIGHBORHOODS IN CITY
description: WNYC Cable, New York City's own cable television service, will begin a four-part mini-series tonight called ''Neighborhood Voices,'' a portrait of four communities in the city that share, in the station's words, ''common geography, ethnicity, culture, history, work or aspiration.'' This is the first in-house production by WNYC Cable filmed on location.

title: U.S. ROLE IN SALVADOR
description: The accusation made by Senator Jesse Helms that United States Embassy officials have manipulated the presidential election campaign here in favor of the Christian Democratic candidate has focused new attention on United States activities in El Salvador, particularly in advance of the election runoff Sunday. The charge, in a letter from the North Carolina Republican to President Reagan, was denied by both the embassy and the White House.

title: PRICES REGISTER SHARP DECLINE
description: Prices fell sharply in the credit markets yesterday, as traders reacted negatively to reports indicating that economic growth remained strong in April. Trading was very light.

title: Raytheon Unit
description: The Raytheon Company said its Raytheon Canada Ltd. subsidiary had received a $390 million (Canadian) contract from the Canadian federal Department of Supply and Services to modernize the air-traffic control radar system. Deliveries are to start in 1988 and completion is scheduled for 1992.

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Three weeks ago, Hal Sutton missed the cut by one shot at the Masters tournament and left Augusta, Ga., that night unhappy with the way his game was going this year.

description: Most everyone is familiar with the story of John Z. DeLorean, the maverick auto maker on trial in Los Angeles on charges of drug trafficking.

title: U.S. Industries Backs Hanson Bid
description: U.S. Industries said its directors had recommended that holders tender their shares to a unit of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London. Hanson is offering $23 a share, or a total of $511 million, for the maker of industrial products, apparel, furniture and furnishings and lighting products.

description: b-Operating earnings c-After realized losses from investments of $775,000. d-Net income after realized losses from investments of $1,092,000.

title: MUSICAL: POP ROCK 'LOVE'
description: ''All my life I've been waiting for a prince; I didn't expect him to ride in on a tractor,'' protests Dolores, a fortyish, divorced nightclub singer, to her much younger boyfriend, James, after he proposes marriage. James has only just arrived in Manhattan from a farm in Arkansas. They meet in the same bar where Alex, who's sexually ambivalent, falls for Frances. In the same watering hole, Harvey, a struggling actor, and Jo- Ann, a wisecracking young widow, pick each other up and begin an uneasy affair. Watching from the sidelines is David, the bar's homosexual pianist, who dates a Puerto Rican drummer named Rosario while pining after Alex.

TIMES SQ. PLAN IS DIVIDING PEOPLE IN ADJACENT CLINTON
description: Back when Fiorello H. La Guardia was Mayor and the United States had not yet entered World War II, Isaac Wolf took his son Stephen outside the family paint store on Ninth Avenue to witness what he thought was a marvelous sight. Workmen were demolishing the avenue's elevated train line, and the humble rows of five-story tenements across the street were emerging in full view for the first time.

title: 'BE MY BABY'
description: Her husband at her side, a woman

title: DOW DROPS SHARPLY: VOLUME UP
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in accelerated trading after two leading economists predicted that interest rates would continue to rise this year and next.

title: NEW PROVINCIAL CARRIERS TO CHALLENGE CHINA'S STATE AIRLINE
description: The Civil Aviation Administration of China, which runs China's state airline, will face unprecedented domestic competition from new provincial airlines that want to improve on C.A.A.C.'s notoriously poor service and management.

title: GEARHART'S BOARD REGECTS SMITH BID
description: Gearhart Industries said today that its board had decided that Smith International Inc.'s $31-a-share tender offer for up to 3.7 million Gearhart shares was inadequate.

title: 'GOTHAM,' A BURG FOR WASHINGTON IRVING, KING JOHN AND BATMAN
description: The Manhattan telephone directory lists at least 81 businesses using the word ''Gotham'' in their titles. For decades, Variety has used it as the showbiz monicker for the Apple. And the legendary Batman and Robin dynamically duoed in a burg of the same name.

title: MEESE FRIEND IN U.S. POST FACING GRAND JURY
description: The chairman of the Merit System Protection Board, a friend of Edwin Meese 3d since law school, will be questioned next week by a Federal grand jury, a board spokesman, Mahlon Anderson, said today.

title: METS DOWN ASTROS
description: For two months, the Mets' management has been hoping for that extra special outing from Ron Darling that would at once solidify the starting pitching staff and justify all of its preseason predictions for greatness.

title: VICE CHAIRMAN OF FED IS CRITICAL OF TIGHT REIN
description: Preston Martin, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve System, took strong exception today to policies of his colleagues, including the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that assume that the pace of the economy's growth could reignite inflation.

title: YONKERS IS WARNED ON U.S. FUNDS
description: Federal officials warned Yonkers today that it would lose millions of dollars in development grants if it failed to submit a satisfactory list of sites for at least 140 units of low-income housing. The order stems from the settlement last March of part of a desegregation suit against the city.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
RIVAL GETS MILTON BRADLEY
description: Hasbro Industries, a toy maker based in Pawtucket, R.I., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Milton Bradley Company, a rival maker of toys and games, in a two-step transaction valued at about $350 million.

title: MAVERICKS BEAT LAKERS
description: Rolando Blackman and Brad Davis combined for 49 points tonight to give the Dallas Mavericks a 125-115 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: JAEGER OF CANADA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Meadowlands Exacta Brings an Inquiry;  Betting Is Examined
description: Authorities today began investigating the eighth race Thursday night at the Meadowlands race track after a 30-to-1 shot and a 20-to-1 shot finished first and second but returned a relatively modest $2 exacta payoff of $255.40.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 month losses include $8.8 million nonrecurring writedown of certain helicopter facilities and unconsolidated aviation subsidiaries.

Winning Is Fun
description: Keith Hernandez's career has been studded with accolades and accomplishments - a batting title, a most valuable player award and all-star and World Series appearances with St. Louis - yet he said without hesitation this week that the Mets' heady play in the first month of the season is ''the most fun I've had in my life.''

title: MARSH'S ENDURING STRATEGY
description: Around the turn of the century, Donald R. McLennan, one of the founders of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance brokerage concern, spent 30 days and nights riding the routes of two railroads so he could offer better advice on managing railroad risk and on the insurance coverage that might be useful.

title: MID PACIFIC AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fifth Alien Hit by Train Dies
description: Douglas Guerrero, a 7-year-old Salvadoran, has become the fifth person to die after a freight train plowed through a group of about 40 illegal aliens last Saturday, officials said Thursday. The aliens had been crossing or sleeping on a narrow, 450-foot trestle over Olmos Creek when a Missouri Pacific freight train bore down on them.

title: Letter: On Student Aid Don't Single Out Poor College Men To the Editor:
description: I couldn't agree less with your May 3 editorial ''Uncle Sam's Campus Bargain,'' on the defensibility of the Solomon amendment, the section of law that denies Federal aid to college students who cannot certify that they have registered for the draft.

title: FOR DERBY WEEK, CELEBRATING IS A CIVIC DUTY ;
description: Only the purest of the purists are grumbling here this week, disappointed that the 20 horses who will run in the 110th Kentucky Derby Saturday may be a substandard and uninspiring bunch.

title: DIANA DORS, ACTRESS IN BRITAIN
description: Diana Dors, the actress who was once described as Britain's answer to Marilyn Monroe, died of cancer today at Princess Margaret Hospital. She was 52 years old.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  2 Choose N.B.A. Draft
description: Tommy Sangodeyi , a 27-year-old center for Sam Houston State University, and Cory Blackwell , a Wisconsin forward, said they would pass up their senior years to join the National Basketball Association draft. Keith Lee , the Memphis State forward who had been considering entering the draft, said he had decided to stay in school. ''I would like to play pro ball,'' he said, ''but if I have a degree I can coach.''

title: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $515,000. c-Net loss.

title: SEASON DISRUPTED FOR GLOBE THEATER
description: WHEN Stuart Vaughan, the producing director of the itinerant New Globe Theater Company, and Marvin Ravikoff, the owner of a contracting concern that purchased the old Capitol Theater in Port Chester, came to what seemed to be a meeting of the minds last summer, great expectations arose for a new, much- needed resident legitimate theater in the county.

Man Freed as Innocent 2 Years After Conviction
description: Ernest Holbrook, imprisoned more than two years for a murder he said he did not commit, hugged and kissed his two sisters and then walked away today from the Lima State Correctional Institute.

title: PURCHASERS SEE STRONG ECONOMY
description: The economy staged a ''dramatic'' advance last month, with employment and inventories posting their best gains in six years and new orders and production registering their best performance in some categories in more than 30 years, according to the April survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Occidental to Seek Oil in Ecuador
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has been given a concession to explore 454,000 acres in northeast Ecuador, the Government said.

title: HART PINS HOPES ON COMPUTER IN TEXAS
description: Here in Texas, land of traditional ways and tall invention, the battle for the state's large block of Democratic Presidential delegates has become a test of old politics versus new, of the personal touch versus high technology.

title: LOUISANA VOTER APATHY SEEN AS AIDING JACKSON
description: Louisiana holds a Presidential primary on Saturday that some Democrats view more as an act of legal obedience than a political exercise.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LIFE IN EAST CLEVELAND: A 1950'S MIGRANT FAMILY CONSIDERS A NEW MOVE
description: Mamie Delaney Williams, matriarch of the Northern branch of her family, was treated to a surprise party for her 70th birthday. Three generations were present, most of them having moved to Cleveland from Montgomery, Ala., in the early 1950's, a small part of a great wave of black migration.

title: No Headline
description: Strings on F.B.I. Stings Beneath the bicker of their majority and dissenting reports, Democrats and Republicans on the House Civil Rights subcommittee reach an important consensus about Government ''sting'' enterprises: They can be useful tools in fighting crime but need much closer supervision.

title: WALLACE RUNNING MATE IN '48
description: Former Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho, a onetime country-Western singer who bolted the Democratic Party in 1948 to run as the Vice-Presidential candidate on Henry A. Wallace's Progressive Party ticket, died last Saturday of Alzheimer's disease at a nursing home in Burlingame, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Millbrae, Calif.

title: PASQUALE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: The 1983 share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: On the Record ; Jesse Jackson on Winning
description: From an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson by The Associated Press, distributed Wednesday, on the meaning of winning in 1984:

title: TOMORROW'S PLAYWRIGHTS TODAY
description: In one of the plays at the Young Playwrights Festival - which opened Tuesday in the Public Theater - a teen-ager is asked to describe his town. ''It's like anywhere,'' he says. ''The kids play baseball, Pac-Man, work at McDonald's, save up and buy a car, then drive it in and out of the driveway.''

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Organizers, City Differ on Taxes

title: 3-TIME PRESIDENT RUNS IN PANAMA
description: Arnulfo Arias Madrid, who has been elected President of Panama three times and been overthrown by the military three times, is seeking to cap an extraordinary political career by winning the presidency again in the national election Sunday. He is 83 years old.

THE YANK FACTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: TIGERS (20-4) WIN AFTER 2-GAME SLIDE
description: Howard Johnson hit a homer and Lou Whitaker had four hits as the Detroit Tigers, after losing two straight for the first time this season, trounced the Cleveland Indians, 9-2, tonight.

title: KENNEDY AUTOPSY: BALANCE OF RIGHTS
description: A Florida judge's ruling Thursday barring the release of any information about the death of David A. Kennedy has focused attention on autopsies, the medical procedures that have been done for centuries to determine causes of death. Judge R. William Rutter of Florida's 15th Circuit declined to allow release of the results of Mr. Kennedy's autopsy because he said they might impede a police investigation into the death of the 28-year-old son of Robert F. Kennedy. Judge Rutter said he was ruling in favor of ''the public's right to be protected'' over ''the public's right to know.''

title: Florida Officials Praise Toxic Waste Collection
description: Residents of Dade County hauled in enough old paint, arsenic and automobile oil to poison the drinking water of a sizable city in just three days of a toxic waste roundup, officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: Office Politics and the Senate Senator James Exon of Nebraska thinks office equipment dealers are being pushed around by their suppliers, and that the Federal Government should do something about it.

title: SEABROOK UTILITY IN GAIN The Public Service Company
description: of New Hampshire, the beleaguered utility that is heading

title: Hart Stumps in Midwest As Texas Appears Lost
description: As his opponents continued their efforts in the steamy spring heat of Texas, Senator Gary Hart campaigned throughout the rainy Middle West today, asserting that he remained within striking distance of Walter F. Mondale in Tuesday's critical political tests.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'LUCKY' WINS KENTUCKY OAKS
description: Lucky Lucky Lucky led every step of the way under Angel Cordero Jr. and held off a late bid from Miss Oceana to win the Kentucky Oaks by a nose today at Churchill Downs. My Darling One, the 4-to-5 favorite, was half a length back in third in the field of six 3-year-old fillies. The winner was timed in 1:51 4/5 for the mile and an eighth.

title: Bulky Field Clouds Outlook for Derby
description: After months of plotting and prepping, it is time to run the 110th Kentucky Derby Saturday, but few handlers are confident about their horses and few handicappers have strong opinions about the race.

title: THE EFFECTS OF GOING PUBLIC ON SEXUAL ABUSE
description: Eugene Hawkins was flying home to Florida from a business trip when he read in a newspaper that his wife, Senator Paula Hawkins, had told a Senate hearing that she had been sexually abused by a neighbor when she was a child. It was the first he had heard of the incident.

title: FORUM SPEAKERS STRESS A NEED FOR RACIAL PEACE
description: Raymond L. Flynn, who was elected Mayor of Boston on a platform that made racial peace a priority, and Basil A. Paterson, who said he would decide this summer whether to seek the New York mayoralty in a similar campaign next year, agreed yesterday that harmony in both cities could be achieved by improving social conditions.

title: Woolworth Stock Rises Further
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said it knew of no reason why its stock has risen more than $5 a share this week, adding, ''We do not know of any takeover attempts.'' Joseph Carroll, vice president for public relations, said, ''We have heard rumors about other companies taking investment positions in our stock but no one has yet filed any notifications with the Securities and Exchange Commission that they have acquired 5 percent or more.''

title: KNICKS DEFEATED CELTIC'S, TRAIL IN SERIES BY 2 TO 1
description: The Knicks took away the Celtics' running game, and behind an outstanding effort by Ray Williams, defeated Boston, 100-92, last night before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Rep. Ferraro Is Choice Of O'Neill for No. 2 Spot
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. says Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, Democrat of Queens, is his choice as the Vice-Presidential nominee on the Democratic Party's ticket.

title: NEBRASKA OFFICIAL CLEARED BY COURT
description: Attorney General Paul L. Douglas of Nebraska, impeached by the State Legislature on March 14 for misconduct, was acquitted of the legislative charges today by a divided seven-judge State Supreme Court.

title: General Interest
description: Fourteen players selected but not signed by the Generals were chosen in the National Football League draft earlier this week.

title: WESTERN CASUALTY & SURETY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income.

title: Al Hirschfeld To Get Award
description: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, will receive the first Brooks Atkinson Award from the League of New York Theaters and Producers and the American Theater Wing. The award will be presented during the Tony Awards ceremony June 3 at the Gershwin Theater.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the office of Hoffman York & Compton that has been closed. It was the Minneapolis office.

title: THE REGION ; DERAILMENT BLOCKS SERVICE IN JERSEY
description: Three people were overcome by fumes and commuter service on the North Jersey Coast Line was interrupted today by the derailment of four railroad cars, one of which leaked a highly flammable substance, authorities said.

title: VON BULOW LEAVES HOSPITAL
description: Claus von B"ulow left a Manhattan hospital yesterday with his doctor's assurances that three recent blackouts he had experienced were not the result of a heart attack or serious neurological problems.
