SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 18.

title: PIANO: WORKS BY NIETZSCHE
description: When a major figure in one field turns his hand to amateur efforts in another, the results can be memorable, as the drawings of William Blake, the autobiography of Benvenuto Cellini, or the caricatures of Enrico Caruso attest. Comparable achievement, unfortunately, cannot be claimed for the German philospher Friedrich Nietzsche, whose piano music was offered by Utaco Knowles in a recital Thursday evening at the Puck Building.

title: CHINESE IMMIGRANT EMERGES AS BOSTON'S TOP BENEFACTOR
description: The way Lorraine Wang recalls it, one day a friend approached her and her husband, An Wang, the chairman of Wang Laboratories, and mentioned that the roof was literally falling in at Boston's main performing arts center.

title: WEST SIDE SOFA BED A LURE FOR OUT-OF-TOWNERS
description: In New York, out-of-town guests are a problem that will not go away. Those people snoring on the sofa bed when New Yorkers go to work and picking the refrigerator shelves clean when they come home are part of the price one pays for living in a city of big buildings and Broadway, break- dancing and Bloomingdale's.

title: CITY PLAN TO BURN GARBAGE IS FLAWED
description: Although fatally flawed, the Sanitation Department's ambitious plan to build eight garbage-burning incinerators is a good starting point for debate about how New York should dispose of its garbage in the future. The course ultimately selected could have far-reaching consequences not only for the city, but for communities across the nation that will be facing similar garbage disposal problems in the future.

title: PAMOUR PORCUPINE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Of Heaters And Relief In Spring
description: Spring brings special relief to several thousand state employees who work at the 22-story State Capitol in Tallahassee. They can stop hiding their electirc space heaters and take them home until next winter.

title:
PATENTS;
LIQUID MEASUREMENT
description: Vladimir Horak, head of a consulting concern in Closter, N.J., that specializes in automated systems of liquid measurement for industry, was granted patent 4,445,627 this week on a method of making the measurement by weight. As the volume being recorded changes with the density of the liquid under temperature variations, the apparatus adjusts the metering tank size accordingly.

title: German Jobless Decline
description: West Germany's unemployment rate fell to 9.1 percent in April, from 9.6 percent in March, and 9.2 percent a year earlier, the Federal Labor Office said today. There were 2.253 million unemployed workers in April, the labor office said.

title: SEAGRAM TO CLOSE GOLD SEAL WINERY
description: Joseph E. Seagram and Sons will close its 120-year-old Gold Seal winery here but will make Gold Seal wines at the nearby Taylor Wine Company, the company said today.

title: U.S. Will Not Prosecute Farrakhan for Remarks
description: There is insufficient evidence to prosecute Louis Farrakhan for his reported threats on the life of a black reporter who disclosed ethnic remarks made by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a Federal attorney said today.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Companies
description: Esmark agreed to a $2.4 billion management takeover by Kohlberg, Kravis, a New York investment house, after months of behind-the-scenes talks. Donald P. Kelly, chairman of the big Chicago conglomerate, would remain in command. The deal, if completed, would become the biggest such buyout in history. (Page 1.) Regulators closed four banks, two in Wyoming, one in Texas and one in Minnesota. The banks were taken over by other institutions with the financial support of the F.D.I.C. The action brought to 25 the number of banks that have failed this year. (31.)

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Recall Issued by Nissan
description: Possibly faulty master brake cylinders have caused the Nissan Motor Corporation in U.S.A. to recall 11,909 early-1984 model 300ZX cars, the company has announced. The brake cylinders may include improperly installed valve clips, which could slip and result in a loss of brake fluid. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in Washington was notified of the action Wednesday, Nissan said.

POPE'S KOREAN MESSAGE: RECONCILIATION
description: Pope John Paul II preached a sermon of reconciliation today in this city in which the Government crushed a student uprising four years ago.

Modern-Dance Groups To Perform in Series
description: Four modern-dance companies will be featured in ''Breaking Even,'' a dance series scheduled at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street, from Friday through June 3.

title: PENTAGON BARS U,S, NEWS GROUPS
description: The Pentagon today denied two United States news organizations permission to cover military maneuvers in the Gulf of Fonseca, United States officials and news agencies here said.

title: NORTHWEST-TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kodak Venture
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had joined 15 other American companies in a research venture on semiconductor packaging, software technology, computer-aided design and advanced computer architecture. The venture, the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex., was founded last year. Other members include the Control Data Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation, Honeywell Inc. and the RCA Corporation.

title: JUDGE TO RETIRE, ENDING MOVE TO IMPEACH HIM
description: James H. Kinsella, the Hartford Probate Court judge, retired today, effective May 31, and a sharply divided State House of Representatives voted not to proceed with his impeachment.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TASS SAYS SAKHAROV WIFE SOUGHT U.S. HAVEN
description: The official Soviet press agency said today that ''timely measures'' by Soviet authorities had foiled an operation planned in part by American diplomats to give refuge to the wife of the exiled dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: IN HONOR OR HUMPHREY
description: For years, Marvin Rosenberg, a hosiery manufacturer, was known to politicians as ''Hubert Humphrey's man in New York.'' Mr. Rosenberg, who raised funds for Mr. Humphrey and dealt with New York politicians on his behalf, has donated $100,000 to set up a public-affairs program at City College to commemorate Mr. Humphrey.

title: STOP IMPORTED HEROIN
description: The plague of heroin addiction is one of the most disturbing problems in our country. The number of heroin-related hospital emergencies has risen for the third year in a row, and law enforcement officials have reported that levels of heroin addiction have a direct correlation with crime rates.

title: ROBERT SCRIVNER, DIRECTOR OF FUND
description: Robert W. Scrivner, the director of the Rockefeller Family Fund, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Cos Cob, Conn. He was 48 years old.

title: 'GOO-GOOS' FOR STEING
description: When Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, announces next week for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in what politicians call the ''Silk Stocking'' Congressional District, on the East Side, he will have a citizens' committee crammed with what politicians call ''goo-goos,'' officials of good-government groups.

title: DOME CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOLL OF THE INFANTS FROM VITAMIN USE
description: Following is the Food and Drug Administration's list of deaths and illnesses from adverse reactions among infants to E-Ferol Aqueous Solution. It was compiled on April 23, before a total of 38 deaths was counted by the F.D.A., and also includes some deaths later found not directly related.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M.. (Television - Channel 9, 730 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. Both starters, Ron Guidry of the Yankees and Moose Haas of the Brewers, have lost 2 out of their 3 decisions. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 8:30 P.M.).

title: Comings and Goings
description: Todd Jamison , the St. John's University quarterback who was named to The Associated Press Little All- America team after completing 128 of 238 passes for 1,631 yards and 18 touchdowns last season, has signed a two-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles, according to his agent, Richard Glazer , who said the 5-foot-9 inch Jamison would be used as a kick and punt return specialist. . . . Danny White , the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback who was accused of punching a high school student in a traffic dispute in February, will be tried June 18, his lawyer said. . . . Bo Diaz , the Philadelphia Phillies' catcher, underwent surgery on his left knee and will be out from three to five weeks. . . Richard M. Perry has resigned as athletic director of the University of Southern California to make room, he said, for ''a new leader with a fresh perspective.'' Perry had been under criticism because of the school's lagging athletic fortunes, and a special committee named to study the department last fall submitted its report earlier this week. Olaf Blab , the 7-footer from West Germany, has signed a letter of intent to attend Illinois, meaning that next season he will oppose his older brother, Uwe Blab of Indiana, on the basketball court.

title: RANCHERS EXPLORATION & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Queen to Visit Horse Country
description: As part of a weeklong visit to the United States in October, Queen Elizabeth II will spend three or four days in the thoroughbred-racing territory around Lexington, Ky. One of the farms that she will visit is the Darby Dan, owned by John W. Galbreath, who is also the chairman of the board of the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: ANNIE LAURIE AITKEN
description: Annie Laurie Aitken, an amateur sculptor whose son-in-law, Claus von B"ulow, was convicted of attempting to murder her daughter, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 83 years old and lived in New York and Newport, R.I.

PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are adjusted for a 4-for-1 stock dividend paid Jan. 10.

title: 77 IN BRIDGEPORT WIN $5 MILLION IN BIAS LAWSUIT
description: This city will pay $5.1 million in back wages to 77 black and Hispanic firefighters in a settlement of a discrimination suit filed nearly a decade ago.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about General Motors' acquisition of a stake in Teknowledge Inc. misstated the acquisition date. It was April 9.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $613,000 for the latest quarter and $135,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Vagaries of Fame
description: Winning a gold medal in the giant slalom at the Winter Olympics was a heady experience for Debbie Armstrong , maybe too heady. When she returned to World Cup competition, the best the 20-year-old skier could manage was a ninth-place finish, and that poor showing, she says, was a direct result of the hullabaloo following her Olympic victory.

title: TIPS LED TO ARREST IN EAST SIDE RAPES
description: A police artist's sketch and tips from residents of a city housing project helped lead to the arrest of a suspect in the rape and murder of an elderly woman and the rapes of nine others, the police said yesterday.

title: China Cites Output Rise
description: China said today that heavy industry output grew 12 percent in the first quarter, and light industry rose 11.9 percent, even though energy shortages, transportation delays and waste plagued many factories. Xu Gang, deputy director of the State Statistical Bureau, said the value of the output of heavy and light industry each totaled $36.4 billion. Balanced development between light and heavy industry ''is very rare in recent years,'' he said.

title: SEOUL SAYS NORTH KOREANS SOUGHT U.S. TALKS DURING REAGAN'S TRIP
description: South Korean officials said today that North Korea called for secret talks with the United States during President Reagan's recent visit to Peking, using China as an intermediary to convey the proposal. American officials said the proposal was rejected.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $782,200 and an extraordinary charge of $1,399,039. c-Including a tax credit of $29,450.

title: PATENTS ; Security Setup Detects Intruder, Fire or Smoke
description: Ronald E. Pyle of Austin, Tex., has patented a home security system intended to offer protection against intrusion, fire and smoke.

title: Bridge: Dallas Team Takes the Lead In the Playoffs at Memphis
description: A team of Dallas experts forged ahead here this afternoon in the semifinal stage of the playoffs that will determine the 1984 United States team for the world championships in Seattle.

title: German Metalworkers Approve a Strike
description: West German metalworkers voted today to approve a strike in their battle to win a 35-hour workweek.

title: Mrs. Peron Plans Return To Argentina in May
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron, who has spent the last three years in exile in Spain, will return home to lead the opposition Peronist party, her spokesman says.

title: Sessions on New Operas
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will start a new series of introductory sessions about new operas Sunday at 6:30 P.M., and to be repeated Monday at 8 P.M. The first program will be devoted to Philip Glass's opera ''Akhnaten,'' which received its first performance March 24 in Stuttgart, West Germany, and will be presented at the New York City Opera in November.

title: STAGE: ENSEMBLE STUDIO'S MARATHON '84
description: The opening round of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '84, four evenings of one-act plays, ends on a crescendo with Jane Willis's ''Slam!'' This is a pungent urban dialogue, tautly directed by Shirley Kaplan and acted with vitality and humor by Rob Morrow and Evan Handler. That it comes after three formulaic one-acts makes it seem all the more impressive.

title: Woman Found Slain in Utah
description: The nude body of an 18-year-old woman believed to be a victim of a dead rape- murder suspect, Christopher Wilder, has been found in southern Utah, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. The body of Sheryl Bonaventura of Grand Junction, Colo., was found along a road 12 miles north of Kanab, Utah. The authorities said she had been stabbed to death. Mr. Wilder was reportedly seen with a woman leaving a motel in Page, Ariz., about 55 miles southeast of Kanab.

description: Kenneth MacMillan's plotless ballet ''Concerto'' made its first appearance of the season with the American Ballet Theater Thursday night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: F.D.I.C. AIDS TAKEOVERS OF 4 BANKS
description: In a major rescue operation, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tonight arranged the takeovers for four failed banks, two in Wyoming, one in Minnesota and one in Texas. The F.D.I.C. is a Government agency that insures individual deposit accounts for up to $100,000 at most of the nation's banks.

title: 14 CHOATE STUDENTS EXPELLED IN INQUIRY INTO COCAINE ARREST
description: Fourteen students have been expelled from the Choate Rosemary Hall School following the arrest of one of them on charges of trying to smuggle $300,000 worth of cocaine into the country, school officials said yesterday.

title: Holly-Internorth
description: The Holly Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell the oil and gas properties of its Holly Energy Inc. subsidiary to an Internorth Inc. unit for $53 million. Holly, through its subsidiary, the Navajo Refining Company, will continue to be engaged in petroleum refining, its main business. Internorth is based in Omaha.

title: JOHN D. ENTENZA
description: John D. Entenza, editor and publisher of Arts and Architecture magazine from 1940 to 1960, died of cancer in La Jolla, Calif., on April 27.

title: ESMARK APPROVES $2.4 BILLION OFFER
description: Esmark Inc., the big Chicago conglomerate, said yesterday that after months of behind-the-scenes talks, it had agreed to a $2.4 billion takeover by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a leading New York investment house.

title: Homecoming For Cosmos
description: May 4 - Former Cosmos stars such as Pele, Franz Beckenbauer and Carlos Alberto will perform here Saturday when the alumni of the Cosmos meet the present team to open their 1984 outdoor season. ''The game is still very young here, but the roots have been planted and it's here to stay,'' said Werner Roth, a member of the 1972 team that captured the Cosmos' first title and the captain in the championship years of 1977 and 1978.

U.S. IS SPEEDING UP AID TO COSTA RICA
description: United States officials said today that shipments of military aid to Costa Rica would be speeded up to help that country's security forces deal with what Washington called border incursions by Nicaragua.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 5, 1984 International
description: The election of Jose Napoleon Duarte, the leader of El Salvador's Christian Democrats, in the runoff presidential election Sunday is expected by the Reagan Administration, State Department officials said. Plans based on that assumption are being made to invite Mr. Duarte to Washington later this month, the officials said, as part of a renewed effort to obtain additional funds for El Salvador from Congress. (Page 1, Column 1.) Poland signed an economic pact with the Soviet Union that appears to offer renewed Soviet assistance to the faltering Polish economy. The 15-year accord was signed by the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, and Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. No details were made public, but the indications were that the pact would bind Poland more tightly to the Soviet economic bloc. (1:2.)

title: Libel Verdict Reversed For Greek Publisher
description: A three- judge court today canceled the libel convictions of the publisher and editor of Greece's top-selling daily newspaper, Ethnos, in a case involving a dispute with the author of a book, a court spokesman reported.

title: Atom Plant Defended
description: Officials of the Consumers Power Company today defended the utility's plans for completing its Midland nuclear power plant, telling staff members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that its schedule is credible.

description: ''Alphabet City,'' which opened yesterday at the Manhattan 1 and other theaters in and around the city, is one of those exercises in romantic film making that owe more to the history of cinema than to the reality of the milieu that is their subject.

title: GLADIATOR SANDALS
description: If shoe designers have their way this summer, women's feet will look as though they are dressed for a revival of ''Ben Hur.'' Sandals, of course, reappear each year with the first daffodils and women welcome their airiness. Since sandals are essentially arrangements of straps, designers are constantly challenged to take a few strips of leather and make them into something new.

description: Only a few days after President Reagan's departure after a six-day visit, China has turned its attention to its northern Communist neighbors.

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: RENEWING THE PAST For those who lament that New York isn't what it used to be, whenever that was, a trip to Staten Island's Richmondtown Restoration is prescribed. Here, in island center, at 441 Clarke Avenue, near Richmond Road and just west of La Tourette Park, are 26 buildings preserved on 96 acres of almost pristine country. These structures were built between the late 1600's and the early 1900's and have been collected here as a sort of panorama of the past.

description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company, buoyed by donations from corporations and individuals, will be able to open ''Henry V'' on schedule Friday at the Shakespeare Center, 165 West 86th Street.

title: New Lives for Old Commercial Spaces
description: Vacant land suitable for commercial development has become so scarce in prime areas of Nassau and western Suffolk Counties that developers and businesses are increasingly renovating buildings rather than building new ones.

title: Amy D. Katz of ABC Weds Bradley Bilgore
description: Amy Deborah Katz, an associate producer at ABC News, and Bradley Allan Bilgore, a stockbroker at Prudential-Bache Securities, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin H. Katz, in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony.

title: SUIT IN BRIDGE FALL SETTLEMENT
description: -The sole survivor among 36 people who plunged 150 feet into Tampa Bay when part of the Sunshine Skyway collapsed four years ago has settled a lawsuit against owners of the ship that struck the bridge. The survivor, Wesley C. MacIntire, 58 years old, a Gulfport truck driver, is to receive $175,000 from the owners of the ship, the Summit Venture.

title: Catherine White Wed in Princeton
description: Catherine No"el White, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph White Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Oscar Ernest Mertz 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mertz Jr. of Philadelphia, were married yesterday. The Rev. Daphne W. P. Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: A Master Colorist in a 'Disinterested Search for Perfection'
description: AS a student of Josef Albers at Yale University in the 1950's, Richard Anuszkiewicz was deeply influenced by the master's idea about the role and function of color. Albers's tireless experiments produced an art devoid of gesture, simple in composition, aimed at communicating ''an exciting discrepancy between the physical fact and psychic effect of color.'' This goal is shared by Mr. Anuszkiewicz, whose work of the last decade is surveyed in an elegant and handsomely installed exhibition at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington.

title: STORM EXPERTS STRUGGLE TO WATCH BIRTH OF TORNADO
description: With more than 100 lives lost so far this year in tornadoes, an ambitious effort to understand how such storms get started is under way. A new airborne radar, ground radar and a device placed in the path of an approaching twister are being used in the project.

title: OFFSTAGE IN KOREA: ANGER OF STUDENTS
description: A question that perhaps drew more curiosity here than almost any other in the last few days was whether Pope John Paul II caught a whiff of tear gas fired by the police at students demonstrating near a seminary where he was celebrating mass.

title: A BIRTHDAY TRIBUTE
description: Looking back more than half a century to the period in which contract bridge gradually displaced its auction predecessor in the public favor, it is now obvious that the established players were unable to adapt to the fresh nuances of the game, try as they might. The new game was immediately dominated by a bunch of young men who were not only brilliant but destined to have long and highly successful playing careers.

title: TV PLAYS THE HISS CASE DOWN THE MIDDLE
description: BOSTON A tall, slender, elegantly dressed Alger Hiss is confronting an ambitious young Congressman from California, Richard M. Nixon. The time is 1948, the place the House Un- American Activities Committee.

title: Single-Parent Homes On Increase in Japan
description: The number of single-parent families in Japan has increased sharply in the last five years, mainly because of the rising divorce rate, according to a report issued today on Children's Day, a national holiday.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Whistle-Blower Vindicated Government bureaucrats, who often accept as a truism that no good deed goes unpunished, can take heart. Irwin Levin is off the hook, thanks to Edward Koch's exercise of Mayoral prerogative. Mr. Levin is a New York City social worker who sought for years to correct the mishandling of child abuse cases.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Sunday on the York Festival in England, some copies of the Travel section included an incorrect telephone number for the festival's box office. The number is York 25536.

title: WINNING'S NOT EASIER THE 2D TIME AROUND
description: UP on the moon, Neil Armstrong and the Eagle had landed. On a farm in Bethel, N.Y., 400,000 people turned the Woodstock Arts and Music Festival into an American happening. HBO and I.R.A.'s were ideas. It was 1969, the year that the Boston Celtics became the last team to win back-to-back National Basketball Association championships.

title: COURTER'S AUDIENCE GROWING By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Representative James A. Courter, Republican of Hackettstown, called a news conference on April 5 to criticize the combat performance of United States troops in Grenada, newspaper reporters and television crews showed up, despite Mr. Courter's lack of traditional foreign policy or defense credentials.

title: U.S. ANTICIPATES DUARTE VICTORY IN EL SALVADOR TODAY
description: awaited presidential election today, and in the final days of the campaign, the extent and propriety of the United States role was fiercely debated in both countries. Senator Jesse Helms, a conservative Republican from North Carolina, asked for the immediate recall of American Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, accusing him of using his influence ''to strangle liberty during the night.'' Publicizing the Senator's critique, aides of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the rightist candidate in the election, complained that the American Embassy was responsible for the veto by Provisional President Alvaro Magana of legislation that would have allowed elections to proceed without requiring voters to go to the voting places where they were registered. Under the registration system, Mr. d'Aubuisson placed second in the March 25 election, well behind Jose Napoleo n Duarte, the Christian Democratic front-runner.

title: SOLDIER DEAD, 4 LOST AS A RAFT OVERTURNS ON POTOMAC OUTING
description: Six off-duty soldiers and a woman companion on an outing were tossed into the rain-swollen Potomac River this afternoon as their rubber raft careened over a small dam and overturned. At least one soldier drowned, two were rescued and the four other riders were missing and presumed dead.

title: EllieA.WittemanAreMarried
description: Eleanor Burns McGrath, a writer in charge of the education section of Time magazine, was married yesterday to Paul Allan Witteman, the magazine's Detroit bureau chief. The nondenominational ceremony was performed at the Abbey Chapel of Mount Holyoke College by the Rev. Brenda Pelc-Faszcza.

AN ENGLISH TEACHER'S LAMENT

When you're an English teacher you are always meeting people who ask, ''Got any good books to read?'' as though you could slip them one from an undercover cache, or want to know ''What should I read on my trip to Buffalo?''

title: Efforts to Save Striped Bass
description: The article ''What Price Elusive Bass?'' contained many quotes from individuals whose interest in the dwindling striped bass resource goes no further than killing as many fish as possible for short-term gain, but there was no comment from the scores of Federal and state scientists, fisheries managers and individuals from the private sector who are struggling against time, greed and ignorance to save a dying fishery for everyone's long-term benefit.

title:
GARDENING ;
DO NOT START PLANTING TOO SOON
description: ONCE again it is time to issue the warning against planting certain things too early. It is true that woody plants are best planted as early as possible after the soil becomes workable. The same applies to cool-season vegetables such as peas, lettuce and potatoes as well as pansies, primroses and all biennials and hardy perennial flowers.

title: Deborah A. Smith Married
description: Deborah A. Smith, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Smith of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Herbert P. Van Ingen, a son of the late Lawrence B. Van Ingen and the late Harriet P. Bush, both of New York. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home in Glen Head, L.I., of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Van Ingen, the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law. The previous marriages of both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: LEADING INDICATORS PORTEND MODERATION
description: The Index of Leading Economic Indicators, an omen of things to come, dropped 1.1 percent in March, ending 18 months of post-recession increases. Although similar movements in the past have signalled the start of a new recession, analysts were confident that this drop foretold no such thing. Instead, they said, it just gave further proof that the economy is moderating. They pointed to such aberrations as a drop in building permits caused by bad weather, and missing data on two of the 12 components of the index. Nonetheless, some expressed concern over the erratic path many economic indicators have taken in recent months.

description: Gelsey Kirkland, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, resigned from the company yesterday.

title: IN ITS OWN DIZZY WAY, 'V' GALLOPS BRISKLY ALONG
description: When NBC's ''V'' was broadcast a year ago in two two-hour segments, the final scene posed the question, ''The first battle's been won, right?'' ''That's right,'' came the answer, ''but the war is just beginning.'' At that very moment, there was some doubt that television viewers would ever get to see the war between small groups of Earth guerrillas and the Visitors from another planet. Demanding a large cast and an awesome battery of special effects, ''V'' was an unusually expensive production and would not lend itself easily to the relatively limited budgets of a weekly series. But then the audience ratings came in and ''V'' turned out to be the highest- rated NBC mini-series of the year. Obviously, the idea for some sort of continuation would be pursued. So, tonight at 9, ''V'' is returning, not yet as a weekly series but once again as a special mini-series, this time in three two-hour episodes. The remaining segments will be shown tomorrow and Tuesday evenings, also at 9.

title: 2 YOUNG MEN SHOT DEAD AFTER DANCE IN BROOKLYN
description: Two young men were shot to death early yesterday as they left a high school dance in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, the police said.

description: Rachel Tabori, vice president of dramatic development for Columbia Pictures Television in Los Angeles, plans to be married in New York June 24 to Edward Myerson of Los Angeles, a motion-picture producer with offices at 20th Century-Fox and Columbia Pictures.

description: Engineers say they have overcome problems with rocket motors that caused the loss of two $75 million satellites, the near loss of a third and the postponement of two shuttle flights.

This goal is shared by Mr. Anuszkiewicz, whose work of the last decade is surveyed in an elegant and handsomely installed exhibition at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington.

The British Royal Mint has issued a revised version of the one-pound coin featuring a portrait of the Scottish thistle and the new design provides some interesting, though probably unintentional, symbolism because the coin, like the thistle, has been a prickly subject since its stormy introduction a year ago.

title: NEW HYBRIDS TO HANG AROUND THE GARDEN
description: If you are a hanging basket aficionado, this is definitely your year. New hybrids in ivy-leaved geraniums, dwarf fuchsias and impatiens have been introduced and are gradually being coaxed into public prominence. What is more, these plants increase growing space because they can dangle from decks, balconies and patios.

title: YANKS FINALLY SCORE BUT LOSE MILWAUKEE, May 5 - Times have been so bad for the Yankees and runs so scarce, that it had to be that when they finally scored, it would come on a double play. Not surprisingly, that run could not stand up.
description: The Milwaukee Brewers scored one in the 9th inning and one in the 10th inning to beat the Yankees, 2-1, and send the New Yorkers into even more desperate circumstances.

title: SOUTHAMPTON SETS GROUP-RENTAL LIMITS
description: RISING on cue, along with the sap and spring weeds, concern over group rentals has surfaced again in the Town of Southampton, erupting this year with particular force in the unincorporated village of Hampton Bays.

title: A FESTIVAL NEARLY AS BIG AS TEXAS
description: San Antonio, the most Spanish of United States cities, seems an unlikely place for an American version of the Salzburg Festival. Its feel is as Latin as the stately missions that have stood spiritual guard over it for three centuries and more, or the strolling mariachis that serenade nine million tourists a year at sidewalk cafes along the Paseo del Rio in the heart of the town.

title: New &Noteworthy
description: DANGEROUS RELATIONS: The Soviet Union in World Politics, 1970-1982, by Adam B. Ulam. (Oxford, $7.95.) A professor at Harvard University traces the rise and fall of detente in some detail in a stimulating sequel to his ''Expansion and Coexistence.'' Our critic, Alexander Dallin, said ''Dangerous Relations'' offers a ''superbly knowledgeable reconstruction of events - primarily as seen from the Soviet side - '' that proves plausible and readable, although there are ''many tantalizing, controversial and unanswered questions in this book.'' BLUEBEARD CANYON, by Dan McCall. (Dell/Laurel, $5.95.) Dan McCall ''builds a sure, sustained narrative'' in his heartfelt novel about Oliver (Trip) Bodley, a Laguna Beach policeman who gets entangled with the Hooker family through Rex Hooker, a high school buddy now violently divided between himself and the soap opera role that has made him famous. Ron Carlson's review said Mr. McCall integrates ''the three levels of his novel . . . superbly: California, the Hooker family tragedies and Trip the orphan searching for a home.''

title: MUSIC: THE CLEVELANDERS
description: While the Cleveland Orchestra may no longer be the nonpareil ensemble it was in the 1960's, it remains an admirable organization, with a lush string section and an aggregate of first-chair players that can rank with the finest in the world. The orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening, the first of three New York performances under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf, was short and sweet: Bach's Cantata No. 202 ''Weichut nur, betr"ubte Schatten,'' which is one of the ''Wedding'' cantatas, and Mahler's Symphony No. 4 in G.

GREELEY OWNS three houses - a city house in Chicago, a beach house in Michigan and a winter house in Tucson, Ariz. title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: UNTIL the Passaic County Probation Department dispatched an unlikely mix of lawbreakers, all carrying paint cans and brushes, to Hinchliffe Stadium in Paterson last month, the stadium was drab and dreary. Concrete walls around the 15,000-seat soccer and football arena were splattered with graffiti and its five locker rooms were blistered and peeling.

title: CHILDREN EXCHANGE ART WITH CHINESE
description: EVEN before President Reagan's visit to help warm up relations with China, some area students and their counterparts in that country had been preparing a special cultural exchange of their own.

title: LIBRARIES AIDING THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: FOR children with learning disabilities, using the library can be a frustrating experience. ''Some select books that are much too difficult for them,'' says Dr. Betty Osman, an educational therapist in Scarsdale, ''while others don't know where to look for information or how to find it. What they need is more guidance.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: A rewarding trio of varied vintage films await cable viewers this week, starting with ''Cry, the Beloved Country'' (1952), the superb version of Alan Paton's novel of apartheid in South Africa. Set forth in simple, human terms, this graphic, moving tale remains one of the screen's finest dramas of racial tensions, shifting from the Natal hills to the teeming slums of Johannesberg.

title: THESE CAMERAS HAVE SHRUNK BUT THEIR CAPABILITIES HAVE GROWN
description: Mental leaps are always good exercise and sometimes even good entertainment. So, let us leap from the general to the particular and follow the generic discussion of video cameras in the last column with an appraising look at three recent models.

title: SWITCH IN PATTERNS HELPFUL TO KNICKS
description: Hubie Brown of the Knicks is considered a predictable coach, less daring than most others.

title: SEWANEE: A BIT OF OXFORD IN TENNESSEE
description: After watching my first sunset from Morgan's Steep, a vantage point of rocks, a lip of stone, really, at the edge of the campus of the University of the South in Sewanee, Tenn. (which rests on the western ledge of the Cumberland Plateau and overlooks the central Tennessee Valley), I called a friend who had gone to school there and raved to him over the telephone about the astonishing beauty of the scene. When the pulsating vermilion ball sank below the horizon and the evening rose up in vapor from the farmlands below I could compare it only to sunsets I had witnessed in the West, from Sandia Peak outside Albuquerque, from the cliffs overlooking the Pacific at Big Sur or just south of Stinson Beach.

title: PICKS AND SHOVELS
description: A plan to erect a 29-story apartment house above the three-story New York Blood Center on East 67th Street will involve excavation procedures so delicate that workers will use picks and shovels rather than modern drilling tools. The age-old methods will be employed to protect the center's labs and sensitive instruments from dust, vibration and electrical interference.

title: DONALD TRUMP'S TOWER
description: I should like to correct the impression made by the quotation in William E. Geist's article 'The Expanding Empire of Donald Trump' (April 8), in which I am credited with calling Trump Tower 'a dramatically handsome structure.' That quotation comes from a preconstruction article, written in 1979, in which I praised the proposed faceted shape of the building for its design response to the zoning of the site, which, like most midtown sites, allows indefensible overbuilding in terms of the city's skyrocketing speculative land values, dwindling amenities and antiquated services. What I also said was that the building was in the wrong place, and wrong for Fifth Avenue.

title: TESTING THE LIMITS OF ISRAELI CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: Israel has always lived in tension between security concerns and civil liberties, between the drive to prevent terrorism and the need to preserve the attributes of a free society. But rarely have the issues been raised as dramatically as during the past week, when the aftermath of two terrorist acts - one by Arabs, the other by Jews - tested Israel's commitment to two fundamental concepts: the right of the press to publish freely and the right of an accused to legal counsel. In both cases, methods once reserved for Arabs were used against Jews. A Jewish- owned newspaper was closed for four days by the military censor, and about 20 Jewish settlers suspected of terrorism against Arabs were held and interrogated for days without access to defense attorneys.

title: THE OLYMPIC HEIGHTS
description: John Jerome's new book, ''Staying With It,'' about aging and athletics, will be published in June. NE OF THE GREAT pleasures of a televised Olympics is the chance to watch, in action, the finest physical specimens on earth. Forget for a moment more complex human qualities: Whatever other attributes the assembled Olympic athletes may or may not have, they are the most finely tuned physical plants that effort, time, experience and natural gifts can create.

title: HINTS ON DEALING WITH DUCKS
description: THESE days one of the hardest things to cook correctly is roast duck. It was only a few years ago that rare duck breast began to appear on the menu of chic French restaurants in the United States. Re-creating this at home, however, is another thing entirely. If the breast is properly pink, the legs are underdone. If the legs are cooked through, then the breast is dried out and gray.

title: International
description: El Salvador's election officials tried, for the runoff election today, to reduce the confusion that plagued the last vote. They finished delivering ballots and ballot boxes for the presidential election that will decide who determines the Government's policies on resolving the guerrilla war and restructuring the country's battered economic and social system. The election will also provide a key test of the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America. (Page 1, Column 4.) Sudanese have fled to Ethiopia by the thousands to escape fighting between the Sudanese Army and rebels in the southern Sudan, according to United Nations and Ethiopian officials. The United Nations estimates that there could be as many as 70,000 refugees in western Ethiopia. Many are in a refugee camp. (1:5.)

Perhaps this is because (assuming the fallacy still holds in the post-Surrealist era) it takes an inanimate object to do justice to one.

title: FESTIVALS WIDEN APPEAL
description: Festivals remain an essential part of the European cultural scene, but their character is changing. Alongside the old established, essentially elitist events, for which prices continue to rise and audiences become more and more restricted, there are festivals that manage to adapt themselves to the temper of the times. They are not necessarily new events - some of the most adventurous, like the Holland and Berlin Festivals, have existed for many years - but they are festivals that refuse to become confined to one type of art or one type of artistic experience.

title: A STRATEGY FOR THE 90'S
description: Stansfield Turner is a retired admiral and a former Director of Central Intelligence. This article is adapted from a chapter he contributed to ''The Art and Practice of Military Strategy,'' compiled by Capt. George Thibault, to be published by the National Defense University. We in the American military can be scarcely satisfied with our achievements in combat since World War II. Despite abundant personal bravery and many individual battles won, we fought to a draw in Korea, we lost in Vietnam, and we failed miserably in the hostage rescue operation in Iran. Only in such lopsided engagements as the Dominican intervention, the Mayaguez affair and the Grenada invasion can we claim success.

title: ROLLIE FINGERS IS BACK SAVING AGAIN
description: He has an old face. The face has dark eyes and looks especially black around the bridge of the nose. The hair, a bother, is swept aside and, except for the famous perfect mustache, curled and precise, it is a face that somehow looks uncared for. Because the shoulders are upright and the neck so riveted and the legs so muscular, it is easy to imagine that the rest of the body stayed fresh while the face grew old alone.

title: Positive Thinking
description: Dan Gable , the coach of the United States wrestling team, has been calling Soviet wrestlers ''robots,'' and predicting that his wrestlers may beat the Soviet team in the Olympics, even though the Russians hold 25 world and Olympic titles. Some observers have suggested that Gable is extreme to make such comments, but Gable disagrees. ''If the coach doesn't believe they are going to win,'' he said, ''then how is the athlete going to think?''

title: PHILADELPHIA THEATER ENJOYING A RENAISSANCE
description: PHILADELPHIAIn 1766, Philadelphia was the site of the first permanent theater in the United States and later it was the home of generations of Barrymores who performed here with regularity. For many years, the city was a primary way station before and after Broadway, but recently even that aspect of its role has diminished. While local residents have supported orchestras and art museums, they have tended to neglect the stage. Nowadays, however, Philadelphia has awakened and has joined other cities of its size as a center for nonprofit, institutional theater.

title: BETTER LATE THAN NEVER Small Comfort New York's Mayor Koch feels ''very uncomfortable'' about the official treatment of Irwin Levin, a social worker who was demoted after breaking a law in order to expose a city agency's negligent response to child abuse. That's why the Mayor has ordered Mr. Levin reinstated in his old job. The reinstatement may relieve some of the Mayor's discomfort, but we hope not all of it. The fact remains that only the messenger with the bad news has so far been held accountable for his actions.
description: With Mr. Levin's status resolved, the Mayor is asking the Department of Investigation why it needed two years to investigate the social worker's allegations. There's a further, tougher question to be asked - of Special Services for Children, an agency of the Human Resources Administration: Were the failures that permitted the deaths of nine abused children caused solely by incompetent case workers who, one hopes, have been replaced? Or were there systemic failures that could recur today?

description: There has been a quiet revolution taking place recently in the wine world, or, more specifically, the sparkling- wine world. Champagne is still the champ in this rarefied country, but, for the first time, there is a lot of fascinating competition.

title: TRACING THE SKEINS OF MATTER
description: THERE'S A SPECIAL TENSION TO people who are constantly in the position of making new knowledge. You're always out of equilibrium. When I was young, I was deeply troubled by this. Finally, I realized that if I understood too clearly what I was doing, where I was going, then I probably wasn't working on anything very interesting.''

title: UTAH GOVERNOR REAFFIRMS HIS PLEDGE TO BOW OUT
description: When Scott M. Matheson was inaugurated as Governor of Utah in 1976, he declared, ''We stay only a moment, and then we're gone.'' Now Governor Matheson has declared that he will be gone after his second term ends in January.

title: ROY NEUBERGER: BENEFACTOR WITH 'RESPONSIBILITY' TO ART
description: A GIFT of almost $1.3 million from Roy R. Neuberger to the State University of New York at Purchase was announced last Wednesday by Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein, president of the college. The State University's Chancellor, Clifton R. Wharton Jr., said the $1.3 million, ''the largest gift to a SUNY campus to date, demonstrates not only Mr. Neuberger's generosity but also his dedication to the quality of education and cultural life at SUNY-Purchase and his determination to enhance the environment for students, faculty and the surrounding community.''

title: TRUCKING EXECUTIVE MAKING BIG PLANS FOR WATERFRONT
description: ARTHUR E. IMPERATORE picked up a napkin from the desk in his office in a renovated riverfront warehouse here and waved it at a visitor.

title: CAMPING OUT IN STYLE
description: For Peter Kump, the first warm breezes of spring mean that his thoughts turn westward - about 60 miles westward, to be precise, along a pristine stretch of the Delaware River south of Milford, Pa. Lazing away on a sunny afternoon in a canoe with a group of friends and camping overnight on the riverbank is one of Kump's favorite ways to unwind from the demands of running his Manhattan cooking school and serving as the president of the New York Association of Cooking Teachers. He is never short of eager boating companions, for the meals prepared on these excursions are a far cry from the trail mix, beef jerky and hamburgers that sustain most other canoeists.

title: ...AND A PROTEST BY ONE LEFT OUT
description: -distance runner Sharon Given of Huntington is refusing to accept the fact that she will not be participating in this country's first women's Olympic marathon trials on Saturday in Olympia, Wash.

title: Pirates Turn Back Dodgers in 10th, 8-7
description: Marvell Wynne, who singled home the tying run in the eighth inning, singled in Amos Otis with the winning run in the 10th as the Pirates rallied for an 8-7 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today to end a five- game losing streak.

title: REAGAN AFTER CHINA
description: During his journey to China, President Reagan spoke in hopeful terms about America's future relations not only with China but also with all of Asia.

title: Judicial Conference Role
description: Former Justice Dorothy Comstock Riley of the Michigan Supreme Court will serve on the United States Judicial Conference, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger announced Thursday.

title: 2 NUNS WHO QUIT ORDER DEFEND POLITICAL ROLE
description: Two nuns who left the Sisters of Mercy rather than abandon politics say the Roman Catholic hierarchy needs to change its stands on political activity by nuns and priests and on the role of women in the church.

description: Scientists and other scholars from around the world called today for concerted international action to protect the global environment and the biological systems that support human life.

description: Nearly half of a 103-acre estate in Irvington, N.Y., now being developed as a residential community has been donated to the village by the Westchester County developers who bought the property last year.

description: Nine British tourists and seven Spanish soccer fans were killed and 80 people were injured today in two bus crashes, the Spanish police said.

title: MaryAnn Van Zanten Weds Hugh van Hengel
description: TMaryAnn Van Zanten, a daughter of Constantin Van Zanten of Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Helen Van Zanten, was married yesterday to Hugh Drake van Hengel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maarten van Hengel of Tarrytown. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y.

description: Robert Shaplen is a staff writer for The New Yorker and the author of a number of books about Asia. MUSIC IN EVERY ROOM

Rabbi Arthur F. Starr performed the ceremony.

title: FRESH AIR FUND OPENS ANNUAL APPEAL TOMORROW
description: There will be youngsters who have never seen a cow being milked, heard a rooster crow at the break of day or picnicked beside a running brook. But they will be boarding trains or buses late next month to travel to camps and homes in the country where those sights and sounds will become reality and an experience unlikely to be forgotten.

description: SUZANNE DALEY

CONNECTICUT OPINION;

title: A COMMENDABLE NEW SPOT
description: WHEN it comes to Gregory's, small is beautiful. Gregory's in Fairfield is the kind of new restaurant you root for. The decor is deceptively simple. Inside a small storefront is a narrow interior of soft lights, white banquettes along one wall, framed fruit engravings on white walls and a single strand of orchids on each neatly napped table. A friendly, well-trained staff expertly serves from a small menu of carefully prepared (for the most part) and unpretentious dishes. These are endearing elements in a restaurant.

title: TAIWAN A NEW SENSE OF CONFIDENCE
description: Fox Butterfield, The New York Times's Boston bureau chief, reported on Taiwan for the newspaper in the 1970's.

title: Keep Shea Free Of Artificial Turf
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LOBSTER UNADORNED
description: For generations, thousands of New England schoolboys have discovered their first taste of the romance of their native region in the pages of Kenneth Roberts's novels. But those well-loved stories carry more than accounts of adventure and more than descriptions of ''the odors of rum, coffee, lemons and spices'' on the Portsmouth wharf in Colonial days. They are also a gastronomic guide to New England.

title: Miss Schneider Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Anne Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Schneider of New York and Brookfield, Conn., was married in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University yesterday to Gary Joseph Casarsa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Casarsa of Amherst, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg, assisted by the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Catholic priest.

title: Over $6.5 Million Bet On the Derby at OTB
description: A total of $13,521,146, almost half of it at New York's Offtrack Betting offices, was wagered on the Kentucky Derby at sites from Boston to Yakima, Wash., today, the first time that tracks other than Churchill Downs have been allowed to take parimutuel action on the race.

title: Award in Lie-Detector Suit
description: A jury awarded $60,000 to a former bank teller who said she had suffered emotional damage because she had been pressed by her employer to take a polygraph, or lie-detector, test.

title: PHILADELPHIA PROJECT FLATTENED BY STATUE OF THE CITY FOUNDER
description: City officials have decided to keep an informal 491-foot height limit for downtown buildings, and a developer says that leaves him ''sitting on top of Billy Penn's hat wondering what to do next.''

title: Freehold Fire Stuns an Area
description: Easter Morn became the last horse to win at Freehold Raceway, beating Ruby Alert and Santantas in the 11th race Friday afternoon. Two hours later, what was believed to be the oldest harness racing track in America burned to the ground.

title: Comings and Goings When the Olympic flame begins its 9,000-mile journey to Los Angeles from the United Nations Tuesday, the first of 4,000 runners carrying the torch during the 82-day relay will be
description: Bill Thorpe Jr., the grandson of Jim Thorpe, and Gina Hemphill, the granddaughter of Jesse Owens .

title: ASTROS BEAT METS
description: After a week of brilliant pitching and solid, occasionally even inspired baseball, the Mets ran into a roadblock last night. The Houston Astros, shut out and held hitless through four innings, came back from a 4-0 deficit to defeat the Mets, 10-6, before 16,895 at Shea Stadium.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: SYDNEY MAREE'S THANK YOU
description: The runner Sydney Maree, a native of South Africa, became a United States citizen in Philadelphia last Tuesday. This article is the speech Maree gave on behalf of the people naturalized with him that day.

title: 37 Accused of Haiti Plot
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, May 5 (Reuters) - The police on the French Caribbean island of St. Martin have arrested 37 people suspected of plotting to overthrow President Jean- Claude Duvalier of Haiti, police officials in Guadeloupe said today. They said the group of purported mercenaries had been arrested while setting up a training camp for anti-Duvalier commandos.

title:
ART;
PERSONAL TASTE, PRIVATE COLLECTIONS
description: SELECTIONS of modern and still fresher contemporary art from the holdings of five art-collecting couples in Westchester and Fairfield Counties make up ''The Private Eye'' at the Neuberger Museum on the State University of New York campus in Purchase.

title: Bertha Cummings Neustadt, Taught English as 2d Tongue
description: Bertha Cummings Neustadt, an educator specializing in teaching English as a second language, died yesterday at her home in Cambridge, Mass., after a long illness. She was 63 years old and also had a home in Wellfleet, Mass.

title: No Headline

title: NEW PRODUCTS AT PMA SHOW IN LAS VEGAS
description: Cononvenience and versatility were the major trends evident at the Photographic Marketing Association (PMA) show in Las Vegas last month (April 3-8). Among the many new products that were publicly exhibited there for the first time were the Nikon FA, the Olympus OM4, the Canon F1 High Speed Motor Drive camera, and the Ricoh model XR-T - all described here previously (April 1, 1984).

title: NOTHERN BURGUNDY'S EARTHY LOCAL FARE
description: This is not hearty Burgundy, the land of escargots, round, rosy cheeks and lush, green vineyards. Rather, this flat to gently rolling region southeast of Paris is marked by both a gastronomy and a land that's gentle and refreshing. The region's uncomplicated terrain takes off slowly and easily just an hour south of Paris, and ends at the doorstep of the Morvan, a rugged forest thick with oak, beech and fir, some 150 miles from the capital.

description: Ainslie Embree teaches Indian history at Columbia University. THE LEDGE BETWEEN THE STREAMS

title: ONE-ON-ONE THEATER GETS AROUND
description: BONNIE GABLE and Sheila Gaeckler have this aversion to what they call ''turnpike cripples'' - regional theaters that Miss Gable said ''tie themselves to big facilities and then go under trying to keep up the overhead.''

title: Judge Prohibits Prayer At School Ceremony
description: School officials may not include prayers in the high school commencement, a judge has ruled in a lawsuit filed on behalf of five seniors.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
GROWING YOUNGER WITH BABY
description: HOW, I am sometimes asked, does it feel to become a first-time father in middle age? (Not often, of course, because I am usually assumed to be the grandfather.) What is life like when the generation gap resembles the Grand Canyon? Blunter people ask outright if insanity runs in the family.

title: DANCE: TAMASABURO BANDO, KABUKI
description: Americans discovered Tamasaburo Bando, a still-young Kabuki actor who has the equivalent of a rock star's popularity in Japan, when he made his New York debut with the Grand Kabuki company in 1982.

title: PANAMANIAN ELECTION TODAY THE FIRST SINCE 1968
description: The two leading presidential candidates in the election Sunday have closed their campaigns with predictions of easy victories and promises that they would curb the military and establish full civilian rule.

title: Common Sense for Starrett City
description: In most of America, whites and minorities who go to school, work and even spend leisure time together still live in segregated neighborhoods. A housing development like Brooklyn's Starrett City is a precious rarity. The 46-building, publicly financed complex laudably sustains a commitment to racially integrated housing.

title: CANADIENS RESPECTABLE AGAIN
description: There was a time, Bobby Smith remembered, when the Canadiens thought things were going their way.

title: JACKSON TAKES LOUISIANA VOTE IN LOW TURNOUT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson easily won the Louisiana Democratic Presidential primary today, his second such victory in a week, as most Democrats joined their Governor in ignoring the court-ordered election. Senator Gary Hart came in second and Walter F. Mondale finished third. The former Vice President had concentrated most of his time and resources in Texas, which held caucuses today.

title: TROUBLE IN THE NATION'S BACKYARD
description: Michael Kramer, the political editor of New York magazine, writes frequently about Central America. VIOLENT NEIGHBORS

title: Verbatim: On Evil
description: ''The Holocaust stands testament to man's moral imperfections. In every one of us is interwoven evil with goodness, impulse with restraint, cruelty with gentleness.

title:
STAMPS;
U.N. ISSUE FOCUSES ON PLIGHT OF REFUGEES
description: There are more than 10 million refugees around the globe, and their numbers are constantly growing due to savage military conflicts, religious and political persecution, the ravages of nature and the struggle to survive in extremely poor lands. What to do about these refugees is the theme of a six new commemoratives from the United Nations entitled ''A Future for Refugees.''

title: PUBLISHERS' CONFESSIONS-REJECTIONS I REGRET
description: In a utopian future, every writer would have William Faulkner's genius, every editor, Maxwell Perkins's judgment and every publisher, the money to match a boundless enthusiasm for fine novels. Like all illusions, however, this one is shattered by facts. Malcolm Cowley once wrote to Faulkner, ''In publishing circles your name is mud. They are all convinced your books won't ever sell.'' Perkins himself, who would otherwise have had a flawless record, turned down Faulkner's work.

title: Elin J. Waring Marries Thomas Glenn Abernathy
description: Elin Joan Waring, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Waring of Ramsey, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Glenn Abernathy, a son of Drs. Robert and Rosalind Abernathy of Little Rock, Ark.

title: DorothyCullmanHeads Lincoln Film Society
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center has announced the election of DoroCullman as chairman of the board.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ROME
description: Nothing special has been announced for Rome's spring and summer visitors. No spectacular museum exhibitions; no major series of concerts or operas in preparation; no anniversary to be celebrated with fanfares, fancy costumes and fireworks.

title: Jets' Top Pick Is on Move Again
description: There will be another moving day for Russell Carter, the Southern Methodist defensive back whom the Jets made their first pick of the draft on Tuesday. But his mother will finally be staying put.

title: SUMMER CONCERTS PROMISE VARIETY
description: Summer concertgoers like to relax, and summer programming usually tries to accommodate them. But along with the predictables, some very interesting, often far- flung, experiences lie ahead in the next few months. One of them begins today in Los Angeles when Pierre Boulez returns to the United States after a long absence to conduct three concerts at UCLA with the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Today's concert and two more, May 13 and 20, will each feature a work by Boulez - ''Notations I-IV,'' ''Trois Improvisations sur Mallarme'' and ''Rituel.'' Mr. Boulez, by the way, will return to the New York Philharmonic for a series of subscriptions concerts in March of 1986. He was music director of the Philharmonic from 1971 to 1977.

title:
ANTIQUES;
JEWELRY THAT REMEMBERS THE PAST
description: ''THE whole idea was man's bid for immortality,'' Edith Weber said recently, gesturing with slender, ring-adorned fingers. ''Especially if one wasn't going to be a famous writer or a famous musician or a famous anything - this was one way of making sure people knew you existed.''

title: Bandits Defeat Bulls Before Crowd of 71,174
description: John Reaves passed for 205 yards, including touchdown throws to Larry Brodsky and Eric Truvillion, to lead the Tampa Bandits to a 31-13 victory over the Jacksonville Bulls before a crowd of 71,174 in the Gator Bowl.

title: Robin Bierstedt, Lawyer for Time, Weds P.J. Mayer
description: Robin Bierstedt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bierstedt of Charlottesville, Va., and Peter J. Mayer, a son of Mrs. Myron L. Mayer of New York and the late Mr. Mayer, were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Justice Felice Shea of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: ACCORD IS SET ON PAYMENTDEADLINES FOR STATE
description: Governor Cuomo and key legislators have agreed on a measure to require the state to pay its bills on time - or pay an interest penalty to state contractors.

description: Dr. Emily Ann Lichtman, a daughter of Sarah Lichtman of New York and the late Samuel Lichtman, was married yesterday to Jean Francis Webb 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Webb 3d of New York.

description: The Wealth

description: In a new effort to curb automobile theft, officials have begun using the city's anti-nuisance law to try to shut down auto-repair and salvage businesses that double as chop shops in which stolen cars are dismantled so their parts can be resold.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: A BALLET MUSICIAN RECALLS BALANCHINE
description: John Martin, the longtime dance critic of the New York Times, once observed, with surprise, that George Balanchine did not always watch his dancers from his seat in the audience. Sometimes, Balanchine sat there with his eyes closed, listening intently to the music being played by his ballet orchestra, of which I am a longtime member.

title: MONDALE CARRIES TEXAS DEMOCRATS IN CAUCUS VOTING
description: Walter F. Mondale posted a solid victory over Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Texas caucuses tonight.

title: J. C. Agajanian, 70, Sponsor Of Cars in Indianapolis 500
description: J. C. (Aggie) Agajanian, a longtime owner and sponsor of Indianapolis 500 racing cars and the owner of Ascot Racetrack in Gardena, Calif., died today of complications from pneumonia. He was 70 years old.

title: UNKNOWN OPERA BY DONIZETTI FOUND IN A LONDON BASEMENT
description: A previously unknown opera attributed to Gaetano Donizetti, most of its music dating from the final and richest period of the l9th-century composer's career, has come to light as a result of recent discoveries in London and Paris.

title: A SUMMER RETREAT GIVES WAY TO OFFICES
description: BEFORE the interstate highway system rolled across the country and turned cars into transcontinental haulers and family trips into long-distance expeditions, New Jersey was dotted with scores of small lakes, amusement parks and picnic groves that were popular destinations for family outings.

title: Peggy McDonnell Becomes the Bride Of Cyrus R. Vance Jr. in Peapack, N.J.
description: The marriage of Peggy McDonnell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., to Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vance of New York, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Peapack. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Alliegro, assisted by the Rev. Vincent Dwyer, director of the Center for Human Development in Washington.

description: MICHAEL PERTSCHUK

title: THE JAPANESE GIFT FOR WRAPPINGS
description: Long before paper bags and wrapping paper, the Japanese had furoshiki, sturdy sheets of cloth that, when properly tied or folded, could hold almost anything, from gifts and groceries to garbage.

title: Candace A. Cummins Becomes a Bride
description: Candace Ann Cummins, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Cummins of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Ethan M. Riegelhaupt, the son Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Riegelhaupt of Wellesley Hills, Mass. Judge Reginald Stanton of ew Jersey Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Cummins home.

title: STUDY URGES USE OF HEALTH AIDES
description: A Congressional study of health care for the elderly in the United States has concluded that an important goal should be to encourage the employment of more nurse practitioners and physician assistants to perform ''routine procedures that do not require a doctor's expertise.''

title: FISH SALES EMBROIL FREEPORT
description: some in their Sunday best, some in jogging suits and others with cameras around their necks - parade down Woodcleft Avenue in Freeport much like pedestrians on Fifth Avenue. On this street, abutting Woodcleft Canal, lined with seafood markets, restaurants and bars, boatyards and boutiques, seagulls circle above shiny pleasure craft and weatherbeaten draggers and colored flags flap in the wind.

title: U.S. CUTS SPENDING ON LOCAL PROJECTS
description: Federal spending on local public works projects has been reined in sharply in recent years from the fast pace clip of the 1970's, according to a recent analysis by the Reagan Administration.

title:
GARDENING ;
DO NOT START PLANTING TOO SOON
description: ONCE again it is time to issue the warning against planting certain things too early. It is true that woody plants are best planted as early as possible after the soil becomes workable. The same applies to cool-season vegetables such as peas, lettuce and potatoes as well as pansies, primroses and all biennials and hardy perennial flowers.

title: A CLEAR VOICE IN SPAIN
description: Spain's Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez took the breath away from a panel of French journalists who flew down to interview him for Radio Europe 1's version of ''Meet the Press.''
