description: HARRIET KING

title: Upsets In Squash Tourney
description: Three upsets marked the third round of the $40,000 North American Open squash racquets championship yesterday at the Park Avenue Squash and Racquet Club.

title: Man Struck by a BMT Train Dies in the Operating Room
description: A man was struck by an RR train in Queens Friday night and died hours later while undergoing an operation in Manhattan, according to the authorities.

title: BUYING A HOME WITH A FRIEND
description: OVER the last two or three years a growing number of young, single people have chosen to buy a home in partnership with a friend. There is not necessarily a romantic involvement. The two simply decide to pool their resources to amass the necessary down payment or to qualify for financing at a time when property prices are so high.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the April 8 Arts & Leisure section, an article about the Academy Awards misidentified the director of ''To Be or Not to Be.'' The film was directed by Alan Johnson.

title: NEW DEBATE ON SCHOOL SILENCE
description: THE United States Supreme Court's decision to review the constitutionality of an Alabama law that permits a silent minute for prayer in the state's schools has reopened a nearly 10-year-old debate in Connecticut.

title: 2 U.S. BRIDGE TEAMS SEEKING SPOT IN WORLD TOURNEY PLAY
description: A team from Dallas clashed with one made up of Easterners and Middle Westerners here this afternoon, aiming to become the the United States team in the 1984 world contract bridge team championship.

title: THE ASKING PRICE: $3,868 A SQ. FT.
description: THE PRUDENTIAL Insurance Company of

title: MUSIC: 7 INSTRUMENTALISTS AND A SOPRANO
description: Seven instrumentalists and one soprano rummaged through a loose pile of Americana in the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night. The bizarre turned up along with the trivial, even the pointless, but interspersed were some vivid clues as to how Americans a century ago felt about themselves.

title: MUSIC: LUKAS FOSS LEADS ALL-BEETHOVEN PROGRAM
description: Lukas Foss is, if anything, an interesting program-maker. Friday night's Brooklyn Philharmonic concert at the Academy of Music, at any rate, managed to be all-Beethoven, include the Fifth Symphony and still seem unusual.

title: Diane Whiting Wed to Deval L. Patrick
description: Diane Whiting, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Bemus of Hollis, Queens, and Deval L. Patrick, the son of Laurdine Patrick of New York and Emily Wintersmith Patrick of Chicago, were married yesterday. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Brooklyn.

title: Broncos Get a Novice He'll have to learn a new grip (you don't throw quarterbacks the same way you do hammers), and he probably won't get his accustomed distance, but
description: Ralph Uebel, a Washington State University hammer-thrower, has decided to give his athletic prowess a new focus.

title: THE VERDICT ON JURIES
description: Irving Kaufman mentioned the time wasted waiting to be impaneled and then accepted on a jury. Aside from this, the current procedure is inefficient.

title: END OF A MOVEMENT, END OF A MARRIAGE
description: Lynne Sharon Schwartz's most recent novel is ''Disturbances in the Field.'' A collection of stories, ''Acquainted With the Night,'' will be published in August. CIVIL WARS

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; MOSQUITO WARFARE
description: Overrun with mosquitoes but reluctant to use pesticides, a group of resi- dents in Wells, Me., imported a natural air force - dragonflies - to combat the mosquitoes in 1976.

title: 40,000 FROM SUDAN CROSS INTO ETHIOPIA TO ESCAPE FIGHTING
description: About 40,000 Sudanese have fled across the border to a refugee camp here in the last six months, United Nations and Ethiopian officials said today.

title: NEW ART AND TRADITION AT THE NEW MODERN
description: The Museum of Modern Art is fundamental to the cultural life of New York. Since it was shut, some months ago, the north side of East 53d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenue has lain like lead in the belly of midtown Manhattan. As for the south side of 54th Street, it has been a scene of desolation. With the familiar entrance off limits, the interior gutted and much of the beloved garden a hole in the ground, the whole area has been an offense against nature. For this is a museum that always had, as The Times's architectural critic Paul Goldberger said lately, ''a feeling of openness and ease.'' ''It is no accident,'' he went on, ''that people speak of museums like the Metropolitan and the Louvre in terms of respect but of the Modern in terms of deep affection.''

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Off the Bench Judges don't always enjoy setting precedents, and one faced by Hartford Probate Court Judge James H. Kinsella promised to be no fun at all.

title: Jessica Rachel Wolff Weds Stephen Wanta
description: Stephen Alastair Wanta, an architect, and Jessica Rachel Wolff, a graduate student at New York University, were married yesterday. Civil Court Judge Solomon H. Katz performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan apartment.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY ;
WHAT VALUES DOES LITTLE LEAGUE INSTILL?
description: I AM a poor loser. Probably because I am a mother - soft-

title: Jill R. Kahn Engaged To Richard A. Abeles
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Kahn of Harrison, N.Y., and Boynton Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill R. Kahn, to Richard A. Abeles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Abeles of Roslyn, L.I. The wedding is to be in September.

title: ACTIVITIES CLUB IS FLOURISHING
description: activities club launched last winter by Jagger's Camp and Trail of Bedford Hills, N.Y., continues to flourish.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; 'GONDOLIERS' IN TUNE
description: THE opening night in 1889 at London's Savoy Theater of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Gondoliers'' marked the greatest success of their careers, rivaled only by their ''Mikado.'' Further, the song ''Take a Pair of Sparkling Eyes'' from ''The Gondoliers'' was one of the most popular ballads of Victorian times. Whether ''The Gondoliers'' is staged in the traditional D'Oyly Carte style or in a more modern version, as in the BBC series recently broadcast on public television, almost 100 years have not dimmed the appeal and musical charm of this slyly satirical, highly theatrical light opera.

title: WHERE WRESTLING IS THE SPORT
description: -TWO years ago, when Russ Riegel was a freshman at Washington High School in Warren County, he wanted to play football. But the football coach was also the wrestling coach, and he expected his football players to wrestle, too.

title: CHINA HAILS ARAFAT ON ARRIVAL PEKING, May 5 (Reuters) - Yasir Arafat arrived in China today for three days of talks and was welcomed with a 19-gun salute and an endorsement of his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang held two hours of talks this afternoon with Mr. Arafat, whose visit is to discuss China's military and diplomatic backing of the P.L.O.

title: THOSE HOLLYWOOD NIGHTS
description: Chris Chase , the author of ''How to Be a Movie Star'' and other books, is media correspondent for the Cable News Network. ZANUCK

title: SCHOOL BOARD EASES RULES FOR HIRING NEW TEACHERS
description: The City Board of Education, anticipating a continuing teacher shortage in the next school year, has eased the requirements for new teachers.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Two concerts of unusual interest are taking place Sunday in New York, and, with careful pacing, the listener can attend both of them. Sunday afternoon at 3, the American Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Moshe Atzmon, will present the world premiere of Gustav Mahler's 1894 transcription of Schubert's famous String Quartet in D Minor (''Death and the Maiden'') at Carnegie Hall. Mahler's manuscript, lost for nearly a century, was unearthed by his daughter early last year.

title: Admission to College: A Systematic Approach
description: Barbara Gerbasi's article, ''Admission to College: That Extra Edge'' (Opinion Page, April 1), elicited comments from many concerned parents and their apprehensive children in our community recently. The letters of acceptance and rejection received by many high school seniors and the realization by many high school juniors that now is the time that they too must begin the college selection process have contributed to the annual raising of the neighborhood's anxiety level.

title: Chilean Is Challenged Over Land Acquisition
description: President Augusto Pinochet is facing a legal challenge over his acquisition of five acres of land bordering his private weekend retreat.

title: EASY ELEGANCE
description: Questo e un vero Missoni!'' This is a true Missoni! Said at a fashion show, that remark would be expected, given the enduring appeal of the intricate, jewel-toned knits and prints that distinguish the men's and women's clothing created by the husband and wife team of Rosita and Ottavio - called Tai - Missoni. But that observation comes as a surprise when it refers not to ready-to-wear but rather to a ready-to-eat rainbow of a baked vegetable casserole created by Tai Missoni.

title: TAGLIONI AND ELSSLER WERE 19TH-CENTURY SUPERSTARS
description: '' Fanny Elssler is the Liszt rhapsody coming after the slow Chopin waltz.'' The slow Chopin waltz is represented, of course, by Marie Taglioni. And in this musical metaphor in 1929, the French-Russian critic and Taglioni biographer, Andre Levinson, conjured up the contrast between 19th-century Romantic ballet's two greatest ballerinas in terms we understand today.

title: 90% UNEMPLOYED
description: After the coal mines in Gary, W. Va., began to close in April 1982, there were hard times and then worse times in the town of 3,500 people.

title: WETLANDS BRIDGES AT ISSUE
description: WHEN Abraham and Esther Bronfeld proposed to build a house on their Remsenburg property two years ago, they also planned on constructing a 330-by-18-foot wooden bridge to reach it.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CBS will be repeating the TV movie ''A Caribbean Mystery'' this Tuesday at 9 P.M. Based on an Agatha Christie novel, the sleuth is the formidable Miss Marple, who used to be played in the movies by Margaret Rutherford with a kind of determined dottiness. For television, the role is being handled by Helen Hayes with her characteristically gentle perkiness.

title: A Tax for Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN

title: TO GIVE MINORITIES A FAIRER BREAK ON ELECTION DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric Graff Is Married To Joanne Meryl Jones
description: Joanne Meryl Jones, the daughter of Phyllis Luxemburg of New York and the late Laurence S. Jones, was married yesterday to Eric David Graff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Graff of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan.

title: 'Greenmail'
description: To the Editor:

title: AID IN THE EIGHTIES
description: Jeffrey E. Garten's article 'Aid in the Eighties' (March 25) correctly warns about the perils of applying a Marshall Plan concept in an open-ended way to Central America. There are indeed differences between Europe in the 1940's and Central America in the 1980's.

title: REAGAN SAYS TALKS IN STOCKHOLM WILL TEST SOVIET INTENTIONS
description: President Reagan said today that the resumption of the European disarmament conference in Stockholm next week would test the Soviet Union's interest in reducing the risk of accidental nuclear war.

title: CONGRESS STAGES A PRE-EMPTIVE STRIKE ON THE GENDER GAP
description: STEVEN V. ROBERTS

title: THE WORLD ; Solidarity Keeps
description: The Flame Alive

title: KAYAKK, FROM OUT OF THE NORTH, IS GROWING IN AREA POPULARITY
description: SEA kayaks in increasing numbers are silently slipping into the coves, marshes and bays along Long Island Sound and the Hudson River. The Coast Guard doesn't know quite what to do with them, some power boaters laugh at them and water skiers sometimes slolam as close as they can to them.

title: D'AUBUISSON BACKERS PREDICT A LOSS
description: Many supporters of the presidential candidate of the far right say privately that they will lose the runoff election Sunday because of what they term the negative tone of their campaign and their candidate's reputation as a man associated with death squads.

title: HART: LET'S FOCUS ON GROWTH
description: FOR a decade, the American economy has been struggling with change. The challenge facing our leadership is meeting that change and mastering it, to make this country more competitive and compassionate.

title: PROPOSAL TOUCHES OFF BATTLE OVER KOREAN WAR MONUMENT
description: More than 30 years after the Korean War ended, a Federal commission has suggested that the Government, instead of a private group, build a monument here to honor veterans of the war.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Advances
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd survived a shaky start and defeated Anne White, 6-3, 6-2, in the semifinals of the $150,000 South African women's open tennis tournament today.

title: CUOMO PANEL TO PREPARE A 1985 TAX-CUT PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo has asked an advisory group to prepare recommendations on tax cuts and tax reforms for consideration as part of next year's state budget.

title: THE VERDICT ON JURIES
description: Irving R. Kaufman's article 'The Verdict on Juries' (April 1) was an important contribution toward greater understanding of the jury system.

title: Miss Larsen Has Nuptials
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Wendelle Page Larsen, the daughter of Robert Roy Larsen and Deborah Page Larsen, both of Fairfield, Conn., to George Edwin Rakerd, a son of George Clifton Rakerd of Salem, Ill., and the late Martha Roden Rakerd. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING ;
DO NOT START PLANTING TOO SOON
description: ONCE again it is time to issue the warning against planting certain things too early. It is true that woody plants are best planted as early as possible after the soil becomes workable. The same applies to cool-season vegetables such as peas, lettuce and potatoes as well as pansies, primroses and all biennials and hardy perennial flowers.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Pilobolus dance company, based in the northwestern Connecticut town of Washington, has finally won town approval for a proposed dance studio.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION ;
MY BOYS' 'PHANTOM TRIP'-AND MINE
description: MY sons are preparing for a bicycle trip in Newfoundland. They feel they have outgrown the local sailing and swimming camps, and have chosen this hosteling group because it offers a summer program that is both novel and far away from home.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHINA'S GARDENS

title: DONALD TRUMP'S TOWER
description: I go to New York quite often with friends, and I really enjoy showing them Trump Tower. It is quite a showplace. Personally, I think it has given Fifth Avenue just the 'kick' it needs.

title: LEAVE THE CHLOROPHYLL IN OUR PLAYING FIELDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Article 164389 -- No Title
Islip's Regulation Of Political Signs
description: The recent criticism by Thomas Shanahan, legislative aide to Philip Nolan, Democratic Suffolk County Legislator, of the Islip Town ordinance regulating political signs (''Political Signs and 'Garbage,'' '' Opinion Page, April 8) requires clarification.

title: HASIDIC JEWS FIGHT CHANGE IN AID PROJECT
description: Eugene Schwartz of Brooklyn got some good news the other day. He found out he was socially and economically disadvantaged.

title: PROFILE OF AN ARTIST
description: Jackson Pollock is the first of the Abstract Expressionists whose careers are explored in 'Strokes of Genius,' a four-part series beginning Tuesday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13. Through still photographs, home movies, stock footage and interviews with associates, fellow artists and his widow, the hour-long premiere program explores the forces that influenced the creator of the 'dripped paint' canvases that have become part of art history.

title: FOLK, FINE AND CERAMIC ART
description: TRENTON RECENT works in clay by Bennett Bean make up one of three new exhibitions currently on view at the State Museum here.

title: Autistics in State May Exceed 10,000
description: As director of the advocacy agency for children and adults with autism in New Jersey, I am pleased that the developmental disability of autism was brought to the attention of readers in an April 1 article. However, a number of inaccuracies should be corrected.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GIANT COLD

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: American Ballet Theater was founded as a living library of dance and its current season at the Metropolitan Opera House suggests the company has kept to that profile. This week alone will see performances of such full-evening classics as ''La Sylphide'' and ''Swan Lake,'' as well as one-act ballets by Jerome Robbins, George Balanchine, Kenneth MacMillan, Antony Tudor and Twyla Tharp.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR IN PARIS AND AMERICA
description: N a hot July day in 1983, a tiny, seemingly frail woman of strong will and stubborn disposition shepherded her skittish companion, who is terrified of flying, onto the Concorde for the flight from Paris to New York. The older of the two was Simone de Beauvoir, the younger was Sylvie Le Bon, a philosophy teacher in her early 40's whom Miss de Beauvoir persuaded to become her adopted daughter several years ago, in order to take charge of her affairs - in much the same way that Jean-Paul Sartre had adopted the young Algerian Jewish student Arlette Elka"im when he felt his powers were beginning to fail.

title: THEY'LL BE POURING OVER BOOKS IN RYE
description: BEFORE the turn of the century, the citizens of Rye established a Free Reading Room, less to bring culture and erudition to their village than to keep the young men of the community out of the local saloons. But this Saturday evening, the current Rye citizenry will convert that free reading room into a saloon, hoping to bring in the men, and the women, of the community.

title:
DINING OUT;
A ONE-OF-A-KIND IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: JOHAN'S is the restaurant I recommend when asked where to eat in Atlantic City. I don't recommend it because the price is low (it isn't) or the food exquisite (it isn't), but because dining at Johan's is an experience that cannot be duplicated in many restaurants.

title: THE BASQUES: ANCIENT TUG-OF-WAR GOES ON
description: The oak tree of Guernica, an ancient hollow tree stump some 15 feet high, sits inside a columned monument on a small bluff. On these warm spring days, busloads of children from all over the Basque region come to see it.

title: SMALL RURAL BANKS RESISTING MERGERS
description: THE compulsion to grow bigger through mergers, a move that has dominated banking since states began easing restrictions on consolidations 10 to 20 years ago, has fallen short of taking over the industry.

title: CONCERT: VEGH AND SCHIFF
description: Bartok was the principal subject of a rewarding concert played by Sandor Vegh, the violinist, and Andras Schiff, the pianist, at the Metropolitan Museum on Wednesday night. The program consisted of the Hungarian composer's two violin-and- piano sonatas separated by Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (Op. 30, No. 2).

title:
ANTIQUES;
ARTISAN HAD CHECKERED LIFE
description: ABEL BUELL could apparently do anything he wanted to except become a business and financial success. Mr. Buell was throughout his life an accomplished silversmith, jeweler, lapidary and mint master.

title: Efforts to Save Striped Bass
description: Two significant articles appeared on April 8, one by Richard Weis smann in the Long Island Weekly section (''What Price Elusive Bass?'') and the other by Nelson Bryant in the Sports section (''More Protection for Salmon and Bass''). Both articles were about the depressed status of the striped bass population. There the similarities end.

title: HART CALLS VICTORY POSSIBLE EVEN IF MONDALE KEEPS LEAD
description: Senator Gary Hart says he could still win the Democratic Presidential nomination even if Walter F. Mondale holds the lead in delegates after the next round of primaries and caucuses.

title: Alta Badia
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; A Rest for Forced
description: Retirement

title: MCCARTER IS MAKING WAVES
description: PRINCETON ALL AT once, Princeton's McCarter Theater has been making news, and it's about to buzz even more resonantly. The past eventful week included:

title: VOLUNTEER OF YEAR HAS TIME FOR MORE
description: ANTHONY FAVA, the owner of Fava's market in the Washingtonville secction of Mamaroneck and the recently named Westchester Volunteer of the Year for 1984, originally thought he was too busy to be more than an observer in community affairs. ''Eight years ago, when the administration of Mamaroneck decided they wanted to help with local improvement, I was serving as exalted ruler of the Elks,'' he said. ''I knew that in no way did I have the time to devote to any other volunteer matter. But when the person designated as the head of the beautification program for Washingtonville found it difficult to get things going, I said that I would help. Soon I found myself in the middle of everything.''

title: Peter Manbeck Weds Anne L. Chamberlain
description: Anne Louise Chamberlain, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Chamberlain of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Charles Manbeck, the son of Harry F. Manbeck Jr. of Weston, Conn., and the late Lois Lange Manbeck. The Rev. J. Bruce Baker performed the ceremony at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title:
GARDENING ;
DO NOT START PLANTING TOO SOON
description: ONCE again it is time to issue the warning against planting certain things too early. It is true that woody plants are best planted as early as possible after the soil becomes workable. The same applies to cool-season vegetables such as peas, lettuce and potatoes as well as pansies, primroses and all biennials and hardy perennial flowers.

title: HIS SIX STEPS DON'T ADD UP TO A POLICY
description: PAUL W. MacAVOY

title: Bowling Over the Boss When
description: Karen Ellingsworth of Des Plaines, Ill., defeated Lorrie Nichols of Algonquin, Ill., 236-217, to win the $50,000 Women's United States Open bowling championship yesterday at Chesterfield, Mo., it was a case of the boss's yielding to the worker's ability to strike.

title: STAGING AN ELEGANT DINNER OUTSIDE
description: The red and black tugboat bobbing gently in the middle of the East River at sunset drew curious stares from the crew of a passing oil tanker. Eight people in formal evening dress were dining lavishly around a table set up at the stern. From the tiny galley, chef Jean- Claude Nedelec, co-owner of Glorious Food, the Manhattan catering firm, and his assistants prepared the meal. After oysters topped with caviar, the first course was radicchio with creamed morels, followed by quail stuffed with foie gras, chanterelles in cream, smoked goose and duck breast and haricots verts with truffles. Then a seafood ragout was served with croutons and

title: WATSON LEADS TOURNEY BY 2
description: Tom Watson, who had not led a golf tournament going into the final round since capturing the British Open last July, came from 4 shots off the lead today to take the lead entering Sunday's last round of the MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT CANADIENS AND GAIN CUP FINAL
description: In one of their most special playoff victories, the Islanders defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4-1, tonight, winning their semifinal series and getting the chance for a record-equaling fifth straight Stanley Cup.

title: Susan L. Mayer and Dr. Stephen Cowan to Marry
description: Susan Lynn Mayer and Dr. Stephen Scott Cowan, graduates of Case Western Reserve University, plan to be married May 27. The ceremony is to take place at Congregation Habonim in New York, with Rabbi Bernard Cohn officiating.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: Last month, Bedford Town residents from the hamlets of Bedford, Bedford Hills and Katonah began receiving copies of a 34-page, 7-by-9-inch glossy booklet containing brief biographical sketches of the 31 members of the Bedford Police Department. Included are the date the individual policemen joined the force, their educational backgrounds and certifications and their law-enforcement specialties - such as burglary investigation and crime-scene analysis. The biographies are accompanied in most cases by a photograph of the officer being discussed.

title: MOVIES TEND TO SOAR ON WINGS OF PLAUSIBILITY
description: The first few minutes of any movie are as crucial to its success as are the first few seconds in the takeoff of a fully loaded 747 jumbo jet, lumbering heavily down the runway, gathering the extraordinary speed necessary to become airborne. And every time the plane does become airborne, it seems a miracle.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: HOW SHALL WE DEAL WITH COMPOSERS?

title: HEADLINERS;
description: In-Laws in Litigation It's a safe bet that Maneka Gandhi doesn't call her mother-in-law ''Mom.''

title: DANCE: A.B.T. OFFERS 'LES SYLPHIDES'
description: American Ballet Theater's Wednesday afternoon and evening programs in the Metropolitan Opera House featured works that are old favorites for many balletgoers.

title: RED GULLS
description: Thousands of sea gulls, attracted by garbage landfills, were posing sanitation problems a year ago in Concord and Manchester in New Hampshire - especially in Manchester, where they were discarding garbage bones and defecating in a reser- voir used for drinking water. The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service was asked to look into the problem.

title: BAR CARS INCREASE ON METRO-NORTH
description: -NORTH sold only 39 sandwiches on all its trains in March - hardly a sign of great commuter demand - and so last Monday the line stopped selling ham and cheese on rye and all the other combinations that 25,000 daily commuters were clearly happy to do without.

title: COSTA RICA ASKS U.S. FOR SMALL ARMS
description: Government officials said today that Costa Rica had asked the United States, along with Taiwan, Panama and Venezuela, for arms to improve their security forces in the aftermath of border problems with Nicaragua.

title: 50 YEARS FOR D. DUCK- NO WISEQUACKS, PLEASE
description: D onald Duck is busier than ever these days, in his 50th-birthday year, and he has little patience for preliminaries. ''Call me Donald,'' said Mr. Duck on a recent afternoon, welcoming a visitor to his suite at the Sherry Netherland. ''I never have wasted much time on intro-duck-tions,'' he quipped.

title: NONPROFIT CAMPS PREPARE FOR SEASON
description: WEST MILFORD WINTER'S dust is being swept out of cabins, fresh paint is being applied to dining halls and paths are being made ready for the onslaught of countless pairs of sneakers as camp directors and their staffs get ready to introduce thousands of disadvantaged children to fishing and canoeing, nature walks and camping.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEWED AS FACT AND FANTASY
description: PARIS

title: Giverny
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics Better Late Than Never
description: Picture Show at Last

title: FINDING HISTORICAL CLUES IN PHOTOGRAPHS
description: WITH his three books ''Abandoned New England,'' ''A Certain Slant of Light'' and ''Coastal New England'' - William F. Robinson, a photographer from Guilford, has established himself as an important historian of this region. His approach is somewhat unusual for a historian, however, in that he does not confine his research to one aspect, but rather, crosses over to make connections between history, art and literature.

title: Body of Missing House Aide Is Found in Baltimore Harbor
description: A body identified as that of a missing staff member of a House investigating subcommittee has been found in Baltimore Harbor, but officials said the death was not believed to have any connection with his investigative work.

title: Not Unemployed, But Uncounted
description: There are a number of us who are not counted in the unemployed statistics blithely reported with great pride by the Federal Government. These numbers, happily, have decreased during the past four years. The State of Connecticut also reports low unemployment percentages.

title: Carol Miller and Richard Levy Jr., Lawyers, Wed
description: Carol Miller and Richard Levy Jr., lawyers in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Michael A. Robinson performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: REPORT IS AWAITED ON USE OF AIRPORT
description: COUNTY officials are awaiting recommendations from a consultant on how to allocate terminal space at the County Airport among the various airlines that want to fly there.

title: Elizabeth F. McMorrow and R. J. Tuscanes Marry
description: Elizabeth Frieda McMorrow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. McMorrow of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Joseph Tuscanes, the son of Anne Tuscanes of Flushing, Queens, and the late Joseph Tuscanes. The Rev. Peter W. Jenkins performed the Unitarian-Universalist ceremony at the Community Church of New York.

title: Nassau Police Seek Escapee From Farm Unit at County Jail
description: The Nassau County police said today that they were looking for a convict who escaped from the County Jail at East Meadow.

title: THE THROES OF CREATION
description: In top-flight tournament play there

title: MANAGING THE GREAT MAN'S MEMORY
description: ADIEUX

title: PANEL SAYS CITY'S DROPOUT PROGRAM IS RUN POORLY
description: A new program intended to prevent academically deficient students in the city from dropping out of high school suffers from poorly defined goals, inadequate planning and insufficient financing, according to a study conducted by the Educational Priorities Panel, a nonprofit umbrella organization of civic and parent groups.

title: LEADER OF SENATE SEEKS A NEW HORIZON
description: HARTFORD OUT in the corridor the booming loudspeaker was summoning State Representatives to another roll-call vote, and in the front office legislators were waiting to confer with the Senate majority leader on pending bills and amendments.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AFTER an earthquake devastated towns and villages in Italy in November 1980, the Essex County community of Nutley pitched in to help one particularly hard-hit village - Torella, in the province of Avellino.

title: DAKOTA TOWN UPSET BY PLAN TO CLOSE SCHOOL
description: For 103 years a branch of the University of South Dakota has dominated the social and economic life of this small town. But earlier this week the American flag was flown at half-staff on the campus and the state flag was removed because the state plans to close the school.

title: CAMBODIAN TELLS OF REBEL DEFENSE
description: A Cambodian rebel leader says a Vietnamese offensive against his troops has been blunted and is unlikely to be resumed because of the imminent rainy season in Indochina.

title: Six Florida Delegates Are Contested by Hart
description: The Florida Democratic Party filled out its 143-member delegation to the national convention today, but some of the delegates chosen could lose their seats later this month because of a challenge by Gary Hart.

title: THEATER MAY GET A NEW LIFE
description: WHEN New Haven's Lincoln Theater closed its doors after a final screening of ''The Last Picture Show'' in September 1982, it was the end of an era for generations of patrons, who had flocked to the quaint theater on Lincoln Street since 1945 to see new foreign and classic American films.

title: THREE RINGS FULL OF EAST EUROPEANS
description: The prospect of spending every February in Eastern Europe, sitting in the cold under tents in Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland and Rumania is not a circumstance likely to arouse enthusiasm even among the most dedicated of travelers, yet every winter Irvin and Kenneth Feld can be found in and around Sofia, Budapest, Warsaw and Bucharest watching people walk on wires, swing from trapezes, dance with bears, jump off teeterboards and contort themselves just so Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus will look the way it does.

title: Shirt Tales
description: To the Editor: It is unfortunate that Mr. Kalb (''A Shirt's Tale,'' Travel, March 18) did not take his shirts to China. Laundry is one of the most ef

title: LILCO LOOKS TO U.S. FOR SHOREHAM DECISIONS
description: THE fate of the Shoreham nuclear power plant is as uncertain as ever, but the arena for the decision appears to have shifted. The events of the last few weeks hint strongly that the Long Island Lighting Company has given up on its search for a savior in Albany, just as it previously found no help in Hauppauge, and is now concentrating its efforts in Washington.

title:
OUTDOOR PLEASURES;
SATURDAY-NIGHT SUPPER
description: Not too long ago, a weekend supper for friends around the pool most often meant beach balls and burgers. And Mexican food, such as exists in steamy kitchens in Guadalajara and outposts of the Yucatan, was a secret shared only by travelers. Up north, border food - nachos, tacos, burritos and beans, and, of course, a fiery hot sauce - prevailed. These days, however, a few avid emissaries are showing Americans the regional Mexican cuisine, a

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: FOR THE SPECIALIST, BOOKS BY MAIL
description: The attitude of Americans toward travel books is changing. Travelers want to know more than what they find in the meat-and-potatoes guidebooks carried by many stores - what to see and where to stay. Among the reasons for the change of attitude are the appearance in recent years of adventure tour companies (whose tours make places like Nepal and Peru much more accessible); the interest in backpacking and bicycling, and a greater awareness of the environment. In general, according to bookstores that specialize in travel, more and more travelers want to take a closer look at other countries.

title: RUSSIAN TOUCH MARKS 'COPPELIA'
description: IT'S not hard to understand why

title: START IN PREAKNESS FOR DEVIL'S BAG IS PLACED IN DOUBT
description: Devil's Bag, who was held out of today's Kentucky Derby in favor of the shorter Preakness Prep and the Preakness Stakes, now may pass up those races and be rested indefinitely, his trainer, Woody Stephens, said today.

title: 2 JEWISH PAPERS BATTLE FOR L.I. MARKET
description: TWO Jewish newspapers are locked in a battle for advertising revenue and circulation among Long Island's 500,000-member Jewish community, with one of the papers saying that the competition is unfair because it is being subsidized by the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: Texas Dentist Chided Over His Claim in Ad
description: The Texas Board of Medical Examiners has found a dentist guilty of ''false, misleading and deceptive'' advertising because of his claim in a newspaper advertisement that gum disease was ''totally preventable.''

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: THE WORLD ; A Soviet Blast
description: At Peking

title: NEW GUERLAIN SHOP
description: On a trip to Paris three years ago, Dawn Mello, president of Bergdorf Goodman, wandered into the Guerlain perfume shop on the Champs- Elysees and was delighted with the way it looked and smelled. It just happened that Bergdorf's was planning a major renovation and already had a rotunda on its main floor that was very much like the Guerlain shop architecturally.

title: THE NEW LOOK IS ART DECO
description: AT the beginning of last summer, the restaurant in the Long Island Hotel in Center Moriches opened with a new look, a new menu and a new chef. The new look is actually a studied old look, a romantic interpretation of 1930's Art Deco with black, gray and white tile floors, lots of pink and gray, potted palms and mirrors.

title: HONORARY DEGREES FOR ARTHUR MILLER
description: AMONG the eight recipients of honorary degrees next Sunday at the University of Hartford's 27th annual commencement will be the playwright Arthur Miller and his wife, Inge Morath, the photographer.

title: NEW DEBATE ON STATE TAXES IS TAKING SHAPE
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN said last week that he had found some money he did not expect to have, and had decided to send it back to the people who provided it - the taxpayers.

title: SOUND ; REMOTE CONTROL DEVICES MAKE THE LISTENING EASY
description: Maybe we're all getting lazy. It certainly seems that way when you look at some of the latest stereo designs. No more getting out of your chair, off the couch or whatever else you may have been resting on. Now you can play records, start and stop tapes, change radio stations or volume levels by remote control.

title: PROM-GOERS GET WARNINGS ON ALCOHOL
description: The following article is based on reporting by Kathleen Ogle, a senior at Spotswood High School in Middlesex County, and Daniel Jackson and was written by Mr. Jackson.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Cross County Mart Plans Bargain Bash

title: MY NAME IS BILL, AND I'M AN ADDICT
description: -year-old lawyer. Dressed in a white turtleneck sweater, flannel shirt and jeans, he looks like a model out of the L. L. Bean catalogue.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Ready, Steady, Go! Volume One: With the Beatles, the Dave Clark Five, the Searchers, Cilla Black, Billy Fury and others. Thorn EMI 60 minutes.

title: A Productive Cow Is Dead
description: -A 19-year-old cow hailed as the most productive in the nation is dead after giving 54,000 gallons of milk.

title:
DINING OUT;
SETTING THE STAGE IN SCARSDALE
description: THE view of a parking lot and a gas station through the picture windows is far from inspiring, but it is quickly forgotten for the eye-catching details inside. Just beyond the wood-paneled entrance stairway with its massive, polished blond rails, a lavish etag ere displays bumper jars of figs, boxes of tomatoes, long, thick ropes of onions and dried red peppers, pineapples and pints and pints of strawberries and marks, on the left, the way to a cozy piano bar. Its ribbed, greenhouse walls - most beautiful after dark when pin lights multiply against the glass - give the feel of the festive deck on an oceanliner.

title: NASA Names 2 Astronauts For Spacelab Mission in '85

title: HARMONY IN TRADE URGED BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned today that efforts to compel allies to abide by American sanctions and jurisdiction were causing disputes that threatened ''the moral foundation of our common defense.''

title: YOUNG PROVE BRAVE AS HEART PATIENTS
description: PEDRO was playing with plastic men and monsters in a recreation room at the Children's Hospital of New Jersey here when he noticed a group of adults looking on. The 5-year-old dropped his toys and moved toward his visitors.

title: ISRAEL, DON'T TRY NAZIS
description: Israel faces a terrible dilemma. It wants to bring to justice every single Nazi criminal, to punish them and - to the infinitesimal degree that it is in its power - to avenge the victims. It wants to show that the Holocaust is not forgotten and to reanimate in the world's consciousness the horrors perpetrated against the Jews. It was the Nazi regime that Adolf Eichmann represented at his trial in 1961, just as Israel represented the six million dead.

title: THE ART OF DRINKING EER

title: PROSPECTS
description: Producing More Inflation

title: GUESTS AND THE WEEKEND
description: There is some truth to both the let-it-be-art and the let-it- happen approaches to weekend entertaining. Here, three people offer glimpses of how they make guests feel comfortable, and at the same time enjoy themselves. Lee Bailey, the author of ''Lee Bailey's Country Weekends'' and the forthcoming ''Lee Bailey's City Food,'' has a year-round house in Bridgehampton, L.I. Betsy Cronkite, the wife of the former CBS anchorman, spends summers on Martha's Vineyard. Lynn Wyatt, the Texas-based international socialite, moves to the south of France in summer. There is only one real ''secret'' to making a weekend run smoothly: careful planning. As obvious as this may seem, I am continually amazed at how haphazardly some people approach it. Maybe ''careful'' is not strong enough; perhaps the word should be ''meticulous.'' Whatever. Begin by working out the menu for each meal, then get as much of it done beforehand as can be managed. Make your chores simpler by having everything possible delivered, being sure there are enough soft drinks, spirits, mixers, wine, firewood, etc.

title: NEW GROUP HELPS FEMALE PRISONERS
description: Fran O'Leary remembers a time when she said she lived ''life on the installment plan,'' going in and out of prison.

title: Ali's Magic Touch He can fly like a butterfly and sting like a bee, but when
description: Muhammad Ali starts revealing the secrets of magic on television, he has gone too far. That, at least, is the view of the British Magical Society.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about the redesigned Museum of Modern Art, gives an incorrect reopening date. The correct date is Thursday, May 17.

title: WEEKENDS IN THE DORDOGNE
description: In a land of plenty, not far from the gentle Cher River, just beyond patches of wheat and corn fields, neatly ordered parks and chateaus, rests the D'Ornano family's country home. At La Renaudi ere, a carefully restored hunting lodge built before the French Revolution, there are rarely fewer than 12 at the table at any given meal. Here, swimming, hunting, tennis, golf and fishing fill the days, and lively dinners with family and friends take place around sunset.

title: Anne Burrows and M. W. Reid to Wed
description: A June 16 wedding is planned by Anne Katherine Burrows and Michael Whitelaw Reid, her parents, Kenneth G. Burrows and Joan O. Strand, both of Seattle, have announced.

description: A New York-based human rights organization says in a report that rights abuses against Nicaragua's Miskito Indian population have ended.

title: LATIN ISSUE: A WELL-ARMED NICARAGUA
description: The insurgency in El Salvador dominates public interest in Central America but, according to a United States general, ''a militarized Nicaragua is far more dangerous'' to United States interests in the region than the fighting in El Salvador. This officer and others interviewed say they believe the Reagan Administration will have to come to grips with the problem of a heavily armed Nicaragua. But they said it would be up to the White House and the State Department to devise a policy to deal with the issue.

title: Japanese Leaders Affirm U.S. Ties in Visit to India
description: Japan's Foreign Minister, meeting his Indian counterpart, said today that his nation hinged its foreign policy on its relationship with the United States.

title: DEMOCRATS START TO WORRY ABOUT HEALING THEIR SCARS
description: HOWELL RAINES AUSTIN, TEXAS S INCE his New Hampshire defeat, Walter F. Mondale has regarded most shows of confidence as a poisonous luxury. But with the approach of critical tests in Texas and Ohio, the former Vice President suggested that a sweep of these states, coming after his success in the Tennessee primary last week, sets him up to claim a nominating majority of delegates by the end of the primary season on June 5. In private, Mr. Mondale was even more assured. He confided to supporters his eagerness to plan a national convention that will be a festival of party unity ''rather than a brawl.''

title: CANADA'S JUDICIARY STARTS USING NEW POWERS
description: The Supreme Court of Canada has embarked on a new constitutional course by deciding the first case under the two-year-old Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

title: TABLE DESIGNS FOR SUMMER
description: No season offers more variety for entertaining than summer. Whether serving a lakeside lunch after a morning of canoeing or a barbecue supper on a city terrace at dusk, the well-organized host or hostess should have a stash of accouterments handy to suit the right occasion.

title: Republican Plan For Infrastructure
description: Over the past few weeks it has been disappointing to see newspaper headlines that dwelt on the conflict in the Democrat Party over how to fund repairs of our infrastructure. There was little mention of the funding plan Republicans in the House of Representatives had developed. We believe it can be done with less costly bonding and through a deeper look at our spending priorities in the proposed budget for fiscal 1985 and coming years, with no gasoline tax increase and no reinstatement of tolls.

title: AMERICAN TECHNOLOGY THRIVES IN PARIS
description: On Friday, at Symphony Space on upper Broadway, Composers' Forum and the American Center in Paris will present a concert of works by two Americans associated with IRCAM, the Institut de Recherche et Coordination Acoustique/Musique in Paris, founded and directed by Pierre Boulez. IRCAM is part of the Centre Nationale d'Art et de Culture Georges Pompidou which is devoted, its brochure proclaims, to the ''collaboration between scientists and musicians . . . to this Utopian marriage of fire and water.'' The Institute's name is bureaucratic French, its promotional language is grandiose French, and its funding is governmental French. But its intellectual and technological substance is primarily American.

THEATER;

Mr. Lewis sums up those crowded years in his autobiography, ''Slings and Arrows: Theater in My Life,'' to be published May 30 by Stein and Day Publishers, from which this article is excerpted.

Rumanian authorities said they scheduled an eight-nation international gymnastics tournament today as a tribute to Miss Comaneci.

description: WHEN replacing a broken pane of window glass, or when replacing the putty on a window because the old material is dried out and cracked, many do-it-yourself homeowners are faced with two chores that seem to pose a problem. One is getting all the old, hardened putty or glazing compound off without damaging the wood, and the other is doing a neat job of putting the new putty or glazing compound in place around each pane.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW ; DOING JUSTICE TO AN OLDER WAY OF THINKING AND SEEING
description: Nothing could be more surprisingly not of our time than the dreamlike world created in the photographs of Arnold Genthe. It is a world of noble men and beautiful women unmarred by any blemishes either moral or physical, a world of picturesque peoples and places where unrest and revolution do not exist, a world of soft lights and veiled shadows that cannot have been very real even in its own time, and now seems dead as the dodo.

title: Fresh Air for Eager Young Lungs
description: Jesse, then 10 years old, looked incredulously at the ocean and pronounced it ''the biggest swimming pool I've ever seen.'' Lamar, 7, found it remarkable that ''the houses and walls don't have graffiti written all over, and it's not dirty.'' Anthony, 11, said after his first hike that though his feet were feeling bad ''outside,'' he was feeling good ''inside.''

They should have read, ''Years later, in Buffalo, still pursuing this track, I was to venture my own contribution to the history of the Hottentots: a memoir, composed out of the air, of Jacobus Coetzee. The memoir went on growing till it had been absorbed into a first novel, 'Dusklands.' ''

title: SIPPING CHABLIS AT THE SOURCE
description: Someone once said that Chablis is to wine what Corot is to painting: three out of four are fakes. The analogy is a bit unfair. Genuine Chablis, from the town of Chablis in France, is, by its nature, the real thing. It may not always be very good, but it's genuine. It's those others: South African chablis, Bulgarian chablis, pink chablis, golden chablis, that make it all so complicated.

title: CHILDREN'S VOLUMES DONATED TO UCONN
description: BILLIE LEVY of West Hartford discovered that book collecting can be child's play while assembling more than 5,000 illustrated volumes for children over the last quarter of a century.

title: SALMON RESTORATION RECEEVES SETBACK
description: THIS was to be the year of the Atlantic salmon in Connecticut. Atlantic salmon experts had been predicting a 1984 Connecticut River run of 1,000 fish, double the previous best year's. There was talk of establishing a ''limited sport fishery'' on the Connecticut River by 1985.

title: CONSUMER RATES
David Kapel Wed To Miss Combier
description: Elizabeth Combier, a daughter of Julia Taschereau of New York and the late P. Hodges Combier, was married yesterday to David Kapel, a son of Regina Kapel of Brooklyn and the late Zelman Kapel. Rabbi David Pozner performed the cermony at the Harkness Ballet Foundation in Manhattan.

description: The African National Congress said at its Lusaka headquarters today that Swaziland had handed over four members of the group to South Africa.

title: Lasting Trauma Found After Child Sex Abuse
description: Children who are sexually exploited by pornographers or sex rings develop severe and long-lasting psychological problems similar to those associated with battlefield trauma or serious accidents, researchers have found.

title: U.S. MUST DISCIPLINE HEALTH-CARE MARKET
description: Controlling medical costs has become the Great American Shell Game. Congress puts a cap on Medicare payments for 467 medical procedures, and hospitals just pass the costs off to the states. States puts their own caps on Medicaid hospital payments, and hospitals just move the pea to private insurers and Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Congress caps payments to physicians in hospitals, and doctors move the pea outside the hospital to their offices or clinics where there are no caps.

title: COSMOS OF THE PAST DRAW FANS' CHEERS
description: Soccer balls bounced again today in the parking lots outside Giants Stadium. Inside, though, there were stronger reminders of the Cosmos' glory days in an exhibition match between the alumni and the current team.

title: SERVICE DISTRICTS HELPING MERCHANTS
description: SEVERAL Connecticut cities are looking into whether to follow New Haven and New Britain in using a little-known state law to help revive their commercial districts.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The double bass may not be the most likely of solo instruments, but the best-realized recital in a week full of first-rate debuts was the one Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall by Edwin Barker, who plays just that instrument.

title: JAPANESE INVESTMENT, A NEW WORRY
description: LAST fall, President Reagan issued a policy statement on foreign investment in the United States. In generous terms, he declared that such investment is always welcome, as long as it is based purely on economic considerations.

title: SEARCH FOR THE PENN STATION SNIPER HAS YIELDED FEW RESULTS
description: For more than two months, the police have been hunting for a gunman they believe is responsible for one killing and six other shootings in and around Pennsylvania Station. Despite an intensive effort, however, investigators say they have made little headway.

title: COUNCIL COMPARES COSTS IN STATE
description: FOR the cost of the average home in Greenwich, one could buy seven homes at the opposite end of the state and have a few thousand dollars left over, according to a tax watchdog group composed of business people in the state.

title: TOURS HELP WITH HOTELS AND TICKETS
description: Music hath charms to draw people from all walks of life to all parts of the globe. Those who love opera seek out the world's great houses and other sites offering lavish productions and top singers. Those with a taste for symphonic music try to catch a favorite conductor or soloist, and those who adore ballet head for a stage dominated by an admired dancer or choreographer.

title: MUSIC: A SHOW OF SOUND AND ART
description: ''The Sound/Art Show,'' which opened Tuesday night at the Sculpture Center, at 167 East 69th Street, underscores recent attempts to combine elements of the visual arts with music and raw sound.

description: GOVERNOR KEAN will narrate Aaron Copland's ''A Lincoln Portrait'' Saturday evening, when Montclair State College celebrates its 75th anniversary with a Diamond Jubilee Gala.

description: Bob Hope was honored for distinguished public service this week by a student organization that was founded by James Madison.

title: FLOATING ON THE WATERS OF WYOMING
description: CURT LEVIANT is the author of two novels, ''Passion in the Desert'' (Avon) and ''The Yemenite Girl'' (Bobbs-Merrill).

title: O'NEILL'S 'MOON'- A FLAWED MASTERPIECE
description: How many plays can you name which touch greatness without actually managing to be good? It would be hard to say confidently where you'd start the list - maybe with ''Hamlet,'' citing as authority T. S. Eliot's famous attack - but much easier to know where and when to end it. Eugene O'Neill could and did write awkwardly, cumbersomely, repetitively, and worse. Sitting through his work can be like standing beneath a landslide, with rock after rock bouncing painfully off your head. And yet the paradox is that it often, very often, seems a privilege to endure the onslaught, and for more than masochistic reasons. One is, after all, being battered into a level of consciousness where one sees and feels things no other playwright has confronted.

title: U.S. and Mexico Cooperating To Restrict Radioactive Steel
description: American officials are installing Geiger counters at every border crossing between this country and Mexico to prevent 600 tons of radioactive steel from entering the United States, the authorities say.

title: 3 Top Candidates to Help McGovern Pay Off Debt
description: The three remaining contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination have agreed to attend a fund-raising party May 31 to help pay off George McGovern's Presidential campaign debt and to finance television broadcasts by the former Senator from South Dakota, Mr. McGovern's office announced on Friday.

title: Garland a Coach It's not every junior college that can attract a $200,000-a-year baseball coach, but Aquinas in Nashville has done just that.
description: Wayne Garland , the 33-year-old right-hander whose pitching career was cut short by shoulder problems after he signed a 10-year, $2.2 million contract with the Cleveland Indians in 1977, has accepted a position as co-coach of the school's baseball team. Garland, who compiled a 55-66 career record, including a 20-7 season with the Baltimore Orioles in 1976, made his last major league appearance with the Indians in 1981. To his wife, Mary, the new job has a certain advantage for a family with four children: ''There are no road games.''

title: Jackson, Invoking 'Integrity,' Repeats Farrakhan Defense
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today strongly defended his continued association with Louis Farrakhan and said adamantly, ''I am not going to negotiate away my integrity trying to impress somebody.''

title: Amy Harvey Has Nuptials
description: Amy Louise Harvey, the manager of employee services at Kidder Peabody & Company in New York, was married yesterday to John Bernard Jardine, the district manager of the Middle Atlantic and Southeast territories for the mortgage and real estate division of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America in New York. The Rev. George A. Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: RANGE WAR IN ROSEBUD VALLEY
description: Jim Robbins is a freelance writer who contributes to The New York Times from Helena, Mont. HARP CRIES RING OUT AND a dozen frightened, year-old calves trot out quickly from behind a tangled mass of wild rose bushes and cottonwood trees along the meandering Rosebud Creek toward a circle of hay laid out in a large meadow. A man on horseback is glimpsed through the growth as he gallops swiftly toward the other end of the meadow, where he chases six more calves from the thicket into the open, their breath pouring like steam into the crisp air.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE

title: Adele Brown to Wed in June
description: Adele Quartley Brown, New York marketing manager for VideoStar Connections, a satellite transmission company, plans to be married June 9 to Dan Simon Nelken, an advertising and corporate photographer. The ceremony is to take place at the home of Miss Brown's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lovett of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Lovett, a limited partner in Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, was Secretary of Defense in the Truman Administration.

title: CHABLIS: THE LAND BEYOND THE LABEL
description: The home of the world's most famous white wine is a quiet village tucked away under the prow of a vine-covered hill that few visitors to France bother to see. But Chablis, which has lent its name to white wine the world over, is more than a celebrated wine-making village. It is also the gateway to northern Burgundy, that lesser known half of France's richest and best known province, which has everything its southern area can offer, plus fewer visitors to share it with.

title: THE NEW CHIC OF CHIFFON
description: Designer James Galanos has brought new life to an ordinary evening fabric.

title: Camilla Cramer Weds Michael Cronin
description: Camilla Bruce Cramer, the daughter of Camilla Spikes Ruffin of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Louis Cramer, was married yesterday to Michael Terrence Patrick Cronin, a son of William H. Cronin Jr. of New York, and Mary Cronin of Stratford, Conn. The Rev. Earl K. Gibson performed the ceremony at the West Market Street United Methodist Church in Greensboro.

title: ARMY ENGINEERS PROPOSE 3 ROUTES FOR WATER TUNNEL
description: -CONTROL experts with the Army Corps of Engineers say they have a foolproof plan to end flooding of the Passaic River Basin, but they still have to win basin-wide acceptance for their idea.

title: BE EUROPTIMISTIC
description: Europessimism. Fiasco and failure in Brussels. The Common Market collapsing. Some recent reports would make one think that green snakes hundreds of feet long were writhing through the streets of Brussels and that the Eurocrats had taken to the hills. But even those Americans who do not go as far as this still put the question: Were we right to back the European Community in the early days? Has it not turned out to be a flop? Was our support a plain mistaken investment?

title: GIFTS TO UNIVERSITIES RISE 6.2%, SURVEY FINDS
description: Gifts to universities and colleges increased by 6.2 percent in the 1982-83 academic year and reached a record total of $5.1 billion, a survey of more than 1,000 schools has found. But the gains were offset because costs, particularly for salaries, increased by 6.3 percent.

title: BUYERS' TASTES SHAPE THE DESIGN OF LAKESIDE HOUSES
description: IN 1967, a broker told Robert F. Lusk, a builder, that the Archdiocese of New York was selling a choice parcel of undeveloped land in the Town of Eastchester, in southern Westchester County.

title: THE NATION ; One Step Back,
description: One Step Ahead For the Economy

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION ; DINNER PARTY DREAM SEQUENCE
description: YEARS ago I overheard two women talking on the tennis court. ''But why do you have to do all that ironing today?'' asked one.

title: Chairman-Designate Of Jaguar Is Named
description: Hamish Orr-Ewing still enjoys puttering about the garage, tinkering with his 1929 Rolls Royce or his 1968 E-type Jaguar. ''I'm something of a mechanical nutcase,'' he admits. ''I was more or less born with gasoline in my bloodstream.''

title: I.M.F. Cites Inflation Rise WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) - Inflation has been increasing sharply in the developing world, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
description: During 1983, while industrial nations recorded their lowest annual inflation rate since 1972 - 5 percent - inflation among developing countries that do not produce oil surged to 54.1 percent, the I.M.F. said.

title: BUSINESSMAN WINS IN ECUADOR VOTE
description: A wealthy businessman who pledged to organize the private sector to provide food, homes and jobs won Ecuador's presidential election tonight.

title: BIGELOW TAKES ROWING TRIAL
description: John Biglow revived his hopes for an Olympic medal in singles sculling on calm Lake Carnegie today, winning at the United States rowing trials on the final stroke.

title: L.I. Pilot Dies as Plane Towing Glider Crashes
description: The pilot of a tow plane was killed today when his fabric-covered, singleengine aircraft stalled while towing a glider about 75 feet over the runway of the Brookhaven Airport, according to officials of the municipal airport.

title: A McLaren WinsAt San Marino
description: Alain Prost of France, driving a McLaren, won the San Marino Formula One Grand Prix today to extend his lead in the world drivers championship standing.

title: Svend Kragh-Jacobsen Dies at 74 in Denmark
description: Svend Kragh-Jacobsen, dean of Danish dance, drama and film critics and an internationally recognized authority on the history of the Royal Danish Ballet and its celebrated 19th-century choreographer, August Bournonville, died Saturday in Copenhagen. Mr. Kragh-Jacobsen had been in poor health since he was injured in a automobile accident three years ago. He was 74 years old.

title: A WARNING SIGNAL
description: For more than a week now Israelis have been living with a devastating piece of news: the uncovering of an alleged Jewish terrorist underground operating in the occupied West Bank. The arrest of 19 settlers has been followed by a string of official leaks: that the suspects admitted planting bombs on Arab buses, that they killed three persons at the Hebron Islamic University last July, that other terrorist cells planned further attacks on Palestinian students.

title: MANY SALVADOR VOTERS, BUT A LACK OF OPTIMISM
description: Antonio Gallejas, a schoolteacher and the father of three children, took a thick black crayon this morning and voted for Jose Napoleon Duarte, the presidential candidate of the moderate Christian Democrats.

title: No Headline
description: Now Judge Legal Services Legally Having failed in three years of guerrilla warfare to destroy the Federal Legal Services Corporation, President Reagan is now pursuing the campaign above board. He tried to strangle the program through ''recess'' appointees, illegally evading Senate confirmation. Congress responded by denying these directors the power to strip funding from disfavored poverty law offices. Now Mr. Reagan has finally done his minimum legal duty and properly nominated 11 board members.

title: U.S. Can Avert '1984' If It's Strong, Bush Says
description: Vice President Bush said Saturday that the United States could avoid the doomsday predictions made by George Orwell in the novel ''1984'' if the nation and its allies ''stand together, firm and strong, in defense of our freedom.''

title: 11 Freight Cars Derail In Columbia River Gorge
description: Eleven cars of an 83-car westbound Union Pacific freight train derailed in the Columbia River gorge Saturday night, railroad officials said.

title: MYSTERY WRITERS CELEBRATE NEW YORK'S INTRIGUE
description: New York City, which has long been the capital of the country's mystery-publishing industry, appears in myriad lights - sometimes strange, sometimes many-splendored - in the pages of recent mystery novels.

title: Thomas E. Drohan Dies at 56; McKesson's Chief Executive
description: Thomas E. Drohan, former president and chief executive officer of the McKesson Corporation in San Francisco, died of cancer Friday at Marin General Hospital in San Rafael, Calif. He was 56 years old and lived in Kentfield, Calif.

description: Rafael Perez of Costa Rica, who has qualified for the Olympics, won the Long Island Marathon in the slow time of 2 hours 23 minutes 8 seconds this morning at Eisenhower Park.

description: Gary Hart is looking to his home state of Colorado for help for his sagging Democratic Presidential campaign.

description: Nadia Comaneci, whose perfect scores in gymnastics at the 1976 Olympics made sports history, bade a tearful farewell to competition today.

description: Hours before the voting in El Salvador's presidential runoff ended, 115 young Salvadoran men and women wearing yellow blazers stood outside polling places in 18 Salvadoran cities and interviewed nearly 2,000 voters.

title: BUSY WEEK FOR TREASURY AUCTIONS
description: Treasury auctions dominate the debt securities calendar this week, starting with $8 billion of bills on Monday and followed by $6.5 billion of three-year notes Tuesday, $5.25 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $4.75 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.

title: Laurie Jacoby, an Actress, And Lee Schneider Marry
description: Laurie Ruth Jacoby and Lee J. Schneider were married yesterday in the Old Tappan, N.J., home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Dr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Jacoby. Rabbi Selig Salkowitz performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSIT UNION HEAD SAYS LABOR RELATIONS HAVE DETERIORATED
description: Accusing the Transit Authority of using ''Gestapo tactics,'' John E. Lawe, the president of the agency's largest union, said yesterday that relations between union and management had deteriorated seriously. At the same time, he reiterated his call for a union seat on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 28 Poles Reported Charged In May Day Demonstrations
description: Prosecutors have filed criminal charges against at least 28 of 100 people detained in May Day disturbances in the Gdansk area, press reports said today.

title: BABY BOOM GENERATION TURNING 30
description: ''MY career as a child prodigy is over,'' a pop music critic intoned recently on the occasion of his 30th birthday. A month before she turned 30, a travel agent told a plastic surgeon, ''I've lived long enough with this nose.'' A magazine sales manager bought a cooperative apartment at age 29, and not long after that she married and became the stepmother of two teen-agers.

title: THATCHER FOES ASSAIL VISIT BY SOUTH AFRICAN
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa is to visit London early next month, and the Government announcement has stirred opposition protests and warnings of mass demonstrations by opponents of apartheid.

title: AD AGENCY FOR ARAB MARKET
description: In 1980, when Muhammad Ali became the spokesman for Toyota in Saudi Arabia, his picture appeared on billboards, his voice blared from radios and sales of Toyota cars and trucks in the kingdom increased by 18 percent.

title: VOTING FOREIGN POLICY
description: In 1960, the new Republican Presidential nominee, Richard M. Nixon, assembled 36 party elders at a midnight meeting at the Blackstone Hotel in Chicago to help him choose his running mate. The Governor of Illinois, William G. Stratton, offered this advice to the nominee: ''You can say all you want about foreign affairs, but what is really important is the price of hogs in Chicago.''

title: Helicopter Crash in Finland
description: A sightseeing helicopter crashed into a crowd of spectators at an auto race today and exploded. The police said 4 people were killed and 25 were injured in Finland's worst helicopter accident.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE ; BRAVES WIN PAIR FROM EXPOS
description: Mike Jorgensen lined a pinch-hit, two-run single with one out in the eighth, and Dale Murphy hit an inside-the-park homer in the ninth as the Atlanta Braves rallied to beat Montreal, 9-8, after wasting a 6-0 first-inning lead to sweep today's doubleheader.

description: LESLIE BENNETTS

title: SHELTERING OF MORE IN ARMORY IS RULED OUT, GOODMAN SAYS
description: After six weeks of negotiations involving city and state officials, Governor Cuomo has dropped a disputed plan to house an additional 250 homeless men in a landmark armory on the Upper East Side, State Senator Roy M. Goodman announced yesterday.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: New Hall of Famers Two years after the last induction into the Madison Square Garden Hall of Fame, Garden officials plan to admit 10 more notables in ceremonies at the arena on June 12.

title: On the Record ; Jackson on Voting Rights
description: Living under the state of apartheid our faces were held low in shame, objects of ridicule just 20 years ago. As we fought to change our predicament state officials threatened the president of our institution, threatened to discredit our diploma and take away our accreditation.

description: The National Park Service will seek airspace restrictions over the most popular part of Yosemite National Park to control sightseeing flights.

title: Four Tie for Lead
description: Sally Little, recovering from ailments that sidelined her eight months last season, fired a 3-under-par 69 today to move into a four-way tie for the lead after two rounds of the $200,000 Potamkin Cadillac Classic.

title: LEADER IN ALASKA
description: William A. Egan, who became Alaska's first elected Governor after leading its drive for statehood, died yesterday in Providence Hospital in Anchorage. He was 69 years old and lived in Anchorage.

title: MONDAY, MAY 7, 1984 International
description: Salvadorans turned out to vote for President in the first such election the military has not interfered with in more than 50 years. The voting took place in circumstances less confused than they were in the preliminary round March 25. Guerrilla harassment was negligible, officials said. (Page A1, Column 1.) Panama's first Presidential election in 16 years brought out many voters in orderly proceedings. The candidates are an 82-year-old physician and three-time former president, Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, and Nicolas Ardito Barletta, a former vice president of the World Bank. (A13:1.)

title: Dr. Lisa Vosburgh and Dr. Peter H. Stone Marry
description: Dr. Lisa Vosburgh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lee F. Vosburgh of Columbus, Ohio, formerly of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Howard Stone, a son of Ronnie Stone of Springfield, N.J., and Harvey Stone of Florham Park, N.J. Rabbi David Whiman performed the ceremony at the Habitat, an estate in Belmont, Mass.

Michael Tilson Thomas, who had been planning two months of opera at the Welsh National Opera, had a falling out with his director and found an unexpected gap in his schedule. When the New York Philharmonic found itself this spring with many concerts and no conductor, these conductors - and others - came running to help.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Business of Golf Amateur golf is big business, as almost any business professional can tell you. According to one survey, 81 percent of the chief executives of the 500 largest corporations are golfers, and that is hardly a coincidence. The course, after all, has long been a favorite place for executives to get to know one another away from the formal and sometimes forbidding atmosphere of the office, and to develop the personal relationships that often pay professional dividends.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Personal Health column in The Living Section on March 14 incorrectly described the speed with which 1,000 milligrams of vitamin C is excreted in the urine. The rate varies greatly from person to person, depending partly on the amount of the vitamin already present in the blood.

title: Cray Gets Japan Order
description: Japan's domestic communications monopoly has ordered a $119 million supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis. The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation said Friday that the computer, used in designing patterns for large integrated circuits, will be installed by August at its Musashino Laboratory.

description: Michael Jackson gave his mother a red Rolls-Royce at her birthday party Saturday. The assistant manager of the Bistro Garden restaurant said the beige-topped auto was tied with a huge white bow and parked outside.

description: Stephen J. Sweeney has been named chief executive of the Boston Edison Company, effective May 24. Mr. Sweeney will succeed Thomas J. Galligan Jr., who will continue to be chairman.

description: Drugs and alcohol are are banned under the Islamic code that President Gaafar al-Nimeiry imposed last September.

description: A man who had reported his elderly mother and stepfather missing has been charged with slaying the couple, whose bodies were found in an upstate New York park, the authorities said today.

title: DIENBIENPHU

The news reached Geneva just as diplomats from nine nations were beginning to explore a solution to the conflict.

title: ERNIE BARNES: AN ATHLETIC ARTIST
description: LOS ANGELES TEN o'clock in the morning and Ernie Barnes is hard at work, dabbling oil onto canvas. Morning light is best, which is why he is working now, even though here in his garage there are no proper windows and he must resort to fluorescent tubes.

title: Marauders for Rent, by Landlords
description: Students of the bizarre in crimes must turn to the memory of Burke and Hare to find any as ghoulish as those charged by Manhattan's District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, in indicting 22 men for harassment of tenants. Burke and Hare, the Edinburgh killers in the 1820's, murdered to produce corpses for medical schools that could not buy them legally. Mr. Morgenthau accuses his suspects of filling apartment houses with prostitutes, derelicts and drug addicts to drive out the dwellers of rent-controlled units, and of following with force when these tactics failed.
