description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 7: MONDAY Chemed CorpLouisiana-PacificCowles BrdcstMeredith CorpGeneral MotorsRaychem CorpJefferson-Pilot

title: Valerie Seiling Is the Bride OfDr.MarkJeffreyGerber
description: The marriage of Valerie Ann Seiling, an associate in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, to Dr. Mark Jeffrey Gerber, a resident at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, took place yesterday. Rabbi Philip Bentley performed the ceremony in the chapel at Fort Wadsworth, S.I.

title: Washington Watch; HOMEOWNERS' TAX LOOPHOLE
description: ASHINGTON

title: Lotto Winner Charged
description: A 34-year-old Cuban immigrant who won more than $2 million in a New York Lotto contest last year was arrested yesterday and charged with abducting a 15-year-old boy at knifepoint and sexually assaulting him, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Count Basie on April 27 incorrectly quoted a jazz critic's description of the Basie band's rhythm section and omitted the name of the critic. He is Whitney Balliett of The New Yorker, and he wrote that the section ''put wheels on all the beats in the bar.''

title: YANKEES END SLIDE, BEAT BREWERS BY 8-4
description: CRAIG WOLFF

title: Dede Seeber and David P. Boyd Marry
description: Judith Ann Seeber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Livingstone Seeber of Fairfield, Conn., and David Parker Boyd, a son of Mrs. Richard M. Boyd of Kenilworth, Ill., and the late Mr. Boyd, were married yesterday. The Rev. Loring Ensign performed the ceremony at the Southport (Conn.)

title: South African Energy
description: South Africa has announced a relaxation of fuel-saving measures and released figures indicating that the embargo imposed by oil-exporting countries because of South Africa's racial segregation policies was weakening. Mineral and Energy Affairs Minister Danie Steyn told Parliament Friday that the maximum premium South Africa is paying for a barrel of oil has fallen to $1.90, from $8 to $10 in 1980. He said the speed limit for freeways would be raised and restrictions on after-hours gasoline purchases and the use of fuel for sport might be eased.

title: A CRY FOR PEACE SILENCED IN BEIRUT
description: A peace march planned for today was canceled after its Moslem and Christian organizers became convinced that the demonstrators would probably be fired on by militiamen.

title: Violence in India Continues
description: One person was killed and four were wounded today in a two-hour gun battle between Sikh militants and paramilitary troops in this Sikh holy city. The authorities here said the slain man was watching the gun battle, which came after a grenade attack by Sikhs on a police patrol.

title: LARGE TURNOUT IN PANAMA PRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: Panama held its first presidential election in 16 years today, a contest between an 83-year-old physician who is a three-time former president and an economist who has the backing of the military.

title: Northern Ireland Riots Continue for Second Day
description: Police arrested 17 people in Northern Ireland early today during a second day of riots marking the anniversary of the death in 1981 of an Irish Republican Army hunger striker.

title: France Seeks Forest Parley
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France would propose a world conference to save forests, particularly those threatened by acid rain. Mr. Mitterrand made his proposal in a message to the European Associations for the Defense of Nature, saying, ''The most urgent question for Europe is to safeguard the forest devasted by acid rains.''

title: Advertising; AD MAN'S CREATIVE SIDELLINE
description: A DVERTISING people frequently have other equally creative lives.

title: ...AS ONLY THE OILERS REMAIN
description: The odds sound stacked, but Mike Bossy, for one, isn't sure he likes the numbers.

title: Mayor of Show Business
description: The price of fame is high. Mayor

title: IN SLUMS, FIELDS AND A HALL OF GRADUATES, JACKSON STRIVES TO TURN ON HOPE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson returned to his college today, slipped on a purple robe backstage and emerged with a glowing smile to urge students to stand up for their dignity.

title: John Henry WinsThe Golden Gate
description: Chris McCarron rode 9-year-old John Henry to a two-length victory over Silveyville in a course record 2 minutes 13 seconds over the 1 3/8- grassy mile to win today's $344,200 Golden Gate Handicap at Golden Gate Fields.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp. has elected Lonnie A. Arnett controller.

title: RANSEY STILL SITS AS ODD MAN OUT
description: ROY S. JOHNSON

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Happy Returns

title: NO TELLING IF METS CAN CAPTURE YANKEE FANS
description: MURRAY CHASS

title: HISS-CHAMBERS CASE DRAMATIZED ON WNET
description: JOHN CORRY

title: CONCERT: JAMACAIN POETRY
description: LINTON KWESI JOHNSON gave one of New York's best attended, most danceable poetry readings Friday at Irving Plaza.

title: A CUBAN WITH CLOUT
description: JOE LAPOINTE

title: WALKER SCORES 3 TIMES AS GENERALS WIN , 49-17
description: WILLIAM N. WALLACE

title: PARK SLOPE: NEW FACES, NEW SHOPS AND NEW WORRIES OVER ITS GROWTH
description: Peggy Greenawalt was telling an acquaintance that in the last few years she had moved from a house in Greenwich, Conn., to a Madison Avenue apartment in Manhattan to a brownstone in Brooklyn. ''What happened?'' the man asked her sympathetically. What happened is the story of Park Slope's continuing surge in popularity. The pace of revival in this Brooklyn neighborhood of Victorian brownstones shaded by Norway maples and ginkgos reflects the notion that the traditional meaning of trading up has changed for many New Yorkers.

title: ISRAELI GROUP SAYS IT INTENDS TO CURB 'ORTHODOX COERCION'
description: A group seeking to counter what it calls ''Orthodox coercion'' has been formed in Israel, and its founders say they hope to to be able to influence the general elections in July.

title: CAP SOUGHT ON FOREGIN LOAN RATE
description: ROBERT A. BENNETT

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ELBOWING THE SEDUCER. By T. Gertler. 306 pages. Random House. $16.95. He wanted to read words that connected to something true,'' writes T. Gertler of one of her characters, a literary editor named Howard Ritchie. ''He wanted to be disarmed, he wanted to be aroused. He was listening for a voice that unmistakably, stubbornly insisted on itself.'' Though it soon becomes evident that Howard is not exactly an admirable human being, he does emerge as a discerning and tough- minded editor, and his standards of literary excellence are fulfilled not only by the fictional heroine of this novel - a young writer named D. Reeve - but also by T. Gertler, the author of ''Elbowing the Seducer.''

title: TROOPS ARE SENT TO COPPER AREAS
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt called out some National Guard troops today to keep the peace in two copper-mining communities where weekend violence erupted in a 10-month-old strike.

title: METHODIST CHURCH FORESEES RENEWAL
description: American Methodists, who trace their roots to the early days of the Republic, are facing the start of their third century with many leaders calling for a burst of evangelistic spirit to stem recent declines.

title: Search for the Missing Fails In Raft Accident in Potomac
description: Police harbor patrols searched the muddy Potomac River without success today for four people missing and presumed dead in a rafting accident just north of the capital.

title: CRACKDOWN ON COUNTERFEITNG
description: STEVE LOHR

title: BUYOUTS SHINE AS STOCKS DRIFT
description: T HERE is nothing like the announcement of

title: Confiscated 'Drug Farm' Brings Treasury $214,000
description: More than 200 acres of land and a secluded, luxurious log cabin reported to have been a distribution center in a large illegal drug operation were sold at auction Saturday for the benefit of the Federal Treasury.

title: HOLLYWOOD THRIVING ON VIDEO-CASSETTE BOOM
description: The video cassette, long underrated by Hollywood as a means of distributing movies to the public and feared as a potential drain on movie-theater attendance, is now becoming an important moneymaker for film studios.

title: STAGE: NEW KOPIT PLAY
description: FRANK RICH

title: Fewer Labor Pacts Due For Renegotiation in '84
description: A total of 595 labor contracts affecting 344,000 workers in Middle Atlantic states are up for renegotiation in 1984, the fewest in recent years, the United States Labor Department said today.

title: OUTDOORS: FISHING THE AMAWALK IN NOSTALGIC RETURN
description: THE best time to go fishing, said a very wise man, is when you can. So the best time to open a new season must be as soon as you can, but under no circumstances later than the first week in May, unless kept from doing so by storm, tax audit, or a broken casting arm.

title: HISPANIC SUPPORT FOR EMPLOYER SANCTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: OF THE MUGGERS IN MADRID AND POLITICAL HAYMAKING
description: The radio spot is riveting: The sound of smashing glass. Fleeing footsteps. The whine of a police siren. Then an announcer's voice, ''Every 60 seconds, somewhere in Spain, a crime is being committed.''

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BROOKLYN DEVELOPER TRIES APPROACH ON 2 FRONTS
description: A two-year effort by state and city officials to strike a balance on the Brooklyn waterfront between commercial development and the preservation of industrial jobs has taken a new twist.

title: SEAGRAM'S LABEL USED
description: After years of handling the soft drinks of other companies, the Coca- Cola Bottling Company of New York is preparing to offer the country its own line, marketed under the Seagram's label.

title: THOSE 'OBSCENE' SALARIES
description: See the obscene auto executive. He is living off the fat of the land: drawing a million-dollar salary, plus a million-dollar bonus, plus rewarding stock options, plus plush perks.

title: TAX PROPOSALS SPUR CONFUSION
description: A NY day now, possibly as early as tomorrow, the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means committees are expected to reconcile their bills governing the taxing of options traded on commodity and stock exchanges. Essentially, the new rules are aimed at giving options traders the same maximum tax on profits, 32 percent, to which futures traders have been subject since 1981.

title: Arrest of a Journalist In Nicaragua Protested
description: Employees of La Prensa, Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper, issued a statement Saturday protesting the arrest of a reporter under the Government's censorship law.

title: Pincay CompletesA Big Weekend
description: Laffit Pincay Jr., who won the 110th Kentucky Derby aboard Swale on Saturday, returned to Hollywood Park today and captured the $221,300 Century Handicap with Interco.

title: BOND CURB IS DEBATED IN CONGRESS
description: JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

title: No Headline
description: A team of Dallas experts this evening led their opponents here by a margin that appeared to be decisive in the playoffs to determine the 1984 United States team in the world championships in Seattle.

title: The Debt Doctors Confer
description: This week's special gathering of central bankers to discuss the world's debt crisis will produce no new agreements; it's a conference, not a negotiation. But it's a welcome demonstration of initiative.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Urges Harmony Talks
description: Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, has urged Prime Minister Robert Mugabe to convene a broad-based conference to resolve the country's growing political and security problems.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH ON 5TH AVE. TO PROTEST SOVIET TREATMENT OF JEWS
description: Thousands of protesters - many carrying photographs of imprisoned dissidents, many shouting slogans about religious freedom and bravery and perseverance - marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday to protest the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption with an article about the newly discovered Donizetti opera, ''Elisabeth,'' in some copies yesterday incorrectly described an autograph page from the score. The vocal parts were originally written in French and, above them, an Italian translation was later added by the composer.

title: COMPUTER-AIDED BLACK NETWORK WON LOUISIANA FOR JACKSON
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson landed here Friday to begin a 21-hour campaign run through the city and into the countryside, there was his state coordinator, Sherman Copelin, smiling. Arrayed behind Mr. Copelin was a black political network three decades in the making.

title: Weinberger Answers Queries Of Callers on BBC Talk Show
description: Some 400 callers from Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia jammed phone lines to the BBC World Service today to ask Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger about United States policies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Paradoxically, one of our main aims was achieved. As soon as we called off the march all of the militias stopped fighting and Beirut enjoyed one of its quietest nights in months.''

title: ASTROS ROUT METS AND GOODEN
description: There were 39,294 fans at Shea Stadium yesterday, the Mets' second- largest crowd of the season, and most had come to see the much-publicized pitching duel between Houston's Nolan Ryan and the Mets' Dwight Gooden.

title: OF HEATERS AND RELIEF IN SPRING
description: Spring brings special relief to several thousand state employees who work at the 22-story State Capitol in Tallahassee. They can stop hiding their electric space heaters and take them home until next winter.

title: One Remedy for Child Abuse
description: The term ''child abuse'' covers a spectrum of injuries, from slaps or fondlings to beatings and rape. The offender can be a harassed or ill parent, a pedophile or a psychotic. The victim, however, is always a child, cruelly betrayed by adults. Often the child lacks words to describe what's happened; sometimes he or she is too young for any speech.

title: TALKING BUSINESS WITH SIGLER OF CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL ; SHIFTING HEADS OF DIVISIONS
description: The Champion International Corporation, a forest products company based in Stamford, Conn., has just finished the first year of an unusual series of executive changes.

title: A BIT OF DIPLOMACY IN THE HASBRO DEAL
description: When he graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1962 with a degree in political science, Stephen D. Hassenfeld toyed with the idea of a diplomatic career. In the final analysis, though, the prospect of selling G.I. Joe and Mr. Potato Head dolls, to name two products, for Hasbro Industries had more appeal than life in Foggy Bottom.

title: Y.&R. Gets Ronzoni Ads
description: Foods agency since 1924, got a

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $24.1 million from the sale of its Avnet Inc. shareholdings.

title: CANADIAN GENERAL INVESTENTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Headline
description: Chess:New York Tourney Winner Lost Only Once in 9 Games

title: 1 KILLED AND 23 HURT IN PANAMA AS RIVALS CONTEST VOTE RESULT
description: Gunfire erupted this evening as supporters of rival presidential candidates clashed in downtown Panama City. First-aid workers and officials at Santo Tomas Hospital here said one man was killed and at least 23 people were wounded by bullets or rocks.

title: Butane Tank Cars Derailed Upstate
description: City schools were closed today and the central part of the city was cordoned off after the derailment of four railroad tanker cars loaded with highly flammable liquid butane.

title: SHOLOM ALEICHEM'S LEGACY RECALLED
description: They celebrated the 125th birthday of Sholom Aleichem Sunday night at the 67th observance of his death, a memorial that each year follows the instructions of the Yiddish writer's unusual last testament, a will that made his legacy one of laughter.

title: POP-JAZZ: AL JARREAU SINGS WITH BAND AT RADIO CITY
description: AL JARREAU, who had to postpone his scheduled appearances at Radio City Music Hall some months ago to undergo a tonsillectomy, finally appeared at the hall for three shows last weekend. The singer was in high spirits and in excellent voice.

title: Larry Stock, 87, ComposerAnd Lyricist of Pop Songs
description: Larry Stock, the composer and lyricist who wrote the Fats Domino hit ''Blueberry Hill'' and many other popular songs over a 60-year career, died last Friday in the Country Manor Rest Home here. He was 87 years old.

title: Dormitory Authority Offers Cornell Issue
description: A $100 million revenue bond issue by the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York was tentatively priced yesterday by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds, for Cornell University, were rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: THE DEFICIT CLOCK
description: Recent events have made clear what anyone steeped in the timeless ways of Washington knew all along - that the road back to something resembling a balanced Federal budget will be long, hard, uphill and as full of political potholes as one of Mayor Ed Koch's Manhattan avenues.

title: DOLLAR UP ON RATE FEAR, GERMAN STRIKE THREAT
description: The dollar closed today at its highest level in three months in European foreign exchange trading, bolstered by the twin fears of higher interest rates in the United States and the possibility of widespread strikes in the West German metal industry.

title: 6 Poles Are Indicted In '83 Death of Youth
description: The Government indicted two policemen, two doctors and two ambulance attendants today in the beating death of a teen-age Solidarity supporter, Grzegorz Przemyk, in Warsaw a year ago.

title: DISPUTE OVER THEATER SPLITS CHICAGO CITY COUNCIL
description: The Chicago Theater, an opulent State Street movie palace where Ronald Reagan announced his engagement to Jane Wyman, is at the center of a controversy that has pitted the city and preservationists against the building's owners.

title: No Headline
description: Comptroller Bank Move Expected

title: 4 PRIMARIES TODAY VIEWED S CRUCIAL
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates campaigned vigorously yesterday toward a series of primaries today that are expected to determine whether the party's nomination battle continues or begins to wind down to an inevitable victory for Walter F. Mondale.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEFIANT BEIRUT CABINET NOMINEE RELENTS
description: A Moslem Shiite leader who had refused to join the new 10-member coalition Government changed his mind today after he was named Minister of State in charge of southern Lebanese affairs and of rebuilding war-damaged areas. The decision appeared to remove a major obstacle to the official appointment of the Cabinet.

title: South Africans In Steel Accord
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced today at its annual meeting that it would withdraw two unfair trade petitions against South African steelmakers after they had voluntarily agreed to reduce shipments to the United States by about 40 percent. South Africa, which shipped 557,000 tons of steel to the United States last year, thus joins Mexico and Brazil in agreeing to reduce steel shipments to the United States. David M. Roderick, U.S. Steel's chairman, said that, despite these agreements, his company would continue to push for a legislative quota on imports, which rose to 26 percent of domestic consumption in the first quarter.

title: Nigeria Plans Budget Cuts
description: Nigeria's military head of state, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, announced a tough austerity budget today for 1984 featuring hefty cuts in Government spending, higher interest rates and cuts in credit growth.

title: A WAR NEW YORK CAN'T WIN ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME RISE AND RIDERSHIP DROPS FOR NEW YORK CITY SUBWAY SYSTEM
description: Major crime went up, ridership went down and passenger comforts - from clean windows to doors that work - became harder to find on the city's subway system this year, transit officials said yesterday.

title: THE ISLANDERS GET TWO NEW FACES
description: Their names are so familiar they

title: METAL CONCERN'S RECOVERY STRATEGY
description: Metallgesellschaft, the giant West German mining and metals conglomerate, has been struggling.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Washington Talk page April 21, about publicity for liberal causes, misidentified a public relations man who is opening a Washington office. He is Richard P. Pollock.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $186,000.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TUESDAY, MAY 8, 1984 International
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte declared himself the winner of El Salvador's runoff Presidential election. Mr. Duarte, the candidate of the moderate Christian Democratic Party, called on all Salvadorans to work to bring peace to the country. (Page A1, Column 1.) Violence marred Panama's election. Government officials said one person was killed and eight were wounded in shooting that erupted between backers of rival candidates who both claimed they had won the presidential election. (A1:1.)

title: Man Killed Near Home Of U.S. Envoy in Peru
description: A suspected terrorist was killed and another was wounded Sunday in a gunfight with the police outside the home of the United States Ambassador, the police said today.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $108,000 for the quarter and $499,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $68,000 for the quarter and $447,000 for the year.

title: AMERICANS' ABRIDGED RIGHTS TO GO ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FINE ART OF INTERPRETING IN A MIAMI COURT
description: When a cocaine smuggler shouted a Spanish phrase while being hauled out of court after sentencing, it fell to the interpreter to tell the judge he had meant something like, ''That really takes the cake!''

title: LARGEST ZALE DIVISION PICKS A&S EXECUTIVE
description: Changes in the executive suites of the nation's leading retailing companies are nothing new. But Melvin A. Wilmore and the move he is about to make are something special.

title: 6 in Cocaine Ring Get Prison Terms
description: Six men convicted of operating a multimillion- dollar cocaine network were sentenced to prison today in Federal District Court here.

title: TESDATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago quarter net and revenue includes gain of $1,358,000 from the sale of warrants.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE-INTERCOMP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NICARAGUA BARS BROADCAST OF CATHOLIC LETTER
description: Nicaragua barred a radio station from broadcasting the text of a letter signed by thousands of Catholics supporting bishops in a call for Government talks with rebels, a church official said today.

title: Steel Import Curb Opposed
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that import quotas sought by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America would cost Americans $768 million a year in higher prices.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for 1984
description: Year-ago results have been restated and include $33 million, or 82 cents a share, of prior years' income.

title: NEW YORK ; THE CITY'S SPLIT TAXES
description: Do you remember the real estate capital gains tax that the developers said was so terminally flawed that it would not only raise no money but would also have a ''chilling'' effect on the real estate industry in New York City? That was the tax that the big operators persuaded Mayor Koch and Governor Carey and the State Legislature to repeal in 1982 after being in effect only six months.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Houston Natural Gas debentures, long-term notes and industrial revenue bonds were lowered to A-2 from A-1 by Moody's.

title: POLLOCK PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MR. STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $1,000. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effective March 24.

title: Why Stigmatize Social Security?
description: Sometime soon, says Treasury Secretary Regan, the Government must ''rethink'' Social Security: ''At the lower end of the scale we shouldn't do anything. But at some cutoff point we should ask why a person . . . should receive anything.''

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: Nat Krinsky, All-American At City College and a Coach
description: Nat Krinsky, an all-America basketball player at City College in 1921 and later a longtime coach at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, died early Sunday morning. Mr. Krinsky, who had been ill with a heart ailment, was 85 years old.

title: SYSTONETICS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $361,000. c-Net loss.

title: A TUG OF ALLEGIANCES AND THE MILITARY INDUSTRY
description: In 1982, the Pentagon gave Sol Love, a former aerospace executive, a contract to study the nation's industrial base. Over the next two years, Mr. Love earned more than $200,000 and, while officially still working on that contract, became an adviser to top Pentagon officials and also serving as a paid consultant to one of the nation's top aerospace companies.

title: Serve and Volley
description: Each afternoon for the last two weeks, Ivan Lendl, the tennis star, went to a course near his Greenwich, Conn., home and played 54 holes of golf. Each evening, or whenever the schedule permitted, he came home and watched the Islander-Canadien playoff series on television.

title: MUSIC: SONGS, SINE NOMINE
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, the musicians of Continuum argued the powers of words versus those of music in an evening of 19th- and 20th-century music. Saturday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, the Sine Nomine Singers under Harry Saltzman continued the dialogue but from a point earlier in history.

title: A 'Fantastick' Run
description: Brooks Atkinson liked ''The Fantasticks'' but underestimated its longevity.

title: WHERE THESIS MATTERS
description: PRINCETON,N.J. THE courses now drawing to a close for most college seniors are their last obstacle to graduation, but for a smaller number such as those at Princeton University there is an additional hurdle: the senior thesis.

title: WILLIAMS-WALKER EFFECTIVE KNICK DUO
description: Ray Williams is the Knicks' most creative player and Darrell Walker, one of their best offensive rebounders. On the road, they clown a lot and on the court, ''we're good for each other,'' Walker said yesterday.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEVIL'S BAG'S CAREER IS ENDED
description: Devil's Bag today was retired from racing after X-rays revealed a chipped bone in his right front knee. The 3-year-old colt, who came here as an early favorite for the Kentucky Derby last Saturday but was withdrawn from the race, will be vanned 70 miles Saturday to Claiborne Farm in Lexington, Ky., where he will begin a new career as a stallion next spring.

title: ON SIDEWALKS OF BOMBAY, LIFE HAS A SLIVER LINING
description: All over Bombay there are makeshift roadside slums, consisting of squatters' huts of scrap wood and corrugated iron, plastic sheeting, rattan matting and bamboo.

title: Losses for the N.F.L.
description: Although the National Football League has projected possible losses of about $14 million in 1985 and more for 1986, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said the league was still the most stable around. The league's projected losses are attributed to the 1982 strike, competition from the United States Football League and the resulting increase in players' salaries.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
STAGE: A TRIO OF PLAYS, PART OF MARATHON '84
description: WHEN we first meet Lois Smith in Ara Watson's one-act play ''Bite the Hand,'' in the second evening of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '84, she is sitting on her front porch - with her feet up, relaxing in the sunshine. Miss Smith's portrait is one of absolute contentment. As played by Miss Smith, the character is not the least self-conscious or defensive about her profession, which happens to be prostitution. It is 1947 in South Dakota, and factory jobs are scarce. From her perspective, she is running her own small business.

title: SPORTS TODAY Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Mike Torrez starts for the Mets after missing several turns because of a groin injury.

title: Dow Rises by 1.25; Trading Slow
description: Stock prices ended with minor changes yesterday in much slower trading following their sharp losses on Friday when fears of rising interest rates depressed the list.

title: HERBERT C. SMYTH Jr.
description: Herbert C. Smyth Jr., a trial lawyer and a former litigation counsel for the Mobil Oil Corporation, died April 29 at a nursing home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 86 years old and had been a resident of Manhattan.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: India and Bangladesh Confer On Reducing Border Tension
description: Chiefs of the Bangladeshi and Indian border guards conferred today to try to reduce tension along the frontier, a Bangladeshi military officer said.

title: CRACKING DOWN ON SALE OF FRAUDULENT DEGREES
description: REPRESENTATIVES of higher education are cooperating with the Federal Bureau of Investigation to crack down on the growing sale of fraudulent college and university degrees.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $4,138,000 from discontinued operations.

title: KIRKLAND SAYS MONDALE GAIN VINDICATES EFFORTS OF UNIONS
description: Lane Kirkland said today that organized labor's venture in Presidential primary politics had been ''vindicated'' by the rebound of Walter F. Mondale's campaign.

title: COMPLEX COERCION BINDS SEX RINGS USING CHILDREN
description: IN a major child abuse study, social scientists have shed new

title: Hart Gets Wide Margin In Colorado Victory
description: Senator Gary Hart got a boost from his home state tonight by winning Colorado's Democratic precinct caucuses where 43 national convention delegates were at stake.

title: STORE SALES IN THE AREA UP IN APRIL
description: Sales at New York City retail stores rose 12.4 percent in April from a year earlier, aided mainly by the late date for Easter, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: William F. Swindler, 70, Dies; Scholar of U.S. Constitution
description: William F. Swindler, an author and a leading scholar of the history of the United States Constitution and of constitutional law, died Saturday at his home. He was 70 years old.

title: M/A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,202,000 for the quarter and $1,766,000 for the 6 months.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Management Systems Inc., Washington, a management consulting and software design firm specializing in financial systems, has appointed Linda Morse and Reginald C. Foster vice presidents.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on April 20 by United Press International about a lawsuit against the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre incorrectly described the suit. It was filed by a former employee of the diocese who says he was wrongfully dismissed. The suit contends he is a victim of libel and slander by a supervisor.

title: GEMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock distribution March 13.

title: CHAUVCO RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reynolds Stock Up;Pickens Role Seen
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, which has huge oil and gas holdings, rose $3.75 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to end the day at $63.375.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Mortgage rates rose sharply in April, with conventional fixed-rate loans reaching 14.11 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: VETERANS ACCEPT $180 MILLION PACT ON AGENT ORANGE
description: Averting a long-scheduled trial, seven makers of Agent Orange agreed yesterday to create a $180 million fund for thousands of Vietnam veterans and their families who said the herbicide had harmed them.

title: STEINBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 7
description: b-Net loss The results for the first and second quarters have been restated. The previous year's results included external sales of $6.5 million by Phenix Flour Ltd. and $20.5 million by Steinberg Foods Ltd., both of which were disposed of at the end of the 1983 fiscal year. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: No Headline
description: Assembly Votes Down Antismoking Measure

title: New Headquarters Planned for Hutton
description: E. F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that it had signed a lease for a 30-story building, to be constructed on an empty lot on 53d Street, that will become its corporate headquarters.

title: SOVIET WIDENING DRIVE, AFGHAN SAYS
description: An Afghan rebel spokesman said yesterday that the Soviet Union's spring offensive in Afghanistan, although most intense in a key valley north of the capital, had expanded into heavy attacks against insurgents around the country.

title: JAW FOSSIL MAY BE OF OLDEST ANCESTOR YET
description: -INCH fragment of fossilized jawbone found recently in Kenya may be a remnant of the oldest known ancestor of man. The fragment of lower jaw, including two teeth, is physically similar to that of the ancient species Australopithecus afarensis, best known from the famous specimen known as ''Lucy.'' This species is believed to have lived between three and four million years ago.

title: DuPont Forecast
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest American chemical company, expects 1984 profits to exceed $6 a share, up from last year's $4.70, the company's chairman said at the annual meeting. The executive, Edward G. Jefferson, also noted that the company's earnings per share had been higher since Du Pont bought Conoco Oil than they would have been had the purchase not taken place, despite $4 billion in debt the company incurred in the deal. Du Pont has repaid two-thirds of that debt, he said.

title: Miss Lewis Leaving
description: Carol Lewis , the No. 1-ranked female long-jumper, said she would turn in her athletic scholarship at the University of Houston after this season. The 20-year-old junior said she planned to represent the Santa Monica Track Club, joining her brother, Carl Lewis , the world's top- ranked male long-jumper.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mitsibushi Bank Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. will borrow $130 million to $170 million in long-term loans from Japanese insurance companies to acquire the Bancal Tri-State Corporation of the United States, the holding company of the Bank of California, banking sources said today.

title: Professor Is Sentenced In Massachusetts Killing
description: An anatomy professor was sentenced to 18 to 20 years in prison today for killing his young lover with a sledgehammer - a crime the prosecutor said he ''would have gotten away with'' had the police not staged a massive investigation.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ONE of the requisite skills for sitting at a fashion show is being able to roll your eyes, talk to the person behind you, chew mints and say ''Yves Saint Laurent did it better years ago'' all at once. There was a lot of that during the past two weeks of American fall collections. Yet there were also moments of great beauty, much of it supplied by Perry Ellis, Anne Klein, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and Stephen Sprouse.

title: BARBARO FACES SURGERY
description: Gary Barbaro, the free safety for the Generals and a stalwart member of their defense, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Tuesday. He will be out of the lineup for at least two weeks.

''La Cage aux Folles,'' a musical about two homosexual lovers, took nine and Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing'' captured the most nominations among plays, with seven.

title: A CHECKLIST OF MAJOR FALL FASHION TRENDS
description: Rarely have the contours of fashion been so clearly defined as they were in the New York fall and winter openings that ended last week. This does not mean one shape for all, just as it doesn't mean one color or one length. The mainstream is wide enough to include significant variations. But what clearly runs through all the collections that make a strong fashion statement for the months ahead is a feeling of ease, whether it is expressed in sweaters that are generously cut or coats that can look a few sizes too big. This is as true of the leaders in fashion as it is of the designers who do moderately priced and sometimes more widely distibuted collections.

JACKSON POLLOCK STORY
description: -1956), born in Buffalo Bill's town of Cody, Wyo., has, like that celebrated Western superscout, achieved the stature of mythic American folk hero. Shy, but two-fisted and hard-drinking, he came out of the West with nothing but honest talent, not only making it big in the scornful, sophisticated world of New York know-it-alls but also writing his name in bold relief across the pages of art history. In the process, he destroyed himself. The saga is irresistible and, like other frontier stories, it seems to bear telling and retelling.

title: No Headline
description: Narrow Chance in El Salvador Having bet heavily on El Salvador's election, President Reagan seems in sight of a victory - but just. Jose Napoleon Duarte, the moderate Christian Democrat who was properly preferred by Washington, seems to have won a narrow victory over a right-wing extremist, and also over the boycott and disruptions of leftist guerrillas. Something rare in Central America and unique in El Salvador seems within his grasp: a legal transfer of power to a centrist committed to human rights, reform and reconciliation.

The film is based on Mr. Cousins's book recounting his successful effort to cure himself of a degenerative bone disease that his doctors had declared incurable.

title: Quake Hits Area on Coast

The epicenter was in rugged back country about five miles north of Lake Cachuma, he said.

Marcus Dupree rushed for 125 yards and a touchdown for the Breakers (7-4).

description: THERE may be a couple more episodes of ''Happy Days'' rattling around in ABC-TV's waiting-for-broadcast vaults, but it is clear that tonight's hourlong special at 8 o'clock was designed as the finale for the long-running series. At fadeout, staged during a marriage reception, Howard Cunningham, the gruff but lovable father played by Tom Bosley, reverts to the past tense, noting how he ''had the joy of raising two wonderful kids and watching them and their friends grow up into wonderful adults.'' Raising his glass of champagne and looking directly into the camera, he tells the audience, ''Thank you all for being part of our family - to happy days.''

title: WORLD POPULATION CRISIS...
description: There is some indication that Third World leaders are finally waking up to the fact that population growth is placing intolerable pressures on the earth's land, water and energy supplies. Among the first to reexamine population policies were the Chinese. After weighing a projected population growth of 300 to 400 million people against the future availability of cropland, water, energy and jobs, China's leaders concluded that they had no choice but to Lester R. Brown is president of the Worldwatch Institute and project director for the study ''State of the World - 1984,'' from which this article is adapted. press for one-child families, lest they jeopardize hard-earned gains in living standards. The main difference between China and other densely populated developing countries, such as Bangladesh, India, Egypt, Nigeria or Mexico, may be that the Chinese have had the foresight to make projections of their population and resources and the courage to translate their findings into policy. But other countries may also find that one-child families are the only humane alternative. Administering a one-child family program is not easy. To hold the line at one child, China relies on an established political structure extending down to the individual, strong peer pressure, substantial financial rewards for having only one child and hefty financial penalties for having more than one. Where a preference for sons is strong, the program is particularly difficult to enforce, as Chinese leaders can attest. And the line between peer pressure, in a society where citizen awareness of the population threat is high, and official coercion is a thin one.

title: TEXAS CAUCUSES: HISPANIC VOTE BUOYED MONDALE AND DISAPPOINTED JACKSON

Mondale's powerful support among white Democrats and Mexican-Americans in the Texas Democratic caucuses Saturday not only enabled him to trounce Senator Gary Hart, it also foiled the Rev. Jesse Jackson's bid for a ''rainbow coalition,'' according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. Ever since announcing his candidacy with Hispanic leaders by his side, Mr. Jackson has vowed to expand upon his natural political base among blacks to form a ''rainbow coalition'' by drawing support from Hispanic voters, American Indians, Asians and other minority groups, as well as whites.

description: In the spring of 1982 the Simmons Market Research Bureau did a syndicated study of newspaper readership.

title: FILM EXPLORES STEEL INDUSTRY DECLINE
description: ''THE BUSINESS OF AMERICA,'' a powerful documentary to be broadcast tonight on Channel 13, is not so much about business in general as it is about the decline of the nation's steel industry and what can be done about it. Although polemical at times, the film succeeds in making personal many abstract economic issues and in raising several important questions about the decline of the nation's industrial heartland.

title: ETHIOPIA'S TOP DIPLOMAT IN U.S. ASKS ASYLUM AFTER HE IS RECALLED
description: The charge d'affaires at the Ethiopian Embassy here said today that he had decided to seek political asylum in the United States.

title: SMOKE ALARMS

title: DANCE: TROUPE FROM NORTH CAROLINA AT PURCHASE
description: North Carolina Dance Theater, the professional troupe affiliated with the North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, is a remarkable little company. Its 16 dancers are good- looking, well-schooled and scrupulously coached. Their dancing unites precision with elan and their mastery of both Classical and contemporary styles is a tribute to the pedagogical skills of Robert Lindgren, the company's director, and Salvatore Aiello, the associate director.

title: Companies
description: Dow Chemical and six other makers of Agent Orange agreed to set up a $180 million fund to compensate thousands of Vietnam veterans and their families who have said they were harmed by exposure to dioxin in the herbicide. Dow and the other companies - Monsanto, Diamond Shamrock, Uniroyal, T.H. Agriculture and Nutrition, Thompson Chemical and Hercules - all denied any liability for the claimants' health problems. (Page A1.) Both the companies and the veterans reserved the right to file claims against the Government; the major companies involved said the accord would not hurt their 1984 earnings materially. (B4.)

title: METHODIST CHURCH WON'T LIFT OPPOSITION TO HOMOSEXUALITY
description: Delegates to the General Conference of the United Methodist Church defeated proposals today that would have removed the church's official opposition to homosexual behavior.

title: E.P.A. Is Pressed to Require Removal of School Asbestos
description: Scientists, union officials and parents urged the Environmental Protection Agency today to require the removal of the carcinogen asbestos from schools and other public buildings.

title: Program Notes
description: Erich Leinsdorf conducted the

title: CAPITALIZING ON COMMODITIES
description: The prices for the basic raw materials and commodities that form a large portion of the exports from debt-ridden developing countries are beginning to stage a comeback.

title: SELLING COMMERCIALS ON CHINESE TELEVISION
description: For the last month, Cable Communications Unlimited of Beverly Hills, Calif., has been offering 30-second TV spots during the Summer Olympics for $15,000 and 60 seconds for $25,000 - and has not gotten any takers. Of course, the time it has been selling will be on Chinese TV.

title: THE HESITANT HOUSE
description: Time is running out for Congressional action on a bill to curtail the flow of illegal aliens, even as Democrats come under growing pressure to stall the legislation.

MCI'S MONTHLY CHARGES TO END STARTING JULY 15TH
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, stepping up its marketing challenge to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced today that it would soon drop all monthly service fees for its long-distance phone service.

description: A strong earthquake followed by more than 20 lesser shocks rocked central and southern Italy today, killing at least three people, interrupting telephone and train service and causing tall buildings to sway.

description: Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has told President Reagan it ''would be a mistake'' to raise the personal exemption from income taxes before completion of the Administration's study of the Federal tax system.

Poll Gives Reagan Lead Over the 3 Democrats
description: President Reagan would defeat either Walter F. Mondale or Senator Gary Hart by about the same margin if the Presidential election were held now, according to a poll published today by The Los Angeles Times.

title: Oklahoma Man Dies In Oil Well Explosion
description: An oil well blew out and exploded in flames today, killing one worker and trapping another high on the rig for three and a half hours while flames seared his back, the authorities said. A county coroner sent to the scene because of the death helped treat the trapped worker's burns and crushed leg until he could be freed.

title: COMPOSER SEES PULITZER AS A LONG-TERM BENEFIT
description: When a playwright like David Mamet, with a show on Broadway, wins the Pulitzer Prize, he can expect a sudden upturn in ticket sales. But for a composer, the rewards - while just as satisfying, emotionally - are considerably less tangible and immediate.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $301,397 for the latest quarter and $1,330 for the year-earlier period. The year-ago share earnings reflect 5 percent stock dividends declared March 28, 1984 and March 23, 1983.

title: Vandals Drain Upstate Reservoir
description: Vandals drained the Garnerville Reservoir here over the weekend, the police said today.

WILLIAM RITMAN, DESIGNER, DIES
description: William Ritman, the prolific scenic designer of ''Morning's at 7'' and plays by Edward Albee, Samuel Beckett and Harold Pinter, among others, died Sunday in his New York apartment. He was 56 years old and had been ill with cancer for more than 18 months.

title: Kallur to Play
description: Anders Kallur , who injured his back in the Islanders' semifinal victory over the Canadiens, will be ready to return when the finals start Thursday night against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Guard Troops Move In After Strike Violence
description: National Guard troops hauled tents and supplies into this copper mining region today as the authorities doubled the forces of state troopers patrolling two strike-torn towns.

title: The Reserved Gettys
description: GORDON and Ann Getty never expected to be public figures. Despite a share of the family trust he inherited when his billionaire father, J. Paul Getty, died in 1976, he, his red-haired wife and their four sons lived quietly, if elegantly, in San Francisco until Forbes magazine, in 1982 and 1983, put them at the top of its list of the nation's richest people.

title: NETS, BUCKS AIDES IN SPOTLIGHT
description: One of them was a head coach in all but title. The other was afraid of losing his pro coaching career altogether.

description: Metro-Meet? The Apple Something-or-Other? Hudson Hall? Knickerbocker Center? The Orchard? How about honoring Jacob K. Javits, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Alfred E. Smith, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, Babe Ruth, Cardinal Cooke?

title: LITIGATION CONTINUED FOR YEARS
description: Following are key events in the Agent Orange case: 1961 to 1973 - More than 2.8 million Americans serve in Vietnam. 1965 to 1970 - About 12 million gallons of Agent Orange, a mixture of the herbicides 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D, is sprayed over millions of acres of South Vietnam to clear vegetation considered helpful to the enemy. April 17, 1970 - United States bans domestic and military uses of herbicide 2,4,5-T, including use of Agent Orange in Vietnam, saying the chemical is associated with animal birth defects.

No Headline
description: Kin of Heroes To Get Torch Gina Hemphill and Bill Thorpe Jr., the grandchildren of two of America's most celebrated Olympic heroes, will light the torch from the Olympic flame today and carry it on the first of 14,615 kilometers on its way to Los Angeles and this summer's Olympic Games. Miss Hemphill is a 23-year-old native of Chicago who graduated from Arizona State with a degree in marketing management.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1984 figures include those of HCR International, which Mangood purchased on Dec. 28, 1983. The share earnings were based on about 629,000 shares outstanding after adjusting for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 30.

BODY OF PRINCE FOUND NEAR PARIS
description: The body of Prince Edouard-Xavier de Lobkowicz, a descendent of families prominent in Europe and New York, has been found in the Seine River outside Paris, judicial sources in Paris said yesterday. The Prince was 23 years old.

title: Lyubimov's 'Rigoletto' Gets a Mixed Reception
description: Boos, catcalls and whistling mingled with applause at the debut of Yuri Lyubimov's unconventional production of ''Rigoletto'' here at the Teatro Communale last Saturday night.

title: CHIEF WITNESS TESTIFIES ON ROLE IN CBS KILLINGS
description: The state's chief witness in the murder trial of Irwin M. Margolies testified yesterday that Mr. Margolies had been upset when a hired gunman reversed the order in which two employees were ''to be eliminated.''

title: GENEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Historian to Head Clark U.
description: Dr. Richard P. Traina, a historian, has been named president of Clark University in Worcester, Mass., by the university's board of trustees. He will assume the post on July 1, succeeding Mortimer H. Appley, who has been the university's president for 10 years.

title: ALLNET COMMUNICATION SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MODEM INSTALLATION: CHILD'S PLAY, ALMOST
description: ONE of the more arcane areas in personal computing is telecommunications. In some ways it is more standardized than, say, software operating procedures. Nevertheless, for the beginner, getting the computer to deal by telephone with another computer is the height of frustration.

title: Offer for Aegis
description: The Aegis Corporation said it had recommended that shareholders accept the acquisition offer made by MIN Acquisitions, a unit of Minstar Inc., for $6 a share.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.S. LIABILITY NOT RESOLVED BY VETERANS SUIT SETTLEMENT
description: Federal officials said today that the settlement of a lawsuit involving thousands of claims against the manufacturers of the herbicide Agent Orange did not resolve the Government's liability for paying millions of dollars in compensation.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Comings and Goings
description: Pete Barry, who coached the University of San Francisco basketball team before the school dropped the sport in 1982, was named head coach at Southern Oregon State. . . . A Philadelphia Commons Pleas Court ruled yesterday that the National Association of Basketball Referees illegally dismissed Richard Phillips as their lawyer and that contracts between the union and Phillips are valid and binding. . . . Terry Porter , a guard from the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point, has recovered from the chicken pox and is working out again to try to make the United States Olympic team.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKEES WIN ON 2 HOME RUNS
description: Unusual objects soared over Yankee Stadium last night, and they were not U.F.O.'s. Though not easily identifiable because of their infrequent appearance this year, the strange sights were confirmed to be home runs. Don Mattingly and Steve Kemp hit them, and they powered the Yankees to a 5-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: MOSCOW RABBI REPORTS RISE IN ATTENDANCE AT SYNAGOGUE
description: The rabbi of Moscow's synagogue said in Manhattan yesterday that there was growing attendance at his house of worship, reflecting increased interest by Jews in their heritage.

title: CUSTOMS ACTS TO TRACK HIGH-TECH SHIPMENTS
description: The Customs Service, in a plan that has raised considerable skepticism and concern in the computer industry, is designing a secret electronic system that will enable officials to track shipments of sensitive high- technology equipment.

title: New President Chosen At Glendale Federal
description: Norman M. Coulson, 51, has been named president and chief operating officer of Glendale Federal, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan, Raymond D. Edwards, chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday. He succeeds Gordon A. Klett, who has decided to take early retirement.

title: 50 DOMINICAN ARRESTS REPORTED
description: More than 50 political, union and student leaders were arrested Sunday night and today in the Dominican Republic ''as a security measure,'' a police official said.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $202,000.

title: PAPUA NEW GUINEA GREETS POPE WITH RELAXED JOY
description: Pope John Paul II received a joyous and informal welcome here today as he arrived from South Korea on the second leg of his Far Eastern tour.

title: GIANT BEE IS BACK
description: WHILE studying the wildlife of an Indonesian island a few years ago, a University of Georgia researcher found several living colonies of the world's largest bee, Chalicodoma pluto, that had long been thought to be extinct, the university reported last week.

title: Bush Starts Asia Trip
description: Vice President Bush started a two-week trip to Asia today. He will discuss trade and economic issues with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and other Japanese officials in Tokyo before going to Indonesia, India, Pakistan and Oman.

title: Doubles Fun' for Lendl
description: First-round play continued at the Tournament of Champions yesterday, with the most noteworthy match at the West Side Tennis Club a rare doubles appearance by Ivan Lendl, who is seeded third in singles behind Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DELOREAN THE DEFENDANT AS CELEBRITY
description: Maybe the curious, the fascinated and the admiring were less noticeable at first. Maybe they were just obscured by the huge, shifting band of news people.

title: Trade Deficit At a Record
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit reached a record high of $25.8 billion for the first three months of this year, up more than 30 percent from the previous record of $19.4 billion in the previous quarter, the Government reported today.

title: Bad Bounces
description: Derek Harper, a rookie guard for the Dallas Mavericks from the University of Illinois, made a mistake on Sunday that may have cost his team a chance to even its National Basketball Association playoff series against the Los Angeles Lakers at two games apiece. The Lakers won the game, 122-115, in overtime and, now holding a 3-1 advantage, can end the series tonight in Los Angeles.

title: Andrettis Hoping For Family Race
description: -year-old son Michael were busy over the weekend making practice runs at the Indianapolis Speedway. Mario, 44, was clocked yesterday at 205 miles an hour, a bit faster than the 203 m.p.h timing turned in by Michael on Saturday.

title: Continental Air Reports Growth
description: Continental Airlines, which filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws last September, is expanding service and giving pay increases, the carrier's president, Philip J. Bakes, announced.

description: b-Including a gain of $949,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A Kabuki Show Added
description: The Japanese kabuki performer Bando Tamasaburo will give an additional performance Thursday at 2 P.M. at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street.

title: 'GOLDEN AGE' OF ASTRONOMY PEERS TO EDGE OF UNIVERSE
description: SCIENTISTS say a new era in astronomy has dawned in which remarkable discoveries are being made by orbiting observatories that are gathering data from radiations invisible to the human eye.

title: Young Predicts Hart Will Be No. 2 on Ticket
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta has predicted that Walter F. Mondale would be the Democratic Presidential nominee and that Senator Gary Hart will be Mr. Mondale's running mate.

title: Death in Hawaii Hotel Fire
description: One man died and four people were injured today after a three-alarm fire broke out at 12:30 A.M. in a Waikiki hotel. Guests at the Princess Kaiulani Hotel were evacuated from the 640-room tower wing after the fire began in an eighth- floor room, a hotel spokesman said. The man who died was a member of the hotel's fire brigade.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Dallas Team Wins Playoffs For World Team Olympiad

title: Addenda
description: * Glamour magazine increasing its circulation rate base, to 2 million from 1.9 million, and its advertising rates 5.3 percent with the September issue.

title: STATE UNITS FACE LOSS ON FUNDS
description: More than 30 New York school districts and counties are exposed to possible losses from their investments with Lion Capital Group, according to bankruptcy papers filed by the small government securities dealer.

title: Public Service Loan Default
description: Four banks have declared the Public Service Company of New Hampshire in default after the utility missed a $3 million payment on April 24, according to a filing made by the company yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, which has said it is near bankruptcy because of cost overruns at its Seabrook nuclear project, has an additional $2 million due today to the four banks, which were not named.

title: CITY BALLET: NEW FACES IN 'GOLDBERG VARIATIONS'
description: JEROME ROBBINS has set the entire Bach score to dance in his ''Goldberg Variations,'' and it is not a ballet for anyone with a limited or even normal attention span. To judge by the tumultuous reception that ''Goldberg Variations'' was accorded last Saturday night, when the New York City Ballet performed it in the New York State Theater, there are a lot of dancegoers around with just the right mind set and appetite for monumentality.

title: Formica Group Put Up for Sale
description: The American Cyanamid Company said it planned to sell the major part of its Formica products business, and it had engaged Morgan Stanley & Company to help it explore the sale. Cynamid said its Formica group is larger than its three closest competitors combined in the production of decorative laminates, a $1.5 billion worldwide market.

description: Murray Roman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Campaign Communications Institute of America, a telephone-marketing concern in Manhattan, died yesterday at a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in Santa Barbara.

description: Sometimes, Tomas Jonsson goes into Manhattan ''just to look at all the people.'' Other times, he goes to plays, the latest one ''Dreamgirls.''

Representatives of the world's most important central banks, along with those of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and some leading private banks, have been meeting there under tight security since Sunday evening.

title: Jets Drop Barkum
description: Jerome Barkum , a big-play receiver for most of his 12 seasons with the Jets, has cleared waivers and has been dropped from the squad to make room for younger players. The 34- year-old tight end, the senior Jet in both age and service, had been placed on 10-day waivers April 27 after he declined an offer to retire, saying he wanted to find a spot on another team.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Dormitory Authority Raising Cornell Yields
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. repriced the financing issue for the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York for Cornell University to raise the yields on the term bonds yesterday.

description: As the Olympics continue to dissolve into

title: ENTREPRENEUR FOR ECUADOR: LEON FEBRES CORDERO RIVADENEIRA
description: Leon Febres Cordero Rivadeneira, a self-made millionaire, campaigned for the presidency of Ecuador in shirtsleeves, knocking on doors, embracing market vendors and projecting the image of a man of the people. His leftist opponent wore dark suits and spoke in the hushed tones of a banker. When the results of the election Sunday were in, Mr. Febres Cordero's old-style populism seemed vindicated. His philosophy is conservative and pro-business, but a majority of voters seemed to choose him over Rodrigo Borja Cevallos of the Democratic Left Party because he promised simple answers to seemingly insoluble problems.

NUMERAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REV. JAMES PINDAR, AIDE TO KEAN
description: The Rev. James A. Pindar, special representative to Governor Kean for more than two years, died today, the Governor's office announced. Father Pindar was 53 years old.

title: HENRY M. MARX
description: Henry M. Marx, a former senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives, died of a stroke Saturday at University Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dun & Bradstreet Buys Datastream
description: The Dunn & Bradstreet Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Datastream, a business information and services company based in London, for about $101 million. Datastream shareowners representing more than 50 percent of the common shares, have agreed.

description: It was a double-header in Central

title: Storm Damage In South Jersey
description: Strong winds accompanied by hail and rain ripped the roof from a South Jersey nursing home and a hospital kitchen and leveled two houses last night, the authorities said. There were no reports of injuries.

description: b-Net income.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADVERTISING;Agency Search For Coffee Ads
description: The National Coffee Association of the U.S.A, which began a $24 million TV ad campaign last August aimed at getting young adults to drink more java, has been interviewing ad agencies. William J. Brooks, director of public relations, said the association was merely looking for a second agency to do projects assisting its current agency, Advertising to Women.

title: 3-YEAR NOTE YIELDS 12.54%; RATES FALL
description: Interest rates fell slightly and credit market prices rebounded yesterday, sparked by optimism over the results of the Treasury's three-year note auction. However, much of the trading activity was dominated by dealers.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECORD CARIER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $30,000. c-Includes a currency translation gain of $46,225. The company announced that it had changed its fiscal year to the period ending March 31 of each year commencing March 31, 1984.

title: Bid Turned Down By Scott & Fetzer
description: Scott & Fetzer said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected an offer of $60 a share, or $420 million, from a group led by Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager.

title: THE DISAPPEARING CIRCLE
description: One familiar form in the gleaming new galleries of the Museum of Modern Art is the pea-green Olivetti M-80 typewriter, designed in 1947 and still sleek. Except for the keys. They look as old-fashioned as granny glasses. They are round.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: strawberries and asparagus in spring, game in the fall, chestnuts in winter - have a special appeal even today, when almost everything is available year round. Among my favorite seasonal specialties is shad roe. When I visited my fish market last week my dealer reminded me that the current supply was nearing the end of its season. Fortunately, we have two to three more weeks to indulge that special taste.

title: MIDWEST ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hot Winds Complicate Fight Against California Brush Fire
description: Hot Santa Ana winds hampered the efforts today of hundreds of firefighters battling a blaze that has blackened 10,000 acres of California mountain brush, one of several fires that destroyed nine southern California homes.

title: ANTI-ARAB VIOLENCE SETS OFF DEBATE IN ISRAEL
description: -Occupied West Bank, May 8 - The arrest of a ring of purported Jewish terrorists has provoked a debate in Israel over the degree to which the movement of settling the West Bank is responsible.

title: Woman, 18, Stabbed to Death In Her Mother's Queens Home
description: An unidenfitied 18-year-old Queens woman was found stabbed to death in her mother's apartment in the Richmond Hill section last night, the police said.

title: CHIPS MOMAN'S VIEWS ON WORLD OF RECORDING
description: NASHVILLE THE record business began making a recovery from its early 1980's doldrums last year, but overall sales are still down. Chips Moman, who is one of Nashville's top record producers, thinks he knows why.

title: SUNS LOSE TO JAZZ
description: Mike McGee scored 27 points, and Earvin (Magic) Johnson had 15 assists tonight to help the Los Angeles Lakers advance to the Western Conference finals by routing the Dallas Mavericks, 115-99.

title: Turner Loses $5.3 Million
description: The Turner Broadcasting System today reported a first-quarter loss but said it had returned to profitability in April and expected no further losses this year.

title: Canada Dry to Sponsor Rod Stewart Concerts
description: Keeping with the apparent requirement of having the help of a popular singer before you try to push a soft drink, Canada Dry Ginger Ale has signed up Rod Stewart and will be sponsoring his national concert tour.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 25
description: Results have been restated to reflect acquisitions on a poolings of interests basis.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE REGION Antismoking Bill Defeated on L.I.
description: The Suffolk County Legislature failed today to override a veto by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan of a stringent bill to restrict smoking in public places. The vote was 11 to 7, 1 vote short of the two- thirds needed to override a veto.

title: Moscow Settles a Score
description: No matter how rationalized, the Soviet withdrawal from the Los Angeles Olympics is nothing more than paying America back in kind for its boycott of the 1980 Games in Moscow. This joust has now deprived what amounts to a whole athletic generation of truly Olympic tests. It has also proved that if the modern Games are to continue, their form and location needs to be thoroughly rethought.

title: ON LEAVING THE HOUSE FOR A LEAP AT THE SENATE
description: A vacancy sign does not show up in the Senate very often.

title: SLAM BY TRAMMELL LIFTS TIGERS, 5-2
description: Alan Trammell hit a grand slam off Dan Quisenberry in the seventh inning to help the Detroit Tigers beat the Kansas City Royals, 5-2, and increase their road record to 13-0.

title: AID TO SALVADOR DEBATED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives opened debate today on a $10.5 billion foreign aid authorization bill as President Reagan stepped up his lobbying for an amendment that would increase aid for El Salvador and loosen the conditions under which the aid would flow.

title: WHEN WOMEN WANT MARRIAGE AND MEN DON'T
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $145,000.

title: Real Estate; 2 Office Projects in Clifton, N.J.
description: CLIFTON, N.J., a Passaic County bedroom comunity of 75,000 residents less than 15 miles from Manhattan, has long been in the enviable position of having a local industrial base that pays 45 percent of its annual tax bill.

title: 2 Die as Plane Hits House
description: A twin-engine plane crashed into a suburban Harrisburg home Monday night, erupting into a ball of fire and killing two people, the authorities said. The victims were the pilot and an occupant of the house, according to an investigator with the National Transportation Safety Board, which began an inquiry.

title: Parents Win Suit On Inoculations
description: Two sisters whose parents did not want them immunized returned to school today, the day after a Federal judge ruled the parents could oppose inoculations on religious grounds without belonging to an organized religion.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,821,000, or 56 cents a share, on the sale of the President Country Club in West Palm Beach, Fla. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,600,000, or 50 cents a share, from a favorable claim settlement on a construction contract completed in prior years.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE winery of the Gold Seal Vineyards in Hammondsport, N.Y., goes out of business Saturday. Or, rather, it will shut down Saturday. The business, such as it is, will move across town to the Taylor Wine Company. Both are subsidiaries of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the American segment of the Seagram Company, the Canadian concern that is the world's largest distiller.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 9, 1984 International
description: Soviet athletes will not compete in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer, Moscow announced. It attributed the decision to a ''gross flouting'' of Olympic ideals by United States officials. In particular, the statement cited plans by anti-Soviet groups to hold demonstrations during the Games and a United States refusal to prohibit such protests. (Page A1, Columns 4-6.) The Soviet decision not to attend the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles was deplored by the Reagan Administration as ''a blatant political action for which there was no real justification.'' Administration specialists on the Soviet Union said they believed that Moscow's action was at least partly in retaliation for the American boycott of the Moscow Summer Games in 1980. (A16:1-4.)

title: WASHINGTON ; A POLITICAL FABLE
description: The other day Bill Brock, the President's overseas salesman, blasted the rich auto executives for robbing the till, and a couple of days later Secretary of the Treasury Regan suggested that maybe the rich didn't need Social Security. Nothing so candid has happened here since 1969, when Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, then 37, said he didn't seek the Presidency in 1968 because he was too young, too inexperienced and too vulnerable, and Senator John J. Williams of Delaware, then 66, announced that he wouldn't run for re-election because he was too old. This latest outburst of candor sent a shudder through the White House. What if truth became infectious and everybody began saying in public what he really thought in private? For example:

title: AFP IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Funds Set for Space Station
description: The Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee today gave preliminary approval to a permanently manned space station that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration hopes to put in orbit by 1992. The committee unanimously approved the budget authorization bill for the agency and sent it to the full Senate. The bill authorizes the spending of up to $151 million to determine the space station's architecture, components, capabilities, missions and support needs.

title: Daniel H. Silberberg, Partner In a Wall St. Brokerage Firm
description: Daniel H. Silberberg, a partner in the Wall Street brokerage firm of Silberberg, Rosenthal & Company, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Bexar Hospital Bonds Repriced
description: A selling group led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. repriced $46.95 million in revenue bonds for the Bexar County Hospital Authority of Texas yesterday to raise the yields on the financing. The bonds had originally been priced on Monday.

description: John E. Donalds has been named president and chief executive officer of Collaborative Research Inc., Orrie M. Friedman, chairman, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Usury Law Sought
description: Representative James C. Wright Jr., Democrat of Texas, the House majority leader, proposed today to eliminate variable-rate home mortgages and enact a national usury law to protect borrowers. The Texas Democrat told reporters that Congress should abolish adjustable-interest loans as ''an abomination.'' ''There will be more homes foreclosed'' under the recent trend by banks to wed mortgage and other loan rates to prevailing interest rates, the House leader said.

title: HBO CHANGES ITS FILM FOCUS
description: LOS ANGELESOne year after its introduction, Home Box Office's made-for-cable- television movie operation has drastically cut back its ambitious production schedule of films and mini- series, while HBO itself has become more involved in the production of movies for theatrical release. But executives of HBO, the nation's largest pay-cable service, with some 13.5 million subscribers, maintain that they still believe that HBO movies and mini-series are a critical component of the service's programming.

title: Bangladesh Says India Will Halt Border Fencing
description: India has agreed to suspend the erection of barbed wire fencing along its border with Bangladesh, a Bangladeshi military spokesman said today.

title: HART IS WINNER OF RACE IN INDIANA, ONCE SEEN AS MADE FOR MONDALE
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado won the Presidential primary today in Indiana, a state that political strategists had generally agreed was ''tailor-made'' for Walter F. Mondale.

title: ITALIANS STATE THE CASE FOR AUTHENTIC PASTA
description: PASTA is one of the most versatile foods there is, but when you do the things they do. . . .'' Alfredo Viazzi paused for a sigh and a lift of his well-defined eyebrows. ''Cold tortellini salad with pesto,'' he said somewhat sadly, ''it's an outrageous thing.'' Mr. Viazzi is a Greenwich Village restaurateur who has been serving Italian food to New Yorkers for the last 30 years. (He owns Cafe Domel, Trattoria da Alfredo and Tavola Calda da Alfredo.) He is one of several Italian chefs who were interviewed recently about pasta, in particular the variations on pasta that are being offered, and apparently consumed, with enthusiasm these days: colored and flavored pasta, cold pasta salads, pasta in strange and, to Italians, unwieldy combinations. Tortellini, for example, the little doughnut-shaped, meat-filled Bolognese specialty, is now often served cold with pesto, a pungent basil and garlic sauce that is closely identified with Genoa.

title: Richardson Shuns Funds From PAC's for Senate
description: Elliot L. Richardson, seeking the Republican nomination for the Senate from Massachusetts, has announced he had ''reluctantly'' decided not to accept campaign contributions from political action committees.

title: INQUIRY INTO EX-OSHA CHIEF
description: The Government is investigating whether the former head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Thorne G. Auchter, violated the law when he became president of a concern for which he had once vetoed proposed fines, according to someone close to the inquiry.

title: WHAT GAVE HART STRENGTH: LATE PUSH, A LOCAL HERO AND WORRIES OVER LABOR
description: Intensive late campaigning in Ohio over the past 10 days helped lift Senator Gary Hart to a surprising victory over Walter F. Mondale in one of the nation's most important industrial states yesterday, according to The New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll also showed that a tendency of many Ohio voters to substitute Mr. Hart for their home- state hero, Senator John Glenn, and their strong worries about the power of organized labor helped lift the Coloradan to his unexpected triumph.

title: Cubs Win, 12-11, Take First Alone
description: A pinch single in the bottom of the ninth by Keith Moreland lifted the Chicago Cubs to a 12-11 victory today over the San Francisco Giants.

title: British Petroleum Caps China Well
description: British Petroleum Ltd. said its fourth well in the South China Sea turned out to be a dry hole following widespread speculation that it would yield a major oil discovery. The B.P. drilling group found some trace of hydrocarbons in its first well in the Pearl River Basin of the South China Sea but the other three wells in the region were ''effectively dry holes,'' a B.P. spokesman said.

title: UNITED PRESIDENTIAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

His reference was to unarmed leftists, mainly those of the Revolutionary Democratic Front.

title: IDIOM OF DANCE SPELLS EAST-WEST FRIENDSHIP
description: TAMASABURO BANDO, the Kabuki actor of female roles who has a tremendous following in Japan, loves classical Western ballet, which he has seen often when troupes tour Japan. But he had never seen the dancers working out.

description: Labor leaders today denounced President Reagan's choice of Rosemary M. Collyer as the chief legal officer of the National Labor Relations Board, which has jurisdiction over labor law violations.

title: ATTACK REPORTED ON QADDAFI HOME
description: At least 20 gunmen yesterday reportedly attacked a barracks usually used as a residence by Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. After several hours of fighting, their attack was ended by Libyan troops, according to reports reaching the West from diplomats and an Italian journalist in Tripoli, the Libyan capital.
