DeLorean were subpoenaed by the Government in connection with a purportedly threatening telephone call that the investigator made to the father of a narcotics agent on the DeLorean case, it was disclosed in court today.

title: Double Courtship
description: Sherwood Weiser , a Florida hotel owner, wants to buy the Washington Federals and move the team to Miami, and if the deal goes through, he apparently wants a coach who will feel right at home - Howard Schnellenberger of the University of Miami. Schnellenberger, whose team upset Nebraska in the Orange Bowl and won the unofficial national championship last season, confirmed that he had met with Weiser last week, but both he and Weiser denied that any offer had been made or accepted. Weiser has been negotiating to buy the Federals from a group headed by Berl Bernhard , but any deal would need the approval of the United States Football League owners, who are holding their midseason meeting in New York today.

title: Soccer Crackdown
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League yesterday imposed heavy fines and suspensions on two players for the New York Arrows and assessed lesser penalties against two members of the Baltimore Blast following a fight that marred last Friday's playoff game. Baltimore, which won the game, 4-3, and took a 2-1 lead in the three-of-five-game quarterfinal series, is scheduled to play the Arrows at Nassau Coliseum tonight, but none of the four players involved in the fight will be allowed to play, the league announced.

title: STEEL MOVES OFF CENTER STAGE
description: Steel was once at the center of things, the backbone of the economy. It was no accident that President Truman seized the steel mills, or that President Kennedy lashed out at price increases by Roger Blough and United States Steel. And Superman was the man of steel.

title: VINEGARS WITH 1,000 YEARS OF TRADITION
description: ALTHOUGH it has been made in Modena, in northern Italy, for about 1,000 years, balsamic vinegar may be more familiar to Americans than to Italians today. In Italy, except in Modena, it is difficult to find in any but the most cosmopolitan shops. In the United States a number of brands are available in fancy food shops, and salads, sauces and marinades made with it regularly appear on restaurant menus and in cookbooks.

title: SOUR CHERRIES: MEMORIES FOR THE PICKING
description: NO one in my family admitted any real understanding of nature. We left it to the specialists: Jacques Cousteau handled the sea, the ''Born Free'' lady handled animals, Frank Field handled weather and NASA handled the universe. For us, a trip to the mountains meant Grossinger's, a day by the sea meant Jones Beach and hiking was a Saturday afternoon walk on the golf course behind our house. We went to Florida, but not to swim, fish or explore the Everglades; we sat on the balcony of our grandparents' Miami apartment and got color in our faces.

Loews, which has interests in insurance, hotels and tobacco, said that net income dropped to $65.9 million, or $2.43 a share, from $77.2 million, or $2.75 a share. Revenues fell to $1.28 billion, from $1.32 billion.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EVER SINCE EVE: Personal Reflections on Childbirth. By Nancy Caldwell Sorel. 388 pages. Oxford University Press. $14.95. HOW people feel about childbirth may tell us more about them than their politics does, or their philosophy - particularly now, when having children is no longer a matter of course, but of choice. When Francis Bacon said ''He who hath a wife and children hath given hostages to fortune,'' he did not seem to recognize that women shared the same predicament.

title: Justice, Mercy and Agent Orange
description: The tentative settlement reached in the Agent Orange trial is not a triumph of justice, because no one knows what justice in the case might be. It's not a triumph for the judicial system, because what drove the parties to settle was fear of the law's costs and delays. But it's the best feasible solution to an intractable problem. Both the makers of Agent Orange and the Vietnam veterans who blame the herbicide for their disabilities stand to gain if the settlement is accepted.

description: The agencies, Ansa and A.G.I., quoting unnamed sources, said the state prosecutor, Antonio Albano, had filed the request with the Court of Appeals in Rome asking trials for Sergei Ivanov Antonov, former Rome manager for the Bulgarian state airline, and two former Bulgarian Embassy employees, Todor Ayvazov and Vassiliev Kolev.

title: ZIMBABWE ACCUSED ON ARMY KILLINGS

description: Colorado Democrats gave Senator Gary Hart of their state a landslide victory Monday in statewide precinct Presidential caucuses.

title: AFTER A MONTH OF HINTS, PARTICIPATION BECOMES 'IMPOSSIBLE'
description: A series of charges and countercharges preceded the Soviet decision yesterday not to participate in the Los Angeles Olympics. Here is a chronology: April 7. Peter V. Ueberroth, head of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, tells a meeting of United States Olympic Committee delegates that ''if they didn't come it would make the Games smaller and lessen their importance.'' April 9. The Soviet National Olympic Committee, listing complaints previously voiced, requests a special session of the International Olympic Committee and ''demands that the United States side strictly respect the Olympic Charter and take effective measures to guarantee proper security.'' The Russians charge that ''the U.S. Administration is trying to use the Olympic Games on the eve of the elections for its selfish political aims.'' Mr. Ueberroth denies that the charter has been violated, and an Administration official counters by saying that ''the Soviet line toward the Olympics is consistent with the very tough anti-Administration position taken by the Kremlin.'' April 10. A source close to top Soviet sports authorities says the Soviet Union has no intention of not talking part in the Olympics. ''Our argument is with the U.S. Government and the I.O.C.,'' he says, ''not with the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee.'' April 11. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, points to the granting of press credentials to Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty as an effort ''to bring the spirit of psychological war and ideological subversion to the world Olympic movement.''

title: Danes on a New Rampage
description: Youths who want to rid the Danish capital of cars today destroyed light signals, disabled a bus and shoved flaming trash bins onto a main road, the police said. The protest was part of a week of actions against what the demonstrators call ''cultural imperialism.'' On Friday 352 young people were arrested after a rampage in which bottles and paint were throwing.

description: The Senate Democrats' plan to cut projected deficits was rejected today in a tie vote, with two Democratic Senators absent. The package would have saved $204 billion over the next three years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

As a matter of fact, music will be very much in mind evenings tonight through Friday, when the South Street Seaport Museum takes visitors on a tour that gets directly to the heart of the subject.

description: When President Reagan named Sandra Day O'Connor to the United States Supreme Court in 1981, most women in legal circles praised the choice.

title: Secretary Sues Over Ouster

The lawsuit, filed Monday, seeks back pay and punitive damages from the employer, Sharon Robertson, co-owner of a kitchen and bathroom products concern.

description: The national chairman of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign denies any conflict of interest between his job as an insurance agent and his duties as a member of the Cleveland- Cuyahoga Port Authority.

The company said that about $6 million of the $9.8 million would be payable over 27 months to one creditor and $3.8 million would be payable to two creditors upon completion of a sale-leaseback transaction involving two aircraft.

description: A Delaware judge today blocked the Royal Dutch/Shell Group from proceeding with its $5.5 billion offer to buy the 30.6 percent of the Shell Oil Company that it does not already own until the group makes further disclosures to minority shareholders.

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect pooling of interest acquisitions.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOUND AT MODERN
description: CHAMBER SOUND spent some of its evening at the Merkin Concert Hall Sunday sounding like a promising young ensemble. At other moments, it seemed something less.

title: JACKSON RUNS AHEAD OF HART
description: The nonbinding preference vote in Maryland's Democratic Presidential primary was won today by Walter F. Mondale, who also took the bulk of the state's 74 convention delegates.

title: Grand Jury Is to Hear Charges of Corruption
description: Presiding Judge Anthony A. Giannini of the Superior Court of Rhode Island today ordered a special statewide grand jury empaneled to investigate charges of municipal corruption in Providence.

title: Addenda
description: * Scholastic has acquired the rights to Microkids magazine from Microkids Publishing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 9, 1984

title: POPE CELEBRATES MASS IN PIDGIN ENGLISH
description: With tom-toms throbbing in the background, Pope John Paul II celebrated mass in pidgin English in this highland town today.

title: N. CAROLINA GOES TO MONDALE WITH HART FINISHING SECOND
description: Walter F. Mondale won the Democratic Presidential primary in North Carolina today, with Gary Hart finishing second and the Rev. Jesse Jackson third.

title: Iraq Reports Attack On 2 Ships in Gulf
description: Iraq said today that its fighters had attacked two large ships sailing from Iran's main Persian Gulf oil terminal. Shipping sources in Bahrain said a Saudi Arabian tanker had been hit and set ablaze.

title: Griffith Denies He's Set to Sell
description: Calvin Griffith, the president of the Minnesota Twins, denied reports today that he was set to sell the majority interest in the club to a Minneapolis bank president, but acknowledged that discussions had occurred.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEAGULL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SUSPECT IN TROOPER'S DEATH HAD MURDER TERM CUT
description: A convicted murderer who was killed after the fatal shooting of a New Jersey state trooper Monday served only 12 years of a 50-years-to-life prison sentence because of changes in the New York penal code in 1975, authorities said yesterday.

title: Sears Is Suing Bank Agency
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company filed two suits today against the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, challenging a board position that it said would prohibit its subsidiary, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., from underwriting shares of publicly owned savings and loan companies.

title: U.S. OLYMPIC AIDES EXPECT SOVIET TO STICK TO DECISION
description: The president and the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee disagreed yesterday on how future Olympics might be affected by the decision of the Soviet Union to withdraw from the 1984 Games in Los Angeles.

title: WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BILL TO PERMIT BROWN-BAGGING IS STALLED
description: -called brown-bag bill, which would allow patrons to bring wine and beer to restaurants in New York State that lack liquor licenses, is stalled in the State Assembly, as opposition forces try to block its passage.

title: The Democrats: A Delegate Update
description: 143 of the 169 delegates at stake

title: Australia Spurs Cup Defense Plan
description: Two coastal marinas are to be built in western Australia for the 1987 America's Cup challenge.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter include a provision of $4,800,000 for the cost of a restaurant closing, $1,300,000 for the repurchase of 10 previously franchised restaurants, and a charge of $390,000 for the pre-opening development costs of several locations that won't be opened as a result of the company's reduced rate of expansion.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $248,000. c-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $122,000 and an extraordinary gain of $3,000.

title: U.S. Official Visits Sudan
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Chester A. Crocker, arrived here today for talks with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry on Wednesday. The visit follows the proclamation of a state of emergency and a Cabinet shuffle.

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Coast Convention Seats Worry Some Reporters
description: Some reporters who plan to cover the Democratic National Convention fear that because of a new seating arrangement on the press platform, reporters assigned to the back rows will not be able to see the action on the convention floor.

title: Amerace Benefits
description: The Amerace Corporation said it had approved the payment of special termination benefits for 16 officers and key employees who might be discharged or choose to leave if the company changed hands. As reported, Nortek Inc. has purchased in recent months about 15 percent of the common stock of Amerace, a maker of parts for the industrial, automotive and aerospace markets. Nortek, which makes building products, drilling pipe and granite products, has indicated that it is considering buying more shares, or making a cash tender offer or a merger proposal.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AS you may know, it is impossible to drive a car in some parts of town without being waylaid by hustlers with squeegees. Yet motorists aren't the only targets for unsolicited services. Pedestrians, too, are being victimized, Metropolitan Diary has learned.

title: THE FAIRER CURE FOR U.S. IMMIGRATION PROBLEMS
description: LIVES THAT NEED SAVING

title: No Headline
description: Social Worker Defends Actions on 2 Aliens

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIDS SEEN FOR CITY INVESTING
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's biggest investment banking house, is expected to propose an estimated $1.8 billion management buyout today of the City Investing Company, Wall Street executives disclosed yesterday.

title: PANAMA LEADER SEEKS TO CALM ELECTION FRICTIONS
description: In the wake of post-election disturbances Monday night that left one person dead and 40 injured, President Jorge Illueca appealed to Panamanians today to remain calm and refrain from further political demonstrations.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $427,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $365,000.

title: BALLET: A SLAVIC 'DANCES'
description: NATALIA MAKAROVA and Mikhail Baryshnikov performed ''Other Dances'' Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was the first time the Jerome Robbins pas de deux to Chopin was seen with American Ballet Theater this season.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After unrealized foreign currency losses of $695,000 and a gain of $246,000, or 1 cent a share, related to the disposal of vessels including a vessel casualty. c-After unrealized foreign currency gains of $2,471,000, or 10 cents a share, and a loss of $1,680,000 on vessel sales.

title: HERBERT MATTER, 77, A GRAPHIC DESIGNER AND PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Herbert Matter, an influential graphic designer, photographer and teacher, died of cancer yesterday in Southampton Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Springs, L.I.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests.

title: Wristbands For Charity?
description: Major league baseball and the Ronald McDonald Houses charity are involved in a battle that neither side seems to enjoy. The main point of contention is the ''Golden Arches'' logo of the McDonald's restaurant chain.

title: The U.N. Today May 9, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: OHIO GIVES HART HIS FIRST VICTORY IN AN IMPORTANT INDUSTRIAL STATE
description: Senator Gary Hart won a narrow victory over Walter F. Mondale yesterday in the Ohio Democratic primary.

title: METHODISTS SEEK TO RESTORE 'UNIFYING VISION'
description: Declaring that the United Methodist Church had lost the ''unifying vision'' that once provided a focus for its mission, the church's General Conference today called for a program to restore a central purpose to the church's ministry.

title: Lautenberg Offers Bill on Dumping
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, introduced legislation today that would permanently ban the dumping of sewage sludge 12 miles off the Jersey Shore.

title: SOUTHLAND TRIAL BEGINS
description: A Federal prosecutor charged in court yesterday that ''top executives'' of the Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, ''ratified a plan to bribe'' New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the company's 7-Eleven convenience store chain.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Resources Company of Shreveport, La., said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company said it had incurred substantial losses, amounting to about $10 million over several years, from its dairy operations. It said it intended to present a plan for satisfying its debt and generating profits by development of its land holdings in Hawaii and Texas.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Gold Recovers Slightly; Narrow Range Is Seen
description: The gold market staged a modest technical recovery yesterday after futures prices fell Monday to life-of- contract lows. But dealers said rising interest rates would continue to weigh heavily on bullion prices.

title: GATE IS LAGGING FOR LEONARD COMEBACK
description: Sigmund Freud never came back here. But in what an English professor, Mike Spingler, said might be the most significant event at Clark University since Freud delivered his only United States lectures there 75 years ago, Sugar Ray Leonard has been working out at the local school for his comeback fight Friday night against Kevin Howard.

title: E. VIRGINIA WILLIAMS, TEACHER AND FOUNDER OF BOSTON BALLET
description: E. Virginia Williams, the founder of the Boston Ballet and a noted American ballet teacher, died yesterday in Malden (Mass.) Hospital. She was 70 years old.

title: U.S. ENERGY SECRETARY URGES TEST OF A SHOREHAM EVACUATION PLAN
description: The Secretary of Energy appealed to Governor Cuomo today to participate in ''an honest test'' of an evacuation plan for the area surrounding the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island.

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Retail Sales Dip
description: Retail sales fell 1.1 percent in March, seasonally adjusted, after February's 1.7 percent rise, the Trade and Industry Department said today. The index was set at 108.3 in March, on a base of 100 in 1980, compared with 109.5 in February.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. SAYS UNESCO WITHDRAWAL WOULD NOT CAUSE CUT IN AID
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States would not cut its spending for communications programs in developing countries when it drops out of Unesco at the end of the year.

title: LILA WALLACE, WHO BESTOWED READER'S DIGEST WEALTH, DIES
description: Lila Acheson Wallace, the co-founder and longtime co-chairman of Reader's Digest whose philanthropic donations totaled scores of millions of dollars, died of heart failure yesterday morning at her Mount Kisco, N.Y., home. She was 94 years old and had been in declining health for some time.

title: Barbaro Out 4 Weeks
description: The Generals placed Gary Barbaro , a free safetyman, on their injured- reserve list after he underwent knee surgery.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp said it had sold $100 million of 91-day paper at 10.95 percent, up from 10.503 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 11.084 percent, up from 10.552 percent last week.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: KATHY ROSE PERFORM WITH FILM
description: NOTHING was ever what it seemed and everything was subject to change in Kathy Rose's program on Thursday night in the Danspace of St. Mark's Church. A maker of animated films as well as a choreographer, Miss Rose celebrated metamorphosis and delighted in visual and kinetic magic. The result was an evening of wonderment.

title: CANDIDATES SPENDING AT RECORD PACE
description: Congressional candidates have already, six months before Election Day, raised $111 million and spent $96 million, an Associated Press analysis of campaign finance records shows.

title: SATURDAY REVIEW IS FOR SALE
description: Eighteen months after its most recent purchase, Saturday Review, the 60-year-old magazine of literature and the arts that has suffered a decade of financial and management woes, is on the trading block once again.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $186,000.

FOOD NOTES
description: Sweet Potato Cookie

description: Year-ago net income does not include earnings from the company's former banking subsidiary of $1,420,000, or 16 cents a share, through Feb. 18, 1983, at which time the stock of the trust company was distributed to shareholders of Wilshire.

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
CMT INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $177,000. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $236,000.

title: CUOMO SEE SIGNS OF L.I. BID-RIGGING
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the state had delayed $30 million worth of highway repair work on Long Island because of what appeared to be bid-rigging by contractors.

title: Rebate by Utility On 3 Mile Island
description: Customers of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company will receive an average rebate of $20 this summer, state utility regulators decided today.

title: Dow Advances by 9.74 In Heavier Trading
description: A technical recovery sent stock prices higher yesterday in heavier trading even after several major banks increased their prime lending rates.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kinney Shoe Deal
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company said its Kinney Shoe Corporation subsidiary had agreed in principle to acquire all of the shares of the Menlo Trading Company, a California- based retailer. Menlo Trading, operating under the name Athletic Shoe Factory, operates 62 stores in California, Arizona, Nevada and Texas that sell brand-name athletic footwear and apparel at discount prices.

title: Continental Bank Denies Rumors
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company denied rumors that it was considering filing for protection under the Federal bankruptcy laws. In response to a question from a reporter from the Reuters news service, Robert McKnew, senior vice president and treasurer, described the rumors as ''totally preposterous.''

title: METS AND YANKS RAINED OUT
description: Nature played no favorites with the Mets and Yankees last night. Both were scheduled to play at home and both were rained out by the stormy weather that hit the city.

title: Educational Issue Priced on Coast
description: A $50.495 million note and bond issue for the California Educational Facilities Authority was priced yesterday by the managing underwriter, L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. The financing is for the Stanford University Project and the bonds were rated triple A by both the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service.

title: TASS CITES PERIL, U.S. DENIES IT; PROTESTS ARE ISSUE
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would not take part in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer.

title: A Safer Baseball
description: A new baseball that is designed to reduce the risk of serious injury to players hit by a batted or thrown ball was put on sale last month by the Worth Sports Company of Tullahoma, Tenn.

title: PANEL IN ALBANY URGED TO EXTEND TOXIC SUIT TIME
description: For 25 years, Raymond Walters applied asbestos insulation to heating pipes, plumbing and air-conditioning systems. In 1966, he was told he had asbestosis, and now, no longer able to work, he lives here on government disability benefits.

title: British Producer Prices
description: Producer prices rose a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent in April, the same increase as in March, the Trade and Industry Department said today. The index was set at a provisional 131.6 in April, on a base of 100 in 1980, 6.5 percent higher than a year earlier. In March, the year-to-year increase was 6.4 percent.

title: 6 Men Missing Off England
description: Rescuers searched the Yorkshire coast today for six men missing after a fishing boat was wrecked and another going to its aid was swamped by heavy seas.

title: No Headline
description: $500,000 Bond Frees Man Charged as a Spy

title: WHOM LOW INTEREST RATES WOULD HURT
description: To the Editor:

title: 19 Yugoslavs Seek Inquiry in Death
description: Nineteen Yugoslav intellectuals have appealed to Interior Minister Stane Dolanc to either clarify the violent death of one of 28 people who were detained last month or resign.

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REDEFINING POVERTY LEVELS
description: Pained at being accused of organizing ''a clandestine cabal,'' the Census Bureau has canceled a private meeting scheduled for May 18th. The purpose of the meeting was to seek advice from experts on how to measure the value of non-cash benefits, such as food stamps and Medicaid, to the poor.

title: POETS AND THE GRANDEUR OF POWER
description: Beyond the drone of bureaucrats, the hoopla of politicians and the hype of lobbyists, Washington is a city of serious poets who are writing what one of their luminaries, Archibald MacLeish, once defined as ''news that stays news.''

title: West German Output
description: West Germany's industrial production fell 4 percent in March, seasonally adjusted, from an upwardly revised February figure, the Economics Ministry said today. Despite the decline, production in March was up 3.1 percent from March 1983, the ministry said. It added that West Germany's industrial production remained strong and that March output figures normally had to be revised upward.

title: TOWARD PHILIPPINE DEMOCRACY
description: The Philippine legislative elections scheduled for next Monday will be held in an atmosphere of considerable controversy. A number of opposition politicians have refused to participate in a contest that they believe will be a rigged by the Government. The United States cannot ignore this controversy, but it must not abandon its efforts to encourage the restoration of democracy in the Philippines. Indeed, we should use this election as an occasion to pursue that goal by linking future aid to our best assessDavid Joel Steinberg is the author of ''The Philippines: A Singular and a Plural Place.'' ment of the fairness of this vote. Until the death of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., last Aug. 21, the Reagan Administration and, to a lesser extent, Congress supported President Ferdinand E. Marcos because he was a stable ally and because America wanted to retain the air base at Clark Field and the naval station at Subic Bay. Meanwhile, the restoration of democracy was slighted. Now, Mr. Aquino's martyrdom and Mr. Marcos's ill health have created the worst instability since independence in 1946 and require a policy reappraisal by the United States. Why should we be concerned about democracy in the Philippines? Eighty-five years ago, Americans conquered the Philippines and imposed their will on a mature nationalist movement. We justified our imperialism as altruism, creating a colonial government that was meant to dissolve itself, evolving in time into independence. The Philippines was to be ''a showcase of democracy'' by which the world could judge the efficacy of the American way.

title: TELXON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $384,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $384,000 for the year.

title: OFFICIALS REPORT OF LIBYAN INQUIRY
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been conducting surveillance of the Libyan Mission to the United Nations and has been trying to determine whether the Libyan Government illegally gave money to some black activists in this country, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: JUST RAVE ME THE PRICE
description: New York theater critics are useless. They never tell what a show is worth. The other night, for instance, I paid $45 to see a big globe of hair, which was attached to the head of the person in the seat in front of me. As hair goes, it was all right, but watching it for two and a half hours wasn't worth $45.

title: AIR QUALITY BETTER, E.P.A. SAYS, AS CONGRESS DEBATES NEW ACT
description: The nation's air quality has improved significantly in recent years, according to a report released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Ethiopian Jews Backed
description: A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on human rights passed a resolution today calling for increased attention to the plight of Ethiopian Jews, who it said had been reduced to 25,000 from hundreds of thousands. The resolution calls on President Reagan to help them emigrate.

title: STUDY SHOWS BIRTHS UP IN WOMEN IN THEIR 30'S
description: Childbearing is increasing among women in their 30's, a group that has its careers under way and wants children before it's too late, a new Government study showed today.

title: RESTAURANTS THAT MAKE THE NEIGHBORS DYSPEPTIC
description: THE surest path to gentrification is often through the stomach, as the appearance of many new restaurants in the city's ''upscale'' neighborhoods attests. But if these places are a boon to diners, to residents of the neighborhood they are often the cause of indigestion.

title: Bears Keep Payton
description: Walter Payton , the all-pro running back who had been offered a reported multimillion-dollar contract by the Chicago Blitz of the United States Football League, re-signed yesterday with the Chicago Bears. Payton, 29 years old, signed three one-year pacts.

title: Market Place; Value Line's Poor Showing
description: -ranking system of the Value Line

title: SOVIET PUTS LIMIT ON SAKHAROV WIFE
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, is under investigation for ''defaming the Soviet system'' and has been barred from leaving the city of Gorky, a friend of the couple said today.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $580,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $203,000 for the quarter and 9 months from a patent settlement. c-Net income.

title: JOHNSON PUBLISHING LEADS LIST
description: The Johnson Publishing Company, which issues Jet and Ebony magazines, has replaced Motown Industries, the entertainment company, as the largest American black-owned business, according to an annual survey by Black Enterprise magazine.

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Moscow's Statement Shuns Term 'Boycott'
description: The Soviet Union, in announcing today that it would not take part in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, did not use the word ''boycott'' to describe its action.

title: Advertising; Hallmark To Switch Agencies
description: WITH surprising suddenness, Hallmark Cards announced yesterday that it would leave Young & Rubicam after two years and take its multimillion-dollar advertising account to either Ogilvy & Mather or the Leo Burnett Company.

title: ABRAMS WILL OPEN AN INQUIRY INTO LION CAPITAL
description: The New York State Attorney General announced yesterday that he was opening an inquiry into the bankruptcy filing of Lion Capital Group, a small government securities dealer that borrowed millions of dollars from more than three dozen school districts and counties in New York.

title: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income figures exclude realized investment gains of $23,000 for the latest quarter and $174,000 for the year- ago quarter.

title: SOLDIER IN QUEBEC OPENS FIRE AT LEGISLATURE, KILLING THREE
description: A Canadian soldier who said his goal was to assassinate Quebec government officials burst into the Quebec National Assembly today, firing volleys of shots with a submachine gun. Three people were killed and 13 wounded.

title: BEHIND THE DECISION
description: Behind the reasons given by Soviet officials for the decision to pull out of the Olympic Games in Los Angeles looms one that has gone unmentioned, but that many Russians instinctively recognize as a deciding factor: the American boycott of the Moscow games in 1980. The statement of the Soviet Olympic Committee today - and press articles over the last few months - focused on problems with security in Los Angeles, meddling by the Government, high costs and commercialization.

title: CONCOCTING CHEAPER SUBSTITUTES FOR VEAL
description: WITH the price of veal cutlets ranging from $6.99 to $8.99 - and more - a pound, cooks tend to think twice before planning a meal of scaloppine or schnitzel. Yet what a pity that is. Cutlets not only represent short-order cooking at its best; they also lend themselves to an almost endless variety of presentations.

title: RULE BANNING YARMULKE IN MILITARY IS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a military rule preventing Jewish personnel from wearing yarmulkes.

title: FILM: DOCUMENTARY ON GYPSY FAMILY IN SWITZERLAND
description: MOST of ''Tenderness and Anger,'' which opens at the Film Forum today, takes place in a Swiss forest where a gypsy couple and their two children have temporarily set up housekeeping. Johannes Flutsch's documentary, with an intimate, informal feeling, patiently observes that authentic family and its way of life.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY GETS RARE MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
description: The Pierpont Morgan Library has been given what is by common agreement one of the finest private collections of illuminated manuscripts in the world - the William S. Glazier Collection.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition in 1983 of Dudley- Anderson-Yutzy Public Relations Inc.

title: ASSEMBLY PANEL REJECTS INCREASE IN DRINKING AGE
description: An Assembly staff report today rejected a proposal to raise New York's legal drinking age to 21, and said there were more effective ways of reducing drunken-driving accidents.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
CADILLAC FAIRVIEW PLANS BUYBACK BID
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said yesterday that it planned to recommend to its board that the company buy, through a tender offer, up to 15 million of its own shares.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN CLERIC IS SEIZED ON BEIRUT
description: An American Presbyterian minister was kidnapped outside his West Beirut home today. He was the fourth American to be abducted in three months.

title: Arizona Troops Begin Pullout From Copper Strike Towns
description: Some of the 300 troops that had been dispatched by the Arizona National Guard and the state police were withdrawn today from the strike-torn copper towns of Clifton and Morenci.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $570,000. c-Net income includes a gain of $5.5 million on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: The Olympic torch relay began here yesterday, surviving a steady rain, the mostly blank stares from the relatively few spectators and the Soviet Union's announcement that it would not take part in this summer's Olympic Games at Los Angeles.

title: Newspaper Ad Sales
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, working with linage data from Media Records, reported that in February the advertising revenues for the country's papers were $1.7 billion, a 22.5 percent gain from a year earlier. Classified ad revenues rose 35.9 percent, to $562 million, while national ads gained 11.8 percent, to $237 million, and retail ads were up 18.3 percent, to $924 million.

title: STAGE: GUARE'S 'LANDSCAPE' REVIVED
description: IN John Guare's ''Landscape of

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOREIGN OLYMPIC OFFICIALS WONDER IF EASTERN BLOC WILL FOLLOW SOVIET LEAD
description: Sports figures and Olympic officials expressed surprise, dismay and anger over the Soviet Union's announcement today that it would not take part in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Some predicted that other Eastern European countries would follow Moscow's lead.

title: 10th Jersey Casino Is Granted License
description: Harrah's at Trump Plaza received a gaming license today from the Casino Control Commission and said it plans to open next week as Atlantic City's 10th gaming parlor.

title: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GIRLS' SCHOOL IN CONNECTICUT EXPELS SIX FOR COCAINE USE
description: The Ethel Walker School, a private boarding school for girls, has expelled six students for using cocaine and three for drinking, a school official said today.

title: AGENT ORANGE: HOW FUND WILL WORK
description: The settlement between makers of Agent Orange and Vietnam veterans who said they were harmed by the herbicide averted what could have been a turbulent court battle. But it also generated a host of complex new issues that will preoccupy the veterans and their lawyers for a long time.

title: JOAN CHASE WINS HEMINGWAY PRIZE
description: The Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award for first fiction by an American writer has been won by Joan Chase for ''During the Reign of the Queen of Persia,'' a novel about three generations of Ohio farm women, published by Harper & Row.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an unrealized foreign currency translation loss of $73,000.

title: College Student Raped in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn College student was raped in a campus restroom Monday morning in what the police believe was the latest of five assaults on students by the same person, Inspector John Hill of the Brooklyn detective unit said yesterday.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the year-ago quarter are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 25, 1983.

title: Colorado Violinist Wins Young Musicians' Prize
description: Michaela Modjeska Paetsch, a violinist from Colorado, won first prize Sunday in the G. B. Dealey Awards competition for promising young musicians.

title: Grace Gets Cocoa Plant
description: W. R. Grace & Company of New York is buying the cocoa processing factory of Allied Cocoa Industries in Singapore for $14.8 million, it was announced today. The troubled Allied Cocoa, which was put up for sale last month, is a joint venture of Allied Food Industries of Hong Kong and its 50 percent owned subsidiary, Allied Chocolate Industries Ltd. The plant employs 260 workers and can produce 27,000 to 36,000 tons of chocolate products annually.

title: FOR CRISP POPOVERS
description: POPOVERS, the English puffed muffins made with eggs, milk and flour, are festive and easy-to-prepare breakfast treats that can be a pleasant change from heavier muffins and bagels.

title: OHIO AND INDIANA ARE WON BY HART, BUOYING HIS DRIVE
description: Gary Hart won the Presidential primaries in Ohio and Indiana yesterday, denying Walter F. Mondale the victories he needed to bring the battle for the Democratic nomination to an early close.

title: BUCKS TOP NETS AND TAKE LEAD IN SERIES BY 3-2
description: For a time it looked as if the Nets were following a familiar script. Just as they had done in the last game of this playoff series, they fell behind the Milwaukee Bucks - this time by 19 points - before slicing the deficit to almost nothing after a spirited rally.

title: ECTOPIC PREGNANCY: INCREASING HAZARD
description: THE word epidemic is not one that doctors use lightly. Yet several times in recent months, in reports published in Obstetrics & Gynecology, the leading American journal in the field, ''epidemic'' has been used to describe the dramatic increase since 1970 of a life-threatening obstetrical problem: ectopic pregnancy, in which the embryo starts outside the uterus - usually in the Fallopian tubes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a report in some editions May 4 on Claus von B"ulow misidentified the hospital where his wife, Martha, is in a coma. She is a patient at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $199,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,681,000.

title: MAGAZINE'S WINNING FORMULA
description: Hot tubs, kiwi fruit and Napa Valley chablis. By now they might be called the cliches of California, but not by Sunset magazine. For the magazine that was promoting the West before the West was won, they come with the territory.

title: LUSITANIA DOCUMENTARY
description: ''DEATH BY MISADVENTURE?,'' a one-hour British documentary, says the sinking of the Lusitania in 1915 could have been avoided. It is unlikely you will argue with the conclusion, and it is unlikely you will be much moved by it, either. The documentary, which appears to be rather musty, drowns in its own solemnity. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

description: Following is the text of a statement by the Soviet National Olympic Committee today saying it would not send a team to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: 39 Go on Trial in Ulster As I.R.A. Suspects
description: The biggest trial ever of anti- British guerrilla suspects in Northern Ireland opened today with 39 defendants facing 190 charges on the word of an informer who had belonged to the Irish Republican Army.

description: Nicaraguan soldiers shot down a military helicopter from Honduras today when it entered Nicaraguan airspace, killing all eight men aboard, the Government announced.

title: TO MODERN TIMES FOR JAPANESE: ADD THE SOCIAL ILLS
description: Foreigners have long marveled at Japan's ability to acquire appurtenances of modernity, like computer-age industries, while seeming to keep underlying social patterns unaffected. But today, two generations after World War II, traditional values are significantly changing in this nation of 118 million people.

title: World Debt Talks End
description: Representatives from about 30 central banks wound up a three-day conference yesterday at which international debt problems were discussed in a longer-term perspective.

title: DIAGHILEV MEMORABILIA IS SOLD FOR $1.1 MILLION
description: The former dancer Serge Lifar, a protege of Diaghilev and the last of the premiers danseurs of the Ballets Russes, today sold at auction his collection of original manuscripts, paintings, notebooks and correspondence from the Diaghilev era.

description: President Reagan today nominated Charles L. Marinaccio, the chief minority counsel on the Senate Banking Committee, to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Upon Senate confirmation, Mr. Marinaccio, 50 years old, would succeed Barbara S.

description: An Israeli Cabinet minister said today that the 1980 bombing attacks on two Arab mayors in the occupied West Bank had been assaults on people ''responsible for incitement.''

title: Fires Level 13,000 Acres In Texas and California By The Associated Press
description: Firefighters in Southern California today fought brush fires fanned by high winds that consumed 11,700 acres, while a blaze in central Texas engulfed more than 1,500 acres and destroyed at least four homes.

description: Professional diplomats often complain that the imperfect art of diplomacy is made even more imperfect when some political appointees try to practice it.

title: THEATER: 'DOG LADY' AND 'SWIMMER'
description: THE sets designed by Ming Cho Lee are the hit of the evening at ''The Cuban Swimmer'' and ''Dog Lady,'' two plays by Milcha Sanchez-Scott. Through the artistic techniques of perspective, suggestion and just plain legerdemain, the two one-acters on Intar's 22-foot stage on West 42d Street make you believe that you're watching a wide-angle spectacle at the Winter Garden.

title: Huge Ticket Sale
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits called it ''the largest single ticket purchase in sports history'' when John Bassett , the owner, purchased 27,500 tickets to the Sept. 1 game between the University of Miami and Florida at the 72,812-seat Tampa Stadium. Bassett said he would reoffer the tickets to the 32,000 Bandit season ticket-holders at the same $15 price he paid.

General Oriental also said that another subsidiary, Diamond Group Inc., had sold to the same investor group its lumber mills in Oregon for an additional $29.3 million.

A large part of the profits from that magazine, The Reader's Digest, were turned to imaginative philanthropic purpose by Mrs. Wallace before her death on Tuesday at 94.

title: F.S.L.I.C. Head to Quit
description: David W. Glenn submitted his resignation today as head of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The letter of resignation was submitted to Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Mr. Gray said Mr. Glenn, 40 years old, had written that he felt he had accomplished most of his goals since he took the position last May. Mr. Glenn has no immediate plans and will remain at the post until a successor has been found.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday with an article on the rededication ceremonies at the Museum of Modern Art misidentified the men standing in front of a painting. Donald B. Marron, chairman of the museum's expansion committee, was at left and the artist Jasper Johns at right.

description: An investment counselor to the 16 principal owners of the Seabrook Nuclear Power plant said today that he was ''optimistic'' that agreement was near on a $1.3 billion plan to bail out the financially troubled project and start construction again.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF MURDER REQUEST
description: A building superintendent testifying yesterday at the murder trial of Irwin M. Margolies said Mr. Margolies, the former president of a diamond company, had told Donald Nash that he wanted Mr. Nash ''to get rid of two people.''

title: A New Showboat
description: Barney Bussey , a defensive back from South Carolina who passed up a chance to sign with the Memphis Showboats after they made him their No. 1 draft choice, changed his mind and signed a four-year, $800,000 contract with the U.S.F.L. team. Bussey had held out for a better deal from the N.F.L., but the Cincinnati Bengals, who drafted him on the fifth round, would not match the Showboats' offer. Bussey's agent said the delay cost Bussey $100,000.

description: HISTORY may yet prove that our generation has underrated Felix Mendelssohn as mistakenly as the Victorians may have overrated him. Today Mendelssohn is known by only a handful of his most popular works, and there is the tendency to write him off with the observation that he was ''born a genius and died a talent.''

title: TAX SHELTER PLANS GONE AWRY
description: A clutch of prominent people from business, entertainment and politics who invested in two intricate partnerships designed to generate tax losses may now have more losses than they bargained for.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS MOVE HIGHER

title: DISTRICT IN CALIFORNIA RETAINS COUNCILMAN IN RECALL OVER RACE
description: A recall election in Stockton in which the major issue was race provided a victory for Councilman Mark Stebbins, despite charges that he had lied about being black to gain votes.

title: Winter Wheat Forecast Flat
description: In its first estimate of 1984 wheat production, the Agriculture Department today forecast this year's winter wheat crop at 1.98 billion bushels, 1 percent below last year's output, which was the fourth largest on record.

title: MUSIC: 92D STREET Y CHORALE
description: FOR many professional musicians and regular concertgoers alike, the first, addictive, hands-on musical experience came in the form of amateur choral singing. But few of us, I imagine, can have experienced it with so lively and well-routined a choir as the Y Chorale, which performed under its director Amy Kaiser at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday.

title: PLAN FOR WEAPONS IN SPACE IS TOLD
description: Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson of the Air Force today gave the first description of the Reagan Administration's timetable for developing space-based weapons. The plan he outlined included fielding weapons in space to protect strategic missiles instead of populations.

title: June 19 'Rinaldo' Opens 18th Met Park Season
description: A performance of Handel's ''Rinaldo,'' with Marilyn Horne in the leading role, will open the 18th season of free park performances by the Metropolitan Opera on June 19 at 8:30 P.M. on the Great Lawn of Central Park. Also performing will be Benita Valente, Edda Moser, Dano Raffanti and Samuel Ramey; Mario Bernardi is the conductor.

description: -and- a-half-year-old Fallon McElligott Rice of far-off Minneapolis was the big winner at the One Show last night at the New York Hilton, with six gold awards.

title: Threat Shuts Florida Bridge
description: A bomb threat forced the closing of the Sunshine Skyway Bridge today, four years to the day after a freighter rammed a piling and collapsed a chunk of roadway, sending 35 people to their deaths in Tampa Bay. Myrna Johnson, a toll booth supervisor, received a telephone call at 6:53 A.M. from an anonymous man who said a bomb had been placed on the bridge and would go off between 7 A.M. and noon, according to Holly Waggoner, a spokesman for the Florida Department of Transportation.

title: Bridge: A Deal in Memphis Playoffs Turned Sour for the Defense
description: The symbol of Western Australia is the black swan, a rare and beautiful bird. One member of the species, lonely, majestic and irritable, swims unexpectedly around the artificial lake at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Memphis, where the international team playoffs were played recently.

title: Market Place; Foreign Stocks Lure Big Funds
description: SINCE stock prices in many foreign countries have outperformed United States equities for 18 months or longer, corporate pension and profit-sharing funds are increasingly turning to investment possibilities overseas. And money managers, in turn, busily court these American institutional investors.

description: Diplomats said today that at least five Libyans and an Ethiopian were killed in an explosion at a house here Tuesday night.

description: THE final Music From Marlboro concert in New York this season, Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, wasn't impeccable in every respect; what is? But in terms of repertory, good intentions and the overall conception of this annual series, it was as deeply rewarding as ever.

description: Tony Gwynn of the San Diego Padres admits that his is not a household name, but he is happy to remain comparatively obscure in the company of more publicized teammates such as Goose Gossage, Steve Garvey, Graig Nettles and Garry Templeton.

STANLEY CUP FINAL MATCHUPS
description: Forwards (Position, Height, Weight, Goals-Assists-Points). Mike Bossy (RW, 6-0, 185, 51-67 - 118)For the seventh consecutive season, he finished with better than 50 goals. After a slow start in the playoffs, he collected three of the four game-winning goals against Montreal in the semifinals and is one goal shy of tying Jean Beliveau's career high of 82 playoff goals. He scored 17 last year, best in the playoffs, but only 2 against the Oilers. Bryan Trottier (C, 5-11, 195, 40-71 - 111)Few forwards or defensemen can match his body-checking and his play without the puck. After averaging better than 17 assists in each of the four previous cup years, he has aided on only six goals. His 47 penalty minutes mirror some of his frustration. John Tonelli (LW, 6-1, 197, 27-40 - 67)He has missed four playoff games because of a shoulder injury, but his one goal was the key to overcoming the Rangers in game 4 of the first round. Greg Gilbert (LW, 22, 6-1, 194, 31-35 - 66)He played only one game in last year's playoffs and has not missed one this year. Spent most of the season on the Trottier-Bossy line and scored on more than 25 percent of his shots, best among Islander forwards. Bob Bourne (LW-C, 6-3, 202, 22-34 - 56)His point production was his second highest in eight years, though he spent much time at center rather than left wing, the position he prefers. He could miss the entire final round as a result of sustaining ligament damage to left knee in opening game with Canadiens.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend in April 1984.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTCHESTER FIGHTS TO KEEP BLUE-COLAR JOBS
description: In the 20 months since the General Motors Corporation canceled the second shift at its assembly plant here, the survival of one of the largest bluecollar employers in the suburbs of New York City has been in doubt.

title: Thomson McKinnon, S.E.C. Pact
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., the big Wall Street brokerage house, with failing to supervise six employees and former employees for several months and thus contributing to more than $2 million in customer losses.

title: HISTORIC-HOUSE TOURS IN NEW YORK AND L.I.
description: Many historic houses and districts are open for public view in the New York area. The following are some building tours available to the public in the coming weeks. Saturday: Brooklyn Heights Landmarks Festival offers a self-guided tour of five 19th-century town houses from 1 to 4 P.M. A brochure and map describe and pinpoint houses from Pineapple Street to Garden Place, one renovated with skylights and sunrooms, another with a carriage house beside a garden. Afterward, tea will be served in the library of the Long Island Historical Society.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Latin Lawmakers Bid U.S. Ease Bank Terms
description: Leading legislators of 15 Latin American countries appealed today to American banks and the Reagan Administration to provide more liberal terms to aid them in dealing with their foreign debts.

title: LIBYAN EXILES ASSERT 15 DIED IN ATTACK
description: Libyan exiles said in London today that all 15 guerrillas who sought on Tuesday to assassinate the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, were killed in a five-hour battle with loyalist forces.

title: LOOKING FOR HOPE
description: This is a time of exceptional danger in the Middle East, and anyone who doubts it should visit Jordan. In this calm country, a model of stability and moderation in the Arab world, he will find a gloomy Government looking anxiously for reasons to find hope.

title: M.T.A. TO SUE MANUFACTURER OF SIDELINED GRUMMAN BUSES
description: The board of directors of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to sue the maker of the Grumman Flxible buses.

title: GUADALCANAL LEADER TELLS POPE HIS CONCERNS
description: Pope John Paul II today visited Guadalcanal, one of the notable battlefields of World War II, and was greeted by the chief of state of this island nation with an address expressing fears over policies of the bigger countries.

title: Top Olympic Officials Are Going to Moscow
description: Three top Olympic officials will go to Moscow on Friday to try to persuade the Soviet Union to reverse its decision to stay away from the Olympic Games in Los Angeles. They are also expected to take up Bulgaria's decision to withdraw.

title: ASPIN TO OFFER A COMPROMISE AIMED AT SAVING MX MISSILE
description: A key Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee today acknowledged plans for a new legislative compromise to save the MX missile.

title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOW SLIDES BY 10.78, TO 1,165.52
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday in much heavier trading after advancing moderately on Tuesday. The star performer was Teledyne, which soared 32 points, to 187 3/4.

title: VERMONT FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HART STRATEGY SHIFT CITED IN VICTORIES
description: Senator Gary Hart laid the groundwork for his surprise victories in Ohio and Indiana in the ashes of defeat in Pennsylvania a month ago, his strategists said yesterday. They refashioned their attacks on Walter F. Mondale and then outflanked him by concentrating on the Middle West when Mr. Mondale chose to focus on Texas.

title: But Is Nine Mile Worth Saving?
description: New York's Governor Cuomo has produced a clever plan for completing the Nine Mile II nuclear power plant without further economic risk to consumers. But the plan skips an important step: a hard judgment on whether the project, even with $3 billion spent, is best abandoned.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said shares outstanding were reduced for the latest quarter and 6 months because of a company stock repurchase program.

title: Koch Appoints Chief For City Rights Panel
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the appointment of Marcella Maxwell to head the city's Commission on Human Rights. Mrs. Maxwell, who is 56 years old, will replace Isaiah E. Robinson Jr., who recently resigned.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

TRANSIERRA EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

description: Natalia Makarova was dancing in

title: S.E.C. Appeal Bid on Carter Denied
description: A Federal Appeals Court late yesterday rejected a bid by the Securities and Exchange Commission to enjoin a stock repurchase by Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. pending an appeal.

title: LEGG MASON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNCLE SAM'S ENDURING TRANSIT MAZE
description: Despite the advent here eight years ago of one of the world's most modern subway systems, departments and agencies of the Federal Government continue to operate, for the most part independently of one another, about 80 shuttle-bus routes for the convenience of their far-flung, and sometimes not- so-far-flung, employees.

title: POP: PAUL YOUNG AT THE RITZ
description: PAUL YOUNG, one of the most successful new English pop singers, embodies the current trend among British groups to incorporate mannerisms of early 1960's American soul music. Mr. Young has a husky, passionate pop-soul tenor, and his gospel- flavored phrasing owes much to the late Sam Cooke.

title: 54 Boycotted in 1980
description: The boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow was called by President Carter to protest the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. These are the 54 nations and territories that participated in the boycott, according to the United States Olympic Committee in Colorado Springs. Albania Antigua Argentina Bahamas Bahrain Bangladesh Belize Bermuda Bolivia Canada Cayman Islands Chad Chile China Egypt El Salvador Fiji Gambia Germany, West Ghana Haiti Honduras Hong Kong Indonesia Israel Japan Kenya Liberia Liechtenstein Malawi Malaysia Mauritius Monaco Morocco Nicaragua Norway Pakistan Papua New Guinea Paraguay Philippines Saudi Arabia Singapore Somalia South Korea Sudan Swaziland Taiwan Thailand Tunisia Turkey United States Uruguay Virgin Islands Zaire

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on May 1 incorrectly described the location and business of Channel Industries, which acquired 50.1 percent of American Vision Centers Inc. The company, based in New York City, makes contact lenses.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. Envoys Nominated
description: President Reagan today announced the nomination of two Foreign Service officers as ambassadors. Peter Sebastian, director of the State Department's Office of North African Affairs, was nominated as envoy to Tunisia, and Clint Lauderdale, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for personnel, to Guyana. The nominations are subject to Senate confirmation.

title: HERNANDEZ HELPS METS END SLIDE AT 3
description: Just as the atmosphere around Shea Stadium was beginning to thicken with discontent after three straight one-sided defeats, the Mets banged out 11 hits and beat the Atlanta Braves, 3-1, before 8,141 fans last night.

title: CITY MAY TAKE PUNITIVE ACTION ON CASEWORKERS
description: City welfare officials are considering disciplinary action against city social workers who handled 17 abuse cases in which 9 Brooklyn children died, Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff said yesterday.

title: CITY WELFARE CHIEF, LIKE PREDECESSORS, IS BESET BY PROBLEMS AND CRITICISM
description: How to stop child abuse and care for the homeless, what to do about the growing number of people receiving welfare, Medicaid and food stamps, where to find money to care for homebound invalids - these are a few of the problems James A. Krauskopf faces every day.

title: METHOD USED FOR VOTER POLLS
description: The accompanying article is based on questionnaires given to Democratic primary voters in randomly selected precincts as they left polling places in four states, Illinois on March 20, Pennsylvania on April 10 and Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday. The polls in Illinois, Pennsylvania and Ohio were conducted jointly by The New York Times and CBS News; the poll in Indiana was conducted by CBS News alone.

title: MUSIC: 'MAIDEN' VERSION
description: IN 1894, Gustav Mahler led a

title: THE REAGAN SPEECH
description: News Analysis

title: NOBEL INSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 15 percent stock dividend issued in March 1983.

title: CUOMO LISTS FUGITIVES CALLED '12 MOST WANTED'
description: Governor Cuomo today released a list of New York State's ''12 most wanted'' criminals and urged the public to help in their capture.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a gross profit of $2.3 million from the sale of land.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MAY 10, 1984

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Homecrafters is a former Union Camp Corp. unit that was brought public by a management group on Feb. 1, 1984. The figures for both years are on a pro-forma basis reflecting interest expense and other costs the company would have incurred as a public company. The company said that the actual net for its 36 stores in calendar 1983 was $838,000 against a loss of $250,000 in 1982. Earlier this year Homecrafters Warehouse changed to a Jan. 31 year from a calendar year.

title: VESCO REPORTED IN CUBA, AS TANGIBLE AS A GHOST
description: Diplomats here say that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, has been living a reclusive life in Cuba for more than a year, dividing his time among modest houses at three beach resorts and aboard a 50-foot ocean-going yacht.

title: RIGHTIST CLAIMS ELECTION VICTORY IN EL SALVADOR
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the far right, said today that according to his party's count he won the presidential election on Sunday. He charged that votes were being improperly counted.

title: NEW CHARGES MADE ON NAZI
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center for the documentation of Nazi war crimes said yesterday that new data from American archives revealed ''a close working relationship'' between a former SS colonel, Walter Rauff, and Roman Catholic Church officials in Italy in World War II and gave credence to assertions of Vatican involvement in the Nazi's later escape to South America.

title: LEONARD APPEARS SHARP FOR RETURN
description: The punches, generally thrown by smaller and quicker fighters, came from all angles, but Sugar Ray Leonard remained with his eyes wide open.

title: Official Result of Vote In Panama Is Delayed
description: Election officials and aides to the two leading presidential candidates said today that they did not expect an official winner of Sunday's election to be proclaimed until at least next week.

title: Supreme Court Backs An Execution in Florida
description: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for Florida officials to execute a man, convicted of murder, who is to be the first black in 20 years to be electrocuted in the state.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Florida National Banks Offering Floating Notes
description: A public offering of $50 million of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. floating-rate subordinated notes due in 1996 was announced by Salomon Brothers. The notes were priced to yield 99.375 percent, plus accrued interest, if any, from May 16.

title: CALMAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

HOMER IN 25TH ENDS FIRST 8-HOUR GAME
description: Harold Baines ended the first eight-hour game in major league history by hitting a home run with one out in the bottom of the 25th inning tonight to lift the Chicago White Sox to a 7-6 triumph over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Texas Banks Give Ex-Regulator a Gift
description: James E. Stewart, who retired last August as Texas Banking Commissioner, does not understand what all the flap is about.

title: FELDSTEIN, AFTER STORMY TENURE, LEAVING REAGAN ECONOMIC TEAM
description: Martin S. Feldstein, who frequently differed with the White House over budget deficits and Federal Reserve policies, said today that he would resign July 10 as the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: SEAGULL ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South African Plans Tour
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha will visit Switzerland on a West European tour, in addition to West Germany and Britain, a Government spokesman said today.

title: CONNORS, LENDL AND MCENROE WINNERS
description: In swirling winds unsuitable even for sailing, Jimmy Connors, the top- seeded player, had plenty of difficulty eliminating Danie Visser in the Mercedes Tournament of Champions yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: A LOOK AT OUTDOOR CHAIRS OF SUMMER
description: -like existence: briefly appreciated during the warm months, it was packed away to a basement or closet as soon as the air turned cool and the first leaves fell.

title: Natalia Makarova Hurt
description: Natalia Makarova, scheduled to perform tonight in Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances,'' will not appear because of a hip injury. The ballet has been replaced by Twyla Tharp's ''Sinatra Suite,'' with Elaine Kudo and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: Census Bureau Reports On Voting-Age Groups
description: People from 25 to 44 years old will predominate among the nearly 174 million Americans eligible to vote in this fall's Presidential election, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tax Rise and Domed Stadium Are Voted Down in Cleveland
description: Mayor George Voinovich minimized the importance of a defeated tax increase proposal today but said the city won a ''new lease on life'' when voters also rejected measures to force the hiring of more police officers and firefighters.

title: Flickinger Talks
description: The S. M. Flickinger Company said it had begun discussions with an unidentified party on the possible acquisition of Flickinger for $36 a share, subject to certain conditions.

description: b-Includes a special gain of $368,857.

title: MADRID GETS A MESSAGE FROM REGIONS: AUTONOMY
description: The nationalist Catalan party was the decisive winner in regional elections in Catalonia last month and the victory is beginning to have an impact far beyond the question of who rules locally in the powerful industrial area of northeastern Spain.

title: 26,000 Porsches Recalled Along With 357 Chevrolets
description: Volkswagen of America said Tuesday it was recalling 26,000 Porsche sports cars and Chevrolet announced it was recalling 357 of its 1984 Celebrity midsize automobiles.

title: IN CUTTING DEFICITS, MODESTY IS NO VIRTUE
description: The conventional wisdom has been stood on its ear.

description: b-Includes a gain of $4,282,000 from disposal of assets. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Thrift Unit Merger
description: San Francisco Bancorp said it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Atlantic Financial Federal for $8.50 a share. Atlantic currently owns about 21 percent of San Francisco Bancorp's common shares outstanding. San Francisco Bancorp, a savings and loan company, had assets of $108.4 milllion as of March 31, while Atlantic, a Pennsylvania-based savings and loan association, had assets of $2.5 billion.

description: Chief Retiring At Marsteller

description: A 3-story commercial complex topped by an 11-story housing tower for the elderly is to be built next to the proposed White Street jail, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

description: A State Department official said today that the United States received a request for emergency military aid from Costa Rica last week totaling more than $7.5 million.

title: WEST EUROPEANS HAIL SALVADORAN VOTE RESULT
description: Reaction to Jose Napoleon Duarte's apparent victory in El Salvador's presidential election was favorable in Western Europe, but commentators stressed that the country's problems, and those of the United States in relation to them, were far from solved.

title: Getty Insurer Unit, G.E. Credit in Talks
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said yesterday that it was holding discussions on the possible acquisition of the Employers Reinsurance Corporation of Kansas City, Kan.

title: ; Thompson Withdraws An Ad for Burger King
description: Speaking of J. Walter Thompson, a week ago it released its fourth pool of Burger King commercials since it adopted its aggressive, competitive and slightly irreverant stance in 1981. One of the new spots was a deliciously accurate rip-off of Mr. Rogers, the kindly TV host for tots.

title: GIFTS; Twenty-Five Lives
description: The reward of good sense is often invisible: an absence of trouble.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 10, 1984 International
description: The President appealed on television for approval of his package of military and economic aid to Central America, warning that ''the Communists will likely succeed'' in toppling the Government of El Salvador if Congress rejects the program. Mr. Reagan made his most explicit appeal for support of what was once known as a program of ''covert'' assistance to rebels seeking to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua. (Page A1, Column 6.) Roberto d'Aubuisson claimed victory in the Salvadoran presidential election, saying that votes had been improperly counted and that by his party's count he had won 52 percent of the votes. Jose Napoleon Duarte, the moderate candidate, said Monday he had won the election with 54 percent of the votes - a statement with which United States officials agree. (A1:5.)

title: AN AUDIT FAULTS THE OPERATIONS OF OTB IN CITY
description: Revenues of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation are shrinking because of poor management resulting in widespread inefficiency in operation of the public corporation, head, according to a state audit released yesterday.

title: DRUMMOND MCCALL METALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest first quarter include operations of the Marshall Steel division acquired Sept. 30.

title: Two Flags Over Belfast?
description: A salutary document has been signed in Dublin by the leaders of four parties representing three of every four Irish voters, South and North. What distinguishes the New Ireland Forum report is its fresh approach to an old and passionate argument.

title: WINFIELD, MATTINGLY LEAD YANKEE ROUT
description: Dave Winfield rapped four hits, including a home run, scored four runs and drove in three. Don Mattingly hit a home run and knocked in five runs. Roy Smalley hit a third home run for the power-starved Yankees, but it was perhaps Toby Harrah's less- prodigious contribution to the 11-4 victory over Cleveland last night that indicated a change in Yogi Berra's luck.

title: BILL ON HUDSON SEWAGE OPPOSED
description: New York City's political leaders and the Reagan Administration lined up today to oppose a Congressional bill that would punish New York City for its discharge of raw sewage into the Hudson River.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE KNICKS AND LEAD SERIES BY 3-2
description: The Celtics' running game resurfaced in the first half tonight and was coupled with the outside shooting that had all but disappeared for them in the last two games as Boston overwhelmed the Knicks, 121-99, at the Boston Garden.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
HELPING THE GARDENER TO HELP THINGS GROW
description: THE gardening season is in full swing and some handy devices will make the work of the gardener easier.
