Cuomo's Book Sells, Too
description: Picked as a Book-of-the-Month Club

title: REAGAN PREDICTS LOSS OF SALVADOR IF U.S. CEASES AID
description: President Reagan, appealing in a television speech for approval of his package of aid to Central America, warned tonight that ''the Communists will likely succeed'' in toppling the Government of El Salvador if Congress rejects the aid.

title: $200 Million Issue Of Utility Bonds
description: A $200 million Orlando, Fla., Utility Commission revenue bond issue was priced at 99 to yield about 10.61 percent. The term bonds, rated double A by both Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, mature in 2014 and were given a 10 1/2 percent coupon.

title: A REALIGNMENT FOR INSURANCE
description: The word in the insurance industry these days is ''demutualize.'' For many of the nation's mutual life insurance companies - insurers owned by their policyholders rather than by stockholders - are thinking of converting to stockholder ownership, a move that could change the face of the industry.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
F.B.I. ARRESTS 2 LIBYAN STUDENTS
description: Two Libyans were arrested in a Philadelphia suburb yesterday after one of them bought three .45-caliber handguns with silencers from a Federal undercover agent on Staten Island hours before, Federal authorities said.

title: TIGERS NOW 25-4
description: Alan Trammell, swinging the hottest bat in the American League at .381, collected 3 hits and led the Detroit Tigers to a 3-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO FLASHES Reflections of German culture are always present at Goethe House New York, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 82d Street (744-8310), but the images that go on view there today come straight from the camera, although they are visions refined by the artist's eye.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SAHARA RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AN AMERICAN PROCESSION. By Alfred Kazin. 408 pages. Knopf. $18.95.

title: TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Peking April 27 about a last-minute concession by the Chinese on a nuclear agreement with the United States incorrectly identified the sources of the information. The information came from commercial sources, not from commerce officials.

title: Wilson Plant Sale
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Cedar Rapids, Iowa, hog slaughtering and processing plant for about $16 million to Cedar Rapids Meats Inc., a new company headed by Keith Barnes, a Minnesota businessman.

title: CUBA SAID TO RESIST LEAVING ANGOLA
description: Cuba has told Angola that it opposes beginning a phased withdrawal of its troops from Angola now because a settlement in southern Africa might help President Reagan's re-election prospects, Administration officials said today.

title: SYNERGETICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Leave the Clean Water Act Unmuddied
description: New York City and part of suburban New Jersey share a harbor into which the city pours raw sewage. The end of that nuisance is in sight, as two new sewage plants are finished in the next 30 months. But that achievement does not assuage New Jersey's Representative James Howard, who is pressing a vindictive amendment to the Clean Water Act. It would prevent use of any New York building built since May 1 if the city's daily raw sewage outflow increases over past averages.

title: Spain Is Closing In on Rumasa Fugitive
description: The eyes of Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos, the financier who left the country after his shaky multibillion-dollar business empire was expropriated last year by the Government, stare from the cover of almost every weekly magazine here.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UTILITY BILL OPTION: LEVELIZED PAYMENT
description: THERE is nothing quite as unpredictable as a utility bill. In spring and fall, when windows are open and thermostats off, gas and electric charges are low. In the winter and summer, when furnaces and air-conditioners work overtime, monthly bills can soar.

title: SENSORMATIC CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOME NON-BANK BANKS CLEARED BY COMPTROLLER
description: In an unusual arrangement with Congress, the Comptroller of the Currency, C. Todd Conover, gave a number of banks permission today to operate units across state lines and told legislators that he might approve scores of similar applications unless they passed a banking bill before the elections.

title: FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $34,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the 9 months. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the quarter and $1,031,000 for the 9 months.

title: DANCE: 'LA SYLPHIDE' BY AMERICAN BALLET THEATER
description: LIVELY storytelling and dance that glowed with delicate color made for a fine performance of August Bournonville's ''Sylphide'' on Tuesday, presented by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: VITAMIN E PRODUCT RAISED BIG HOPES
description: When Santa Rosa Children's Hospital received its first shipment of E-Ferol, a new form of Vitamin E that can be injected intravenously, a few months ago, the hospital director, Dr. Howard Britton, said he had high hopes for it.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: AT CARNEGIE HALL, DAME JANET BAKER SINGS
description: A SONG recital by Dame Janet Baker is, among other things, an oasis of civility and good taste. When you go to hear Britain's foremost lieder singer you can relax in the certainty of enjoying an evening of exquisitely shaded interpretations and a general atmosphere of refinement. By now, there will be few surprises, perhaps, but her devotees do not want surprises. They want flawless musicianship, elegance, gentility and thoughtful understatement.

title: THOMAS DICKENS, EX-JUSTICE, DEAD
description: Thomas Dickens, who retired from the New York State Supreme Court on Dec. 31 after a 32-year judicial career, died of heart disease Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived on Roosevelt Island.

title: Islanders Aiming At 5th Cup Tonight
description: From beginning to end, trailing or leading, the Oilers spray the pck in the wide- open style that has been so successful for them. The Islanders, who have seen and overcome almost every style known to hockey in the last five seasons, are patient but opportunistic, which has been successful for them.

title: Article 180493 -- No Title
description: Caesars World Inc. announced that its subsidiary, the Caesars World Finance Corporation, had placed $100 million in 14 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due May 15, 1996.

title: O'NEILL PRAISES LAWMAKERS AS THE LEGISLATURE ADJOURNS
description: The General Assembly tonight adjourned a three- month legislative session that gave Gov. William A. O'Neill most of what he had sought.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Angry Milk Producers Block French Roads
description: French milk producers blocked the main roads out of Arras in northeastern France this morning to protest plans to cut milk output, the police said.

title: S.E.C. BACKS NEW TAKEOVER RULES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a sweeping legislative package of changes in Federal takeover regulations that could restrain a company's efforts to repel takeovers.

title: C.D. Yields Rise Again
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose in a week that saw the third increase of the prime rate in three months, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of 45 Godfather's Pizza restaurants purchased in July 1983.

title: Barney M. Giles, 91; Was Air Force Leader
description: Lieut. Gen. Barney M. Giles, who served as commander of the 20th Air Force in the Pacific in World War II and was knighted by King George VI of Britain, died Sunday at the Brooke Army Medical Center here. He was 91 years old.

title: A SHODDY TRICK
description: Something funny is happening on the way to the reform of Unesco. The United States announcement that it will withdraw at the end of this year has had real effect.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp.'s Bendix Aerospace Sector said it plans to begin construction this year of a $28 million manufacturing facility in Columbia, Md., to produce microcircuits for Allied operating units.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Coast Savings and Loan Association of California said its wholly owned subsidiary, Coastfed International Finance N.V., had signed for the sale of $125 million of 12 1/4 percent notes due May 15, 1988, through Goldman Sachs International Corp. The offering is one of the largest single financings in Europe by an American thrift association.

title: Scranton Officials Worry As Water Alert Is Lifted
description: State officials gave 140,000 residents of the Scranton area the go-ahead today to drink their water without boiling it first, but city officials said they did not believe the danger from a parasite had passed.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income of approximately $950,000, or 12 cents a share, from the net settlement of two lawsuits.

title: A SAARINEN COLLECTION
description: -Walker showroom, a smooth space by Robert A. M. Stern at 666 Third Avenue (43d Street), is the setting through May 25 for an exhibit of furnishings from the Eliel Saarinen family collection. Included are a candleholder, top left, by J. Robert F. Swanson, the architect's son-in-law; sugar bowl and pitcher, left; tea urn, above; torch ere, right, and buffet, below. Also on view are Arkitektura copies of Saarinen designs. Hours: Monday to Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: GENERAL FOODS PROFITS AHEAD 6.7% IN QUARTER
description: The General Foods Corporation, a leading coffee and packaged food company, said yesterday that net income for its fourth quarter, ended March 31, rose 6.7 percent, to $117.3 million, or $2.26 a share, from $109.9 million, or $2.15 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenues rose 1.3 percent, to $2.27 billion, from $2.24 billion a year earlier.

title: Convicted Slayer, 18, Adopted by Attorney

Bell said he would not appeal the league decision. . . . A player who did appeal a league suspension, Tony Bernazard , second baseman of the Cleveland Indians, lost out yesterday when Brown upheld the suspension for bumping an umpire during an argument April 10. Bernazard, who also was fined $300, will miss games against Toronto tomorrow and Saturday.

title: 'GAME SHOW MOMENTS' AND CLIPS OF CELEBRITIES
description: ONE of the more irritating developments in television programming - and one that shows no sign of abating - is something that might be called the Clips Caravan. These are compilations of old video and kinescope footage wrapped, not very artfully, around a convenient theme such as ''most embarrassing moments'' or ''greatest commercials'' or ''censored bloopers.'' Tonight ABC-TV, obviously running out of first-run material, is offering two such belabored exercises: ''TV's Funniest Game Show Moments'' at 8, and ''Celebrities! Where Are They Now?'' at 9.

THE OTHER POLAND
description: Westerners were surprised but puzzled last week when Lech Walesa and several thousand supporters joined in May Day rallies in Gdansk and a number of other Polish cities. Some people took this as a sign that Solidarity may soon re-emerge in much the same form as we knew it in 1980 and 1981. Others concluded that the May Day protests were no more than the last flames from dying embers. My own visit to Warsaw this spring persuades me that neither reaction is warranted.

title: Reuters Board Adds 3
description: Reuters today added three members to the board of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. The three are Walter B. Wriston, 64 years old, chairman of Citicorp; Pehr Gyllenhammar, 49, chairman of the Swedish auto maker Volvo, and Christopher Hogg, 47, chairman of Courtaulds, a British group of companies. Reuters Holdings was formed as part of a plan that the news agency said would preserve its integrity after it sells stock to the public.

title: Sale of a Calder Sets 2 Records

title: FILM: REDFORD AND DUVALL IN MALAMUD'S 'NATURAL'
description: WHEN it was published in 1952, ''The Natural,'' Bernard Malamud's first novel, was received with rather grudging admiration. Now, more than 30 years and many celebrated works later, ''The Natural,'' the story of the rise and fall of a legendary baseball player, is still seen as something of a Malamud aberration. Though it remains one of his most popular novels, it's not easily associated with works like ''The Fixer'' and ''Dubin's Lives,'' in which the writer explores aspects of the Jewish experience, past as well as present.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE APPROVING AID FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 212 to 208 by which the House of Representatives today approved an amendment by Representative William S. Broomfield, Republican of Michigan, to the $10.5 billion foreign aid bill. The amendment approves President Reagan's requests for military and economic aid to Central America. A ''yes'' vote was to approve the aid. Voting ''yes'' were 56 Democrats and 156 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 200 Democrats and 8 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, xxx; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes.

description: and another such time may be on the horizon - when the future of American opera seemed to lie in cross-fertilization with the Broadway musical. The foremost surviving examples are ''Porgy and Bess,'' the late works of Kurt Weill, Leonard Bernstein's opera-musicals, and those of Marc Blitzstein. Blitzstein's ''Regina,'' revived by the Opera Ensemble of New York at the Lillie Blake School, provided an interesting and thought-provoking evening at its third performance Wednesday night.

title: Salvador Slogans and Remedies
description: It was not the Democrats but Richard Nixon who offered the best response to President Reagan's militant simplicities about Central America Wednesday night. Speaking about third-world social crises just a few hours before the President's address, Mr. Nixon said, ''The trouble is that the Communists at least talk about the problem, and too often we just talk about the Communists.''

title: G.M. Workers
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had recalled 1,000 employees from indefinite layoff for work at parts plants and placed 3,300 workers at its Wilmington, Del., assembly plant on temporary layoff until mid-August. G.M. said the Wilmington factory, where subcompact Chevettes and Pontiac 1000's were built, would undergo conversion after the shutdown to assemble full-sized B-body cars. Assembly of the subcompact models was previously shifted to G.M.'s plant at Lakewood, Ga., which reopened last month.

title: BLOSSOM TIME IN BROOKLYN
description: There is still time to see cherry blossoms and crabapple trees in all their glory at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden this weekend. In the opinion of many, Brooklyn's magnificent cherry-tree collection surpasses the famous trees along Washington's Tidal Basin. Washington's 260 cherry trees are primarily Yoshino, a light- pink, single-flowering tree. Although the botanic garden has fewer trees, 180, it probably has greater diversity. Thirty cultivated varieties can be seen in Brooklyn, including many that are quite rare.

title: CORRECTIONS

Among the population groups responding to such a possibility, independent men shifted to Republicans by 14 percentage points and Democratic men shifted to Republicans by 7 points.

title: Anton Pawlowski In Recital on Guitar
description: The guitarist Anton Pawlowski presented a spotty concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night. Mr. Pawlowski is an uneven artist; his playing, often sensitive and musically convincing, is just as frequently sloppy and technically maladroit. It sometimes seemed as though Mr. Pawlowski had learned half of a composition by heart, and then attempted to memorize the rest a half-hour before curtain time.

title: APPETITE FOR A FULL-COURSESOUTHERN LUNCH APPEARS TO WANE
description: For years this has been a city of heavy industry and even heavier lunches: groaning noonday meals of fried chicken or country ham, tall tumblers of sweetened ice tea, plates of steaming cornbread and three side orders of vegetables, seasoned with bacon drippings.

title: BROADWAY
description: TO the playwright David Rabe the title ''Hurlyburly'' signifies ''a time of great turmoil and spiritual confusion in which change is possible but difficult - and necessary.'' To the Promenade Theater, at 76th and Broadway, it signifies a coming production with a stellar cast directed by Mike Nichols. Starting June 5, William Hurt, Harvey Keitel, Christopher Walken, Sigourney Weaver, Judith Ivey, Jerry Stiller and Cynthia Nixon will be appearing in Mr. Rabe's new play, whose official opening is June 21.

title: Denmark Votes to Halt Money for Missiles
description: The Danish Parliament voted today to stop payments for the deployment by NATO of new United States nuclear missiles in Western Europe. The center-right government abstained in the voting, allowing passage of the measure by the opposition Social Democrats and two other parties.

title: Reagan and 3 Democrats Receive $3.5 Million
description: The Federal Elections Commission on Wednesday authorized the payment of more than $3.5 million in Federal matching funds to President Reagan and three contenders in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Ford Chairman Silent on Plans DETROIT, May 10 - Philip
description: Caldwell, chairman of the Ford

title: MASSTOR SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include the operations of Masstor Systems International which merged with Masstor in March 1984.

title: 15 Philadelphia Officers Enter Not Guilty Pleas
description: Fifteen city police officers, including the former second-highest ranking official in the department, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of conspiring to protect illegal gambling and extorting $350,000.

title: Long-Deserved Honor
description: The two dozen sponsors are farflung: John Marin Jr., writing from Maine, said his painter-father had introduced him to Patric Farrell nearly 40 years ago. Letters came from Kermit Roosevelt Jr. and J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery, in Washington, from J. Willard Roosevelt Jr. in Massachusetts and from Bess Myerson and Paul O'Dwyer in New York.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 11, 1984 International
description: The House gave President Reagan a major victory by narrowly approving his request for military aid to El Salvador that would give him broad discretion in spending the money. The measure was approved in the Democratic-controlled House by a vote of 212 to 208. Proponents argued against imposing human rights conditions that could not be met by a struggling new democracy. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The World Court upheld Nicaragua in ruling unanimously that the United States should halt immediately any attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports. The Court, granting Managua's request for a preliminary restraining order, also asserted by a vote of 14 to 1 that Nicaragua's political independence ''should be fully respected and should not be jeopardized by any military or paramilitary activities.'' (A1:5.)

title: The Reason for Runoffs
description: It's only May but there's already a provisional 1984 winner of the Landslide Lyndon Award. Recent winners include Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey, who defeated Representative James Florio in 1981, 44.77 percent to 44.70 percent. This year it almost surely belongs to Representative Kent Hance, Democrat of Texas, and the 1984 citation concerns runoff primaries.

title: THE BIG-POWER CHILL
description: After several months of holding out the hope of reviving serious exchanges with the Soviet Union, key Reagan Administration officials are now saying they see no likelihood of any significant improvement in relations until after the November elections. They have concluded that Moscow is trying to avoid doing anything to help President Reagan be re-elected, and this means maintaining a public freeze.

description: President Reagan, expressing displeasure with ''recent upticks'' in interest rates, said today that there was ''no satisfactory reason'' for them.

description: He has been retired for six years and on Friday he celebrates his 90th birthday. But Ellsworth Bunker is still very much a diplomat, still the Ambassador.

title: JERSEY CHARGES 5 COMPANIES WITH SELLING TAINTED HEATING OIL
description: Seven New Jersey men and five companies were charged today in a 109-count indictment with illegally selling residential heating oil laced with 66 different types of dangerous chemical waste.

description: The Mets' departure for an 11-day West Coast swing after yesterday's game with Atlanta couldn't have come at a better time. After losing four of their last five games, the team and its fans could use some time apart to forget what's happened at Shea Stadium in the last week.

description: King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain began a visit to the Soviet Union today, marking the full renewal of relations after a split that followed the Spanish Civil War.

title: The One and Only Mr. Feldstein
description: In the 38 years since the Council of Economic Advisers was created, it has never had a chairman like Martin Feldstein. Of his dozen predecessors, some may have been brighter, or better at Washington politics, but none were more willing to stand up and speak out. He's served the country well.

title: ;  Merrill Lynch Sets Mortgage Venture
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and the Great Western Financial Corporation said they had formed a joint venture, Merrill Lynch/Great Western Mortgage Securities Inc., to acquire mortgage collateral and to issue mortgage-backed securities.

description: WHILE programs devoted entirely to the oeuvre of one young composer are fairly commonplace in downtown loft spaces, they are rare in New York's established concert halls.

description: Espionage charges against a Bulgarian trade official were reinstated yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. had agreed to ask shareholders to vote at a special meeting on the company's recent sale of one million convertible preferred shares to the General Cinema Corporation. The meeting must be held no later than June 28.

LaRouche Backer Wins House Primary in Ohio
description: Lyndon LaRouche Jr. did not fare well as a Democratic Presidential candidate in Ohio's primary Tuesday, but a LaRouche supporter won the right to seek a House seat in the Seventh Congressional District.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Ray Fontenot, still trying to win his first game of the season, goes against Matt Young of the Mariners. (Television - Sports Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles, 10:30 P.M. title: MRS. BRUCE ON THE WASHINGTON SALON
description: Evangeline Bruce, daughter of a career Foreign Service officer, grew up abroad. In the years of her marriage to the late diplomat David E. K. Bruce, she served as chatelaine of the United States embassies in Paris, Bonn and London.

title: Court Delays Plans For Brooklyn Jail
description: The state's highest court today temporarily blocked plans by New York City to move 600 prisoners into a former brig at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: REAGAN TELLS G.O.P. DONARS TAX POLICIES ARE FAIR
description: President Reagan, presiding over what Republicans described as the richest fund-raising dinner in political history, tonight contended that his tax cut had been proportionately harder on the rich than on the poor.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., a bank holding company based in Jacksonville, filed a public offering of $50 million of floating-rate subordinated notes due 1996 through Salomon Brothers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An application by the Chicago White Sox owners, Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn , to participate as owners of a new U.S.F.L. franchise in Chicago was approved unanimously by American League owners. . . . With six quarterbacks on their roster after the recent acquisition of Steve DeBerg from Denver, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers placed Jerry Goldsteyn , a former Giant quarterback, on waivers. Zoran Jovonovich , a 7-foot-1 inch center on the Yugoslavia club team, has accepted a scholarship to Louisiana State, according to Coach Dale Brown .

title: FROM THE WINGS TO THE LIMELIGHT
description: NO one loves an understudy. Their names do not appear on marquees and they have to be gleaned from the fine print in the playbill. On the rare occasion that an understudy is actually called on to play a full-scale role, audiences groan when it is announced that A. Star will not be appearing. Afterward, understudies are often remembered for who they weren't.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES PLAN FOR A DRILL NEAR SHOREHAM
description: A study by the research service of the Library of Congress says the Federal agencies seeking to conduct an evacuation drill around the Shoreham nuclear plant have ''no clear authority'' to exercise the police powers needed to hold the drill.

title: Ship Afire in Gulf Is Saved
description: A salvage team has saved a Saudi Arabian oil tanker that had been afire in the Persian Gulf for 50 hours after reportedly being hit on Monday by an Iraqi missile, shipping officials said today. Roberto Georgi, general manager of the Amar Line Maritime Ltd., a company based in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, which owns the 117,710-ton supertanker Al Ahood, said the ship was considerably damaged, but no oil had leaked and the 42 men in the crew had been rescued.

title: PRESS ACCESS TO WAR ZONES URGED
description: A panel of military officers and journalists has recommended that journalists be assured access to future United States military operations. But Pentagon officials said the proposals faced several hurdles before they could be adopted.

title: WORLD COURT, A PART OF U.N., WAS SET UP IN '45
description: The interim decision handed down in The Hague yesterday in Nicaragua's case against the United States was rendered by a 15-member court headed by a Nigerian and including judges from the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: AToday
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended City Schools Chancellor, will make a statement at 11 A.M. today at the Sheraton Center Hotel, a spokesman said last night.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $25,132,000 from the sale of the company's Canadian operations.

title: Israeli Foreign Debt Up
description: Israel's foreign debt rose 8 percent, to $22.5 billion, at the end of 1983, from $20.8 billion at the end of 1982, Israel radio said today. Bank of Israel officials could not be reached for comment, but Israel television said the increase was mainly in Government debt.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AFTER a long, hard day of selling, when a group of businessmen, and an occasional businesswoman, want to relax and let down their hair, a steakhouse can be just the spot. It doesn't matter if, after a few drinks, the laughter is loud because the energy level is high, and everyone is having a wonderful time.

title: KOCH LEADS 2-STOP ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT TOUR
description: Standing among empty building shells in Queens and later beneath a towering cargo crane on the Brooklyn waterfront, Mayor Koch yesterday reminded people outside Manhattan that in these two projects his administration had assembled $66 million in public money for industrial and maritime development.

title: 11 Hurt in Crash With School Bus
description: Eleven people were injured yesterday when a school bus carrying 10 handicapped children and a car collided at Amsterdam Avenue and 93d Street, the police said.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT INDIANS, 7-6, IN 16
description: The Yankees, who have been shut out seven times this season, went through 11 consecutive innings - from the fifth through the 15th - without scoring last night. Then, after Cleveland scored an unearned run in the top half of the 16th, the Yankees rallied in their half of the inning for two runs and a 7-6 victory.

title: LILLIAN HELLMAN WINS ROUND IN SUIT
description: The playwright Lillian Hellman yesterday won a preliminary round in a $2.5 million lawsuit that accuses Mary McCarthy, the novelist and critic, of making libelous statements about her more than four years ago on Channel 13's ''Dick Cavett Show.''

title: ; BBDO Doubles Shares, Elects Board Members
description: BBDO International, parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, had its annual meeting Wednesday at the agency.

title: Outlaws Sign Anderson
description: Turning down an offer from the Detroit Lions, Ernest Anderson , an Oklahoma State running back, signed with the Oklahoma Outlaws of the U.S.F.L. yesterday and prepared to join the team in time for its game against the Tampa Bay Bandits Monday night.

title: CUBA SEEKS CAPITALIST TO BUILD CAPITALISTS' PARADISE
description: On this nearly deserted island 40 miles southwest of the Bay of Pigs, the Marxist Cuban Government is proposing to go into partnership with one of its enemies: capitalist business.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICT'S FINANCIAL JOLT
description: MICHAEL QUINT

title: SHRINKING SUPPLY SHIFTS CHARACTER OF OIL REGION
description: Texas and the other states of the American oil region are gradually but surely running out of oil and gas, and signs are mounting that this unwelcome geological fact of life is changing the face and economic character of the region.

title: E.P.A. FREE FUNDS FOR CLEARING PCB'S FROM HUDSON RIVER
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency agreed today to release $18 million to New York State to remove PCB's from the Hudson River.

title: MIXED SIGNALS GET SOME GOOD RESULTS
description: There is hutt-hutt-hutt and there is hutt- HUTT-hutt, Brian Sipe explained. The quarterback of the Generals was talking about cadence in calling signals and how important the HUTT can be. ''It's a matter of emphasis,'' he said.

title: U.S. SAID TO SEEK COSTA RICA SHIFT
description: Government officials here say the Reagan Administration is privately putting pressure on Costa Rica to abandon its public stand of neutrality and openly support United States action against Nicaragua's Sandinista Government.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Toronto, has elected R. Donald Fullerton, president, to the additional post of chief executive officer, succeeding Russell E. Harrison, who continues as chairman.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there is anything I can leave with you in terms of the treatment of patients with a terminal illness, it is this: We are all terminal - we all die sometime - so why should a terminal illness be different from terminal life? There is no difference.'' - Jacob K. Javits. (A18:3.)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HIM WITH HIS FOOT IN HIS MOUTH AND OTHER STORIES. By Saul Bellow. 294 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95. IN ''Cousins,'' the last of the five stories in Saul Bellow's new collection, a man's former wife says: ''You have an exuberance that you keep to yourself. You have a crazy high energy absolutely peculiar to you. Because of this high charge you can defy the plain dirty facts that other people have to suffer through, whether they like it or not. What you are is an exuberance-hoarder.''

description: Text of ruling is on page A9.

description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today it had a profit of $22.8 million in the latest quarter, compared with a $5.5 million loss in the period a year earlier.

title: ART: WHAT WILDERNESS MEANS TO RICHARD LONG
description: RICHARD LONG'S installations are based on visits to wilderness areas around the world. Using natural materials, such as stone and earth, and documentary materials, such as photographs, Long attempts to turn gallery spaces into halfway houses between the natural world and art. The effectiveness of his work depends to a very large degree on a balance between his seemingly nonstop mind and the reality of nature, which does not think, but is.

title: Standex Offer
description: The Standex International Corporation said that, as expected, its directors had received an offer for a leveraged buyout of the company. The proposal, which the company said last week was being considered, calls for an exchange of $15 in cash and $6 principal amount of a new issue of subordinated discount debentures for each of the approximately 13.8 million Standex shares outstanding. Standex, based in Salem, N.H., is a diversified manufacturing and marketing organization.

description: -MEMBER jury recommended Thomas Berger's novel ''The Feud'' for the 1984 Pulitzer Prize for fiction, but the 16-member Pulitzer Prize board, which makes the final decision, instead awarded the prize to William Kennedy's ''Ironweed.''

title: A SUNDAY AFTERNOON OF JAZZ THE WAY IT USED TO SOUND
description: A SERIES of Sunday afternoon concerts devoted to the jazz styles played before World War II, which are now collectively identified as ''traditional jazz,'' offers a performance Sunday at 3 P.M. by a quartet headed by the clarinetist Jack Maheu and the vibraphonist Warren Chiasson. The site is the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street.

description: A chart in Business Day Wednesday on steel's role in the economy incorrectly described the amount of steel used to calculate the ratio of consumption to gross national product. The measure was tons.

description: The Cuomo administration yesterday proposed tougher penalties for the evasion of state taxes.

title: PROFILES OF EAST GERMANY'S LEADING TEAMS AND ATHLETES East German athletes had seemed sure to win most of the gold medals in women's swimming and perhaps half of the gold medals in women's track and field in the Los Angeles Olympics, and they are strong in many other sports. Among the best East German teams are these:
description: Women's Swimming - East Germans won all 15 gold medals in the 1983 European championships and 10 of 14 in the 1982 world championships. Their potential winners in Los Angeles would have included Ute Geweniger, the world record-holder in the 100-meter breast-stroke and the 200- meter individual medley; Kristin Otto, an Olympic favorite in the 100- meter freestyle and the 100-meter backstroke, and Astrid Strauss, the Olympic favorite in the 400-meter and 800-meter freestyles. Last January, in the United States International meet in Austin, Tex., Miss Strauss, barely 15 years old, defeated Tiffany Cohen, America's best distance freestyler, in three finals.

title: The Worm and the Apple Bagged in Bushwick With an estimated 70 acres of vacant lot, the Brooklyn community of Bushwick is one of New York's most dumped-on, and therefore rat-infested, neighborhoods. And for years all the residents did about it was to dump on the Department of Sanitation. Then last fall during a turbulent community meeting a city planning official suggested that trash and rats might yield if the community and Sanitation joined forces. The impressive result: ''Sanitation Awareness Week,'' culminating with ''Bag It in Bushwick'' day last Saturday.
description: Working with neighborhood leaders, half a dozen city agencies mobilized for a publicity campaign about the direct connection between bad housekeeping and rats in a neighborhood where many simply ''airmail'' garbage out the window.

description: The Rapid-American Corporation, the diversified retailer and distiller, has purchased a large number of shares of the F. W. Woolworth Company on the open market. About one million shares were involved, Wall Street analysts said yesterday, representing about 3 percent of Woolworth's 31.35 million shares outstanding.

title: HART TERMS MONDALE POLICIES 'ECONOMIC SUICIDE'
description: Senator Gary Hart today criticized the trade policies of Walter F. Mondale as ''economic suicide'' and accused the Reagan Administration of knowing the identity of secret death squads in El Salvador.

description: Results for the latest quarter are for a 14-week period as compared to a 13-week period ended Feb. 25, 1983. Results for the latest year are for a 53- week period as compared to a 52-week period a year ago.

description: The Central Intelligence Agency and the American Civil Liberties Union joined today in endorsing a House bill that would exempt most of the agency's operational files from requests for material under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: BLACK MEN, WELFARE AND JOBS
description: As much as we hear about the phenomenal growth in families headed by black females and the attendant rise in poverty, little is made of the ''flip side'' of this trend: The economic status of black men. If so many black women are raising children alone, where are the black men who would otherwise be heading families?

description: Phoenix will meet the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference finals, a four-of-seven-game series.

description: Candy Maldonado drove in three runs with a double and a sacrifice fly, and Bob Welch scattered seven hits as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 5-1 victory today that broke a three-game winning streak for the Cubs.

description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority sued the makers of the Grumman Flxible buses yesterday, charging them with fraud and conspiracy to defraud.

description: The managing editor of The Wall Street Journal said today that when he found out one of his reporters had given outsiders sensitive stock information, it was ''every editor's nightmare come true.''

title: Ben Bonus Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ben Bonus, the producer, director and star of Yiddish theater who died last month, will be held Wednesday at 6 P.M. in the Central Synagogue's Folksbiene Playhouse, 123 East 55th Street. The service, organized by figures prominent in Yiddish cultural and theatrical life, will be open to the public.

title: LIGHTS, CAMERA, ACTION
description: The Islanders and the Oilers stuck to hockey last night and avoided the operatic death scenes that marred last year's Stanley Cup finals. They staged a taut opening game, with Grant Fuhr saving the Oilers for two periods and Kevin McClelland's goal beating the Islanders, 1-0.

title: STAGE: 'ON APPROVAL,' COMEDY BY FREDERICK LONSDALE
description: FREDERICK LONSDALE'S 1927 ''On Approval,'' a genteel comedy of manners, was recently treated to an elegant British production, presented last year on television's ''Masterpiece Theater.'' At the Roundabout Theater Company's Susan Bloch Theater, Daniel Gerroll leads an all-American quartet through the Old World paces, with generally salubrious results.

Tickets, $16 and $18, are available at the box office. Information: 564-4400.

description: East Germany, a nation of 17 million people that has become a world power in sports, announced today that it would not take part in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer.

title: MCO-Horizon Tie

MCO said the agreement calls for it to receive 416,235 authorized but unissued Horizon shares and a five-year option to purchase an additional 832,485 shares.

John Looks Ahead
description: He will celebrate his 41st birthday later this month, and in baseball time that's retirement age, but not for Tommy John . The California Angel pitcher thinks he has a few years left.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on April 26 with the Helpful Hardware column misidentified the fluorescent double light bulb. It was a Philips PL lamp made by the North American Philips Lighting Corporation.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: -Star Pictures gallops across the screens of theaters showing ''The Natural,'' it will undoubtedly take some viewers by surprise. Tri-Star, the studio formed by a consortium made up of CBS, Columbia Pictures and Home Box Office, is barely a year old. But it already has a schedule of films that will include work by the directors Robert Benton, Alan Parker and Louis Malle, with Richard Pryor, Tom Selleck and even the Muppets to star in coming Tri-Star movies. ''The Natural,'' which opens today at the Sutton, National and other theaters (reviewed on page C15), will mark the first real test of the new company's marketing apparatus.

CONCERT: 'WAR REQUIEM'
description: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S ''War Requiem'' is a lamentation for the dead of all battles, past, present and future, but it is particularly rooted in the First World War, during whose final days the English poet Wilfred Owens was killed at the age of 25. It was Britten's inspired idea to weave together texts drawn from the traditional requiem mass and Owens's poetry, whose aim in the poet's words is to show ''the pity of war.''

title: COMPLAINTS BY JACKSON GET NO ACTION BY PARTY
description: A meeting of Democratic party state chairmen took declined today to act on the Rev. Jesse Jackson's criticisms of runoff Presidential primary elections and of a delegate selection process he says has deprived him of a fair share of delegates to the party's national convention.

title: BEST WORLD-DEBT POLICY: REFORM THE F.D.I.C.
description: Only a few weeks ago,there was a general sigh of relief over the third world debt situation. Too soon! Our banks, with the cooperation of the International Monetary Fund, are making a mess of third world economies by asking them to restrict essential imports - thereby freeing up funds to repay the banks and protect them against having to declare losses. For their part, the debtor countries may soon be forced into withholding repayment, thus threatening the solvency of the banks and making a mess of our economy.

title: Utility in Jersey May Raise Rates
description: Public Service Electric and Gas Company customers may be paying from 10 to 15 percent more when the company's Hope Creek nuclear power plant goes into commercial operation in 1986, two State Senate committees were told today.

title: On the Frontier of New Music
description: LAURIE ANDERSON'S performances this weekend at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, are not going to be reruns of ''United States, Parts I-IV,'' the acclaimed multimedia epic she staged last year at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Only 3 of the 20 songs in the new two-hour show were included in ''United States,'' and they have been rescored.

description: b-Includes gains from a minority share in a subsidiary of $17,144 for the quarter and $29,613 for the 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $407,500.

title: Boryla Is Back
description: Vince Boryla, remembered by New Yorkers as a player, coach and general manager of the Knicks from 1949 until 1962, is the new president of the Denver Nuggets. The former star at Notre Dame and the University of Denver had been president of the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association from 1970 until 1974.

title: LEGAL ISSUES STALL PACT TO MAKE PHOTO LICENSES
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams today approved the form of the contract between New York State and a Rochester company to produce driver licenses with photographs. But he cautioned that there were ''substantial legal issues'' that could result in lawsuits to block the contract.

title: McGee's Chance
description: A year ago, during the National Basketball Association playoffs, Mike McGee of the Los Angeles Lakers sat on the bench a lot. He was the fourth guard, behind Earvin (Magic) Johnson, Norm Nixon and Mike Cooper.

title: City Investing Bid Studied by Posner
description: Victor Posner, chairman of the Sharon Steel Corporation, which owns 8.9 percent of the City Investing Company, is ''contemplating'' whether to make an offer for City, an attorney for Mr. Posner said. ''He is making an analysis of the company and is contemplating whether he will make an offer and if so at what amount,'' said Bruce Greer, the lawyer, who is based in Miami Beach.

title: COMPUTER'S REVENGE
description: Never abuse a computer; it has a way of getting even.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS U.S. FINANCED SOME SALVADOR GROUPS IN POLITICS
description: The White House said today that the United States had not taken sides in the election in El Salvador, but did provide help to labor unions, business groups and other organizations that endorsed or worked for candidates.

title: DEBATE SET TO OPEN ON BANKS BILL
description: The Assembly's Banking Committee will begin debate next week on a controversial Cuomo administration bill aimed at halting the loss of financial jobs to other states by making it easier for banks to operate in New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: In ''Cousins,'' the last of the five stories in Saul Bellow's new collection, a man's former wife says: ''You have an exuberance that you keep to yourself. You have a crazy high energy absolutely peculiar to you. Because of this high charge you can defy the plain dirty facts that other people have to suffer through, whether they like it or not. What you are is an exuberance-hoarder.'' <TD WIDTH=2

title: Death in Parachute Drop
description: A sudden wind gust collapsed the parachute of an Air Force captain Wednesday, sending him hurtling to his death, a spokesman said today. The captain, Michael E. Dionne of Orlando, Fla., 34 years old, died at the Air Force Academy Hospital.

title: Hart on Trade Policy
description: On the Record

title: HOUSE PANEL CLEARS BILL TO AMEND AND RENEW THE CLEAN WATER ACT
description: The House Public Works Committee today approved legislation to renew and amend the Clean Water Act, which has been in effect without formal authority since it officially expired in 1982.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Pat Metheny Leads Trio at the Vanguard
description: The guitarist Pat Metheny left behind his jazz-rock group to lead a trio at the Village Vanguard this week. With the bassist Charlie Haden and the drummer Billy Higgins, both of whom have played with Ornette Coleman, Mr. Metheny tested himself against trickier pieces and subtler syncopations.

title: SCREEN: 'FIRESTARTER,' A STEPHEN KING STORY
description: nicknamed Charlie - McGee doesn't want to set the world on fire but, with increasing frequency, she does. Sometimes something just comes over her, and what she wills in her mind actually happens. Once, standing in an airport lobby, she sees a young soldier telling his pregnant, tearful girlfriend that he doesn't want to settle down yet. Charlie gets carried away, and the soldier's shoes miraculously burst into flame.

title: CANADA AIR RULES ARE EASED
description: Canada took a first step today toward airline deregulation, but stopped well short of the sweeping measures adopted in the United States in 1978.

title: Passaic Mayor Gets Gun Permit
description: Mayor Joseph Lipari of Passaic, whose life has been threatened several times in recent years, today became the only mayor in New Jersey with a permit to carry a gun.

title: SALVADOR'S RIGHT QUITS VOTE COUNT
description: The delegates from the far-rightist party of Roberto d'Aubuisson refused today to take part in the official count of votes in the presidential runoff election, saying the results were being tallied in an illegal fashion.

title: HENRY F. WERKER, FEDERAL JUDGE, DEAD AT 64
description: Judge Henry F. Werker, who blocked an attempt by the Reagan Administration to require family-planning clinics to notify parents when minors received prescription contraceptives, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: REPORT FOR CONGRESS DOUBTS MX'S VALUE AGAINST SOVIET ARMS
description: Recent advances in Soviet technology cast doubt on the ability of the MX missile to accomplish its objective of destroying the Soviet land-based missile force, a new report from the General Accounting Office says.

title: PEAK SEASON FOR SEEING ART AT AUCTION HOUSES
description: THIS is one of New York's two biggest auctiongoing weekends of the year (the other is in in November), a time to browse among treasures of great and small price at the galleries and to begin bidding on art, antiques and autographs. More than $60 million worth of Impressionist and modern art and rare letters and documents by Abraham Lincoln and all the signers of the Declaration of Independence may be viewed free in advance of next week's sales.

title: JANE FONDA, GRITTY MOUNTAIN WOMAN
description: movie debut on Channel 7 at 8 P.M. Sunday, Jane Fonda has shrewdly chosen a vehicle for the kind of bravura performance out of which awards are plucked. Based on a novel by Harriette Arnow about a tough and gifted Kentucky mountain woman, ''The Dollmaker'' has been adapted by Susan Cooper and Hume Cronyn. This is an unabashed celebration of Gertie Nevels, her simple dignity and her determination.

title: G.E. CREDIT TO ACQUIRE INSURER
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Employers Reinsurance Corporation from Texaco Inc. for $1.08 billion in cash. The acquisition of Employers, a unit of the Getty Oil Company, which Texaco recently acquired, would be one of the biggest deals in the insurance business.

title: 6.1% CUT IN RATES ON LONG DISTANCE ORDERED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to cut its long-distance rates by 6.1 percent, beginning later this month. The move is expected to save consumers $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion a year.

METHODISTS RESTATE HOMOSEXUAL CLERGY BAN
description: Voting on the issue for the second time in two days, the United Methodist Church declared firmly tonight that active homosexuals ''are not to be accepted'' as ministers.

title: Generosity Protested
description: Jeff Van Note , a 38-year-old center for the Atlanta Falcons, has been a union activist for years, so it was no surprise to hear him sounding off against an owner. What was a bit surprising, however, was that Van Note was not complaining about an owner's tight-fisted ways, but about the $250,000 signing bonus and $1 million salary that J. William Oldenburg , the owner of the Los Angeles Express, has reportedly offered Rod McSwain , a third-round Atlanta draft choice from Clemson.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER REVIVES 'MISS JULIE'

title: Libyan Demonstrators Back Qaddafi's Regime

title: MUSIC: ORLANDO GIBBONS
description: THE music of the English composer Orlando Gibbons (1583- 1625) is not exactly a commonplace in our contemporary American musical life. Even his 400th anniversary celebration last year hardly elicited a superfluity of performances. And so it was an unusual pleasure that two of our best early-music groups, Pomerium Musices and the New York Consort of Viols, combined Wednesday night at the Abraham Goodman House for an entire evening of Gibbons's music.

title: IN MOSCOW, ATHLETES FOLLOW KREMLIN
description: Off the track at the Luzhniki sports complex today, among coaches and judges preparing for the opening meet of the season as well as among Moscow's best young athletes, there was little discussion of the sporting topic that seized most of the rest of the world in the last 48 hours.

title: JOHN PAUL CELEBRATES MASS IN BANGKOK
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here Thursday in this overwhelmingly Buddhist country and celebrated mass at a stadium before 45,000 people.

title: Soviet Grain Import Data
description: The Soviet Union is expected to import 35 million metric tons of grain in 1984-85, the second largest amount ever and the sixth consecutive year of imports exceeding 30 million tons, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: AN ARTIST'S SEARCH: THE PEONY IS HER PRIZE
description: Niki Goulandris says with some hesitation that she is probably the second best-known woman in Greece. ''Whenever anybody wants a woman's opinion on something,'' she says, ''first they ask Melina Mercouri, and then they ask me.''

title: Suspect in Street Attack Surrenders in Quebec
description: An unemployed factory worker who was suspected of shooting and slightly wounding two people on a city street surrendered this morning after holding the police at bay outside his home for more than a day, the authorities said.

title: Gunman Holds Hostages 12 Hours in Texas Bank
description: A fugitive held three people hostage for 12 hours in a bank building today before armed law-enforcement officers rushed in late tonight and overpowered him, a sheriff's deputy said.

Southwest said in March that it planned to be acquired by a group of investors organized by Morgan Stanley & Company and led by W.A. Franke, Southwest's chief executive officer, for $24 a share.

title: U.S. Teacher Dies in France
description: Margaret Eriksson, a 73-year-old high school French teacher from York, Pa., died Wednesday at a hospital in Marseilles from injuries she sustained during a robbery April 30, officials said. On April 30, as she was walking to the Arles tourism office to be honored for her part in making Arles and York ''sister cities'' in 1954, two men on a motorcycle raced by, ripped her purse from her and knocked her down. .

title: JOAQUIM AGOSTINHO
description: Joaquim Agostinho, a champion cyclist and one of Portugal's most acclaimed sports heroes, died today, 10 days after falling and fracturing his skull in a local tour. He was 41 years old. Agostinho, who twice finished third in the Tour de France, never recovered from the deep coma he fell into hours after a stray dog toppled him to the ground while he was cycling at high speed on April 30.

description: The Knicks, who led by 13 points with 3 minutes 31 seconds to play last night, barely withstood a Celtic surge in defeating Boston, 106-104. The victory forced a seventh game in their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series.

description: Salvador Dali marked his 80th birthday today at his lonely castle retreat amid signs that he has regained his zest for life after months of depression.

description: A Federal judge today blocked a state court order that limited pickets outside hotels along the Strip in the 41-day-old strike by resort workers. He also blocked the prosecution of 754 pickets arrested in the walkout.

''He's coming down next weekend,'' Bassett said yesterday, explaining that the meeting was being arranged by the team's co-owner, Burt Reynolds , the actor, a friend of Brown.

title: HONG KONG DESIGNERS: THEIR OWN LOOK
description: It isn't upper Madison Avenue, but the sleek Central District here is rapidly turning into a shopping district with almost as many boutiques as banks. Most sell European designs such as Armani, Chloe, Basile and Krizia as well as a smattering of Japanese clothes. But in the last year there has been a marked change; for the first time, Hong Kong's own designers have opened shops here, too.

title: TIMES SQ. ALSO BECKONS WITH LESS SINISTER JOYS
description: One of the less-publicized al fresco facts of life in Manhattan is that on a sunny spring weekend, the block of 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues is likely to attract larger crowds than the most popular pasture in Central Park. And even more surprising is that many of the strollers are ordinary people out for a good time, in search of a cheap double bill, a fast-food dinner and a glimpse of glitter and excitement.

ONLY 14 MILLION YEARS UNTIL DOOMSDAY
description: Halley's comet appeared in 1066, on the eve of the Norman invasion of England. It cuts a striking figure in a contemporary tapestry woven to celebrate the Conquest, altogether more moving than our 1910 photograph of its last visit. The medieval artist gives us the human scale, with men shrinking from the comet but unable to look away. It's a revealing look across the millenium that separates us from medieval Europeans, and their response looks pretty authentic.
