description: The year-ago quarter results were restated to exclude the accounts of Midlands Energy Co. whose stock was distributed to K N Energy shareholders on Dec. 12, 1983. The shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend paid on July 19, 1982.

title: G.E. Plant Hiring 1,200
description: The General Electric Company, anticipating a possible record number of orders for commercial jet engines this year, is hiring 1,200 new employees at its plant here. The plant already has 13,500 workers.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago second quarter ended April 2 and comprised of only 12 weeks.

title: Tigers Go to 26-4, Set Mark for Start
description: The Detroit Tigers, buoyed by Dave Bergman's three runs batted in and the pitching of Milt Wilcox and Willie Hernandez, beat the California Angels, 8-2, tonight and improved their record to 26-4 for the best start in major league history.

title: Hostetler Pursued
description: George Young , the general manager of the Giants, was deep in negotiations yesterday with the club's third- round draft choice, Jeff Hostetler , the former West Virginia quarterback who is also being wooed by the United States Football League. The talks between Young and Hostetler's agent, Robert Bennett , were expected to continue next week, and the Giants seemed optimistic that Hostetler would sign. Since taking over as general manager in 1979, Young has signed every one of the club's draft choices.

title: BAKER UNSURE OF PASSAGE OF REAGAN'S BUDGET PLAN
description: After staving off two strong challenges to President Reagan's deficit-reducing plan this week, Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, said today that he was still unsure the Administration's plan would be approved on the Senate floor.

title: CHATHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: The Inside Story

title: Tough to Get
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' executive vice president, spent much of yesterday in hiding, trying to stay away from the telephone and from friends and celebrities seeking tickets for last night's sixth playoff game between the Knicks and the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden. The game has been sold out (19,591) since Thursday morning.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARGENTINE DEBT: A CASE STUDY
description: It is one of the anomalies of the Argentine foreign debt crisis that the country's largest company is mired in debt and has barely anything to show for it.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indianapolis Driver Hurt
description: Michael Chandler of Dana Point, Calif., a driver in the last three Indianapolis 500 races, was listed as unconscious and in ''serious but guarded'' condition at Methodist Hospital today after his new Eagle race car slammed into the third-turn wall during practice for Saturday's first qualifying runs at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: YANKEES DEFEATED IN 17-INNING GAME
description: For the second consecutive game, the Yankees played extra innings last night and this morning. The similarity, though, ended there.

title: THE RED-AND-WHITE TICKET TO WEALTH
description: The quest for a Lotto prize starts with a $1 purchase: a betting form that provides two chances to win.

title: Meese's Deputy Resigns
description: James E. Jenkins, deputy to Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, is leaving his post Tuesday to become executive vice president of Transworld Group and chairman of the Transworld Engineering and Construction Services Company, an export-import concern.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: ZIMBABWE VILLAGERS TELL OF ABUSES
description: With a Government escort standing by, foreign journalists on a tour of a rebel area have heard charges from residents that soldiers pressing a counterinsurgency drive have resorted to raping, torturing, beating and murdering villagers.

title: Favorites Struggle to Win
description: Jimmy Connors, John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl - in order, the first three seeded players - advanced as expected yesterday to the semifinals of the Mercedes Tournament of Champions at the West Side Tennis Club. Unexpectedly, each one had to overcome a lost set before winning.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AGENT ADMITS FINANCING PLAN KEPT DELOREAN IN DRUG DEAL
description: A Government agent said today that if he had not proposed a method of financing an ostensible narcotics deal, John Z. DeLorean would at that point have been out of the deal for which he is on trial.

title: 3 ARE ARRESTED IN JEWEL THEFT IN MANHATTAN
description: Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $6 million in gold chains from a Fifth Avenue wholesale jewelry company in April 1983, one of the largest such thefts ever in New York City, the police said.

title: Feldstein Optimistic On Outlook
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the outgoing chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that, despite surging interest rates, there was little risk of a severe economic slowdown and that he did not see ''any signs at all'' of a recession this year or in 1985.

title: WOMAN IN FALLOUT CASE GREW UP WITH TESTING
description: Jacqueline M. Sanders's earliest memories of nuclear fission were of the way her family would bustle out onto the front porch and peer over the red-rock rim of this town at the unnatural fireball lighting the western sky.

title: NETS LOSE SHOT-CLOCK PROTEST
description: The final buzzer on the Nets' season sounded officially today when the National Basketball Association's commissioner, David Stern, denied the team's protest of their series, ending 98-97 playoff loss to the Milwaukee Bucks Thursday night.

title: 6 Bombs Go Off in Marseilles
description: Corsican separatists demanding political status for nationalist prisoners detonated six bombs early today at banks and public buildings, causing damage but no injuries, the police said. The bombs went off in succession at about 1 A.M. in this southern port city. The Corsican National Liberation Front took responsibility for the attacks.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $123,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $97,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from San Francisco yesterday on a meeting of state Democratic chairmen misstated an objection by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to election procedures. He opposes runoff primary elections for state and local offices; there are no runoff primaries in the Presidential contest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I cannot allow my wife and family to suffer further anguish.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas Attorney General Ordered to Stand Trial
description: Attorney General Jim Mattox of Texas was ordered today to stand trial Sept. 17 on charges of commercial bribery.

title: KEEP REGULATORS' HANDS OFF CORPORATE MERGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Runners Vary
description: According to a demographic study by the National Running Data Center of 468 men and women who qualified for marathon trials for the United States Olympic team, median ages were 28 for women and 27.7 for men.

title: BOON TO SMALL BUSINES: ELECTRONIC LEDGERS
description: The booming use of personal computers is enabling thousands of small enterprises - lumber yards and law offices, small banks, shops and farms - to do a better job of running their businesses.

title: Dole to Return Money From Some Developers
description: Senator Bob Dole is offering to return money donated at a fund-raising event sponsored by developers who seek an interchange for an interstate highway near a luxury housing project in this area.

title: SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $446,000.

title: BERKLEY, W R, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a realized gain on investments of $138,000. c-Net income.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CLINGING TO SOCIAL ANTIQUITY
description: One consequence of the computer will probably be the elimination of the office. With a terminal at home in the parlor or bedroom, tied into the company's central computer, work that is done entirely with electronic help need no longer require the work force to assemble in a central hall.

title: Mayor Koch's Recession 'Profits'
description: A company that survives an economic downturn usually emerges leaner and meaner: austerity forces more efficient management practices and reduced payrolls. The challenge is to sustain the new efficiencies to maximize profits after the economy turns up again. A similar challenge now faces Mayor Koch in managing his enterprise, New York City.

title: DUARTE DECLARED SALVADOR WINNER WITH 54% OF VOTE
description: The Central Elections Council today declared Jose Napoleon Duarte, the moderate candidate, the winner of Sunday's presidential election. He received almost 54 percent of the vote.

title: POPE JOHN PAUL'S POSITION ON JERUSALEM
description: To the Editor:

title: NISSAN TO START BUILDING CARS IN U.S. NEXT YEAR
description: Japan's No. 2 auto maker, the Nissan Motor Company, announced today that it would begin assembling cars at its Smyrna, Tenn., plant next spring.

title: MONDALE RESUMES CRITICISM OF HART'S 'FLIPFLOPS' IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: After several weeks in which he eased his attacks on Gary Hart, Walter F. Mondale today accused the Colorado Senator, his principal rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, of ''unsteadiness,'' ''inconsistencies,'' ''flipflops'' and a lack of experience to lead the nation.

title: IF A GARLIC CLOVE ISN'T ENOUGH, BAKE A WHOLE HEAD
description: The first time I printed in a newspaper a recipe calling for a head rather than a single clove of garlic, I recieved several letters from cooks correcting me. But there was no error.

title: ALVARADO RESIGNS AS SCHOOLS CHIEF, OFFERING APOLOGY
description: Irony, inevitability and miscalculation marked the Chancellor's precipitous downfall. Page 14.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Riding in Style

title: DO SERVICE CONTRACTS SERVE THE CUSTOMER?
description: The purchase of a refrigerator, television or automobile is likely to be accompanied by a suggestion that the customer buy a service contract. After all, the sales agent may say, what could be more reassuring than a guarantee that a repair agent will be on the spot if anything goes wrong?

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Carmichael Released
description: He has the National Football League record of catching passes in 127 consecutive games, and he has caught more passes (589) for more yards (8,918) and more touchdowns (79) than any other receiver in the history of the Philadelphia Eagles. But at age 34, Harold Carmichael no longer fits in with the team's plans. Yesterday the club announced it had put the 6-foot-8-inch wide receiver on waivers after failing to find a team that would take him in a trade.

title: Some Immunity in Navy Case
description: P. Takis Veliotis, a Greek-American accused of defrauding the United States Navy while a vice president of the General Dynamics Corporation, has been granted immunity from prosecution in connection with statements he made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a lawyer said today.

title: G.M.'s Venezuela Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation of Venezuela has proposed a plan to the Government for the manufacture and export of 65,000 automobiles, financed by capital from Japan. The proposal has been submitted to Venezuela's Econmomic Cabinet.

title: HART DELEGATES 'ELECTED' IN CITY BY PARTY CHIEFS
description: Six members of the Democratic State Committee pulled up chairs in a rough semicircle at Manhattan Democratic headquarters yesterday and proceeded to vote in an ''election'' in which there were three candidates for three positions.

title: QUARTERLY LOSS POSTED BY MARSH AND MCLENNAN
description: Heavy losses in bond trading led the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the large insurance broker, to report yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss of $28.3 million and a $29.7 million reduction in its 1983 earnings.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALLY & GARGANO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Revenue figures represent gross billings and fees.

title: WYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CREWS WORK FRANTICALLY ON EVE OF THE WORLD'S FAIR
description: An army of 5,000 workers raced to complete construction on the 84-acre World's Fair site today amid concern that some exhibits and pavilions would not be ready when the gates open to the public at noon Saturday.

title: STRIKE AT NBC DURING CONVENTION IS THREATENED
description: NBC Television cameramen, newswriters and technicians, who have been working without a labor contract for more than a year, have threatened to strike during the Democratic National Convention if no agreement is reached by then.

title: RETAIL SALES UP BY 2.9% IN APRIL
description: Sales at the retail level surged 2.9 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $99,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Coopervision Inc.
description: The investor Ivan F. Boesky said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had bought 1.3 million common shares, or 6.5 percent of the shares outstanding, of Coopervision Inc. Mr. Boesky said he bought the shares of the Palo Alto, Calif., firm from April 23 to May 8 at prices ranging from $21.50 to $24.375.

title: A Further Delay In Trilogy Venture
description: Trilogy Ltd., the troubled developer of a new technology for mainframe computers, said in a 10-Q filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it would not ship its first computer until 1987, the third such delay announced in recent months.

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Salvador Aide, Seized in '82, Released by Rebels in Trade
description: Guerrillas have freed El Salvador's former Deputy Defense Minister after nearly two years of captivity in exchange for eight jailed leftist leaders, a rebel radio station reported today.

title: Reagan's Big Drawback Called His Antagonism
description: Robert M. Teeter, the Republican pollster, said Thursday that President Reagan's biggest weakness in this election year was that he had ''almost gone out of his way'' to antagonize groups opposed to his policies.

title: VAC-TEC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-After a charge of $153,000 for a change in accounting for production contracts.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a net realized investment loss of $1,499,000. c-Including a net realized investment gain of $2,642,000.

title: RADIATION-CANCER LINK KEY TO RULING
description: The landmark ruling Thursday by a Federal district judge that the Government had been negligent in the way it conducted nuclear tests in Nevada was based on the ''contributory role'' that radiation from the explosions played in causing 10 cancers, nine of them fatal.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $622,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,134,000.

title: U.S. Labels Remarks By Greek 'Outrageous'
description: The State Department said today that statements by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece labeling the United States an imperialist power and praising the Soviet Union constitute an ''outrageous'' and ''totally uncalled for'' comparison.

title: JOHN SACCHIA
description: John Sacchia, national production manager of Hearst newspapers and an employee of the Hearst Corporation for 49 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Syosset, L.I. He was years old.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: 3-Year Pact for Penney
description: Steve Penney , the Montreal Canadiens' rookie goaltender, has been given a three-year contract and installed as the team's No. 1 goaltender. ''There's no doubt he's going into camp No. 1,'' said the Canadiens' managing director, Serge Savard , who noted that Penney had won the position with his impressive postseason play.

title: PRECAMBRIAN SHIELD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Will Pay $1,200 In Spraying by Prince
description: Buckingham Palace has promised to pay a press photographer $1,200 for damage caused when Prince Andrew sprayed paint on a group of reporters, a spokesman for the British Consulate General said today.

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,485,000 for the quarter and $39,626,000 for the year. The company filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in April 1983.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MORALS OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The White House moved swiftly this week to deny that President Reagan wanted to cut back Social Security benefits for the affluent elderly. But the comments of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan earlier in the week, hinting at such changes, raised basic questions about the nature of the Government's commitment to pay benefits to millions of workers who have contributed to the Social Security trust fund.

title: Sanitation Union Opens Bargaining
description: The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association began bargaining yesterday for a new contract with proposals for higher pay and improved pensions and health benefits.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ALVARADO RESIGNATION STATEMENT
description: Following are excerpts from the statement in which Anthony J. Alvarado resigned yesterday as Schools Chancellor of New York City:

title: Ellamae Cobb Marries Ben Ali Haggin
description: Ellamae Mason Cobb, the daughter of Mrs. Egon Love of Ridgewood, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Herbert Charles Mansfield Cobb of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Ben Ali Haggin, a son of Mary Haggin of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Ben Ali Haggin. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Grand Jury Indicts 3 In Providence Inquiry
description: A reputed figure in organized crime, Frank L. Marrapese, and a city official have been indicted in a continuing investigation of Providence city government by a state grand jury.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET OLYMPICDECISION IS PART OF PLAN TO 'FREEZE' TIES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Soviet decision not to attend the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer was part of an overall Soviet plan to put relations with the United States ''in a sort of deep freeze.''

title: BANKS FREE TO OFFER IMPROVED SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. SAID TO AID SALVADOR PARTIES
description: The Central Intelligence Agency gave $1.4 million to two political parties in El Salvador in an effort to prevent the election of a right-wing candidate as president, a Reagan Administration official familiar with C.I.A. operations said today.

title: Why Single Out Religion?
description: After the school prayer amendment failed in the Senate in March, some legislators began pressing a measure called the ''Religious Speech Protection Act.'' That title accurately described a bill that would require public school officials to let students hold religious meetings on the school grounds during their free time.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POPE ADDRESSES REFUGEES, THEN LEAVES THAILAND
description: Pope John Paul II visited an Indochinese refugee camp today and told the thousands gathered there that they should not forget they were ''free people who have a rightful place in this world.'' He said he looked forward to the day when all exiles could return to their native countries.

title: DANCE: 'LIEBESLIEDER' RESTORED BY CITY BALLET
description: Among George Balanchine's indisputable masterpieces, ''Liebeslieder Walzer'' holds a special place. After an absence of 10 years from the City Ballet, the still-daring ballet was restored to the company's repertory Thursday night in the State Theater.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an unusual pre-tax charge of $110,000,000 in connection with investment activities. c-Net income.

title: Air Florida Cuts
description: Air Florida said it would lay off 290 more workers by June 1, meaning the financially ailing carrier has slashed its work force by a third in the last month.

title: 8 PEOPLE KILLED, 7 HURT IN BLAZE AT THEME PARK
description: Eight people were killed and seven others were injured last night in a fire at a haunted house attraction at an amusement park in Jackson, N.J., according to authorities.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,000 from the sale of properties and investments. c-Includes a gain of $35,000 from the sale of properties and investments.

title: Federal Express
description: The Federal Express Corporation said it had ordered six McDonnell Douglas DC-10 aircraft for the company's small-package air express service.

title: ARMSTRONG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $36,084. c-Net loss.

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $32,565, or 1 cent a share.

title: THE YEAR THE FISH RETURNED TO CROTONA PARK
description: There was a little boy - Wilma Brooks says he couldn't have been more than about 6 years old - walking all by himself through the Crotona Park neighborhood of the South Bronx the other day with a fishing pole in his hand. She watched out a store window as he crossed with the light at Third Avenue and strode purposefully past the rundown stores, the bookie joint and the open fields of busted brick.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FILM: 'HARDBODIES' ON BEACH
description: ''We spent years trying to get our businesses to work the way we wanted so we could come and do this!'' declares one of the three middle-aged lechers who decide to move to a California beach to ogle the teen- age talent. Thus begins ''Hardbodies,'' which tells of what happens when the lechers hire a smug, oversexed beach boy named Scotty (Grant Cramer) to help them make cute little friends.

title: KAISER STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss includes loss from discontinued operations of $10,110,000. The year-earlier results restated.

title: MULTITUDES LINING UP TO WIN MILLIONS
description: A man who said he was an investment banker stood with a red-and- white Lotto slip in his hand yesterday in a line at 45th Street and Third Avenue. He said he was late for a luncheon engagement, but still thought the wait worth the time.

title: CHANGE IN BASING OF THE MX REPORTED LINKED TO SHORTCOMINGS IN ITS RANGE
description: The Air Force changed its basing plans for the MX missile last year to make up for shortcomings in its range, according to a General Accounting Office report and Pentagon sources.

title: TOOTH FAIRIES DON'T RENT
description: Seminars convened to predict the future are usually helpful to no one but insomniacs, but such an exercise this week on what lies ahead for New York City did produce a revealing debate about the real estate industry.

title: Philharmonic Preview
description: A preview of the New York Philharmonic's New Horizons '84 series can be heard on radio station WKCR, 89.9 FM beginning tomorrow through June 1. Included will be live interviews with Roger Reynolds, Charles Wuorinen and Jacob Druckman on three consecutive Sundays from 9 P.M. to midnight. Other programs can be heard during the week of May 28 from 3 P.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Texaco to Sell Japan Oil Interest
description: Texaco Inc. said it had reached agreement to sell the 50 percent interest in Japan's Mitsubishi Oil Company for $335 million in cash, continuing Texaco's efforts to unload unwanted assets acquired when it purchased the Getty Oil Company for $10.1 billion earlier this year.

title: ; ACTORS DOWN ON UPDATED SHAKESPEARE
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS' SIMPLIFIED DATA
description: A REVISION authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission is permitting mutual funds to shorten and simplify prospectuses for their stockholders. Some of the new prospectuses have begun to appear, and within the next five months, the short-form prospectus will be the only one used by the industry.

title: FIVE COAST RIVERS ARE RULED 'WILD'
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the designation of parts of five northern California waterways as wild rivers over the objections of local governments and businesses that asserted the designation would have an adverse economic impact.

title: ISSUE IN SALVADORAN AID
description: On the surface, the House debate that led to approval of President Reagan's aid package for El Salvador was over a defined and practical issue: Should Congress tie the aid to performance on human rights by the Salvadoran Government, and if so, how? Or should the President be given the flexibility to do it his way?

title: FATHER SENTENCED TO PERFORM PUBLIC SERVICE FOR KILLING SON
description: A retired Army officer who shot to death his disfigured, suicidal son was sentenced today to perform 100 hours of community service a month for the next five years.

title: Tandy to Offer Mobile Phone Line
description: The Tandy Corporation said it would enter the cellular mobile telephone business as both a manufacturer and marketer. In an agreement with the Bell Atlantic Corporation, Tandy will provide cellular service and equipment at about 70 retail outlets in the Middle Atlantic region.

title: Merger Talks For Southmark
description: The Southmark Corporation has begun discussions with American Realty Trust on the possibility of a merger, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Shell Bid Ruling
description: The success of a $5.5 billion bid by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies for the 30.6 percent of the Shell Oil Company it does not already own was thrown into doubt for at least another 20 days by a Delaware Chancery Court ruling. The judge directed that Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment advisers to Royal Dutch, provide more information to minority shareholders because of questions raised on the fairness of the $58- a-share offer. Among other things, the revised offer must disclose the internal company information that had led Shell to value its stock at $91 a share.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary credit of $2,500,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: TALKS ON NAMIBIA OPEN WITH A DISPUTE
description: The insurgents who oppose South Africa's disputed control of South-West Africa and their white South African adversaries and other political foes met here today in a major effort to seek a settlement, but a procedural wrangle held up substantive deliberations for hours.

title: GUERRILLAS SEIZE 73 IN CAPITAL
description: A group of 15 to 20 leftist insurgents shot their way into a discount supermarket this evening, taking 73 customers and employees hostage, according to a cashier inside the building.

title: SOVIET GUARDS SAKHAROVS' FRIEND
description: Plainclothes policemen have posted a 24-hour guard at the apartment of a woman who briefly visited Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife in Gorky last week and reported on their plight.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes equity of $3,200,000 in net losses of Chromalloy American Corp. c-Includes equity of $2,096,000 in net losses of Chromalloy American Corp.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 3
description: b-Includes nonrecurring expenses of $34.7 million consisting of Chapter 11 losses, severance pay provisions and writeoffs of deferred charges. The net is also after an extraordinary gain of $37.7 million consisting of Chapter 11 debt foregiveness of $63.1 million less $18.2 million attributable to stock issuable to unsecured creditors and Chapter 11 administrative expenses of $7.2 million. c-Net loss after nonrecurring expenses of $22 million from Chapter 11- related losses and writeoffs of data processing development costs.

title: No Headline
description: Limited Health Risks From Dioxin Reported

title: METROMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After a loss of $1,894,000 on the anticipated sale of a radio station. c-Net income which includes a gain of $3,859,000 on the sale of a property.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1984 International
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte got 54 percent of the vote in Sunday's presidential election in El Salvador, according to the Central Elections Council's official figures. The far-right opposition party said it would not accept the council's tally. (Page 1, Column 6.) Two Salvadoran political parties received $1.4 million from the Central Intelligence Agency, according to a Reagan Administration official familiar with C.I.A. operations. He said the C.I.A. was seeking to prevent the election of a right-wing candidate as president. (6:3.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Invitation to the Grange

title: Tavoulareas Will Retire
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Corporation for more than 14 years, will retire in November when he reaches the age of 65, the company announced on Thursday.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hudson Crossings To Get New Signs
description: Electronic signs telling motorists of delays and suggesting alternative routes are to be placed on approaches to the six Hudson River crossings within the next four years.

title: U.S. USES NEW WEAPON IN VOTING RIGHTS SUIT
description: The Justice Department charged today that county commissioner districts in Pike County, Ala., were not of equal population and thus diluted black voting strength in violation of the Voting Rights Act.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Libya Accuses Tunisia Of Harboring Terrorists
description: Libya said today that terrorists were using Tunisia as a base for attacks on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and warned of ''the grievous danger'' relations between the neighboring North African countries might face as a result.

title: Continental Rally
description: The stock of the Continental Illinois Corporation rallied yesterday, following a sharp decline Thursday on rumors about the bank's financial situation.

title: Bridge: It Takes an Expert to Know The Use of the Active Voice
description: In an everyday sense, the words ''mood'' and ''voice'' have obviously distinct meanings. When the words are used technically, any professional grammarian would understand. This department confused the two in a column some time ago and will now improve.

title: Riot Prevention in the Caribbean
description: Those food riots that rattled the Dominican Republic have also rattled Washington. Everbody concedes that more should have been done to bolster a democratic Government before food prices jumped up in compliance with austerity terms for an International Monetary Fund loan. The State Department has now scraped up $15 million in additional credits and Congress is considering $75 million more in aid. Why wasn't this help extended before Santo Domingo was shaken by the worst violence in a generation?

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital losses of $5,000. c-Net income including capital gains of $60,000.

title: COLUMBIA STARTS MAJOR CRACKDOWN ON DRUG TRADE
description: The Government has begun its biggest crackdown against Colombia's multi- billion dollar narcotics industry.

title: Clash on House TV Coverage WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters) - A change in the television coverage of the House of Representatives has led to an angry charge by Republicans that Democrats are playing political tricks with the system of televising sessions.
description: Republicans said today that they were upset that the Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., a Massachusetts Democrat, ordered television cameras in the House chamber to show empty seats as Republicans delivered speeches Thursday night. The cameras normally focus only on members who are speaking.

title: CORRECTION

description: Nearly 200 militant Sikhs were released from jail today in an effort to defuse tension in Punjab, the north Indian state that has been torn by violence.

description: A Federal District Court jury today awarded $90,000 to an inmate who said Missouri's director of prisons and two subordinates violated his civil rights by beating him in 1980.

Folklore, and the stories that are part of it, speak of the people's lives, and the three-day Jewish Folklore Conference starts its deliberations on ''Living Tradition: Jewish Folk Creativity and Cultural Survival.''

title: OFFICER CHASING ROBBERS IS SHOT IN A BRONX BANK
description: An off-duty police officer was shot yesterday by an officer who mistook him for a bank robber. The shooting occurred as both were searching with their guns drawn for two men who had just held up a Citibank branch in the Bronx.

And this engagement follows directly four concerts that Mr. Leinsdorf led here with the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: POPE OFFERS TO GO TO SOVIET IF ASKED
description: Pope John Paul II returned today from a 10-day, 25,000 mile journey to the Far East and said he would continue his world travels, even going to the Soviet Union and China if such trips could be arranged.

title: Utah Volunteers Prepare For Floods From Snow
description: Thousands of volunteers built and fortified sandbag dikes today along streams brimming with snow runoff from the mountains as the National Weather Service warned that its earlier forecast of flooding in Utah was near reality.

title: 'The Witches of Eastwick'
description: ''THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK'' is John Updike's first novel since the much-celebrated ''Rabbit Is Rich,'' and a strange and marvelous organism it proves to be. Like his third novel, ''The Centaur,'' it is a departure from baroque realism. This time, too, Mr. Updike transposes mythology into the minor keys of small town America, but this time he pulls it off, possibly because, like Shakespeare and Robert Louis Stevenson before him, he finds wickedness and mischief more engrossing as subjects than goodness and wisdom.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION ; WALTER IS WALTER IS WALTER

Just last year my friend Jean could hardly contain her glee as she showed me a piece of paper she had received Special Delivery for her birthday. It was a certificate from Donald, her husband, entitling her to a month's use of a limousine. You know those sleek mile-long cars that cruise Manhattan driven by a chauffeur in uniform to match the car.

The metal workers' union mobilized 13,000 of its 2.5 million members for scattered walkouts tomorrow in pursuit of the 35- hour workweek. The opening blows will be limited, but the Government and businessmen fear they might snowball, endangering incipient economic recovery.

title: COURTROOMS ON CAMERA-REALITY VS. DRAMA
description: One very good argument for not televising trials is that it is the camera, not the prosecution and defense, which selects what the viewer will see. The judicial system, flawed as it may be, operates on the assumption that the search for truth is arduous, complicated and often confusing. Evidence is not always what it seems; witnesses are not always accurate. Therefore, prosecution and defense argue, even quibble, and out of their debate is supposed to come truth. It is not a perfect process; it may not even be a very good one, but bearing in mind the alternatives - a Star Chamber, say - it is probably the best one around.

title: Students Striken by Fumes
description: Scores of students and teachers at a San Fernando Valley elementary school were striken with nausea attributed to toxic chemical fumes that wafted into classrooms Friday for the third day in a row. The fiberglass styrene fumes from a manufacturing plant a block away caused stomach aches, headaches and chest pains at the Sylvan Park School in the Van Nuys area, schools officials said. The plant, Custom Home Spas Inc, was cited by the South Coast Air Quality Management District for styrene odor problems in October.

''I'm just out here to play a little baseball and bring some fans to the league,'' said Jenkins. After a shaky first inning in which he gave up a three-run home run, Jenkins completed his five-inning assignment and left the game with London ahead, 6-4, to earn the victory.

title: International

Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who apparently fears that rising interest rates will lead to more financial pressures on third world debtors. He said it now seemed appropriate to move to ''a new phase in financing'' as part of a broad program to help consolidate the gains made by some countries and to prevent a significant worsening in the positions of others. He made his remarks at a news conference in Hot Springs, Va., where he was attending a meeting of the Business Council. (Page 1, Col. 6.) title: WHAT 'MODERN' MEANT IN 1913
description: EXHIBITIONS that turn the clock back are useful in measuring how far we have progressed from any point in our cultural history. ''The Shock of Modernism in America: The Eight and Artists of the Armory Show'' at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor brings us back to the first years of this century, when a group of eight artists joined together to protest the stifling standards of the country's traditional art establishment. Their crusade ultimately led to the formation of a committee that rented New York's 69th Regiment Armory for a 1913 exposition showcasing modern art from both sides of the Atlantic.

More and more, English-speaking musicians and listeners are paying attention to music from the Third World, and lately that has meant African pop.

title: No Headline
description: Among the friends of Walter F. Mondale, nothing arouses as much anxiety as the suggestion that the former Vice President can do everything required of a Presidential nominee except expand his appeal outside hardcore Democrats. Mr. Mondale had just about laid the ''electability'' question to rest by making the most significant comeback from an early reversal by any recent Democratic candidate. Last week, by narrowly losing the Ohio and Indiana primaries to Gary Hart, he gave new life to the old doubts just as he gave new life to Mr. Hart's candidacy. Few Historical Guideposts Moreover, the nomination battle has now entered territory for which there are few historical guideposts. The anomaly is that the Colorado Senator now has a longshot chance at the nomination, even though it is almost a numerical impossibility for him to overtake Mr. Mondale's lead in the delegate count. Of the 1,967 delegate votes needed to nominate, Mr. Mondale's tally last week, according to United Press International, was 1,518, and Mr. Hart's, 886; 829 remain to be selected. Among party leaders, there was grumbling that Mr. Mondale had blown an opportunity to cinch the nomination by falling victim to his old nemeses, caution and overconfidence. He was particularly faulted for campaigning down to the wire in Texas, leaving Ohio to Mr. Hart for a couple of days. ''We made a series of decisions that with 20/20 hindsight we might not have made,'' said James A. Johnson, the Mondale campaign chairman.

title: CAN GREAT ART BE THE STUFF OF DRAMA?
description: Contrary to what is often supposed, an artist's professional activity is not the stuff of drama. Michelangelo tucked up under the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel may well have been a remarkable sight. To see Jackson Pollock pour paint on canvas, as happens in Hans Namuth's famous documentary movie, is to understand him better. But in the case of almost every other artist, from Giotto down to our own day, there was in theatrical terms no action at all. One man with a sketchbook on his knee is much like another. Great art is not made with histrionic gestures. It is made slowly and in silence with movements of the hand and arm that are more likely to remind us of a watchmaker than of an orchestra conductor at grips with Mahler's Eighth. This is not a procedure that can be acted out.

title: TRANSFORMING THE SCREEN INTO ART
description: Artists throughout history have pioneered in collecting period or foreign artifacts and, in so doing, have occasionally sparked innovative revivals in the decorative arts. A small, creative movement - and one of the least publicized - began a century ago when French painters, immersed in Japanese art and culture, transformed the Oriental folding screen into a Western furnishing. The results were - and are - stunning, as can be seen in ''The Folding Image,'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the first exhibition to examine this development . The screens on view dating from 1870 to the present include examples of most of the art styles that emerged in this period, executed in paint, carved wood, embroidered silk and bronze- framed opalescent glass.

title: NEW LINES ADDING INTEREST

title: TRUMAN AND THE BOMB
description: The day Harry S. Truman may have saved my life is not one I've thought about very often over the years, but it deserves some reflection in this centennial year of his birth. The day was August 6, 1945. I was a G.I. who had weathered the war in Europe and now awaited my place in the storming of Japan's home islands. On Truman's orders, the first atomic bomb ever wielded in war exploded over Hiroshima. For Americans in uniform and those who waited for them to come home, outrageous as this may appear from the moral heights of hindsight, it was a sunburst of deliverance.

The Punjab troubles threaten to widen into the most serious civil conflict since shortly after India's independence in 1947. They have placed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government under an election-year cloud, restricted her freedom of movement and called into question the ability of the system to deal with conflicts inherent in Indian society.

title: IMPORTANT SONDHEIM, BUT LESS THAN SUCCESSFUL
description: By now one should expect nothing but the unexpected, predict nothing but the unpredictable, of Stephen Sondheim. The next step for a composer who has forged Broadway musicals from dour recollections of American imperialism in Japan, a sardonic movie about marital woe by Ingmar Bergman, and a tale of insanity, mass murder and cannibalism in 19th-century London, could be pretty well anything strange and slippery: a gaudy cantata about Genghis Khan, maybe, or a chamber version of Samuel Beckett's ''Waiting for Godot.'' So no one should be much astonished by the small but intractable subject, the mountainous molehill, he has in fact decided to make his latest challenge.

title: LEONARD CHOOSES RETIREMENT AFTER FINDING SPARK IS GONE

Not even a fight with Marvelous Marvin Hagler, which he admitted today was the only one he came back for, the one on which he had planned to end his career, could tempt Sugar Ray Leonard now. But over the final 30 seconds of one of boxing's most brilliant chapters, Leonard fought with the same demonic look in his eyes as in his finest moment, 32 months ago, when he rallied to knock out Thomas Hearns.

title: NETS FEELING UNEASY AS CHANGES LOOM
description: There is a strange and often uncomfortable air at team meetings held at the end of the season. There are 12 men who have spent more than 7 months together in pursuit of a goal - the National Basketball Association title. They have sweated, run, lived and traveled together. They have high-fived together after victories, and sulked together after losses. They have also competed against one another. That competition is over for the Nets. They survived the pitfalls of uncertainty and jealousy that haunted them during the regular season, attaining playoff success by eliminating the defending-champion Philadelphia 76ers in the opening round before losing to the veteran Milwaukee Bucks, four games to two, in the Eastern Conference semifinals. Yet, despite the success, there was again an uncomfortable air as the Nets emptied their lockers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Friday afternoon, and said goodbye to one another. Was it goodbye for the summer, or for good? ''I always like to get out of there quickly,'' said Buck Williams, who hurried for an appointment. ''I don't know if I'll play with some of these guys again. I know that's the way it always is, but it's still a funny feeling.'' Despite the stability that Coach Stan Albeck brought to a franchise previously wrought with change, it was clear that some changes would have to be made if the Nets were to carry their postseason success through season. Even Otis Birdsong, the guard who returned to his all-star form with his best season as a Net, admitted that it would be a critical summer for the franchise.

title: THE SPECIALS REALLY ARE
description: WESLEY'S, in Greenwich, like a number of other restaurants, is a different restaurant by day than by night. The nighttime persona is preferable. At dinner, subtle lighting casts a romantic glow, softening the look of what by day is a rather plain, U-shaped dining area, decorated in gray and red. The renovated interior of a 19th-century brickmill, once the American Felt Company, has been simply but handsomely executed. Wide windows allow viewing a waterfall and stylized pieces of felt are used attractively as decoration to remind you of the building's origins. Taped classical music provides a low backdrop for conversation.

title: HART KEEPS HIS FOOT IN THE DOOR--BUT IT HURTS
description: A MONG the friends of Walter F. Mondale, nothing arouses as much anxiety as the suggestion that the former Vice President can do everything required of a Presidential nominee except expand his appeal outside hardcore Democrats. Mr. Mondale had just about laid the ''electability'' question to rest by making the most significant comeback from an early reversal by any recent Democratic candidate. Last week, by narrowly losing the Ohio and Indiana primaries to Gary Hart, he gave new life to the old doubts just as he gave new life to Mr. Hart's candidacy.

description: -shoot of original material in 1970 comes off as an archaic, somewhat amateurish effort in the Hartman Theater's diluted production of the soft-rock musical, ''The Me Nobody Knows.''

description: NORMAN KOTKER's most recent novel is ''Miss Rhode Island'' (Farrar, Straus).

title: Administrator Steps Down
description: Christopher C. DeMuth, the manager of the Reagan Administration's deregulation effort, will leave his post in early July to go into business and to work in President Reagan's re-election campaign, the Office of Management and Budget said Friday.

title: TWO SET STANDARDS IN RUNS
description: Peddy King and Eileen Ellig posted impressive track performances today at the 17th annual Laucks Games on the White Plains High School Field.

title: PINK FLOYD AT POMPEII
description: 83 minutes. $29.95

title: Joan Calahan Marries Cornelius Shannahan
description: Joan Calahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Calahan of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Cornelius Kevin Shannahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius E. Shannahan of Chappaqua and Ludlow, Vt., were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller, assisted by the Rev. Charles Kavanagh, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 11% of Kindergartners Failed in Minneapolis
description: School officials here have failed more than 11 percent of this year's kindergartners and are requiring them to attend summer school before they can go on to first grade.

title: SALVADOR REBELS FREE 73 HOSTAGES
description: Seventy-three men, women and children were taken hostage Friday night by Salvadoran rebels in a discount supermarket and held for nearly nine hours before being released early today.

title: SOVIET RAILROAD OFFICIALS CAUTIOUS ON SIBERIAN 'GOLDEN SPIKE'
description: Soviet railroad authorities have cautioned that the scheduled driving of a ''golden spike'' on the Baikal-Amur Mainline next fall, after 10 years of construction, would still leave the 2,000-mile-long rail project in eastern Siberia far from completed.

title: FENNEL COMING INTO OWN IN THE MARKET
description: FENNEL is gradually making the transition from exotic to the commonplace in our produce markets. To those of Italian extraction who know it as finocchio, it is not at all unusual. In fact it would be surprising if slices or wedges of fresh, crisp fennel were not included on a platter of raw vegetables that is often served as an antipasto.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SHOW HAS APT SETTING
description: A CARAVAN of 125 antiques dealers from throughout the Northeast will travel to Woodbridge Saturday for the 11th annual Woodbridge Outdoor Antiques Festival. The show, staged on the grounds of the Old Center School, faces the village green; it thus is provided with one of Connecticut's more attractive settings for such an event.

title: CLASSES FOR HANDICAPPED PRESCHOOLERS
description: IN one class they are making

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: Aphrodite Mavricos and Bruce D. Garrison Marry
description: Aphrodite Mavricos, an industry analyst for the Mobil Oil Corporation, and Bruce Dwight Garrison, a tax counsel for Mobil, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alex Karloutsos, assisted by the Rev. Nicholas Magoulias.

title: RITES OF FIRE ON A GREEK ISLE
description: MARVINE HOWE, formerly chief of the New York Times bureau in Athens, is now a reporter on the paper's metropolitan staff.

title: AUTO DEATHS ON RISE
description: AFTER three years of decline, automobile fatalities in Connecticut are again on the rise. During the first 115 days of 1984, 107 people were killed in traffic accidents, a 23 percent increase over the same period in 1983, when 87 died, according to the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: THE REGION ;
description: Can OTB Get Back on Track?

title: THE IMAGE REMAINS A PROBLEM FOR LIFTERS
description: LAS VEGAS,Nev.

title: Czech Dissident Detained
description: A former spokesman for the Charter 77 Czechoslovak human rights movement, Ladislav Lis, has been in custody since Thursday for failing to report to the police, emigre sources said here today. Mr. Lis, released last March after serving a 14-month sentence on charges of incitement, told his family by telephone that he was being held for violating the ''protective supervision'' order imposed on him on his release from jail, the sources said.

title: FERNANDO BUJONES IN 'COPPELIA'
description: Fernando Bujones, one of American Ballet Theater's most brilliant danseurs, is seen here in spectacular form. Nevertheless, this presentation is a peculiar one.

title: EUROLINGO
description: ''There is no way out.'' That lugubrious conviction, supposedly rampant among many important European businessmen and politicians, was described by Washington Post ecolumnist Hobart Rowen on April 8 of this year as

title: PREVIEW IN MEMPHIS
description: As a result of the international team play-offs in Memphis a week ago the United States will have some of its most experienced players to represent it in the World Team Olympiad, scheduled to begin in Seattle on October 27.

title: JAPAN IS DELAYING MILITARY BUILDUP
description: Japan has conceded that it cannot meet its own timetable for strengthening its armed forces sufficiently to resist foreign attack.

title: CRIME
description: Martha Grimes is an American writer whose mystery novels have been set in England, as is THE DIRTY DUCK (Little, Brown, $14.95). The book is another in the series featuring Detective Superintendent Richard Jury and his friend Melrose Plant, a rich and titled young man who is a sort of latter-day Lord Peter Wimsey. The action starts with performances at the Royal Shakespeare Theater in Stratford-on-Avon, where the body of an American tourist is found. Then follow the murders of members of an American family also touring England. Jury happens to be on vacation in Stratford, but the officer in charge asks him to help, and of course he does. The Dirty Duck, incidentally, is the name of a pub near the theater.

title: SPORTS AND POLITICS
description: The argument between Washington and Moscow over the Olympics is coming out just right. The Russians did without the U.S. athletes last time, and we'll struggle along without their athletes in Los Angeles this summer.

title: SILENCE MASKS SHIPMENT OF BROOKHAVEN'S NUCLEAR WASTES
description: IN a specially designed building

title: AUDITORS FEEL THE HEAT OF A NEW SCRUTINY
description: WHENEVER Abraham J. Briloff, a prominent educator and longtime critic of the accounting profession, lectures to auditors these days, he advises them to carry in one hand their ''Generally Accepted Auditing Standards,'' the guiding principles for audit examinations, and a Bible in the other. ''Hoping against hope,'' he tells them, ''that one or the other will be your salvation.''

title: Greenbrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboy Case Dropped After months of investigation, Federal authorities have reportedly decided not to seek prosecution of several present and former members of the Dallas Cowboys whose names had surfaced in connection with the investigation of a cocaine ring. Federal officicals were not available for comment yesterday, but The Dallas Times Herald reported that the United States Attorney,
description: James A. Rolfe was wary of the case because one key witness was a convicted drug dealer and another has disappeared.

title: NEW ECHOES OLD
description: A new apartment house planned for a vacant lot that lies between two 19th century buildings on Willow Street in the Brooklyn Heights Historic District will reflect in its scale and style the buildings on either side as well as other structures on the block. Jonathan Eichner, the developer of the four-story residential project planned for 54 Willow Street, said the building's architect, Alfredo De Vido, had included such features as a cornice, lintels and dormered windows in his design for the facade of the new building.

title: NEW YORK CELEBRATES THE GENIUS OF JEAN COCTEAU
description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Columbia and Yale, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust'' and ''Francois Truffaut.''

title: Vietnam Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: WINEMAKERS TRYING TO WIDEN APPEAL
description: FINESVILLE WINE producers and a small group of entrepreneurs in the state are gambling that they can change the wine-drinking habits not only of New Jerseyans, but also of wine aficionados elsewhere.

title: MCENROE, LENDL EASILY GAIN FINAL
description: At least Jimmy Arias could say that a 51-minute rain delay contributed to his one-sided defeat by John McEnroe, the hottest player in men's tennis. Jimmy Connors had no such excuse.

title: A GREAT LOVE FOR TINY BOOKS
description: AT the age of 60, Whitney North Seymour Jr., a former United States Attorney and a partner at the New York law firm of Brown and Seymour, is enjoying success in another field, book publishing.

title: REPAIR PLAN MARKS '84 LEGISLATURE
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly, shaping some of the issues for the legislative elections in November, adjourned its 1984 session last Wednesday with divided assessments of what it had accomplished during the last three months.

title: TALKS STALLED IN SIXTH WEEK OF STRIKE AT WESTERN UNION
description: A strike by 400 employees of Western Union International is ending its sixth week with both sides reporting an impasse. Union officials say this could jeopardize communications operations at the summer Olympics, but the company says it has people doing the groundwork at the Olympic site and ''fully intends'' to serve the Games.

title: AFTER WEATHERING FEARS OF A GLUT, NEW YORK MAY FACE A SPACE SHORTAGE
description: LAST year, when developers in places like Houston and Atlanta were almost giving away excess office space, their New York City counterparts had nearly completed 11.2 million square feet of office space - more than had been built in any yaer since the last boom bust cycle in office development between 1959 and 1974. Were New York developers about to take another dive?

title: About Men; Facing Violence
description: Michael T. Kaufman

title: RETURN OF THE TEST OATH
description: * To the Editor: By concentrating on the particular facts of draft registration, your editorial on the Solomon amendment ignored the larger dangers posed by this new - and old - law enforcement technique. The Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination arose chiefly out of the colonists' opposition to test oaths. Instead of a process establishing guilt by investigation and adjudication, the test oath permits the state to punish all who cannot - or will not - attest to their innocence, thus reversing the presumption of innocence.

title: C.I.A. HAS LONG SOUGHT TO SWAY FOREIGN VOTERS
description: The report that the Central Intelligence Agency contributed more than $1.4 million to two political parties in El Salvador's presidential campaign is the latest episode in the agency's history of involvement in foreign elections.

title: NEVER FORGET: MONEY PLAYS THE STAR ROLE IN HOLLYWOOD
description: The next time you hear someone wondering why more good films aren't made, give him a copy of Variety, the show business weekly, and turn to the chart that reports the box office receipts of the 50 top-grossing films of the previous week. The chances are that he'll stop wondering why more good films aren't made and will, instead, be surprised that any good films are ever made at all.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: Hindu Editor Slain By Sikhs in Punjab
description: Sikh terrorists assassinated a leading Hindu newspaper editor in the northern state of Punjab today, touching off violence in which hundreds of Hindus attacked buses, stores and banks, reports from the area said.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO SPONTANEITY IN PERFORMANCE?
description: Looking back over the last few months, I see that I have heard a dozen well-known pianists of various ages and degrees of talent. A few, such as Vladimir Ashkenazy the other evening, played well enough to leave more than fleeting impressions. Far too often, however, after a couple of weeks have passed I am not able to recall even one piece that a particular pianist played, or one memorable phrase. Was it Virtuoso X who thundered his way through the ''Appassionata''? Or was it Virtuoso Y? Or, come to think of it, was it the ''Waldstein''?

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Dies of Wound After Protests in Chile
description: An 18-year-old boy died today after being shot in the head during disturbances Friday night during protests against the rule of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: FRENCH ROMANTIC REPORTORY YIELDS DIVERSE RICHES
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recorded music.

title: NAME OF ROAD SPURS A DEBATE
description: ON a rural lane called Swamp Road in the Botsford section of Newtown, the question, ''What's in a name?'' has triggered a lively debate.

title: Ellen Schmertz Becomes a Bride
description: Ellen Margaret Schmertz, the daughter of Dana Lee Van Buskirk of Stony Brook, L.I., and Eric J. Schmertz of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Douglas John Bowen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bowen of Brick Town, N.J. Judge Bernard S. Meyer of the New York State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: VOLCKER SUGGESTS LIMIT ON INTEREST FOR THIRD WORLD
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, apparently fearing that sharply rising interest rates will lead to new pressures on third world debtors, suggested today that banks consider limiting the rates they charge such countries on loans.

title: COMPUTERS IN THE GROVES OF ACADEME
description: Edward B. Fiske is education editor of The Times.

title: INSIDE CASTLE, CRIES OF 'I'M CHOKING'
description: Two young women who were inside the Haunted Castle attraction Friday evening when the fire at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park swept out of control, recalled yesterday the eerie confusion and the fear that gripped them as they realized the playful horror for which they had paid admission had become tragic reality.

title: 'THE ME NOBODY KNOWS' AT THE HARTMAN
description: STAMFORD, Conn.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AN AD HOC coalition of conservationists and planners will disclose tomorrow what it calls ''a bold new plan'' to preserve natural areas in parts of Mercer and Middlesex Counties and actively encourage developers to build parks and save land.

title: RETIREMENT: BALANCING THE SCALES
description: THE first Federal legislation aimed at improving private pension benefits for women

title: MORRIS JAIL NEAR COMPLETION
description: MORRISTOWN SEEN from above, the nearly completed addition to the Morris County Jail here looks as if might be the original structure around which the rest of the county seat was built.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
UNLOCKING THE PRISON OF ILLITERACY
description: OSSINING

title: Sara Davis Married to Stephen Bache
description: Sara Elizabeth Davis, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Rodney Davis of La Verne, Calif., was married yesterday to Stephen Kenneth Bache, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Michael Bache of Washington and Lavallette, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Laubach, assisted by the Rev. Dena Pence Frantz, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: THE NATION;
description: A Step Closer To Capitol Hill

title: A COOL FIT
description: For the heat of the summer, wearing loose and easy- fitting oversize shirts over long skirts or pants, or even as a dress itself, is an ideal way of staying cool.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS May 13, 1984Fiction
description: 1 GENTLE FEUDING, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) True love overcomes a bloody feud between two Scottish clans.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW COMMEMORATIVE PAYS TRIBUTE TO RESEARCH
description: A commemorative recognizing the achievements of the men and women engaged in the many facets of health research is being issued on Thursday in New York City. The first-day-of-issue ceremony will be held at 11:30 A.M. at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, one of the great health research facilities in the nation. The principal speaker will be Dr. Irvin F. Hermann, national medical director for the United States Postal Service.

title: A BALLERINA VENTURES INTO CHOREOGRAPHY
description: Love, lust and infamy will live on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday. They have before, certainly, particularly during the opera season. But this time the occasion is the New York premiere of ''Amnon V'Tamar,'' a new ballet by Martine van Hamel for the American Ballet Theater that is based on the biblical story of incestuous love between the children of King David.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHAT MOTHERS FEAR THE MOST
description: IF you are eligible to celebrate Mother's

title: Constance Young Becomes a Bride
description: Constance Burnham Young and William Thomas Moore were married yesterday at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien, Conn. The Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert O. Weeks, assisted by the Rev. Claude Peters of the Community Church.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Is there a new human face to Ray K. Metzker's work? Or is he still primarily a very talented creator of photographically derived abstract designs? The current exhibition at the Laurence Miller Gallery, 30 East 57th Street, through June 2, does not give a definitive answer to the question, but it does allow the question to be asked.

title: BRIDGE REPAIRS TO GET UNDER WAY SOON
description: THE General Assembly approved a massive infrastructure repair program only 11 days ago, but the State Department of Transportion is ready to seek bids for work on the first of the projects this week.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
EVERYDAY OBJECTS FROM ANCIENT ISRAEL
description: HELEN GORENSTEIN is a novelist who lives in New Jersey.

title: DUTCH UNREADY TO FULFILL MISSILE PLAN
description: The Dutch Government, buffeted by conflicting pressures on the issue, has concluded that it will be unable to go through with the deployment in 1986 of all 48 cruise missiles allotted to it by NATO, senior political officials said this week.

title: No Headline
description: The Market for Mothers Telephones are ringing, restaurants are full, florists are happy. This is Mother's Day, the work of Anna Jarvis, who began lobbying for such a celebration in 1907, and who is reputed to have been at odds with her own mother. If so, she may have been propelled by guilt - a feeling with which most of us are all too familiar. Who among the millions now toasting Mom doesn't have a little something to feel guilty about?

title: Martha A. Nairn to Become the Bride Of Seth M. Milliken 2d, an Executive
description: Announcement has been made by R. Frank Nairn of Guernsey, the Channel Islands, and Mary-Anna Nairn of Petworth, England, of the engagement of their daughter Martha Ann Nairn of New York to Seth M. Milliken 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Minot K. Milliken of New York and Hulls Cove, Me. The wedding is to take place Sept. 22.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: '' IT'S a long way, baby, from 'Mother of the Year' to the New Jersey Legislature,'' says Dolores G. Cooper of Atlantic City, who, at age 61, is serving her first full term as an Assemblywoman from Atlantic County.

title: FILIPINOS' QUANDARY: TO VOTE OR NOT TO VOTE
description: I have decided to boycott the legislative elections to be held here in the Philippines tomorrow precisely because I believe in democracy. We Filipinos have always been proud of the freedom and democracy we learned from the United States. But we in the boycott movement feel that this freedom and democracy has been distorted by the Marcos Government, and we have decided not to participate in a vote that we believe can only serve to prop up that tottering regime.

title: Texas Governor Seeks Tax Increase for Schools
description: Gov. Mark White is proposing a three- year tax package of $4.8 billion to pay for improvements in the state's education and highway systems.

title: DOES VOTER REGISTRATION CUT TWO WAYS?
description: With the assistance of space-age technology and techniques, the Republican parties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are employing an ancient election-year gambit that they have been reluctant to try before: registering people to vote.

title: A YOUNGER CHAUTAUQUA
description: JAMES FERON is chief of the Times bureau in Westchester County.

title: THE WORLD;
description: The Shootout In Tripoli

title: THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE HOME COURT
description: THE bad thing about the

title: Jeannette K. Woo, an Insurance Aide, And
description: Jeannette Katherine Woo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Chi-wen Woo of Guilford, Conn., and John Richard Eliasberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Eliasberg of Pikesville, Md., were married yesterday at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in New Haven by the Rev. William Randolph Robbins.

title:
AFTER THE I.B.M. CASE;
THE PRICE OF DROPPING THE ANTITRUST SUIT
description: MORE than two years have passed since William F. Baxter, the seventh antitrust chief on the case, turned his back on the Government's 13-year lawsuit against the International Business Machines Corporation. In so doing, he was decisive - but wrong. His decision has permitted I.B.M. freely to exert its enormous power throughout the industry.

title: Susan Dallas, Lawyer, Is a Bride in Bronxville
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday, Susan Mary Dallas, a daughter of Mrs. Kevin D. Dallas of Bronxville and the late Mr. Dallas, was married to Noel John Sterrett, the son of Jean Sterrett of Atlanta and the late John W. Sterrett. The Rev. George W. Rutler performed the ceremony.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ON AUG. 1, NJ Transit, the state's commuter transportation agency, will take over operating control of Pennsylvania Station in Newark from Amtrak, Governor Kean and other state officials announced last week. The move is seen as a key to the further redevelopment of Newark's downtown business district and as enhancing plans for the construction of a hotel and office complex near the station.

title: WOOING THE DESIGN TENANT
description: WHAT fruits and vegetables are to Hunts Point, streamlined architectural leather chairs and thousand dollar marble base Italian lamps are to the interior furnishing and design business in New York City.

title: FEET CARE: A YEAR-ROUND TASK
description: REVEALING SUMMER sandals highlight the need for year-round foot care. Yet the feet are often neglected until it is time to replace boots and shoes with scanty warm-weather footwear. Then, for a quick make-over, many women head to the pedicurist. Placing unswerving faith in soothing foot baths, glossy nail polish and pumice stones, they hope, in one miraculous hour, to undo the ills brought on by months of poorly fitted shoes, tight stockings, poor hygiene and lack of care.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: EDGEWATER
description: WHEN a pharmacy opened in Edgewater late last year, it was greeted with more than a few banners and a welcoming note from the local Chamber of Commerce. For in this municipality along the Hudson River directly across from upper Manhattan, a drugstore is an entirely new thing.

title: LOBBIES COMING BACK INTO THEIR OWN
description: IN the years following World War II, architects tended not to pay much attention to the process of getting into and out of office buildings. Prabably more time was spent in making sure the fire exits were right and visitors would pass through each and every day.

title: NEW YORK AREA GAINED 200,000 JOBS IN A YEAR
description: The number of people employed in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey region climbed by 200,000 in the year that ended last February, an unusually large gain.

title: Cosmos in Opener With 8 Newcomers
description: The Cosmos will open their North American Soccer League season today with a roster of eight new players and only nine remaining from the team that was eliminated in the first round of the playoffs last season.

title: THE NAME OF THE DISCIPLINE
description: John Sturrock is the editor of ''Structuralism and Since: From Levi-Strauss to Derrida.'' SEMIOTICS AND THE PHILOSOPHY OF LANGUAGE
