AFTER THE I.B.M.;
A CASE FOR KEEPING I.B.M. BIG
description: Those who lament the fact that the

title: THE NATION;
description: Feldstein Says He's Leaving, And Other Things

title: Jackson Campaign Told To Account for Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission has told the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign organization it is not complying with Federal laws requiring a detailed accounting of expenditures.

title: Miss Howard Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Howard, director of corporate public relations at the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation in New York, and Charles A. Schwefel, director of planning and development for the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Harold Eliott Barrett performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Ross Wright .

title: Not 'the First'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 'MADWOMAN'S' ENDURING CHARM
description: IT has been written that the endurance of the French dramatist Jean Giraudoux's plays is

title: MODERN SCIENCE VERSUS THE BURGLAR
description: IN the first office park Donald E. Axinn built in Jericho, L.I., in 1967, he recalls. ''We put a lock on the door and gave the tenants keys, and the cleaning people were responsible for locking the doors when they left at night.'' Tenants who wanted more security installed it at their own expense.

title: Panama's Candidates Challenge Vote Results
description: The head of Panama's Election Tribunal said today that more than half the results in last Sunday's presidential election had been challenged by rival candidates claiming fraud.

title: OFFICIALS OBJECT TO PLANS FOR NUCLEAR WASTE SHIPMENTS
description: FRESH from the conflict over nuclear planning at Indian Point, the county next week begins looking at a new challenge, the shipment of radioactive waste over its highways.

title: THE THRIVING POLYTECHNIC
description: WHILE British M.B.A. programs face a hesitant market and a questionable future, the nation's Polytechnic institutes have benefited from a growing demand for undergraduate and part-time business education.

title: Royalty Trusts
description: To the Editor:

title: D-DAY PLUS 40 YEARS
description: JOHN VINOCUR is the Paris bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: SHOWPIECE FOR BULGARIAN-AMERICANS
description: On weekends and in their free time after work, a dozen volunteers - including a psychiatrist, a building superintendent and a poet - have worked countless hours transforming a dilapidated church on the West Side of Manhattan into the showpiece of Bulgarian-American life in the New York metropolitan area.

title: MORE STATES CHAFE UNDER FEDERAL BITS
description: It is easy to see from here why the old issue of states rights is taking on new meaning. A triangle of land almost as large as the state of New York, embracing Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, San Antonio and Austin, is evolving into a giant economic and population complex far different from the older populous regions of the North and West. And like a number of other states, Texas wants more autonomy in shaping its growth. On several fronts, it has revolted against the national standards that have been imposed on almost every area of public life over the past few decades.

title: Anderson and
description: Younger Writers To The Editor:

title: Votes In Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: LEAGUE SHOWS FIVE ARTISTS' WORKS
description: WITH a sizable membership and limited gallery space in its new headquarters on Little Plains Road, the Huntington Township Art League, one of the Island's oldest and most active artists' organizations, is usually forced to restrict the size of entries submitted to its members' exhibitions. This can be a handicap for those who prefer to work on a more ample scale, so the league is making an effort to redress the imbalance with a show titled ''Members-at- Large,'' a selection of major canvases by five area painters.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SANTA FE
description: WILLIAM HART contributes to The New York Times from Santa Fe.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Lower long-distance rates mandated in a Federal Communications Commission order to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company marked the first in a promised series of sweeping phone rate changes. The 6.1 percent reduction will bring the rates of A.T.& T., with 94 percent of the market, more in line with its discount competitors, although MCI said it would end its monthly fees. The competitors received a break from the F.C.C. in the form of lower fees to connect to local networks. Other changes ordered by the F.C.C. will add to phone costs: Charges will be imposed for long-distance directory assistance and businesses with multiple lines.

title: A PREMIERE WINDS UP A GALA SEASON
description: THERE are five more chances to say happy anniversary to the Hartford Symphony this week before the end of the orchestra's expansive and exciting 40th anniversary season. The final Bushnell Hall subscription concerts are Tuesday and Wednesday at 8:15 P.M., with the renowned cellist Lynn Harrell as soloist in the Concerto No. 1 by Saint-Sa"ens, and the orchestra's music director, Arthur Winograd, conducting Beethoven's ''Eroica'' symphony. Also featured both evenings is the premiere of ''Cornet: A Tale of Love and Death'' commissioned from Earl Kim, the composer in residence at Harvard University, to mark the anniversary.

title: MUSIC: LAURIE ANDERSON AND TAPE-BOW VIOLIN
description: As Laurie Anderson has increasingly integrated live music into her performance art, her work has grown in richness and power. In the first show of a four-night engagement at the Beacon Theater Thursday, Miss Anderson used a musical ensemble that remained on stage much of the time.

title: CARTRIDGES THAT HONOR MUSIC
description: Don't draw conclusions exclusively from dinosaurs. In the course of evolution not all species die out after the arrival of some more recent model. Consider, for example, the peaceful coexistence of mankind with wombats and nightingales.

title: Don't Coax The Russians
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ENGLISH GARDENS WITH A U.S. FLAVOR
description: THE WORLD OF ENGlish landscape gardening is an area of enterprise as closed to outsiders as are the gardens within their protective walls. Yet, for more than 30 years, one American was able to penetrate the secret and sometimes sacred garden doors of England. That man was the late Lanning Roper.

title: 'WONDERFULLY TERRIBLE' WIRTERS DISCOVERED
description: The third annual competition to see who can write the worst possible opening sentence for a novel has produced entries even more deplorable than those last year, contest judges at San Jose State University say.

title: Miss Unger Weds David A. Kopitz
description: Victoria Regina Saroula Unger, a daughter of Mrs. Oliver A. Unger of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Unger, was married yesterday to David Allan Kopitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kopitz of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Data Bank; May 13, 1984
SAVING A THEATER
description: A 400-seat auditorium in the East Islip, L.I., junior high school building, now being converted to rental apartments, will be left intact by the developer so the Suffolk County community can have a small theater for live performances.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: In reviewing Broadway's revival of ''You Can't Take It With You'' last year, Frank Rich of The Times wrote that ''youre glad to be a part of the merriment.'' The critic cited the ''large, powerhouse cast'' as ''a family that almost anyone would want to adopt for far longer than three acts.''

title: NASA CURBING SPACE-FLIGHT MERCHANDISING
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is clamping down on the entrepreneurial spirit of Americans hoping to turn a profit on the space shuttle.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF

title: New & Noteworthy; SHIP OF FOOLS, by Katherine Anne Porter. (Atlantic/ Little Brown, $7.95.)
description: ''My book is about the constant endless collusion between good and evil; I believe that human beings are capable of total evil, but no one has ever been totally good: and this gives the edge to evil.'' Thus wrote Katherine Anne Porter about her first and last full-length novel, written over a period of 20 years and published in 1962 when she was 71. Basing the work on a 15th-century moral allegory, the distinguished short story writer drew on her impressions of her first trans-Atlantic voyage in the early 1930's for an analogy with our own times. Though it provoked controversy among the critics, the novel had the full approval of our reviewer, Mark Schorer: ''Her perfectly poised ironical intelligence is constant and in complete authority. . . . As in any great work of art, something larger is in the air and we know we are in another ship as well, another voyage, sailing to another harbor.''

title: THE UNEASINESS BETWEEN BLACKS AND UNION LEADERS
description: When the executives of the A.F.L.-C.I.O convened here last week to talk politics, their mood was one of subdued self-congratulation. Even after Walter F. Mondale lost Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday, the labor political director, John Perkins, consoled himself that union voters stayed with the former Vice President by a comfortable margin. The feeling was that union members have by and large delivered for the labor federation's candidate. But one group of union members has not. According to New York Times/CBS News exit polls, black union members have overwhelmingly voted for the Rev. Jesse Jackson. In Illinois, Pennsylvania, New York, and now Ohio - union strongholds all - they, like blacks at large, have turned out for Mr. Jackson. In so doing, they have aligned themselves with a candidate who has on occasion poked fun at the organized labor establishment. In a favorite Jackson metaphor, labor is one of the institutional ''old wine skins'' that should be making room for ''new wine.'' He has faulted unions for being slow to pute blacks into leadership positions, saying, ''A black or a woman will clearly be President of this country before one will even be able to run for head of the A.F.L.- C.I.O.'' He has charged that when unions control the gateway to employment - as they do in the building trades, where employers commonly muster their manpower at the union hall for each project - they have protected white workers at the expense of young blacks entering the workforce.

But it was a perfect little thing as danced by Robert La Fosse Thursday, when the Twyla Tharp work was presented by the American Ballet Theater in the Metropolitan Opera House. This was such an understated and fluent and bravura performance that it was hard to imagine anyone else dancing the role. And considering the fact that the role was created by Mikhail Baryshnikov, that is quite an achievement.

title: LAY OFF COSTA RICA
description: Costa Rica is being ensnared in the widening Central American war. Border clashes with Nicaragua combined with considerable pressure from the State Department are pushing this small democracy, which boasts a unique history of civilian government and neutrality, to take sides and fight against its neighbors. In this, the Reagan Administration is pursuing an ill-considered and ultimately self- defeating policy that threatens to destroy the only truly stable and democratic enclave in Central America.

The fire did $2,000 worth of damage.

title: LIFE OF ERNIE KOVACS IS PORTRAYED
description: FOR all of his zaniness, there was something curiously distant about Ernie Kovacs. As a comedian, he inhabited his own intensely private little world, avoiding both the traditional standup patter of a Bob Hope or the contemporary-neurosis catalogues of a Woody Allen. He did his routines with a seemingly total disregard for structure. Scripts were mere hindrances. He seemed to be constantly preoccupied, not even caring whether or not a routine got a laugh.

title: Futures/Options; Amex Widens Index Contract
description: THE American Stock Exchange, in an effort to

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Finance/New Issues column in Business Day Friday incorrectly quoted a spokesman for the Charter Company in explaining why the company had rejected a $20 million loan. He said the loan ''was not in the company's best interest.''

title: SIMPSON-MAZZOLI PENALTY FOR LAW-ABIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEWIS FAILS IN BID FOR RECORD
description: The three red flags brought a collective groan from the spectators, and Carl Lewis, sensing he was on center stage, spread his arms and stared at the ground as if wondering what had gone wrong.

title: BORROWERS AND LENDERS HUNT SOLUTION TO LATIN DEBT CRISIS
description: Almost overnight, the plight of the Latin American economies, where most of the third world debt is concentrated, has produced a frenzy of conferences, speeches, hearings in Congress and globe-hopping trips of dignitaries searching for solutions. It is more activity even than in the fall of 1982, when concern sprouted over Mexico's debts.

title: QADDAFI ASSAILANT IS REPORTED KILLED
description: Libyan forces have tracked down and killed the leader of the attack last week on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's barracks, the Government said today. About 10,000 Libyans gathered in the capital in a rally to show support for the Libyan leader.

title: Brown Wins Eastern Rowing
description: Brown took all the varsity heavyweight rowing honors today at the 39th Eastern Sprint Championships on Lake Quinsigamond.

title: A TRIBUTE TO MOTHERS AT SHELTER
description: As Mother's Day celebrations go, this one was simple and private and more poignant than it was joyous. What made it important for the women and children who attended was that it had happened at all. The ritual of the holiday had been observed.

title: Johns Hopkins Gets Top Seed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday seeded Johns Hopkins No. 1 for the Division I lacrosse championship tournament.

title: SURGING ORIOLES TOP A'S,5-1
description: Wayne Gross drove in five runs with a single and a homer today, leading the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-1 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: No Headline
description: Supermedicine, Supermoney It's the ultimate X-ray machine, harnessing magnetism and radio waves to create images of the body's internal organs, and it's fast becoming high fashion in the world of medical technology. To health economists, however, it's a source of high anxiety because its stunning pictures also mean stunning increases in hospital costs.

title: THE VIEW FROM SYRIA
description: What could improve relations between Syria and the United States? I asked Abdel Halim Khaddam, vice president in charge of foreign affairs. He answered: ''Very simply, the United States should follow an

title: No Headline
description: CORRECTIONS

title: Right Name, Wrong Number
description: Michael Jackson's telephone hasn't

title: PERILS OF LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: They used to be called bootstrap financings. Now they are known as leveraged buyouts, and they have become more popular in recent months. But some people fear that the buyouts may carry the seeds of the corporate world's next big bust.

title: Vermont Democratic Party May Send Jackson Delegate
description: Vermont Democrats may be allowed to send at least one delegate supporting the Rev. Jesse Jackson to the San Francisco convention, even though he did not receive enough support in the caucuses to qualify for national delegates, state party officials say.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Chiat, Ogilvy Top Winners

title: DAUNTING JOB FOR DUARTE
description: As President of El Salvador, Jose Napoleon Duarte will have to balance his own ideas of democracy and increasing the power of the civilian Government with the task of calming suspicions held by some private citizens and the armed forces that his efforts will rob them of wealth and power.

title: STAGE: 'COURAGE' BY JOHN PEILMEIER
description: JOHN PIELMEIER'S ''Courage'' is a charming and often moving play about J. M. Barrie, who wrote ''Peter Pan'' 80 years ago. Paul Collins portrays the Scottish playwright looking back at the high moments of his life.

title: The National Chorale In American Tribute
description: The National Chorale Soloists paid tribute to the rich diversity of American vocal music in their Friday evening concert at St. Peter's Church. Entitled ''America Sings,'' the program featured the colonial era counterpoint of William Billings, several eloquent part songs by Samuel Barber, a selection of theater music by Stephen Sondheim, and a setting of vernacular American songs by Aaron Copland.

title: ELECTION'S FAIRNESS AT ISSUE IN PHILIPPINE VOTING TODAY
description: In the election Monday for the Philippine National Assembly, the integrity of the election process itself appears to be the key issue and the focus of attention at home and abroad.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Glubok Team Rallies to Win The Grand National Teams

title: PRICE OF A CLEANER HARBOR: THE MARINE BORER
description: As one unwanted resident of New York harbor, pollution, has begun to disappear, another, the marine borer, has begun to reappear.

title: Europe's Factories In Space'
description: When Prof. Luigi Napolitano, an Italian physicist, lectured here recently on manufacturing in outer space, he began by recalling all the famous scientists who had said that trans-Atlantic air travel, television and space flight were impossible dreams.

title: Lance and Jackson Meet in California
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met here today with Bert Lance, chairman of the Georgia Democratic Party, before opening his drive for votes in California's June 5 primary. The meeting took place at Mr. Jackson's request, Mr. Lance said.

title: THE CHANGING LIVES OF DENIS POTVIN
description: ''the player and the real person'' - says the man who happens to be both, ''and they haven't met yet.''

title: CELTICS RESPOND TO PRESSURE
description: It has been nearly two years since the Boston Celtics have faced the pressure of a seventh and deciding game in playoff competition. The scene was the same, here in the famed Boston Garden. The opponents were the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Washington Watch; Reconciling Tax Increases
description: WASHINGTON THE tax writers in Congress may not be

title: A NEW LIFE FOR DEVIL'S BAG, BUT THE MYSTERY LINGERS
description: DEVIL'S BAG stopped short and looked straight ahead at the race track, which was silent and empty now that training hours were over. It was Saturday morning on the backstretch at Churchill Downs, and the colt had been walked from his stall in Barn 41 almost up to the gap in the rail on the backstretch, the spot where horses leave the stable area when they go to the races.

title: STAGE:'DANCE OF DEATH' AT C.S.C.
description: THE person who has never before seen August Strindberg's turn-of-the-century play ''Dance of Death'' may feel a little tentative about it all when it begins to unfold in the recently reopened East 13th Street house of C.S.C.: City Stage Co. There is a dusty, mysterious light that enfolds the stage and the audience that surrounds it on three sides. On stage, a woman sits nervously on one seat and a man sprawls slackly on another. What, indeed, is up?

title: HART SAID TO HAVE EDGE OVER MONDALE IN NEBRASKA
description: This is a state that likes Ernest Hollings for President.

title: RepairsDisruptService On No. 1 Subway Line
description: The Transit Authority is providing free transfers every weekend through June 3 from the No. 1 subway line to M104 buses to permit structural repairs to the Broadway IRT tracks.

title: Joan Emery Is Married T D E R
description: Joan Emery, a project director for the Coalition for the Medical Rights of Women and the California Abortion Rights Action League, both in San Francisco, was married yesterday to Dr. Edward M. Rubin, a member of the medical genetics group at the University of California at San Francisco, where he is a molecular biophysicist with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch performed the ceremony in the Manhattan apartment of the bride's grandparents, Dr. and Mrs. Fritz Landshoff.

title: ;  Insurance Worries
description: The remarkable increase in lap speeds at Indianapolis during practice for this year's 500 may be the major topic of conversation at the Speedway, but the $20 million award made to the heirs of the former 500 winner Mark Donohue by a jury last month in Providence, R.I., has spread a note of uncertainty through American motor sports.

title: Sri Lankan Kidnappers Say U.S. Couple is Safe
description: Tamil separatists who kidnapped an American couple reported them still safe today but reiterated that the two would be killed on Monday unless the kidnappers' demands were met.

title: SIDE BY SIDE: UNIONS AND ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Aide at White House In Congressional Post
description: Dan C. Roberts, a former White House economic aide who has just been named executive director of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, thinks it will be ''very interesting'' to work at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Casino Strikers Accuse Nevada Officials of Bias
description: Union leaders accused the Governor and the District Attorney today of being on management's side in the 42- day strike against two dozen Las Vegas casinos.

title: Sluggish Cosmos Win, 1 to 0
description: The Cosmos defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 1-0, in their North American Soccer League opener before 21,385 at Giants Stadium this afternoon. But the new version of the Cosmos, resembled nothing of past teams.

title: Letter: On Garbage Disposal
description: Get Going on Trash-Burning Guidelines

title: Conrail Chief Critical on Bids
description: L. Stanley Crane, chairman and chief executive officer of Conrail, ending months of silence concerning the possible merger of his railroad, said a combination with either of two competitors would mean a loss of jobs and the abandonment of track.

title: Election Material Sealed After Fraud Is Charged
description: A Baltimore judge has ordered voting machines, authorization cards and other election material from five Baltimore precincts sealed in response to a suit by the campaign for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., a Democrat Presidential candidate.

title: POLAND AND 11 PRISONERS STILL AT IMPASSE
description: An effort by the authorities to persuade a group of key figures in the banned Solidarity labor union to leave jail fell apart over the weekend when they rejected the Government's latest offer, dissident sources said today.

title: Accused Spy Tells of U.S. Plot
description: Richard Craig Smith, an accused spy, says he passed American military secrets to a K.G.B. officer in Japan as part of a clandestine operation by the Central Intelligence Agency to infiltrate Soviet intelligence.

title: OF C.I.A. GAMES AND DISPUTED RULES
description: They are keepers of secrets on Capitol Hill, the members of the House and Senate intelligence committees, and they are becoming increasingly perturbed. The Central Intelligence Agency is playing games with them, they say, sometimes deliberately misleading them and preventing them from fulfilling their responsibilities.

title: STAGE: O'HARA'S PAL JOEY' PRESENTED
description: WHEN John O'Hara's cynical but straightforward presentation in ''Pal Joey'' of the quid pro quo sexual relations of a sleazy self-serving nightclub singer and dancer, and a hard, experienced woman of acquired wealth was first presented in 1940, there was some strong critical reservations about the subject matter. The most notable was Brooks Atkinson's ''Can You Draw Sweet Water From a Foul Well?'' an opinion he revised 12 years later when the show returned to Broadway in a triumphant revival.

title: REDS' STREAK ENDS
description: George Hendrick drove in two runs with a homer and a sacrifice fly and the pitcher John Stuper singled home a run as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 6-2, today to snap the Reds' six-game winning streak.

title: BARKLEY IS CUT IN U.S. BASKETBALL TRIALS
description: Four more players, including Charles Barkley of Auburn, were cut today from the list of candidates seeking a spot on the United States men's Olympic basketball team.

title: When Ketchup Was More Than a Condiment
description: There was a time when ketchup and

title: DRAMA: ONE-ACTPLAYS AT COLONNADES
description: -act plays, written by Bill Harris and Pearl Cleage, intersect at the corner where cheerfulness meets despair. A project of the National Black Touring Circuit, both plays confront the black experience in marriage and careers. Despite moments of laughter, both end as sadly as the latest sociological report on broken homes. One might dispute the artistry of the playwrights but not their accuracy.

title: Celia Colbert Is a Bride
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday Celia A. Colbert and Frederick J. Watts, 1982 graduates of the Columbia University School of Law, were married by the Rev. Ann Redding.

title: U.S. LEADS IN SALE OF ARMS ABROAD
description: The United States was the world's leading exporter of weapons to developing countries in 1983, according to a new study by the Congressional Research Service.

title: Women in Politics See a Very Good Year
description: Nineteen eighty-four looks as

title: CONTINENTAL AIR'S GAINS AND FEARS
description: Continental Air Lines is apparently winning its struggle to prove its long- term viability despite strikes by pilots and other unions and the distractions of trying to reorganize under the bankruptcy law.

title: DAY CARE FOR THOSE OVER 60
description: When the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged began its pioneering geriatric day-care program for residents of the Bronx 10 years ago, it faced an uphill battle. Skeptics said prospective participants were too frail and belonged in institutions. Other people had trouble with the term ''day care.''

title: ISLANDERS SHOWING COMEBACK ABILITYZ
description: It is not that the Islanders are lazy, Coach Al Arbour suggested today, trying to explain why his team seems obsessed with bad beginnings and great comebacks.

title: Candidate for SenateLeaves Race in Virginia
description: Edythe Harrison's sole rival for the Democratic Senate nomination from Virginia has dropped out of the race, virtually assuring her of the chance to challenge Senator John W. Warner, a Republican, in November.

title: OLYMPIC BOYCOTT IS CALLED FIRM
description: The Soviet Union appears unlikely to reverse its decision to boycott the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, United States and Soviet officials said today.

title: Advertising; Gillette's Return to The Brush
description: REMEMBER the shaving brush and soap? Perhaps many of the 55 million so-called ''wet shavers'' do. But about 83 percent of them use aerosol shaving products instead, among other alternatives.

title: PUBLICITY IS ISSUE IN DELOREAN CASE
description: A prosecutor in the trial of John Z. DeLorean on charges of trafficking in cocaine stood before the judge one day last week and complained that, as he put it, ''the defense has a press conference every day'' on the courthouse steps.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOUSING CALL What inspires art? Everything of course, from vases to violence, from war to love. But the exhibition now on view in the sixth-floor Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street (691- 1660), was prompted by that most prevalent quest of the New Yorker: apartments.

title: ;  Training Diet
description: The 200 runners who are part of the entourage accompanying the Olympic torch on its 8,700-mile, 82-day journey from New York to Los Angeles are all experienced athletes, but the company that is providing them meals during the run decided they could use some special nutritional advice.

title: DALAI LAMA UNSURE ABOUT TIBET VISIT
description: Now that he has lived in exile for 25 years, the Dalai Lama of Tibet says he is having second thoughts about even a short visit to his Chinese-ruled homeland, although plans are under way for him to return briefly in 1985.

title: ALFRED ANTENUCCI
description: Alfred Antenucci, a labor union official who helped Secret Service agents capture John W. Hinckley Jr. after President Reagan was shot in 1981, died Wednesday, eight days after he apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: Author, Author
description: Book signings are nearly as commonplace as books, but on Wednesday Donald E. Westlake will be signing four new books from three different publishers written under two names.

title: FABRIC LAMINATE RIDES FASHION WAVE
description: It began one October night 15 years ago when a chemical engineer, experimenting in his laboratory, yanked a bit of preheated Teflon, a coating material developed by Du Pont and used in cookware and electrical insulators. Instead of snapping, the Teflon stretched the full length of the engineer's extended arms.

title: 17 Are Freed in Angola, 80 Days After Abduction
description: An ordeal that began with their kidnapping 80 days ago ended today for 16 British men and a Portuguese woman as they shook hands with the Angolan guerrillas who had held them captive and started their journey home.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Credithrift Financial Corp. of Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of American General Corp., filed a shelf offering of $400 million in senior and/ or subordinated debt securities.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many major league baseball players have had more walks than hits for a season? Which player came closest to getting as many walks as he had hits?

title: 4 TO SHARE $22.1 MILLION LOTTO JACKPOT
description: Popping the bubble of suspense, New York State Lottery officials announced yesterday that four people - all as yet anonymous - had beaten 3.5 million-to-1 odds and would share a $22.1 million Lotto jackpot, the richest lottery strike ever made in North America.

title: ON FAULTING NONEXISTENT REHABILITATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Illness Kills 252 Children As It Spreads in Brazil
description: A disease that may be caused by a virus has killed 252 young children in two weeks in this impoverished city and is spreading to nearby towns, local health officials said today.

title: Market Place; Chartist Sees Summer Rally
description: THE current market ''is much better than it

title: AFTERMATH OF JERSEY FIRE: SCHOOL MOURNS THE DEAD
description: David Barriera changed his mind at the last minute about going on his school trip to the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park. He decided to take the money he had saved and go shopping for new clothes instead.

title: RobertWedsJane Goldschmidt
description: Jane Helen Goldschmidt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goldschmidt of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Warren Hassler, a son of Howard Edward Hassler of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Gina Jaspar of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg at the Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Beirut Fighting Raises Weekend Deaths to 19

title: ;  People
description: * Robert H. Cherins elected an executive vice president, and Bruce Kramer and Steven M. Bernstein senior vice presidents at McCaffrey & McCall.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 14, 1984: MONDAY Colonial Penn GrpPitney-BowesFlorida Pwr & Lt

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate, Culver City, Calif., a software publisher, has appointed Frank Murnane vice president of finance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 14, 1984

title: An Ailing Gymnast Getting 2d Chance
description: The men's program committee of the United States Gymnastics Federation approved today a request by Bart Conner, a two-time Olympian, to participate in the Olympic trials June 1 in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: IT'S FOR YOU, CLARKIE
description: M OST people call their mothers on Mother's Day, but Clark Gillies's mother beat him to the draw Saturday night, an hour before it officially became Mother's Day on Long Island and three hours before Mother's Day back in Saskatchewan.

title: AT 15, THE PADRES COME OF AGE
description: SAN DIEGO K EVIN McREYNOLDS and Carmelo Martinez wince if someone as much as whispers the phrase ''M and M.''

title:
PRESS NOTES;
STUDY IS CRITICAL OF SOME SCIENCE NEWS SOURCES
description: If news organizations exaggerate the health risks of new diseases, nuclear power accidents or toxic waste spills, the fault is probably in their sources of information, not their ways of operating, according to a recent study conducted for the Twentieth Century Fund.

title: MCENROE BEATS LENDL IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe, playing so well that he turned the final with Ivan Lendl into a mismatch, remained undefeated in 1984 and captured the $100,000 first prize in the Mercedes Tournament of Champions yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

title: A NIGERIAN GOVERNMENT LOOKING TO THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubans Said to Arrive From Central America
description: More and more Cuban refugees are immigrating illegally to Florida from Central America, United States immigration officials say.

title: BRIEFING
description: Defense Dept. Departures

title: OPERA: SOPRANO IN DEBUT IN 'NABUCCO' BY VERDI
description: OPERA fans do not have the chance very often to demonstrate in favor of a major new voice, but that opportunity came for them last night at Carnegie Hall, where Ghena Dimitrova made her New York debut as Abigaille in a concert version of ''Nabucco.'' To say they seized the chance enthusiastically would be less than precise. They bellowed and stomped until the floorboards rocked.

title: CLAUDIO ARRAU PERFORMS IN CHILE TRIUMPHANTLY
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau stood with his head bent and hands over his heart for a long moment Saturday night as the roar from the standing audience swept over him. After 17 years' absence from his native Chile, the maestro, tears in his eyes, had returned home.

title: Trumans' Home Is Dedicated As Part of U.S. Park Service
description: The home in which Harry S. Truman and his wife, Bess, spent much of their life together has been dedicated as the 334th unit of the National Park Service.

title: URANIUM LEFTOVERS DUG OUT IN WEST
description: Slowly and expensively, Federal and state agencies have begun to trace and clean up homes and properties that were contaminated by radioactive waste in the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Audit Urges Shift InCourtTransport
description: The Correction Department pays $750,000 a year for overtime because of an unnecessary court order that requires it to transport all inmates who are scheduled for a court appearance by 9:30 A.M. the day of the appearance, an audit has concluded.

title: METHODISTS' CONFERENCE: SOME SIGNS OF A REBIRTH
description: Two hundred years after Methodists gathered here to organize a new church, delegates to the United Methodist General Conference appeared to experience something of a badly needed rebirth. The signs of uplift were modest and undramatic, but most delegates agreed that the tone and substance of the conference could portend better days for the beleaguered, 9.4-million-member church.

title: Boxer Conscious
description: The Filipino junior lightweight boxer Bell Torino, who fell into a coma after being knocked out in a fight here Sunday, regained consciousness today, according to a spokesman for Sunchonhyang Hospital. The spokesman said Torino is expected to recover fully. He was floored in the eighth round by Choi Chin-shik of South Korea.

title: MONDAY, MAY 14, 1984 International
description: Covert action in Central America was defended by President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, who said such action was increasingly necessary to give the United States an alternative between going to war and doing nothing when a friendly nation is under attack. He gave one of the strongest Administration justifications for actions carried out in Central America under the supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency. (Page A1, Column 6.) Latin America's troubled economies, where most of the third world debt is concentrated, have produced a frenzy of concern almost overnight. The sense of urgency rose last week when the prime lending rate in the United States was raised to 12 1/2 percent. Some Federal officials and bankers expect significant steps on the debt problem to take effect soon, in weeks or months. (A1:1.)

title: Seabrook Utilities Weigh Refinancing
description: Sixteen New England utilities decide Monday whether to adopt a refinancing plan to save the Seabrook nuclear project and possibly prevent its chief owner from going bankrupt.

title: THE DANCE: MET OPERA GALA
description: MOST people will tell you a centennial comes along only every hundred years. But if you're the Metropolitan Opera, you celebrate your hundredth birthday twice.

title: THE PAST STILL SHADOWS MARRIAGES IN INDIA
description: The young women of India, some of them, may be wearing blue jeans these days or dancing the night away at discoth eques, smoking in public, dating, eyeing strange men and defying Indian convention in other ways.

title: Bangladesh Ruler Postpones Elections
description: The Government today postponed parliamentary and presidential elections, which had been scheduled for May 27.

title: ;  Ford Executive Named President of Credit Unit
description: Stanley A. Seneker has been elected president of the Ford Motor Credit Corporation, the financing arm of the Ford Motor Company.

title: NEOCONSERVATIVES ASSESS POLITICAL TRENDS AND FOREIGN POLICY
description: ''We're all pro-American and hawkish,'' said Midge Decter, executive director of the Committee for the Free World, describing the 200 people who met here this weekend to discuss such questions as ''What's Going on Out There?'' and ''Can the Political System Respond?''

title: BREAKERS DEFEAT PANTHERS
description: Johnnie Walton used a controlled passing game to account for 120 yards and a touchdown today to lead the New Orleans Breakers past the Michigan Panthers, 10-3.

title: A RUSH FOR SINGERS TO PROMOTE GOODS
description: At the Hard Rock Cafe on West 57th Street last week, Canada Dry U.S.A. announced its sponsorship of the 40-city concert tour by Rod Stewart, the rock singer. It was a deal negotiated by Jay Coleman, the 34-year-old president and founder of Rockbill, a seven- year-old music marketing company with $5 million in revenues.

title: Trade Surplus Wider in Japan
description: Japan's trade surplus widened in April to $3.1 billion, from $2 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A television review May 2 of the ''Complete Gilbert and Sullivan'' on Channel 13 incorrectly attributed the libretto of ''Cox and Box.'' It is by F. C. Burnand.

title: Julie Renee Grob Is Married to Andrew N. Shapiro
description: Julie Renee Grob, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Grob of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Andrew N. Shapiro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Shapiro of New York. Rabbi Lawrence Kotok performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Club in Roslyn, L.I.

title: HARLEM CENTER LOSES STANDING IN ORTHOPEDICS
description: The orthopedic training program at the Harlem Hospital Center, a large municipal institution, has lost its accreditation on the ground that its instruction in surgical skills is inadequate.

title: KEY RABBI REPORTED ARRESTED IN ISRAELI TERROR INVESTIGATION
description: Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a leader of the movement to build Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, was arrested today by police investigating a Jewish terrorist ring, Israeli radio and television broadcasts reported.

title: STADLER CAPTURES NELSON BY STROKE
description: Leading by four strokes when the day's play started, Craig Stadler shot par 71 today to earn a one-stroke victory in the Byron Nelson Classic over David Edwards, who closed with a 65.

title: ARTISTS' FAVORITE STUDY: CENTRAL PARK IN SPRING
description: Artists have been popping up among the statues by the Central Park Mall. Sketchers have been migrating along upper Fifth Avenue. A painter's palette has been seen floating across the Lake in Central Park near West 76th Street.

title: SEABROOK RESCUE BID APPROVED
description: Owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant today unanimously approved a plan that they said should save Seabrook's first reactor and avert bankruptcy for the plant's main owner.

title: City's New Bond Offer Carries Rise in Yield
description: Rising interest rates in the Treasury securities market have spilled over into the tax-exempt bond market, leading to higher yields at this week's $250 million offering of New York City bonds compared with a similar sale three months ago.

title: NIEKRO WINS 6TH
description: The Yankees' most reliable asset this season, Phil Niekro, and their most unused one, Omar Moreno, gathered forces last night and produced a 3-1 victory over the Oakland A's at the Stadium.

title: OPERA: SOPRANO'S DEBUT IN 'NABUCCO'
description: OPERA fans do not have the chance very often to demonstrate in favor of a major new voice, but that opportunity came for them Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, where Ghena Dimitrova made her New York debut as Abigaille in a concert version of ''Nabucco.'' To say they seized the chance enthusiastically would be less than precise. They bellowed and stomped until the floorboards rocked.

title: THE TIELESS MILTON PETRIE
description: MILTON PETRIE knows the score, and he knows when he is being softened up. At a recent dinner, a major hospital president hurried forward to greet him. ''Stop worrying,'' Mr. Petrie told the startled official, ''I'm sending you a million.'' And, of course, he will.

title: MET OPERA GALA HONORS PERFORMING ARTS
description: MOST people will tell you a centennial comes along only every hundred years. But if you're the Metropolitan Opera, you celebrate your hundredth birthday twice.

title: MISS BELLAMY TRADES CHARGES WITH KOCH OVER SCHOOL SUPPORT
description: Mayor Koch and Council President Carol Bellamy traded accusations yesterday over who was more committed to the public school system.

title: Yamani View On British Oil
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, was quoted today by the Middle East Economic Survey as saying he was disappointed by a recent increase in Britain's output of crude oil.

title: Advertising; Western Union's Easylink
description: ELECTRONIC mail is one of the computer revolution buzzwords that excite communications giants. ''The guy who gets out there first gets the lion's share'' of the business, said Richard F. O'Brien, executive vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the agency handling the account for one of those giants, the Western Union Corporation.

title: PHILS, ON 3 IN NINTH, DOWN DODGERS, 3-2
description: -Len Matuszek, a pinch-hitter, was hit by a pitch with the bases loaded to force home the deciding run as Philadlphia struck for three runs in the ninth inning tonight and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2. It was the Phillies' fourth straight victory.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV SPORTS ; THE KNICKS' ANNOUNCERS
description: Despite what happened to the Knicks in Boston on Sunday, their game on Friday night in Madison Square Garden was memorable on several counts.

title: Mrs. Kennedy Returns Home
description: Rose Kennedy, the 93-year-old matriarch of the Kennedy family, was flown Sunday to the family compound here, a family spokesman said. Mrs. Kennedy, who spent the winter in Palm Beach, Fla., was accompanied on the plane by her son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy; a daughter, Jean Smith; a granddaughter, Sidney Lawford McKelvey; two nurses, and a doctor, said Edward Martin, a spokesman for the Senator. ''She's much more comfortable at home,'' Mr. Martin said.

title: COLUMBIA SAID TO ALTER HARLEM HOSPITAL STAND
description: City hospital officials said yesterday that Columbia University, under criticism for the medical care at Harlem Hospital Center, was prepared to start sharing its responsibilities at Harlem with Presbyterian Hospital.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: THE ESSENCE OF LIFE
description: Jacob K. Javits was always the public person - married to his work, serious, single-minded - but in three and a half decades in government office, he rarely let his private self show, he didn't let his public get close to the man.

title: GIANT PORTLAND MASONRY & CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMMONWEALTH FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,126,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-There are no year-ago per share figures because the bank went public in April 1983. Results for the latest periods include nonrecurring gains of $2,258,000 for the quarter and $2,901,000 for the year from the sale of mortgage- backed bonds. Year-ago results include nonrecurring gains of $25,000 for the quarter and $3,385,000 for the year from the sale of mortgage-backed bonds.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS A SPECIAL INQUIRY INTO '80 CAMPAIGN
description: A Federal district judge ordered Attorney General William French Smith today to seek an independent counsel to investigate possible crimes by top officials in the transfer of documents to the 1980 Presidential campaign of Ronald Reagan from the Carter White House.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Foote, Cone Earnings Up Sharply in Quarter

title: No Headline
description: Enterprise Zones Deserve a Test The Senate has passed a tax bill that authorizes subsidies for 75 ''enterprise zones'' in depressed areas. The long nourished hope is that Federal tax relief might encourage industrial expansion where jobs are most needed.

title: ;  Toys 'R' Us to Grey
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., a specialty toy retail chain, named Grey Advertising Inc. as its advertising agency.

title: ARNOLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Anti-Gun Lobby Lists Pro-Gun Contributions
description: A group that lobbies for tougher gun laws says Senate Judiciary Committee members, who last week voted to ease the nation's gun control law, received $171,334 in campaign help from the pro- gun lobby.

title: U.S. COUPLE MAY BE RELEASED
description: A Sri Lankan official said today that the kidnappers of an American couple had announced they would release their captives, but hundreds of police and military troops failed to find the Americans.

title: Business and the Law; A Broad Field For Libel Suits
description: WASHINGTON MENTION the word ''libel'' and most people think of publishers and broadcasters. But businesses outside the news media often find themselves named as defendants in libel suits.

title: ;  Son Succeeds Father As Best Products' Head
description: Andrew M. Lewis, 38, has been named to succeed his father, Sydney Lewis, as chairman and chief executive officer of the Best Products Company.

title: Pennsylvannia Court Rejects Idea of a Single-Sex Divorce
description: The state Superior Court ruled today that people of the same sex could not contract a common law marriage, and thus were not eligible to divorce.

title: Carter Has a New Grandson
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has a new grandson. Jeffrey and Annette Carter became the parents of a boy, their first child, on May 8, Fairfax Hospital in suburban Virginia disclosed today.

title: FASHION AT MIDNIGHT: A 'LIVELY ART' OF THE MET
description: Sunday evening started with springlike weather, and out came the new party dresses. The women were in chiffons and silks, sequins and feathers - nobody really believed the night would include a downpour.

title: KEG RESTAURANTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CABANAS LETS EASY CHANCE SLIP AWAY
description: Several minutes earlier, the

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit $55,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Bridge column May 9 about the Long Island Regional Championships in Hempstead misidentified one of the two Flight B Pairs winners. He is Leonard Helfgott of Teaneck, N.J.

title: HOUSING OFFICIAL DEFENDS REMARKS
description: A Reagan Administration official sought today to explain his comments about the housing preferences of Hispanic Americans as Democrats criticized him for perpetuating ethnic stereotypes.

title: Basques Bomb Spanish Boat
description: A bomb planted below the waterline blew up a Spanish Navy launch today, killing a seaman, naval officials said. Telephone callers to newspapers said the bomb was planted by a previously unknown Basque guerrilla group, which called itself Ataska.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush and Mrs. Gandhi Hold Talks in New Delhi
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi met Vice President Bush today and was reported to have complained that United States arms sales to Pakistan could lead to a regional arms race.

title: ;  Lehman Corp. Manager Joins Rothschild Asset
description: The effects of the takeover of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. by Shearson/American Express, which was completed Friday, are beginning to reverberate through the executive suite.

title: Nielsen Retires
description: Gifford Nielsen said yesterday that he was retiring as a quarterback for the Houston Oilers to become the sports director at a Houston television station. The 29-year-old Nielsen, who played six years for the Oilers, said his decision was not the result of the club's signing Warren Moon , the former Canadian Football League star who is regarded as the leading candidate for the starting quarterback job next season.

title: THE TOUGHEST YEAR FOR JERRY MARTIN
description: SAN FRANCISCO As he went about his clubhouse routines in recent days, Jerry Martin paused periodically, turned to whoever was listening and repeated, almost like a mantra, ''It's just around the corner now.''

title: CONSERVATIVE PARISH DEFIES A BISHOP ON REVISED EPISCOPAL PRAYER BOOK
description: A dispute over the use of the Episcopal Church's revised Book of Common Prayer has expanded into a liturgical and legal argument here between the Bishop of Colorado and an old Denver parish that is resisting the change.

title: City Hall Will Get A Metal Detector
description: A metal detector and a fluoroscope will be installed as security measures at City Hall, officials said yesterday.

title: FAULTY STROBE CITED IN FIRE FATAL TO 8
description: A fire that killed eight people and injured seven Friday night in a haunted house attraction at an amusement park here was started by a malfunctioning strobe light used to create an eerie scene, officials said tonight.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT'S not enough for fashion designers to present new collections and

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Genetic Sciences, Greenwich, Conn., an agricultural genetic- engineering company, has appointed Anthony G. Markert chief financial officer.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $41,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $20,981,000 from the disposal of an affiliate. c-Includes income of $410,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MARCOS FOES TAKE EARLY VOTING LEAD
description: Scattered early returns from the parliamentary elections Monday showed foes of President Ferdinand E. Marcos running ahead of Government candidates in both metropolitan Manila and in the provinces.

title: Explosion in Athens Leaves 53 Injured
description: Fifty-three people were injured, 10 of them seriously, by a powerful explosion in the crowded city center of Athens today, the Athens News Agency quoted police officials as saying.

title: Taiwan Nuclear Plant
description: Taiwan plans to build its fourth nuclear power plant at a cost of $4.3 billion, the chairman of the state-owned Taiwan Power Company said today. Chen Lan-kuo, the company's chairman, said bids from companies in the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Canada and Japan would be invited for the project, which is to have a generating capacity of 2 million kilowatts. The plant is scheduled for completion in 1994.

title: Unilever Net Rises by 20%
description: Unilever, the food products and consumer goods conglomerate, said today that profits in the first quarter rose 20 percent, to $131 million, from the period a year ago.

title: INTERNATIONAL TOTALIZATOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income after a tax credit of $86,000.

title: MX MISSILE FACES ANOTHER TEST IN CONGRESS
description: After more than a decade of technical development and perhaps the most controversy over any modern weapon, the Air Force's MX strategic missile is once again a hot political issue in Congress.

title: Borman Contract
description: Eastern Airlines' directors offered a five-year contract today to Frank Borman, its chairman, and he is expected to accept it, a company spokesman said.

title: Jackson's 485th Is Over the Roof
description: American League batters have hit the ball over the roof of the right-field stands at Tiger Stadium in Detroit only 16 times. Perhaps the most famous shot was by Reggie Jackson in the 1971 All-Star Game before a national television audience.

title: LAWHON, JOHN F, FURNITURE reports earnings for Year to Jan 31

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Omaha yesterday omitted a name from the list of active Democratic candidates competing in the Nebraska Presidential primary today. Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. is on the ballot in addition to Gary Hart, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Walter F. Mondale.

title: Occidental Unit in Bahrain
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would set up a $430 million, Bahrain-based gas- and oil-exploration and development subsidiary and offer half of its shares for sale outside the United States, primarily to Middle East investors. In a statement released here, the company said 50 percent of the shares in the new company, Arab Oxy, would be privately placed outside the United States by the Arab Banking Corporation and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RED CROSS EVALUATES TEST TO DETECT AIDS IN DONATED BLOOD
description: THE American Red Cross announced yesterday that it plans to start evaluating the accuracy of a test to detect acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, in blood donated for transfusions.

title: Columbia Receives $6 Million in Gifts
description: More than $6 million in gifts has been received by Columbia University to benefit young faculty members, research and the school's libraries, officials announced yesterday.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE PLANNING FUTILE, CUOMO SAYS
description: Governor Cuomo said today that it was futile to draw up plans to protect civilians in a nuclear war, but his chief spokesman said that the Governor would not halt the work of state employees engaged in such work.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TALKING COMPUTER TO COMPUTER
description: -DIMENT

title: TRANSCRIPT OF NEWS CONFERENCE BY PRESIDENT ON MONEY FOR THE MX
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference today, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: OLYMPICS OFFICIAL PRESSES FOR TALKS
description: The head of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today that he wanted to talk with a Russian sports delegation later this week to counter its charges that ''anti-Soviet hysteria'' surrounding the Games would make them unsafe for athletes from Communist nations.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,079,000.

title: CAN PASTURE LANDS BE RESTED TO DEATH?
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. MORE than 30 years ago in an attempt to control severe soil erosion at Chaco Canyon National Monument in the northwestern New Mexico desert, where portions of some 10th-century Pueblo cliff dwellings have been washed away, cattle grazing was banned at the park.

title: China Says Tourism Climbed By 11.5% in Peking Last Year
description: More than half a million foreign tourists visited the Chinese capital last year, the city statistical bureau said today.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it planned to spend $20 million to construct three buildings here and about $76 million to expand existing facilities. The company said the expansion was prompted by increasing demands for its digital telephone- switching systems. The company, which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, said it plans to employ 5,000 people in the Raleigh-Durham area.

title: Strauss Sees Difficulty For Mondale in California
description: Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today it would be ''very difficult'' for Walter F. Mondale to win the California primary June 5. But he predicted that the former Vice President would be the Democratic Presidential nominee even if he lost all five primaries held on that final primary day of 1984.

title: MONDALE WOOS HISPANIC VOTERS WITH JABS AT HART
description: ''Gary Hart's trying to introduce himself to you,'' Walter F. Mondale told an enthusiastic group of Hispanic high school students this morning. ''Well, where's he been?''

title: THE METEOROLOGICAL OLYMPICS
description: Meteorologists will have their own Olympic event this summer, when they will provide some of the most extensive weather reports and forecasts in history to participants in the summer games at Los Angeles.

title: Margaret Mitchell Heirs Win Film Sequel Rights
description: Heirs of Margaret Mitchell, the author of ''Gone With The Wind,'' won a Federal court ruling today giving them sole rights to any sequel to the film based on the novel.

title: Israeli Rabbi Arrested In Plot Against Arabs
description: A prominent leader of the Jewish settlement movement on the occupied West Bank was arrested Sunday night by the Israeli police, reportedly on suspicion that he had knowledge of terrorist attacks on Arabs being planned by some of 25 Jews now in custody.

title: TURBO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an unusual charge of $148,000,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $12,000,000. Year-ago revenues have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for Turbo's 90 percent interest in Bankeno Mines Ltd. to an equity basis rather than a consolidated basis because of Turbo's announced intention to sell its Bankeno stake.

title: STUDY SEES NO END TO SOVIET STAY IN AFGHANISTAN
description: The Soviet Union is likely to keep its forces in Afghanistan and continue its efforts to destroy the Afghan insurgents despite the rebels' continued resistance, according to a staff report prepared for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Debt Issues
description: Avco Financial Services Inc. filed for a shelf offering of up to $650 million in debt securities. Underwriters may include Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: WAS AN ACCUSED WAR CRIMINAL
description: Walter Herman Julius Rauff, a former Nazi SS colonel accused of directing the killing of hundreds of thousands of Jews in mobile gassing vans in World War II, died of natural causes yesterday in Chile, which had harbored him for more than 25 years.

title: AS NEOLIBERALS SEARCH FOR CLOSEST FIT, HART IS OFTEN MENTIONED
description: Neoliberalism is a political spirit in search of a candidate.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Down to Business
description: Les Steckel , the new head coach of the Minnesota Vikings, has let it be known early that training camp will be tougher this year. During a three- day minicamp, Steckel, a former Marine, put veteran players through an endurance course that included the following challenges, all in rapid order: a 40-yard dash, bench-pressing one's own weight, power curls of 75 percent of one's weight, pushing a blocking sled weighing one's weight and two minutes of situps. ''We want to be the best-conditioned team in the National Football League,'' Steckel said.

title: WAR ON AIDS: PROMPT ENTRY BY NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE-UPMANSHIP IN THE HOUSE IS OVER 'GUERRILLA' USE OF TV
description: A simmering dispute over the use of television in the House of Representatives turned into an acrimonious verbal skirmish today between the Democratic leadership and a group of aggressive young Republicans.

title: SELF-DEFENSE RULED IN SHOOTING OF MAN ALREADY FATALLY HURT
description: A liquor store owner who continued shooting a robbery suspect he had already fatally wounded was found not guilty today of attempted second-degree murder.

title: QADDAFI PROPOSES ACCORD ON CHAD
description: France is considering proposals by Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, for the withdrawal of French and Libyan troops from Chad, French officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: ;  Intermountain Power Bonds
description: The Intermountain Power Agency is offering $300 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 11 3/4 percent for bonds due in 2012, according to tentative prices set yesterday by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: OREGON VOTERS LIKELY TO REPEAT MAVERICK PAST
description: Oregon voters in 1984 seem ready to follow their maverick past that included support in 1964 for Nelson A. Rockefeller and in 1968 for Eugene J. McCarthy.

title: COMPUTER COMPANY THRIVES ON GLITCHES
description: For Timothy P. Ahlstrom and F. Morgan Lamarche, the founders of Avant-Garde Computing Inc., failure means success. ''We thrive on breakdowns,'' as Mr. Ahlstrom says.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $775,000 relating to the sale of a restaurant.

title: Inventory Rise Strong In March
description: Businesses increased their inventories by nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, the ninth consecutive monthly rise, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ;  People
description: John Nieman elected a senior vice president of Young & Rubicam USA.

title: New Perspective
description: Rather than being the object of curious stares and the target of autograph hunters at Los Angeles Airport on Sunday night, the Mets joined a crowd of travelers ogling a celebrity of a different sort.

title: Lendl's Injury After losing Sunday to
description: John McEnroe in the final of the Mercedes Tournament of Champions at the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, Ivan Lendl said that the shoulder he injured two days earlier had not bothered him and was not a factor in his loss.

title: CLEVELAND S. WHITE
description: Cleveland S. White, a former partner of the investment banking firm of F. S. Smithers & Company in Manhattan, died Thursday at the Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in West Falmouth.

title: 'Sanctuary' Worker Convicted in Alien Trial
description: Jurors convicted a Colorado church worker today of conspiring to smuggle two illegal aliens from El Salvador into this country as part of a growing sanctuary movement that is causing friction between the church and the Federal Government.

title: 5 Nations in Naval Exercise
description: Some 80 ships, 250 planes and more than 50,000 sailors and marines from five nations started a six-week naval exercise today. In a brief announcement, the Pentagon said naval forces from Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United States would take part in the exercise, which will center off southern California and the Hawaiian Islands.

title: LION CASE BROKERAGE'S INEXPERIENCE
description: National Money Market Services, a brokerage firm that arranged for New York school districts to invest millions of dollars in sophisticated Government securities transactions, was founded less than three years ago by two men without experience in securities trading, according to public records in New York and California.

title: The U.N. Today May 15, 1984
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: JESSE JACKSON CROSSES INTO MEXICO TO DENOUNCE AN IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson sought Hispanic votes today with an unexpected dart across the Mexican border, where he declared that illegal immigrants were a boon to the United States economy, not a drain.

title: AT CITY U., PERSISTENCE IS KEY REQUIREMENT
description: A STUDENT at a community college who carries a regular load of courses and makes normal progress can graduate in two years, but at some community colleges in the City University of New York not even 1 percent of the students get degrees in the traditional two-year time period.

Arco Drops Leasing Plans
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company notified the Interior Department that it is withdrawing from the purchase of seven environmentally sensitive offshore oil and gas tract leases. The company said it would forfeit its $10 million deposit on the central California tracts that it bought for $172 million with four partners.

title: Shelling in Beirut Kills Boy, 12, in Playground
description: An artillery shell exploded in the playground of a school in the city's Christian sector today, killing a 12- year-old boy and wounding 20 other children, hospital and radio reports said.

title: CHEMOTHERAPY MOVES TO FORE AS A CURE FOR CANCER
description: CHEMOTHERAPY, once the black sheep of cancer treatments, has become the leading weapon for increasing the number of patients who can be cured of cancer.

title: 2 Boys to Be Confined For Murdering Infant
description: Brothers aged 7 and 9 were sentenced today to an child care institution for the torture death of an 8-month-old girl left in their mother's care.

title: Article 192963 -- No Title
description: Sixteen of the nation's leading banks - with the tacit support of the Federal Reserve System - joined yesterday to make $4.5 billion in credit available to the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the nation's eighth-largest bank.

Phelps Dodge Sets Smelter Opening
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said its Ajo smelter, shut down two years ago, is being reopened with a work force of about 100 people.

title: THE TAX CUT AS CAMPAIGN STEAK OR BOLOGNA
description: A setting of record political wealth might seem a delicate forum for raising an issue of poverty. But President Reagan was in unapologetic fighting trim the other night as he spoke at a lucrative campaign dinner and drew Republican cheers in his most detailed attempt thus far to rebut the Democrats' contention that his Administration is unfair to the poor.

title: BAR EXAM LAWSUIT BLOCKED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that an applicant who fails a bar examination cannot bring a Federal antitrust suit against the state bar examiners. The court's finding will have the effect of insulating the bar admissions systems in nearly all states from antitrust challenges.

title: CRITIC OF CBS YIELDS TAPES TO WESTMORELAND LAWYERS
description: A former TV Guide reporter, angered by CBS attacks on his book, last week gave Gen. William C. Westmoreland's lawyers 37 tape recordings of telephone interviews with CBS officials.

title: THE SEABROOK TROUBLES: ONLY IN AMERICA
description: The financial ''meltdown'' of the Seabrook power plant and its nearly bankrupt builder, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, is being widely interpreted as proof that nuclear power is no longer economic.

description: R. SHIPP

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE POPE'S PACIFIC SWING
description: The dancers were lined up on the runway of the Mount Hagen airport, in the interior of Papua New Guinea, to see off Pope John Paul II. Their faces were painted in glowing hues, thickly laid on and artfully patterned. Seen from close up, they looked as if they were wearing intricate masks.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend.

description: The Calendar listing on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly reported the date of a news conference scheduled by the economists Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison. It will be held 10 A.M. Thursday at the National Press Club.

Metal Strike In Germany
description: West German metalworkers began walkouts today called by unions to back demands for a gradual introduction of a 35-hour workweek, five hours shorter than the current workweek.

title: Market Place; Stock Buyback Advantages
description: WHILE leveraged buyouts like the recent $2.4 billion offer for Esmark Inc. are creating the greatest excitement in Wall Street, corporate buyback programs also are on the rise.

title: K Mart Net Up 30.1%
description: The K Mart Corporation said today that booming sales of clothing helped it achieve record first-quarter profits of $58 million, or 45 cents a share, up 30.1 percent from the previous record of $44.6 million, or 35 cents a share, in the first three months of 1983.

description: b-Including tax credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 9 months.

THE COMPUTERIZATION OF CARS
description: The Chrysler Corporation's electronics division here has developed an electronic navigation system for cars. Once it is operating, a driver will be able to pinpoint his car's location to within a city block, anywhere in the United States.

title: United Plans Rise in Fares
description: United Airlines announced yesterday that it would increase many of its fares on May 31.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 15, 1984 International
description: Lobbying for the MX missile was stepped up by President Reagan. At an impromptu news conference, Mr. Reagan asserted that House disapproval of the missile ''would only encourage the Soviet Union to ignore our arms control efforts.'' The consensus is that a majority in the House now opposes production money for the missile. (Page A1, Column 5.) A new vote on the MX missile is expected in the House tomorrow. At issue is a bill that would delete about $2.5 billion approved by the Armed Services Committee for production of 30 MX missiles. (A1:4-6.)

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS-WORCESTER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income after a gain of $3,203,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The year-ago quarter net per share is unavailable since the company went public in January 1984.

title: Earthquake in Colorado
description: A small earthquake rattled dishes, shook windows and awakened people in west central Colorado early today, but caused no serious damage, the authorities said. Officials of the United States Geological Survey said the temblor measured 3.2 on the Richter Scale.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ron Guidry, off to a slow start, goes against the A's Ray Burris, a former Met. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Giants , at San Francisco. After taking two of three in Los Angeles, the Mets try to continue their success on this West Coast swing. They will start Ron Darling (3-2). (Television - Sports Channel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 10:30 P.M.).

title: Bank's Decline Tied to Energy Loans
description: Three years ago, banking analysts described the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company as ''solid,'' and explained that the conservative bank's great success was a result of cautious, formal banking practices.

title: SCHOOLS REALIZE QUALITY IS REQUISITE FOR SURVIVAL
description: ONE year ago, the National Commission on Excellence in Education, appointed by the Department of Education, warned the country of a ''rising tide of mediocrity'' in education. Is the tide still rising?

title: U.S.F.L. MAKING SMALL GAINS IN 1984
description: The United States Football League continues to show overall gains in season's attendance and television ratings. But the revenue from those gains seems to be too modest to keep pace with rising payroll expenses.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Help for Sanderson
description: Derek Sanderson , the former Boston Bruin, who is almost bedridden as a result of health problems, alcoholism, drug dependence and injuries, has benefited from the Federal system that, in better days, he once characterized as ''a great hustle.'' Sanderson, who played for the Bruins between 1965 and 1974, recently became eligible to receive $700 a month in Social Security disability benefits for the rest of his life, The Boston Globe reported Sunday.

title: RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net realized gain from investment of $9,791,000. c-Includes a net realized gain from investment of $13,612,000.

title: HERZOG INTRODUCES A POLITICAL ISSUE AT CANNES
description: Werner Herzog, the West German director, brought a new film about the clash of civilizations in Australia to Cannes today. After the showing, the Cannes Film Festival was still awaiting its first hit, or its first scandal, but Mr. Herzog provided an interesting bit of politics-goes-to-the-movies with an unexpected denunciation of the Nicaraguan Government's treatment of the Miskito Indians.

title: PESTS THRIVE ON POLLUTION
description: AIR pollution appears to strengthen the gypsy moth's annual onslaught on the nation's trees. Scientists seeking ways to control the insect have discovered that air pollutants such as ozone and sulfur dioxide, increasingly prevalent in urban areas, weaken the leaves of trees and make them more attractive to the insects than the leaves of trees in unpolluted areas. The environmental problems posed by the pollutants and the insects are thus compounded.

title: UNILEVER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STANISLAW ULAM, THEORIST ON HYDROGEN BOMB
description: Stanislaw M. Ulam, who has been described as one of the greatest contemporary mathematicians and who played a key role in developing the hydrogen bomb, died Sunday in Santa Fe, N.M., after apparently suffering a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: Topics Mother, Nature
description: Icebreaker

title: Big Bat at U.S.C.
description: After setting Pacific 10 Conference records with 31 home runs this season and 53 for his three-year career at Southern Cal, 20-year-old Mark McGwire is looking forward eagerly to the major league draft in June.

title: FOR ECUADOR INDIANS, PRIDE AND PROFITS IN WEAVING
description: Alfonso Morales still wears the white trousers, blue ponchos, braided hair and felt hats typical of Otavalo Indians. And he speaks the halting Spanish of someone who is more comfortable talking in Quechua.
