SYNTHETIC FUELS AGENCY FACES A FUNDS CUTBACK
description: The Reagan Administration said tonight that it had decided to ask Congress to slash by two-thirds the uncommitted funds of the embattled Synthetic Fuels Corporation. The move would curtail the Government's program to develop synthetic fuels and save $9.5 billion, the Administration said.

title: Drink Linked to Death Not Poisoned In Factory
description: Cyanide found in a bottle of Coca-Cola that killed a 34-year-old man was placed in the container after it left the bottling plant, the authorities said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times May 8 on advances in astronomy incorrectly identified an American astronomer and misstated his estimate of the percentage of objects and phenomena in the universe that have been surveyed. He is Martin Harwit, and he suggests that astronomers have recognized 10 percent to 30 percent of all cosmic phenomena.

title: MICKELBERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include the operations of Caribiner Inc. and Ventura Associates Inc. which were acquired during the first quarter of 1984 and accounted for as purchases.

title: RULING SAYS STATE JUDGES MAY BE SUED IN CIVIL RIGHTS CASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that state judges may be sued for civil rights violations and may be ordered to pay the lawyers' fees of those who sue them successfully.

title: DECISIONS LOOMING
description: The Knick season belonged to Bernard King. Never before in the 38 years of the franchise has a player contributed so much to the team's success.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is very clear that Congress did not intend to create an elaborate independent counsel machinery - which makes sense only in the context of a distrust of the Attorney General with respect to the prosecution of alleged wrongdoing of his official and political colleagues - only to establish the Attorney General as the 'gatekeeper' of that machinery, able, without the slightest review by anyone, to open the gate or slam it shut as it may suit his purpose.'' - Judge Harold H. Greene. (A19:1.)

title: MEXICAN LEADER TO MEET REAGAN TODAY
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico arrived in Washington today for talks with President Reagan aimed at narrowing differences over their views of what is troubling the hemisphere.

title: 6 VIE FOR SENATE NOMINATION IN NEBRASKA PRIMARY TODAY
description: Six Republicans are vying for their party's nomination for the United States Senate in the Nebraska primary election Tuesday.

title: SINGER FETED FOR BACKING SAFE DRIVING
description: Michael Jackson volunteered a tune today to a national campaign against drunken driving and received an award from President Reagan in return.

title: IN EMOTIONAL PROBLEMS, THE RICH RESEMBLE THE POOR
description: MANY of them lead lives of emptiness, cannot hold a job, have no lasting relationships and move aimlessly from place to place in an isolated orbit - and no one cares. The reason: They are extremely rich.

title: AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Gets Krystle Fragrance
description: Charles of the Ritz Group Ltd. named Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson to handle its new Forever Krystle fragrance line. The fragrance is named for the saintly character Krystle Carrington played by Linda Evans in the television show ''Dynasty.''

title: CANADIAN VICTORIES AGAINST ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPICS DECISION FINAL, SOVIET SAYS
description: The top Soviet sports official said today that the decision not to participate in the Los Angeles Olympic Games was final.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT OVERRULES FINE AGAINST CLERK OF HOUSE
description: The Clerk of the House of Representatives does not have to pay about $150,000 in fines imposed by a Federal judge for contempt of court in refusing to answer a subpoena for Congressional documents, a Federal appellate court has ruled.

title: No Headline
description: Mudslide Buries Man Near a Mine in Utah

title: EVANS NAMED EDITOR OF PRESS
description: Harold Evans, the former editor of The Sunday Times and The Times of London, has been named editor in chief of the Atlantic Monthly Press, the book publishing division of the Atlantic Monthly Company, which also publishes The Atlantic magazine.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'Oliver' Closes
description: ''Oliver!,'' the revival of the musical by Lionel Bart, closed after the Sunday evening performance at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The play, directed by Peter Coe, ran for 12 previews and 17 performances.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $5.6 million from the sale of 13 Memco stores.

title: Rexnord Agrees To Buy Clausing
description: Rexnord Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Clausing Corporation in a transaction valued at nearly $68.9 million.

title: Pipeline Company Seeks Extension
description: The Northern Border Pipeline Company has filed a request with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to build a 290-mile pipeline extension from Ventura, Iowa, to Sandwich, Ill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MAY 15, 1984

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 COUNTIES RESOLVE DISPUTE OVER COSTS OF THE BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A dispute between Rockland and Westchester Counties over the security costs of the Brink's murder and robbery trial was resolved today.

title: CELTICS EAGERLY AWAITING BUCKS SERIES
description: It was there for all to see, a not-so- subtle sign sitting in the back of M. L. Carr's locker that explained just how the Boston Celtics feel about their meeting with Milwaukee in the Eastern Conference final.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: A NEW LOOK

title: Offer for After Six
description: After Six Inc. said a newly formed company, including members of its management, had proposed to buy out After Six for $15 a share.

title: Mondale Scores Upset In Alaska Delegate Race
description: Alaska Democrats wound up their annual convention Sunday by giving Walter F. Mondale an unexpected victory, awarding him 6 of the state's 14 delegates to the national convention. Senator Gary Hart of Colorado ended up with 4 delegates.

title: New Ashton-Tate Data-Base System
description: Ashton-Tate, which markets one of the most popular data-base managers for the I.B.M. Personal Computer, said that it would introduce dBaseIII, a successor to its dBaseII program.

title: Japan's Steel Output Up
description: Japan's production of crude steel in April rose 10.2 percent from a year earlier, to 9.7 million tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. The federation said steel output in April was 2.6 percent more than in March. Based on the April figures, Japan's steel production this year would be 107.5 million tons, the federation said.

title: U.S. CALLS THE SOVIET COMPLAINTS A 'CLASSIC CASE' OF DISTORTION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the latest Soviet complaints about American preparations for the Olympic Games in Los Angeles represented ''a classic case of complete distortion and twisting of facts to fit a particular Soviet line.''

title: 2 IN REPUBLICAN PRIMARY COMPETE TO FACE BRADLEY
description: The race for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey pits a veteran conservative against a comparative newcomer to elective politics.

title: PRESIDENT LINKS CONTROL OF ARMS TO MX MISSILE
description: President Reagan, stepping up his lobbying campaign to salvage money for the MX missile in the House of Representatives, said today that disapproval of the missile ''would only encourage the Soviet Union to ignore our arms control efforts.''

title: Nurse Gets a 99-Year Term
description: Genene Jones, a vocational nurse, today was formally sentenced to 99 years in prison for the drug injection murder of a 15-month-old Kerrville child. She was convicted of the crime on Feb. 16, but Judge John Carter of Williamson County District Court said he postponed formal sentencing for three months to ''let things calm down.'' The 33-year-old nurse was convicted for the murder of Chelsea McClellan, who was injected with a muscle relaxant at a clinic in Kerrville, Tex., on Sept. 17, 1982.

title: Ground Breaking For Clear Comfort
description: Alice Austen, one of the first women

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Actor Pays Fine Of $20,000 to City
description: The city has received a check for $20,000 from the actor Darren McGavin - the amount of ''reparations'' he was penalized by a judge for lying about his rent-controlled Manhattan apartment, officials said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Political Puzzle on Civil Rights Does President Reagan wish to make a significant gesture to women, racial minorities, the handicapped and senior citizens all at once? He has a chance to do just that by seizing the leadership of a bipartisan effort in Congress to revitalize the laws against discrimination that were diluted by the Supreme Court decision in the Grove City College case last winter.

title: DOW DROPS 6.07 AMID RATE WORRIES
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the second consecutive session in sluggish trading. Apprehension over rising interest rates continued to depress the list.

title: Reunion Overflow
description: What happens when you throw a

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Toshiba Plans Plant in Britain
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it would begin manufacturing microwave ovens in Britain to meet growing demand in European markets. Toshiba also said it would increase its investment in its microwave oven plants in the United States and Japan in an effort to attain a 15 percent world market share in 1985 with a production of 1.6 million ovens annually.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kevin McHale , who averaged 18.4 points and 7.4 rebounds a game and led the Boston Celtics with 126 blocked shots during the regular season, was named the winner of the National Basketball Association's Sixth- Man Award. . . . Maurice Lucas of the Phoenix Suns, complained of a sore right heel and is a doubtful starter for tonight's playoff game with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Bandits Romp
description: John Reaves passed for 378 yards and 4 touchdowns tonight to lead the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 48-21 victory over the Oklahoma Outlaws. It was the sixth straight triumph for the Bandits (9-3), and it spoiled the homecoming of the Outlaws' quarterback Doug Williams, who jumped to the Outlaws after five seasons with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Williams, who was booed by the crowd of 45,116, completed 25 of 48 passes for 317 yards and 3 touchdowns.

title: Polish Cardinal Visits Paris
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, arrived in France today for the start of what was described as an eight-day pastoral visit to Paris and Rome.

title: ALBERTA WANTS A CUP
description: EDMONTON,Alberta

title: REAGAN REFUSES TO JOIN CRITICS OF FED
description: President Reagan refused today to endorse criticism of the Federal Reserve Board that was expressed last week by Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, and by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.

title: Bridge: Everyone Is Invited Tonight To International Fund Game
description: The cost of sending American teams to world championships, a considerable financial burden on the American Contract Bridge League, is met each year largely by the International Fund Game.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bancorp Hawaii Inc. , a one bank holding company in Honolulu, was informed that a group of three Liechtenstein-based concerns had increased its holdings in the company's common stock to 9.9 percent of the total outstanding.

title: ;  Rise in New Products
description: New product introductions in the food, health and beauty aids categories took a strong jump in April, to 174, up from 140 in the same month last year, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News.

title: VOLCANO SENDS UP A BLAST OF STEAM
description: Mount St. Helens shot a plume of ash and steam four miles high today, and a small mudflow poured down its flanks.

title: Projected 5-Club Payrolls
description: The labor agreement reached last year between the National Basketball Association and the players' union placed salary caps on the Knicks, the Nets, the Los Angeles Lakers, the Seattle SuperSonics and the Philadelphia 76ers, the teams with the highest payrolls, for the 1983-84 season. The other 18 teams in the league will be subject to caps for next season.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Waste Cleanup
description: A 57-acre toxic waste dump near Philadelphia International Airport will be cleaned using $4.82 million in Federal and city funds, officials announced today.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Radio Under the River
description: The bottom of the ninth, the winning

title: STAGE: 'TO MECCA,' BY ATHOL FUGARD
description: NEW HAVEN THE heroine of Athol Fugard's new play, ''The Road to Mecca,'' is a reclusive, elderly South African widow named Helen who has spent 15 years on an obsessive artistic project. That project is an overgrown sculpture garden representing a fantasy pilgrimage to Mecca - full of life-size camels, wise men and glittering peacocks. Though the neighbors in her desert village regard Helen as mad and her creations as ''monsters,'' she is driven to keep at her solitary work no matter what. The images for her sculptural figures spring into her gut ''like pictures'' - begging to be shaped in cement at once.

title: Two Accused Libyans Agree to Extradition
description: Two Libyan students who were called a ''grave danger to the community'' by a United States magistrate waived a hearing today and agreed to extradition to New York to face charges of buying three pistols equipped with silencers.

title: MOOD GRIM IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: The mood in the credit markets remained grim yesterday. Long-term Treasury bond prices fell more than 1 1/4 points while securities dealers cut prices in an effort to find levels that would attract buyers.

title: THE PLUMS AT CITY INVESTING
description: George T. Scharffenberger, chairman of the City Investing Company, has developed a reputation as a conglomerate builder. But now, with his participation in a $2.3 billion management buyout offer for City Investing, many analysts are saying he could become just as well known for breaking up a conglomerate.

title: Swiss Trade Deficit
description: Switzerland's trade deficit narrowed in April to 664 million Swiss francs, or $291 million, from 970.4 million francs in March, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today.

title: A Search Is Urged For a Schools Chief
description: A group of black leaders said yesterday that the successor to Anthony J. Alvarado, who resigned as the city's Schools Chancellor on Friday, should be chosen through an open search.

title: Oregon St. Cited
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed Oregon State on one-year probation today and ordered the return of $342,634.62 in 1982 postseason earnings for violations that took place primarily in the men's basketball program. The penalties will not affect eligibility for postseason play or television appearances. The violations, which occurred from 1979 to 1983, generally involved the selling of complimentary tickets, extending loans to athletes and providing automobiles and transportation to players and their families.

title: WORDS TO THE WISE AND OTHERWISE
description: Sidney Hook, the New York University philosopher and guru of either the new conservatives or the old liberals (depending on the person filling out label), lectured tonight in an ornate auditorium here on the humanities and the defense of a free society.

title: EX-N.F.L. PLAYER KILLS HIMSELF
description: Eric Washington, a former defensive back for the St. Louis Cardinals, shot and killed himself today as police tried to question him in connection with two recent bank robberies, authorities said. The 34-year-old Washington, who played for the Cardinals in 1972 and 1973 before being dropped, shot himself in the head with a pistol after officers and F.B.I. agents knocked on the door of his apartment.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend payable May 31, 1984.

title: 10TH AND LARGEST CASINO OPENS IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: This city's 10th casino hotel, the $210 million Harrah's at Trump Plaza, opened in the center of the Boardwalk strip today, the first entry in an expected new wave of casino openings prompted by the booming gambling business here.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $128,355. The year-earlier results were restated to reflect disposition of the investment in the company's Lidex subsidiary.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Headline
description: National Defense, Private Agendas Congress intends to cut the defense budget, and the Secretary of Defense could surely help by laying out a rational list of priorities. But he won't. Mr. Weinberger insists, cutely, that every item is equally essential. He intends that Congress seek savings by slowing the general pace of purchases, so that his program will be merely delayed, with nothing eliminated.

title: EVIDENCE IS FADING AS U.S. INVESTIGATES USE OF 'YELLOW RAIN'
description: While arguments continue over whether the Soviet Union and its allies have used a new poison weapon, ''yellow rain,'' in the developing countries, the trail of evidence is growing colder.

title: MEDIA HORIZONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $35,690 from an installment sale on a publication sold in 1983. c-Includes a one-time gain of $102,022 from the sale of a lease and leasehold improvements.

title: HIGH COURT DEFINES 'INEFFECTIVE' COUNSEL AS A BASIS FOR APPEAL
description: The Supreme Court today defined for the first time the standards for deciding whether a criminal defendant has received the ''assistance of counsel'' guaranteed by the Constitution.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Before stock dividends of $7,600,000. c-Net income.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a realized investment gain of $250,000. c-After a realized investment gain of $2,466,000 and an extraordinary credit of $758,000.

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $48,019 from discontinued operations. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $106,998. d-Net loss after a loss of $65,242 from discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN'S SALVADOR ALLY...
description: Like many American Presidents before him, Ronald Reagan inherited a stark dilemma in Latin America: He was asked to choose between dictatorship and chaos, between ''stability'' and subversion. Virtually all previous Presidents chose ''stability'' - that is, dictatorship. In this, they disregarded Latin Americans' real democratic possibilities and gave many of us the impression that the United States' interests are at odds with its moral ideals. At first, Ronald Reagan seemed almost certain to follow this unfortunate path. But he has surprised us in El Salvador.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HARVARD M. HODGKINS, HELPED CATCH 2 NAZI SPIES
description: Harvard M. Hodgkins, who as a 17- year-old Boy Scout helped catch two Nazi spies who had landed on the Maine coast in World War II, died Sunday at his home in Hancock, Me. He was 57 years old.

title: Wrong Business
description: Almost every day, there are rumors that the financially troubled Larry Holmes-Gerrie Coetzee heavyweight title bout will be called off. But a news conference is planned tomorrow in Las Vegas, Nev., to announce that the fight will take place as scheduled on June 8 with new backing.

title: CITY AGAINST REGIONAL FUND UNLESS TRADE CENTER IS SOLD
description: The Koch administration, in an effort to pressure Governor Cuomo to agree to the sale of the World Trade Center, said today that it would oppose the creation of a Port Authority regional development bank until the twin towers were sold.

title: Chase & Sanborn Bid by Chock Full
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said it had raised its buyout offer for Chase & Sanborn to $14.4 million from $12.5 million. Howard Leitner, chief financial officer of Chock Full o'Nuts, said the new offer was $2 million higher than an increased offer for Chase & Sanborn made last week by Hills Brothers Coffee.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain. The latest first quarter results include the effects of the conversion of the Array Processor R & D partnership into equity.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC UNITS
description: THE concert by the New York Philharmonic Ensembles Sunday afternoon at the Asia Society got better as it went along; best, therefore, to start at the end. Prokofiev's wiry Quintet for Oboe, Clarinet, Violin, Viola and Doublebass (1924) was given a sharply etched performance by Joseph Robinson, Peter Simenauer, Gabriel Banat, Peter Kenote and Jon Deak.

title: NEW ARCHEOLOGY TAKES BROADER VIEW OF LIFE
description: JEREMY Sabloff stood on the hillside by a stone ruin and looked out across the wooded valley in the Puuc region of Mexico's Yucatan. Jutting out of the jungle growth here and there were a somber pyramid and some crumbling palaces, a sight to stir any archeologist's mind.

title: ; Management Shuffle At MCA Advertising
description: In a management reorganization at MCA Advertising Ltd., Morgan V. Hunter, president, was named chairman and William W. Bishop, executive vice president, was named president.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier figures are restated.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $638,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $273,000 and a gain of $32,443 from discontinued operations.

title: ...NEEDS REAGAN'S HELP
description: The election of Jose Napoleon Duarte as president of El Salvador is a significant step forward, but it is not a panacea. Mr. Duarte alone cannot impose fundamental change in his country.

title: Norcen Purchase
description: Norcen Energy Ltd. said it had agreements that allow it to increase its stake in the Hanna Mining Company to 28 percent, from 20 percent.

title: Food Crisis in Africa
description: A bipartisan group of Senators have written President Reagan asking whether the ''unmatched disaster relief capabilities'' of the Defense Department should be ''mobilized at once to combat the threat to human life in Africa.''

title: Border Patrol Searches For Aliens, Finds Drug
description: Border Patrol agents poking through alfalfa in a horse trailer looking for illegal aliens instead found two tons of marijuana, officers said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; First Pennsylvania To Get New Leader
description: In his spare time, Frank E. Reed is an outdoor enthusiast who enjoys pitting himself against Mother Nature. But the 49-year-old banker, who is currently a group executive at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, apparently relishes challenges in business as well.

title: DEBT AND THE DEFICIT
description: Paul Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave voice the other day to one of those ideas whose time appears to have come - a limit on the interest rates charged to Latin American countries burdened with overwhelming external debt.

title: Williams Will Sell Its Edgcomb Unit
description: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of the assets of its Edgcomb Metals Company unit to a subsidiary of Edgcomb Steel of New England Inc. for more than $100 million.

title: PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chess: KTor First in Sarajevo Event
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Jan Timman of the Netherlands tied for first in the Sarajevo International Tournament in Yugoslavia. Both grandmasters scored 9-4 in the 14- man field.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OILERS SEEKING TO MAKE CHANGES
description: The message Wayne Gretzky had was directed at himself, but it just as easily could have been pointed to anyone in the Oiler dressing room.

title: Net Result: No Sale After several weeks of negotiations with Sports Channel, the cable-television company,
description: Joe Taub has decided not to sell the Nets. At the same time he resigned as team president, relinquishing the post he had held since he headed a group of investors that purchased the Nets in 1978.

title: 'Beethoven's Tenth' Closes
description: ''Beethoven's Tenth,'' the comedy by Peter Ustinov, closed after Sunday's matinee at the Nederlander Theater. The play, directed by Robert Chetwyn and starring Mr. Ustinov, ran for 14 previews and 25 regular performances.

title: REBELS ATTACK SOUTH AFRICAN REFINERY AND ARE SLAIN AFTER A CHASE
description: Guerrillas made a rocket attack on an oil refinery in the port of Durban Sunday night that led to a series of gunfights early today between rebels and the police. Seven people were killed, four of them suspected guerrillas.

title: 3 OF 4 WINNERS STEP FORWARD TO SPLIT HUGE LOTTO JACKPOT
description: A cleaning woman who had just begun playing Lotto, a manicurist who had played it consistently and a machinist who had played each week with the very same numbers claimed their shares yesterday of the richest lottery prize ever offered in North America.

title: Canada Installs Mrs. Sauve
description: Jeanne Sauve, a former journalist and Cabinet minister, today became Governor General of Canada at a colorful investiture ceremony. Mrs. Sauve, 62 years old, is the first woman to occupy the largely ceremonial post.

title: DANCE: SWAN LAKE
description: THERE are times when a ballet isn't a ballet, or even a performance, but simply an occasion. One of those times was on Friday when American Ballet Theater presented its first ''Swan Lake'' of the current season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The production, whose choreography is attributed to Petipa, Ivanov and David Blair, isn't the most lively or poignant of stagings of this ballet classic. Its leads at this performance have both danced better. But the audience had come to pay homage to what it clearly saw as the crown prince and princess of Ballet Theater, and Fernando Bujones and Cynthia Gregory lived up to the event.

title: A SCHOOL'S WRONG RESPONSE TO DRUG ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ben Roberts, 68, a Writer And a Producer of Films
description: Ben Roberts, a writer and producer whose works included ''Portrait In Black,'' ''Midnight Lace,'' ''White Heat'' and the television show ''The Rogues,'' died Saturday in Centinela Hospital following a stroke suffered several weeks ago. He was 68 years old.

title: VALUES CLASH IN JERSEY'S GROWTH BELT
description: Ray Catanio spent his boyhood and early manhood tending cows and corn on farms owned by his grandfather and a neighbor. Now, he makes his living driving truckloads of bricks to construction sites in New York City 90 minutes away.

title: The Sewage Wars (Cont'd.)
description: New York City's right to dump raw

title: HIGH COURT BARS MOON'S APPEAL OF TAX VERDICT
description: The Supreme Court refused today, without comment or dissent, to review the conviction of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon for Federal income tax fraud.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OAK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $1,906,000 for idle STV decoders used in the company's over-the-air subscription television systems. c-After a tax benefit of $2,870,000.

title: UNILEVER N V reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Limited Assails Carter Move
description: The Limited Inc., in an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, charged that the recent stock repurchase program by Carter Hawley Hale Stores had violated California law.

title: Boesky Stock Buy
description: Ivan F. Boesky has bought 390,800 common shares, or 5.5 percent, of the 7,152,051 shares outstanding of Management Assistance Inc., according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Mr. Boesky purchased the shares of the New York computer manufacturer for prices ranging from $22 to $24.875 a share, from March 15 to May 9. The stock closed at $22.75, down 50 cents, today on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Boesky said the purchase had been made for investment purposes.

title: NORMAN COUSINS STORY
description: ''ANATOMY OF AN ILLNESS,'' the made-for-television movie on CBS-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is part biography and part pamphleteering. The problem is that one part keeps getting in the way of the other, and neither emerges with dramatic conviction. Lawrence Roman's script is based on the autobiographical book by Norman Cousins, who at the time he wrote it was the editor of Saturday Review magazine.

title: CALIFORNIAN GETS LIFE SENTENCE IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: James Durward Harper Jr., the engineer who last month pleaded guilty to conspiring to sell United States missile research data to Polish intelligence agents, was sentenced to life in prison by a Federal district judge here today.

title: ZALE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $10,600,000 for the year related to the settlement of a tax examination.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOSCOW ADDS MORE MISSILES TO COUNTER WEST
description: The Defense Ministry said today that the Soviet Union was placing additional tactical nuclear missiles in East Germany to counter what the Russians called a continuing buildup of American medium- range missiles in Western Europe.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISES SHARPLY
description: Consumers took out $5.87 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in March, despite a sharp drop in car loans, the Government reported today.

title: ; EXECUTIVES WORTH EVERY MILLION THEY GET
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 16, 1984 Companies
description: Victor Posner entered the bidding for City Investing, offering $52.50 a share for the conglomerate, compared with the $50 offered by a management group last week. The Posner group's bid totals $2.4 billion. City Investing said the offer would be studied. (D1.) Continental Illinois used some of its emergency credit line, but it was unclear whether the bank had succeeded in stopping a run on deposits. It would not say how much it had borrowed from the $4.5 billion credit offered by 16 banks or whether it had borrowed from the Federal Reserve. (D1.)

title: Indians 7, Red Sox 5 CLEVELAND (AP) - Andre Thornton had to break three ties before he was finally credited with the game-winning hit in the Cleveland victory. Thornton drove in three runs, putting the Indians up 1-0 in the first, 5-4 in the sixth and, finally, 6-5 in the eighth, when Cleveland scored two runs to clinch the victory.;  Blue Jays 5, Twins 2
description: Mitch Webster scored the tying run in the ninth inning and knocked in one of four runs in the 10th as Toronto rallied.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
2 MAJORS USEFUL FOR TEACHERS
description: AT a recent meeting called to help college students chart their careers, a mother asked if a double major in music and science would help her son follow a teaching career. The answer was a resounding ''Yes, a great double major.''

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Three Children in West Beirut Are Killed Playing With Shell
description: Three children playing with an artillery shell on a West Beirut street were killed today when the shell exploded.

title: CHIEF QUITS D.D.B. FOR SHOWTIME
description: TEN years ago, Neil R. Austrian,

title: HOTEL RESTAURANTS ARE STRIVING FOR GASTRONOMIC HEIGHTS
description: LITTLE more than a generation ago in New York, when big bands swayed through the night and every man wore a hat, some of the best dining in the city was found in hotels. The Ambassador, the Plaza, the Sherry-Netherland, the St. Regis, the Waldorf- Astoria and the old Ritz-Carlton, where the chef Louis Diat invented vichyssoise - those were the places you went for memorable meals.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated.

title: Allianz Backs AwayFrom Armco Unit
description: Armco Inc. announced yesterday that it and Allianz Versicherungs A.G., a West German insurance company, had terminated a letter of understanding giving Allianz the exclusive right to negotiate for the purchase of the diversified steelmaker's insurance operations.

title: MONDALE ASSERTS PRESIDENT PLANS 'SURPRISE' THAT RAISES WAR THREAT
description: Walter F. Mondale today warned that President Reagan, if re-elected, was planning a ''December surprise'' in Central America that raised the threat of war.

title: FOOD ADVENTURES: A DOCUMENTARY PRODUCER'S CHINA TRAVELS
description: ''PEOPLE expect me to give them recipes,'' said Sue Yung Li, ''but I'm not a food person, really. I like to cook, but if I had to write down a recipe I wouldn't know where to begin.''

title: SAKHAROVS' SON SAYS HE FEARS THEY WILL DIE
description: The son of Yelena Bonner, wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, said today that the couple could die soon unless the Soviet authorities allowed his mother to leave the country.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $241,573 loss on coal operations which exceeded a $575,000 allowance provided in 1983. c-Net income

title: CRITICS VOTE 'REAL THING' BEST NEW PLAY OF '83-84
description: Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing'' was selected as the best new play of the 1983-84 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting yesterday in the Alqonquin Hotel. David Mamet's ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' was named best American play, and the Stephen Sondheim- James Lapine musical ''Sunday in the Park With George'' was chosen as best musical.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: LYRICAL Dorothy Fields, the prolific lyricist, died 10 years ago, but her music, represented by more than 400 songs, including those in 19 Broadway shows and 25 motion pictures, lives on. The music that Miss Fields wrote with such composers as Jerome Kern, Fritz Kreisler, Harold Arlen, Arthur Schwartz, Sigmund Romberg and Cy Coleman, will be on tap from 10 o'clock tonight through Saturday at Rachel's, the restaurant-club in TriBeCa at 25 Hudson Street, (334- 8155).

title: MAN ON THE SPOT AT TROUBLED BANK: DAVID G. TAYLOR
description: With the banking industry's largest rescue package arranged, David G. Taylor, the chairman and chief executive officer of the beleaguered Continental Illinois Corporation, is clearly the man on the spot in the banking industry. He is in the somewhat delicate position of a doctor whose cure turns into a new ailment. Mr. Taylor, elevated to his present job last February to help rescue the bank holding company and its flagship bank, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, did so partly through an injection of funds from Europe and the Far East. Now it is those depositors who, having become skittish over rumors that the bank's financial position had worsened, have caused a new cash squeeze by withdrawing their money.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Banking on Uncle Sam
description: ''Is my money safe?'' Thousands of depositors at Continental Illinois have been asking that in recent months as news dribbled out about bad loan losses by the nation's ninth largest bank.

title: CASABLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $157,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $116,000 and an extraordinary credit of $376,000.

title: BARRINGER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $296,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $462,000. Year-ago revenues include a nonrecurring gain of $2 million from the sale of technology.

title: Hostetler Likes Giants
description: The Arizona Wranglers have outbid the Giants in the competition for Jeff Hostetler , the former West Virginia quarterback, but Hostetler plans to report to the Giants' minicamp next Monday, his agent said yesterday. ''My philosophy is that when the Giant coaches see Jeff close up, they'll find out how valuable he is,'' said the agent, Robert Bennett , who spent the last week weighing offers and counter-offers from the teams.

title: ADDENDUM
description: * General Mills European Toy Group consolidated all of its advertising at Grey Advertising.

title: 20,000 March to Back Costa Rican Neutrality
description: An estimated 20,000 to 30,000 Costa Ricans paraded through downtown San Jose today in a march against war and for peace and neutrality.

title: AN OFFBEAT HORSE IMPRESSES TRAINER
description: Jack Van Berg says he can't really complain about his luck at the race track. After all, he has sent out more than 4,000 winners over the last 15 years, more than any other trainer in the country, including a record 496 in 1976. He is the biggest operator around, with 154 horses in training at 4 tracks and another 98 on his Van Berg Farm in Kentucky.

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOVERNMENT PAID INFORMER $32,000 DURING INQUIRY INTO DELOREAN
description: While James Timothy Hoffman, an informer, was helping the Government put its cocaine-trafficking case together against John Z. DeLorean, the Government spent more than $32,000 to protect and support him, a Federal agent testified today.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW BANK OF AMERICA CENTER IN CITY
description: The Bank of America, long considered an out-of-town cousin when it comes to New York financial dealings, formally opened its new regional headquarters on Madison Avenue yesterday.

title: MX, Binaries and Bargaining Chips
description: The House can redress the excesses in the Administration's rearmament program this week by cancelling the MX missile and the new chemical weapons program. The best use of these worn ''bargaining chips'' is to trade them promptly for cash.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $107,000. c-After an investment gain of $45,852.

title: DESPITE GAMES PULLOUT, SOVIET SEEKS TRADE TALKS
description: A high- level Soviet trade and economic delegation is due to arrive next week to lobby for an easing of Administration trade restrictions and to meet with some leading American business executives, officials said today.

title: Frances Lois Willoughby, 78; First Female Doctor in Navy
description: Dr. Frances Lois Willoughby, a psychiatrist and the first female doctor commissioned in the United States Navy, died Sunday of a heart ailment at Underwood Memorial Hospital in Woodbury, N.J. She was 78 years old and lived in Pitman, N.J.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLEXI-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include insurance recoveries of $260,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,230,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: DR. JEKYLL AND MR. KINGMAN
description: As the Oakland A's chartered bus

title: RAPIST IS SOUGHT FOR 12 ATTACKS IN EAST FLATBUSH
description: Two woman were raped and robbed at gunpoint in separate attacks early yesterday in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The police said the crimes were committed by the man who was also responsible for 10 other rapes in the area since Feb. 6

title: The Living SectionFood
description: Hotel restaurants strivingC1

title: ELECTRIC CAPACITY: TIME TO PROVIDE FOR THE 90'S
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: When Mr. Smith Judges Himself Question: What's more humiliating to an Attorney General than a Federal court's judgment that he has violated a law designed to restore confidence in Federal justice? Answer: An order from the same court directing him to obey the law.

title: CONCERT: 3 PREMIERES IN COMPOSERS SERIES
description: THE concert that the American Composers Orchestra gave Monday evening in Alice Tully Hall was the fifth and last of its eighth season. As usual, the program mixed recent and older works by American composers, this time under the direction of two conductors, Paul Dunkel and Leonard Slatkin. Two of the pieces were world premieres and a third, Joseph Schwantner's ''Magabunda,'' received its first New York performance.

title: U.S. JOURNALIST APPEALS BAN BY COSTA RICA TO THE O.A.S.
description: A United States journalist appealed to a commission of the Organization of American States today for help in overturning the verdict of a court in Costa Rica that convicted him of illegally writing for publication there.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 16, 1984 International
description: -Mexico disagreements over Central America were expressed by President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid at a White House welcoming ceremony. The Mexican leader warned that the ''risk of a generalized war'' was growing in the region. Mr. Reagan said that responsible governments ''cannot afford to close their eyes to what is happening or be lulled by unrealistic optimism.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Opponents of Ferdinand E. Marcos appeared to be on the way to winning a larger bloc of seats in the Philippines's new National Assembly than had been expected before Monday's elections. (A1:5.)

title: GUILFORD RAIL SYSTEM NAMES FIRST PRESIDENT
description: Robert W. Anestis, a lawyer who makes no pretense of being a railroad expert, has just been named the first president of Guilford Transportation Industries, a privately owned railroad holding company. Since June 1982 he had been its executive vice president and chief planning and financial officer. The company was formed in 1981 by Timothy Mellon, its chairman and a member of the Pittsburgh banking family.

title: HOW TO MEASURE CHOLESTEROL
description: From the patient's perspective, measurement of cholesterol and other blood fats is one of the simplest of medical tests. After the patient has fasted for at least 12 hours, a physician takes a sample of the patient's blood and sends it to a laboratory, where the number of milligrams of cholesterol in the blood is determined.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described an agreement between National Shoes Inc. and the Butler Shoe Corporation. Butler Shoe will buy 115 shoe stores from National Shoes for $21 million.

title: Eagle Loss in Quarter
description: Eagle Computer Inc., the Los Gatos, Calif., maker of computers that are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's computers, said yesterday that it lost nearly $9.9 million in its fiscal third quarter on revenues of $10 million. In the quarter a year earlier, Eagle posted profits of $767,000, and sales also totaled $10 million. The company, which had previously predicted a more modest loss for the period ended March 31, also said that it expects a loss in the current quarter, although not as large.

title: FIRST THE BEETHOVEN AND THEN THE BUFFET
description: ONSTAGE the pianist Peter Serkin was in the last bars of Beethoven's Sonata No. 31 in A flat (Op. 110). The full house Monday evening in Symphony Space was quiet and still.

title: TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: YIELDS AT 6 1/4% TO 10% FOR CALIFORNIA'S BONDS
description: A $175 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9 percent in 1994 and 10 percent in 2009, through underwriters led by the Bank of America.

title: No Headline
description: Features/NotesMan in the News: David George

title: JOBLESS RATES: CONCERN RISES
description: A GROUP of leading economists, assembled by the Council on Foreign Relations, a nonprofit and nonpartisan foreign policy organization, concludes that unemployment, which has taken a back seat to inflation as the leading problem of the industrial countries in recent years, needs greater stress and action if the Western alliance is to avoid being torn apart.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES UP SHARPLY
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday by as much as 1 1/4 points, a large one-day gain that came in trading that was less hectic than the disorderly activity of the previous three trading sessions.

title: OMEGA HYDROCARBONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAUL KAPP
description: Paul Kapp, a New York music publisher, died yesterday at a nursing home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 76 years old and had lived in Hastings-on- Hudson, N.Y.

title: Home Is the Sailor
description: John Kretschmer , a 25-year-old skipper from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sailed into San Francisco Bay in a 32- foot sailboat named Gigi on Monday, ending what he described as an often- harrowing, 160-day, 15,500-mile voyage from New York round Cape Horn. Kretschmer, who plans to write a book about his trip, said he believed that Gigi was the smallest vessel ever and the first American yacht to make the New York-San Francisco trip round the southern tip of South America. He never had more than one crewman at a time and used a total of three on different legs of the journey.

title: Oilers' Blossoming on Their Home Ice
description: Glen Sather couldn't understand why people were acting as if the Oilers had their backs to the wall after losing last Saturday on Long Island. His optimism was dramatically backed up tonight by Edmonton's come-from- behind 7-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: Clarke Quits Playing
description: Bobby Clarke, who won three most- valuable-player awards and played on two Stanley Cup championship teams during a 15-year career with the Philadelphia Flyers, retired as a player, and was named the club's general manager. ''It's not an easy decision to give up playing a game and living a life I loved as much as hockey,'' the 34-year-old Clarke said.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: This year's first quarter results include 9 stores that were not in existence a year ago.

title: LIMELIGHT AT LAST FOR JOHN WIDEMAN
description: THE receipt of the P.E.N./ Faulkner Award last week for his novel ''Sent for You Yesterday'' has thrust 42-year- old John Edgar Wideman into the literary limelight. Moreover, it represents an important stop on the author's unconventional odyssey.

title: BRAND INSULATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the latest first quarter and $167,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: THE SAKHAROVS' FATE BECOMES A SOVIET SECRET
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Clarification

title: Tobacco CompaniesSued by Cancer Victims
description: Three lung cancer victims have sued 14 tobacco, distribution and advertising corporations, asserting that they were not warned that cigarettes were addictive.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times April 17 misidentified a school that has established a core curriculum based on a specific list of great books. It is St. John's College in Maryland.

title: SAY, HOW ABOUT A LITTLE RESPECT FOR RHUBARB?
description: WHAT rhubarb needs is an agent. Someone to give it cachet, like kiwis or fiddlehead ferns. As it stands now rhubarb's place in the culinary pecking order is somewhere above baked apples and below poached pears.

title: SPORTS TODAY Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. A left-hander, Ray Fontenot, will try to win his first game of the season for the Yankees.

title: Democratic Chief Urges Party to Pursue Unity
description: A group must be set up to reduce the blood-letting among the Democratic party's Presidential candidates in the closing weeks of the campaign, according to Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic National Chairman.

title: Household Notes
description: The Household Finance Corporation said it planned to sell $100 million of medium-term notes as part of a $400 million shelf registration it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission earlier this month. The company said that the maturities would range from nine months to 10 years and would be offered on a continuous basis though Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: GROUPS OF ARAB-AMERICANS AND JEWS BACK JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson received the joint endorsement of a group of Arab-Americans and a group of Jews and won a tumultuous welcome from 300 homosexual men and women in San Francisco's Mission District today as he campaigned for votes in the California primary June 5.

title: WAR IN GULF: WHAT HAPPENED TO 'FINAL' PUSH?
description: Military intelligence specialists, noting that the Iraqi-Iranian war has taken an unexpected turn, say new questions have been raised about what has happened to the ''final ground offensive'' that Iran had promised against Iraq. The questions have come as a result of reports that Iranian planes, following the Iraqi example, have begun bombing shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: Stock Increased By Texas Utilities
description: The Texas Utilities Electric Company increased its adjustable rate preferred stock financing to a million shares from 750,000 and is offering them at a price of 100 with an initial dividend of 11.04 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The stock is rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: G.O.P. AIDES ORGANIZE ON HOMOSEXUAL ISSUES
description: A group of Republican political activists, most of whom secretly lead homosexual lives, have begun organizing to counter what they say is the dominant influence of the party's conservative wing on the issue of homosexual rights.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MACY, R.H. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
COURT BACKS CHURCH'S PROPERTY FIGHT
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that a Presbyterian church in Schenectady was entitled to control its property, but refused to decide whether the church could secede from the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

title: Transierra Filing
description: The Transierra Exploration Corporation said it would file under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company said it had failed to work out a restructuring of its debt with its prime lender.

title: STORY BEHIND THE TONY FOR 'CARMEN'
description: ''LA TRAGEDIE DE CARMEN'' is being given a Special Tony Award ''for outstanding achievement in the lyric theater'' in part to avoid a labor dispute between producers and Actors Equity, according to some members of the committee that voted the award. The story behind the award indicates the pressures and compromises constantly at work in the theater industry.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DOCTORS' CORPS FILLS RURAL AND URBAN VOIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Vote for Olympia
description: The cry is to get the politicians out of the affairs of the Olympics. But not quite yet, please. One very astute politician - Ronald Reagan - has endorsed the idea of a permanent base, in Greece.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $40,300. c-Net loss.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE phone rang the other day. It was a young friend who is a hot shot in cable television and who used to call, quite faithfully, to brief us on social trends among her peers. We chided her for not calling in donkey's years and demanded to be given a trend. ''That's the trend - not calling,'' she said. ''I hardly ever talk on the phone any more. I talk almost exclusively to answering machines. This is definitely a trend with my peers who are busy. My nonbusy peers don't understand it yet.''

title: CITY AMBULANCE DRIVERS ALLOWED RELIGIOUS HATS
description: The president of the City Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that he had ordered ambulance supervisors to allow employees to ignore department's uniform requirements if the requirements interfered with religious practices.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Bakken , the former place- kicker for the St. Louis Cardinals, was named athletic director at St. Louis University. He succeeds Larry Preo , who resigned in March to take over as director of recreational sports at Purdue. . . . Alvin Davis , the Seattle Mariners' slugging rookie first baseman, who suffered a broken nose in a game against the Yankees Saturday night, will be out until next week, the club said after Davis had been examined by a specialist in New York. . . . Sam Kornhauser, the defensive coordinator at Norwich in Northfield, Vt., has been named head football coach and assistant professsor of physical education at Stony Brook on Long Island. . . . Darryl Gee, a Cosmos defender, was placed on the 21- day disabled list with a dislocated pelvis. . . . William Cash , president and chief operating officer of the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League, resigned, and Fred Bullard , the chairman, said he would take over his duties.

title: FREER TRADE AN AIM OF U.S. AT LONDON TALKS
description: At the London economic summit meeting next month, the Reagan Administration wants to negotiate curbs on government subsidies to exporters that the United States and other countries have adopted to support their farms and industries.

title: MEXICO TO SHIFT GUATEMALA EXILES FROM BORDER CAMPS TO SINGLE SITE
description: The Mexican Government is creating a single new community to house all 46,000 of the Guatemalan refugees it plans to remove from its southern border, a Mexican Interior Ministry official said today.

title: THORN-BRITISH AEROSPACE TALK
description: Thorn-EMI P.L.C., a leading British electronics and entertainment company, and British Aerospace P.L.C., which is 48 percent state-owned, said today that they had begun talks that could lead to a merger.

title: WINE IS HIS FAVORITESUBJECT
description: SAUSALITO, Calif.

title: PENTAGON SAYS MILITARY READINESS HAS IMPROVED SHARPLY SINCE 1981
description: The Deputy Secretary of Defense, William Howard Taft 4th, asserted today that the nation's armed forces were far better able to fight a war than they were when President Reagan took office three and a half years ago.

title: THEATER: 'THE HASTY HEART' REVIVED
description: WHILE other popular Broadway plays of the 1940's show their age, ''The Hasty Heart'' shows its mettle. In revival at the Mirror Repertory Theater, the John Patrick play has mellowed into a period piece that continues to touch audiences with an archetypal story about friendship under fire.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Chef's New Shop

title: Weinberger's Outside Income In '83 Was $285,680 or Over
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger made at least $285,680 in outside income last year, mostly from investments in money market funds and tax- exempt bonds, according to his 1983 financial statement.

title: Jury Is Selected For Brink's Trial
description: A jury of nine men and three women was selected today in the trial of Samuel Brown, the last of the defendants charged with murder and robbery in the 1981 holdup of a Brink's armored truck in Rockland County.

title: DOC OPTICS O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARCO'S OUTLOOK: ANALYSTS DIFFER
description: SHARES of the Atlantic Richfield Company enjoy considerable backing in brokerage- house research departments, but Standard & Poor's Outlook has just deleted the issue from its master list of ''foundation stocks for long-term gain.''

title: BILL FOR RELIGION IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS LOSES HOUSE VOTE
description: The House of Representatives today narrowly defeated legislation that would have made it possible for students in public high schools to meet voluntarily in free time in school for religious purposes.

title: FIRING UNIONS
description: Working people, under pressure to accept declines in their earnings and living standards, are haunted by the question of fairness. They read about tax bonanzas to the rich, ketchup for schoolchildren and leftover cheese for the poor. They read about profit-taking on Wall Street and astronomical bonus-taking by corporate executives. Now, the Supreme Court has joined the Administration on management's side of the bargaining table in interpreting and administering laws in ways that favor employers and injure working people and their unions.

title: ROSE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
A.T.& T. Backlog Increases
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told regulators today that its backlog of business orders for private long-distance phone lines had almost doubled since March and probably would not be eliminated nationwide until the end of the year.

title: Rain, Rain Go Away
description: The major athletic teams of DePauw University all enjoyed unbeaten home seasons during the 1983- 84 school year, but 32 days of rain and snow in Greencastle, Ind., during March and April probably helped to keep the Tigers' home record clean, if not dry.

title: MULTIMEDIA: A COLLAGE
description: JULIA HEYWARD, the SoHo performance artist who has done impressive experimental work in the field of music- video, has turned to multimedia performance pieces with rock instrumentation, slides and film. ''No Local Stops,'' the absorbing hour-and-a-half show she is presenting at Ohio, at 59 Greene Sreet, through next Sunday, features a versatile rock group called T-Venus that plays stark pop-jazz and light funk.

title: Lockheed Payout
description: The Lockheed Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share, the first dividend on common stock since December 1969, Roy Anderson, the company's chairman, said at the annual meeting. The dividend is payable June 11 to shareholders of record May 29. Mr. Anderson said the company's directors decided to resume dividends in the light of the downward trend in Lockheed's total debt. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Lockheed closed at $37.875, up 25 cents.

title: FLICKINGER, S.M. CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Turner Plans to Beam CNN to Europe
description: The Turner Broadcasting System plans to beam Cable News Network throughout Europe via satellite by next year, and eventually will also transmit programming from WTBS- TV, a so-called superstation, Judy Borza, a Turner representative, said Monday.

title: BLUNT TALK MARKS REAGAN'S WELCOME FOR MEXICO'S CHIEF
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES

title: BALLET: GALA BY SCHOOL
description: THE School of American Ballet, the New York City Ballet's school, holds annnual student performances that it modestly calls workshops. This year, in the Juilliard Theater, there were three - a benefit Monday night and two last Saturday, all commemorating the school's 50th-anniversary year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MONEY BAZAARS. Understanding the Banking Revolution Around Us. By Martin Mayer. 394 pages. Truman Talley/E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: FAMILIES A GOAL OF JEWISH STUDENTS
description: MOST of the Jewish college students questioned in a recent survey said they intend to marry and have at least two children, but a significant proportion of them said that marrying within their religion is not a primary goal.

description: b-Net income.

EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $473,598 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Including a gain of $869,258 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: U.S. REVIEWS ALLEGATION OF EFFORT TO BLUNT '82 INQUIRY ON DONOVAN
description: Federal prosecutors are looking into allegations that private investigators made secret tape recordings, obtained confidential documents and exploited rivalries between Senate staff members in seeking to counter a committee's investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in 1982.

title: THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $29,000.

title: MeningitisFatality Spurs Precautions
description: Some Long Island students are receiving antibiotics to protect them from a rare form of meningitis that killed a Garden City High School junior, a Nassau County health official said today.

title: Flickinger Takes Scrivner Offer
description: The S. M. Flickinger Company agreed to be acquired by Scrivner Inc. at $36 a share, the companies said. Based on Flickinger's approximately 4.8 million shares outstanding, the deal would be valued at nearly $173 million.

title: ANDREW D. WEINBERGER, LAWYER
description: Andrew D. Weinberger, a member of the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from 1943 to 1967, died of heart disease Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEXTER PERKINS, 94, EXPERT ON U.S. DIPLOMATIC HISTORY
description: Dr. Dexter Perkins, an authority on United States diplomatic history and chairman of the history department at the University of Rochester from 1925 until his retirement in 1954, died Saturday at the Brightonian Convalescent Care Center in Rochester. He was 94 years old and a longtime resident of Rochester.

title: A LINE DRIVE THAT SINKS IS AN OUT
description: Picture this play in the ninth inning of a World Series game.

DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
