title: CHILD-ABUSE CASELOADS ARE PROTESTED
description: Almost all the child-abuse caseworkers in the Manhattan office of the city's child welfare agency have signed a petition protesting ''intolerable working conditions'' and demanding immediate improvements in the city's efforts to protect children.

title: May 1-10 Auto Sales Jumped 25.5%
description: New-car sales in the first 10 days of May jumped 25.5 percent from the period a year earlier, the nation's major manufacturers reported today.

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MCNAMARA ON RECORD, RELUCTANTLY, ON VIETNAM
description: In two days of questioning this spring, Robert S. McNamara said he ceased to believe that the Vietnam War could be won not long after American combat troops were committed to the conflict in 1965.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Annette Green is hyperosmic. There are moments when it seems to her a measure of fate's cruelty that she must live in New York.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MONITOR LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IF THE SAKHAROVS DIE
description: A tragedy for mankind is unfolding in the city of Gorky, 260 miles east of Moscow. On May 2, Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, recipient of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize, began a hunger strike, declaring that he would ''fast to the very end'' if the Soviet Government did not let his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, go abroad for desperately needed medical attention. On May 12, Miss Bonner, in spite of a severe heart condition, joined her husband in the hunger strike. The Government responded by placing Miss Bonner under investigation for ''defaming the Soviet system,'' barring her from leaving Gorky and threatening to charge her with treason.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: MORENO, WINFIELD HELP YANKEES WIN
description: The A's center fielder twisted and turned, all night long it seemed. He circled to his right in the fifth inning before charging back, arms flailing helplessly. In the seventh he turned left and chased wildly for another long shot.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pursuing Trivial Pursuit

title: Jackson Hopes to Go To Soviet on Olympics
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has applied for a visa to visit the Soviet Union to try to persuade officials there to change their minds and participate in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: Iacocca Offers Deal on Prices
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, today offered to freeze the price of Chrysler's small cars and cut executive bonuses in half if the Reagan Administration would take action against what he said are currency and tax inequities that give Japanese auto makers a cost advantage of $1,600 a car.

title: FORMER EUCLID OFFICIAL JOINS BANNER INDUSTRIES
description: William Clay Hunt has been elected to the new position of president and chief operating officer of Banner Industries, Samuel J. Krasney, its chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: NEW IN CONDOMINIUM SALES: STOREFRONTS ON MADISON
description: Wherever rents have risen sharply in New York City, condominiums have followed. It began in New York's residential market, then spread to offices and industrial space, although the movement there was slow to start and is only now gathering momentum.

title: Changing Courts
description: The future for Len Elmore seems more likely to lead to the halls of Harvard Law School than to more of the noisy arenas of the National Basketball Association.

title: RUSS BERRIE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUSTICES RULE CITIES CAN BAN ALL SIGNS FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a city can bar all signs, including campaign posters, from public property without violating the free-speech rights of political candidates and their supporters.

title: ENERGY EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Greek Accused in Blast
description: The police issued a warrant today for the arrest of a shop owner after an explosion in his pizza parlor in downtown Athens on Monday injured 53 people, 14 seriously. The owner, Michalis Mavroyannis, was charged with negligence for failing to fix a gas leak in his shop, a police spokesman said.

title: SHANLEY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Pope Donates Bullet To Fatima Sanctuary
description: Pope John Paul II has donated a bullet that wounded him in Rome in May 1981 to the Roman Catholic sanctuary at Fatima, a sanctuary spokesman said today.

title: Bid for Carter Extended Again
description: The Limited Inc. said that it had been tendered 2.84 million common shares of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., at $35 a share, and that it had extended its offer once more, from midnight Monday until this Friday. The Limited, a retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, has been seeking 19 million shares of Carter Hawley in a tender offer conditioned on its receiving a minimum of 15.5 million shares.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHENEVER I am asked whether I eat junk food, my response is always ''It depends on what you mean.'' To me junk food means salty, nutritionally questionable snack foods, and those I rarely touch. But a lot of people include hamburgers in the junk-food category, and there I disagree.

title: OUT OF THE MANY, CHOICE SELECTIONS OF CALIFORNIA CABERNET
description: NOTHING in the wine books, the wine courses, the wine tours or any other wine experience can prepare one for the cabernet sauvignon scene. At any given moment, there are a couple of hundred wineries making California's premium red wine and each winery usually has two or three vintages on the market. Consistency may be the hobgoblin of small minds, but one longs for it after a few hours of trying to sort out labels, appellations, regions, vintages and styles. And states: Oregon and Washington make cabernet now, and however much their wine makers hate it, they are still lumped in with the Californians.

title: Pornography Dealer Given a Four-Year Term
description: A mother of five whom prosecutors have called the ''kiddie porn queen'' was sentenced today to a maximum of four years in prison for distributing child pornography.

title: CHINA'S PREMIER PROMOTES MARKET FORCES IN RESTRUCTURING OF ECONOMY
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang urged today that China devote greater attention to restructuring its domestic economy, while opening up further to commerce with the West.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rise in Dump Fee Upheld by Court
description: An appellate court today rejected a challenge to rate increases granted by the Board of Public Utilities to a Middlesex County garbage dump.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1.3 million for the quarter and $2.6 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $4.4 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: 'RETURN OF MARCUS WELBY' ON ABC
description: WHO has practiced 46 years, made 9,000 house calls and still believes, he says, that patients should be treated with love and understanding? Marcus Welby, that's who, and he is back tonight on ''The Return of Marcus Welby, M.D.'' The two-hour film will be seen on ABC at 9 o'clock.

title: Frederick Mayfield, 58, Dies; Doorman at the White House
description: Frederick Mayfield, 58 years old, the doorman at the White House, died of a heart attack Saturday.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results of the latest and year-ago quarters are not comparable because its principle objective is to sell or otherwise dispose of its assets and distribute proceeds to unit holders.

title: BETTER FARE IN OTHER CITIES
description: OVER the last 15 years I have seen more hotel rooms than I care to remember and have consumed more hotel food than anyone should be exposed to in a lifetime. Before going on trips in this country I used to do detailed research on restaurants to avoid falling hostage to hotel meals, which ranged from dismal to indifferent, even in the more luxurious establishments.

title: Former Navy Brig Gets First Inmates
description: The Department of Correction said last night that it was moving the first inmates into the new Brooklyn Correctional Facility, which was formerly the Navy Yard brig.

title: RACK TO ROAST OR GRILL
description: THE best way to cook fowl evenly is to suspend the roast so heat can circulate around it. When I roast a chicken, I begin cooking with the backbone side up, then during the next hour or so turn it three or four times to make sure it is exposed to the same amount of heat all over.

title: POSNER BID FOR CITY INVESTING
description: Victor Posner, the Miami-based financier, announced yesterday that an investors group that he heads has offered to acquire the City Investing Company for $52.50 a share in cash and stock. He put the value of the offer at about $2.4 billion.

title: Ex-Mayor Faces New U.S. Charges
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City was indicted today on additional charges of extorting money from businessmen and property owners in the resort community.

title: BRIEFING
description: Of M. Caldwell Butler

title: Hart Aide Charges That Mondale Is Unfair
description: Oliver Henkel, campaign manager for Senator Gary Hart, charged today that Walter F. Mondale was waging a campaign of ''distortions, fabrications, false rhetoric'' in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The conflagration in Central America appears too close to ignore. Like a fire in one's neighborhood, this threat should be of concern to every nation in the hemisphere.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Tentative Settlement Reached in Bias Suit
description: A tentative agreement was reached yesterday calling for payment of $7.5 million in settlement of a long- pending discrimation suit against the City University by female members of the faculty and staff.

title: DRIVER HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COAST MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
400 LEFT WITHOUT WORK BY FREEHOLD TRACK FIRE
description: The fire that destroyed the enclosed grandstand and clubhouse at Freehold Raceway earlier this month has left 400 people jobless and sent owners and trainers scrambling to find other tracks.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: TWO months into her yearlong treatment with five drugs to control breast cancer, Judy and her partner won the mixed doubles tournament at their New York club. When the medication makes her tired and nauseous, she works at home instead of going to the office.

title: D'ARCY SETS CHANGES IN ITS CHICAGO OFFICE
description: The Coca Cola Company today will announce a new $26 million national advertising campaign for its 21-year- old Tab diet soda. Tab, which had been Coca-Cola's leading diet soda until Diet Coke was introduced in 1982, has been reformulated and sweetened with Nutrasweet, a low- calorie sweetener used in its Diet Coke since August.

title: ANTIPOLLUTION-TOWER PLAN SPARKS FEUD IN QUEENS
description: More than 50 years ago, Charles Quick established a factory in Elmhurst, Queens. The business flourished while the neighborhood became residential, with tree-lined streets and well-kept homes.

title: STIX PIX NIXED
description: That there Miss Jane Fondar, she made a right good job of playin' a lady hayseed on the television t'other night, but I'uns wouldna seen it less'n this lady from Camden, New Jersey, said you'uns doan wanna sit around pickin' your fiddle all night long when the ABC got Miss Jane Fondar up a holler in Kentucky.

title: Michael Sedutto, 76, Is Dead; Partner in Ice Cream Concern
description: Michael Sedutto, a partner in the Sedutto Ice Cream Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of spumoni and biscuit tortoni, died Monday at Community Memorial Hospital, Toms River, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Toms River.

title: 2 SIDES INTENSIFY LOBBYING EFFORTS AS HOUSE BEGINS MISSILE DEBATE
description: As the House of Representatives began a crucial debate on the future of the MX missile today, supporters and opponents mounted last-minute lobbying efforts aimed at influencing what is likely to be a very close vote.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kings Hire McKinney
description: Jack McKinney , who was dismissed as coach of the Indiana Pacers after the team turned in the worst record in the National Basketball Association for two seasons in a row, has been named coach of the Kansas City Kings. He replaced Cotton Fitzsimmons , who resigned to take over as coach of the San Antonio Spurs. ''The Kings needed someone of good coaching caliber, and I believe I'm a good coach,'' said the 49-year- old McKinney, who was named N.B.A. coach of the year in 1981 after having led the Pacers to the playoffs with a 44-38 record in his first full season.

title: F.T.C. Allows Mobil Merger
description: The Government will not challenge the Mobil Corporation's proposed $5.7 billion takeover of the Superior Oil Company, Federal Trade Commission officials said today.

title: 16 Knicks, Celtics Fined
description: Darrell Walker of the Knicks, Danny Ainge of the Celtics and 14 of their teammates were fined $3,750 by the National Basketball Association today for their participation in a brawl during a playoff game last week at the Boston Garden. The fight, which lasted 5 minutes, broke out with 50 seconds remaining in the third period of Game 5 of the Eastern Conference semifinals, when Ainge fouled Walker as the Knick drove for the basket.

title: SEA CONTAINERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from the sale of container assets of $17,000. The company said that first quarter earnings were aided by the gain of $6,387,000 on the sale of one of the company's two large Contender-class vessels near the end of the period.

title: Few Highlights
description: When a National Football League team has a 3-12-1 record, as the Giants did last fall, the people who make a 25-minute highlight film may have to stretch to find enough positives.

title: SOUTH BOSTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: South Boston converted to a public stock company on Nov. 9 with issuance of 3,081,192 shares. Per share figures have been stated to reflect the issuance of these shares as if they had been outstanding during the second quarter and first half of fiscal 1983.

title: CACHE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: REAL ESTATE FEES TERMED TOO HIGH
description: A Federal Trade Commission staff report said today that many buyers and sellers of private homes were paying more than they had to because of real estate practices and a lack of knowledge.

title: Franklin Products
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation of Pennsauken, N.J., introduced several personal computers, the CX series, that can run on three different operating systems within the same unit. The company said its new models are compatible with a variety of other computers, including Apple, Kaypro and Osborne, and can run some International Business Machines Personal Computer programs without modification. The CX models, which are portable, are priced from $1,395 to about $2,650 and include a monitor and word processing, spreadsheet, graphics and spelling programs.

title: OFFICIALS RAISING FIRE CODE ISSUE IN BLAZE AT PARK
description: The Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park here was allowed to operate its Haunted Castle attraction without smoke detectors even though the Town Assessor had ruled that it fell under fire codes that required the detectors and other safety devices, former and present town officials said today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE Jam never found a substantial audience in the United States, but in England it was the most popular rock group of the late 1970's and early 80's. Paul Weller, the Jam's singer, songwriter and guitarist, was widely admired, by critics as well as fans, for his outspoken support of nuclear disarmament and his idealist populism.

title: HENRIETTE LUND
description: Henriette Lund, a social worker and former welfare consultant to the National Lutheran Council, now known as the Lutheran Council in the U.S.A., died Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: DEATH SQUADS IN INDONESIA SAID TO KILL 4,000
description: A typical killing begins when a group of armed men, unknown in the neighborhood or village, appear at a doorway in the middle of the night. A man, later identified by the authorities as a criminal, is taken away by force. In a day or so his bullet-riddled body is found nearby, where it has been deposited after the killing in some more distant place. Sometimes the killers leave 10,000 rupiahs, about $10, on the body to cover the cost of burial.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Radioactivity Found in Workers
description: Tests on four employees of a sewage treatment plant contaminated by a radioactive substance found no signs of radioactivity in their lungs or bones, the State Health Department said today.

title: OPERA CONDUCTOR-TRANSLATOR
description: Thomas Martin, an opera conductor best known for the many English-language opera translations he wrote with his wife, Ruth, died of a heart attack Monday morning. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COURT INCREASES ARREST RESTRAINS
description: The Supreme Court today strengthened the constitutional protection against arrests without warrants in private homes.

SHAW INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KIDNAPPED U.S. COUPLE RELEASED BY GUERRILLA GROUP IN SRI LANKA
description: An American couple kidnapped and held for five days under threat of death was set free tonight.

title: 1892 GAUGUIN IS SOLD
description: Paul Gauguin's ''Mata Mua,'' a rare 1892 scene from the artist's first trip to the South Pacific, was purchased last night at auction by Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, a Swiss industrialist and art collector.

title: Schmidt Clouts No. 400
description: Mike Schmidt blasted the 400th home run of his career, and Len Matuszek cracked a two-run homer and drove in four runs as the Philadelphia Phillies rolled to a 12-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: Southwest Forest Cancels Takeover
description: Southwest Forest Industries said it had terminated an agreement in principle to be acquired by a group of investors, including some members of management, for $24 a share.

description: The story ended yesterday morning where it began nearly three years ago - under the Biltmore clock.

description: Construction of the Westway would result in a ''significant adverse impact'' on the Hudson River striped bass population, but there is a ''reasonable chance'' that the impact can be lessened, the Army Corps of Engineers said yesterday.

O'NEILL ASSAILS A REPUBLICAN AND IS REBUKED BY THE CHAIR
description: A political wrestling match between House Democratic leaders and conservative Republicans rose to a new level of anger and recrimination today.

title: Jurists Criticize U.S.
description: The International Commission of Jurists today condemned the decision by the United States not to recognize the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice on matters relating to Latin America. The United States move was announced April 6, before a ruling by the World Court last Friday that the United States should stop attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Nikolai Nekrasov, Specialist On the Resources of Siberia
description: Nikolai N. Nekrasov, a leading Soviet economist specializing in Siberian resource development, died in Moscow this month, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported May 6. He was 77 years old.

description: Senator Gary Hart today won the Democratic Presidential primary in Nebraska by more than 2 to 1 over Walter F. Mondale.

CONCERT: 20TH CENTURY BY AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: NOTA BENE, a composers' organization dedicated to 20th-century music that is ''both beautiful and melodic,'' presented three new or recent orchestral works Sunday at Tully Hall, with the American Symphony Orchestra under Peter Bellino. The concert was a polemic - and not, be it regretfully noted, a persuasive one - for the return to past concepts of beauty and melody that has been espoused by a striking number of composers in recent years.

title: HELMS IS REPORTEDLY REBUKED BY SENATE
description: The chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence have rebuked Senator Jesse Helms for disclosing secret committee information in violation of the rules of the Senate, according to two committee members and sources close to the committee.

description: b-Includes a gain of $732,849 on the sale of a plant in California in November 1983.

description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago said yesterday that it had borrowed yesterday and Monday against its $4.5 billion emergency credit line from 16 leading American banks.

description: The share earnings were adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 50 percent stock dividend distributed March 27.

title: REGIONAL VOTE ON SCHOOL ACCESS
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House defeated legislation that would have permitted student-initiated religious groups to meet in public secondary schools outside class hours. A two-thirds vote of 281 lawmakers was needed for passage.

title: Nippon Statement
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation has filed a registration statement for the sale of $150 million of guaranteed notes due in 1994 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes, which are guaranteed by Japan and are not callable before maturity, will be subject to annual sinking fund payments of $20 million beginning in 1988.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $695,000 for the quarter and a gain of $13,739,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,193,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income including income of $556,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $109,000. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,516,000 and a tax credit of $109,000.

title: OILERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS AND TAKE SERIES LEAD, 2-1
description: The Islanders finally saw the other side of the Edmonton Oilers tonight, the scoring side, and the cost for looking was a 7-2 drubbing that placed the defending champions in a 2-1 disadvantage in their four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup final playoff series.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no share earnings for the latest periods because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: John Jay Keeps
description: Baseball Title Roberto Minaya hit a home run and a triple to drive in three runs as John Jay defeated Lehman, 11-6, yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium and won the City University of New York championship for the second straight year.

title: DISPUTE RESUMES OVER 'BLACK FOCUS'
description: A dispute resumed this week over a television program about Jewish- black relations that was part of a series canceled by WNYC in January.

title: FOLKS RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JERSEY FACING PROSPECT OF A PRIMARY THAT COUNTS
description: Unlike New Hampshire voters, who are accustomed to the national spotlight of a Presidential primary, New Jersey residents have come to expect that their primary will be too late to make any difference.

title: Lakers Win for 2-0 Lead
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson set a league playoff record with 24 assists, and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 21 points tonight to lift the Los Angeles Lakers to a 118-102 victory over the Phoenix Suns and a 2-0 lead in their Western Conference championship series.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOES OF MARCOS APPEAR TO MAKE BIG VOTE GAINS
description: The opposition to President Ferdinand E. Marcos appeared today to be on the way to winning a larger bloc of seats in the new National Assembly than had been expected before Monday's parliamentary elections.

title: HART WINS EASILY OVER MONDALE IN VOTING IN OREGON AND NEBRASKA
description: Senator Gary Hart defeated Walter F. Mondale by almost a 2-to-1 margin in the Oregon primary today. The Rev. Jesse Jackson finished a distant third.

title: HOLMES-COETZEE FIGHT IS OFF
description: The Larry Holmes-Gerrie Coetzee heavyweight title fight, scheduled for June 8 in Las Vegas, Nev., ran out of money and time yesterday and was called off, not by the promoters or fighters, but by the site.

title: SCREEN: DANISH 'ZAPPA'
description: ''Zappa'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 3. The film opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

title: Turkey Blocks Petition Signed by Intellectuals
description: The martial law authorities today blocked publication of a petition signed by 1,256 Turkish intellectuals denouncing press censorship and other features of military rule, newspaper editors said.

title: No Headline
description: Brazil Killings Spur Concern Over a Death Squad Revival

title: 2 MEDICAL SCHOOLS CLOSED IN SCANDAL
description: Three thousand medical students from the United States have been cut off from classes in the Dominican Republic as a result of the closing of two large medical schools implicated in schemes to sell medical diplomas.

FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TWO PARTY CHAIRMEN WEIGH PLAN TO ASSUME DEBATES' SPONSORSHIP
description: The chairmen of the Republican and Democratic Parties are considering a plan under which their organizations would take over from the League of Women Voters the sponsorship of Presidential debates in the general election campaign, according to Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: Clippers Moving To Los Angeles
description: The San Diego Clippers announced today that they had moved their National Basketball Association franchise to Los Angeles and would play home games at the Sports Arena starting next season.

description: Stock prices finished with minor changes yesterday in heavier trading after dropping sharply in recent sessions because of rising interest rates.

No Headline
description: New Computer From NEC NEC Information Systems, the United States subsidiary of the NEC Corporation, a major Japanese electronics company, introduced a desktop computer to compete with the I.B.M. Personal Computer. The company said its new system would retail for $1,995, including a single disk drive for data storage and 128,000 characters of internal memory.

title: MISSOURI'S AUDITOR HEADS NEW BOARD
description: James Antonio, the State Auditor of Missouri, has been appointed chairman of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, which came into being last Friday.

DIET TO PREVENT HEART ATTACKS AIMS TO CUT BLOOD FAT LEVELS
description: The American Heart Association, encouraged by recent proof that lowering high cholesterol can prevent heart attacks, yesterday outlined an aggressive and progressive dietary plan to help Americans lower their blood fat levels.

title: Engine for Airbus
description: International Aero Engines said it had signed an agreement with Airbus Industrie of France under which Airbus's A320 aircraft would be powered by International's V2500 engine. International, based in East Hartford, Conn., is a consortium of five companies: the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford, Rolls-Royce of Britain, Motoren- und Turbinen- Union M"unchen G.m.b.H. of West Germany, Fiat Aviazione S.p.A. of Italy and the Japanese Aero Engines Corporation.

title: Twins' Ticket Blitz The great Twins' ticket buyout began in Minneapolis yesterday as
description: Harvey Mackay , a local businessman, walked up to the Minnesota box office and ordered 45,400 tickets to games in the Metrodome.

title: Cubs 6, Reds 3
description: Gary Matthews had four hits, and Mel Hall and Ron Cey had key blows in a three-run fourth inning that carried the Chicago to victory.

description: Bristol-Myers Co. says Bruce S. Gelb, executive vice president, will assume responsibility for its health care businesses, and the company has named five new group presidents: Nicholas M. Evans, consumer products; Charles A. Heimbold Jr., health care; Wayne A. Davidson, U.S. pharmaceutical and nutritional; Joseph E. Maroun, Bristol-Myers international, and Dr. Abramo Virgilio, science and technology.

title: WASTE AT THE CORE OF OUR HEALTH SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: METS TOP GIANTS IN 11 INNINGS
description: The Mets are proudly counting comeback victories this season and they would be within their rights to count tonight's twice. On their second brave rally, in the 11th inning, the Mets scored an unearned run on Keith Herandez's sacrifice fly to beat the Giants, 7-6, for their 10th come-from- behind victory, eighth in one-run games, and third in extra innings.

title: STAGE: 'SOUVENIRS,' TOURISTS ON A MYTHICAL ISLAND
description: SHELDON ROSEN'S play ''Souvenirs'' is so crisply written, directed and performed that you wish it were one instead of - unwittingly - two plays. As co-produced by the New York Theater Workshop and New York Theater Studio and presented at the Cubiculo Theater, the play is never less than professional at the same time that it is experimental in its multimedia effects.

title: REPUBLICANS OFFER CHANGE IN REAGAN BUDGET PLAN
description: The Republican leadership in the Senate this evening offered a compromise amendment to the President's deficit-reducing package that is aimed at winning enough Republican support to assure Senate approval of the Administration's plan.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CBS MOVIE BASED ON KIPLING'S 'KIM'
description: STORIES about India as a colony of the British Empire are understandably fond of identity crises. HBO's ''Far Pavilions'' featured a hero torn between England, the land of his dead parents, and India, where he was raised as the son of a servant. A similar device was used by Rudyard Kipling in the tale of ''Kim,'' the son of Irish parents - his last name is O'Hara - who is raised as an Indian orphan. A 1950 film starred Dean Stockwell as Kim and a supporting cast that included Errol Flynn and Paul Lukas. Tonight at 8 o'clock on CBS, television is offering its own three-hour version of ''Kim.''

title: PANEL REJECTS A REAGAN NOMINEE AFTER 3-DAY HEARING ON BLACKLIST
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today rejected President Reagan's nominee for deputy director of the United States Information Agency.

title: Petro-Lewis Posts a Loss
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, the nation's largest seller of oil and gas income funds, today reported a loss of $46,000 for its fiscal third quarter, citing a sharp drop in revenues from a year earlier. The company, which has been struggling since the oil slump began, had profits of $12 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, 1983.

PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. TO SPEND MILLIONS ON LATIN BASES
description: The Defense Department plans to spend $149 million to build military installations in Central America and the Caribbean in the next four years, according to a Pentagon report.

title: Bush, in India, Defends Arms Sales to Pakistan
description: Vice President Bush, ending a four-day visit to India, today defended American arms sales to Pakistan's military Government and expressed hope that Pakistan would ''move forward to its democratic objectives.''

title: MOROCCANS ENTERTAIN ISRAELIS
description: Crown Prince Mohammed was host at a dinner Monday night for delegates to a conference of Moroccan Jews that included an official 35-member group from Israel.

title: Genetic Defect Linked To Cancer in Children By The Associated Press
description: Researchers have identified a genetic defect that triggers a kidney tumor that is one of the most common children's cancers. The finding could lead to simpler diagnosis and better treatment of the disease.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Police Blotter
description: A post office at 805 McDonough Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn was held up by the same man yesterday for the second time in less than three weeks. The robber told a clerk shortly after 10 A.M. that he had a gun in his pocket and that he was ''a sick man.''

title: CONCERT: A CLARINET AND SOPRANO
description: THE concert Sunday by the clarinetist Michael Limoli and the soprano Elizabeth Poore Dolbashian's at Carnegie Recital Hall was truly a joint endeavor. Not only did the two artists share an accompanist - the reliable Benton Hess - and some repertory, but they also seemed directly attuned to each other's musical instincts.

title: The Oxford Dictionary Is Being Computerized
description: The O.E.D. - the 13-volume Oxford English Dictionary - in the next few years will be computerized into what will be called the N.O.E.D. - the New Oxford English Dictionary - at a cost of about $10 million, it was announced yesterday by the Oxford University Press. When completed, the N.O.E.D. will constitute the largest electronic dictionary database in existence.

title: COVER-UPS FOR THE BEACH; FOR SEEING IN THE DARK
description: 1.*Hardly Rags

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: The company said that the net for both 1984 and 1983 included after-tax capital gains of $1.5 million from a real estate sales agreement made in 1982.

title: A New Beginning for Jets
description: The Jets opened a four-day mini-camp for their veterans, who returned to a place with new names over many lockers. Since the end of their disappointing 7-9 season, seven starters or former starters, including the quarterback Richard Todd, have either been traded, cut or moved to the United States Football League.

title: SALVADOR ELECTION PANEL RULES OUT A RECOUNT
description: The Central Elections Council late tonight rejected the petition by the far right candidate for a recount of the vote in the presidential election.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it had no sales for the year-ago quarter and 6 months. Revenue figures given comprise interest income only.

title: Industrial Production Up by 1.4%
description: Industrial production rose 1.4 percent in April, almost three times the March increase, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, as the economy continued to rebound from its March lull.

title: REUTERS OFFER SPANS ATLANTIC
description: Reuters, the British financial information and news service, is expected to raise as much as $373 million for itself and for its owners in an unusual trans-Atlantic stock sale next month, its underwriters said yesterday.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hope for Castino
description: John Castino , the Twins' third baseman who batted .444 in eight games, has missed most of the season with a painful back ailment. According to the team physycian, Dr. Harvey O'Phelan , if he is to return before the end of the season, he may have to remain on the sidelines eight more weeks while he tries a new treatment for a bulging spinal disk. The doctor has recommended enzyme injections as the best way to dissolve the disk.

title: THE PRIDE OF CASTRO'S CUBA: A PRE-CASTRO CABARET
description: It is 10:40 P.M. in a lush tropical forest in a residential section of Havana. Suddenly, trumpets blare, a stage rises in a clearing and through an arc of pulsing crimson lights strides a corps of dancing women in tiny gold and silver lame costumes with huge plumed bustles and towering hats of fruits and palms.

title: Yugoslavia Changes Cabinet and Presidency
description: Prime Minister Milka Planinc announced nine new Cabinet members today in Yugoslavia's biggest Government shuffle since World War II.

title: VICTOR D. ZIMINSKY, A FORMER PRESIDENT OF UNION NEWS CO.
description: Victor D. Ziminsky, former president of the Union News Company and a department store executive who was active in Catholic charities and social services, died Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Bridge:South Africans Missing Out On the World Level of Play
description: An explosive issue was temporarily defused eight months ago when South Africa tactfully announced that it would not enter teams in the 1984 World Team Championship.

title: PICKENS SEEKS MESA ROYALTY
description: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company and one of the nation's foremost exponents of royalty trusts, said yesterday that he was prepared to pay $35 a share, or $570 million in cash, to buy back the Mesa Royalty Trust. Mr. Pickens created the trust himself nearly five years ago to reward stockholders and avoid corporate taxes.

title: Laboratory Blast Kills Man
description: A blast at Megabar Inc., an explosives research laboratory, killed one man and seriously injured another Monday, the authorities said. John Peterson, vice president of Megabar, said the blast occurred during an experiment but was unsure what kind of experiment it was. The dead man was identified as Harvey A. Jessop, 42 years old, of Lehi.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Prosecution Rests In the Pisani Trial
description: Federal prosecutors completed their case yesterday against State Senator Joseph R. Pisani on charges that he embezzled more than $80,000 and failed to report the money on his tax returns.

title: Two to Be Honored At Theater Benefit
description: The playwright William Gibson and the director Arthur Penn will be honored at a benefit given by Staret, the Directors Company and the Writer's Theater next Monday at 7 P.M. in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on April 10 about a bill in the New York State Legislature to provide tuition assistance to Vietnam veterans incorrectly reported criticism of the bill's Assembly sponsor, John F. Duane, Democrat of Queens. While individual members of the Jewish War Veterans of New York criticized him, the state organization itself took no position.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS BY THE TWO PRESIDENTS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico at an arrival ceremony at the White House today, as recorded by the White House: President Reagan

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Scavenger Hunt For Celebrities

title: Block Asserts Texan Seeks to Replace Him
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said Monday that Jim Hightower, the Agriculture Commissioner of Texas, an outspoken critic of Reagan Administration policies, appeared to be campaigning to replace him.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $592,000 and an extraordinary charge of $2,692,000. c-After a loss of $267,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains from foreign currency translation of $11,000 for the quarter and $6,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from foreign currency translation of $43,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 6 months.

title: COPING WITH REALITIES AT SCHOOL IN THE BRONX
description: When Grace M. Rosa was sent to the Bronx five years ago to become the principal of Christopher Columbus High School, it was for her much more than a promotion. Mrs. Rosa was coming home.

title: THE SAKHAROVS' FATE BECOMES A SOVIET SECRET
description: To the Editor:

title: CELTICS ROMP IN OPENER OF EASTERN FINAL
description: Coach K. C. Jones of the Boston Celtics said he was worried going into the game.

title: Lilco Turns Down Gas Company Bid
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited bid to purchase its gas operations.

title: 5 RETAILERS POST GAINS IN QUARTER
description: Five of the nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported sharply higher net income in their most recent fiscal quarter, ended April 28. But the largest of those reporting, the Federated Department Stores Inc., had lower earnings, citing the change of its profit-sharing plan to a pension plan and pricing competition in its supermarket division.

title: 25th Anniversary
description: To celebrate their 25th season of pro football, the original eight members of the American Football League will wear special logos on their uniforms next season.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in the De Gustibus column on the Style page last Saturday gave an incorrect amount for the butter in baked garlic heads. A quarter cup should be used.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Borman Stays in Post
description: Frank Borman, the 56-year-old chairman of Eastern Airlines, today accepted a five-year contract. He earns $331,524 a year but has taken a 22 percent pay cut, along with other employees. He had worked without a contract since becoming chairman in 1976.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Espionage Is Hinted At a British Inquest
description: A Russian-born woman whose husband, a British banker, died under mysterious circumstances in Moscow told a coroner's inquest today that he had had contacts with both Soviet and British agents.

title: PRECISION FILM & VIDEO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $70,500. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of 1,981,823.

title: JUDGE'S RULING REVIVES DISPUTE ON MARBLE HILL
description: The tiny community of Marble Hill has seen its geopolitical fortunes bobble back and forth across the Spuyten Duyvil for almost 90 years, unsure whether its true home was in Manhattan or the Bronx.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 14
PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUOMO URGED BY ANDERSON TO ACT ON SHOREHAM PLANS
description: The Senate majority leader urged Governor Cuomo today to participate in an ''honest test'' of an emergency evacuation plan at the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island.

description: b-Including income of $57,000 from discontinued operations.

title: JETS' PROBLEM: WHERE TO USE KLECKO
description: In the strange new world of the Jets, where players read the depth chart to see if they are still on the team, Joe Klecko is listed at two positions.

title: Hewlett's Net Jumps 29.4%
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal second quarter rose 29.4 percent, on a rise in sales of 29.9 percent.

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $27,076. c-Including a capital gain of $53,332.

title: MISSILE TOTAL CUT
description: The House of Representatives adopted a compromise proposal tonight that would keep the MX missile in the nation's arsenal but in a significantly reduced and restricted form. The vote, on a major amendment, was 229 to 199.

title: Japan Buses in Turkey
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation signed agreements today with Termo-Mekanik Sanayi ve Ticaret of Turkey to make and sell buses in that country. Mitsubishi plans to assemble 200 buses a year, increasing to 2,000 a year by 1990.

title: Yes Plays a ConcertAt the Garden
description: Theatrical excess is built into the music of Yes, the British band that played Monday in Madison Square Garden. In a typical Yes song, the band will burble along gently while its leader, Jon Anderson, sings of mystical notions in his piping countertenor.

title: SOVERN WARNS OF WAR AT COLUMBIA GRADUATION
description: Under gray skies that released showers upon confetti, balloons and tassels, good humor and champagne were plentiful as Columbia University yesterday conferred graduate and undergraduate degrees to 7,500 students at its 230th commencement.

title: Reversal Sought in Bias Case
description: Civil rights advocates urged Congress today to undo the effects of a Supreme Court decision that they said narrowed the scope of laws banning discrimination at schools and colleges.

title: Widowers Win Round In Drunken Driving Case
description: The Texas Supreme Court today upheld a decision that allows the husbands of two women killed in an accident involving a drunken driver to sue the driver's employer.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RENAISSANCE MAN TAKES CARE OF SWALE
description: Every morning for the last two months, Michael Klein has heard the same questions: How is your horse? Is he feeling good? How did he sleep and eat today?

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Financial Corp. Buys Zero Coupon Securities
description: The Financial Corporation of America, a Los Angeles-based savings and loan holding company, has arranged through the First Boston Corporation to buy about $225 million face amount of zero coupon Treasury securities, which it will use to help pay the costs of more than $1 billion of good will it paid in last year's acquisition of the First Charter Corporation, a savings and loan association.

title: Florida Votes Banking Law
description: The Florida Legislature today approved regional interstate banking, a major step toward forming a banking district among states in the Southeast.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 21
A HOSPITAL CELEBRATES 100 YEARS IN THE BATTLE TO VANQUISH CANCER
description: It was exactly 100 years ago today - in the days when the streets of New York were filled with gas lamps and horse-drawn carriages - that a wealthy young woman named Elizabeth H. Cullum stood at the upper reaches of Central Park and unveiled the cornerstone for a structure that would change the direction of health care.

title: WOMEN FACE LOW PAY AFTER LOSING STEEL JOBS
description: Lured by good pay and the satisfaction of working with her hands, Sheryl Johnson turned to the steel mills in the late 1970's, a time of job opportunities for women and members of minority groups.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective February 1984.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HERE are some new products and materials that will help the do-it-yourselfer with home improvement projects and speed up or simplify work on maintenance problems:

title: POTVIN PROVIDES MYSTERY ELEMENT
description: Coach Al Arbour, standing in the middle of the fun and frolic of the annual National Hockey League luncheon, today explained why Denis Potvin of the Islanders so mysteriously left Game 3 of the Stanley Cup final after only two periods Tuesday night.

title: STREET-LEVEL LIVING IN A HIGH-RISE CITY
description: A GROWING number of small specialty shops have been springing up in Manhattan. These emporiums, with a sense of their own style, offer a new and enticing array of home furnishings, practical and fanciful, affordable and extravagant.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results have been translated at the rate of 14.002 Philippine pesos per $1 for the latest first quarter and 9.4462 Philippine pesos per $1 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: Big Crabs

title: PLAN FOR SHELTER FACES CHALLENGE BY BROOKLYNITES
description: A group of Brooklyn officials and neighbors are challenging the Koch administration's plan to open a shelter for the homeless in a building that the Board of Estimate set aside last November for a day-care center.

title: DAON DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: NationalGalleryOfficial ToHeadTexasMuseum
description: -century art at the National Gallery in Washington, has been appointed director of the Fort Worth Art Museum in Texas.

title: TAKING DEEP BREATHS ON A JOB PLAN
description: A delegation from the National Conference of Black Mayors will visit President Reagan's Rose Garden Thursday, but its members say they will have a wary eye out for the thorns.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SECRET ARMS AID FOR SALVADORANS BARRED IN HOUSE
description: The Reagan Administration has reportedly developed a plan to send some military equipment to El Salvador secretly through the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Tax System Hearings Set
description: The Treasury Department announced today that public hearings would be held in seven cities next month on suggestions for changing the Federal tax system. The hearings will be held in Atlanta, June 20; Houston, June 8; Los Angeles, June 12; Minneapolis-St. Paul, June 19; New York, June 25; Springfield, Ill., June 28 and Washington on June 6 and June 26. Anyone wishing to testify should write to the Treasury Tax Reform Study, Department of the Treasury, P.O. Box 299, Washington, D.C., 20044

description: From the short story ''The Girls in Their Summer Dresses'':

LLOYD MCCORKLE, PRISONS AIDE
description: Dr. Lloyd W. McCorkle, Commissioner of New Jersey's corrections system from 1963 to 1971 and a professor at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice until last December, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Titusville, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: PLAN TO OMIT RIGHTS AMENDMENT FROM PLATFORM BRINGS OBJECTIONS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the chairman of the Democratic platform committee, suggested today that the party's platform drop specific mention of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Federal Constitution.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quiet Big Stick
description: Don't count Ken Linseman among the Edmonton Oilers who think that Billy Smith is overly aggressive with his goalie stick.

title: Eritrean Rebels Report Killing 700 Ethiopians
description: The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said today that its forces had killed about 700 Ethiopian soldiers in a battle around the guerrilla stronghold of Nakfa on May 12-13, and many more Ethiopian soldiers were killed, wounded or captured in subsequent ambushes.

title: HELMS A FOCUS OF CONTROVERSY ON DISCLOSURE OF SENATE DATA
description: Senator Jesse Helms found himself in the center of a controversy among his Senate colleagues today as he vehemently denied that he had disclosed information from the Senate intelligence committee.

title: ON LACROSSE FIELD, GOALIE REFINES SKILL
description: PHILADELPHIA This spring, the end of the lacrosse season came suddenly for

title: No 'Red Wheat' Class
description: A proposal that would have established a new ''red wheat'' class under Federal grain inspection standards has been rejected, the Agriculture Department said. Kenneth A. Gilles, administrator of the department's Federal Grain Inspection Service, said on Tuesday that grain trade comments on the proposal had mostly been against it.

title: German Appeals Court Bans Ex-Nazi Reunion
description: A West German appeals court today banned a group of Nazi veterans from holding a reunion next week, ruling that counterdemonstrations that are planned would threaten order and security.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: OPENING The Museum of Modern Art, closed since January for renovation, reopens today, particularly heartwarming tidings for displaced cinemaphiles whose habitat over decades has been the uniquely cozy screening rooms where they have gaped at the world's finest old movies. The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2, a new theater completed before the big refurbishing began, will serve as the museum's sole film center until the theater's larger partner, No. 1, joins it in October.

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHNIQUES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SAUDI SHIP IN GULF HIT BY WARPLANES
description: Unidentified warplanes attacked a Saudi oil tanker today in the Persian Gulf, reportedly starting a fire but not crippling the vessel. It was the fifth tanker attack in the gulf in the last three weeks as the focus of the Iraqi- Iranian war has shifted to attacks on shipping.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Seligman & Latz
description: Seligman & Latz Inc. said its directors had found inadequate a revised offer of about $20 a share from the City Stores Company.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONTENDERS ASSESS OLYMPIC ISSUE
description: The Soviet Union's decision not to participate in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer will be cited in the campaign against President Reagan as another indication of the deterioration in Soviet-American relations, according to the contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination and their aides.

title: BALLET: TWYLA THARP
description: ONCE complimented about ''Sc enes de Ballet,'' which he choreographed in 1948, Sir Frederick Ashton replied, ''Yes, but it's a ballet for specialists.''

title: SOLOMON AMENDMENT: UNFAIR AND BAD POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: IRWIN SHAW, EXTOLLED FOR SHORT STORIES, DIES
description: Irwin Shaw, for more than 40 years a prolific and successful writer of short stories, plays, screenplays and novels - most notably the World War II saga ''The Young Lions'' - died of a heart attack yesterday in a hospital in Davos, Switzerland. He was 71 years old.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on April 28 misidentified the company signing a merger agreement with Jefferson Bankshares Inc. of Charlottesville, Va. It was the Citizens Trust Company of Portsmouth, Va.

title: Revised Offer Made For Scott & Fetzer
description: A group led by Ivan Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, said today that it had modified its offer to acquire the Scott & Fetzer Company, dropping two conditions objected to by the company.

title: Christopher Trakas, Baritone, in Debut
description: Christopher Trakas, a winner of the 1983 Young Concert Artists Auditions, was presented by the contest organization in his New York debut at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night. A baritone with a smoothly produced voice of moderate size and pleasing bright quality, he brought in a program that touched many bases and called for the participation of three assisting musicians - Steven Blier, pianist and harpsichordist, Paula Robison, flutist, and Ronald Thomas, cellist.

title: Robert Barr, Pianist, In Carnegie Recital Hall
description: Robert Barr opened his debut piano concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last Saturday with the New York City premiere of Ted Hansen's ''Configuration for Piano.'' This aptly named work, seemingly discursive yet in fact rigorously formal, has elements borrowed from several composers - most notably George Crumb and Prokofiev - yet retains a granitic individual profile.

title: ACF INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $537,000 and a tax credit of $137,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,627,000 and a tax credit of $478,000.

title: Stunt Fliers Going Abroad
description: The Thunderbirds stunt flying team will take to the air over nine European countries on its first tour across the Atlantic in 13 years, the Air Force said today.

title: JUDGE IN '68 TEACHER-STRIKE CASE
description: Francis J. Bloustein, a retired State Supreme Court justice, died last night at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 77 years old.

title: C. A. Keusseoglou, 64; Cruise Line President
description: Charalambos A. Keusseoglou, founder and president of Sun Line and a leader in the cruise industry for more than three decades, died yesterday in Monte Carlo. He was 64 years old.

title: ARTS-LETTERS CEREMONY
description: At the annual ceremonial of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday, Octavio Paz, the Mexican author and former diplomat, recalled the first time that he met John Kenneth Galbraith, the American economist and former diplomat - and president of the academy-institute - when both served as ambassadors to India in the 1960's.

title: Newsweek Says Writer Left Moscow After Harassment
description: Official of Newsweek magazine said yesterday that the Moscow bureau chief for the magazine had left the country voluntarily because of ''outrageous trumped-up charges.''

title: STARTS SOAR BY 19.3% IN HOUSING
description: Construction of new housing, rebounding from its sharpest monthly downturn in history, soared by 19.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. Although the figure seemed to signal a strong beginning for the second quarter, analysts cautioned that rising interest rates could soon dampen activity.

title: COALITION TO SUPPORT TOUGHER WARNINGS ON CIGARETTE PACKS
description: Both a coalition of public health groups and representatives of the tobacco industry agreed today to support legislation to require tougher health warnings on cigarette packages and advertising.

description: THERE are five garbage cans clustered in front of Sidney Thayer's ground-floor window on West 113th Street, a worrisome fact, though Mr. Thayer, an associate producer of sports films, shrugs it off: ''I have really clean neighbors. They tell me, 'Sidney, we always think of you when we take out our garbage.' ''

title: McCormick Deal

Paterson Jenks is involved in the grocery business, distributing and marketing a variety of products, including the Schwartz brand of herbs, spices and seasonings. McCormick, based in Baltimore, produces seasonings, flavorings and specialty foods.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Stauffer Chemical Fills 2 New Posts
description: Kenneth E. Davis and Milton Stern have been appointed to newly created posts as vice chairmen at the Stauffer Chemical Company, H.B. Morley, chairman and chief executive officer announced yesterday.

description: Amanda McBroom, who is singing at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, through May 26, seems to be a multitude of people.

title: Staged Burglary Nets 4 Officers
description: A police sergeant and three other officers assigned to the 61st Precinct in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn were suspended without pay yesterday after they were accused of taking property from a store during a burglary investigation, the Police Department said.

title: After 6 Years, A Soccer Defeat
description: It took 6 years and 110 games for the Scarsdale High School girls' soccer team to lose, but the first loss during that time for the Westchester County school came Tuesday with a 1-0 defeat to John Jay of Katonah, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: The Enduring Promise of 'Brown' Anniversaries of Supreme Court decisions don't usually inspire celebration. But nothing less is in order this week, the 30th anniversary of the decision by which the Court struck down its own colossally wrong acceptance of ''separate but equal'' treatment for blacks and whites in the preceding half century. To celebrate Brown v. Board of Education is to celebrate a continuing revolution in America's race relations.

title: Reagan to Get Checkup
description: President Reagan will visit the Bethesda Naval Center Friday for a routine physical examination, his spokesman said today. The President will fly by helicopter to the hospital complex in suburban Bethesda, Md., in the morning.

title: WHEN CHILDREN CHANGE SCHOOLS
description: EACH year in New York, some children change schools. While most such changes take place among private schools, some parents elect the convenience of a neighborhood public school or others choose public schools offering special programs for the gifted, or in science and the arts. The most common reasons for such changes may be boredom with an undemanding curriculum, or poor grades, lack of friendships or a conflict with the school's philosophy.

title: Released U.S. Couple Hailed in Sri Lanka
description: The American newlyweds held hostage for five days by rebel kidnappers were assured from the start that they would not be harmed and shook hands with their captors on their release, officials said today.

title: Bangladesh Hit by Floods
description: More than 40 people have been reported killed by rainstorms, floods and landslides in Bangladesh and northeast India in the last four days. ThePress Trust of India news agency said at least 19 people were killed and more than 100,000 had lost their homes in the Indian state of Tripura. In Bangladesh, the authorities said heavy rains and cyclones had killed 22 people and injured more than 100.

title: Bank of New York
description: The Bank of New York Company cannot buy a Connecticut bank, the Federal Reserve Board ruled, siding with Connecticut officials. Bank of New York had wanted to acquire Northeast Bancorp Inc., a New Haven bank holding company, to gain control of its subsidiary banks in Stamford and Waterbury. A Connecticut law allows banks to be acquired by out-of-state holding companies only if the holding companies are in New England states that have passed interstate banking laws similar to Connecticut's.

title: OFFER BY THE U.S. TO GUARD TANKERS IN GULF REPORTED
description: The United States has reportedly offered to provide Arab countries on the Persian Gulf with air cover to deal with military threats such as the recent attacks on Kuwaiti and Saudi oil tankers.

title: DEATH IN MOSCOW RULED 'UNLAWFUL'
description: A coroner's jury issued a verdict today that a British banker did not commit suicide when he died in a fall from his Moscow apartment last June.

title: Regan Delays Decision On Soviet Import Ban
description: The Reagan Administration, after a heated internal conflict, has decided to postpone until after the November election any decision to ban imports of Soviet products believed to have been made with forced labor.

title: Swiss Rule On Santa Fe
description: The Swiss Supreme Court ruled today that the Swiss Government should give legal assistance to the United States in its investigation of possible inside-trading violations in the 1981 sale of the Santa Fe International Corporation to the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: Hungary Joins Soviet In Quitting Olympics
description: Hungary today announced its withdrawal from the Olympic Games in Los Angeles. It is the ninth Soviet ally to withdraw, leaving only Poland and Rumania.

title: Advertising; Olympic Campaign For Fuji
description: FOR almost three years, Fuji

title: China's New Growth Plan
description: China today announced modest growth targets for 1984 in the face of an increasing strain on its energy resources.

description: International Marketnet, a competitor to such market data services as Telerate, Quotron and Reuters, is on the move with the selection of its top officers.

PANAMA ANNOUNCES A WINNER
description: Nicolas Ardito-Barletta, 45 years old, who was the Government's choice to run Panama for the next five years, was named President-elect today for the second time in 17 hours, ending a day of confusion and uncertainty.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $324,000 and a tax credit of $2,069,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $348,000 and a tax credit of $1,499,000.

title: REAGAN DISCLOSES $8,800 IN GIFTS, WITH 2 HEARING AIDS ON THE LIST
description: The hearing aid President Reagan began wearing last fall was not paid for ''out of his own pocket,'' as his spokesman had said, but was one of two given him by the manufacturer, according to financial disclosure statements filed today.

title: BROWN V. BOARD OF EDUCATION: UNEVEN RESULTS 30 YEARS LATER
description: In 1968, more than a decade after the Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education, two-thirds of black students were in virtually all-black schools. Today, after 15 years of earnest efforts at desegregation, that figure is down to one-third.

title: MEXICAN CONTINUES TO DIFFER WITH REAGAN ON LATIN ISSUE
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico, asserting that democracy cannot be imposed by force, told Congress today that the Central American conflict had economic and political roots and must not be permitted to become ''part of the East-West confrontation.''

title: President Will Not Campaign Until Labor Day, Baker Says
description: President Reagan will remain in the White House during the Democratic National Convention in July instead of ''getting into a campaign mode,'' a top aide said today.

title: City Investing To Consider Offer
description: George T. Scharffenberger, chairman of the City Investing Company, said that a $2.4 billion offer for the company from an investor group headed by Victor Posner, the Miami businessman, would be considered by the company's independent directors. Mr. Posner, who owns 8.5 percent of the company, has proposed a management buyout, subject to his being able to get the financing, for $40 a share in cash plus $12.50 a share in 13 percent preferred stock.

title: MRS. THATCHER, GIVE ULSTER TOP PRIORITY
description: Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, has one year left in which to convince Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland that their interests can be served by peaceful political action. If the opportunity is not taken, some very unreasonable people are likely to emerge as the main voice of that community.

title: NI Industries

title: U.S. ASSAILS SOVIET ON SAKHAROV FAST
description: The Reagan Administration today called Moscow's handling of a hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and dissident, ''inhumane and virtually incomprehensible.''

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE THAT KEPT MX MISSILE ALIVE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 218 to 212 by which the House of Representatives today refused to kill the MX missile program. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to kill the missile. A ''no'' vote was against eliminating money for the missile. Voting ''yes'' were 194 Democrats and 18 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 72 Democrats and 146 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Erdreich, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, no.

REVISIONIST 'MOON' BY YOUNG DIRECTOR
description: DURING the final rehearsal of ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' Kate Nelligan looked from the stage to see David Leveaux, the director, in the first row of seats, crying. The tears seemed out of character, for Mr. Leveaux - although only 26 years old and facing his Broadway debut - had remained every bit the stoic through five trying months with the show. Now that he realized ''Moon'' would go on, he could indulge in a public show of emotion. The tears were not in sorrow, but in relief.

title: FUEL BOARD MEMBER RESIGNS
description: The embattled Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which has been immobilized since April 27 because it lacks a quorum of directors, suffered a further blow today with the resignation of John B. Carter Jr. as a director.

title: Italy Jails 76 In Mafia Raid
description: Seventy-six people suspected of having links to the Mafia were arrested overnight in Naples and nearby towns when the police moved against a local Mafia group known as the Camorra, the police said today. They said they confiscated 23 stolen cars, other stolen goods worth $23,000 and 7 guns.

description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today rejected a proposal to permit American manufacturers to export products that have been withdrawn from the American market because they were found to be hazardous.

description: It is time for Gary Hart to withdraw from the race and to endorse Walter F. Mondale. It also is time for Mr. Mondale to announce that he intends to ask the Democratic National Convention to nominate Mr. Hart as his running mate.

The first product resulting from the agreement will be an eight- millimeter home-video system to be shown by Polaroid next month at the International Summer Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago.

title: HOPES RISING FOR HOLMES-COETZEE FIGHT
description: While efforts were made last night to save the financially-troubled Larry Holmes-Gerrie Coetzee heavyweight title fight by moving it to an arena named for bankers, Holmes said he would be willing to put up money for it. One way or the other, it seemed the fight would go on as scheduled June 8 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: 31 WESTERN BANKS LEND $250 MILLION TO MOSCOW
description: In the largest Western bank loan to Moscow since the Russians' 1979 military intervention in Afghanistan, an international syndicate of 31 private banks agreed today to lend the Soviet Union $250 million, the Dresdner Bank announced today.

title: Cuomo Signs Aid Bill For Part-Time Study
description: Part-time college students in New York will be eligible for state aid for the first time as a result of a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: ROCK: CHRISTINE MCVIE SINGS
description: -blues voice and original songs that suggest stormy emotions brewing beneath a placid surface, Christine McVie is the musical center of the British-American folk-rock group Fleetwood Mac. Miss McVie is the latest member of the group to record a solo album. Monday, the singer and keyboardist appeared at the Beacon Theater with a solidly professional band that included Todd Sharp, the guitarist with whom she has collaborated on many of her recent songs.

title: Peters Can Return
description: Tony Peters , the onetime all-pro safety who was suspended by the National Football League when he was convicted of Federal cocaine charges last fall, was cleared by Commissioner Pete Rozelle yesterday to rejoin the Washington Redskins. Peters pleaded guilty last October to conspiracy to distribute cocaine and was fined $10,000, given two concurrent four-year suspended prison terms and ordered to perform 500 hours of community service. Yesterday's action by Rozelle cited Peters's ''intensive and effective community service.''

title: LEBANESE CABINET AGAIN DISAGREES ON PEACE PLAN
description: Lebanon's new national unity Cabinet failed again today, because of bickering over foreign policy questions and the future role of the army, to draw up a plan for restoring peace in the country.

title: New Hearing Foreseen
description: The jockey Jacinto Vasquez is likely to get a new hearing on whether he should be forced to serve a one- year suspension imposed by the State Racing and Wagering Board, sources close to the board said yesterday. Vasquez began serving the suspension in March because of the board's finding that he had offered a bribe to another jockey, Eddie Maple , in 1974.

title: Chile Orders a Curfew In Capital After Blasts
description: The military Government today imposed a nightly curfew for vehicle traffic in metropolitan Santiago and announced a law formalizing the secret police agency's arrest powers after a wave of bombings in three cities.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 17, 1984 International
description: A Saudi oil tanker was attacked by an unidentified warplane in the latest of five air attacks this month on tankers in the Persian Gulf. American officials attributed the latest attack to Iran's Air Force. (Page A5, Col. 1.) American air cover for tankers in the Persian Gulf has been offered by the Reagan Administration, according to Administration officials. They said that Washington offered last month to discuss the subject with Persian Gulf states, but that they did not act on the proposal. However, they said that all the states said privately they wanted Washington to maintain its carrier task force in the Arabian Sea to respond in emergencies. (A1:4.)

title: British Union Leader's Wife Arrested While Urging Strike
description: Anne Scargill, the wife of Arthur Scargill, who leads the National Union of Mineworkers, was one of 14 women arrested today as they urged coal miners to join a 10-week-old strike to protest plans to close unprofitable mines, the police said.

title: Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with China's Ministry for the Electronics Industry to form a joint venture to sell microcomputer products in China.

title: Weight Off His Mind
description: Terry Hadlow , a weight lifter from Canada who was convicted in March of smuggling anabolic steroids into that country, had the conviction expunged from the record yesterday, clearing the way for his possible selection by the Canadian Olympic team. Hadlow and three other weight lifters returning from the world championships in Moscow last October were arrested when an airport baggage check turned up 414 vials of the male hormone testosterone and 22,515 tablets of anabolic steroids, a chemical derivative of the hormone that some athletes believe can aid their training.

title: Beirut Marine Chief Given a Security Post
description: The commander of the 241 American servicemen killed in a terrorist attack in Beirut last Oct. 23 has been named security chief at the Norfolk Naval Station.

The company said the liquidation would consist of a distribution of cash, securities and assets other than Oral-B Labs within one year following the meeting.

title: Oil Output Dips in Soviet
description: Soviet oil production dropped slightly in the first four months of 1984 and has fallen short of its target every month since September, according to official statistics released today.

description: Tunisia recalled its Ambassador to Libya today to protest Libyan charges that Tunisia is serving as a base for a campaign to destabilize the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: No Headline
description: Shift the Insanity Burden The way has been cleared for New York's Legislature to make a modest but useful change in the way the insanity defense is tried in criminal cases: shifting the burden to make defendants prove insanity instead of prosecutors having to prove their sanity. The State Senate has already agreed. The Assembly can concur now that Melvin Miller, chairman of its Codes Committee, has withdrawn his opposition.

description: Industry operated at 81.9 percent of capacity in April, nine-tenths of a percentage point above the March level and the biggest gain since a one-point increase in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Connally Proposes A Six-Year Presidency
description: John B. Connally, a former Presidential candidate, said today that the world had become so complex that the United States desperately needed a Presidency of one six-year term and senators serving one eight-year term.

title: South African Police Patrol Tense Township
description: The police patrolled a black township today where the South African Government had closed schools after four months of classroom boycotts and violence in which a teen- ager died.

description: A sad feature of the national bridge scene in the past decade has been the decline and virtual disappearance of intercollegiate bridge. Organized competition began in 1940, when Radcliffe became the first and only women's college to win an intercollegiate tournament, and ended in 1979.

The only previous recipient was Martha Graham in 1974. John Updike, in presenting the award, said: ''For 70 years, Alfred Knopf and his publishing firm have brightened the world of American books.

description: A planned ''unconvention'' for thousands of demonstrators who want their own gathering at the time of the Democratic National Convention in July has been rejected by the city's Recreation and Park Commission.

title: 5-HOUR TV SAGA OF THE SIOUX
description: When the producer Stan Margulies traveled to Rapid City, S.D., recently for a public screening of his new ABC-TV miniseries, ''The Mystic Warrior,'' he was apprehensive. The screening was for members of the Oglala Lakota Sioux, the tribe depicted in this five-hour saga about the life of the Plains Indians during the early 19th century. Recalling all the protests that had erupted while he and his partner, David L. Wolper, were developing the project, Mr. Margulies said, ''I wasn't sure if I would get out of there alive.''

description: The new chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company faced more than 1,000 shareholders here today at the utility's annual meeting. They were mostly friendly but generally worried, and the three-hour gathering was punctuated by occasional catcalls and angry outbursts.

title: AT SCOTTISH MANOR, PRICE OF UPKEEP IS ITS ART
description: A hundred years ago, they say, the Duke of Sutherland and his relatives were even richer than the royal family. In 1877, according to one study, they held no less than 1,358,500 acres.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Cheers for Scurry
description: It was Rod Scurry 's first relief appearance in Pittsburgh since returning from a month of drug treatment, and, when he took the mound with two on and none out in the bottom of the ninth in a 2-2 game against the Houston Astros on Tuesday night, he was welcomed home with an ovation. The cheers were even louder when Scurry pitched his way out of the inning and set up a 10th-inning Pirate victory. ''Everybody in Pittsburgh felt great about this one,'' said Chuck Tanner , the Pirate manager, who kissed Scurry on the forehead after the game.

title: KOHL KILLS A BILL AFTER PARTNERS REBEL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition was forced today to withdraw a draft law that would have granted an amnesty to politicians and businessmen involved in illegally deducting party contributions from income taxes.

title: JUDGE BARS OUTDOOR TEST OF GENETIC ENGINEERING
description: Federal District Judge John J. Sirica today ordered a delay in the first proposed outdoor experiment using genetically engineered organisms. He ordered the National Institutes of Health not to authorize any more experiments that would release such organisms into the environment until a full hearing.

description: A Superior Court judge today granted a postponement in the competency hearing for the father of the slain soul singer Marvin Gaye to permit the elderly preacher to have brain surgery.
