title: SOME NEW DEVICES TO HELP SAVE TIME
description: DURING the busy spring planting season, gardeners welcome any shortcuts. Here are a few new products that should help: Apple Maggot Traps: For years the bane of many orchardists has been the apple maggot or railroad worm, which is probably the most persistent pest for apple growers. The larvae tunnel through young fruit and render them inedible. The standard control has been a rigidly followed spray schedule with a multipurpose formula to protect trees and developing fruit not only from maggots but also from other prominent fruit-tree pests and diseases.

title: Letter: On Deficits A Misguided Tax on Tax-Exempts To the Editor:
description: In your otherwise laudable editorial on Congressional action to close the budget deficit (April 17), you called the tax on tax-exempt bonds for Social Security recipients a ''sensible reform.'' I disagree.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Youths Are Honored For Heroism in Subway
description: Martin Lopez and Geronimo Wilkerson were in class at I.S. 369 in downtown Brooklyn when they saw a man running from the subway into their schoolyard with a purse in his hand. The two ran after him, caught him and recovered the purse.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Adrian Dantley , the Utah Jazz forward who recovered from a severe wrist injury to become the National Basketball Association's scoring champion, was named comeback player of the year in balloting by a panel of sportswriters. Dantley, who missed 60 games in the 1982-83 season, averaged 30.6 points a game in 1983-84. . . . The Pittsburgh Maulers, who play the Generals Monday night at Giants Stadium, are expected to be without Mike Rozier , the running back, who has a swollen knee and foot.

title: STRATEGY OF THE NAVY FOR WARS OF THE FUTURE
description: ''THE RETURN OF THE GREAT WHITE FLEET'' is not so much about whether we need a Navy, as it is about what kind of Navy we need. In particular, the ''Frontline'' documentary questions the role of aircraft carriers. Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. favors carrier battlegroups and a ''forward strategy.'' His critics, dominating the documentary, say the strategy won't work. The documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

description: Jody Newman flew off to Charlotte, N.C., this week for a visit with Susan Green. Their meeting was a small link in the emerging ''old girl network'' that is starting to influence the male-dominated ways of Washington.

title: HERS
description: MY reality no longer has one face. I am traveling through the desert in Rajasthan - brown, bleak and alien. I miss the gentleness of the terrain where I was born. Yet these miles of desolation, the gods vivid against the stark land, the women revealed in fierce tones of brilliance - slowly, these make themselves felt.

title: THE THEATER: OSTROVSKY'S 'ARTISTS AND ADMIRERS'
description: THE New Theater of Brooklyn has opened its first season in Park Slope with a rare American production of Alexander Ostrovsky's ''Artists and Admirers.'' The author of 48 plays, Ostrovsky (1824-1886) was one of Russia's most popular dramatists, both a predecessor to and a precursor of Chekhov.

It cited the organization's reputation ''for violence and murder'' as a threat to the life of a Government informer in his case.

description: A Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn is investigating potentially significant new evidence in the murder of a prospective witness in the 1982 investigations of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, according to sources involved in the matter.

title: Tate's Troubles
description: John Tate , the former garbage collector who became a heavyweight boxing champion, says he cannot control his ''spendthrift habits'' and has placed his finances under a court-appointed conservator in Knoxville, Tenn. Court officials said that Lawrence Ault , an attorney, had been named to replace Tate's trainer, Ace Miller , as manager of the boxer's $300,000 estate. Documents filed for Tate in Knox County Chancery Court said the boxer was ''fearful that he will dissipate his entire estate.''

title: MOSLEM OFFICIAL ASKS PULLOUT OF ISRAELI GUARDS AT 2 SHRINES
description: The Moslem leader in Jerusalem urged the Israeli authorities today to withdraw border troops from the vicinity of two Moslem shrines on the Temple Mount. The troops have been stationed there since a plot by Jews to blow up the mosques was foiled in January.

title: New Clashes Reported By Vietnam and China
description: The official Vietnam press agency reported today that Vietnamese troops and civilians killed or wounded hundreds of Chinese troops who crossed the border on Tuesday. The official New China News Agency reported clashes, but said they were with Vietnamese troops who occupied a strip of Chinese territory.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE PEACEFULLY IN HIGH SCHOOL MELTING POT
description: Each day at lunchtime, when the students leave their assigned seats in the classroom, they re-create in the cafeteria the boundaries and divisions of the world outside Christopher Columbus High School.

The notes are rated Ba- 2 by Moody's Investors Service.

title: THE COMFORTS OF HOME, TO LET: RENTAL FURNITURE

title: Occidental Stock
description: The shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation jumped $2.125, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on a volume of nearly 2.6 million shares. Analysts said the activity stemmed from unconfirmed reports that the Olayan Group, controlled by Suliman S. Olayan, the Saudi Arabian businessman, had increased its stake in the company to at least 5 percent from about 4 percent. Wall Street analysts discounted the significance of the reports - even if true - arguing that Mr. Olayan had been a supporter of Occidental's chairman, Armand Hammer.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: * Wang Laboratories Inc. , a computer company in Lowell, Mass., said it had completed the sale of $100 million in 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Twins' Sale Called Near
description: Calvin Griffith , the owner of the Minnesota Twins, said he hoped to conclude an agreement ''in the next 10 days'' to sell his family's majority interest in the club to a local banker who says he would keep the team in Minneapolis. Griffith said he and Carl Pohlad , president of the F. & M. Marquette Bank, had agreed on a selling price of $30 million for the 52 percent interest owned by Griffith and his sister, Thelma Haynes .

title: FRITZIE ZIVIC, 71, FIGHTER WHO HELD WELTERWEIGHT TITLE PITTSBURGH, May 17 (UPI) - Fritzie Zivic, whose catlike quickness helped him win the world welterweight championship and 165 fights in an 18- year professional boxing career, died of Alzheimer's disease Wednesday at a Veterans Administration hospital in suburban Aspinwall. He was 71 years old and had been a patient at the hospital for the last three years.
description: Zivic, a native of Pittsburgh, had a checkered career. He beat some of the greatest fighters of his day, including Jake La Motta, but also lost to many of much lesser regard.

title: Noah Is Upset in Rome
description: Yannick Noah, seeded third, became the latest of a string of upset victims in the Italian Open tennis championships today when he lost a third-round match to an unseeded player, Diego Perez of Uruguay, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4. The loss by Noah, rated sixth in the world, left only 2 of the top 10 seeded players still competing on the clay courts of Rome's Foro Italico. They are Andres Gomez, seeded fifth, who advanced to the quarterfinals by beating Anders Jarryd, and Jose-Luis Clerc, No. 8, who beat Gianni Ocleppo.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BEYOND GOOD AND EVIL'
description: FRIEDRICH (FRITZ) NIETZSCHE, played by Erland Josephson, Lou Andreas- Salome (Dominique Sanda) and Paul Ree (Robert Powell), whose menage a trois is examined in Liliana Cavani's ''Beyond Good and Evil,'' are spending an evening together. Fritz dares Lou to take a vase off the piano and use it as a chamber pot; Lou, the oft-proclaimed free spirit of the three, calmly obliges. Then Lou and Paul couple on the floor, with an anguished Fritz looking on and finally grasping Paul's hand. At last, weary of all the merriment, Lou pauses. ''Intellectuals!'' she says.

description: An article in some editions yesterday about an art sale at Christie's misidentified the purchaser of Manet's ''Portrait of Madame Brunet'' and incorrectly described his output of figure paintings. The work was sold to a foundation in the Boston area that prefers anonymity, and it will be on long-term loan to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. He produced many figure paintings; this was one of the few still in private hands, according to Christie's.

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; The ITT Computer Campaign
description: IT is hard enough these days for a

title: SAVING A BANK: HOW THE U.S. PITCHED IN
description: It is the biggest, most complete defense of an ailing bank that the Federal Government has ever undertaken, an effort intended to arrest the flight of the bank's deposits almost overnight. The bank, the Continental Illinois, has suffered a run in the last week that has reached $8 billion a day, company executives said.

title: HOUSE VOTE DROPS BINARY NERVE GAS OVER REAGAN PLEA
description: Ignoring a last-minute plea from President Reagan, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to reject a $95 million proposal for a new nerve gas weapon.

title: THE DESOLATE LEGACY OF KNOXVILLE'S WORLD'S FAIR
description: The 266-foot-tall Sunsphere, the giant globe of gold-tinted glass that was the symbol of the 1982 World's Fair here, still dominates the low skyline of this Tennessee River city.

title: Host, Not Hostage, to the Bass
description: Young striped bass, as restless as tourists, find New York harbor a great place to visit, but they don't necessarily want to live there. That is the essence of the Army Engineers' report on the possible effects of filling about 250 acres of the Hudson River for Westway, the long delayed Manhattan highway and development project. The report estimates that 20 percent of the bass that winter in the harbor might be displaced; the other 80 percent are out of harm's way along both sides of the Hudson.

title: PANEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $280,000 for the quarter and $23,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $119,000 for the quarter and $153,000 for the 6 months.

title: OILERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS AND TAKE 3-1 LEAD IN SERIES
description: The Islander four-year dynasty, the National Hockey League's second- longest championship run, moved one game short of termination tonight as the Edmonton Oilers scored a 7-2 victory to take a 3-1 lead in their four-of- seven-game Stanley Cup final.

title: The Worm and the Apple Stopped Clocks, Soiled Justice
description: ''From the ceiling, just shy of cathedral height, little clumps of plaster fall occasionally into the lights and the proceedings. . . . The velvet rope guarding access to the court leaks crumbled sponge rubber where it has split from being overhandled. Thick ridges of greasy dirt balance on the folds of the limp flag hanging behind the judge. Above the flag, there is a bullet hole in the wall, right under the

title: EUROPE PLANS A SAKHAROV PROTEST
description: Jack Gold's film ''Sakharov,'' with Jason Robards as the Soviet physicist, was shown at Cannes. Page C3.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Violent Solution

title: ISLANDERS: 'WE'RE PLAYING FOR OUR LIVES'
description: ''We're playing for our lives; I think it will show Saturday,'' Denis Potvin said tonight, minutes after the devastating 7-2 loss to the Oilers that put the Islanders in a 3-1 deficit in the Stanley Cup final.

title: Starting a Streak
description: Dave Stegman of the Chicago White Sox does not display his home-run trot often. In 271 times at bat over 5 seasons with the Detroit Tigers and the White Sox, the right-handed-hitting outfielder hit only 6 homers, the most recent, before Wednesday, on May 28, 1980, at Yankee Stadium off Ron Guidry.

description: Two youths were charged yesterday with robbing and assaulting a 28- year-woman on a Brooklyn subway platform on Tuesday.

Marcos Foes on Alert For Vote Count Fraud
description: A leader of the Philippine opposition said today that opposition leaders, candidates and workers had been told to use citizens' arrests if necessary to prevent fraud in the counting of votes from the elections on Monday for the National Assembly.

title: INCREASING HOSTILITY FEARED
description: House Republicans, angry over Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill's verbal attack on one of them this week and his control of television cameras on the floor, castigated the Massachusetts Democrat in a caucus today. Members of both parties expressed fears of an erosion of courtesy and respect in the chamber.

description: A situation in which two Federal agencies appear to be working at cross purposes has prompted a Senator to seek a legislative resolution of the matter.

title: SAILED WITH BYRD
description: Sven Edward Roos, a member of Adm. Richard E. Byrd's first and second expeditions to Antarctica, died Tuesday of a stroke following cancer surgery at Cape Canaveral Hospital in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Cocoa Beach.

title: RATES RISE DESPITE FED ACTION
description: Interest rates rose yesterday, despite a generous provision of credit to the banking system resulting from loans to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

title: ART: INAUGURAL SHOW IS SURVEY OF NEW YORK
description: NEXT to being beaten up on the street and seeing everyone else pass by on the other side, one of the more unpleasant things that can happen to a museum curator is to be asked to choose, organize and install a large miscellaneous international exhibition of new art.

title: A CRITIC'S WALK THROUGH THE NEW MODERN MUSEUM
description: AFTER yesterday's reopening of the Museum of Modern Art has been duly celebrated and we have finished luxuriating in the knowledge that our artistic roots are once again within reach, it will be time to consider just how those roots are now presented to us, which ones have been extended, watered, trimmed and cut.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after special charges for restructuring of the company's banana and meat businesses of $120,000,000 for the quarter and $137,649,000 for the year. In 1983 the company changed its fiscal year-end from June 30 to March 31. Fiscal 1983 figures are pro forma.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reporter's Notebook article from Washington on Saturday, about a convention of newspaper editors, gave an incorrect title for Jody Powell's new book. The book is ''The Other Side of the Story.''

title: Seaver Adjusting To Other League
description: ''This is the first time I've been to Toronto since 1966, when I was pitching for Jacksonville of the International League,'' said Tom Seaver yesterday. ''I remember Tony Horton hit two home runs off me, and I think I lost the game.

title: TRIBORO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There were no comparable year- ago results as a consequence of Telecom Plus International's acquisition of more than a majority of Triboro Communication's common stock. The transaction is recognized as a reorganization under common control retroactive to July 1, 1983. This date is considered to be the conception date under such common control. The company was formerly known as Triboro Telephone Planning & Interconnect Inc.

title: Comings and GoingsThe Jets signed two rookies,
description: Bret Wright , a punter from Southeastern Louisiana who was an eighth-round draft choice, and Ronnie Cone , a running back from Georgia Tech, a 10th- round selection. . . . Jacques Villeneuve , 28-year-old brother of the late Formula One driver Gilles Villeneuve , was hospitalized in satisfactory condition with a concussion after a crash during practice for the May 27 Indianapolis 500.

title: PAGE PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of U.S. accounting principles.

description: b-Includes income of $400,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $3,917,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Happy Landing
description: He doesn't have the clout of a Warren Moon, the Edmonton quarterback whom the Giants sought, but Cedric Minter was pursued by seven National Football League teams when he decided to play out his option last season in the Canadian Football League.

description: Once again, the MX missile has been shown to be a sort of nuclear cat, complete with the proverbial nine lives.

title: SWALE CHOICE AT PIMLICO
description: Swale won the Kentucky Derby 12 days ago by the widest margin in a decade, but 9 trainers are not convinced he will win the 109th Preakness Stakes and have entered their colts to run against him here Saturday.

title: For Reagan, a Week of Chill and Ill Winds
description: Spring suffered a reversal in Washington this week, and so did President Reagan.

title: FOR JULIE INKSTER, IT'S EASY DOES IT
description: Juli Inkster, the leading candidate for rookie of the year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, was described by her business agent as a golfer ''who has no preconceived notions of golf success and is not hung up on titles and things.''

title: RID-A-BUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: First Case, First Victory

title: ENERGY RESEARCHERS SUCCEED IN FOCUSING BEAM OF IONS IN LAB
description: Scientists at Sandia National Laboratories said today that they had succeeded in focusing an intense beam of ions to the size of a pinhead. The feat is a major step toward duplicating in the laboratory the process of fusion, the energy source that powers the sun.

title: Money Funds In Big Jump
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds showed their second-largest weekly gain since Feb. 8 in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: IN HUDSON VALLEY SPRING, NOSTALGIA'S IN FULL BLOOM
description: Nostalgia is the keynote of a series of events in the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: DOWN from Harlem and up from Greenwich Village, Southern cooking is on the march as New Yorkers explore the latest culinary rage, regional American foods. Now that Alberta Wright's restaurant, Jezebel, has arrived at Ninth Avenue and 45th Street, grits and corn bread, ham hocks and sweet potato pie are appearing nightly in the theater district.

title: SENATORS WARNED TO KEEP SECRETS
description: The Senate Republican and Democratic leaders formally warned their colleagues today that Senate rules prohibited disclosure of intelligence information obtained from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence or any other sources.

title: NFA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: -Day and the Battle for

title: 'OLD FASHIONED' HERO IS OFFICER OF THE YEAR
description: Detective Robert T. Gallagher is, as far as anyone can determine, the most decorated detective in the history of the New York City Police Department.

title: The Message to Mr. Marcos
description: Never at a loss for a sardonic word, President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines had a ready explanation for the surprising gains by his opponents in this week's parliamentary election. He told a CBS interviewer: ''I would presume that our instructions to our people to allow the opposition to win some seats might have been taken too literally.'' Whatever the truth in this wisecrack, the happy result is a modest step toward greater freedom, which Americans should welcome and encourage.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3,252,000 on the retirement of debt.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a securities gain of $1,000.

title: HALLEY'S SURE THING
description: This world needs more things it can count on.

title: STATE FAULTS CITY DENIAL OF SOME WELFARE CLAIMS
description: The city mistakenly denied public assistance to many residents by incorrectly applying rules designed to prove eligibility for welfare payments, according to a state audit released yesterday.

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE IMPORTANCE OF A U.S. HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Hatcher Is Unseated From Indiana Party Post
description: Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary has been voted out as Democratic Party chairman in Indiana's First Congressional District, a post he has held for 10 of the last 12 years.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Credit Suisse Picks Chief for New Unit
description: Gordon L. Bowyer has been elected president and chief executive of Credit Suisse's new investment management subsidiary in the United States.

title: BALLET THEATER: PAQUITA
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER has a highly promising ballerina - in the honorific sense of the description - in Cynthia Harvey. And on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House she danced a splendid ''Paquita.''

title: Man, 20, Arrested In Trunk Slaying
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with the slaying of a 32-year-old woman whose nude body was found last week inside a steamer trunk in a midtown apartment.

title: MUSIC: MORDECAI SHEHORI
description: MORDECAI SHEHORI'S Tuesday evening piano concert in the Abraham Goodman House served as a welcome reminder that there is a place for originality in re-creations of classic material. Most of the works he played were well known - Weber's ''Invitation to the Dance,'' Busoni's piano transcription of Bach's Chaconne for violin, Beethoven's Sonata No. 32 in C Minor (Op. 111) - but Mr. Shehori's inventive playing provided for several fresh insights along the way.

title: TEXT OF F.D.I.C. ANNOUNCEMENT
description: Following is the text of the announcement by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation regarding the financial aid arranged for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company:

title: FRANCIS BLOUSTEIN, EX-JUDGE OF NEW YORK SUPREME COURT
description: Francis J. Bloustein, a retired State Supreme Court justice, died Wednesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 77 years old.

title: 'Sea Day' Parade
description: A ''Sea Day'' parade, made up of as many as 35 working vessels from New York Harbor, will set sail tomorrow at 11 A.M. from the Bay Street landing in St. George, S.I., with its destination the South Street Seaport at Fulton Street in Manhattan.

title: THE WINNER OF PANAMA
description: A few days before the election May 6 that propelled Nicolas Ardito Barletta to the presidency of Panama, one of his most influential backers explained how such an unlikely figure was selected to head the Government ticket. ''We made a list of all the qualifications we were looking for in a candidate, and put the information into a computer,'' said the backer, a longtime political kingmaker. ''The only name that came out was Nicky.''

title: WORLD COURT DECISIONS HAVE 'BLINDING FORCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Injured Boy Dies; Aid Time Is Cited
description: A Staten Island high school student injured Wednesday in a woodshop accident died early yesterday and an inquiry ordered by Mayor Koch found that a city ambulance had taken 18 minutes to reach him, about 9 minutes longer than average.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $758,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. MILITARY PLANE LANDS IN COSTA RICA AND IS UNDER GUARD
description: A United States Army plane landed here unexpectedly today and was quickly placed under armed guard at a remote part of Juan Santamaria Airport, outside the capital. United States planes of the same type fly reconnaissance missions from the Palmerola Air Base in Honduras to provide intelligence information on guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: FINDING THE RIGHT COLOR: ARE YOU SPRING OR FALL?
description: Rosemarie Sena says she has abandoned wearing ''those boring beiges and grays.'' Since her recent $100 visit to Colorconscious in Manhattan, she's thinking pink and is ''delighted.''

title: ANDY KAUFMAN, A COMEDIAN KNOWN FOR UNORTHODOX SKITS
description: Andy Kaufman, the unorthodox young comedian who starred in ''Taxi'' and on ''Saturday Night Live,'' died of lung cancer Wednesday at Cedars- Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 35 years old.

title: Hanoi Frees American 11 Months After Capture
description: A 19-year-old American who went looking for buried treasure in Vietnam and was imprisoned for 11 months was freed today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Significant Victory

title: SUIT SEEKING TO PAY INTERNED JAPANESE DISMISSED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a suit brought on behalf of the 120,000 Japanese-Americans removed from their homes and detained in camps in World War II.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AMID all the hoopla over fancy ice cream concoctions, such as the whimsical combination of cookies, candies and nuts mixed into ice-cream cones at Steve's (Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street) and at David's Cookies (Broadway and Eighth Street; Third Avenue and 65th Street, and Broadway and 96th Street), the notion of an old-fashioned ice- cream soda may seem quaintly anachronistic. If prepared well, however, an ice-cream soda is one of the most uplifting warm-weather drinks.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Includes tax credits of $590,000. c-Includes a tax credit and a gain on the sale of land totaling $6,182,000.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.5%
description: The personal income of Americans in April rose five-tenths of 1 percent and their spending rate was up 1.1 percent, recovering from two months of lackluster performance, the Government reported today.

title: SORREL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bowater Unit Shares Sold
description: The Bowater Corporation said today that its offering of 7.31 million common shares of Bowater Inc. at $18 each, raising $131.6 million, was carried out successfully today in the United States.

title: Soviet Import Step Opposed
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee today voted its disapproval of the decision by the Treasury Department on Wednesday to postpone any decision to ban imports of Soviet products believed to have been made by forced labor.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The talk was of ''Cats.'' ''I liked the sort of Moses one,'' said Senator Howard Baker, the majority leader. ''He's my kind of cat.''

title: PHILADELPHIA CHEFS COOK UP A CENTER CITY FEAST
description: It was planning day for the second Philadelphia Restaurant Gala and the Bellevue- Stratford Hotel here was awash with chefs staking out kitchen work space.

title: Economic Scene; Who Will Deal With Deficits?
description: BIG budget deficits and climbing interest rates in the United States are intensifying worries, both at home and abroad, of the danger of a crackup in the international financial system.

title: Rio Grande Talks
description: Rio Grande Industries said talks had been terminated with other railroad companies regarding its acquisition or merger. The company, on Feb. 27, had referred to preliminary talks with companies that it did not identify. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Rio Grande was the biggest percentage loser, plunging $7, to $39.25.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: 2 ON PANEL FAULT HEAD OF N.R.C. OVER SHOREHAM
description: Two of the five members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House subcommittee today that the commission chairman had acted improperly in his handling of the application by the Long Island Lighting Company for a license for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: PUBLISHING: NIXON DOING BOOK ON VIETNAM POLICY
description: RICHARD NIXON'S latest book, ''No More Vietnams,'' has been acquired by Arbor House and will be out early next year. ''We will have it by Sept. 1, and it will be published in April,'' Eden Collinsworth, publisher of Arbor House, said. ''That's the first month of our spring-summer list, but the book will be available in bookstores in February, which will be the 10th anniversary of the fall of Saigon.''

title: NINE KLANSMAN INDICTED BY U.S. IN A RIGHTS CASE
description: A four- year struggle by an Alabama lawyer to identify the Ku Klux Klan members responsible for a violent clash with black marchers in Decatur, Ala., in 1979 resulted today in a Federal indictment of seven Klan leaders and two Klansmen.

title: ROYAL DUTCH-SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum listed on the New York Stock Exchange had share earnings of $3.24 for the latest quarter compared with $1.78 for the year-earlier period. Shell Transport and Trading, listed on the Big Board, had share earnings of $1.97 for the latest quarter against $1.08 for the year-ago period.

title: ACTIVE IN THE ARTS AND EDUCATION
description: Lord Robbins, a prominent British economist and a figure in the arts, education and journalism, died Tuesday of a stroke in his London home. He was 85 years old.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company changed its fiscal year-end from May 31 to Dec. 31.

title: HART, AT JERSEY WASTE SITES, SAYS REAGAN 'DOESN'T CARE'
description: Senator Gary Hart began his New Jersey campaigning today by visiting two toxic-waste dump sites in the state that are among the country's most hazardous, according to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Carter Hawley Net Rises 37%
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores said yesterday that its net income in the fiscal first quarter rose 37 percent, to $8.5 million, or 21 cents a share, from $6.2 million, or 18 cents a share, the year before.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coleco Adds Ketchum For Creative Work
description: Coleco Industries has assigned creative advertising for its consumer electronics product line to Ketchum Advertising/New York.

title: Reynolds May Put Oil Unit Up for Sale
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, which has substantial interests in tobacco, foods, beverages and oil, said yesterday that it was considering the sale of its oil company - estimated to be worth about $1 billion.

title: TEACHERS ON THE FRONT LINE OF THE CLASSROOM STRUGGLE
description: Room 352: Frank Kron, the biology teacher, admired by students, who strive to please him, known among his colleagues as a stereotype of the profession - a case of burnout. ''This is not what I want to do,'' he says, after 19 years in the classroom. ''There is no reward for being a good teacher.''

title: PITTOCK FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

A FIGHT FOR HONESTY, PURITY, AND VEAL
description: Washington, the town, as distinct from Washington, the nation's capital, is forming its wagons in a circle these days to preserve the next-to-last outpost of a major local institution. Sholl's New Cafeteria, the home of the $1.55 veal cutlet with tomato sauce, faces eviction.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Accounts
description: * Manhattan Inc. magazine, making its debut in September, to Slater Hanft Martin.

title: CHINA ADDS COMPASSION TO ITS BIRTH CONTROL DRIVE
description: When China began one of its periodic family planning drives early last year, the family planning officials of Shunyi County responded with a vengeance. Middle- aged women using intrauterine devices were told to undergo sterilization. Other women were taken off oral contraceptives and fitted with IUD's.

title: MR. OCTOBER REFLECTS AT 38
description: Reggie Jackson is back in town today with a birthday, a book and a better batting average. But he wishes people would forget all three. He denies that he has any new insights just because today is his 38th birthday. He doesn't know how New York will react when he appears in Yankee Stadium tonight for the first time since he criticized the Yankees in published excerpts from his forthcoming book, ''Reggie.'' And, mostly, he doesn't want everybody asking if he's making a comeback after hitting .194 last year in his worst season in baseball.

title: Lehman Corp. Replaces Its Departing President
description: C. Charles Hetzel was elected president and a director of the Lehman Corporation, Henry R. Breck, chairman of Lehman's board, announced yesterday. The appointment is effective May 25.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMPOWER TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FROM NINTH AVENUE MELTING POT, THE FESTIVAL GOOD ENOUGH TO EAT
description: THE Ninth Avenue International Festival of Food, ''New York's youngest tradition,'' as they call it in the neighborhood, and the city's largest annual outdoor block party, will open tomorrow at 11 A.M. with an official proclamation by Borough President Andrew Stein.

title: MUSIC: CONSONANCE PRESENTS TWO PREMIERES AND DANCE
description: There were some surprises, as when the choreographer Lisa Green chose to accompany a reading of the poems that inspired Griffes's ''White Peacock'' and Liszt's ''Sonett del Petrarca No. 104,'' rather than Miriam Brickman's performances of the resulting compositions. However, Miss Green's dancing was always engrossing; her agile, elegant slices of motion recalled a sinuous pair of scissors.

title: VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PADRES' WIGGINS TIES STEAL MARK
description: Alan Wiggins of the Padres tied a modern National League record with five stolen bases and scored what turned out to be the winning run on Tony Gwynn's two-out eighth-inning single today as San Diego snapped a seven- game losing streak by defeating the Montreal Expos, 5-4.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split March 12, 1984.

title: Post Card Bourse
description: ''The International Post Card Bourse,'' with more than two million post cards and nearly 60 dealers and collectors from all over the world, will be held this weekend in the main ballroom of the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ON the theory that ''intelligent adult movies'' are relative rarities, the distributors of the independently made low-budget romance ''Cold Feet'' are trying a new marketing technique. The film, according to Ira Deutschman, executive vice president of Cinecom International Films, which is distributing it, offers ''an honest look at contemporary relationships - it's about two people who are afraid to get involved, and who don't go to bed until the last reel.'' Accordingly, it is aimed at a specific, post-teen-age, mostly single audience, and Cinecom is marketing it with that in mind.

title: LEGISLATORS HARD TO NUDGE FROM OFFICE
description: To the Editor:

title: George Coleman
description: The tenor saxophonist George Coleman will lead his quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard (255-4037), 178 Seventh Avenue South. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is an $8 cover ($7.50 on Sunday) and a one-drink minimum.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CELTICS ROMP FOR A 2-0 LEAD OVER BUCKS
description: The Milwaukee Bucks have a matchup problem. They have no one to handle Boston's 6-foot-10-inch Kevin McHale. Alton Lister, Paul Mokeski and Bob Lanier all tried tonight, with little success, as the Celtics overwhelmed the Bucks, 125-110, at the Boston Garden to take a 2-0 lead in the Eastern Conference final.

title: TITLE-BOUT CARDS RESHUFFLED
description: Gerry Cooney is back, replacing Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Larry Holmes-Gerrie Coetzee is off, for now, perhaps replaced by Thomas Hearns-Roberto Duran.

title: Orioles Release PalmerAfter almost two decades with the Baltimore Orioles,
description: Jim Palmer , a three-time Cy Young Award winner, was released yesterday during an emotional news conference in Baltimore. Palmer, a 38-year-old right- hander, has a 268-152 career record.

U.S. WEIGHING ITS GULF OPTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration is weighing options for keeping the Persian Gulf open to oil shipping but has made no specific offers of military support in the area, Government officials said today.

title: Merrie Spaeth Is Married to Tex Lezar
description: Merrie Spaeth, a special assistant to President Reagan, and Tex Lezar, counselor to the Attorney General, were married yesterday. Judge Patrick E. Higginbotham of the Federal Court of Appeals in Texas performed the ceremony at the boyhood home of Robert E. Lee in Alexandria, Va.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times May 15 about trends in archeology misidentified the director of the University Museum of the University of Pennsylvania. He is Robert H. Dyson Jr.

title: SPECTRUM LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HARVESTER SHARPLY NARROWS DEFICIT
description: International Harvester, struggling to return to profitability, reported yesterday that it had sharply narrowed its loss in the second fiscal quarter ended April 30 to $817,000, from $159 million the year before, on a strong gain in revenues.

title:
ANALYSIS;
FOR REAGAN, A WEEK OF CHILL AND ILL WINDS
description: Spring suffered a reversal in Washington this week, and so did President Reagan.

title: Florence Museum Reopens Five Days After Explosions
description: The Pitti Palace museum opened today for the first time since explosions injured 10 people on Saturday.

title: Economic Panel's Head
description: Edmund B. Fitzgerald, president of Northern Telecom Ltd., yesterday was elected president of the Committee for Economic Development. Mr. Fitzgerald succeeds Fletcher L. Byrom, former chairman of the Koppers Company, as the head of the public policy research and education organization. Mr. Fitzgerald, 58 years old, joined Northern Telecom in 1980 as president of the company's American subsidiary, Northern Telecom Inc. He was named president of the Canadian parent company in 1982.

title: Baldwin Aid Is Considered
description: More than 30 life insurance companies are considering contributing a total of $50 million to holders of annuities sold by the Baldwin-United Corporation, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said. Baldwin-United, before filing for reorganization last September, had sold 163,000 single-premium deferred annuities valued at about $4.2 billion.

title: STUDY FAULTS U.S. ON ITS LATIN POLICY
description: The situation in Central America is rapidly deteriorating and United States military involvement in the region is one of the main causes, according to a new study by the Inter-American Dialogue, an organization of 50 prominent United States and Latin politicians, diplomats, businessmen and scholars.

title: FILM: 'FINDERS KEEPERS,' COMEDY DIRECTED BY RICHARD LESTER
description: FOR a farce, especially a farce directed by Richard Lester, ''Finders Keepers'' takes an unconscionable amount of time to get going, but don't be too impatient.

title: STAGE: 'THE BABE,' AT PRINCESS
description: BABE RUTH was, in Red Smith's phrase, ''the complete ballplayer,'' and probably the most colorful character ever to play our national pastime. A great bear of a hero whose exploits on and off the field were legendary, he would seem to be a monumental subject for a movie or a play. But, except for the 1948 popcorn biography, ''The Babe Ruth Story,'' starring William Bendix, he has managed to elude dramatic interpretation.

description: Fifteen prisoners being transferred to Trenton State Prison were injured by guards at the prison on Tuesday night, State Corrections Commissioner William H. Fauver said today.

title: House Panel Supports 4 Cigarette Warnings
description: A compromise bill that would require four rotating health warnings on cigarette packs, including specific admonitions that smoking can cause lung cancer, heart disease and birth complications, today won the unanimous approval of the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

title: INDIANS OF ANOTHER DAY AND THE AGED TODAY
description: SEVERAL years ago, ABC programming executives were rhapsodically anticipating a new mini-series titled ''Hanta Yo,'' based on a best-selling book by Ruth Beebe Hill. This was going to do for American Indian history what ''Roots'' did for black Americans. Even the executive producers of the two shows were the same, David L. Wolper and Stan Margulies. Then the project ran into artistic and political objections. Gradually, the nine-hour ''Hanta Yo,'' which was to span several generations, was transformed into the five-hour single-generation portrait of ''The Mystic Warrior.'' The generally sad result can be seen on Channel 7, the first part Sunday at 8 P.M. and the concluding part Monday at 9 P.M.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32,916.

title: AMANDA MCBROOM'S OWN SONGS AT BALLROOM
description: SEVERAL years ago, Amanda McBroom, a Los Angeles based singer-actress, who had only recently taken up songwriting, received a call from a friend, who told her about a movie being made called ''The Rose.'' The friend, who was having lunch with one of its producers, remembered that Miss McBroom had written a song called ''The Rose,'' and he volunteered to slip the producer a cassette of it.

title: AGENCIES SEIZE SMALL PORTION OF SMUGGLED DRUGS
description: On the seas and at 300 ports of entry along the nation's borders, Federal law-enforcement authorities say their limited resources enable them to seize only a small percentage of the illicit drugs entering the country.

description: Gorman Thomas , the outfielder acquired by Seattle from Cleveland during the off-season in hopes that he could add punch to the Mariner lineup, has left the team for surgery after aggravating a shoulder injury.

title: A New York Tale of Aging And Caring for Parents
description: ''Bella,'' written by Susan Mernit and directed by Mark Mannucci, is a New York play, more cheerful than not, that deals with everyday problems of aging and caring for parents, and will be shown Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 5.

title: MEXICO PRESIDENT ENDS VISIT TO U.S.
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico ended his visit with President Reagan today, saying the two leaders had progressed in learning ''respect for one another's truth.''

The film means to be a comedy about the adventures of a tough city fellow when he's hired by a rich young man to take his place at a snobbish Eastern prep school.

description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today rejected calls for a new approach to the international debt crisis, as America's Western allies expressed alarm over the renewed upward trend in interest rates in the United States and the resulting debt burden on third-world nations.

title: 'Smart Money Bank': What Went Wrong
description: The announcement yesterday that the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company was considering merging with another big bank was the culmination of a series of events that started nearly two years ago. It was then that the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma failed, touching off severe financial difficulties for Continental, once regarded as ''the smart money bank'' - a term it uses in its advertising.

title: KOCH TIGHTENS RULES ON 'HAUNTED HOUSES'
description: Operators of New York City's nine ''haunted houses'' were directed yesterday by Mayor Koch to install new safety measures, including smoke detectors and emergency lighting. The steps, which also affect other enclosed amusement attractions, are intended to avert the kind of fire that killed eight young people at a New Jersey amusement park last week.

title: Woman Reported Slain In a Palestinian Camp
description: At least one woman was killed and three teen-age boys were wounded today when gunmen opened fire on demonstrators in a Palestinian refugee camp, according to witnesses who said the shots were fired by Israeli-supported militiamen. An Israeli account of violence inside the camp said two women were shot dead, but it did not blame Israelis or Israeli-backed militia for the shooting.

title: 'YOU GOTTA HAVE PARK,' A WEEKEND CELEBRATION
description: ''It should have an aspect of spaciousness and tranquillity,'' Frederick Law Olmsted wrote of the great park he began to design in 1857, ''affording the most agreeable contrast to the confinement, bustle and monotonous street division of the city.''

description: After five wearing weeks of debate, the Senate today approved President Reagan's ''down payment'' package aimed at reducing the projected budget deficit by $142 billion through 1987.

title: MUSIC: RECITAL BY ELMAR OLIVEIRA
description: ELMAR OLIVEIRA, a violinist who holds the Tchaikovsky Gold Medal, gave a recital of Handel (13th of the Opus 1 sonatas), Prokofiev (Op. 80), Suk (Four Pieces, Op. 17) and Brahms (Third Sonata) in Carnegie Hall Wednesday with the pianist Robert McDonald.

title: JACKSON WOOS ASIAN-AMERICANS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told members of this city's large Japanese-American community today that Asian-Americans had been victims of more than a century of discrimination and that a new generation of leaders was needed to ''change the course of history.''

title: DUN AND NIELSEN TO MERGE
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a business services company best known as a supplier of credit information, said last night that it had reached an agreement to merge with the A. C. Nielsen Company, the big market research and television rating organization.

title: Canadian Offering
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it had decided to make its 15 million share tender offer because two large shareholders, Bank of Nova Scotia and Toronto-Dominion Bank, wanted to sell their holdings. The real estate development company gave its reason in a special report to shareholders. The company has said the banks hold 7.2 million out of 81.7 million shares outstanding.

title: Merger Study Focuses On Overseas Suitors
description: As bankers scrambled yesterday to expand an emergency line of credit to help keep the Continental Illinois Bank in business, attention focused on potential merger partners that could help the bank survive.

title: Intruder Tries to Rape Nun in Her Convent
description: A man armed with a knife entered a Manhattan convent last night and attempted to rape a nun, according to the police. The nun, Cynthia Wilhelmy, 28-years-old, fought off the man and was hurt in the struggle, but she refused medical aid, the police said.

title: HOMELESS SHOULD BE REHOUSED
description: Each night, 800 men sleep on cots inches apart on a drill floor the size of a football field in Manhattan's Fort Washington Armory. The Mayor boasts about the vast sums we spend to open such shelters for the homeless. But are we doing the right thing with our money? In the long run, it would be less costly and more humane to encourage community groups to develop permanent, small- scale housing for homeless people. The homeless should be rehoused, not just sheltered.

title: Soviet-U.S. Relations Called Worst Since '62

title: MOSCOW IN MAY: ICY TOWARD THE U.S.
description: A middle-aged Russian said recently that he had heard songs on the radio he had not heard since the 1950's. title: FRIDAY, MAY 18, 1984 International
description: The White House bypasses Congress and exceeds spending limits set by Congress in financing military and intelligence activities in Central America, according to Administration officials, members of Congress and classified documents. The officials and documents revealed that the methods involve accounting procedures and circuitous transfers that disguise both the value and quantity of military aid. (Page A1, Column 2.) American policy in Central America was criticized in a new study by the Inter-American Dialogue, an organization of 50 prominent United States and Latin politicians, diplomats, businessmen and scholars. The group said that the situation in Central America was deteriorating rapidly and that American military involvement was a major cause. (A6:3-5.)

description: Alfred Brendel, Gerard Schwarz and the Y Chamber Symphony concluded their three-concert survey of Beethoven's piano concertos and assorted orchestral music in Carnegie Hall Thursday night. One might have hoped for something a little more unusual - the piano version of the Violin Concerto, for instance, or the Choral Fantasy. But there is always room for the standard repertory when it is as admirably rendered as this.

City Investing To Study Bids
description: The City Investing Company is retaining the First Boston Corporation to evaluate two offers for the company and directors will consider the bids at a meeting on July 25, City Investing's chairman, George T. Scharffenberger, said at the company's annual meeting here. Victor Posner, a Miami Beach investor, proposed acquiring City Investing on Tuesday for $2.4 billion, or $52.50 a share, following an offer last week of $2.3 billion, or $50 a share, from a group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Mr. Scharffenberger told an audience of about 100 shareholders that both offers are ''very responsible'' and are regarded as friendly.

title: PROGRAMS UNLIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28

title: K Mart Services
description: The K Mart Corporation said it plans to expand its financial services operations - offering certificates of deposit and money market accounts - to Texas on Monday. The retailer began the offerings, issued by Troy- based Standard Federal Savings and Loan, earlier this year in Florida. Robert E. Brewer, K Mart executive vice president of finance, said K Mart would expand the program and eventually would ''probably fill in the states between Florida and Texas in the Sun Belt.''

title: CABLE-READY TV: IS IT WORTH THE PRICE?
description: The rush by cable-television systems to prevent unauthorized viewers from pirating their programs is making it impossible for millions of consumers to take full advantage of the expensive circuitry that was supposed to make their new television sets ''cable-ready.''

title: Ex-Officer Gets Life Term
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for the murder of a firefighter. Justice Lawrence J. Tonetti of State Supreme Court in the Bronx ruled that the defendant, 44-year-old Sheila Ryan DeLuca, must serve 20 years before she can be eligible for parole. A jury convicted Mrs. DeLuca in the Sept. 23, 1982, shooting death of Robert Bissett, 27, after they had sex in his van.

title: Disney Nephew Leery on Arvida
description: Roy E. Disney, nephew of the late Walt Disney and the owner of nearly 5 percent of Walt Disney Productions, expressed ''serious reservations'' about a company agreement to pay $200 million in Disney stock for the Arvida Corporation, a real estate company controlled by the Bass family of Texas. Mr. Disney said the venture appeared to dilute earnings and to waste corporate assets. He said he had asked his lawyers and investment bankers to study the deal.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect the issuance of 1 million additional shares of common stock in May 1983 and have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Sept. 2, 1983.

title: BLAZE FATAL TO 8 LINKED TO LIGHTER
description: The fire that killed eight young people at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park last week was started by a youth who lit a lighter to find his way, investigators reported today.

title: GENERAL KEY ROLE IN U.S. POLICY ON LATINS
description: As United States policy in Central America has come to emphasize an increasing military presence and cooperation with allied armies in the region, Gen. Paul F. Gorman has emerged as a key American strategist, according to diplomats and military officers.

title: OLYMPIC GROUP FAILS TO SWAY SOVIET
description: The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee met here with a Soviet delegation today in an apparent effort to reverse Moscow's decision to stay away from the Games in Los Angeles. The effort was apparently unsuccessful.

description: Japan, which depends on the Persian Gulf for most of its oil, expressed its worry today over attacks on tankers in the gulf and urged restraint on both Iran and Iraq.

title: RUTGERS PROFESSOR RESIGNING AFTER PLAGIARISM ACCUSATION
description: A 46-year-old associate professor of economics at Rutgers University has agreed to resign following accusations that he plagiarized an article submitted to a professional journal, according to university officials.

title: Brett Returns
description: George Brett , the all-star third baseman who has been out since the start of the season because of an injury to his left knee, was reactivated by the Kansas City Royals, who placed him in his familiar No. 3 spot in the batting order for last night's game against Texas. He was in all- star form, going 3-for-3.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VAST NETWORK OF AID CALMING DEPOSITORS, CHICAGO BANK SAYS
description: The unprecedented $7.5 billion emergency aid package extended by Government agencies and private banks to insure the survival of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has apparently halted the run on the giant Chicago bank and calmed world financial markets.

title: SENATORS' SPEAKING FEES UP 25% IN FINAL YEAR BEFORE CRACKDOWN
description: Eighty-two senators received a total of more than $3 million from speaking and writing fees in 1983, the final year before a self-imposed limit on honorariums went into effect, according to reports released today by the Secretary of the Senate.

description: A leading French editor, often described as an intimate of President Francois Mitterrand, wrote today that the Soviet Union had indicated it would allow Andrei D. Sakharov to go to the West if Mr. Mitterrand called for a halt in the deployment of NATO medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: LIFTER SEEKS END TO PENALTY
description: Jeff Michels, the 23-year-old who until August was considered the best American hope for a medal in weight lifting at the Olympics, sat in his lawyer's office Thursday, staring out at Lake Michigan. ''I never imagined I'd ever set foot in a law firm,'' said Michels, a soft-spoken young man who grew up under modest circumstances on this city's West Side. ''I prefer the gym.''

description: Three young brothers were killed Thursday when fire raced through their three-story apartment building here, but a baby sitter carried their 18-month-old sister to safety, fire officials said.

title: Gordon Sinclair, 83, Is Dead; Broadcaster Defended U.S.
description: Gordon Sinclair, the irreverent Canadian newsman who became a folk hero to many Americans in 1973 when he scolded the world for being ungrateful to the United States, died Thursday, two days after suffering a heart attack. He was 83 years old.

title: E.E.C. and I.B.M. In Antitrust Talks
description: The commission of the European Economic Community said it is in the ''final stages'' of negotiations with the International Business Machines Corporation to end one of the longest antitrust inquiries in the Common Market's history. The commission said last month that it planned to charge I.B.M. in June with abusing its dominant market position in Europe.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, Carol Bellamy's article yesterday misstated a proposed policy for housing homeless people. It should have read: ''The city should limit shelter development in communities that already provide housing.''

title: STUDENTS FIND HAVEN IN SEA OF TROUBLES
description: Daniele's father killed himself last year. Her mother is unable to provide for her. Daniele is a high school senior who has been fending for herself since she was 14 years old. ''I just cut off the dream that everything was going to work out, because it wasn't,'' she said.

title: Harwood Memorial Service
description: There will be a memorial service this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Church of the Good Shepherd for the late conductor C. William Harwood, who died of viral pneumonia on April 26. Mr. Harwood, who conducted Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' last year on Broadway, also led the world premiere performance of George Rochberg's ''Confidence Man'' and two operas by Stephen Paulus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the newly created Harwood Fund at Yale University. The Church of the Good Shepherd is located at 236 East 31st Street.

description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe vowed today to begin a crackdown on opposition forces, whom he blamed for the murder of an aide.

description: The huge market for Treasury bonds is normally so active that a seller can find a ready buyer by shaving the asking price by as little as 1/ 32 point - or a mere 31 1/4 cents on a $1,000 bond.

description: A pro football job may be coming after all to Howard Schnellenberger , the head coach of the national champion University of Miami team.

description: Physicians conducting a full medical examination of President Reagan today discovered and partly removed a small polyp from Mr. Reagan's colon. Hours later they determined that it was benign, the White House said tonight.

Paramount made ''The Winds of War,'' based on the first volume of Mr. Wouk's World War II saga.

U.S. to Recommend Wider Use of Vaccine
description: Recent improvements in influenza vaccines prompted Federal health officials yesterday to recommend vaccinations for a wider group of people, including many health professionals and any individuals who want to reduce their chances of getting the flu.

SOVIET STRATEGY ON JEWS
description: The rabbi of the Choral Synagogue in Moscow, Adolph Shayevich, is touring the United States as part of a delegation of Soviet religious dignitaries whose host is the National Council of Churches. This startling development - the first time a Russian Jewish religious figure has been permitted to visit the West since 1976 - apparently is part of a propaganda counteroffensive. Moreover, the new look has not improved the situation of Soviet Jews. Nor has it softened official Soviet attitudes toward protests by Jews, here and in the Soviet Union.

title: PARK-FIRE INQUIRY FINDS THE SYSTEM FELL SHORT
description: The responsibility for inspecting the rides and attactions at amusement parks in New Jersey is determined by a complex and varied set of local, state and Federal laws.

A WORLD OF LECTURES IN NEW YORK CITY: FROM BALI TO NOAH'S HAMBURGER
description: If Samuel Pepys, that tireless man- about-17th-century London, were chronicling the edifying events available in New York in any given week, he would be hard put to find time to write all of them up in his diary.

title: GENERAL MOTORS GOES COURTING
description: It might have been Fay Wray describing how King Kong had come calling at the stake: ''When a company the size of G.M. approaches,'' H. Ross Perot, the founder and controlling stockholder of Dallas-based Electronic Data Systems told a business group Thursday, ''you have to consider it. We were flattered that they came to us.''

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $237,000. c-Net income includes an extraordinary gain of $159,000.

title: Police Occupy La Paz Bank
description: Armed policemen in combat gear occupied the central bank today while employees remained on strike to hamper the introduction of austerity measures aimed at getting a loan for Bolivia from the International Monetary Fund.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., a diversified company based in Valley Forge, Pa., said it had agreed in principle to acquire Brown Drug Co., a wholesale distributor of pharmaceuticals, health and beauty aids and general merchandise, for an undisclosed price.

title: FAULTING JUDGES ON PRISON
description: TheFederati on of New York State Judges has called on its members to fight crime by sending more felons to state prison, thereby endorsing the fundamentally misguided crime-control policies that have been in effect in the state for more than a decade. Crime cannot be controlled by the courts alone, nor by building more prisons. The brute logic underlying the judges' statement that locking up more people for longer periods of time will enhance public safety fails on nearly every count.

title: BODY IN THE BRONX IDENTIFIED AS KIDNAPPED BUSINESSMAN
description: A body found Wednesday in a park in the Bronx was identified by the police yesterday as that of a New Jersey businessman who had been kidnapped in Manhattan's garment district while apparently carrying thousands of dollars.

title: MONDALE STEPS UP HIS ATTACK ON HART
description: Walter F. Mondale today ridiculed Senator Gary Hart's assertion that a sizable share of the former Vice President's national convention delegates were ''tainted'' and might have been elected with illegal campaign funds.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies yesterday about charges of stock fraud involving advance knowledge of articles in The Wall Street Journal misidentifed the man who was reported to have arrived at a lawyer's office with a ''stack of $100 bills'' and to have expressed a desire to ''flee the jurisdiction.'' The man was Peter N. Brant, the former stockbroker, not David W. C. Clark, the lawyer.

title: Swiss to Vote On Bank Law
description: After years of intense public debate, Switzerland will decide in a referendum Sunday on whether to modify what has become as much a part of the Swiss image as watches and chocolate - the secret bank account.

title: Briton Facing Inquiry
description: The British Amateur Athletic Board announced yesterday the squad of marathon runners it will send to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, and then immediately said that its No. 1 star, Geoff Smith , winner of last month's Boston Marathon, could be disqualified. Smith, a Providence College student, may have violated rules of the International Amateur Athletic Federation by wearing a vest with the name of a computer company, Prime Computer of Natick, Mass., in the Boston race. Smith said he had written a letter to the British board, which will hold an inquiry, and he added, ''I hope everything turns out all right.''

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Dallas woman who may never have set foot on the Baylor University campus has left property worth $13.8 million to the institution, the largest single gift in Baylor's 139-year history, university officials said today.

title: Miss Crile Weds Dr. Joseph S. Murphy
description: Susan Crile, an abstract painter, and Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, were married yesterday. The New York State Commissioner of Human Rights, Carl McCall, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's Manhattan residence.

title: DRUG TALK IN 1980 LAID TO DELOREAN
description: James Timothy Hoffman told a jury today that John Z. DeLorean discussed the narcotics business with him in 1980 and said at that time he ''had at least one episode of cocaine trafficking for profit.''

title: WHITE HOUSE IRKED ABOUT DISCLOSURE
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, today accused David A. Stockman, the budget director, of giving out a ''bum story'' about White House attitudes toward the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Picaresque Parable
description: The allegorical terrain of the comic novel ''Budding Prospects'' is ironically bracketed by its two epigraphs: a homely Benjamin Franklin adage advocating the virtues of planning, rationality and thrift (''Plough deep, while Sluggards sleep; and you shall have Corn to sell and to keep''), and the bragadoccio refrain of rugged adventurism from ''Death of a Salesman'' (''Why, boys, when I was seventeen I walked into the jungle, and when I was twenty-one I walked out. And by God I was rich.'').

After using only five players for most of last season, Coach Pete Carril , the first recipient of the endowment, could probably use a bench as well as that chair.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 19, 1984 International
description: Its effort to limit the Iran-Iraq war was reaffirmed by the Reagan Administration. A State Department spokesman said the United States was ''prepared to work with others, particlularly the states of the region, in common efforts to contain the effects of this tragic war,'' but sought to minimize any appearance of a military crisis. (Page 1, Column 6.) Refuge for Andrei D. Sakharov's wife in the United States Embassy in Moscow was sought by him in letters that were given by his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, to embassy officials, State Department officials said. Dr. Sakharov was said to have also disclosed plans for a hunger strike. But the officials said Miss Bonner had not discussed the hunger strike, which began May 2, or the appeal for her to stay in the embassy. (1:5.)

description: A shopper in a Brooklyn grocery store was shot in the head yesterday by a gunman who calmly walked up to the victim, pulled a revolver and fired once without saying a word, the police said.

description: Richard Wirthlin, President Reagan's principal poll-taker, told the executive committee of the Republican National Committee today, ''It's going to take a full-blown effort of all Republicans to re-elect this President.''

title: No Headline

title: Gala Dance Benefit Set For Felt Forum June 4
description: Some 1,200 children, a dozen New York City policemen and celebrities including Mary Tyler Moore and leading members of the New York City Ballet will dance in a new musical written and directed by Jacques d'Amboise June 4 at 8 P.M. at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

title: SOVIET RESTRICTING NEWS OF DISSIDENT
description: Sixteen days after Andrei D. Sakharov is said to have started a hunger strike, the Soviet authorities are maintaining a solid lid on information about the physicist and dissident.

title: Air Illinois Filing
description: Air Illinois, citing ''continuing financial difficulties'' after a fatal crash and temporary shutdown of its flight operations, has filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws. The carrier did not say how much it owes, but in its statement filed in the United States District Court, the airline said the move was forced by ''continuing financial difficulties and the results of lawsuits being filed by various creditors.''

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF 'AMNON V ' TAMAR'
description: With ''Amnon V'Tamar,'' which received its New York premiere at American Ballet Theater's performance Thursday night in the Metropolitan Opera House, Martine van Hamel made an ambitious attempt to choreograph a work in the strongly dramatic style for which this company is known. Yet though it dealt with such matters as lust, incest and homosexuality, ''Amnon V'Tamar'' (which means ''Amnon and Tamar'' in Hebrew) was strangely tame and bloodless.

title: 4 Cosmos Starters Face Salary Cuts or Waivers
description: Four of the Cosmos' starting players are facing a demand by the club that they take salary cuts and will likely be dropped from the team by Tuesday afternoon if they refuse to do so.

title: NEW YORK BIKERS-TOO FREE-WHEELING AND A PUBLIC MENACE
description: Spring in New York City once meant the arrival of the best foot- traveling season. That was in the days before bicycles burst unrestrained onto this most congested American scene. Now, each spring means more bikes entering the already perilous fray, bikes of all sizes and speeds, pedaled by novices, experts and a lot in between. Whether riding for wage or fun, to work or to school, what most pedalers share is a blithe unconcern for common traffic laws.

title: Disappeared - in Pakistan
description: It is a sad, appalling reality that in much of the world, governments kidnap with impunity. In the euphemistic state of martial ''law,'' people vanish, sometimes for months, sometimes forever. And the roster of victims is as coldly anonymous as the phone book.

title: Letter: On Auto Imports A Quota in the National Interest To the Editor:
description: Your May 7 editorial ''Earned, and Unearned, Auto Bonuses'' is filled with false logic and defeatist economics. It completely ignores the future well-being of U.S.-based auto manufacturing, the other domestic industries dependent on auto making and all the workers and communities involved.

title: Back in the Ring
description: Oscar Bejines , fighting for the first time since his brother, Francisco (Kiko) Bejines , died of injuries received in a World Boxing Council bantamweight title bout with Alberto Davila last September, scored a unanimous 10-round decision Thursday night over Kelvin Lampkin at the Olympic Auditorium in Los Angeles. This was the same ring in which Kiko Bejines had his last fight, and there was a grim reminder in another scheduled 10-rounder when Claude Noel of Trinidad, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, was knocked unconscious in the second round by Rene Arredondo of Mexico and carried out of the ring on a stretcher. He was taken to a hospital, where he was treated for a concussion and released.

title: YANKS LOSE IN 10 INNINGS
description: One week after the Yankees followed a 16-inning game with a 17-inning affair, they sent their game with the California Angels into overtime last night by rallying for two runs with two out in the ninth inning. This time, though, the Yankees did not reach the 17th or the 16th inning.

title: Historic Autograph Set Auctioned at Christie's
description: A set of 56 autograph letters and documents of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, assembled by Philip D. Sang, a Chicago ice cream manufacturer, was purchased at a Christie's auction yesterday by Kenneth W. Rendell, an autograph dealer of Newton, Mass. It went for $352,000, a record for a set of signers of the declaration.

title: Scott & Fetzer
description: The Scott & Fetzer Company said that it is studying a revised proposal to be acquired by the Ivan F. Boesky Company, but that a preliminary analysis ''indicates that the revised proposal does not appear to have addressed all of the significant conditions that were of most concern'' in Boesky's original offer, which was rejected. Both of Boesky's proposals for the Westlake, Ohio-based company, which produces Kirby vacuum cleaners and the World Book encyclopedia, were for $60 a share, or a total of about $420 million. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Scott & Fetzer fell 87.5 cents, to $52.375.

title: Slayer Sentenced to Death
description: Ottis Elwood Toole, a 37-year- old drifter linked to as many as 100 slayings nationwide, was sentenced to death in Florida's electric chair today for starting a fire that killed a resident at a boarding house.

title: STAGE: 'HANG ON TO ME' AT THE GUTHRIE THEATER
description: A little over a year ago, the maverick 26- year-old director Peter Sellars was dismissed from ''My One and Only'' during that Gershwin musical's pre- Broadway tryout. Mr. Sellars may have little regard for Broadway these days, but his ardor for George and Ira Gershwin remains undimmed. In ''Hang On to Me,'' his new show at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater, Mr. Sellars has created another new Gershwin musical by injecting 15 vintage songs into a ''book'' by Maxim Gorky.

title: Defund the Un-Left?
description: It sounds like a juicy scandal: Federal agencies allowing nonprofit organizations to promote leftist causes with Federal grant money. On closer examination, the ''scandal'' is mostly a figment of fevered far-right fears. Yet the Office of Management and Budget takes it seriously, issuing restrictive new grant and contract rules.
