title: A.I.A.W. Denied Antitrust Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court threw out today a suit by a now-defunct national women's athletic group that had accused the National Collegiate Athletic Association of forcing it to disband. The decision, issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, upheld an earlier ruling by a district court.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MARCO'S PARTY TAKES LEAD IN ELECTIONS
description: For the first time since Monday's elections for the National Assembly, both Government and independent tallies showed the ruling party winning more seats than the opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DR. HENRI ABEL
description: Dr. Henri Abel, a dermatologist and member of the emeritus staff of the Elizabeth (N.J.) General Medical Center, died of heart disease May 11 at the hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Elizabeth.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS PLAN TRADE AND DEBT STEPS
description: The United States and the other leading industrial nations agreed today to take several new steps to liberalize international trade and to help ease the developing world's debt burden.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KOCH URGES BILL TO SHIFT RULINGS IN ABUSE CASSES
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he would support legislation requiring the Family Court to decide whether an abused child should be removed from foster care and returned to his parents.

title: THE MATING GAME AND OTHER EXERCISES AT THE VERTICAL CLUB
description: A young woman in a leotard stands at the juice bar in an East Side health club, enjoying some low-fat Dutch Apple yogurt. A remarkably handsome, sweaty stranger with really good deltoid definition sidles up and orders carob peanuts and freshly squeezed grapefruit juice, large. He turns slowly, looks her in the eyes, and speaks. ''Yogurt is mucous forming,'' he says softly. ''My name is Sharon,'' she replies.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NATURA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Ex-Press Aide to Ford Gets Mutual News Post
description: Ron Nessen, a former broadcast reporter who was press secretary to President Gerald R. Ford, is returning to journalism as the top news executive of the Mutual Broadcasting System, the radio network announced today.

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $177,000 from discontinued operations and a tax benefit of $113,000. c-Includes a tax benefit of $30,000.

title: BELGIUM STANDARD LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have stated that the U.S. Government will stand behind its banking system and I mean it. We want to make sure in these perilous times that there is no doubt we support our banks.'' - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. (33:4.)

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including investment gains of $21,446,000. c-Including investment gains of $10,120,000. Year-ago revenues restated to include additional companies in consolidation.

title: THE REGION ; Creedmoor's Violent Ways
description: Life in the ''secure unit'' at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center was anything but, according to a report last week in The New York Times. State investigators found evidence of widespread abuse of those in the unit for the most violent patients at the Queens hospital.

title: WARD RETURNS IN RALLY
description: Bruce Ward led New Rochelle High School to two impressive relay victories today in the 44th annual Eddy Games at the Union College Field.

title: RED BANK RELAXES ITS RIVERRFRONT ZONING
description: SET high on the red-soil bluff just above the Navesink River, Red Bank's West Front Street is an urban hodgepodge where shops and supermarkets rub shoulders with churches, banks and once-stately mansions.

title: International
description: A ship bound for an Iranian port sank in the Persian Gulf after being attacked by Iraqi jets Friday, State Department officials said. The 17,000- ton bulk carrier was apparently carrying steel to the port of Bandar Khomeini. It was the first reported case of a merchant ship being sunk in the Iran-Iraq war. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Amanda Brown Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Amanda Tilgham Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bowers Hynson Brown of New York, to Burton Jonathan Megargel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Welles F. Megargel of Bronxville, N.Y., and Lake Ariel, Pa., took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Anne Brewster Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Mondale Edges Jackson For Virginia Delegates
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale narrowly defeated the Rev. Jesse Jackson today as Virginia Democrats finished picking 78 delegates to the national convention.

title: TOURING FRANCE EN FAMILLE
description: We were on final approach to Paris's Charles de Gaulle Airport when my 5-year-old daughter announced she was going to be sick. My 8-year-old son, who had kept me up most of the night, lay collapsed across my lap. In short, it was a disaster.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH FOR 3-0 LEAD
description: Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks said he couldn't ask his team to play any better than it did today in the third game of the Eastern Conference final series with the Boston Celtics. If that is true, then he can ask his players to begin making plans for the summer.

title: JAMES BAKER: CALLING REAGAN'S RE-ELECTION MOVES
description: Francis X. Clines is a correspondent in The Times's Washington bureau who covers the White House.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Dance
description: Annabelle Gamson is probably best known as a powerful interpreter of the dances of Isadora Duncan, though she has performed her own choreography and that of Mary Wigman. On Wednesday, she will celebrate her 10th anniversary as a ''Duncan dancer'' with a gala at Carnegie Hall.

title: Letitia C. Biddle Is Betrothed
description: James Biddle of Andalusia, Pa., and Louisa Copeland Duemling of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Letitia Copeland Biddle to Seth Matthew Blitzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hollander Blitzer of Roslyn Harbor, L.I. A winter wedding is planned.

title: IN MX PLAN, THE HOUSE MAKES THE PROBLEMS THE SOLUTION
description: Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat, once said that if you give Congressmen a chance to vote on both sides of an issue, they'll do it every time. Last week Mr. Aspin had another example. With the House of Representatives facing an excruciating choice over whether to halt production of the MX missile or forge ahead with a full-scale procurement schedule, Mr. Aspin found a way for the lawmakers to settle somewhere in the middle. His compromise, approved 229 to 199, provides $1.8 billion for only 15 missiles; that compares to 40 requested by the President and 30 approved by the Armed Services Committee.

title: NEW LEADS IN DONOVAN CASE ARE DISCOUNTED
description: An attorney for a New Jersey businessman discounts the significance of leads being pursued by a Federal prosecutor in the 1982 murder of a man who had been questioned in investigations of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Caution, Fish X-ing
description: The fate of Westway and the revival of Manhattan's lower West Side may depend on the ability of New York State officials to relocate some of those who now call the area home. That became clear last week when the Army Corps of Engineers released a study concluding that construction of the $2 billion project would have a ''significant adverse impact'' on striped bass who spend a portion of the year in the lower Hudson River. The study also determined, however, that there was a ''reasonable chance'' that the impact could be cushioned. State officials must now convince the Army engineers that new habitats for the bass can be created elsewhere.

title: An Olympic Site
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS WITH SHALLOW ROOT SYSTEMS
description: THE problems that resulted from this spring's windstorms affected many homeowners and gardeners in this region. Most of the trees uprooted had very shallow root systems. The combination of strong winds and saturated soil had allowed them to be torn from the earth. The real culprit, however, was most often a shallow soil underlain by a hardpan.

title: THE UPHILL BATTLE TO PAY FOR COLLEGE
description: IT'S no secret that financing a child's college

title: THE SEARCH GOES ON FOR STRADIVARI'S SECRET
description: Boil 1 lb. shrimp shells with strong lye for a whole day. Strain it through cheesecloth and wash the residue with a lot of water. Dissolve residue in vinegar to a maple syrup-like consistency.

title: COMMUNITY FILMS TV DOCUDRAMA
description: MORRISTOWN A FILM on the Revolutionary War winter of 1779-80, as seen through the eyes of an 18th-century Presbyterian clergyman here, is scheduled to be shown in the fall on public-television stations across the country.

title: Angela Burdeau Haggerty Is Married To P S S i O B
description: Angela Burdeau Haggerty, a daughter of Mrs. Richard Farnsworth Hunnewell of Locust Valley, L.I., and New York, and Joseph J. Haggerty Jr. of Amagansett, L.I., and New York, was married yesterday to Pierce Stewart Sioussat, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Sioussat of Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Peter Sweisgood and the Rev. Peter Jacob.

title: Future Events
description: Artistic Pursuits

title: KRICKSTEIN IN FINAL IN ITALY
description: Aaron Krickstein, at age 16 the youngest semifinalist in the history of the Italian Open tennis championships, and fifth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador advanced to the final today.

title: Japan's Stake
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Not Missed
description: Pete Johnson, the fullback for the Cincinnati Bengals, is boycotting the team's minicamp, and Coach Sam Wyche said the absence of the club's career-leading rusher is no loss to the team.

title: POLLY D. EMMONS IS BRIDE IN DARIEN
description: Polly Dean Emmons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. and Mrs. Harry I. Emmons of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stuart McAlpin Tilghman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Tilghman of New York and Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Henry A. Tilghman, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Peking Planning an Increase In Trade With Eastern Europe
description: China is to increase trade ties with Eastern Europe, a Chinese official indicated in an interview published today.

title: PREAKNESS IS WON BY GATE DANCER
description: Gate Dancer, the colt who ran so erratically only two weeks ago that he became the first horse ever disqualified for interference in the Kentucky Derby, straightened out under Angel Cordero Jr. today and won the 109th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course in track-record time.

title: KENTUCKY'S WOMAN AT THE HELM
description: Gov. Martha Layne Collins of Kentucky, the nation's only governor who is a woman, says that her husband, Bill, is the real politician in the family, even though he enjoys his role as ''first spouse.''

title: SCHOOLS COUNSEL ON ALCHOHOL
description: IN spite of themselves, convicted

title: BOTTOM LINEMANSHIP
description: America is suffering from an unhealthy emphasis on success as measured by The Numbers. The tendency to boil the world down into analytic abstractions distorts and oversimplifies the richness of life. It insists upon evaluating the world through ratings and lists, matrices and polls, the bottom line, winners and losers.

title: South African Arms Plans
description: Defense Minister Magnus Malan told Parliament on Friday that South Africa was considering making its own submarines and helicopters in view of a United Nations embargo against selling the weapons to the Pretoria Government.

title: VOTE DRIVE AN ISSUE AGAIN IN BRIDGEPORT
description: WHILE voter registration drives are in progress around the country, a similar effort in Bridgeport is stuck at the beginning: getting permission to go out and sign up new voters.

title: A CRITIC'S IMPERTURBABLE ASSURANCE
description: Donald Davie teaches at Vanderbilt University. His most recent book is ''Collected Poems 1970-1983.'' SELECTED ESSAYS OF JOHN CROWE RANSOM

title: Offers Made on Homes Imperiled by Mine Fire
description: Nineteen families threatened by a 22- year-old underground mine fire received offers for their homes Friday in the start of a four-year, Government- sponsored relocation program.

title: CABARET: SHOW TUNES
description: ''Broadway Babylon,'' a cabaret revue featuring songs from commercially unsuccessful Broadway shows, takes the seed of a nice idea and buries it in the arid sands of a bargain basement production.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BERLIN
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Bonn bureau of The Times.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
PRINCE CHARLES STARS AT THE OPERA
description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on the cable TV scene.

title: ACOUSTICAL PROBLEMS STILL PLAGUE THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The musicians of the New York Philharmonic have never been entirely happy in their Lincoln Center home and neither have some discriminating listeners. That is understating the case. When Philharmonic Hall opened in 1962 it immediately became clear that an acoustical egg of legendary size and cost ($21 million) had been laid. In 1976, after 14 years of minor tinkering, major remodeling and further expenditures totaling $7 million, the hall changed its name and tried to begin a new life. Under its new identity as Avery Fisher Hall, it has lived down to some extent the curse of its birth and its bad reputation. Certainly it is now possible, on selected good nights under selected good conductors, to enjoy orchestral music there.

title: MOSCOW HONORS PSYCHIATRIST
description: The Soviet Union today honored the nation's leading psychiatrist, who has been accused by the World Psychiatry Association of abusing his science to punish political dissidents.

title: 49 Food Outlets Cited by City ;
description: 49 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

title: Return to Religion
description: I was not surprised to see Fran Schumer's article, ''A Return to Religion'' (April 15), depicting the rise of religious interest among intellectuals today. What bothered me was that this response to faith is largely an armchair one.

title: THE WORLD;
description: Panama's New Leader

title: 'UNSINKABLE MOLLY BROWN' IN DARIEN
description: DINNER theater need not subsist on a steady diet of tried and tired musicals. Such establishments can aspire to fill the need for an ongoing musical repertory theater, instead of settling for obvious crowd pleasers.

title: MONDALE-HART RACE DELIGHTS G.O.P.
description: Walter F. Mondale's inability to knock Gary Hart out of the Democratic Presidential contest has encouraged President Reagan's campaign planners and stirred new doubts among some Democrats about Mr. Mondale's strength for the general election, according to strategists in both parties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing on April 29 of food establishments cited for violations of the health code misidentified a Manhattan outlet. It was Kennedy Fried Chicken at 2419 Second Avenue, not Kentucky Fried Chicken.

title: STEWART POSTS 64 TO LEAD BY 2
description: Payne Stewart shot a six-under-par 64 today and pulled away to a two-stroke lead over Peter Jacobsen in the third round of the $500,000 Colonial National Invitation golf tournament.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Broadcast TV
description: ''The Regard of Flight,'' Bill Irwin's masterful clown show, will be given a special repeat performance on Monday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13. Originally produced at the American Place Theater, this is a high-flying revue with mime, eccentric dancing and physical and verbal comedy.

title: THE COSTS OF SELLING U.S. TECHNOLOGY
description: The Reagan Administration's campaign to plug leaks of Western high technology to the Soviet bloc is causing fresh tensions in the Atlantic alliance.

title: Beekman Place Co-op To Consider Sale Offers
description: Four-fifths of the shareholders in a cooperative apartment house at 455 East 51st Street have voted to consider selling the property, leaving the future of the building at the north end of Beekman Place uncertain.

title: OCEAN DUMPING: NO GUIDELINES
description: THE continuing pollution of the Atlantic Ocean and of harbors in New Jersey and New York is partly a result, according to environmental lawyers, state and Federal officials and conservationists, of Congress' failure for more than a decade to enact specific scientifically sound pollution-abatement laws.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS WITH SHALLOW ROOT SYSTEMS
description: THE problems that resulted from this spring's windstorms affected many homeowners and gardeners in this region. Most of the trees uprooted had very shallow root systems. The combination of strong winds and saturated soil had allowed them to be torn from the earth. The real culprit, however, was most often a shallow soil underlain by a hardpan.

title: 44 REPORTED KILLED IN NEW INDIAN RIOTS
description: At least 50 people were reported killed today in a second day of rioting between Hindus and Moslems in and around Bombay.

title: COOKING AIDS FROM ACROSS THE CENTURIES
description: -century American pantry boxes are neatly stacked next to a terra-cotta, 20th-century African storage jar. A glazed ceramic teapot, designed in 1968, echoes the form of the nearby 16th-century Chinese ceramic water pot. Cookie cutters, dessert molds and pastry tubes, common items in most households, acquire added design interest displayed in multiples while a bronze, Chinese Han Dynasty stove, shaped like a dragon, stands alone.

title: JONES REFLECTS ON FESTIVAL
description: YEARS ago, when officials at the State University of New York at Purchase approached Brooks Jones to, as he describes it, ''evaluate the viability of a theater built in the middle of a field in a town that had a population of 1,000,'' he told them very simply that it was ''a silly idea'' that ''didn't make a whit of sense.''

title: Filet Mignon or Cream Puff?
description: To the Editor:

title: ON LANGUAGE ; That Says It All
description: The ultimate shorthand is upon us. A single phrase is rampant in the American language, a phrase that seems to encapsulate long arguments and reduce complex explanations to a single line.

title: BATTLING A 'BROOK' IN BASEMENT
description: THREE sump pumps work virtually around the clock in Art Foure's Smithtown basement in an attempt to remove the two feet of water he has faced since November. To publicize his plight, he has posted a sign in front of his house that reads ''Nissequogue River, Foure's Brook.''

title: NOTEBOOK: BRINK'S JURY ALMOST COMPLETE
description: JURY selection in the Brink's murder and robbery trial, a long and complicated procedure that involved thousands of potential panelists, months of effort and considerable sums of money, was concluded here last week - almost.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MAY is National Older Americans Month. According to three ''older'' New Jerseyans, age has nothing to do with their way of life, which resembles a whirlwind.

title: Stephen Dirks Is Wed To Christine P. Flynn
description: Christine Patrice Flynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Flynn of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Stephen Merle Dirks, a son of Lee E. Dirks of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Barbara N. Dirks of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. John C. Purdy, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Roof Garden on West 26th Street.

title: CABARET: MISS FIELDS REMEMBERED
description: Dorothy Fields's range as a lyric writer often comes as a surprise because the names of the composers with whom she wrote many of her most successful songs - Jerome Kern, Arthur Schwartz, Sigmund Romberg, Cy Coleman - are better known than hers. But she contributed to a rich catalogue that includes ''I Can't Give You Anything but Love,'' ''Exactly Like You,'' ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' ''A Fine Romance,'' ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' ''Big Spender'' and many others.

title: No Headline
description: Under the Clock This week a friend of ours walked over to the new Bank of America Plaza, on Madison at 43d, for a look at the old Biltmore clock and, in a sense, her past. Once she was one of the young women in camel's-hair coats who stood in the Palm Court, under that clock, waiting for their rep-tied dates and feeling more worldly than they'd ever felt before, or ever would again.

title: 35 U.S. SCHOOL BOARDS SUE TO FORCE MANUFACTURERS TO REMOVE ASBESTOS
description: With the Environmental Protection Agency stepping up its campaign against asbestos in schools, more than 35 school boards around the nation have filed lawsuits to get asbestos manufacturers to pay for removing the potentially hazardous material from their buildings.

title: FINE PASTA AND A WARM WELCOME
description: MANDUCATI'S in Long Island City, Queens, looks like a neighborhood bar on an avenue lined with warehouses and small industrial plants. The impression is hardly dispelled upon entering the premises, a large barroom with a television set, a pay phone and a penetrating beery aroma. But carrot fettuccine with asparagus, listed among the daily specials on the blackboard at one end of the room, provides the first clue that there is more than spaghetti and beer to be had at Manducati's.

title: Senate Bites
description: The Deficit

title: PRIVATE ISLAND POSES PUBLIC ISSUE
description: ALTHOUGH Francesco Galesi was not certain exactly what use to make of Clam Island on Noyack Bay when his development company, Northeastern Industrial Park, bought the land three years ago, he found the site exceptionally attractive and knew he wanted to reserve at least part of it for himself.

title: WONDERING HOW IT CAN BE 'SO LATE SO EARLY'
description: ONE Mother's Day, I was saddened by my gifts. It's not that I was forgotten by my four daughters: there was a bouquet of flowers, Betty Friedan's latest book, a designer scarf and a small French cast-iron casserole. But there wasn't a single garish potholder, no clay handprint paperweight, no decorated juice-can penholder. The price and taste of my gifts was one more indication that my children have grown up.

title: MT. ST. VINCENT GIVES DEGREE TO MRS. AQUINO, '53 ALUMNA
description: The wife of the slain Philippine opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., told the 72d graduating class of the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx yesterday that last week's election results in her country were a tribute to ''the courage and faith that shone luminously through my much troubled people.''

title: TOXIC SUBSTANCE BILL CLEARS A HURDLE
description: The State Senate's Codes Committee this week approved and sent to the full Senate legislation to extend the time in which people injured by exposure to toxic substances can sue for damages.

title: HANGING ON.
description: The trouble with Robert Beason's first novel, ''Hanging On,'' is that its narrative voice works overtime at sounding authentic about the issues of old age without ever sounding like the voice of an authentic person. Set in a senior citizens' residence in Connecticut, ''Hanging On'' is narrated by Ben Carpenter, 73, a widower and retired journalist.

title: Nassau's Budget And Illegal Dwellings
description: The budget gap and crunch in Nassau County could be eased a good bit if the Supervisors and the County Executive took a positive but a ''politically dangerous'' stand in the respect of illegal multifamily dwellings.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION ;
FAMILY VIOLENCE: THE PRICE WE PAY IS DEAR
description: DAVID is 17 years old. He is tall and lean, with blond hair and a bony face. He is pleasant and polite but, as he readily acknowledges, capable of brutal and unprovoked violence.

title: BILL ON ZONING OF GROUP HOMES
description: -year struggle, a bill exempting group homes for the mentally ill from local zoning ordinances emerged this year from the General Assembly.

title: LEBANESE CABINET AGREES ON POLICY
description: Lebanon's 19-day-old Cabinet reached agreement today on a policy statement that Prime Minister Rashid Karami said would provide a new national accord for ending nine years of civil strife in the country.

title: NEW BOOK ON POPE CAUSE OF DISAGREEMENT BETWEEN VATICAN AND AUTHOR
description: A new book on Pope John Paul II has created a disagreement between the author and the Vatican. The author says that his report on the Pope's personal life, the factors behind his election and the attempt on his life was based on 200 hours he spent talking with the Pope. But a Vatican official says that the author never spoke to the Pope at all.

title: HARSH WORDS ARE A STAPLE OF THE DEBATE
description: The words flew out like pellets from a slingshot here the other day as the delegates of member nations turned a meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council into a forum for denunciation.

title: GIAN CARLO MENOTTI: 'I'M TAKING STOCK OF WHAT I'VE DONE'
description: In the spring of 1979, Gian Carlo

title: Police Question Students After Seoul Protests
description: The police said today that they were questioning 59 students accused of leading anti-Government demonstrations in Seoul on Friday, the fourth anniversary of the violent uprising in Kwangju.

title: THE WORLD;
description: A Wide Appeal To Let the Sakharovs Go

title: PHYSICIAN-WRITERS DISCUSS THEIR CRAFT
description: '' MEDICINE is my lawful wife; literature is my mistress,'' wrote Anton Chekhov, describing his life as both a physician and a writer.

title: TROOPER KILLED
description: A man sought in the disappearance of at least six residents of this tiny fishing village died today in shootout with the police after killing a state trooper, the authorities said.

title: Sabrina Rood Is Bride Of Howard W. Sinker
description: Sabrina Mary Rood, a daughter of George M. Rood of New York and Joanna Goddard Stevens of Burlington, Vt., was married yesterday to Howard Warren Sinker, the son of Bertram W. Sinker and Elaine K. Sinker, both of Skokie, Ill. The Rev. Calvin Roetzel, a Methodist minister and professor of religion at Macalester College in St. Paul, performed the ceremony in the Macalester College chapel.

title: Miss Purcell Has Nuptials
description: Kathleen Ann Purcell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Purcell of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Mace Prime, a son of Theodore F. Prime of Lake Placid and Essex, N.Y., and Ruth Prime of Lake Placid. The Rev. Douglass Ray performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: HOBOKEN MAY LOSE VESTIGE OF AN ERA
description: HOBOKEN THE brawny heart of Hoboken has always been the city's waterfront. Oldtimers here remember when the piers stretched for a mile from one end of the city to the other, packed with ocean liners and tramp steamers from around the world and crawling with hundreds of roughneck longshoremen.

title: ADULT DYSLEXIACS HELPED TO LEARN ANEW
description: '' IT'S like being in jail, knowing you didn't commit a crime,'' said Donald DeSandre of New Rochelle, describing how it feels to be dyslexic.

title: THE FLAME FROM GREECE THAT REFRESHES
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: LIBRARY MUSICALES

title: ADS PICKING UP AT USA TODAY
description: USA TODAY, the Gannett Company's national newspaper, had 13.1 pages of advertising in Monday's edition, the best day yet for a venture that is still struggling to become profitable.

title: Arizonan to Yield To Backer of Jackson
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona plans to step down as an uncommitted delegate to the Democratic National Convention and give his place to a supporter of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: CIRCULATION SHOOT-OUT IN DALLAS
description: IN the latest installment of the

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: FLYING TO EUROPE AND PAYING LESS
description: Last year, spurred by a stronger dollar and competition that pushed fares down, more Americans took European vacations than ever before. This year, the dollar is continuing its rise (although more slowly) and fares again are being subjected to downward pressure (although the force has been reduced), and even more Americans are expected to make the flight across the Atlantic.

title: FERRY PLAN STIRS MONTAUK
description: EVENINGS during the off season in Montauk Village are still. The only sound might be, as Walt Whitman wrote of the area in 1888, ''That inbound urge and urge of waves/Seeking the shores forever.'' It is a stillness some would prefer to maintain while others would prefer to change, a difference of opinion recently renewed by a proposed year-round ferry service from Lake Montauk to New London, Conn., scheduled to start on Memorial Day.

title: NEW GALLERY SHOWS ART 'FROMM THE HEART'
description: A FTER 20 years as a corporate art dealer in New York City, Stephen Haller has established a more personal outlet for his artistic inclinations. With his wife, the actress and writer Cynthia Griffin, he has opened the Griffin-Haller Gallery in the heart of Washington Depot.

title: Renee Schaff Married To a Copyright Lawyer
description: Renee Schaff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Schneider of Flushing, Queens, and Tel Aviv, was married yesterday to Sheldon Palmer, the son of Sam Pomerantz of Hallandale, Fla., and the late Ella Pomerantz. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at the Players Club in New York.

title: NEW TROUT BOOKS WORTHY OF PERUSAL
description: Although it sometimes seems as if more than enough books have been written on the subject of fly fishing, and fly fishing for trout in particular, some new ones have emerged worthy of mention.

title: FOR LANDLESS GARDENERS, THERE'S AMPLE ACREAGE IN TUBS AND BOXES;
description: Condominium terraces, apartment balconies, townhouses, swimming pool patios and redwood decks. What do they all have in common? No arable land, yet many of them sport beautiful flower gardens.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation: Up Again

title: INSULT AS ENTERTAINMENT: CULTURAL EVIL OR FAD?
description: Whatever other inequalities continue to afflict the nation, no American, regardless of race, religion, gender, sexual predilection or physical or mental distress, need be deprived these days of public insult. Generous compensation for years of neglect is available, with insults being doled out according to incapacity, affinity and heritage.

title: Lisa J. Leinbach Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Jane Leinbach, the daughter of Jill Long Leinbach of Rye, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late David Amole Leinbach, was married yesterday to Joseph Jonathan Huertas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Christopher Huertas of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Donald D. M. Jones performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of White Plains.

title: METS LOSE AS PITCHING FALTERS
description: The Mets suffered a total pitching collapse tonight as Ed Lynch, Tim Leary and Tom Gorman allowed eight runs in two innings and the Padres rolled to an 8-3 victory.

title: MORE JOBS, NOT ARMS
description: The House of Representatives has now accepted a last-gasp compromise to save production funding for the controversial and costly MX missile. The compromise calls for reducing the number of missiles to be procured in fiscal 1985 from 30 to 15, and for fencing off the actual funds for six months as an inducement to the Soviet Union to return to the strategic arms talks in Geneva.

title: THOUGHT POLICE
description: Adam Bromke , whose last book was ''Poland, the Protracted Crisis,'' is a professor of political science at McMaster University, Ontario. THE BLACK BOOK OF POLISH CENSORSHIP

title: THE NATION;
description: A Question Of Credulity

title: Elizabeth Psillas the Bride Of Gordon Cyril Lahey Jr.
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Stacey Psillas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lionel Psillas of Charles Town, W.Va., to Gordon Cyril Lahey Jr. took place yesterday at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Harpers Ferry, W.Va.

title: NEW MEASURE DEFINES ABUSE OF COMPUTERS
description: BACK in the days when the word ''apple'' only meant something to eat, a Connecticut lawmaker foresaw the need to cope with computer- related crime. So, the legislator, Richard D. Tulisano, a Democrat from Rocky Hill who is chairman of the State House of Representative's Judiciary Committee, introduced a bill in 1978 that would have established stiff criminal penalties for computer crimes, and began the legislative procedure.

title: BEWARE THE SELF-SERVING CRITICS
description: SHAREHOLDERS, taxpayers,

title: Shoreham's Effect On School Districts
description: As if there wasn't enough misinformation about the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station relating to safety, evacuation plans and fiscal implications, we now have two letters to the editor (April 29) muddying the waters about the effects of the plant on school finances.

title: F. J. Bartek Wed To Ann C. Draper
description: Ann Catherine Draper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Christopher Draper of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Frederic John Bartek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Bartek, also of Pittsburgh. The Very Rev. George L. W. Werner performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Cathedral, where he is the Dean.

title: R.M. GLEN, ALIXE C. REED ARE MARRIED
description: Alixe Claire Reed, deputy press secretary to Vice President Bush, and Robert Maxwell Glen, a political columnist for the News America Syndicate, both of Washington, were married yesterday in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Belasalus Rearris performed the ceremony.

title: TRAMPING OUT THE VINTAGE
description: IF YOU WERE SO FORTUNATE AS TO have Bordeaux wines from the 1975, 1976, 1977, 1978, 1979 and 1980 vintages stored safely in your wine cellar, you would try to drink them in the same order, beginning with the oldest, leaving the younger ones to age. Right? Wrong. With some minor variations, the best order for drinking those particular vintages probably would be: 1977, 1980, 1976, 1979, 1978 and 1975.

title: Faulty Air Conditioning Forces Two Jets to Land
description: A Republic Airlines DC-9 was forced to land shortly after takeoff because of smoke from the air conditioning system, airline officials confirmed today.

title: BALLET THEATER: A ROMP
description: Michael Vernon sent Marianna Tcherkassky and Danilo Radojevic off on a holiday romp. Since Mr. Vernon is a choreographer and Miss Tcherkassky and Mr. Radojevic are talented members of American Ballet Theater, it was only appropriate that this romp was ''In a County Garden,'' the pas de deux that received its New York premiere at the company's performance Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: HOW THE CHIP SPURS TV GROWTH
description: FOR years, parents have wondered how they could control the TV viewing habits of their offspring. Within a year, they may be wondering how they can control their TV.

title: IRAQI PLANES SINK A MERCHANT SHIP, STATE DEPT. SAYS
description: State Department officials said today that a Panamanian-registered cargo ship had sunk in the Persian Gulf after being attacked by Iraqi jets Friday.

title: AN EXPERT LOOKS AT FAMILY VIOLENCE
description: A Federal task force that has been studying violence in American families has concluded that ''what we know is that we don't know anything.'' That was one observation made in Washington the other day by Lois Haight Herrington, chairman of the Attorney General's Task Force on Family Violence.

title: DOCTOR'S EXAM A FIRST STEP TO THE FRESH AIR PROGRAM
description: A doctor pricked the child's arm, testing for tuberculosis. That elicited a yelp and a look of consternation from 10-year-old Wakisha Dames. But the pinch on the cheek and the tweak of the nose that followed brought a dimpled smile and laughter.

title: THE SELF LIKE A SHADOW
description: Robert Pack is Abernathy Professor of Literature at Middlebury College and director of the Breadloaf Writers Conference. His latest volume of poetry, ''Faces in a Single Tree: A Cycle of Monologues,'' will be published this summer. AFTER ONE

title: COPING WITH KIDS IN THE AIR
description: ''Try flying any plane with a baby if you want a sense of what it must have been like to be a leper in the 14th century,'' writes Nora Ephron in ''Heartburn.'' And she was talking about the New York-Washington shuttle.

title: BILL BANS FORCED RETIREMENT
description: TRENTON ABILL to prohibit compulsory retirement because of age has been passed unanimously by the Assembly and is now before the Senate State Government Committee.

title: No Headline
description: The downfall of Russia's Czar Nicholas, the Bolshevik takeover and all the murky, bloody doings in that corner of history are, and probably will remain, as irresistible to novelists as catnip to cats. Duncan Kyle, a British practitioner of the suspense genre, has peeked once again into that corner with convoluted but engaging results. Although the novel is set in the present, it revolves around a plot initiated in 1917 by Britain's King George V and the nefarious Sir Basil Zaharoff to rescue Czar Nicholas from the hands of the Bolsheviks. For their purpose they employed an English naval officer, whose background made him as fluent in Russian as he was in English, to offer $:50-million to the harried Bolsheviks to save the Czar. Mr. Kyle's tale alternates between the details of this plot (revealed through excerpts from the memoirs of the naval officer) and current events in the English banking house that is still paying out $:50,000 a year to an account in a Swiss bank, with no questions asked. This sum has been paid out since 1920 even though Sir Basil died in 1936. The British bank executives, in their inimitable way, have never questioned the practice, but a new American partner does question it and thereby sets into motion events that have been lying dormant for almost 50 years. The mission to Moscow, the Czar's immense gold treasure, the intrigues and passions surrounding the capture of the royal family, and the devilishly clever ruse the English naval officer uses to get both revenge and a final airing of his story are all revealed in rococo detail.

title: THE WORLD;
description: Libyan Overtures For Chad Accord

title: NEWER STATISTICS BECOME AVAILABLE FOR BASEBALL FANS
description: How often do baseball fans argue over which statistic provides the best measure of a player's value? Beginning today, The Times will add fuel to the arguments by presenting some traditional statistics that fans rarely see regularly and some new measures of hitting and pitching value.

title: About Men ; Last Will and Testament
description: William D. Zabel

title: PARABLES, PARODIES AND METAFICTIONS
description: Robert Coover teaches at Brown University and is the author of ''The Public Burning,'' ''Spanking the Maid'' and ''In Bed One Night and Other Brief Encounters.'' A CERTAIN LUCAS

title: NEW SALVADOR LEADER TO MEET WITH REAGAN
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, El Salvador's President-elect, left for the United States today for conferences with President Reagan and members of Congress after completing a round of meetings with the leaders of three Central American nations.

title: MANAGING YOUR FINANCES - A GOOD BOOK CAN HELP
description: ONE of the least expensive ways to get professional help in organizing your finances is to buy a good book on the subject. Several recently published books offer help - both for the neophyte and the financially sophisticated. Even those who are thinking of consulting a financial planner might find it profitable to sit down with a book and get their thoughts organized first. Some of the books offer worksheets for this purpose; others are more valuable as a references to cover all sorts of financial conditions. There are even books for those who are looking for entertaining reading, as well as financial information.

title: TWO ATHLETES ON THE SOVIET DECISION TO PULL OUT
description: THE refusal of the Soviet Union's National Olympic Committee to participate in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles is primarily prompted by the concern about the purity of the Olympic movement. Although I was preparing for the Games in real earnest, and could hope for a medal in the equestrian sport, I believe that this decision is the only correct one.

title: RATE TREND HAZY
description: NEARLY 60 percent of the mortgages being written today have adjustable rates, with the most common set about two percentage points above 3-month Treasury bills.

title: POTENT AMPLIFIERS MEET THE CHALLENGES OF THE CD ERA
description: When audio writers wax metaphorical - a frequent temptation - they usually call the amplifier the heart of the sound system. In this case, the metaphor is apt, for the amplifier indeed serves a central function. All signals - radio, records or tape - must pass through it on their way to the loudspeakers, and what happens to them on their passage through the amplifier is crucial to the quality of the sound.

title: ; DON'T SHOOT THE MINT JULEP'S BOURBON
description: To the Editor:

title: Lilco Gets More Bad News At Shoreham
description: Federal regulators decided last week not to change their rules and, as a result, the Long Island Lighting Company may have lost the game. Lilco has been racing to open its Shoreham nuclear reactor before the company runs out of cash.

title: KING CRIMSON: DESPITE UPHEAVAL, THE BAND PLAYS ON
description: The convoluted history of King Crimson is a rock genealogist's nightmare. The first group with that name was founded by the guitarist Robert Fripp in 1969, and during the next five years, every King Crimson album and tour featured a new lineup of musicians. The only player in every edition of King Crimson was Mr. Fripp himself.

title: DAVE JOHNSON IS ALWAYS ASKING 'WHY?'
description: They buried Col. F. A. Johnson in San Antonio last week with a three-gun salute and a bugler playing ''Taps.''

title: Burma Destroys Drug Bases
description: Burmese troops with air support have destroyed the bases of two drug warlords near the Thai border and seized large quantities of opium, Brig. Gen. Aye San, army commander for Burma's eastern region, said at a press briefing today. He said five heroin refineries had been destroyed in the raids on the bases of the Shan United Army and the Shan United Revolutionary Army.

title: LIFE-CARE CENTER OPENS
description: BLOOMFIELD THE first residents began to move into Duncaster, the state's newest life-care community for the aged, last week. The 216-unit development, which includes a 60-bed nursing unit and recreational facilities, is located on a 72-acre tract that had been a farm.

description: At St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Blauvelt, N.Y., yesterday Nancy Rae Ford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Ford of Blauvelt, was married to Lance John O'Neill Ford, the son of Frances C. Ford of San Diego and Brian J. O. Ford of New York. Msgr. Hugh D. Curran performed the ceremony.

title: PRIVACY JUST A CHIP SHOT AWAY
description: A 53-acre tract of undeveloped woodland in Southampton, L.I., is being turned into a condominum community designed to appeal to wealthy golf enthusiasts, and the developer says the goal is keep it as natural as possible. ''We're doing everything we can to protect the land,'' said Mary L. Crowe, a principal in the project, called Cold Spring Fairways, ''More than 75 percent of the property will be left in its natural state.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on April 29 about Prospect, a monthly magazine financed by a group of Princeton University alumni, incorrectly described its founding and misidentified the journalist William A. Rusher. Prospect was founded in 1972 by the Concerned Alumni of Princeton; Mr. Rusher is publisher of National Review.

title: TALK OF A U.P.I.- REUTERS MERGER
description: UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL may soon merge its foreign photographic operation with the foreign communications facilities of Reuters, the British-based news and financial information service, according to a source who asked not to be named.

description: Joanne Kaufman is a freelance writer and critic. QUEEN OF SWORDS

title: HOW PERSONAL COMPUTERS CAN MANAGE YOUR FINANCES BETTER
description: YOU bought the personal computer you always wanted. Unfortunately, its sole use has been to hone an already considerable talent at ''Space Invaders.'' How can you make that machine earn its keep? Why not marshall all those kilobytes and put them to work minding your finances? Balancing the checkbook might be a good start. Then, have the computer set up a budget and keep track of outlays by category. That way you'll know when you've overspent on expensive restaurants or underallocated for the Individual Retirement Account. And it can keep track of changes in your investment portfolio.

title: MAKING WILLS CAN AVERT PROBLEMS FOR HEIRS
description: THANKS to recent changes made by Congress, fewer and fewer Americans need pay a Federal estate tax. But, notwithstanding the generous reforms, lawyers and accountants specializing in estate planning say it is vitally important for all adults to analyze the size of their estate and then write a will. This procedure is essential for people who are seeking to minimize or even avoid estate taxes.

Judith Karen Stanley Is Married in Bedford

The Rev. Louise Weld performed the ceremony at St. Mary's in the Woods Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: 2 Legislators Tangle Over Diverted Spouse
description: A Rhode Island State Representative has sued her next-door neighbor, a State Senator, for alienation of affection.

title: NOW MARCOS'S RIVALS CAN LOOK OVER HIS SHOULDER
description: For President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the striking gains that were scored by his political rivals in elections for the National Assembly last week represent a challenge more than a defeat. Mr. Marcos will now have to contend with a genuine opposition in government for the first time since 1972, when he declared a reign of martial law that lasted until 1981.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
MORE PRECIOUS THAN JEWELS
description: THE minister had been busy all week with youth meetings, the committee for the Christmas bazaar, the building fund committee. On Saturday night he realized he didn't have a sermon for Sunday morning. He couldn't warm up an old one for hash, not for Mother's Day, the worst Sunday of the year. He tended more toward the ''cows of Bashan'' kind of thinking, the Pauline attitude toward women.

description: Ruth Mary Wimer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Wimer of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Timothy Aloysius Chorba, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Chorba of the Bronx. The Rev. Louis L. DeNinno performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Cathedral.

title: PAKISTAN TIGHTENS CURBS ON DISSENT
description: Pakistan's military Government appears to be clamping the lid ever more tightly on dissent and free expression in an attempt to prepare the ground and set the terms for the elections that President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq has promised to hold by next spring.

title: SEARCHING THE ECONOMY FOR GUIDANCE
description: IT was mid-1982 and many analysts thought the economy was on the verge of pulling out of the worst postwar recession. But Bernard Schoenfeld, an economist at the Irving Trust Company, wasn't taken in, not when he saw what was happening to the Government's count of how many people were making first-time applications for unemployment insurance.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
ON THE ROAD: ADVENTURES IN 'COMMUTING' TO ALBANY
description: ACTORS and hockey players are not the only ones who spend time on the road. There is a whole army of aides commuting from Long Island to Albany every week that the State Legislature is in session from January through June.

description: A foot-long chunk of ice caused a national stir when it landed in a school playground in Changsha last month.

description: Because of a decision last week by New York City's Department of Personnel, some career tracks at the Transit Authority may soon be switched. The new chiefs of the authority and its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have been lobbying to have some transit supervisory positions stripped of their Civil Service and union protections.

title: IT'S ALL OVER

title: Custody Decision Put Off
description: Saying a 6-year-old girl should not be treated like ''a herd of cattle,'' a judge refused Friday to settle quickly a two- year racial custody battle in which the United States Supreme Court has said prejudice should play no part. Circuit Judge Manuel Menendez said it would probably be a month before he decided whether the girl should remain in Texas with her white father, or be brought to Florida to live with her mother and the black man to whom the mother is married.

title: HOW REAGAN SURVIVES
description: There seems to be no end to the criticism leveled against President Reagan these days, but little evidence so far that it is reducing his chances of re- election.

title: EMPHASIS IS ON YOUTH IN TODAY'S PERFORMANCES
description: YOUTH is having its musical say at two intriguing programs today. In the first, an award-winning young pianist, Orazio Maione, who is 22 years old and has been performing in public since he was 9, will make his American debut at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich at 4 P.M. He has included in his program four landmark scores of the keyboard repertory: Beethoven's final sonata (Op. 111), Ravel's ''Gaspard de la Nuit,'' the Brahms Fantasia (Op. 116) and Schumann's Sonata in G minor.

title: MOSCOW IS OVERHEATED
description: The Russians have delivered their message. It's loud and clear. They are very angry with the Administration, not necessarily just with President Reagan, and they won't talk to the U.S. Government until it ''does'' something to prove good will.

title: JACKSON LEADS 5,000 PROTESTING IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson led a march of an estimated 5,000 people today to protest raids conducted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and pending immigration legislation.

title: 2.4 Billion Gallons
description: The 2.4 billion gallons of raw and treated sewage and industrial waste discharged daily into the Hudson- Raritan Estuary is roughly equivalent to what 16 of the world's largest supertankers can carry. And the 200 million gallons of raw sewage that New York City dumps into the Hudson and East Rivers each day would fill more than a supertanker.

title: Cocaine Cache in Colombia
description: Three tons of cocaine have been found near the place where troops discovered a large laboratory producing the illegal drug, officials said. The cocaine, which was found Thursday hidden in a tunnel, escaped the investigators' initial search last week, officials said Friday.

title: Pa Kows
description: Pamela Ann Kinsella, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Kinsella Jr. of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Sumner Wheeler White 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. White 3d of Summit and Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. William B. Robbins performed the ceremony at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in New Haven, assisted by the Rev. Edward Konat.

title: DUARTE SEEMS TO HAVE BREATHING ROOM
description: As Jose Napoleon Duarte prepared last week to return to the presidency of El Salvador, he faced familar challenges from leftist rebels fighting in the countryside and far- right forces in the capital. Mr. Duarte, who is to meet President Reagan in Washington tomorrow, is still a contentious populist. But this time, in contrast to his term as head of the junta in the early 1980's, he began in a conciliatory vein.

title: 194 Dodge Trucks Recalled
description: The Chrysler Corporation is recalling 194 Dodge pickup trucks to determine whether their wheels were from a bad batch prone to cracking.

title: CONCERT: PRO ARTE QUARTET
description: Despite the relative youth of its four members, the Pro Arte Quartet has been established since 1912, bequeathing its collective identity from one generation to the next. Now in residence at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, the group comprises the violinists Norman Paulu and Martha Francis Blum, the violist Richard Blum and the cellist Parry Karp, and Thursday night this 1984 incarnation of the Pro Arte Quartet presented an engrossing evening of music in Carnegie Recital Hall.

description: THE end of May is traditionally a slow time in the concert world, because most major spring series have ended and the summer programs have not yet begun. But the cultural calendar reveals a number of intriguing and enticing events, including four this afternoon.

description: This, the patients said the other day, was like no hospital they had ever seen.

description: New Jersey's Election Law Enforcement Commission, noting a sharp increase in the cost of campaigning, has recommended the elimination of a spending limit next year on candidates for Governor who accept public financing.

title: YANKEES SHUT OUT BY ANGELS, 4-0
description: Phil Niekro has not had much help in keeping the Yankees within sight of the rest of the teams in the American League East this season, and he did not receive any yesterday in trying to gain his seventh victory.

title: RECENT RELEASES

title: Meanwhile, Back in the G.O.P.
description: Delegates, delegates: That's all the Democratic candidates can talk about. Unfairly denied delegates, tainted delegates, super delegates. The emphasis is understandable; there's a contest for the Democratic nomination whereas a Republican President is unopposed. What's not understandable is the lack of interest in the way the Republicans choose their delegates.

title: No Headline
description: Animal Medical Unit Gets a New Chairman

title: STATE GETS GRIP ON REGULATING RENT
description: IN its first week of responsibility for regulating 1.2 million apartments in New York City, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal screened 39,000 rent-overcharge complaints and sent 23,000 notices to the landlords warning them not to destroy rent histories for the apartments.

title: HE MAY BE SECOND FIDDLE BUT BUSH IS RIGHT IN KEY
description: The Vice Presidency has come a long way since Garret Augustus Hobart was incumbent and outfitted his office in the Capitol with a velour ''slumber robe'' to complement his work load. Some weeks, Vice President George Bush barely seems to have time to refuel, never mind slumber, as he returns from another Presidential mission overseas and flies back out onto the domestic political circuit, where he has raised more than $35 million for the Republican Party. Mr. Bush was scheduled to come home today from such a visit, this time a five-nation tour of the Far East. By the four-year clock that still drives his metabolism, the day could be remembered as the fourth anniversary of the last 1980 primary in which he clearly defeated Ronald Reagan, 57 percent to 32 percent in Michigan. That may seem trivial now, but it wasn't easy for Mr. Bush to concede then that Mr. Reagan was unstoppable. He did so, however. Mr. Bush invited his delegates to turn to his rival and thus spared his party a nasty California primary. George Bush hasn't looked back since then. His strategy in the matter stands in sharp contrast to the current one of Gary Hart, who has launched a last- mile challenge of Walter F. Mondale this year. ''I would have remained an asterisk,'' Mr. Bush says now. Instead, he enjoys his job and a relationship with Mr. Reagan that has evolved as such a model of personal loyalty that the President chose to scotch all talk of a ''dump Bush'' movement among conservative party members early last year.

title: THE APTED TOUCH: NO FINGERPRINTS ON HIS FILMS
description: Michael Apted is one movie director who does not leave fingerprints. It is hard to believe that the same man, English to boot, made the slice of authentic Appalachia that was ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' the tense, pounding Russian thriller ''Gorky Park'' and ''Continental Divide,'' a romantic comedy starring John Belushi as a gruff but endearing Chicago newspaperman in love with a Rocky Mountain bird- watcher.

title: JOAN KENNEDY CITES LIBERAL ARTS TO GRADUATES AT MANHATTANVILLE
description: Joan Kennedy stressed the importance of the liberal arts as a foundation for dealing with life's choices and uncertainties to 290 graduates this morning at Manhattanville College's 134th commencement.

title: LIFE: GETTING THE RIGHT COVERAGE
description: LIKE many things in life, the need for life insurance tends to run in cycles. At certain stages, there is a vital need for a large amount of coverage. But at other times, the sales pitches of life insurance agents to the contrary, many people need little or none. The people who most need life insurance - and large amounts of it - are young couples who have as yet not accumulated sizable financial assets to fall back on and who have young children to support.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHOSE LIFE WAS THAT, ANYWAY?
description: T HE trouble with Howard Greene was that he wouldn't accept that he was paralyzed from the neck down.

description: WHITE PLAINS TWO county legislators last week criticized the county's lack of success in obtaining cheap electricity from upstate sources 25 months after voters authorized creation of a Public Utility Agency to do so.

title: NEW CLINIC FOR PRE-MENSTRUAL SYNDROME
description: -Menstrual Syndrome, often agreed by health professionals to be ''the world's most neglected medical condition,'' can now be treated in the first comprehensive program available to them in the county.

title: JACKSON RENEWS VOTE PLAINT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has written a letter to the chairman of the Democratic National Committee asking for ''results and not just efforts'' to eliminate the disparity between his proportion of the popular vote and the number of delegates he has won in the race for the Presidential nomination.

title: Patty Conroy Married to John M. Doar
description: Frances Ferguson Conroy, a freelance writer, and John M. Doar, who was special counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate investigation, were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles Amstin of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: U.S. FINDS 14 NATIONS NOW HAVE CHEMICAL ARMS
description: Fourteen to 16 countries, or about 10 more than had been estimated, have acquired chemical weapons in recent years, Defense Department officials say.

description: The meeting scheduled for Monday morning among the president of the Cosmos and four starting players dominated the conversation today as the team prepared for its game Sunday against the Vancouver Whitecaps.

description: CHICAGO SLOWLY, the nation's largest

title: CONTRASTING EXHIBITIONS AT RUTGERS'S ZIMMERLI MUSEUM
description: NEW BRUNSWICK '' SELECTIONS From the Ackland Art Museum'' could easily be eclipsed by the flashier ''Ruins and Revivals,'' two exhibitions now on view at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Museum at Rutgers, the State University.

title: SAVING - A MATTER OF PSYCHOLOGY
description: TO be financially secure, experts say, you need a regular plan for saving and investing, not just a good job. The savings provide the cushion for emergencies and allow you to achieve such long- term goals as financing the children's education or your own retirement. But many people have a psychological block against saving: more than others, they have difficulty putting aside something from each paycheck.

title:
ART;
JURIED SHOW COMBINES WORKSOF VITALITY AND COMPLEXITY
description: SOME artists eagerly enter juried exhibitions, hoping for a career boost. Others just as eagerly avoid such competitions, believing them to be incompatible with an artist's creative temperament.

title: CRIME
description: Robert B. Parker's VALEDICTION (Delacorte, $12.95) operates on two levels. It is the 11th in the series about Spenser, the big, tough private eye from Boston. One side of the story has to do with Spenser and his troubled love life. and the resulting Sturm und Drang is a little bit of a bore. The other has Spenser and his pal Hawk taking on a right- wing religious group, and that is just fine.

title: Penn State Leads IC4A Track
description: Rob Boulware won the long jump today to help Penn State take the lead with 25 points at the 108th Outdoor IC4A track and field championships.

title: JOHN CROWE RANSOM: 'THE FIRST POET I EVER SAW'
description: WHEN, in September 1921, I timidly entered one of the sections of English 1 at Vanderbilt University, I first laid eyes on John Crowe Ransom. He was a cut over 30 years old, perhaps a trifle under medium height, but erect and strongly built, with a handsome head, brown hair and a penetrating blue gaze. His voice, though not particularly loud, was remarkably clear, the result, I then surmised, of his scarcely ended career as a first lieutenant of artillery - a notion to be revised when I learned that he had spent several years at Oxford. As I grew to know him a little better, I observed a constant and undefinable courtesy, cool in a strange way but friendly. And always I was to observe the close attention he gave to even the most stupid question a stupid freshman could dream up, and his carefully considered answer.

title: A NOT-SO-GOOD RISK LIKES HIS CHANCES
description: WHEN he was cut from one of the United States rowing team's official training camps at Princeton a couple of weeks ago, Bob Reininger was sure the decision was not based on his rowing ability.

description: THE BRUBECKS IN CHURCH

title: CONSUMER GUIDE TO HOME MORTGAGES
description: 'Creative Financing' for Homes Comes in Many Forms Because of the unpredictability of interest rates and home purchase prices, lenders are increasingly turning to ''creative financing'' techniques and away from traditional fixed-rate mortgages. These plans can involve more risk for home buyers and are frequently tied to changes in the market. But they can also make home buying possible and may offer lower interest rates. Below are the more prominent plans now being offered.

title: Comings and GoingsFifty years after he won the first of his three consecutive Wimbledon titles, it appears that
description: Fred Perry is going to be a recognizable figure in British tennis circles for decades to come. A full-size sculpture of the 75- year-old former champion is to be unveiled today at the Somerset Road entrance to the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, the site of Wimbledon. . . . Earl Campbell , the Houston running back, will have arthroscopic surgery Wednesday to remove a bone chip in his right knee, but he predicts he will be fit for training camp in July. ''I just look at it as an 8,000-mile tuneup,''said Campbell, who has 8,296 yards rushing in six seasons. . . . The Baltimore Orioles placed the designated-hitter Ken Singleton on the 15-day disabled list with a severely bruised right foot.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: A NO-NONSENSE TRAVEL GUIDE
description: EDEN ROSS LIPSON is the children's book editor of The New York Times.

title: FORDHAM GRADUATION HONORS WALESA IN ABSENTIA
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Polish union Solidarity, declared in a letter made public at Fordham University's graduation ceremonies yesterday that the Polish people could not ''forsake their dialogue'' with the Warsaw regime ''without risking confrontation.''

title: NORWALK HONOR SET FOR CALVIN MURPHY
description: THE proposal to build a replica of the house where some people think Yankee Doodle lived was recently rejected in Norwalk amid considerable controversy.

title: DOCTORS HARMED BY DOMINICAN CASE
description: The bogus medical diploma scandal that led to the closing of two universities in the Dominican Republic is bringing turmoil to several thousand Americans who are students or graduates of the institutions.

title: WEIGHING MORTGAGE CHOICES
description: THE profusion of adjustable-rate mortgages has dramatically complicated the experience of shopping for a mortgage. It is not a simple choice between adjustable and fixed-rate mortgages; rather, financial advisers are urging their clients to examine the many options available within the adjustable spectrum - options that vary sharply from lender to lender - as well as to compare them with fixed mortgages.

title: NON-AMERICAN VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NATION;
description: Instant Interest In Continental

title: NONFICTIONAL SEVENTY: A Journal.
description: What's it like to be 70? ''I do not feel old at all, May Sarton writes in ''At Seventy,'' ''not as much a survivor as a person still on her way.'' Those who have followed Miss Sarton ''on her way'' know her as the author of 14 volumes of poetry, 17 novels (most recently ''Anger''), two children's books and eight books of nonfiction (including two recent journals, ''The House by the Sea'' and ''Recovering'').

title: Musicians in Las Vegas Resume Negotiations
description: Musicians resumed bargaining today with Las Vegas resorts where weekend gamblers were greeted by more striker demonstrations and arrests.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: Legal Heat Over Frost-Free Bugs

title: KOCH DELAYS EFFORT TO EXPAND SCHOOL BOARD
description: Mayor Koch has temporarily abandoned an effort to expand his influence over the Board of Education by changing the board's structure. He said he thought the effort would fail.

title: HEADLINERS
description: One-Man Squad Two of the longest arms of the law must belong to New York City Detective Robert T. Gallagher , whose 210 citations for exceptional valor are thought to have made him the city's most decorated police officer. Last week the 16- year veteran added a major accolade to the list when Governor Cuomo named him the state's first Police Officer of the Year. Mr. Cuomo said the 6-foot-2, 190-pound officer was ''a beautiful person'' and praised his ''old-fashioned virtues.'' The detective works with a unit that specializes in confiscating illegal weapons; last year alone he was responsible for arresting 125 armed offenders.

title: SUSTENANCE IN OXFORD AND ENVIRONS
description: The colleges are usually open to visitors in the afternoon, from 2 until 5 (although some close at dusk). There is no central information office for the university, but the Tourist Information Center, St. Aldate's Street (telephone: 726871) can generally answer questions. From April through October, the Tourist Center also offers walking tours of the colleges; they depart daily at 10:45 A.M. and 2 and 2:30 P.M.; the price is about $2.50 for adults, about $1.10 for children. In Town Le Petit Blanc , 272 Banbury Road (telephone: Oxford 53540). Both lunch and dinner are prix fixe; the menu changes every day. Lunch is about $15, and might begin with fillets of mackerel or rillettes of pork. Main courses include grilled breast of pigeon, served with a white wine sauce, and pork stuffed with prunes in a wine and cream sauce. Half a carafe of house wine is included in the price. The dinner menu, at $22, includes such traditional French country fare as onion soup, baby lamb, and boudin noir (black pudding), as well as a range of seasonal specialties. Reservations are essential.

title: THE DANCE OF JOGJAKARTA
description: Jogjakarta has always gone its own way; its cultural primacy in Indonesia has never been challenged. It is a city of pleasant contradictions: a small town full of big ideas, a laconic village that quickens the pulse of Java, a modern place with ancient motifs.

title: TENANTS WIN IN CO-OP CASE
description: A BOUT 130 tenants of a Glen Cove apartment complex joined to celebrate recently after the sign outside their building was changed to read ''Trousdell Village Garden Apartments'' instead of ''Co-Op Apartments.'' It signaled their victory in a case that clarified a five-year-old state law affecting evictions in cooperative conversions in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: NOTE OF COMPROMISE STRUCK ON COAST IN DISPUTE OVER CITY'S OFFICIAL SONG
description: Since Oct. 6, 1969, the official song of this city has been ''I Left My Heart in San Francisco,'' which was made famous in the 1960's by Tony Bennett.

title: BUDGETING MEANS SETTING UP PRIORITIES
description: LIKE the word ''diet,'' the word ''budget'' can also raise unpleasant images of forced self-denial. But, financial planners say that this should not be the case. This much maligned word deserves to be viewed more favorably: It is really the process by which we figure out what we want and how to pay for it.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
'JUST A HOUSEWIFE' ATTENDS A REUNION
description: A FAT envelope arrived from my alma mater and for once the alumni association didn't want to sell me insurance, circus tickets, or a trip to Italy and Sicily with my fellow graduates. This time they wanted my presence at the 15-year class reunion.

title: BANKERS' GREY: COLOR IT LIVELY
description: IT was 10:30 on a cold, wintry night when a Manhattanite decided to play with his newest electronic toy, home banking. So, he pulled out his Atari computer, plugged it into his television set, then into his phone jack and dialed HomeBase, Citibank's home-banking program. Soon, records of the checks that had cleared his account were flashing before him, letting him know just where he stood, financially at least.

title: NIEKRO: MASTER OF A SERENE ART
description: IF Yankee Stadium were a museum, the prize

title: HART OPENS COAST DRIVE WITH ATTACK ON REAGAN
description: Gary Hart opened a campaign swing through California today with a sharply worded attack on President Reagan's nuclear arms policies and a pledge to try to eliminate the risk of nuclear war with the Soviet Union.

title: MARY H. THOMSON AND D.G. RUSSELL WED IN HARTFORD
description: Mary Hotchkiss Thomson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lindsay Thomson of West Hartford, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt., was married yesterday to Douglas Gibson Russell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gibson Russell of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James Kidd performed the ceremony at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: PARENT-CHILD TACTICS FOR EDUCATION
description: BECAUSE of recent action by the Supreme Court and Congress, the number of ways to set aside money for a child's college education is narrowing. But several ways still exist, especially if the parents, in the words of one expert, are willing to be ''aggressive.''

title: HURRICANE WINDS SPUR RENEWAL IN GALVESTON
description: Nine months ago today, a powerful hurricane called Alicia wrecked much of Galveston. Today, odd as it may seem, many a Galvestonian is saying the storm may have been about the best thing that ever happened to this chronically depressed and decaying old island city.

title: ICONS FOR A DEMOCRACY
description: THOMAS EAKINS

title: ROBUST BEGINNING FOR THE 2D QUARTER
description: Explanations that bad weather caused lackluster economic data for March seem to be borne out by much improved reports for April. Housing starts, which plunged in March, gained 19.3 percent in April, and were running at an annual rate of 1.96 million units. Although that pace probably cannot be sustained in the face of rising interest rates, total housing starts are expected to exceed 1.8 million this year. Personal income rose five-tenths of 1 percent, but personal spending jumped, indicating more confidence in the recovery. Industrial production rose 1.4 percent, three times the March rise, and factory utilization jumped to 81.9 percent.

title: REMEMBERING WILLIAM EMPSON
description: John Gross is an editor of The New York Times Book Review.

title: RUCKELSHAUS ENDS FIRST YEAR BACK AT E.P.A. WITH MIXED REVIEWS
description: --One year after his return as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus is widely credited with restoring morale, stability, purpose and credibility to an agency he found in a state of chaos.

title: AN OLD OXONIAN'S OXFORD
description: Everyone knows that Oxford is not only one of the most historic but also, in large part, one of the most beautiful cities in Europe, a treasured possession of the English- speaking world. There is something in it for everybody - history and architecture, ancient colleges and gardens, picture galleries and museums, science and music - to say nothing of its magical situation between two rivers, the Thames (locally called the Isis) and the Cherwell; its old city girdled by parks and meadows; its hills within view and walking distance.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: WHY HAS there been a precipitous decline in the catch of deep-water sports fish off the New Jersey coast since 1981?

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: ANNUAL HOUSING SQUEEZE BEGINS ON CAPE COD
description: Cape Cod, like many resort areas, is facing its annual problem: a squeeze on rental housing.

title: HIKERS ARE TENDING APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: AT Northwest Camp near Salisbury on the Appalachian Trail, Joe Bickel, 34 years old, talked to a small group of volunteers about ridgerunning.

title: DISPARITY BETWEEN JACKSON'S VOTE AND DELEGATE COUNT VEXES PARTY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson won 16 percent of the votes in the Ohio Democratic primary May 8, but he received only eight delegates, about 5 percent of the 154 that were allocated on the basis of the election.

title:
SPORTS;
HOW L.I. RUNNERS TRAIN FOR OLYMPICS
description: TO many, the marathon is an enigma. Just completing the 26-mile, 385-yard distance is the goal held by most who attempt it. But theories of how best to prepare for such a challenge vary as much as the runners themselves.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: WESTPORT
description: IN the 1930's and 1940's, when a colony of affluent artists and writers settled in what was then the quiet summer resort of Westport and New York's Theater Guild established the Westport Country Playhouse, the town acquired a lively, arts-oriented ambiance that set it apart from its more sedate neighbors.

title: Hungary Reported to Agree To a Memorial to Wallenberg
description: The Hungarian authorities have agreed to establish a memorial to Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Jews from death at the hands of the Nazis in World War II, a Jewish delegation said Friday.

title: Among the Lost
description: He was one of the growing number of children who disappear mysteriously, but news reports said his case had ''touched the heart'' of San Francisco. The child, Kevin Collins, 10 years old, vanished Feb. 10.

title: ANDREW L. ALEXANDER
description: Andrew L. Alexander, father of Gov. Lamar Alexander, died today at Vanderbilt University Hospital aftr a short illness.

title: Suns Bounce Back, With Help of Davis
description: In critical situations, the Phoenix Suns usually turn to Walter Davis, and the all-star guard seldom disappoints them.

title: CANADA GETS A LOT MORE CIVIL ABOUT CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Franklin Baker was acquitted of second-degree murder last month after a Canadian judge threw out his confession. Mr. Baker said he had stabbed a 50-year-old man with a scissors, but forensic experts said the victim's wounds could not have been inflicted by scissors. The defendant, who is 17 years old, half black and half Indian, told the judge that Hamilton, Ontario, police beat his head against a wall until he confessed.

title: Guerrillas Tell of Attack On Western Sahara Port
description: Polisario guerrillas asserted today that they had destroyed the port terminal at Aiun, the main town in Moroccan-controlled Western Sahara, according to a statement reported by the Algerian press agency.

title: State's Teachers Do a Good Job
description: Slow down, would be the best professional advice I can give to Nicholas P. Criscuolo in his support of recertifying teachers every five years (''Recertification of Teachers Is a Good Idea,'' March 25).
