description: To the Editor:

title: BALANCHINE INFUSED WALTZES WITH SUBTLE DRAMA
description: ''Liebeslieder Walzer,'' which George Balanchine choreographed in 1960, is one of the world's loveliest ballets. After an absence of 10 years, it has just been revived for the New York City Ballet with spectacular new decor.

title: A MALL VILLAGE
description: As it has grown into one of the largest office and research complexes in the country, the Princeton Forrestal Center in Plainsboro, N.J. has generated a growing need for services. To meet that need, a $100 million commercial complex of restaurants and a major hotel will be built next door.

title: A LEFTY'S TROUBLE WITH BASEBALL LORE
description: JUST suppose. Just suppose, now, that when

title: France Repays a Debt Incurred by Napoleon
description: France today settled Napoleon's debt to this Swiss village for 80 unreturned pots and pans, 2,037 uprooted trees, 3,150 logs for the transport of cannons and local labor.

title: U.S. Plane Breaks Up In Honduras Landing
description: A C-130 cargo plane leased by the United States Army snapped in two as it landed with supplies for American troops, but the crew of four escaped injury, a United States Embassy official said.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
PANEL NEVER APPROVED OLYMPIC DOLLAR DESIGN
description: should designs for United States coins be subject to the approval of outside experts--including a formal veto? That is one of the questions raised by the issuance of the 1984 Olympic silver dollar, a coin whose design continues to elicit negative comments.

title: SHOPPING FOR THE BEST INSURANCE
description: ALMOST all buyers of single-family houses or condominiums these days also become buyers of title insurance. Mortgage lenders insist on it because they may want to sell their mortgages later in the capital markets, and investors in those markets want this safeguard from loss.

title: Dr. John Bauer, Psychologist AndCityU.DepartmentHead
description: Dr. John Bauer, chairman of the department of psychology at City University's Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, died of cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Verbatim: Planning for Nuclear War
description: 'I'm not emphasizing preparedness or evacuation of large areas of the state in the event of a nuclear war because I think that's silly.

title: VIETNAM RELIVED IN 'A WAYNE HERO'
description: THE Arena Players in East Farmingdale recently opened another, smaller theater, the Second Stage, to serve as a showcase for original plays and children's theater and for the continued run of popular successes from the Main Stage. Now, at the Second Stage, they have given the world premiere of ''A John Wayne Kind of Hero'' by Joseph Lizardi, Arena's playwright in residence. The play's topic is the still sensitive issue of the war in Vietnam.

title: Stacy Shaw Osha Married To Hugo Flores, Teacher
description: At the North Church in Cornwall, Conn., yesterday Stacy Shaw Osha was married to Hugo Flores by the Rev. Peter Hammond, a Congregational minister.

title: 'HAUNTED HOUSES' INSPECTED
description: house attractions along the Jersey Shore have been closed pending internal, state and local fire-safety inspections that will ultimately update or revamp their fire-protection systems.

description: Anthony Sampson is the author of ''Anatomy of Britain'' and other books. THE RISE AND FALL OF THE POLITICAL PRESS IN BRITAIN

title: BORROWING TO PAY FOR YOUR EDUCATION
description: FOR families seeking to finance a child's college education, the story this year is bittersweet. The bad news is that despite the slowdown in inflation, college tuition continues to rise at nearly double- digit rates. The good news is that, notwithstanding tougher eligibility requirements and elimination of some Government-run aid programs, billions of dollars in loans remain available.

title: The New MOMA
description: As a student of architecture, I see the end of the modern period radically affecting my curriculum (''The New MOMA,'' by Paul Goldberger, April 15). Yet, until reading Paul Goldberger's article, I hadn't comprehended its full effect on all the visual arts.

title: Tigers (31-5) Win Behind Morris (8-1)
description: Darrell Evans went 3 for 3 and had 2 runs batted in and Lou Whitaker hit a homer for Detroit as the streaking Tigers beat the Oakland A's, 5-4, tonight and improved their major league-leading record to 31-5.

title: SUFFOLK GETS ITS OWN S.P.C.A.
description: THIS spring, for the first time, Suffolk County will have its own Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals - and the mystery of it all is that nobody really knows why one never existed before.

title: THE CASE AGAINST SOCIOBIOLOGY
description: Philip Kitcher, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota, is the author of ''Abusing Science: The Case Against Creationism'' and ''The Nature of Mathematical Knowledge.'' NOT IN OUR GENES

description: a delegate in Florida.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: STARTING today, after ribbons are cut and the inaugural rites of passage are celebrated, Nassau will have its own Green Belt Trail, courtesy of the Long Island Green Belt Trail Conference, Nassau County and the Long Island State Park Commission.

title: Those Mysterious Untaxed Acres
description: In the article ''Mystery of 135 Untaxed Acres'' (April 29) there are a few minor errors I would appreciate being corrected.

title: COLOMBIA STARTS TO FEEL SIDE EFFECTS OF DRUG TRADE
description: While he lived, neither Government nor public seemed to support Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla in his campaign against Colombia's powerful narcotics rings. Instead he received only daily death threats for his efforts. Yet Mr. Lara's murder three weeks ago appears to have achieved what he had been unable to accomplish during eight months in office; the Government is waging its first full-scale offensive against drugs, and Colombians have suddenly awakened to the damage caused by narcotics to their entire society.

title: Dyson Is Renominated AsPowerAgency
description: Governor Cuomo has nominated John Dyson to a second five-year term as chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: Hobart Wins Fifth Title In Division III Lacrosse
description: Tom Grimaldi scored a goal and had five assists today to lead Hobart College to a 12-5 victory over Washington College of Chestertown, Md., for its record fifth straight Division III lacrosse title.

title: FAMILY RENTALS
description: PROVIDING housing for children away at school can be a costly expense for parents, or an investment opportunity. Similarly, under present tax law it can be profitable to help other family members who cannot afford the homes they would like. But homeowners must make sure they charge family members ''arms-length rents'' to be eligible to deduct depreciation, utilities, maintenance and other household costs for tax purposes, according to M. Donald Wright, a tax partner in Arthur Andersen & Company. Also, the housing must be the renters' principal residence.

title:
ART;
WOODD'S VERSITALITY EXPLORED
description: honored medium for sculpture, but also can be used as the matrix for printmaking. Although woodcuts are no longer as popular as they were in the 19th and early 20th centuries, quite a few artists are attracted to the unique texture that the material imparts to the graphic image, and the longstanding popularity of wood for carving and construction is undiminished.

title: No Headline
description: Patricia Scanlan Weds

title: LED FOOD CONCERN William Thomas Brady, former head of the Corn Products Company, the forerunner of CPC International Inc., one of the country's largest food products companies, died Friday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88 years old.
description: A native of Illinois, Mr. Brady joined Corn Products in 1919 as a worker in one of its Illinois milling plants. He rose through the company's managerial and executive ranks to become a vice president in 1947 and first vice president in 1956.

title: Former Iran Hostages Seek to Revive Lawsuit
description: Thirteen Americans held hostage by Iran for 14 months asked the Supreme Court Friday to revive their $65 million lawsuit against the Iranian Government.

title: TOUCHED WITH FIRE: The Future of the Vietnam Generation.
description: John Wheeler, who was the chairman of the board of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund that helped build the controversial monument on the Washington Mall, tells about his life as a member of the Vietnam generation in ''Touched With Fire.'' His aim is to heal - to close the breach between those who served in Vietnam and those who protested the war.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BERGEN IS SAVING ITS STONE HOUSES
description: HACKENSACK THE perceptible decline in the number of Bergen County's old stone houses - one of the remarkable features of the North Jersey architectural landscape and a legacy of early Dutch, English and Huguenot settlements - has prompted an outstanding preservation effort by the county's Office of Cultural and Historic Affairs.

title: POP: BERLIN, A COAST SEXTET
description: Berlin, the rising young pop sextet from Los Angeles, is an American variant of so-called ''new romantic'' English groups like Eurythmics and Duran Duran. Like its British counterparts, Berlin makes hard-edged, heavily synthesized dance pop that is directly descended from late 1970's disco.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
HOW TO LIVE WITH A DIETER
description: IMAGINE my horror. My wife

title: THE NEW MOMA
description: Documents recently published by Rona Roob in the Journal of the Archives of American Art establish that Alfred Barr, the first director of the Museum of Modern Art, did very much want the museum to be designed by a European modern architect, whether Gropius, Oud or Mies van der Rohe, contrary to Mr. Goldberger's statement that Mr. Barr was not ''particularly comfortable with the idea of enlisting most of the modern masters'' and feared losing control of the building. Mr. Barr believed that ''the museum, as a patron of modern architecture, cannot afford to run the risk of mediocrity in the design of its new building. It must have the superlatively best . . . .'' He did not believe that any American was capable of that.

title: THE ABSENTEE FATHER
description: While reading Jacques Leslie's ruminations of a stepfather, I found myself feeling alternately sympathetic and angry - and, perhaps, jealous.

title: GETTING BY ON $35,000 TO $250,000 - BE ORGANIZED
description: THE ways of the household budget are many and mysterious. There are spenders and scrimpers, and a lot of people somewhere between. There are planners, and there are people who pay others to plan for them. The four household budgets below, ranging from nearly $35,000 a year to about $250,000, are not meant to represent any ideal budgeting system. They are simply snapshots, glimpses into the spending patterns of a few people whose budget pressures and goals vary as widely as their incomes.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
FILM EVOKES LOWENSTEIN SPIRIT
description: JULIE THOMPSON never met the late Allard K. Lowenstein; Jacqueline Richman worked ''day and night'' on his successful 1968 campaign for Congress from Long Island's Fifth Congressional District. But by the time Miss Thompson, a California film maker, had finished ''Citizen: The Political Life of Allard K. Lowenstein,'' a documentary that makes its Long Island debut Friday at the Port Washington Public Library, she came to share the views of Mrs. Richman, a Long Beach resident.

title: CANADA PROTESTS U.S. MOVE ON OIL LEASES IN DISPUTED WATERS
description: Canada has protested United States moves to sell offshore oil leases in territory whose ownership the two nations dispute.

title: A CASE OF MANAGEMENT INSENSITIVITY
description: CORPORATE executives work hard. Their jobs demand many skills (including the consummate skill of reaching the top), long hours and heavy responsibilities. Surely they are entitled to be liberally compensated.

title: Phillies Win Eighth Straight
description: Tim Corcoran's pinch three-run double was the key hit in a seventh-inning rally that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The victory was the eighth in a row for the Phillies.

title: IN SICILY, A CLASSIC VIEW
description: There are beaches in Sicily, of course, and the countryside is unexpectedly beautiful, especially in the spring when fields of wildflowers - purple, yellow, fuchsia, red - stretch out of sight. It's inexpensive there too, yet it doesn't seem overrun by tourists. But one unbeatable reason for going to Sicily is to see the Greek temples. Some of the most complete and majestic in the world, including Greece, are in Agrigento, on Sicily's southern coast.

title: HOUSING TO BE BUILT ON STADIUM SITE IN JERSEY CITY
description: Roosevelt Stadium, which has been a landmark here since the 1930's, is to be demolished this summer to make room for a 1,600-unit housing development, officials said this week.

title: MRS. WHITE LEADS GOLF TOURNEY BY 1
description: Donna White shot an erratic round of par 73 today and then was surprised to find that her performance was good enough for a 1-stroke lead over Pat Bradley in the second round of the ninth annual L.P.G.A. Chrysler- Plymouth Classic.

title: ARE SMALL STOCKS READY TO REBOUND?
description: DURING a stock market decline, investors holding signficant positions in small-company shares are often tempted to liquidate those equities. The reason: Companies with lower market capitalization (the market value of a company's shares) almost invariably lose more of their value during bear markets than the issues of larger companies, such as those that make up the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Window Treatments And Wall Coverings The seventh yearly window-treatment sale at Motif Designs in Larchmont is being extended to May 26 - with 50 percent off on Levolor miniblinds; 40 percent off vertical blinds, woven woods, Roman, Austrian and roll-up shades; and 25 percent off pre- finished and finished shutters. Reminders on sales can be by means of the yearly calendar of events and by specific mailings to customers who sign the guest book or phone to ask to be included.

title: LITERARY HUMORISTS SPIN A WEB OF WIT
description: ''There is no humor in heaven,'' wrote Mark Twain, and anybody who has watched enough stand- up comedians at work or listened to them on recordings performing their routines might pause to wonder whether the statement isn't somewhat applicable nowadays to the world down here as well. Yet there has always been a happy hunting ground in literature, where the humorist has pursued with pen and paper not the easy quarry of the yock, the boffola or the hilarious one-liner but the civilized smile to be provoked by the comic essay. Such entertainment, as Max Eastman found out long ago when he was interviewing professional humorists on the subject for his 1936 classic, ''The Enjoyment of Laughter,'' is frequently genial and therapeutic even though the pleasure it elicits may be closely linked with pain. Some of the best has also found its way to records.

title: BOOKS
description: THE true story within ''Stranger in My Bed,'' by Beverly Slater, with Frances Spatz Leighton (Arbor House, New York, $15.95), resembles, for many of us, the nightmares that cast us adrift in an alien world.

title: THE ECONOMIST ON THE COUCH

title: New York Typographers Unit Rejects a Teamster Merger
description: Members of the International Typographical Union Local 6, in New York City, have voted 4,267 to 524 against a merger with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Bertram A. Powers, the printing local's president, reported Thursday.

title: No Headline
description: Lansing Homosexuals Lose on Housing Bias

title: CHANGE IN THE KITCHEN
description: The Kitchen, the SoHo site of avant-garde musical events of various kinds over the past several years and a generally influential artistic forum for over a decade, has a new executive director, Stuart Hodes. He comes to the Kitchen after a distinguished career as a dancer with the Martha Graham troupe, and later as chairman of the dance department for the New York University School of the Arts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is so much money to be made that average middle-class people are going into coke and heroin dealing. They know the odds are on their side, that most dealers who take care of friends and neighbors don't get caught.'' - Sterling Johnson Jr., New York City's special narcotics prosecutor. (50:1.)

title: TORVILL & DEAN.
RETURN TO RELIGION
description: The sterility of materialism, the narrowness of narcissism, the exhaustion of modernism - all these are adduced as reasons for the recent upsurge in religious interests. How ironic that the subject of Bernard Levin's article - enthusiasm - in the same issue of The New York Times Magazine never finds its way into this discussion.

title: A QUICKER OMNI
description: WHEN I was in high school, one of the guys lavished all of his money and affection on a black 1946 Ford sedan. He spent not on comfort or flash but under the hood, and the car was as subtle as it was fast.

title: No Headline

title: SHOWING REALITY OF DRIVING DRUNK
description: THE slide shows a glamorous couple in formal clothing sitting at a candlelit table in an elegant restaurant.

title: HOME, HEALTH AND CAR: SMART WAYS TO CUT COSTS
description: THE need for what is commonly known as homeowners insurance extends to renters and homeowners alike. Homeowners need it to cover damage and losses to the structure and contents in the event of fire, vandalism, theft or other perils, and to protect against liability claims in case a passerby slips on the front sidewalk and sues for negligence. Renters need specially tailored policies to cover their personal possessions in case of fire or burglary and to protect against liability claims in case a guest trips over the living room coffee table.

title: IRAQI CLAIMS IRAN BLOCKADE GAINS
description: A high-ranking Iraqi official was quoted today as saying that Iraq had cut Iran's oil exports by 55 percent with its blockade of Iranian oil terminals.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: A NEW WORLD OF FIELDS AND FENCES
description: CHANGES IN THE LAND

title: Coe Wins Fast 800
description: Sebastian Coe displayed some of his old form today when he won the Middlesex County 800-meter run in 1 minute 45.2 seconds - the fastest time in the world this year. It was Coe's first individual track race since illness forced him out of the world championships eight months ago.

title: A UNIFORM PLAN FOR NEWSPAPER DESIGN
description: BY July 1, a sweeping revolution in newspaper design will have taken place that readers may barely notice, but which many big advertisers are greeting with relief. The change - a minor revolution for the newspaper business - is the standardization of newspaper size and basic format so that the same advertisement will fit perfectly into newspapers from Maine to Hawaii.

title: NEW WAYS TO DETECT POLYPS USED AGAINST CANCER

title: 'THEY FIT EACH OTHER'

And when he was announced as the rider for Gate Dancer, the controversial colt with the purple earmuffs, it was a parimutuel marriage for the hunch horseplayers at the 109th Preakness Stakes.

title: UNIONS BATTLE AGAINST JOBS IN THE HOME
description: Six mornings a week at 6:30, Sharon Jones sits down before the green glow of a word processor and begins copying stacks of Blue Shield medical insurance claims into a computer.

title: OTHER CENTERS
description: Following is a listing of some of the other nature centers in the state: Bartlett Arboretum , 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford. 322-6971. Administered by the University of Connecticut's department of plant science, the Arboretum offers 63 acres of ecology trails, swamp lands, woods and gardens. The facility includes a greenhouse and an extensive horticultural library. Building hours: Monday-Friday, 8:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Grounds are open seven days a week, 8:30 A.M. to dusk. No admission charge.

title: College Rebirth
description: In the late 1960's, when a surfeit of students scrambled for openings in higher education, Windham College in Putney, Vt., had an enrollment of 950. In December 1978, when the college closed, it had but 254 students and $8 million in debts.

description: Of the House members from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, Representative Richard L. Ottinger is among the wealthiest, according to 1983 financial disclosure statements released this week.

description: Sheila Lea Terry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Terry of Yonkers, was married there yesterday to Oliver D. Cromwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Cromwell of Cleveland. The Rev. John J. Foley performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: WHERE THE BUFFALOES BEGIN. By Olaf Baker. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Frederick Warne. Paper, $5.95. (Ages 8 to 12) A hauntingly beautiful paperback edition of a prizewinning modern version of the American Indian legend of Little Wolf, the boy who led the stampeding buffaloes away from his people.

But next year she will be eligible, and whatever she puts into the plan will be matched 100 percent by her employer.

title: PRESSURE IS ON PUBLISHERS TO PICK WINNERS

The acquisition of Scribner Book Companies, a privately-owned business founded in 1846 and headed by fourth- and fifth-generation family members, by Macmillan Inc., a company whose American operation began in 1869 and now includes communications and marketing subsidiaries in addition to book publishing interests, was announced with great enthusiasm last month. It was received with something less than enthusiasm in some book industry circles.

description: Alison Margaret Dalton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dalton of Lake Havasu City, Ariz., was married in New York yesterday to Robin Jared Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Lewis of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Thornton Lewis, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Columbia University Faculty Club.

title: Jon Pines Is Wed To Janet Upright
description: Janet Upright, a daughter of Jerome Seid of East Orange, N.J., and the late Alice Seid, was married yesterday to Jonathan Pines, a son Dr. and Mrs. Kermit L. Pines of Tenafly, N.J. Mayor Richard Van Nostrand of Tenafly performed the ceremony at the Pines home.

title: Susan Orbe Is Married To Dr. Steven P. Smith
description: The marriage of Susan Ada Orbe, director of materials management at the Beverly (Mass.) Hospital, to Dr. Steven Philip Smith, a fellow in neuroradiology at the New England Medical Center in Boston, took place yesterday.

Winn and Mary W. Winn, both of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Summit.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION ;
THE EARLY PLEASURES OF THE BEACH
description: On this glorious day with a clear sky, bright sun and sparkling sea, several dozen visitors are enjoying the newly arrived spring weather at West End No. 2 Beach, the largest beach of the 2400-acre Jones Beach State Park. This is part of the barrier beach that extends for 15 miles along the South Shore from Jones Inlet on the west to Captree State Park on the east, with the westernmost six miles belonging to Jones Beach State Park.

title: THEATER FESTIVAL PLANNED
description: WESTCHESTER, backed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and its Office of Cultural Affairs, plans to hold a theater festival and competition within a year to encourage greater awareness of and excitement about the theater in the county.

The capsule melodrama's message is that in housing-discrimination cases, the authorities render justice swiftly and surely.

description: Barbara Ehrenreich's most recent book, ''Hearts of Men: American Dreams and the Flight From Commitment,'' was published last year.

title: THE NATION;
description: The Fourth 'R' Loses Again

title: Q AND A
description: In June 1982, I signed a sublet agreement on a rent-stabilized apartment that included a 15 percent sublet charge above the base rent. Now the landlord is offering me a lease, plus a vacancy increase. Was the sublet charge legal? Would this new lease be calculated on the old base rent, or the base rent plus the sublet increase? . . . S. H. A., Manhattan

title: Interventionism, Without Humbug
description: Few words in diplomacy are so imprecise and negative as ''interventionism.'' No nation admits either the urge or the deed. Your country may intervene, ours only protects vital interests, common values, or whatever. So when Mexico's President Miguel de la Madrid cautioned President Reagan against ''interventionist solutions'' in Central America last week, he was offering only laudable sentiment for obscure meaning.

title: THINKING OF DAISY
description: Madison Bell is the author of ''The Washington Square Ensemble.'' THE OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER

title: NAKED IS THE BEST DISGUISE: My Life as a Stripper.
description: For five years Lauri Lewin, the child of a middle-class family, led a double life. Mornings she attended classes at the University of Massachusetts; afternoons she worked as a stripper and bar girl. ''Naked Is the Best Disguise'' is the harrowing cautionary tale of her sojourn in the often violent netherworld of Boston's Combat Zone, where as ''Lolita'' she stripped out of a little-girl costume, using a doll as her prop. Why would a young woman with, presumably, other options choose this way to make a living? Her stated reasons - not enough money from her estranged family, boredom with office and restaurant jobs and fierce sexual competition with her older sister, who was also a stripper - seem too simple. Miss Lewin also alludes to, but unfortunately never expands on, a ''need to put myself in the most hostile environment and wage a struggle for survival there.'' Initially, at least, stripping seemed to offer an affirmation, however crude, of her sexual power and desirability. But the illusion of glamour was harder to sustain while hustling drinks. As time went on, Miss Lewin, who was turning into a feminist, became dependent on cocaine so Lolita could do her job. Ultimately, as the strain of her double life became unbearable and her cocaine habit threatened to get out of control, she pulled back from the abyss. Some of Miss Lewin's feminist insights seem to have been slapped on after the fact, and they have a flattening effect on her narrative.

title: Miss Guggenheim, Account Executive, To Wed Frederick Z. Lodge on Sept. 2
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Guggenheim of Cincinnati and Snowmass Village, Colo., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Susan Stix Guggenheim of New York, to Frederick Ziegler Lodge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sears Lodge of Beverly, Mass. The wedding is planned for Sept. 2.

title: TAPPING BUILT-UP EQUITY IN YOUR HOME
description: TO many people, their home is less a castle than a gold mine. And they are constantly looking for ways they can tap into the equity vein built up over the years - whether to fund college costs, to buy a boat or vacation home, to make improvements, to consolidate debts, to buy a business or take advantage of investment opportunities.

title: No Headline
description: Alison Sommers to Be Bride

title: Celestial Thanks
description: After a six-year tug-of-war over whether to install high-pressure or low-pressure sodium street lights, the San Diego City Council ended the struggle in February by voting for low pressure. This delighted astronomers at the renowned Mount Palomar telescope, 60 miles to the north.

title: Miss Gilleaudeau, Systems Analyst, Weds a Physician
description: Aimee Larkin Gilleaudeau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Gilleaudeau of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Walden Lundy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burdette Walden Lundy of Canandaigua, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. McDermott, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Jean M. Christofferson of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in Grove City, Pa.

title: THORIUM CLEANUP BY U.S. FAULTED
description: MAYWOOD THE Federal Government will embark next month on what is expected to be a $2 million cleanup to remove traces of thorium, a radioactive element, from eight homes here, but homeowners say that Washington should pay for their being relocated while the work is done.

title: Dr. Ellen M. Friedman and Dr. Robert Gross Wed
description: Dr. Ellen Mae Friedman, the daughter of Miriam R. Friedman of Northfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Martin B. Friedman, was married at Congregation Beth Judah in Ventnor, N.J., yesterday to Dr. Robert David Gross, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Perry Edward Gross of Dallas. Rabbi Alan Lucas officiated, assisted by Cantor Edmund Kulp.

title: THE EARLIER YOU PLAN THE GREATER THE SECURITY
description: COMFORTABLE retirement seems a reasonable reward for a lifetime of work. But, except for the few who have planned wisely or have amassed substantial resources or inherited wealth, financial security in old age may be an elusive goal. Until recently, financial planners suggested that age 55 was about the right time to begin planning for retirement.

title:
STAMPS;
SUPERSTAR OF THE 20'S
description: Douglas Fairbanks, superstar of the silent movies and ''King of Hollywood'' in those days, is the subject of a new commemorative in the ongoing Performing Arts Series being issued this Wednesday in Denver, Colo., his birthplace.

title: DRUG USERS, RICH AND POOR, TELL OF THE COSTS AND THE ANGUISH
description: Some grew up in wealth and comfort in the city, the suburbs and upstate New York. They went to private schools and Ivy League universities before moving almost effortlessly into well-paid executive jobs in finance or in the fashion industry. Their lives in New York City involve business deals in the garment district and Wall Street, fashionable Gramercy Park apartments, expensive restaurants and parties.

title: TURNING TO A FINANCIAL PLANNER
description: IN today's tightening fiscal squeeze, people in all economic circumstances, could use advice on at least one source of financial pressure - whether it's financing a new car or home mortgage, paying for a child's college education or simply trying to get a greater return on available cash.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINON;
UNDERSTANDING POTENTIAL HOLOCAUST OF 'NUCLEAR WINTER'
description: AT a meeting of the Harrison Nuclear Freeze Committee, a guest speaker, a biochemist from the Sloan-Kettering Institute in Rye, spoke to our group about the ''nuclear winter.'' She had attended a conference called ''The World After Nuclear War'' last October at which Dr. Carl Sagan and other scientists reported on the effects of nuclear explosions on our ecosphere. Her presentation was informed, low key and devastating.

title: DEATH IN CYPRUS.IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE. THE KING'S COMMISSAR.
description: By Fanny Howe. (Fic tion Collective, $12.95.) Set in ''Ashville,'' a small town between Providence and Boston, this ambitious, sad little novel describes the temporary conjunction of four rootless lives. After the rector of the local Episcopalian church commits suicide, Lachlan St. George, a young minister from a prosperous Boston family, arrives as a replacement. He quickly meets the other actors in this quiet drama - the sweet-voiced teen-aged soloist of the church choir, an itinerant auto mechanic and a divorced, college-educated mother living on welfare. All of them are unsure of their desires, unfocused in their ambitions. Born elsewhere, they feel unwelcome in the closed society of the old New England town. As they fumble in their attempts to find solace in love - and direction for their lives - their frustration deepens and becomes volatile. Eventually, one dies an unrecognized martyr's death; two flee south. And St. George, the only one of the four initially convinced of his faith's sturdiness and support, discovers that he, after all, is lost. In the unsettled world of America's middle class, as Fanny Howe protrays it, the unfulfilled promises of 1960's progressive politics, the ''liberation'' of women and the equivocal ''I'm-O.K.-you're-O.K.'' position of the clergy have created a confusion of values and expectations. Her characters suffer acutely from the absence of new systems of guidance and reassurance to replace traditional social structures, and their uncertainty has fatal consequences. Unfortunately, Mrs. Howe stylizes her story with irregularities of format and punctuation that must be intended to evoke in her readers feelings of dislocation comparable to those suffered by her characters.

description: The Stamford Museum and Nature Center is at 39 Scofieldtown Road, Stamford (322-1646).

title: Cola Death Ruled a Suicide
description: A man who died last week after drinking Coca-Cola laced with cyanide mixed the deadly potion himself to commit suicide, the Manitowoc County District Attorney, Denis Vogel, said Thursday.

title: A STITCH IN TIME FOR G. WASHINGTON
description: '' IT was just a stroke of luck, I would imagine,'' said Lola Sumien, ''because it was so farfetched.''

title: CREDIT CARDS - THE KEY TO EXPANDING SERVICES
description: FOR better or worse, depending on your luck in getting credit, the 600 million cards floating around in American wallets are becoming electronic keys, capable of unlocking a dizzying array of services. Indeed, for consumers, the rush by American Express, Diners' Club, MasterCard and Visa, among others, to expand the utility of their cards is somewhat bewildering. It is no longer a simple task to determine what kinds of services and limitations each card carries, much less what types of cards most people need.

title: INVESTING FOR CHANGING STEPS OF LIFE
description: INVESTING money so that it grows steadily and significantly is not a mysterious art known only to the wizened few with doctorates in finance. Even middle-income people can accumulate respectable wealth if they invest part of every paycheck. ''Time and money are analogous,'' said Donald J. Ercole, a tax partner at the Arthur Young accounting firm. ''We let time slip away, and we also let money slip away.''

title: CHERNENKO ASKS U.S. TO GIVE UP SPACE ARMS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, urged the United States today to abandon plans for developing space weapons and urged the two superpowers to sign an accord banning the advanced arsenals.

title: MONDALE STILL SEARCHES FOR A BACKDOOR
description: Speaking to campaign workers in San Francisco last week, Walter F. Mondale noted that usually by the time Presidential candidates arrive in California the race for the nomination is all but over. This year, he cracked, he was striving for a different ending. ''That's the reason I went out and deliberately lost New Hampshire and Maine,'' he said, as the audience laughed. ''And when it looked like I had it almost all locked up I forfeited Ohio and Indiana. But I wanted the fight to be decided by California, so here we are.''

title: MANY PASTIMES COME FORTH TO MARK SPRING
description: THE dandelions popped up, and the dogwood blossoms unfurled. While some of the county's residents reached for their lawnmowers, others broke out their water pistols, guitars and jump ropes to celebrate the rites of the spring that was at least three weeks late.

The Rev. John O. Mellin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

CAMERA;

description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance photographer and the auther of several books on photography.

description: Hylah Lydecker Brown, the daughter of Catherine Young Brown of Englewood, N.J., and the late Coley Tallman Brown, was married at the South Congregational Church in Kennebunkport, Me., yesterday to Christopher John Riley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Riley of Waltham, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Howes, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Curran, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SIR JOHN BETJEMAN, POET LAUREATE, DIES AT 77
description: Sir John Betjeman, the poet laureate of Britain, died yesterday at his vacation home in Trebetherick, Cornwall, after several years of failing health. He was 77 years old.

While other towns in Westchester and Fairfield Counties have been struggling to keep pace with a steady influx of well-paid, white-collar workers, Yonkers has been struggling to keep its schools open and its policemen paid.

title:
DINING OUT;
MIDDLE EAST COMES TO HOPEWELL
description: THERE'S a Middle Eastern restaurant called Casablanca on a lonely road in Hopewell. If you have the good fortune to look like a young Ingrid Bergman, and you decide to pay a visit some Friday or Saturday evening, Donival Brown, the restaurant's pianist, may play ''As Time Goes By'' on the white upright. However, the only Humphrey Bogart you will find is on a poster.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SOUVENIRS OF THE CHARTER OAK
description: OVER many generations age and storms trimmed the branches of an ancient tree - some said it was 1,000 years old - that once stood just west of Main Street in Hartford.

title: Today's Women Have Divided Loyalties
description: ''The Stress of Making Choices,'' by Mary Anne B. Cox (April 22) reminded me of a recent article about a study done at Wellesley College by Grace Baruch and Rosalind Barnett. Dr. Baruch states, ''The greatest sense of well-being is among women who have high-level jobs, are mothers and are married. Juggling these multiple roles does not stress women.''

title: FRESH FISH AND YOUNG LAMB WITH AN ENGLISH TOUCH
description: ENGLAND had one of its best springs ever this year, as a recent visit proved. The parks were filled with daffodils, bluebells, tulips and lilies of the valley; the weather for once was warm and bright. The first young vegetables had come into the market and the best restaurants were garnishing their dishes with baby turnips, young carrots, new potatoes, spinach and tiny leeks.

Heat and sun parch the skin and hair. The lust for exercise wilts. But that's just the beginning. In subtropical Texas, prolonged exposure to the sun imperils the youthful glow and elasticity of the skin as well as its healthy functioning.

The broadcast, monitored by the BBC, did not say when the incident took place but said the guards would be buried tomorrow in the southeastern town of Zahedan.

His status in that context began to emerge in private toward the outbreak of World War II, when he was quite clearly one of the cleverest people in Paris.

Residents know that they don't have to wait for seasonal craft fairs or seek out an artists' area of town; they buy woven shawls, rugs and tapestries in local shops or maybe from their neighbor.

title: POLISH OLYMPIC CLUBS STUCK WITH FUNDS BUT NO ATHLETES
description: Polish-American sports enthusiasts, who raised thousands of dollars to help finance the Polish Olympic team at the Los Angeles Games this summer, now have to decide what to do with the money.

title: A.T.&T. EXECUTIVE IS CHOSEN PRESIDENT OF PACE UNIVERSITY
description: Dr. Edward J. Mortola, who has been president of Pace University since 1960, has been named to the newly created post of chancellor and will be succeeded as president by Dr. William J. Sharwell, the university's board of trustees has announced.

title: SHELLFISH INDUSTRY MAKING A COMEBACK
description: CONNECTICUT'S shellfish industry has emerged from a 20-year tailspin, thanks to cleaner waters and better cultivation methods, and marine experts say the future looks even brighter.

title: AN AMERICAN CONDUCTOR SUCCEEDS AT HOME
description: Tim Page writes regularly on music for The Times.

title: STICKS AND STONES
description: THE RUSSIANS AND REAGAN By Strobe Talbott 140 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: TEXAS TREAT
description: When not spicing up quiches with jalapeno peppers, Miss Moss operates An Affair to Remember Inc., a company that dreams up and executes fanciful parties. There was, for example, the ''Murder in Marrekesh'' soiree, which she staged in Las Vegas for the Young Presidents' Organization, complete with live camels and a sultan's tent.

title: RIVALS PREPARING FOR TEXAS RUNOFF
description: For a moment, the rally seemed right out of the 1960's.

title: IN SHORT
description: By M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) By rescuing from obscurity these two linked, sentimental novels by a pre- Civil War Southern minister and educator, J. Michael Pemberton (a graduate professor of Library Science at the University of Tennessee and a former student of the late, renowned Southern literary scholar Richard Beale Davis) has done a service for readers of American fiction.

title: HANDICAPPED DISCOVER MUSIC'S JOYS
description: MELISSA MERCED of Bridgeport, blind since birth, looks forward to her weekly piano lesson.

title: BLAMING THE CORPORATE SECTOR
description: Robert Lekachman teaches economics at the Lehman College and Graduate Center campuses of the City University of New York. His most recent book is ''Greed Is Not Enough: Reaganomics.'' REBUILDING AMERICA

title: Paterno for Politics
description: Joe Paterno is only 57 years old and figures he has a few years of coaching to go, but after 34 years at Penn State, 18 as the head coach, he thinks it's time to give some thought to life after football. ''I've got to sit down and program myself for what I might want to do five or six years from now if I don't want to coach,'' Paterno said in an interview the other day.

title:
DINING OUT;
BRUNCH, FROM SIMPLE TO FANCY
description: WARM and lazy, late Sunday mornings require something more celebratory than the ritual, workaday breakfast, something to reassure us that we are at leisure. Adapting naturally to the insouciance of the day, brunch seems the ideal choice.

title: Guerrillas in Peru Kill 35 In Andes Village Raid
description: Maoist guerrillas shot and killed 35 people and wounded 25 others in the remote Andean village of Pilccas this week, the police said Friday.

title: Weinberger Ends Trip To Europe and Africa
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ended a weeklong trip through Europe and North Africa today and left for home, a day after signing an accord that extends United States rights to a vital mid-Atlantic air base for seven years.

title: MARYLAND GENTLY TURNS RECIPIENTS TO WAGE EARNERS
description: Few states have been more hostile to President Reagan's social and economic policies than Maryland, one of only six states that went for Jimmy Carter in 1980. Democratic Gov. Harry R. Hughes, welfare officials and Democratic state legislators have repeatedly criticized the Reagan Administration's cutbacks of the last three years. But Maryland is one of about 20 states to take advantage of a major change that Mr. Reagan requested in Federal welfare law in 1981, and Maryland officials seem to like the results. For the first time, states were permitted to put welfare recipients to work - or, as Maryland officials prefer to say, help people move into jobs.

title: FEWER SAID TO HOLD JOBS AT A MIDDLE-CLASS WAGE
description: It is getting more difficult for American workers to find and keep jobs that pay them middle-class wages, according to a new report released today.

title: SET GOALS, LOOK AT THE RESOURCES AND ACT
description: THERE is an old saw in the financial planning business that few people plan to fail, but most people fail to plan. Yet, at no time in the past has such planning been so necessary. The shifting financial sands - spurred by deregulation, the growth of financial services supermarkets and the development of new legal devices - have destroyed many of the rules that formerly governed personal money management. As a result, saving, investing, borrowing and spending wisely today require continual attention and analysis.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AGIANTS' game in May? No, their season wasn't extended to compete with the New Jersey Generals, but the Meadowlands- based team did play last week, albeit another kind of ball.

title: A NOSE FOR TALENT-- AND FOR TRADITION
description: IN 1953, Lee Stevens turned down a

title: GREEK EDITOR SAYS THE U.S. IS TRYING TO INTIMIDATE HIS PAPER
description: The editor of Greece's largest daily newspaper, Ethnos, told a court here today that the United States was seeking to intimidate the newspaper and undermine the interests of the Greek people.

title: Dee Whalen Has Nuptials
description: Denise Helen Whalen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Whalen Jr. of Brockton, Mass., was married yesterday to Kevin James Conway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Conway of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I. Msgr. John Connor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHEN the Congress of Members of the Band and Orchestra of Freeport High School (Combo, for short) invited me to look into its preparations for a concert to honor Dr. J. Maynard Wettlaufer, the band-orchestra's director for 30 years, I looked forward to a rare opportunity for the kind of music buff I am. Other people like concerts. I like rehearsals.

title: THE NEW MOMA
description: The otherwise excellent article on MOMA's past, present and future overlooks a man who had his share in the museum's rise to international fame: Rene d'Harnoncourt, its long-time director. He should not be forgotten. WERNER HOFMANN

title: TUITION INCREASE FOR STATE COLLEGES
description: UNDERGRADUATE students attending the state's public colleges and universities will be paying about $50 to $125 more in tuition in the 1985-86 school year, under a new tuition policy approved last week by the State Board of Governors for Higher Education.

title: Encountering Problems In Home Health Care
description: I have just finished reading a recent letter to the editor with an overview of home health care vs. nursing homes. I have tried both of these methods and have found only heartaches in home health care. While the principle involved is honorable and most therapeutic, the employees who work in this field for the most part leave much to be desired.

title: A DUAL PURPOSE
description: For more than 60 years, the Mannes College of Music occupied a row of town houses at 157 East 74th Street. When it moved late last February to larger quarters at 150 West 85th Street, the houses were quickly demolished and the site became a hole in the ground.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BACK TO THE BOARDS

title: Data Bank; May 20, 1984
BUILDING A CREDIT HISTORY: PROCEEDING WITH CAUTION
description: ONLY people who do not need credit can get it, or so the saying goes. The sheer number of banks attests to the falsity of that axiom. Indeed, at some point in life, virtually everybody needs credit, and most people are able to get it. But establishing a credit rating - and using credit judiciously - can require some preparation and understanding.

title: HUNT FOR SUNKEN TREASURE SET
description: OCEAN CITY AFTER three years of planning, a private salvage effort will get under way next weekend in an effort to recover what is left of the cargo of the four-masted bark Sindia, which ran aground in a storm off the beach here in 1901.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: The Fine Print On Health

title: JOAN BENOIT IS BACK ON COURSE AFTER A MONTH OF DETOURS
description: IN the backround, there was the

title: WEIGHING THE LATEST PORTABLE VCR'S
description: Even the best video camera is useless without a suitable recorder. The rapid developments among cameras reported in the previous column are therefore logically paralleled by corresponding design improvements in portable video-cassette recorders (VCR's). Together, they have sparked growing interest in ''videography'' - making one's own video shows.

title: THE WORLD;
description: The Message From Mexico

title: THE FLAME FROM GREECE THAT REFRESHES
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Awarded 90 World Cup
description: Italy, the 1982 champion, was named today the host for the 1990 soccer World Cup by the International Federation of Football Associations.

title: PYRRHIC VICTORY OVER MOON
description: The Supreme Court, urged on by the Justice Department, has decided not to review the conviction of the Rev. Sung Myung Moon for Federal income tax fraud. But President Reagan may have won a Pyrrhic victory by insulting a politically and racially diverse coalition of organizations that filed friend-of-the-court briefs in Mr. Moon's behalf.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS WITH SHALLOW ROOT SYSTEMS
description: THE problems that resulted from this spring's windstorms affected many homeowners and gardeners in this region. Most of the trees uprooted had very shallow root systems. The combination of strong winds and saturated soil had allowed them to be torn from the earth. The real culprit, however, was most often a shallow soil underlain by a hardpan.

title: TORIES SEE BIG GAINS ON THE WAY IN QUEBEC
description: With a national election scheduled for later this year, the opposition Progressive Conservative Party appears to be undergoing a revival in Quebec.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS May 20, 1984Fiction1
description: GENTLE FEUDING, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) True love overcomes a bloody feud between two Scottish clans. 2 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young Englishwoman caught between Israeli and P.L.O. agents. 3 SEEDS OF YESTERDAY, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $3.95.) Concluding volume of a horror series about the Dollanganger family. 4

title: Court Upholds Ouster Of 11,400 Air Controllers
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the dismissal almost three years ago of 11,400 air traffic controllers, rejecting arguments that included alleged interference by President Reagan and coercion by strike leaders.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE OXFORD SHAKESPEARE: ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' edited by H. J. Oliver. ($6.95.) ''Julius Caesar,'' edited by Arthur Humphreys. ($6.95.) ''Henry V,'' edited by Gary Taylor. ($6.95.) ''Titus Andronicus,'' edited by Eugene M. Waith. ($7.95.) ''Troilus and Cressida,'' edited by Kenneth Muir. ($6.95.) (Oxford University Press.) The first five titles in the long awaited Oxford Shakespeare editions will hardly be thought controversial in the sense that A. L. Rowse's recently released Contemporary Shakespeare editions have been, with their ''updated'' language and spelling. Conceived by a special Shakespeare department at the Oxford University Press in England, under the general editorship of Stanley Wells, the Oxford Shakespeare makes an essential distinction between ''mere modernization'' and emendations based on recent close study of the original texts to render the plays ''up to date in all areas of scholarship.'' Beautifully printed and easy to handle, each volume provides legible and useful footnotes, along with an introduction by an eminent scholar. The editions also place greater emphasis on the theatricality of the plays, with added stage directions and stage history that includes film and television performances. There will be four plays annually until the list is completed.

title: ADVANCE FUNERAL PLANNING CAN KEEP FINANCES ORDERLY
description: OF all the purchases that people make, perhaps none is more difficult than a funeral. Too upset to bargain as they would when making any other expensive purchase - and too rushed to do any serious comparison shopping - customers often accept a salesman's suggestions, only to discover, too late, how high the price of burying a loved one can be.

title: 100,000-Yard Honor In 443 consecutive games for 50 years,
description: Bernie Sherman has carried the first-down chains up and down the sidelines at DeWitt Clinton High School football games, covering perhaps 100,000 yards in the process.

title: SEEKING RELIEF FOR AGONY OF HEADACHE
description: FOR almost 30 years, Roberta McKinley's life was plagued by pain behind her right eye, ranging in intensity from dull to throbbing. At times, she would lie down on the bathroom floor, tired and nauseated. Sometimes, the ache would continue for days.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROCK HOUNDS
description: BEDFORD JERRINE ANTHONY and Harold Uhlin were scampering over the big boulders like children. ''Look,'' Mrs. Anthony called. ''Look at what I found. I think it's beryl.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE SERIOUSNESS OF CHOOSING A CAMP
description: T HEY trudged through the midwinter snows and the early spring mud. They are gone now, but their tracks and their arguments have left lasting impressions.

title: Topics Doings in Black and White
description: Phys-Ed for Pandas

title: TWO OPENING STYLES
description: Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union years ago advised against using sharp, forcing moves in the opening, presumably because they alert the opponent to danger and give him clear clues to the correct strategy. The former world champion thought that gentle moves gave the opponent more chance to misunderstand the position and go astray.

title: RETURN TO RELIGION
description: It is not surprising that thoughtful people should come to appreciate the integrating value of religion in their personal and scholarly lives.

title: BUILDING A RETAINING WALL TO REGRADE SLOPING YARDS
description: WHEN a homesite is higher than the surrounding earth on one or two sides, or when a yard slopes at a decided angle, soil washouts after a heavy rain can be a persistent problem. In addition, lawns or yards that slope also make it difficult to use lawn furniture for comfortable lounging, and they necessitate the installation of walks or paths that also slope. These paved surfaces can be a hazard when they are wet or icy.

title: FROM POLAND, A NEW BREED OF EMIGRE
description: Eva Hoffman, deputy editor of the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times, grew up in Poland.

title: DOINGS IN BLACK AND WHITE Different Stripe The words ''It's a boy'' and ''It's a girl'' have resounded through delivery rooms (or the equivalent thereof) for centuries. Last week was probably the first time, however, that anybody exclaimed, ''It's got stripes.''
description: That's what the attending veterinarian shouted when a Kentucky quarter horse gave birth to a 70-pound zebra whose embryo had been implanted last May.

title: CAREFUL PLANS AT EACH STAGE MAKE FOR A WELL-SPENT LIFE
description: UNPLEASANT financial surprises and missed opportunities are sure to occur at various points in our lives. ''Why didn't I prepare more for my retirement needs,'' is a refrain tax and personal financial advisers often hear. Parents, struggling to pay for their children's college education, ask themselves how it is possible that, after all these years, they still have not accumulated enough money to pay for it. Or a newly wed woman discovers that her credit rating has vanished with her maiden name.

title: PAPERS OF FLYNN GO TO HYDE PARK
description: The papers of Edward J. Flynn, who was the Democratic leader of the Bronx from 1922 until his death in 1953 and a political adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, have been presented to the Roosevelt library here.

title: DAVID NIVEN'S MOST DEVASTATING BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AGENCY HONORS TEENAGE BROKER
description: WASHINGTON FOR Sam Salter 2d, a Newark native who recently was named Young Entrepreneur of the Year by the Small Business Administration here, being 19 years old, black and in the loan brokerage business - where almost everyone else is middle-aged and white - is irrelevant.

title: REYNOLDS TO SHUT ITS JERSEY RECYCLING CENTERS
description: The Reynolds Aluminum Corporation plans to close its recycling operations in New Jersey after 15 years. A company spokesman attributed the action to what he said was the public's lack of zeal in turning in soda and beer cans.

title: GROWTH OF HOSPICE PROGRAMS IS CITED
description: WHEN a patient is dying, nothing is more important than the quality of his or her day-to-day living, according to Maureen Flannery Bryden, hospice coordinator at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Tarrytown. Those patients for whom all hope of a cure is passed need services to enhance the quality of their days, she says, rather than a continuation of curative efforts.

title: Kim Ament Wed in Bethlehem, Pa.
description: Kim Austin Ament, an artist, and Stephen Howland Taber, an international banking officer with the Marine Midland Bank in New York, were married yesterday at the Old Moravian Chapel in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Peter Skelly performed the ceremony.

title: A LITTLE MORE STRANGENESS, PLEASE
description: Richard Gilman is the author of ''The Making of Modern Drama'' and ''Decadence: The Strange Life of an Epithet.'' THE ARTS WITHOUT MYSTERY

title: Fusina Leads Stars In 45-12 Rout of Bulls
description: Chuck Fusina threw for 302 yards and 3 touchdowns as the Philadelphia Stars earned their 10th straight victory, routing the Jacksonville Bulls, 45- 12, tonight.

title: Miss Zuckerman Becomes a Bride
description: Robin L. Zuckerman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Zuckerman of New York, was married yesterday to Peter E. Mathes, a son of Mrs. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Cornwall Bridge, Conn., and the late A. Herbert Mathes. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in Manhattan.

title: THE NATION;
description: Affair of the Briefing Papers Flares Anew

title: FINE LEADING MAN IN 'MOLLY BROWN'
description: DINNER theater need not subsist on a steady diet of tried and tired musicals. Such establishments can aspire to fill the need for an ongoing musical repertory theater, instead of settling for obvious crowd-pleasers.

title: GREAT BOOKS ARE NOT THE STUFF OF GREAT MOVIES
description: ''The Natural,'' the screen version of Bernard Malamud's first novel, has just opened, and in coming weeks we'll be getting ''Swann in Love,'' based on a comparatively small portion of Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' as well as adaptations of Malcolm Lowry's ''Under the Volcano'' and Henry James's ''Bostonians.'' I must admit to feeling a certain amount of apprehension every time I hear that another moviemaker has fixed his eye on a recognized literary work.

title: THE T.V.A. HAS COME TO A BEND IN THE RIVER
description: When President Carter named S. David Freeman chairman of the three-member board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the agency, one of the most enduring and successful legacies of the New Deal, was under fire from both consumers and environmentalists.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
PROS AND CONS OF KINDERGARTEN
description: -DAY kindergarten has become a very controversial issue in communities around the country.

title: RETURN TO RELIGION
description: I was incensed by the characterization of religious expression during the 1960's and 1970's in Fran Schumer's article.

title: DESPAIR ON A LONELY HILL
description: Jakov Lind is the author of ''Soul of Wood,'' ''Landscape in Concrete,'' ''Counting my Steps'' and other books. His last is ''Travels to the Enu.'' He is working on a new novel. THE RETREAT

title: WHEN GREAT ACTORS PUT THEIR STAMP ON A ROLL
description: Theatergoers fortunate enough to have seen the current revivals of Eugene O'Neill's ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' and Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' no doubt left those shows with two extraordinary images implanted in their imaginations. One is an image of Kate Nelligan playing O'Neill's Josie as one of those worn yet beautiful women in a Walker Evans' photo, a woman whose unqualified love for a man redeems her life and reveals the radiant vulnerability beneath her fierce, tough-girl persona. The other image is of Dustin Hoffman playing Miller's Willy Loman as a scrappy shrimp of a salesman - a little hustler, all duded up in his Sunday best and battering away at anything that stands between him and his swiftly receding dream.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Tannen of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Tannen, to Stephen Henry Weitzen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Weitzen, also of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: IN 'INDIANA JONES' STUNTS GET STAR BILLING
description: LANCASTER, Pa.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Tops at Annapolis Grades count at the United States Naval Academy, but so does military achievement, and it was her accomplishments in the latter category that made Midshipman Kristine Holdereid the first woman to finish first in her class at any of the service academies.

title: DUTCH HESITANCY ON MISSILES DISMAYS NATO
description: The apparent reluctance of the Netherlands to deploy United States cruise missiles has dismayed officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, who say they see serious consequences if the Dutch actually refuse to accept the weapons. The Dutch decided last week to postpone for a month a final decision on the stationing of 48 cruise missiles.

title: THE BOLD GEOMETRY OF CORNHUSK BAGS
description: ''Woven Cornhusk Bags.'' Sound provocative? It is. The title refers to an exhibition of these handcrafted sacks at America Hurrah, 766 Madison Avenue (at 66th Street), the first such show in New York. Judging by the 28 stunning selections on view (through May 27), it will not be the last. The riotous display of rectangles, squares, diamonds and triangles on these compelling woven works shows a rare sophistication in the command of pattern.

title: 42DemonstratorsAreSeized AsNuclearSubIsChristened
description: Forty-two people were arrested at antinuclear demonstrations today as the nation's sixth Trident submarine, the Alabama, was christened here.

title: BEING BROOKE ASTOR
description: Marilyn Berger, a former newspaper and television correspondent, is a freelance journalist.

title: Elizabeth Harrington Scott Is Married
description: Elizabeth Harrington Scott and Mark James Marenakos were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del. The Rev. Adam Lewis, assisted by the Rev. Robert Griffiths, performed the ceremony.

title: Qualifiers at Indy Headed by Brayton
description: Scott Brayton today led six early qualifiers who filled the tentative 33- car field for the Indianapolis 500 on May 27 and assured the fastest starting lineup in the history of automobile racing.

title: MUSEUMS MAKE ROOM FOR THE ART OF ARCHITECTURE
description: Five years ago it was hardly possible to visit a single major museum anywhere in the United States or Canada and expect to see architectural drawings and models - not to speak of a special department dedicated to them. Even New York's Museum of Modern Art, which has had a department of architecture since 1932, dedicated its first permanent architectural gallery - the Philip Johnson Gallery - with the museum's recent reopening.

title: Jacqueline Silverberg Wed
description: Jacqueline Silverberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond R. Silverberg of Hackensack, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Richard Alan Marks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron J. Marks of Eastchester, N.Y. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Chandler Awakens All
description: Michael Chandler said was, ''Hi, Dad,'' but that was enough to touch off an emotional celebration in his hospital room in Indianapolis. After four days in a coma and three days slipping in and out of consciousness, the 26-year-old driver, who suffered a brain contusion when his racer crashed into a wall at 200 miles an hour at Indianapolis Motor Speedway on May 11, had finally emerged from the depths.

title: 2 THEATERS IN SEARCH OF AN AUDIENCE
description: THE Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven and the Palace Theater of the Arts in Stamford opened a day apart last December in refurbished, historical theaters. But so far neither has drawn the audiences that had been expected - a problem theater officials describe as the natural growing pains of a new arts venture. Nevertheless, steps are being taken at both theaters to present the kind of entertainment that will convince state residents to enjoy drama, music and dance locally, instead of going to New York City.

title: TWO ATHLETES ON THE SOVIET DECISION TO PULL OUT
description: I FEEL for the athletes who will not come to

title: ELECTION POLLING DEBATED IN FORUM
description: A leading poll taker and a key Congressman urged television networks last night to take account of public unhappiness with their election reporting and stop indicating who has won before the polls close.

title: THE ABSENTEE FATHER
description: Jacques Leslie's account of stepparenting reads like a Louisa May Alcott novel compared to my experience with it.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Bergen County community of Tenafly is the home of the Limousine Transportation Dispatch Network, which provides service in a number of cities throughout the nation.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: NORTHERN PUFFER (BLOWFISH)

title: BOARD SEEKKS STUDY IN DUMP DISPUTE
description: CORTLANDT'S Town Board voted unanimously last week to require Felix Industries to study the environmental impact of its proposed landfill at an abandoned granite quarry before the town would issue a permit to dump at the site. The process could take six months to a year to complete, depending on the yet-to-be-determined scope of the study.

title: CUTTING TAX LIABILITY: A FAST TRACK TO WEALTH
description: MANY Americans spend their lives struggling to reach the top income tax bracket, a symbol of wealth and status. Yet, the closer people come to fulfilling this aspiration, the more they realize the pressing need to find ways to stay out of the top tax bracket. Indeed, devising ways to cut taxes is one of the fastest tracks to increased wealth, considering that the Federal Government will otherwise collect up to half one's earnings, with state and local governments typically collecting an additional chunk.

title: WHO LIKED WHAT, AND WHEN, IN FRENCH DRAWINGS
description: No matter where you look on the map, this looks to be the year of the drawing. A remarkable anthology of drawings by Georges Seurat - lately seen at Bielefeld in Germany - attracted visitors from all over. The exhibition in Paris of recent acquisitions by the department of drawings in the Louvre was immensely admired - as much for its pioneering forays (J. M. W. Turner and Caspar David Friedrich were among the artists not previously represented in the Louvre) as for the arrival of such key works from the French school as Fragonard's drawing after the ''Triumph of Prince Frederick Henry'' by Jacob Jordaens.

title: SAKHAROV TAKEN TO SECRET PLACE, HIS FRIENDS SAY
description: Andrei D. Sakharov was removed from his Gorky apartment to an unknown destination on May 7, according to a telegram from his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, sources close to the family reported today.

title: Accessibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Wordsworth on Intellect
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE TAKES CENTER STAGE IN THE PRIMARY
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY residents will not have to watch the Democratic Presidential campaign on television this week. It will be on their doorsteps.

title: DR. YVONNE TSAI, PHYSICIAN, WEDS
description: St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Dr. Yvonne Mae Tsai, the daughter of Dr. Mary Y. Y. Tsai of New York and the late Raymond C. H. Tsai, to Nicholas Scott Kukshtel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nick Kukshtel of Warner Robins, Ga. The Rev. Charles Thorne, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.
