description: Mr. Moon Is A Step Closer To a Jail Term

title: TERMS OF FINANCE
description: Finance, like every discipline, has its own terminology. Understanding it will help a family develop its own financial plan. Below are some of the common terms used by bankers, brokers, accountants and financial planners.

title: Miss Jackson Has Nuptials
description: Lynn Caroline Jackson, an account officer at the Bankers Trust Company, and Charles Deane Urstadt, a vice president of the real-estate firm of Pearce, Urstadt, Mayer & Greer Inc., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: WHO'S MINDING THE STORE? 2nd GRADERS
description: SARA ALIPERTI said that ''opening the packages'' was the most exciting part of the project. Her classmate Tara Levin was happy that she and her friends could help handicapped youngsters. Sara and Tara are two of the 77 second-grade pupils at the Indian Hollow School in Commack who will be behind the sales counters when the school's 16th annual second- grade school store opens this week.

title: DRUG FLOOD ALTERING PATTERNS OF USE
description: Supplies of illegal heroin and cocaine have grown so plentiful in the New York City area that drug experts see a dissolving of the traditional lines between people who use the two drugs as well as between people who sell them.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MAMA'S SECRET

title: THE RETICENCE OF THE AMERICAN WRITER
description: THERE is no autobiography of William Faulkner. Ernest Hemingway's ''A Moveable Feast,'' published three years after his death in 1961, is a thin communique from a writer otherwise very visible on the American scene. Willa Cather, although she was prominently associated with McClure's Magazine and no stranger to public life, wrote little on the writerly experience. Theo dore Dreiser's autobiographical writing was tied to his travels in Russia, his socialism and his newspaper days. ''The Crack-Up'' was arranged by Edmund Wilson after F. Scott Fitzgerald's death. John Cheever has left only letters.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SCHOOLCHILDREN nationwide are rushing to aid the restoration of Miss Liberty as the venerable statue approaches its 100th birthday Aug. 5.

title: Submarines For State Police?
description: The recent announcement that the state police are acquiring two airplanes certainly says something about the fiscal priorities of Governor O'Neill's administration.

title: Dr. Jane Ellen Korn Wed to Dr. Robert D. Madoff
description: Dr. Jane Ellen Korn and Dr. Robert David Madoff were married yesterday by Rabbi Dennis Math at 126 Fifth Avenue in New York.

title: VACATION HOMES SHELTER TAXES, AS WELL AS FAMILIES
description: SECOND homes can provide investors with more than a welcome weekend or vacation retreat. Many can be sound investments and inflation hedges, as well as play a key part in retirement programs. Alternatively, when personal use is limited, second homes can serve as a means of sheltering income from the tax collector.

title: G.O.P. STYMIED ON MRAZEK RIVAL
description: TWO years after Long Island Republicans lost a Congressional seat to Robert J. Mrazek of Centerport, the Republicans are having problems coming up with an opponent to Representative Mrazek in the Third Congressional District.

title: ROMAN BLUNDERS
description: Carol Verderese is a freelance writer and critic living in New York City. YEAR OF THE GUN

title: WAVE OF BOMBINGS IN CHILE SPURS FEAR OF RADICAL VIOLENCE
description: A wave of bombings over the last year by leftists opposed to President Augusto Pinochet has raised widespread concern in this already politically torn country.

title: STAGE: 'SNAPSHOTS,' FATHER AND SON
description: Sam Henry Kass's first play, ''Side Street Scenes,'' was an engaging comedy with music about youthful aspiration. His new play, ''Family Snapshots'' (at the TOMI Theater), is about adult desperation. It is both more serious and less fully realized, but it offers additional evidence of Mr. Kass's talent, especially of his ability to write pungent, character- revealing dialogue. The playwright has a voice that is worth listening to, and Peter Kass, who is his director as well as his father, operates on the same wavelength.

title: ARAB LEAGUE HEAD ISSUES WAR APPEAL
description: The secretary general of the Arab League appealed today to the ''most influential states'' to take steps to end the war between Iran and Iraq.

title: NIGHT SKY.
description: World War II offers novelists a sumptuous cache of engrossing situations. Among those Clare Francis includes in ''Night Sky'' are high-level espionage, maritime derring-do and the merciless persecution of Jews by the Germans.

title: The Absentee Father
description: I read Jacques Leslie's essay, ''Stepping In'' (About Men, April 15), with tears in my eyes.

title: IMPACT OF MITCHEL FIELD BUILDUP DEBATED
description: DURING the early 1900's, thousands of spectators would crowd the roads surrounding Mitchel Field to watch daredevil fliers perform their feats. Today, in the age of the automobile, the roads themselves are more likely to be crowded as the former aviation center is transformed into a center for business and industry.

title: OILERS WIN, 5-21, TO END ISLANDERS' CUP REIGN
description: The Edmonton Oilers, who for so long have said that there were lessons to be learned from the Islanders, tonight learned what the Islanders knew best for so long - the feeling of being champions.

title: L.I. READIES GAMES FOR DISABLED
description: NASSAU COUNTY is preparing to welcome more than 1,800 disabled athletes from 54 countries next month with all the pomp and security of the International Olympic Games that will be held this summer in Los Angeles.

title:
HOSTILE TAKEOVER;
IN DEFENSE OF THE CORPORATE DEFENDER
description: CORPORATE chieftains have come under substantial criticism of late because of their efforts to stop unfriendly takeovers. Yet, the critics do not seem to have a sufficient grasp of certain management and economic realities that justify many of these defense tactics and raise key questions about who should control public corporations and how they should be governed.

title: UNFORTUNATELY FOR MANY OF US, WE ARE WHAT WE EAT
description: R ECENT research on cholesterol confirms what has long been suspected: one way to heart disease is through the stomach. That is unfortunate news for many Americans. Although consumption of cholesterol-rich butter and eggs has dropped in the more than 20 years since the American Heart Association sounded a dietary alarm, the typical American still consumes 450 milligrams of cholesterol each day and gets 40 percent of his calories from fats, nearly half of which are saturated fats that boost blood cholesterol even higher. Last week, the association unveiled an aggressive plan to help steer Americans away from red meat, cheese and whole milk and toward poultry, fish, vegetables and grains. The three-step approach starts with a ''prudent diet'' limiting fat to 30 percent of daily calories, no more than a third of it saturated, and cholesterol to 300 milligrams a day. It ends with a regimen of 20 percent fat and just 100 to 150 milligrams of cholesterol. Though designed for people in the top 5 percent in cholesterol levels - for men and women in their early 40's, 260 milligrams per deciliter of blood or higher - the association said the plan would benefit all those above the national mean of 210, the point at which coronary risk rises sharply. But there is still debate about how much cholesterol is too much, and what the best way is to cut down on it. Dr. W. Virgil Brown of New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center, chairman of the heart association's nutrition committee, Dr. William E. Connor of the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland and Nathan Pritikin, founder and director of the Longevity Centers, recently discussed these issues at a symposium at Mount Sinai.

title: BUYING A CAR ON CREDIT? SHOP ABOUT FOR BEST DEAL
description: BUYING an automobile is one of the most complex, and costly, financial dealings most people face, second only to the purchase of a home. In addition to selecting from a bewildering array of domestic and imported models and negotiating over price and options, most car buyers also need to arrange a loan to buy a new car.

title: A MEDICAL PAVILION
description: Barely a stone's throw, 300 feet across Flatbush Avenue from the Kings Plaza Shopping Center in Brooklyn, a large new brick-and-glass complex is going up at Coleman Street and Avenue V. It is the Park View Professional Pavilion at Kings Plaza, and its developers see it as the successful updating of an old practice.

title: GOOD VALUE AND FRIENDLY STAFF
description: -MEX and Cal-Mex, American versions of Mexican cooking, have been wending their way to the Northeast for a dozen years. There has been no stampede, to be sure, but interest continues.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Cable TV
description: With no major new cable programing this week, there are some rewarding vintage films. Take ''Where the Lilies Bloom'' (1974), generally neglected family fare that The Times reviewer deemed ''refreshing as a dip of spring water.''

title: DEALING IN ABSOLUTES
description: Bridge writers as a body tend to be wary of absolute words. If a contract is said to be impossible, some reader will demonstrate that it is possible, that it can be made by some far-fetched impractical line of play. Or if a contract is said to be impregnable, someone will burn the midnight oil and prove that it is pregnable.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: SQUEEZING INSPIRATION FROM THE 1896 OLYMPICS
description: The ideal, or myth, of pure sportsmanship has been taking a battering in real life these days, but it lives on virtually unblemished in popular entertainment. A couple of years ago, the film ''Chariots of Fire'' snagged an Oscar with its portrait of noble athletes. And now, beginning tonight at 8 on NBC and continuing tomorrow at 8, ''The First Olympics - Athens 1896,'' obviously with an eye to the success of the movie and to the hoopla being generated for this summer's Games in Los Angeles, ventures smartly into inspirational territory. The recent withdrawal of the Soviet Union from the 1984 Summer Olympics may have been yet another disheartening reminder of how politicized the Games have become, but there is clearly a good deal of audience-grabbing sentiment still to be extracted from the loftier motives traditionally associated with the event.

title: AND IN THIS CORNER...BOXING RULES NEED REVAMPING
description: SINCE the advent of casino gambling in New Jersey, boxing has become a major adjunct of the state's expanded sporting events. Rarely does a week pass without a boxing program being televised from one of the Atlantic City hotel-casinos.

title: Headliners
description: Tickled Blue Some ride rafts down rapids, some cross oceans in balloons; David Hempleman-Adams takes long walks in the cold.

title: KOPIT'S 'END OF THE WORLD' IS SERIOUS, URGENT DRAMA
description: Arthur Kopit's shrewd and lively ''End of the World'' is clearly not to the taste of all my professional kith and kin. So blithely have some critics dismissed Harold Prince's production at the Music Box that you'd think they'd spent the Broadway season guzzling and gourmandizing on theatrical riches past compare. But that has hardly been the case, at least as far as fresh American work is concerned. Before considering Mr. Kopit's educated anguishings about the Bomb, let's briefly remind ourselves of the thin and watery diet on which we've subsisted to date.

title: A MAJOR WORK BY A MUSICAL MAVERICK IS FINALLY RECORDED
description: From afar, the world of classical music may seem like some eternal temple of art, with the pantheon all picked and the elected gods of music in blissful Apollonian repose. Closer up, however, the temple is infested with all manner of cranks and eccentrics; indeed, the artistic temperament being what it is, eccentricity and genius often go hand in hand.

title: When a Residence Is a Floating Home
description: In ''Resistance to Houseboats Grows on L.I.'' (April 22), apparently people who live in these homes were not interviewed, and that was a mistake.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: Bumping Day, at Indianapolis. The final day of qualifying trials for the Indy 500. Cars that did not qualify for the field of 33 last week have another chance to bump the slower cars out of the race. In 1974, Johnny Rutherford qualified on bumping day, started in the 25th position and won the first of his three 500 crowns. (Television - Channel 7, 6 P.M.)

title: BIG FOOD CHAINS LOOK TO 'UNDERSTORED' NEIGHBORHOODS
description: A JARGON word that leaps with ease and frequency from the lips of those who help supermarkets find locations for expansion is ''understored.''

title: STATES SEEK BUSINESS IN JAPAN
description: In the Tokyo telephone book, under ''embassy,'' there is a listing for the State of New York.

title: IOWA'S STAR OF SUDS
description: In the big bucks brewing business, where Anheuser-Busch, Miller and a couple of others disgorge a river of beer and obliterate all others in television advertising, is there a small place for Dubuque Star, brewed on the banks of the Mississippi and long celebrated as Iowa's last brewery?

title: THE TERRORISM OPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Get Out of the Way in Times Square
description: Five New York legislators who may never have walked on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in the dark think the huge city-state plan to transform the area needs more time. In effect, they call for more crime in a block that sees so many drugs, muggings and holdups that people say it's the worst in the city.

title: AGA KHAN'S U.S. ARCHITECTURE PROJECT IS STALLED AFTER 5 YEARS
description: Five years ago the presidents of Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced that the Aga Khan, a Harvard alumnus who is the hereditary imam of the world's 12 million Ismailian Moslems, had granted the two schools $11.5 million to establish an ambitious new program in Islamic architecture.

title: Michels's Appeal Rejected
description: The International Weight Lifting Federation yesterday rejected American weight lifter Jeff Michels's appeal to lift the suspension barring him from international competition, including the Olympics, according to Michael Dockterman, his Chicago-based attorney.

title: SPEK OF GENERALS UNFORESEEN BONUS
description: Most pass receptions, game: 10, Jeff Spek, New Jersey, vs. Washington, 5/11.

title: Ray Copeland, 57, Trumpeter; Who Played With Jazz Bands
description: Ray Copeland, a jazz trumpeter and teacher who played and recorded with Thelonious Monk, Dizzy Gillespie, Lionel Hampton, Randy Weston and many others, died on Friday in New York after a lengthy illness. Mr. Copeland, who was 57 years old, lived in Sunderland, Mass., near Hampshire College in Amhurst, Mass., where he had been teaching for five years.

title: BUDGET: A SILVER LINING
description: It's easy to be pessimistic about budget deficits. They're $200 billion annually as far as the eye can see, we're told. Interest rates are going up. We're saddling ourselves and our children with a terrible burden. One can paint a bleak picture of future economic growth constricted by huge Federal debt requirements. While the prevailing wisdom contains some substance, a brighter picture can also be painted.

title: AN EXHORTAION TO TAKE RISKS
description: The television journalist Jim Lehrer, speaking at Vassar College's 120th commencement, urged graduates today ''to take risks, to be willing to put your mind and your spirit, your time and your energy, your stomach and your emotions on the line.''

title: EXERCISE INDUSTRY SEES SPURT IN SALES TO HOMES
description: Costly and crowded health clubs, modesty and a continuing desire to remain fit have sent thousands of Americans in search of creative and effective ways to work out at home.

title: ARTS AND PUBLIC SERVICE CITED
description: A former Treasury Secretary, William E. Simon, and an actor, Michael Moriarty, received honorary doctoral degrees today in ceremonies at two campuses of Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Angelica S. Whitman Weds Daniel Aronson
description: Angelica Schuyler Whitman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Whitman of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Aronson, a son of Rhoda Alben-Aronson and Norman Aronson, both of New York. Judge Marie-Louise Nickerson of Nassau County District Court performed the ceremony at the Whitman home.

title: I.B.M.'S ROLE IN BRITAIN GROWS
description: Late last December, the International Business Machines Corporation's subsidiary here unintentionally set off a political firecracker. In a letter to 30 companies that leased its products, British I.B.M. cautioned that users were required to obtain United States Government approval before moving certain kinds of mainframe computers, even from one office to another.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A runner for Team A is on third base with less than two out when his teammate hits a fly to the outfield that obviously is catchable and could result in a close tag-up play at home. Seeking an advantage, the runner positions himself slightly beyond third base and with a running start touches the base at top speed just as the Team B outfielder catches the ball. If the runner is not thrown out, does the run count?

title: INJURIES AND TIME HALT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders were already departed when cars lined the downtown streets in Edmonton, Alberta, and sleepy-eyed children, too young to understand the childlikeness of adults, toddled around in their No. 99 T-shirts. The Oilers won their first Stanley Cup Saturday night, and it wasn't until well into yesterday morning, with the sun ready to rise, that the raised emotions of their fans began to settle down.

title: Jet Air to Pay NASA
description: The president of Jet Air Inc. has agreed to pay the National Aeronautics and Space Administration $690,000 as part of a settlement in a civil-criminal suit. George Thomas Straza, 55, of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., pleaded guilty Friday to one count of making false statements in connection with a NASA subcontract to build panels for five Space Shuttle orbiters.

title: DUN AND NIELSEN: COMPATIBLE GOALS
description: One monitors business credit; the other measures consumer sales. And if neither company is precisely a household word, both the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation and the A. C. Nielsen Company are part of the basic business vocabulary.

title: Abdullah Wins
description: Abdullah, ridden by Conrad Homfeld, won the $25,000 Almaden Vineyards United States Equestrian Team show-jumping championship today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  At a Police Station, Fun With a Purpose
description: The police at the 19th Precinct held

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Bucks vs. Celtics , at Milwaukee. Game 4 of the four- of-seven-game Eastern Conference final. The Celtics have won the first three games and have a chance to turn the tables on the Bucks, who swept Boston last year in the conference semifinals.

title: PLEA ON THE BEST USE OF TIME
description: Saying that it was a day for ''congratulations, not speeches,'' the president of St. John's University kept his remarks brief and his message personal to the 1,336 Queens campus students who graduated yesterday at the university's 114th commencement exercises.

title: THE DRUG PIPELINE: FROM EUROPE TO NEW YORK
description: Arriving in New York City on flights from Geneva or Paris, Albert Camille Gillet gave all the appearances of a prosperous European businessman. A chauffeured limousine usually waited to drive him to Manhattan, where he always stopped at fine hotels and dined at expensive restaurants.

title: JEROME ROBBINS: TAKING THE LONG VIEW
description: IN 1948, Jerome Robbins wrote a

title: Congress Study Doubts Space Arms Feasibility
description: A House of Representatives subcommittee said today that need for defensive weapons in space was still open to question, and its chairman asserted that the United States should rely more on arms control and less on unproven technology.

title: Oscar Schisgall, 83, a Writer; And a Corporate Historian
description: Oscar Schisgall, a corporate historian and a prolific contributor to the Reader's Digest, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: AN ISRAELI SOLDIER AND HER VIVID MEMORIES OF WAR
description: Netiva Ben-Yehuda, one of the first Israeli women to be a soldier, is still affectionately known in her country as the ''Blond Devil.'' She was 18 in 1948 during Israel's war for independence when that name was bestowed upon her by the Syrians, who, shocked by the sight of a woman fighter, offered a reward for her capture. She was then a commander in the volunteer army, a demolition expert and an accomplished field spy.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Hill of Fame It's always nice to win a major golf tournament, of course, but victory in next month's United States Golf Association's Senior Open Championship should be especially sweet.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE RESOLUTION
description: Following are excerpts from a resolution concerning the relationship of Jews and blacks that was adopted yesterday by the trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations:

title: CAMEROON'S UNEASY ECONOMY
description: During April's failed coup, a rebel spokesman charged the Government of President Paul Biya with having brought about the ''bleakest period'' in Cameroon's history. The Government, the spokesman charged, had participated in ''unmeasurable and unqualified graft.''

title: 2 Women Scale Nepal Peak
description: Vera Komarkova, a 41-year-old plant ecologist from Boulder, Colo., and Margita Dina Sterbova, 44, a mathematics teacher from Olomouc, Czechoslovakia, became the first women to conquer Cho Oyu, one of the world's highest mountains, when they reached the 26,867-foot peak on May 13, the Nepalese Tourism Ministry said today.

title: KOCH ASSERTS PUBLIC SERVICE CAN BE 'NOBLEST OF PROFESSIONS'
description: Mayor Koch played campus recruiter yesterday and urged the 1,100 graduates of Manhattan College to consider careers in public service.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SUNDOG. By Jim Harrison. 241 pages. E. P. Dutton/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95.

title: PREP SCHOOL REUNION: CHANGE AND MEMORIES
description: They came to remember things past: the red-brick school buildings with cupolas and white trim, the lush lawns and the gray Gothic Revival chapel where they prayed daily and twice on Sundays for up to six years of their lives.

title: 3 Die in Vienna Collapse
description: A four- story apartment building collapsed Saturday, killing at least three elderly residents, the police reported. A rescue crew was searching through the ruins for a fourth occupant. The police said a loud explosion preceded the collapse and they presumed it was caused by natural gas.

title: BODIES OF SEVEN SOUGHT AFTER SHOOTOUT IN ALASKA
description: Alaska state troopers searched the icy Tanana River today for seven people believed to have been killed by a drifter who shot a trooper to death Saturday and was killed in a shootout.

title: ISRAEL BOMBS SHIITE BASES IN LEBANON
description: Israeli planes bombarded bases belonging to pro-Iranian Shiite guerrillas in Lebanon's Bekaa region today. It was the first such Israeli attack in Lebanon since early April.

title: SUBMARINE-BUILDING CITY PROTESTING THE PROTESTERS
description: The usual crowd was here this weekend.

title: Futures/Options; Final Pleas On Margin Ban
description: ONE of the most vexing problems facing the commodity options markets is the inability of floor traders and other market makers to finance positions because, unlike with futures contracts, options buyers cannot make partial payment of premiums.

title: JACOBSEN TRIUMPHS
description: Peter Jacobsen fulfilled a promise to his father, as he rallied to win the Colonial National Invitation golf tournament in a playoff today.

title: Marathon to Hart
description: Bill Hart of the Heights-Inwood Track Club overtook Scott Mosenthal with four miles to go and won the 48th Yonkers Marathon in 2 hours 39 minutes 44 seconds today. Mosenthal fell victim to the heat and humidity, and finished 650 yards behind in 2:41:23. Kathy Horton of New York won the women's title in 3:08:17.

title: Houston Pupil, 13, Wins National Math Contest
description: Mike Edwards, 13 years old, an eighth grader from the Kinkaid School in Houston, won the first national championship in the Mathcounts program Saturday.

title: Greenmarkets Growing
description: ''The first day was terrible,'' Ed

title: Cosmos on Top, 2-1, Before Only 16,719
description: The heroes on opening day last Sunday came through again today and led the Cosmos to a 2-1 soccer victory over the Vancouver Whitecaps before a crowd of 16,719, the smallest to watch a league game at Giants Stadium since 1977.

title: Raise the Drinking Age, Save Lives
description: Do New York State's 19- and 20-year-olds have a right to drink? Plenty of them think they do, and so do the restaurant and bar owners, who fear a loss of business if the Legislature raises the drinking age to 21. But Governor Cuomo believes the change essential if drunk driving is to be reduced.

title: U.S. MILITARY POLICY ASSSAILED
description: The military has ''burst out of control'' under the Reagan Administration and is endangering peace as well as the nation's relations with its allies, the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. said today in a commencement speech at the State University at Albany.

title: MRS. PERON GOES HOME TO ARGENTINA FOR TALKS
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron returned here from Spain today to join in talks with President Raul Alfonsin about the nation's political divisions.

title: Ben Bella Reported Seeking A Political Return in Algeria
description: Ahmed Ben Bella, the first leader of Algeria after it gained independence from France, says he will seek a political comeback, according to a newspaper here.

title: STUDIED TV'S EFFECT ON SOCIAL BEHAVIOR
description: Dr. Joseph Thomas Klapper, a leading researcher on the effects of television on behavior, died last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Agency Approves Estrogens to Aid Bones
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of estrogens, female hormones, to prevent and treat osteoporosis, the brittle bone ailment that accounts for many of the hip, wrist and spinal fractures suffered by elderly women.

title: EMOTIONAL FAREWELL TO SUMO WRESTLER
description: In midafternoon today, a 429-pound man-mountain who goes by the professional name of Takamiyama hit the clay floor in an airless arena. With that fall came the end of the most remarkable career any foreigner has had in the feudal Japanese world of wrestling known as sumo.

title: Bill Holland, Car Racer, Dies; Won 1949 Indianapolis 500
description: TUCSON, Ariz., May 20 (AP) - Bill Holland, the record-setting winner of the 1949 Indianapolis 500 auto race, died Saturday of Alzheimer's disease, according to his family. He was 76 years old.

title: TV: FOOD FOR SPIRIT IN CHINA
description: TELEVISION made much of the winds of change in China during President Reagan's recent visit, but for the most part the television image has been one of mass: a huge country, multitudes of people, a culture caught in lock step. ''A Taste of China,'' a public-television series with modest intentions, is a pleasant corrective. It looks at food. The chapter tonight, ''Food for the Body and Spirit,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 10.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Smog Alert The way the Mets are telling it, the smog in Los Angeles doesn't arrive on little cat feet. It's more like a mugger who sneaks up from behind and gets a stranglehold on an unsuspecting shortstop.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 21, 1984

title: Advertising; New Chief Of D.D.B. Optimistic
description: IN his more than 30 years in the

title: OUTDOORS: A FISHING TRIP WITH SPECIAL GOALS
description: T AKING a child fishing is like writing a poem: one is never sure where either will lead. Conditioned by the exigencies of economic survival, most adults approach an angling excursion with a youngster believing that fish and plenty of them are the measure of success.

title: MRS. GANDHI TO VISIT AREA TODAY
description: Rioting set off by Hindu-Moslem tension engulfed new areas of Bombay today, where the police opened fire on attacking crowds.

title: DUARTE, IN WASHINGTON, ASSERTS SALVADORAN ARMY WILL BACK HIM
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the President-elect of El Salvador, said today that he was confident that the Salvadoran Army would support his efforts to introduce democracy and abolish the right-wing death squads in his country.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 21, 1984: MONDAY Bk Amer Rlty InvNorthwest AirlinesCentury Tel EnterpSears Roebuck & CoConn Nat GasUtah Pwr & LtGoodrich (B F) Co

title: 10-Kilometer Run Captured by Bayi
description: Filbert Bayi of Tanzania and Anne Audain of New Zealand overcame driving rain to win 10-kilometer races today in the sixth annual Revco Cleveland Marathon and 10-kilometer run.

title: MUSIC: THOUVENEL QUARTET
description: THE Thouvenel String Quartet, which has established its usefulness on the concert scene mostly with new or out- of-the-way works, confirmed it in a perfectly standard program at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon. The four players, Eugene Purdue, Edmund Stein, Sally Chisholm and Jeffrey Levenson, performed with vigor, understanding, commitment and a generally high level of execution.

title: AMERICAN MYSTERY SERIES FOR CANADIAN TV A HIT
description: TORONTOThe Canadian Broadcasting Corporation faces an unenviable and formidable task - developing programming with a Canadian content that can compete against all the glitter, dross and gems emanating from the United States, most of which are pervasive here.

title: SWISS VOTE BARS PLAN TO EASE BANK SECRECY
description: The Swiss decisively rejected a proposed constitutional amendment today that would have opened bank records to tax authorities.

title: EUROPE'S TECHNOLOGY REVIVAL
description: The British, like many other Europeans, are increasingly frustrated by their poor record at turning technological innovations into profitable, job-creating businesses.

title: J.P. IS NOW PITCHING B.P.
description: BALTIMORE

title: The Vicious Cycle of Debt
description: When America's interest rates rise one percentage point, the added annual cost to third-world borrowers is nearly $4 billion. The rates have risen more than a point in two months, and may go higher. It's a new phase of the world debt crisis, posing a particular dilemma for the United States, which thus appears to be profiting from the troubles of the poorest nations.

title: U.S. Weather Service Sued in Fishing Deaths
description: The forecast called for fair weather when the 52-foot Fairwind and the 46-foot Sea Fever set out from Cape Cod on Nov. 21, 1980, for a week of lobster fishing.

title: MONDAY, MAY 21, 1984 International
description: Iran was accused of aggression in the Persian Gulf war by the Foreign Ministers of the 21-member Arab League. The ministers accused Iran of aggression against Iraq and specifically in connection with attacks against Arab shipping in the Persian Gulf. In a rare departure from its usual public unanimity, the group overruled objections from Syria and Libya, the only Arab League supporters of Iran. (Page A1, Column 6.) Soviet submarines off the U.S. have been increased by Moscow, and their nuclear missiles are within 10 minutes of American targets, the Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri F. Ustinov, said. Marshal Ustinov also said the number of SS-20 medium- range missiles in the European part of the Soviet Union would be increased ''accordingly'' if the United States proceeds with its plan to deploy additional Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe. (A1:5.)

title: MARCOS PLAYS DOWN OPPONENTS' GAINS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos insisted today that the gains achieved by his opponents in the National Assembly elections last week were not a reflection of widespread dissatisfaction with his Government.

title: LOOKING AT RELIGION AND BABIES
description: THE baby is born or on the way.

title: INADEQUATE APPROACH TO FIGHTING GUM DISEASE
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Applied Data Research Promotes a Co-Founder
description: -founders of Applied Data Research Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of the Princeton, N.J., software concern.

title: Topics Hazarding Candor
description: Nanny 1, Hobgoblins 0 The Consumer Product Safety Commission has been pondering whether to let manufacturers export products that have been banned from domestic markets. It finally decided no, but how could that even be a question for debate? For the Administration's free marketeers, regulation is bad enough, and its extension abroad is worse.

title: Paterson Going Abroad
description: Straws in the wind? Basil Paterson, who is considering running for Mayor next year, is going to visit Israel as a guest of the Jewish Community Relations Council.

title: UNSPENT FUNDS FOR ARMS CREATE BUDGET PROBLEM
description: Because of the Reagan Administration's vast military buildup, the Defense Department has accumulated the largest backlog of unspent funds since the Vietnam War era, creating management and budget problems for the Pentagon and Congress.

title: Ford Backs Republican Opposing Tom Hayden
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford has thrown his support behind a Republican candidate who will be trying to unseat Assemblyman Tom Hayden, a Democrat, this year.

title: CHARTING TEEN-AGERS' MOODS AND DAYS
description: A detailed portrait of the day-to-day world of the average American teen-ager is emerging from new research into adolescents' activities, private thoughts and emotional ups and downs.

title: Anderson Scores 3 As Bandits Win
description: Gary Anderson ran for three touchdowns today to lead Tampa Bay to a 31-20 victory over the New Orleans Breakers and enable the Bandits to remain one game behind Birmingham in the Southern Division of the United States Football League.

title: Cambodian Day of Hate Marks Pol Pot's Victims
description: The Cambodian Government declared today a National Day of Hatred to commemorate the more than 2.7 million people who it says died during the reign of terror by the Pol Pot regime from 1975 to 1979.

title: G OMEZ DEFEATS KRICKSTEIN IN ITALY
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador won the Italian Open today, defeating 16-year-old Aaron Krickstein of the United States, 2-6, 6-1, 6-2, 6-2, in a windy final.

title: RECALCULATING THE '84 DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON FIRST, the good news.

title: MONDALE PREDICTS VICTORIES IN 2 KEY PRIMARIES JUNE 5
description: Walter F. Mondale predicted today that he would win the Democratic Presidential primaries in New Jersey and California on June 5 and gain enough delegates to secure his nomination before the national convention in July.

title: Petty Wins 119th DOVER, Del., May 20 (UPI) - Richard Petty took the lead with 47 miles to go in today's Dover Downs 500 and swept to the 199th victory of his career, beating Tom Richmond by 4.48 seconds.
description: Petty, who started from the fifth position and averaged 118.717 miles per hour, was in the top five all day.

title: Addenda
description: * General Mills European Toy Group consolidated all of its advertising at Grey Advertising.

title: Camacho Stops Williams in 7th
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho, the World Boxing Council junior- lightweight champion, stopped Rafael Williams in the seventh round of a nontitle bout today.

title: COMING PRIMARY HEATS JERSEY CITY'S OLD FERVOR
description: If ever a city qualified as the birthplace of the ''veteran political observer,'' this is the one.

title: THE PACIFIC & ATLANTIC CAMPAIGN CO.
description: With barely enough time to recover from jet lag after his trip to China, President Reagan is preparing for a trip to Europe that White House officials hope will be one of their greatest displays yet of pageantry, sentiment and statesmanship overseas.

title: MUSIC: SIMON ESTES IN FIRST CARNEGIE HALL RECITAL
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera announced that the forthcoming season would include its first production of ''Porgy and Bess,'' questions were immediately raised by Gershwin fans about how the company would approach his famous folk opera. Simon Estes, who will sing Porgy, answered some of those questions last night when he gave an unscheduled performance of ''I Got Plenty o' Nuttin' '' in his Carnegie Hall recital. Mr. Estes had been planning to sing Mussorgsky's ''Flea'' but, as he explained to the audience, he and his excellent pianist, Paul Liljestrand, were unable to find an English-language arrangement that they both knew.

title: Dr. Susan Levine Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Susan Levine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Levine of Mexico City and New York, was married yesterday to Wade Hooker Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hooker of Bridgewater, Mass. Dr. Sheldon Ackley, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture in New York, performed the ceremony at the United Nations Plaza Hotel.

title: ECONOMISTS STILL EXPECT SLOWDOWN
description: Despite reports of strong growth during April, many economists believe the economy is slowing and they are sticking to forecasts of 3 to 5 percent growth for the second quarter.

title: Alberto R. Cellario, Journalist In Argentina and Later in U.S.
description: Alberto R. Cellario, an Argentine journalist who went into exile as an opponent of the Peron dictatorship, died Thursday of heart failure during a visit to his native Buenos Aires. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Marston and Burgess Lead Pairs at the Cavendish Club
description: The Cavendish Club Invitational Pairs Championship began here Saturday, and is sure to be the strongest pair event to be played anywhere in the world this year. Almost half the partnerships included at least one player who is or has been a world champion.

title: REFORM JEWS ASK HEALING OF SPLIT IN TIES TO BLACKS
description: The leaders of Reform Judaism called on American blacks and Jews yesterday to preserve their historic social alliance despite ''traumas of the moment'' that they said had been engendered by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign.

title: SUPPLY OF TREASURY ISSUES GROWING
description: The supply of high-grade corporate bonds remains scanty, but there is still an ample amount of Treasury issues in a variety of maturities for investors to buy.

title: No Headline
description: Karen Kwilecki Marries

title: JACKSON EXPANDS VOTE-RULE ATTACK
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the disparity between his proportion of the popular vote and the number of delegates he has been awarded in the Democratic Presidential race meant that the ''struggle for enfranchisement must continue.''

title: Pole-Vault Mark Is Set by Tully
description: Mike Tully broke the American pole- vault record today with a vault of 18 feet 11 inches at the Southern Pacific Association regional meet for The Athletics Congress.

title: 4 LATIN CHIEFS JOIN IN DEBT WARNING
description: The presidents of four Latin American countries, citing rising international interest rates, have warned in a joint statement that they will not be forced into insolvency by their foreign debts.

title: THAT EXTRA SEASON
description: T HEY were Ruth and Gehrig, Russell and Cousy, Starr and Kramer. They were the best hockey team of their time, one of the finest teams ever put together, and now it is over.

title: DENUNCIATION OF OPPRESSION
description: Dr. Lipman Bers, the mathematician and human-rights activist, told the graduating students at the State University at Stony Brook today that the United States was supporting governments that brutally oppress their citizens.

title: Sarah A. Morris, Actress, Marries Louis Eli Rousso
description: Sarah Anne Morris, a daughter of Andrew R. Morris Jr. and Sarah Cooper, both of New York, was married yesterday to Louis Eli Rousso, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Louis Rousso of Hewlett, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: YANKS LOSE,3-0; PADRES FALL, 4-2
description: When the afternoon was over, Manager Dave Johnson looked like a genius. He had benched Darryl Strawberry, and his replacement, Jerry Martin, hit a home run. He had called on Strawberry to pinch hit in the ninth inning, and the sulking slugger drove in the tying run. He had brought Jesse Orosco from the bullpen and the reliever made a big defensive play, then scored the winning run in the 10th inning and was credited with the Mets' 4-2 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Motorist Drowns in Hudson When Car Plunges From Pier
description: An unidentified motorist drowned when his sedan plunged from a Greenwich Village pier into the Hudson River last night, the police said.

title: HENDERSON SPARKING CELTICS
description: The Boston Celtics, who had dispatched the Milwaukee Bucks so easily in the first two games of their Eastern Conference final series, were struggling early in Game 3 Saturday afternoon and trailed by 13 points at halftime.

title: Arab Leader Criticizes 2 Democratic Candidates
description: Robert D. Joseph, chairman of the National Association of Arab Americans, contends that both Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart are captives of Israeli interests.

title: A TRADITION OF SUCCESS STILL REMAINS
description: T HE Islanders were different. In the midst of their plenty, the memory of the lean early years always seemed to hang over them. That memory helped spur them to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships. The great dynasties of sports history - the Canadiens, the Yankees, the Celtics - were built on a foundation of success. Their championship seasons simply were logical progressions.

title: ROONEY ENDS TALK TO STOP TAPING
description: Andy Rooney, who does humorous commentaries for the CBS news program ''60 Minutes,'' walked off the stage during his speech to the Alaska Press Club because a televison crew refused to stop taping him.

title: REGISTRY OF MISSING CHILDREN FACES STATE INQUIRY
description: The chairman and a director of Child Find Inc. have resigned and staff members have been dismissed over problems at the prominent nonprofit organization, which collects fees to help locate missing children.

title: IN WASHINGTON, NEW YORK'S SENATORS AT ODDS
description: A state of formal detente between New York's Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, has apparently done little to mask continuing tensions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DANCE

title: Change at Lush Life
description: Ernestine Anderson, who was scheduled to appear at Lush Life starting tomorrow, has canceled the engagement. She will be replaced tomorrow through Sunday by Jon Hendricks performing without the usual accompaniment of his Family but backed by Eddie Chamblee's group.

title: The U.N. Today May 21, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: CITIES URGED TO TRIM TRANSIT FUND REQUESTS
description: The Reagan Administration has told cities to trim their requests for Federal assistance in building public transit systems, saying the $19 billion they want is not there.

title: PHILLIES WIN 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Len Matuszek and Juan Samuel hit home runs during a five-run second inning today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to their ninth straight victory, a 7-4 decision over the San Francisco Giants.

title: SENIOR-YEAR DECISIONS BRING OUT THE ADULT IN THE STUDENT
description: Even the quick mothers sometimes get fooled senior year.

title: ERRORS ON EYE SURGERY
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch Saturday on the Reagan Administration's determination to limit the war between Iraq and Iran contained an incorrect description of the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk. It is conventionally powered.

title: A BREATHER FOR RATE WORRIERS
description: When Federal Reserve officials meet today and tomorrow to chart a course for monetary policy, it is widely expected that the problems of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company will inhibit any further moves toward a tighter monetary policy and higher interest rates.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage firm, has elected to its board Kenneth Black Jr., dean of the college of business administration at Georgia State University.

title: UPSTATE, $1 MILLION IN HEREFORDS SOLDS
description: Inside the auction shed at the Overlook Farm, nervous cows, with their calves at their side, were paraded before a packed audience. As each animal entered, the auctioneer broke into a frenzied patter. Though his words blurred together, the numbers - starting in the hundreds and working toward the tens of thousands - were unmistakable.

title: PREAKNESS UPSET PAVES WAY FOR BIG BELMONT
description: The two trainers had not had a chance to talk after the race. Jack Van Berg had been tied up with ceremonies and celebrations after Gate Dancer won the 109th Preakness Stakes here Saturday. Woody Stephens had not wanted to talk to anyone after Swale finished a dull seventh as the 4-to-5 favorite. Finally, at 9 A.M. today, when all the other trainers were gone, Van Berg walked down to Stephens's end of the Preakness barn.

title: The Democrats: A Delegate Update
description: Virginia, Indiana and Tennessee

title: Ionesco Made an Officer
description: Thirty-four years after his play ''The Bald Soprano'' was nearly hissed off the stage by a Paris audience, Eugene Ionesco has been made an officer of the French Legion of Honor.

title: AN IMAGE PROBLEM FOR DETROIT
description: To some people, the decision of General Motors and Ford, the two largest automobile makers, to pay record bonuses to their executives while enjoying protection from Japanese competition is a symbol of management high-handedness that may cause political problems for all of corporate America. The auto bonuses, in the two weeks since they were disclosed, have stirred a storm of protests that Detroit seems to be feathering its own nest.

title: MONDALE AND HART FACE TIGHT VOTE IN CALIFORNIA
description: Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart appear to be running virtually even as they prepare for the last two weeks of California's Democratic primary election campaign.

title: No Headline
description: A.T.&T. Files Rate-Cut Plan

title: Miami's Transit System Draws Throngs at Debut
description: Thousands turned out today for free rides on new Metrorail trains on the first day of service for Miami's $1.1 billion rapid transit system.

title: Syracuse Reaches Final in Lacrosse
description: Tim Nelson, a junior attack man, had four goals and two assists today to lead Syracuse to an 11-9 victory over Army in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse tournament.

title: IN HOMETOWN, GUY LOMBARDO WON'T BE FORGOT
description: It had been a day of warm breezes and spring blossoms. But Saturday night at Wonderland Gardens, where thousands of colored lights twinkled and three shimmering silver balls hung from the ceiling, it was New Year's Eve.

title: Threat on a Computer Baffles Albany Airport
description: Federal and local authorities were trying to find out today who put a message on a computer terminal at Albany County Airport warning that armed individuals would be boarding a plane, according to an F.B.I. spokesman.

title: IT WAS U.S.A. WEEKEND AT CANNES FILM FESTIVAL
description: J. DIONNE Jr.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We condemn as indefensible threats of terrorism and reprisals directed against blacks or Jews, whether emanating from the Jewish Defense League or the Nation of Islam.'' - the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. (A1:1.)

title: Monday
description: The week shapes up as unusually busy.

title: WHEN ZHAO SAID COME, 20 HEARTS FLUTTERED
description: When Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China paid a state visit here in January, he canceled his formal farewell ceremony on the Washington Monument grounds in order to visit Sidwell Friends, a private school where a class of students had been studying Chinese for several months.

title: MISS BUNKOWSKY
description: GORDON S. WHITE Jr.

title: SOVIET SAID TO ADD NEW SUBS OFF U.S.
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that the Soviet Union had increased the number of missile-carrying submarines off United States coasts and that the missiles were within 10 minutes of American targets.

title: ANOTHER ANDRETTI SPORTING LOOKS OF A WINNER
description: INDIANAPOLIS THEY pushed his car out into position for a run. He yanked the fire-retardant sock over his head, tugged on the helmet. Faces behind the pit wall inched closer for a better glimpse. He was small, tan and he looked strong. He squirmed into the shovel-nosed racer. The removable steering wheel was attached last, the fit was that tight. The engine sprang to life with a piercing whine, and he thundered out onto the track.

title: Villanova Wins IC4A Meet
description: Villanova's speed and endurance overcame Maryland's strength as the Wildcats won the 108th annual Outdoor IC4A Track and Field Championships today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Early last month, Representative Jim Courter, House chairman of the Military Reform Caucus, made public a report called ''Lessons Learned in Grenada,'' which explored the military efficiency of the 1983 American-led invasion, not always favorably. The New Jersey Republican said he felt that hearings of the House Armed Services Committee, of which he is a member, had been inadequate and that the public was entitled to know more about the invasion, which he had supported in principle if not entirely in execution.

title: Milk and Bread Prices Are Raised in Portugal
description: The Government increased prices for bread and milk today by 18 to 20 percent as part of an austerity campaign intended to reduce public deficits.

title: E.P.A. BATTLE ON HAZARDOUS WASTE IS IN FULL SWING
description: To the Editor:

title: TIGERS WIN NO. 32, BEATING A'S BY 4-3
description: Dwight Lowry cracked his first major league homer to help Detroit beat the Oakland A's, 4-3, today as the Tigers improved their record to 32-5 behind the combined four-hit pitching of Milt Wilcox and Willie Hernandez.

title: Miss Karpatkin, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Deborah Hendrick Karpatkin, staff counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, and Ian Joseph Benjamin, an accounting supervisor with Deloitte Haskins & Sells in New York, were married yesterday at the Manhattan home of the bride's mother, Rhoda Karpatkin. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony.

title: A PROFOUND CONTEMPT
description: A fundamental change is taking place in America, and the world sees it. The most legal- minded of societies, as it has been by instinct and tradition, now has a Government that feels and displays a profound contempt for law.

title: WHERE'S THE PRIME?
description: Tarzan of the Apes swings into his treehouse, frantically quaffs a double martini handed him by his mate, and says with a shudder: ''It's a jungle out there!''

title: Presenting the Latest In Design for Podiums
description: The Republicans have staked a claim to the lead in political fashion: They have broken the tyranny of blue in podium decoration for national conventions.

title: Penn's Hat Must Bow, It Appears
description: Tradition here is fighting what now appears to be a losing battle with economics. as a result, two tall buildings seem destined to cast shadows where none have ever fallen, on William Penn's hat.

title: J. David Aides Cleared
description: Felony counts against Calman Hart and his wife, Debra Hart, former employees of the bankrupt J. David & Company currency concern, were dropped at a preliminary hearing Friday. The Harts were charged with bankruptcy fraud and conspiracy.

title: Ellen M. Rosenthal Weds in Princeton
description: Ellen Marcy Rosenthal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray W. Rosenthal of East Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Theodore W. Logan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Logan of Scarborough, Me. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS FORGIVING SOME OF COLLEGES' LOANS
description: The Education Department says it can save $5 billion over the next 20 years by forgiving portions of long-term, low-interest campus construction loans made to colleges and universities.

title: Tracy Winthrop Young Weds Peter Allen Levitan
description: The marriage of Tracy Winthrop Young, an assistant district attorney in the appeals bureau of the Kings County District Attorney's office, to Peter Allen Levitan, who graduated Tuesday from Columbia Law School, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. Rabbi Morrison Bial performed the ceremony.

title: 'INDIANA JONES' STIRS RATINGS DEBATE
description: Steven Spielberg's ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' will open in 1,685 movie theaters across the country on Wednesday with voices already wondering if the long-awaited sequel to the phenomenally successful ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' is too violent for its PG (Parental Guidance Suggested) rating.

title: LAUDA, IN MCLAREN, WINS 2D OF SEASON
description: Austria's Niki Lauda, in a McLaren- TAG Porsche, gained a hard-fought victory over the Renault of France's Patrick Tambay in the French Grand Prix auto race today.

title: Linda Sharon Wiesenfeld Weds Dr. Richard Snyder
description: Linda Sharon Wiesenfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Wiesenfeld of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Joel Snyder, a son of Judge and Mrs. Arthur I. Snyder of North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: A CONCERT FOR Sakharov
description: The pianist Dmitri Shostakovich, grandson of the late Russian composer for whom he is named, was suffering yesterday from an onslaught of hay fever that might well have led him to skip a rehearsal on a less important occasion. But he was on hand at the Wellington Hotel yesterday morning, red-eyed and sniffling, as the Soviet Emigre Orchestra rehearsed its ''Concert for Andrei Sakharov and Peace'' amid mounting concern for the dissident Soviet physicist, who began a hunger strike on May 2.

title: DANCE: THE CLASS OF '84
description: THE School of Performing Arts presented its Performing Arts Dancers of the class of 1984 on Saturday afternoon at Norman Thomas High School. It was a heartening concert that demonstrated that the School of Performing Arts dance department, directed by Lydia Joel, offers solid training.

title: Japanese Fight New Runway
description: TOKYO, May 20 (AP) More than 3,000 farmers, students and union members rallied today near the New Tokyo International Airport to protest plans to build a second runway, the poice reported. No confrontations were reported between the demonstrators and 7,000 policemen.

title: Mass for Mabel Mercer
description: A mass for the singer Mabel Mercer, who died on April 20, will be offered at St. Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th Street, at 5:30 P.M. Wednesday. Among those who will take part in the service are the singers Sylvia Syms, Thelma Carpenter and Bobby Short and the jazz festival producer George Wein.

title: Nominee for Interior Dept.
description: President Reagan plans to promote Robert N. Broadbent, the Interior Department's Reclamation Commissioner, to Assistant Secretary for Water and Science, the White House said Friday. The nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: ; On the Dark Side of Too Much Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Brandt Is Elected Head Of German Party Again
description: Willy Brandt, who was the West German Chancellor from 1969 to 1974, was re-elected chairman of the opposition Social Democratic Party today by a vote of 391 to 19 at a party congress here. Mr. Brandt, 70 years old, has led the party for 20 years.

title: THE HIGH-STAKES SCRAMBLE TO RESCUE CONTINENTAL BANK
description: At 4 A.M. last Thursday William M. Isaac was roused from his New York hotel bed by a telephone call. After a roller-coaster week of desperate rescue efforts, the fate of the Continental Illinois bank was still hanging in the balance. The lawyers were at loggerheads.

title: YANKS LOSE, 3-0; SHUTOUTS IS 10TH
description: If the Yankees seek consolation for their incredible penchant for suffering shutouts, they should know that Ron Romanick played last season for a minor-league team that was shut out an average of once every eight games, and that Gary Pettis said he was certain they would ''get going and start swinging the bat sooner or later.''

title: LONGER, HEALTHIER LIVES SEEN
description: Wearing cap and gown, an unidentified graduating senior arrived by parachute for today's commencement ceremonies at the University of Connecticut here.

title: 2 Freed Soviet Soldiers To Stay in Switzerland
description: Two Soviet soldiers who were captured by guerrillas in Afghanistan were freed after two years of internment in Switzerland today, but they decided not to return to the Soviet Union, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said.

title: President Is Named Chief of Southdown
description: Laurence E. Hirsch, president and chief operating officer of Southdown Inc., has been named chief executive officer of the Houston-based cement, sugar and energy producer. Donald E. Peiser, who had been chief executive, will remain as chairman.

title: U.S., SOVIET AGREE ON EXCHANGE PLAN
description: Leaders of the United States and Soviet Olympic Committees have agreed in principle to an exchange program of athletes, coaches and sports-medicine personnel, an American official said today. However, this would have no effect on the Soviet decision not to participate in the Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: SJN
description: The marriage of Simi Jaye Neger and James Gerard Matera took place yesterday in Westport, Conn., at the home of the bride's stepfather and home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Stahl, also of New York. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth A. Epstein Marries R. L. Kadin
description: Elizabeth Anne Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Richard Epstein of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Lewis Kadin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kadin of White Plains. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye.

title: Lakers Defeat Suns
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 31 points and Bob McAdoo added 23 today as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Phoenix Suns, 126-115, and took a 3-1 lead in their Western Conference playoff series.

title: MUSIC: ELGAR PERFORMED BY TORONTO ORCHESTRA
description: EDWARD ELGAR'S ''Kingdom'' is a wonderful work, and we owe the Toronto Symphony an automatic debt of gratitude for offering a rare New York performance at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. That said, it is a pity that this last of the composer's three great oratorios was not awarded the monumental presentation it deserved. Saturday's performance, under the direction of Andrew Davis, while not without its merits, left quite a bit to be desired.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.36

title: U.S. AIDE DISCLOSES RADIO LEAKS TIPPED HANOI TO AIR ACTION
description: The United States Air Force declined to change tactics for fighter-bomber strikes against North Vietnam even after learning that radio leaks were giving Hanoi advance warning of the missions, a senior intelligence official has written in the communications journal Signal.

title: PAST-30 GROUP OF UNMARRIEDS FOUND IN BIG RISE BY CENSUS
description: A rising number of people in their early 30's are remaining single, suggesting an increasing proportion of the population will never marry, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Cuts Approved In Citro"en Jobs
description: The Government approved a cut of 4,000 jobs at Citro"en and urged workers to end a strike that has idled the financially troubled car maker for more than a week, but did not give the go-ahead for layoffs. The job cuts approved Friday are primarily voluntary departures through early retirement. Citro"en also has offered incentives to immigrant workers to return to their native countries.

title: Market Place; Dow Dropped 23.35 in Week
description: THE specter of rising interest rates and concern over the possible failure of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, the nation's eighth-largest bank, undermined the already fragile confidence of investors last week. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 23.35 points, to 1,133.79, as part of a broad market retreat.

title: Meg Michaelson Weds Dr. Richard E. Boehme
description: Meg Michaelson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Michaelson of New York and Hope, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Edward Boehme, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Boehme of West Paterson, N.J. Judge David Jubanowski of the Municipal Court of Sussex County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Michaelson home in Hope.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: A PROHIBITIVE GAP IN THE MINIMUM WAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Confrontation With a Scofflaw
description: Three people in civilian clothes

title: GOLDWATER DENIES HE REBUKED HELMS
description: Sen. Barry Goldwater, the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, has denied that he rebuked Sen. Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, for issuing classified information without authorization.

title: MOSCOW HINTS SAKHAROV'S WIFE FACES ARREST FOR ANTI-SOVIET ACTS
description: The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that Andrei D. Sakharov's wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had ''gone too far in her anti-Soviet activities'' and that law enforcement agencies were taking measures against her.

title: PENN'S HAT MUST BOW, IT APPEARS
description: Tradition here is fighting what now appears to be a losing battle with economics. As a result, two tall buildings seem destined to cast shadows where none have ever fallen, on William Penn's hat.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: * Chicago & North Western Transportation Co. plans to file an offering of $50 million of consolidated series B mortgage bonds.

title: Papell Triumphs
description: Ben Papell of Sands Point, L.I., seeded fifth, upset second-seeded Randy Vigmostad of Greenlawn, L.I., 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the Miller DePhillips Eastern Hardcourt tennis championships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. Papell, who is 17 years old, had moved into the final by eliminating top-seeded Mark Freedman of New York on Saturday.

title: Salvador's Leadership Rebuked Over Killings
description: Amnesty International today accused the Salvadoran Government of failing to take steps to end widespread killings of civilians by security forces.

title: RAILROAD TO START DRUG ABUSE FIGHT
description: The nation's third largest railroad system is to initiate a joint union-management program next month to fight drug and alcohol abuse by employees.

title: FRENCH ARE SAID TO GIVE A D-DAY REBUFF TO WEST GERMANY'S LEADER
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany sought, through intermediaries, to receive an invitation to the D-day commerorative ceremonies that will bring allied chiefs of state to France on June 6, French and American officials reported last week. But they said the initiative was turned aside and the West German leader would not take part.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Wall of Fame It is known as the ''Yaz Wall,'' and it is filled with memorabilia of Carl Yastrzemski's career with the Boston Red Sox.

title: CITY BALLET: CHANGES IN CAST
description: WEEKEND programs by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater included several cast changes, as well as performances of ballets that revealed some of the many ways in which George Balanchine used choreographic energy.

title: MATH BOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company went public in January 1984.

title: DANCE: DAVID GORDON
description: A NEW work by David Gordon is always of interest. But in ''Framework,'' a new full- evening piece that is being performed at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater through May 27, Mr. Gordon has the work of a career.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ohlmeyer Account

title: G.M. Will Retool Westchester Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation's troubled North Tarrytown assembly plant, which has been operating at half capacity for 20 months, will be retooled before the end of the year to manufacture a different model of car, the company said yesterday. Workers at the plant, who had feared it might soon be closed, regarded the decision as good news.

title: Kearny, N.J., Plant Is Sold
description: A.T.& T. Technologies Inc. today announced the sale of the Western Electric Company plant here to the Union Minerals and Alloys Corporation for use as an industrial park designed to employ more than 4,000 people.

title: CAPITOL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GULF WAR: IRAN HAS FEW JETS FIT TO FIGHT
description: United States and allied intelligence experts say Iran has been attacking Persian Gulf shipping with American- built F-4's but appears unlikely to be able to step up such operations because of a shortage of military resources. They note that Saudi Arabia is militarily much stronger than Iran but say the Saudis are unlikely, for political reasons, to use their air power against Iran.

title: SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN EFFECTS TRANSITION
description: The guard has begun to change at Scientific American Inc., the privately held magazine and book publishing company.

title: Repairs on Molitor
description: The injured right elbow that has prematurely ended the season for Paul Molitor , the Milwaukee Brewers' regular third baseman, was repaired yesterday by Dr. Frank Jobe, the sports physician. During a two-hour operation in Los Angeles, Dr. Jobe found that a ligament and a muscle had been partly torn away from the bone. He reattached the muscle and, as part of the reconstruction process, removed a tendon from the left forearm to replace the ligament. . . . The Seattle Mariners, saying they want to explore other options, have put off the scheduled June 1 rotator-cuff surgery on the right shoulder of Gorman Thomas , the veteran slugger. . . . The Red Sox second baseman Jerry Remy , who is hitting .250, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to May 19 because of an injury to his left knee.

title: 2 Moslem Sects Clash At Mosque in Pakistan
description: Thousands of Moslems from rival sects clashed at a mosque in Lahore today, and at least 35 were injured, 6 of them seriously, witnesses reported.

title: MANHATTAN MEETING IS THE TALK OF SCIENCE
description: FOR sheer intellectual esoterica, nothing can top the limited engagement hit that is opening in Manhattan this week. Billed as the Town Hall of Science, this production will bring together 5,000 scientists and science buffs from around the country for a sometimes rowdy run of discussions, arguments and occasional protests involving hundreds of subjects ranging in importance from atomic weapons to U.F.O.'s.

title: KILLER ASSERTS WITNESS LIED ON MARGOLIES
description: The convicted killer of a diamond company employee and three CBS workers who came to her aid told the defense yesterday in the murder trial of the man accused of hiring him, Irwin Margolies, that the state's key witness had perjured himself.

title: Murphy Honored In Connecticut
description: Calvin Murphy retired last year after a 13-year professional basketball career during which he averaged 17.9 points a game and set National Basketball Association records for consecutive free throws made, 78, and for the highest free throw percentage in a single season, .958 in 1980-81.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TALKS RESUME ON RESCUING SEABROOK ATOM UNITS
description: Officials of the Rural Electrification Administration and representatives of New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear power plant today resumed negotiations in Washington on a White House-backed rescue plan intended to allow completion of the financially troubled project.

title: Chess: 2 Qualities of a Good Player Are Patience and Vigilance
description: Those who don't play chess complain that it demands too much patience, while followers of the game complain that it demands too much vigilance. The truth is that both are required.

title: BIBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $460,000 from the sale of a plant and a gain of $1.4 million from the liquidation of LIFO inventory quantities. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $750,000, or 45 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary yesterday of Dr. Joseph Thomas Klapper, a researcher into the effects of television on behavior, gave an incorrect site for the funeral service. It will be held at 11:45 A.M. today at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SALVADORAN LEADER'S ADDRESS

description: After the Boston Celtics had taken a commanding 3-0 lead over the Milwaukee Bucks in this Eastern Conference final by overcoming a 15-point deficit to win Game 3, the Bucks' reserve center Paul Mokeski said: ''It was like they had a button, and they could push it whenever they wanted.''

description: The Election Commission opened hearings today on candidates' allegations of fraud in parliamentary elections held May 14. It had 53 formal complaints before it.

description: The Rev. John Baiz, rector of the Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh and a co-founder of the Pittsburgh Pastoral Institute, died of cancer Saturday at the church's rectory. He was 66 years old.

title: NEW YORK ; THE CRIME OF POVERTY
description: There's nothing like a political campaign to get vote-seekers talking about crime. Tough talk gets headlines, if not results. It's also useful if you can orate away any connection between criminals and ''ordinary people.'' That way, when you verbally beat up on criminals, you don't appear to be beating up on anyone else, such as the poor or hungry or unemployed.

title: Reagan's Conference To Be Broadcast Live
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast. Channel 13 in New York City, for example, will broadcast the conference at 11 P.M.

title: PISANI, ON STAND, DENIES CHARGES OF EMBEZZLING AND TAX EVASION
description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani testified yesterday in his trial in Manhattan, denying Federal charges that he had embezzled more than $80,000 and evaded taxes on the money.

description: MOTION sickness, whether on the sea, in the air or on the highway, seems to result from the brain's response to excessive variety of accelerations as registered by the balance apparatus inside the ear. Space sickness is thought to come from a discordance of signals the brain gets from the body in the novel conditions of weightlessness.

description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, home from a West Coast trip on which they were 4-4, are hosts to a disappointing San Francisco team that is off to a 14-25 start.

description: A statewide grand jury was called today to begin an investigation of what a prosecutor calls ''astounding'' corruption in the government of the city of Providence.

description: Six Irish groups opposed to President Reagan's policies on nuclear weapons and Central America said today that they planned to protest his four-day visit to Ireland starting June 1.

description: The Generals won their game against the Pittsburgh Maulers tonight, 16-14, but won no accolades for their play.

description: The Senate began another effort today to adopt legislation creating a new system of bankruptcy courts.

description: Sam Shepard's ''Fool for Love'' has won the Obie Award for best new American play of the 1983-1984 theater season and ''Gospel at Colonus,'' by Lee Breuer and Bob Telson, won as best musical. The 29th annual Obie Awards for outstanding achievement Off and Off Off Broadway were presented last night at the Cat Club.

title: HANSEN OF IDAHO CONFIDENT OF VOTE
description: Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, who won re-election eight years ago by a narrow margin after pleading guilty in a campaign fund case, says voters in his rural district will send him to Congress again despite a recent conviction for violating a Federal ethics act.

The second half of the exhibition, ''Kosode: 16th-19th Century Textiles from the Nomura Collection,'' which is a striking display of these beautiful robes, today starts the second half of its stay through June 17 at Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street (752-0824).

title: TOO FEW INSIGHTS ON HOCKEY
description: Among the many subjects about which the viewer admits profound ignorance, hockey ranks very high. On Saturday night, he decided to tune in anyway to the fifth game of the Stanley Cup final, between the Islanders and the Edmonton Oilers, on WOR-TV. This was the first hockey game he had seen on television this year, the first hockey game he had seen on television in many years.

title: U.S.-SOVIET IMPASSE
description: Reagan Administration experts say they believe that recent Soviet actions are aimed at more than making things difficult for President Reagan in a Presidential election year and may reflect a basic hardening of policy. ''What they have been doing for many months now,'' an Administration analyst said, ''does not indicate simply an effort to defeat Reagan in November, although they would like to do that. It is a more serious effort to soften up or moderate second-term Reagan policies or the policies of his successor.''

title: The No-Win Goal in the Gulf
description: In Henry Kissinger's apt phrase, the ultimate American interest in the war between Iran and Iraq is that both should lose. The underlying hope is that mutual exhaustion might rid the Middle East of the aggressive regimes of both Ayatollah Khomeini and Saddam Hussein, yet leave their nations intact to avoid a superpower rush into any vacuum.

title: Some Debts Paid By Air Florida
description: Air Florida System Inc. said that it had paid its past-due obligations to the Internal Revenue Service and that the I.R.S. had released its liens on company assets. Air Florida said it had sold four Boeing 737 aircraft to the Gap Group Ltd. for $47 million, and used proceeds to repay about $8.9 million to the I.R.S., $6 million to the General Electric Company's G.E. Credit Corporation unit, and ''a substantial portion'' of its obligations to the Federal Aviation Administration.

description: The Sun Refining and Marketing Company said it had agreed to sell most of its Sunoco retail marketing holdings in Virginia to the Southland Corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
