title: SHAMIR DENOUNCES JEWISH TERRORISM
description: In Parliament, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today denounced the Jewish settlers who are said to have confessed to acts of terrorism against West Bank Arabs.

title: Protecting the System, Not Depositors
description: Bank deposits up to $100,000 are insured by a Federal agency. But what about the hundreds of billions in accounts that exceed the limit? Since the 1982 failure of Penn Square, a medium-sized bank in Oklahoma, Federal regulators have let big depositors take their losses. Now, in the case of Continental Illinois, they've made a very large exception, guaranteeing every depositor's every cent.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $37,447 for the latest first quarter and $23,364 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Addendum

title: REAGAN AFFIRMS U.S. WOULD GUARD SHIPPING IN GULF
description: President Reagan sent a message to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today, affirming support for Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries in any potential confrontation with Iran.

title: Black Judge to Get Klan Case
description: The first black Federal judge in Alabama has been assigned the civil rights case of nine Ku Klux Klansmen accused of disrupting a protest march in support of a black man the judge represented while he was a private lawyer.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $112,000. c-Including a tax credit of $223,000.

title: DIFFERENCES IN LIFE EXPECTANCY WIDENS BETWEEN THE SEXES
description: Americans of both sexes are living longer, but the gap between life expectancy of men and women is actually widening, a recent conference of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists was told.

title: SCIENTISTS EMERGE AS SOCIAL ACTIVISTS
description: THE public is increasingly aware of the advances of science, and increasingly anxious about their impact on society, according to William D. Carey, the chief executive officer of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: Democrats Discuss Issues for Platform
description: Democrats shaping a platform for the Presidential campaign accused President Reagan today of orchestrating a ''cosmetic recovery'' that has left millions jobless.

title: Sunday Novel Planned As Newspaper Insert
description: As if there were not enough to read in the Sunday newspapers, here comes Jack H. Gordun with The Sunday Novel, an insert that each month will contain a piece of pre-1970 fiction, as well as advertising.

title: Bankruptcy Is Not a Weapon
description: Can the bankruptcy law become a tool for breaking unions? That's what organized labor says will happen unless Congress amends the law to protect union contracts in what are called Chapter 11 reorganizations.

title: SUMMER GASOLINE OUTLOOK: SUPPLE UP, PRICE DOWN
description: The nation's gasoline supplies are rising, and as the summer driving season opens this weekend, oil analysts are saying that gasoline prices, bucking trends in other fuels, will be lower than last year and could even drop from current levels.

title: MICHIGAN OFFERING
description: A $50 million issue of Michigan State Trunk Line bonds was tentatively priced with yields ranging from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 10 percent in 1995 and 10 1/2 percent in 1999, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express. The bonds, rated A/AA-, are backed by motor vehicle fuel taxes, registration fees and related taxes. Proceeds will maintain highways.

title: WALTER READE ORGANIZATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-No year-ago revenue figure was given.

title: ITT's Spending
description: The ITT Corporation said it would spend $3.1 billion on research and engineering in Europe between 1984 and 1988. Of this, $2.6 billion would be used in electronics and telecommunications, notably to finance the development of ITT's System 12, the company's digital telephone exchange system. The company said it would spend an additional $1.7 billion on capital investments, including the introduction of advanced manufacturing technologies.

title: THE VALUE OF 'SPECIAL INTERESTS'
description: For more than five months now, Gary Hart has been accusing Walter F. Mondale of ''pandering'' to ''special interests.'' This is a misleading and ill-considered charge. In fact, I would argue that such ''pandering'' is good politics - exactly the kind of good politics that is indispensable to effective political leadership.

title: Penalty Waived
description: Missouri Valley Conference officials have waived the second year of a two- year penalty imposed on Wichita State University's football program for recruiting violations, the league announced today.

title: U.S. FAILS TO RECOVER MILLIONS IN WEST, WILDLIFE GROUP SAYS
description: The Government is losing millions of dollars a year by failing to recover Federal funds advanced for the construction of six major water and power projects in the West, according to a report issued today by the National Wildlife Federation.

title: 'THE ZANY ADVENTURES OF ROBIN HOOD' ON CBS
description: IF there isn't one already, there

title: League Folds
description: The Central Hockey League's Board of Governors has voted to suspend operations for the 1984-85 season, Commissioner Bud Poile said today.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Charlotte Curtis; A DANCE AT THE MET
description: MRS. GORDON P. GETTY was in New York twice last week. She came in from San Francisco first for the Metropolitan Opera's centennial celebration, presiding as the vice chairman over a front box filled with big names. The program was so long, a sympathetic friend sent out for sandwiches to hold her famished guests until the postmidnight supper.

title: Bradshaw Scores
description: Last year he was hobbled by arm and elbow injuries and played in only one game, prompting speculation that he had played his last National Football League game. But Terry Bradshaw had other plans, and the Pittsburgh Steelers' veteran quarterback proved it recently by recording the highest score ever on the Steelers' physical stress exam.

title: LIVERPOOL'S SOCCER DYNASTY ROLLS ON
description: Two years ago, Manchester United's manager, Ron Atkinson, said that the toughest task facing anyone who hoped to win the championship in British soccer's First Division would be beating Liverpool. He said it again last year, and once more last week.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLAYS DOWN SOVIET SUB THREAT
description: The White House said today that the Soviet Union's buildup of missile-carrying submarines off American coasts did not alter the balance of power.

title: U.S. AND MEXICO SEEK TRADE ABROAD
description: The United States and Mexico are making progress toward an agreement that would resolve important trade questions and let more Mexican products enter the United States.

title: DIRECTOR SACRIFICES FOR A VISION
description: While he has won awards as a theater director and for his work on the television series ''Hill Street Blues,'' Jeff Bleckner gained even greater visibility when he directed ''Concealed Enemies,'' the acclaimed dramatization of the Alger Hiss case that the Public Broadcasting Service televised earlier this month.

title: NEW PRESIDENT CHOSEN AT JOHN H. HARLAN CO.
description: Robert R. Woodson yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the John H. Harland Company, the Atlanta-based check printing company.

title: VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: A NEW spirit has come to jewelry

title: T G I F TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. BONDS LITTLE CHANGED
description: The Treasury bond market tried to improve yesterday, but after a morning rally, prices fell steadily during the afternoon to close little changed on the day.

title: LANDLORDS' COSTS FOUND TO RISE 6%
description: The cost of operating rent-stabilized apartment buildings in New York City rose by 6.1 percent last year, more than double the increase calculated for each of the two previous years, according to a study presented yesterday to the city's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: ANTITANK TESTING UNREALISTIC, SOME OFFICIALS SAY
description: On Dec. 15, 1982, a team of Defense Department officials and commercial engineers parked 15 obsolete, gasoline-powered tanks on a bulldozed, treeless New Mexico desert within a few thousand yards of a radar vehicle. They then fired a rocket at the array of tanks from a distance of about 50 miles.

title: ESPANOLA, N.M., EMBRACES ESPANOLA JOKES AND LAUGHS LAST
description: When Judy Vigil bought her son an almanac she was outraged to find that this city was not even included in the map of New Mexico.

title: BEATRICE IS SEEKING ESMARK
description: The Beatrice Foods Company, one of the biggest food producers in the country, will offer $2.5 billion in cash to buy Esmark Inc., James L. Dutt, chairman of Beatrice, said late yesterday.

title: GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 22
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a merger with Famous Restaurants Inc.

title: OSCAR BAKKE, FORMER OFFICIAL IN 2 AVIATION AGENCIES, DIES
description: Oscar Bakke, a former military pilot who held high positions in two aviation agencies during a 28-year civilian career in the Federal Government, died at his home in Mountain Lakes, N.J., Sunday after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Hearns-Duran Shifted
description: The expected change in site for the World Boxing Council's superwelterweight title bout between Thomas Hearns and Roberto Duran became official yesterday. Shelly Saltman, one of the promoters, said that the fight, to be held June 15, was being moved from the Bahamas to Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev. The fight will be held in a 26,000-seat parking- lot stadium that was to have housed the on-again, off-again Larry Holmes-Gerrie Coetzee heavyweight title bout.

title: MERRILL LYNCH OFFICIAL IN KEY SEABROOK ROLE
description: Robert Hildreth, managing director and vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, helped draft a plan last week to raise approximately $1 billion to complete the Seabrook 1 nuclear power project. His reasons for wanting to help rescue the beleaguered project go beyond dollars and cents, he says.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: HELEN OF TROY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $34,872.

title: Military Contracts
description: The McDonnell Aircraft Company, a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, received a $66.9 million Air Force contract for 11 F-15 aircraft for sale to Israel, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said that the United Technologies Corporation had received a $46.1 million contract from the Navy for 11 C/MH-53E helicopters, and that the AM General Corportion, a unit of the LTV Corporation, had received a $31.9 million contract for five-ton trucks.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 22, 1984 International
description: American support for Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries in any potential confrontation with Iran was affirmed by President Reagan in a message to King Fahd. In the letter, Mr. Reagan, apparently taking note of the stated desire of the Gulf countries to handle the problem by themselves, said the United States would be willing to help them if asked to do so. (Page A1, Column 6.) Jose Napoleon Duarte pledged he ''will never'' request that United States troops fight in El Salvador. At the same time, the Salvadoran President-elect appealed to Congress to approve more aid for his country now without attaching what he called degrading conditions. (A1:5.)

title: HAITIANS QUIETLY FIND BETTER LIFE IN THE CITY, DESPITE THEIR FEARS
description: In a one-bedroom apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Paulette lives with her two young children, a boyfriend and four other people.

title: JUSTICES ALLOW U.S. TO RECOUP OVERPAYMENT DESPITE MISTAKE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Government can recover an overpayment of Federal funds from a recipient who relied on mistaken Government advice that the payments were proper.

title: Korean Payments Gap
description: South Korea's deficit in international payments, as measured on the current-account basis, narrowed to $708 million in the first four months of 1984 from $1.19 billion a year earlier, the nation's central bank said today.

title: Agreement Expected In Las Vegas Walkout
description: An agreeement to settle with 10 hotels and one casino was in the final stages today as negotiators sought to end a 50-day strike that has cost the city and its workers tens of millions of dollars, according to officials.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of computer problems yesterday at The Associated Press, many financial tables published today were composed manually.

title: STRATEGIES DIFFER IN THE WAR ON DRUGS
description: From their desks on the 17th floor of a West Side skyscraper, the agents of a Federal drug task force have a majestic view of New York and New Jersey.

title: Justice Upholds Ban On Colby Fraternities
description: Fraternities and sororities were expelled from Colby College today, after a judge rejected a last-minute attempt to block a new housing policy adopted by trustees of the private liberal-arts school.

title: DUARTE DECLARES HE'LL NEVER CALL FOR U.S. TROOPS
description: President-elect Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he ''will never'' ask American troops to fight in his country.

title: 4 Cosmos Facing Pay-Cut Deadline
description: Hubert Birkenmeier was asked by the Cosmos yesterday to take a 45 percent cut in his salary, while Angelo DiBernardo, Jeff Durgan and Steve Moyers were asked to take cuts of 20 percent each. All four were told they had until noon today to accept or be put on waivers, but DiBernardo said he had already decided to refuse. The three others indicated they were inclined to do the same.

title: LESS BUOYANT HOUSING VIEW
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, based in Houston, is one of the nation's largest home builders, with operations in 28 states. Its main product is the single-family attached or detached home for the first- time buyer.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Aluminum unit of the Martin Marietta Corporation said that it would cut smelting operations here to 50 percent of capacity, because of higher power rates and weakening metal prices. The cut, effective June 1, will result in the layoff of about 175 employees, the company said.

title: TREASURY DEADLINE PROMPTS DEBATE ON U.S. DEBT CEILING
description: Like a hardy spring perennial, the debt ceiling debate is back. Before Congress leaves on Friday for a 10-day recess for Memorial Day, the Treasury Department says the lawmakers must raise the ceilng on the national debt so that the Treasury can continue to borrow to finance the budget deficit and keep the Government operating.

title: MIDLAND DOHERTY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NASSAU G.O.P. TO STOP SUPPORT FOR DEMOCRATS
description: The Nassau County Republican organization announced yesterday that it would break a tradition and no longer endorse Democratic judges seeking re- election.

title: Return to Arms Parley Ruled Out by Gromyko
description: West German sources said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had rebuked the NATO allies for deploying new American nuclear missiles in Europe. He said Moscow would stay away from arms control talks until the missiles were removed.

title: Venerable Vegetables
description: Agriculture in the Middle West may have begun thousands of years earlier than previously thought, adding new insights into the transition of some North American Indian societies from hunting and gathering to cultivation, according to researchers at the University of Rochester, Northwestern University and the United States Geological Survey.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: WHAT READY FOR WAR MEANS, AND ARE WE OR NOT
description: On the last page of a long Defense Department report is posed this question: ''Are American military forces more or less capable now to successfully wage a conventional war with the Warsaw Pact over a prolonged period than in December 1980?''

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after extraordinary credits for tax credits and the forgiveness of debt of $56,591 for the quarter and $166,058 for the 9 months.

title: PRELATE ASSAILS SANDINISTAS AS CONFLICT SHARPENS
description: In the last four weeks, the conflict between Nicaraguan bishops and the Government has become more strident than at any time since pro-Sandinista demonstrators disrupted a mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II in Managua 14 months ago.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,600 for the quarter and $27,000 for the 6 months.

title: Czechs Said to Arrest A Minority Leader
description: The unofficial leader of Czechoslovakia's Hungarian minority has been arrested, dissident sources in Budapest said today.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

title: 4 Arabs in West Bank Given Life Sentences
description: An Israeli military tribunal in Nablus imposed life sentences today on four West Bank Arabs in the murder on July 7 of Aharon Gross, a Yeshiva student in Hebron.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HIGH COURT BACKS TRIAL DATA CURB
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that parties to a civil lawsuit, including news organizations, may be barred from disclosing information obtained from the other side before the trial.

title: COURT IS TOLD AQUINO WAS FATED TO DIE
description: A security officer testified today that despite tape recordings produced by television networks, he did not hear anyone shout ''Shoot him!'' last August just before the slaying of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the political opposition leader.

title: Stockbridge Voters Approve New Rockwell Art Museum
description: Residents of this western Massachusetts town where Norman Rockwell lived and painted for 25 years aproved a zoning change tonight allowing an estate to be converted into a $3.3 million park and gallery for a new museum devoted to his works.

title: Dropout Aid to Go To Early Grades
description: A new state appropriation of $22.5 million for programs to improve the high school dropout rate will be used not only in high schools but also in the earlier grades, Nathan Quinones, the Acting Schools Chancellor, said yesterday.

title: GRIEF AND WARINESS GRIP TOWN AT END OF THE ROAD
description: It was 10 A.M. and already Mac Burke, a trapper and fisherman, had had three beers at the Manley Roadhouse. A friend urged him to go easy, but, in tears, Mr. Burke said, ''We all grieve in our own way, we all grieve in our own way.''

title: Illinois Bank Fails
description: The office of the Comptroller of the Currency said it had declared the Washington National Bank of Chicago insolvent and appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver.

title: ABORTION DEBATE IS HELD A THREAT TO RIGHTS BILL
description: A debate over abortion is said by both legislators and lobbyists to be endangering passage in the Legislature of a proposed amendment to the State Constitution designed to guarantee equal rights for women.

title: Soviet and Poland in Economic Pact
description: The Soviet Union and Poland have signed a 15-year accord calling for greater economic independence from the West, but at the same time calling for broader trade with Western countries that will ''not try to use economic relations for political pressure.''

title: NEW WAY TO REACH MOTHERS
description: IF you think that a magazine dedicated to educating new mothers on

title: Whittaker Pact
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it expects to stop operating a Saudi Arabian health-care program when its contract expires May 31.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (AUSTIN) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no year-ago share earnings because the company went public in August 1983.

title: Trainer Retires
description: A 10-year man suddenly quit the Islanders yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
PAULSON CAPITAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings amounted to less than 1 cent a share after adjusting for a 10-for-1 stock split in August 1983. The company was formerly known as Paulson Trading Co., and later as Paulson Investment Co. Inc.

title: ADVANCED ENERGY CONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $198,898.

title: Brink's Defendant Put at Crime Scene
description: The attorney for Samuel Brown, the last defendant on trial for the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders, admitted today that his client had been at the scene but said Mr. Brown was innocent of the crimes.

title: OLYMPIC BOYCOTT RAISES DOUBT IN SEOUL ON '88
description: The Soviet refusal to participate in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer has raised concern among South Korean officials about possible effects on the 1988 Games to be held in Seoul.

title: PROFIT POTENTIAL OF NEW DRUGS
description: THE earnings of several major pharmaceutical companies promise to benefit over the

title: U-2 Spy Plane Crashes Near South Korean Base
description: A United States U-2 reconnaissance plane crashed today near the Osan Air Base, 30 miles south of Seoul, American military officials in South Korea said.

title: MASSACHUSETTS UNIT OF JAYCEES CHOOSES WOMAN AS ITS HEAD
description: When Jean B. Hudson joined the Jaycees in Massachusetts five years ago, she was told ''by the way'' that the national organization did not recognize women as full members.

title: AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADVERTISING
description: The Clio Season Begins Happily for Chiat/Day

title: NEW YORK UTILITY
description: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation filed three shelf registration statements for $100 million of first mortgage bonds, 1.8 million preferred shares and 4 million common shares. The underwriters may include Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Limited Ends Bid for Carter
description: The Limited Inc. today ended its tender offer for control of Carter Hawley Hale Stores, but officials said the company would carry on a court challenge to Carter Hawley's antitakeover tactics. Leslie H. Wexner, The Limited's chairman, said at the annual meeting that the company would withdraw its $35-a-share offer at 5 P.M. without buying any of the 3.1 million shares tendered, unless conditions were met.

title: COMPUTERS IN THE OFFICE CHANGE LABOR RELATIONS
description: Donna Rao, 26 years old, is one of 73 workers sitting in front of video display terminals in a medical- claims office of the Equitable Life Assurance Society here.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TO ALLOW A MOTHER TO RETURN TO SCHOOL
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN'S PANEL USING ECONOMY TO BACK REAGAN
description: What is good for the economy is good for women is the message that will be carried across the country by the National Women's Coalition, a group of some 70 business and professional women assembled by the Republican National Committee to persuade women to vote for President Reagan.

title: New Seiko Color TV Is Flat, Pocket-Sized
description: The Hattori Seiko Company introduced a flat pocket-sized color television set today, apparently the world's first.

title: MRS. GEORGE REEDY
description: Lillian Greenwald Reedy, wife of the former Presidential press secretary George Reedy, died of cancer Sunday.

title: THE DANCE: 'AMNON' AND 2 BY BALANCHINE
description: MARTINE VAN HAMEL'S ''Amnon V'Tamar'' zips along with surprising lightness and quickness, considering that incest, a difficult marriage and memories of a homosexual affair are its subject matter. The pain is blessedly painless in this abstracted drama. But new cast members did make it all believable when American Ballet Theater presented the new ballet on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Troop Exercise in Honduras
description: One thousand United States Army and Air Force troops will join about 1,800 Hondurans and 1,300 Salvadoran soldiers Wednesday in a monthlong series of counterinsurgency exercises in Honduras, the Defense Department said today. The Pentagon said, ''The U.S. decision to participate in Granadero I reflects U.S. resolve to reassure Central American nations of our continuing support and cooperation.''

title: KANSAS TURNPIKE DUAL BOND ISSUE
description: A financing by the Kansas Turnpike Authority consisting of $100 million of revenue bonds backed by road tolls and about $32 million of special obligation bonds backed by United States Treasury securities is offered through underwriters led by Stern Brothers & Company, a Kansas City, Mo., firm.

title: Warning Given On Brazil Debt
description: Brazil will ruin itself if it continues to pay half its export earnings to service its $93 billion foreign debt, Vice President Aureliano Chaves said in an interview published today. ''Brazil runs the risk of self-destruction if it is forced to allocate, for a long time, half of the receipts from its exports to pay interest on foreign debt,'' Mr. Chaves was quoted as telling the daily newspaper Correio Braziliense.

title: TRADE ISSUE: JAPAN ISN'T THE CULPRIT
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Richardson Is SeenAs Senate Race Leader
description: Elliot L. Richardson has opened up a substantial lead over two opponents in the race for the Republican Senate nomination in Massachusetts, according to a poll published Sunday by The Boston Globe.

title: CITY ASKED TO KEEP ITS KINDERGARTENS OPEN UNTIL 6 P.M.
description: The head of the New York City Youth Bureau yesterday proposed an after- school program that would extend all- day kindergarten to 6 o'clock at night. His plan won immediate approval from the chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee.

title: 2 New Oral Diabetes Drugs Approved
description: After years of debate and delay, two drugs for adult diabetics that have been sold in Europe for many years are becoming available in the United States.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER CELEBRATES A NEW LOOK
description: Rockefeller Center was filled with Rockefellers last night. They gathered as if in reunion to celebrate the opening of a $22.5 million complex of four new restaurants built around the sunken ice rink-promenade of Rockefeller Plaza.

title: TROOPS PATROL RIOT-TORN BOMBAY AFTER 114 DIE IN RELIGIOUS STRIFE
description: The army moved in today to patrol riot-ravaged parts of this port city, India's richest and most important commercial and industrial center.

title: John Moran, 54; Led Building Concern
description: John Peter Moran, the president of Lewis C. Bowers & Sons Inc., a Princeton, N.J., construction company, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Princeton. He was 54 years old.

title: Advertising; European Deals Near For D.D.B.
description: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INTERNATIONAL is close to acquiring ad agencies in Lisbon; Milan, Italy, and Auckland, New Zealand, Barry E. Loughrane, its new president and chief executive, told the company's annual meeting yesterday.

title: DOCUMENTARIES ON POLKA AND BLUEGRASS
description: ONE of the many happy participants in Les Blank's ''In Heaven There Is No Beer?'' observes, at the end of the film, that he would prefer polka music to remain well outside the mainstream of American popular culture. That way, the music and its enthusiasts could retain the joyful, un-self-conscious vitality that is captured so beautifully here.

title: TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2 ALBANY PANELS PASS A BILL TO RAISE DRINKING AGE TO 21
description: Legislation that would raise the state's legal drinking age from 19 to 21 was approved by two key committees today, clearing the way for a vote in the Legislature as early as next week.

title: SCREEN: 'INDIANA JONES,' DIRECTED BY SPIELBERG
description: IF you've ever been a child or,

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss after a provision of $15.3 million for past due casino receivables primarily from foreign players. c-Net loss after a net loss of $1.9 million from discontinued operations.

title: Ex-StateAideGets Suspended Term
description: Former Agriculture Commissioner H. Earl Waterman Jr. was given a suspended five-year prison sentence and fined $10,000 today for defrauding the town of Suffield.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES NORTHEST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 100 percent common stock dividend declared in May 1983.

title: COMPACT OUTDOOR GRILL
description: SUMMER and barbecuing are synonymous for many a cook, or at least for those fortunate enough to have a place to set up a grill. Many urban dwellers must resort to movable feasts for summer barbecues - at the beach, a campground or a weekend retreat. Lugging a grill and a bag of charcoal with the food can be cumbersome. An alternative is the compact gas-fired grill pictured here, which is made by Nordic Ware of Minneapolis.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Herbs on Window Ledges

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 21
TWO MEN BEAT FATHER-IN-LAW OF THE GOVERNOR
description: Governor Cuomo's father-in-law was severely beaten yesterday by two men during an apparent robbery attempt in a vacant supermarket he owns in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: RANGE OF FLAVORS, RANGE OF PRICES
description: THE term ''American caviar'' is generally understood to mean the eggs of sturgeon from American waters as well as eggs from other domestic fish such as whitefish, salmon and lumpfish. Strictly speaking, however, only the eggs of sturgeon can carry the designation.

title: The U.N. Today; May 23, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Finance Reports Show Hart Led Rival in April
description: The amount of money raised by Gary Hart slumped from $3 million in March to less than $1.5 million last month, but the Colorado Senator still managed to raise and spend more money in April than Walter F. Mondale in their battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Ex-Providence Mayor To Run for Job He Lost
description: Saying he wants to prove to his daughter he is not a quitter, the ousted Mayor of Providence, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., added his name today to the list of more than a score of people running for Mayor.

title: Plane Demolished, Pilot Walks Away
description: A Rockland County pilot walked away with only minor injuries to one hand today when his plane crashed and was destroyed at Ramapo Valley Airport, officials said.

title: RUCKELSHAUS IS OPPOSED TO ENVIRONMENTAL POLITICS
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, urged today that the environment not be made a political issue in the national election.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PHILS TRIUMPH, 3-1, FOR 10TH IN A ROW
description: Ozzie Virgil collected two singles, scored a run and batted in one as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1, tonight and extended their winning streak to 10 games, the longest in the majors this season.

title: MAJOR AIR CRASH SUIT SETTLED
description: An out- of-court settlement of $375,000 today averted a trial that would have asked a jury to determine how much agony the victims of the nation's worst air disaster suffered in the final minute of their lives.

title: SOUTHWEST REALTY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCHOOL GIVES GOVERNOR A CELEBRITY'S WELCOME
description: When Grace M. Rosa, the principal of Christopher Columbus High School in the Bronx, told her students last week that an important man would be visiting the school, a lot of them naturally assumed the mystery guest would be Frank Sinatra.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Hart Wins Primary in Idaho
description: Senator Gary Hart today won Idaho's nonbinding Democratic Presidential primary over Walter F. Mondale.

title: PANEL SAID TO FIND CASEY GOT CARTER PAPERS
description: A Congressional report identifies William J. Casey, manager of President Reagan's 1980 campaign, as the man who obtained briefing papers prepared for President Carter, Congressional sources said today.

title: Careers; New Stress On Liberal Arts Study
description: IN seminars all over the country

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: ;  New Crain Publications
description: Crain Communicatons, a trade publisher best known for its Advertising Age, announced yesterday that it plans weekly city business newspapers for New York and Detroit, adding to the ones it already has in its home city of Chicago and in Cleveland. Crain said the New York publication would start either in the fall or by the end of the year; a circulation of 75,000 is expected. Crain's Detroit Business, to appear next year, is expected to have a circulation of 30,000.

title: MANAGEMENT MAY BUY BALDWIN'S MGIC UNIT
description: The management of the MGIC Investment Corporation is preparing an offer to acquire the unit of the troubled Baldwin-United Corporation, a commission of insurance regulators said yesterday.

title: PRIORITIES FOR HIGHER CITY SPENDING LISTED BY CHIEF OF FINANCE PANEL
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee said yesterday that he would seek more money in next year's budget for increased health care, summertime activities in the parks and improved library services.

title: INDIANA STANDARD'S BUYBACK

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene of the crime was Central Park. The perpetrators were a young couple named Dottie and John. And the motive, they allege, was merely gratitude for happy hours spent in the park, picnicking, listening to concerts, rowing on the lake. On bright Sunday mornings in spring Dottie and John like to row out to the middle of the lake with a jug of Bloody Marys. They read the papers and they feed the ducks. No crime in that.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: COCAINE, a euphoriant drug that is the most potent natural stimulant yet discovered, is said to make occasional users feel full of energy, self-confidence, control, sexuality, drive and willpower. But it can also turn users into impotent, emaciated, thieving, hostile, paranoid, groveling addicts who live for nothing more than another dose. It has ruined countless marriages, wiped out fortunes, destroyed careers and even claimed lives.

title: Driver, 19, Acquitted In Deaths of 4 Youths

title: Continental Illinois Backed
description: The Illinois Bankers Association has thrown its support behind a bid by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company to amend state banking laws that prohibit the acquisition of Illinois banks by out-of-state banks. The change would be necessary to accommodate several possible bids for the financially troubled Continental.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Bears have lost the wide receiver Ken Margerum for the 1984 season. Margerum, who started nine games last year, tore a ligament in his left knee on the last day of a Bear minicamp. . . . Walter Lewis, starting quarterback for the Memphis Showboats, will be sidelined for the rest of the U.S.F.L. season because of an injury to the middle finger of his right hand. . . . Wayne Gretzky of the Stanley Cup-champion Edmonton Oilers says he will probably undergo minor surgery on June 17 to correct a circulation problem in his left ankle.

title: Disney Investor Can Raise Stake
description: Saul Steinberg, the New York financier, has a green light from the Government to increase his stake in Walt Disney Productions to 25 percent, Federal officials said today. Neither the Federal Trade Commission nor the Justice Department has raised objections to Mr. Steinberg's plan to more than double his holdings in the entertainment company.

title: Kodak I.D. Cards

It said the new products were aimed at markets such as hospitals, universities, government agencies, banks, health clubs and recreational groups. The company said the system created photo identification cards such as badges and passes ''in minutes, with features designed to reduce film waste.''

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 23, 1984 International
description: The possibility of military aid to protect shipping in the Persian Gulf is being discussed by Washington and its allies, according to President Reagan. But, in a news conference, he said the possibility of direct American intervention was ''very slight.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Jose Napoleon Duarte won predictions in Congress that an all-day lobbying effort would help to gain approval for $62 million in emergency military aid for El Salvador. After the Salvadoran President held a 90- minute meeting with House Democratic leaders, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said, ''I think the votes are there overwhelmingly.'' (A1:5.)

title: Indians' Franco Fined
description: Manager Pat Corrales of the Cleveland Indians has fined the shortstop Julio Franco an undisclosed amount for failure to hustle. Franco leads American League shortstops in errors, but it was his tardiness down the baseline in Monday night's loss to Boston that led to his fine. He was out on a tag play at first in the third inning, even though the throw from Wade Boggs, the third baseman, was way high.

But he emphasized that he would not take a position with the Washington Federals unless the club moved to Miami.

title: MAYAN SPECIALISTS HAIL A 'FANCY DISCOVERY' AT THE RIO AZUL SITE

title: CLASSES AT SEVEN TOP STUDIOS
description: OF the 36 studios visited, the 7 listed here offer the most demanding workouts. Facilities, which range from primitive to plush, were secondary considerations. Good studios emphasize such fundamentals as sufficient warm-up, protection of the lower back and knees, proper breathing, sustained stretching rather than bouncing, correct positioning and an adequate cool-down period.

title: JURY IN DELOREAN TRIAL SEES DISCUSSION OF DRUG DEAL ON VIDEOTAPE
description: A jury today watched John Z. DeLorean on videotape discussing with another man the explicit financial details of dealing in illicit drugs.

title: COOKERY REOPENING WITHOUT MUSIC
description: The Cookery, a Greenwich Village restaurant that has featured jazz musicians and singers such as the late Mary Lou Williams, Alberta Hunter, the late Helen Humes and Big Joe Turner for the last 15 years, is scheduled to take on a new name and new policy this afternoon when it opens as a chicken-and-ribs restaurant called B-B-Cue, without entertainment.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; N.Y.U. Backing Bonds With Endowment Fund
description: New York University, the largest private university in the country, is using some of its $350 million endowment fund to back a $150 million issue of tax-exempt bonds and thereby reduce the interest paid on the bonds.

title: JAPAN LETS A U.S. LAB TEST GOODS
description: The Japanese Government is preparing for the first time to allow an American testing laboratory to certify products as meeting Japanese safety and quality requirements, Japanese and American officials said today.

description: The Minolta Corporation's Business Equipment division makes copiers, and in that arena it competes with Canon, another camera maker. Canon uses the gravel-voiced Jack Klugman as its ad spokesman.

description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income.

title: PRESIDENT SEES NO TAX RISE UNTIL SPENDING IS CUT MORE
description: President Reagan said tonight that while he remained opposed to tax increases, he might have to review the tax structure ''when we get to the absolute bottom of where we can get'' in cutting Federal spending.

description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani angrily denied a prosecutor's accusations yesterday that he had stolen money from law clients and political campaigns.

title: WATCHING GRASS GROW, PAINT DRY AND SHULTZ WAIT
description: The quadrennial season of slow, dreary diplomacy has begun at the State Department a few months earlier than usual. Barring an unexpected crisis, such as an outbreak of very heavy fighting in the Persian Gulf, active diplomacy is about over until after the November elections. The word has gone out, up and down the department, to, in effect, bring out the diplomatic mothballs.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Welfare Aide Facing Charges
description: A former caseworker for the Human Resources Administration was charged yesterday with extorting bribes from nine people seeking emergency welfare aid, officials said.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mrs. Hall Seeks Recount
description: Representative Katie Hall filed suit today seeking a recount of the May 8 Democratic primary in the First Congressional District. She lost by fewer than 2,400 votes in a three-candidate race. Mrs. Hall, who is black, charged after the primary that she was a victim of racism, particularly in predominantly white Porter County, where she logged only 715 of more than 8,000 votes cast.

title: Turner Near Pact
description: The National Basketball Association is near a contract that would give the Turner Broadcasting System, headed by Ted Turner, the Atlanta Hawks' owner, exclusive rights to cable telecasts of the league's games. Ed Desser, the N.B.A.'s director of broadcasting, said the two-year package would allow a maximum of 75 national telecasts annually and be worth a total of $20 million. This season 150 games were shown nationally on cable by USA, ESPN and Turner Broadcasting's WTBS.

title: PAPER CHALLENGES CURBS IN SEXUAL ASSAULT CASES
description: A Manchester, Conn., newspaper that published the name of a woman who said she had been raped is asking the courts to void a state law intended to protect the identity of sexual assault victims.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $530,848 for the quarter and $451 for the 9 months.

title: DR. THOMAS WHITE, A CARDIOLOGY LEADER IN JERSEY SINCE 1926
description: Dr. Thomas J. White, who founded the first cardiac clinic in New Jersey in 1926 and was a leading cardiologist there until his retirement in 1981, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FROM HIGH IN ANDES, BIBLE'S MESSAGE CARRIES FAR
description: On the afternoon of Christmas Day 1931, an old organ played, a trombone accompanied and a group of American Protestant missionaries standing in a converted barn 9,300 feet above sea level belted out the hymn ''Great Is Thy Faithfulness.''

title: BRZEZINSKI SEES U.S. AND SOVIET AT 'END OF THE ROAD' ON ARMS CUTS
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser to President Carter, said today that the Soviet Union and the United States appeared to have come ''to the end of the road'' on reaching major strategic arms control agreements.

title: Driver's Luck Runs Out
description: Joseph Briggs, whose car slammed into two utility poles, plunged down a 20-foot embankment and crashed through a fence, walked away from his demolished car only to be struck and killed by a truck. The police said Mr. Briggs, 60 years old, of West Philadelphia, apparently lost control of his car Monday in the Eastwick neighborhood. He got out of the car and climbed up the embankment to the street, but was killed when a tractor-trailer rig swerved to miss a toppled light standard and struck him.

title: CONCERT: WILSON-GLASS MUSICAL EPIC
description: ''THE CIVIL WARS: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down'' is a mammoth minimalist musical epic by conceived by Robert Wilson, with music by Philip Glass and others, planned for the Los Angeles Olympic Arts Festival. The projected performance there has been abandoned, but sections of the work are being unveiled in various parts of the world. The fifth act, an ''Italian Section'' lasting about two hours, with music by Mr. Glass, was given its American premiere in concert form Sunday night at the City Center.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
PROLIFERATION OF THE SALAD BAR
description: IT happens mostly around midday and late in the afternoon.

title: MACKERAL RUNNING AND PRICES ARE LOWER
description: THE Atlantic mackerel are schooling off Long Island on their long annual run north to the Gulf of Maine and the St. Lawrence. While the market prices for these flavorful fish vary depending on the daily catch, in general they are now reaching seasonal lows. Buyers can expect to pay 99 cents to $3.50 a pound, depending on quality and the location of the market.

title: Security Official Named
description: Lieut. Gen. John Chain of the Air Force will serve as director of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs starting July 1, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: HIGH COURT RULES RIGHTS LAW COVERS LAW PARTNERSHIPS
description: The Supreme Court, acting in a sex discrimination suit, ruled unanimously today that law firms may not discriminate on the basis of sex, race, religion or national origin in deciding which young lawyers to promote to the status of partner.

title: ALVIN TOFFLER'S 'THIRD WAVE' LOOKS AT THE FUTURE
description: TWO cheers for the future, and let's get on with it as quickly as we can. In Alvin Toffler's ''Third Wave,'' once a best- selling book, now adapted for television, the future shimmers. In fact, ''The Third Wave'' is really more appropriate for television than print. Electronic technology and the bluebird of happiness, it says, are both the same thing. The 90-minute program, with Mr. Toffler as host, will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: BAHRAIN AIDE SEES GULF CRISIS EASING
description: The Prime Minister of Bahrain said today that he did not believe the conflict between Iran and Iraq in the Persian Gulf would worsen.

title: U.S. JUDGE RESIGNS CASE AFTER THREAT TO HIS LIFE
description: Federal District Judge U.W. Clemon removed himself today from the trial of nine Ku Klux Klansmen because he was once warned his name appeared on a Klan ''hit list'' for assassination.

title: RECESSION VS. BABIES
description: The most shameful aspect of recession - ignored in analyses of debt, deficits, interest rates and inflation - is that young children suffer the most. This is the real ''trickle-down'' economics, which no amount of pious rhetoric or pictures of politicians kissing babies can disguise.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.5% IN APRIL
description: The Consumer Price Index - the most widely followed inflation barometer - rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase since January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: China Plans to Restore Ranks in the Military
description: China disclosed a new military service law today that will reduce the size of its army and restore ranks, which were abolished during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.

title: NATIONAL ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Telephone Company To Limit Credit Card Use
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Company, faced with increased fraudulent use of telephone credit cards, says it will bar direct-dial credit-card calls from south Florida to 26 countries next week.

title: LTV Shutting Mill
description: The LTV Corporation said that the electric furnace and blooming mill operations at the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation's Pittsburgh Works will be shut down indefinitely next week. About 600 workers will be affected by the May 31 closing, an LTV spokesman, Chuck Palmer, said from the company's headquarters in Dallas. A spokesman for Jones & Laughlin, which is owned by LTV, said the shutdown is unrelated to the pending $770 million merger of LTV and the Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland.

title: WITNESS IN ATHENS TRIAL SAYS MOSCOW HELPED FINANCE PAPER
description: A former business associate of the publisher of Greece's largest daily newspaper testified before an appeals court here today that Soviet intelligence officers, operating as representatives of the Soviet copyright agency, arranged to finance the paper's founding in 1981.

title: Europeans Launch a Satellite
description: KOUROU SPACE CENTER, French Guiana, May 22 (Reuters) - A European rocket today successfully completed the world's first strictly commercial space venture by putting an American-owned communications satellite into orbit 22,300 miles above the equator.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Somebody could have been hurt. Sid Bernstein put out the word to a few people in the music business recently that he was looking for a song for a new singer he had signed. This simple, careless act precipitated an avalanche of cassette tapes, raining down at first by the dozens and then by duffel bags, filling his office until he could not get in. Mr. Bernstein admits he should have known better than to try something like this in New York.

title: SAN JOSE LOSES $60 MILLION IN BOND 'IRREGULARITIES'
description: The city of San Jose lost $60 million in the bond market because of ''irregularities'' in its investment portfolio, and the city's finance director, treasurer and investment officer were placed on leave pending an audit, the mayor said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMCA International, Hanover, N.H., a machine tool and construction equipment maker, has named Ross E. Chamberlain and Robert H. Elman senior group vice presidents.

title: MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oregon Frog's Leap Wins
description: An Oregon frog jumped 21 feet 1 1/2 inches Monday to win the Calavaras County jumping frog contest. This broke the record of 20 feet 3 3/8 inches set at the contest last year, according to a contest spokesman. The winning frog, named Weird Harold won $1,500 for its owner, Janet Seiber.

title: ARMY AND AIR FORCE AIM TO IMPROVE COORDINATION
description: The Army and the Air Force made public a new agreement today intended to increase tactical coordination between their forces in the field, to improve cooperation in drawing up annual budgets and to reduce duplication in costly weapon programs.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YANKEES SCORE, BUT STILL LOSE
description: The Yankees were not shut out tonight. But with the way their season is slipping away so early, that was of little consolation.

title: Penney's Net Rises by 19%
description: The J. C. Penney Company reported today that net income in the first quarter rose 19 percent, to $69 million, or 92 cents a share, from $58 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: Market Place; 'Defensive' Stock Picks
description: IT looks more like a bear market than a bull market on Wall Street these days. The Dow Jones industrials yesterday sank to their lowest closing in 13 months, while the transportation average posted a 15-month low on Monday.

title: VECTOR AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEIGHBORS OF ROCKWELL ACCEPT SITE OF MUSEUM
description: Despite fears that tourists would trample the small-town life that Norman Rockwell captured on canvas in his years here, townspeople have decided to allow the building of a new museum to house the artist's works.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Voznesensky, a Soviet Poet, Cancels Oberlin Appearance
description: Oberlin College said yesterday that Andrei A. Voznesensky, a Soviet poet, had canceled a visit to the Ohio campus, where he was to have received an honorary doctorate and given the commencement address on Sunday.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: PRESS IRAN TO TALK PEACE
description: Despite international fears caused by attacks in the Persian Gulf, America continues its shortsighted policy in failing to confront the escalating Iran-Iraq war. Until very recently, Administration officials and influential policy makers elsewhere held the view that the war's continuation was beneficial since it prevented both Gulf powers from directing their hostility against our interests in the region. In the wake of Iranian air attacks on Saudi and Kuwaiti oil tankers, the Administration has come close to offering Saudi Arabia and its allies military support. Yet despite the Administration's preference for a negotiated solution, Vice President Bush said in Oman that he saw no American role in negotiations at this time.

title: HOW SOME AMERICANS TREAT SOVIET ATHLETES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SEARCH OF AMERICAN CAVIAR
description: OVER the years it has been my good fortune to observe the harvesting of a number of culinary delicacies. I have been on a truffle hunt in Italy, watched vineyard snails go from vine leaf to snail pot in Burgundy and, near Strasbourg, witnessed the transfer of foie gras from a fattened goose to the table of a great French chef.

title: Venezuela's Debt Goal
description: Venezuela has set a priority goal of paying off $700 million in public and private sector interest arrears before June 15, Carlos Guillermo Rangel, the nation's chief debt negotiator, said today.

title: NEW SOVIET OUSTER DEEPENS MYSTERY
description: In the latest twist of a tangled spy intrigue, the Soviet Union ordered the expulsion of a British diplomat today.

title: L.I. JUDGE FINES 8 IN CABLE TV PIRACY
description: In a decision hailed as a key step in reducing the piracy of cable-television signals, a State Supreme Court judge has levied punitive damages against four taverns and four individuals for tapping illegally into a cable-television service.

title: Neapolitans Greet Muti Leading Philadelphians
description: A packed San Carlo Opera house audience shouted ''Welcome home, Ricardo,'' and asked for encores Monday night as Ricardo Muti conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in his hometown.

title: RIVALS GET NEW JERSEY TV EXPOSURE
description: In terms of electronic geography, New Jersey is a land of 7.4 million people lodged between the transmitting towers of New York City and Philadelphia. Residents in southern New Jersey overwhelmingly get their television news from Pennsylvania, and those in the north from the studios of New York, with some overlap.

description: The Government summarily liquidated, or took over, 11 companies associated with two large private savings and loan institutions today on the ground that they had far overextended their financial obligations.

title: A Rugger Is Impressive
description: Having watched American football on television at his home in Ashstead, England, Tim Bainbridge, a rugby player since he was 9 years old, wrote to a dozen National Football League teams for a tryout as a kicker. Only the Houston Oilers and the Washington Redskins expressed interest. After having watched the 23-year-old Bainbridge kick 65 yards, the coaches at Redskin Park invited him to camp this summer.

description: The Raytheon Company said its Badger Engineers Inc. subsidiary had received a $100 million contract from the Chevron Chemical Company to design and build a phosphate fertilizer complex near Hot Springs, Wyo. Under the contract, Badger is responsible for the engineering, design, procurement and construction of all facilities at the site. Raytheon said the plant is scheduled to be completed in late 1986.

TENNIS JUNIORS CHASING A PRESSURE-FILLED LIFE
description: Children with tennis ambitions must grow up fast to keep up these days. If a recently completed tournament in Tucson, Ariz., is any indication, an alarming percentage of America's top-ranked youngsters are moving at an unnatural pace from adolescence to adulthood.

title: SOVIET BLOC PLANS MEETS IN SUMMER
description: The sports ministers of Soviet-bloc nations will meet tomorrow in Prague to arrange multination competition for their athletes this summer. But though these nations have decided not to compete in the Los Angeles Olympics, it seems certain they will not stage a counter Olympics.

description: Five British and French banks said today that a privately financed tunnel could be built under the English Channel by the year 2000.

title: STRESSES OF CONNODITIES VS. SECURITIES
description: When Philipp Brothers acquired Salomon Brothers in October 1981, the marriage was considered timely and logical. The once formidable market wall that separated the commodity trading world of Philipp Brothers from equally huge investment bankers such as Salomon Brothers was crumbling. Helping undermine the wall was a severe recession that had reduced business in stocks, bonds and investment banking, while dealers in raw materials needed access to dependable and ample sources of credit.

title: THE AUDIENCE FOR RAPPERS BROADENS
description: TALKING probably won't replace singing as pop music's most characteristic mode of verbal expression. But vocalists who chant, rap or recite seem to be popping up on all sorts of records these days. With the help of films like ''Wild Style'' and the soon-to-be-released, Harry Belafonte-produced ''Beat Street,'' inner-city rappers are gaining a broader audience. In Jamaica, fast-talking ''dee-jays'' and heavily politicized ''reggae poets'' are among the most popular performers. In the rarefied New York art world, performance artists have been fitting their archly satirical recitatives to adventurous rock frameworks.

title: Investors Savings
description: Empire of America, a savings and loan association based here, said it had acquired the Houston-based Investors Savings Association. It said Investors Savings, with two offices in Houston and one in Pasadena, Tex., had assets of $31.9 million. Empire already has five branches in the Houston area and 10 in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 8 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1990, to 10.70 percent in 1999, and 10 7/8 percent in 2004.

description: If a good player sits down behind someone he does not know at a duplicate game, he will usually know after a hand or two whether or not the player he is watching knows what he is doing. But there are some occasions when he may feel rather confused.

title: KARL-AUGUST FAGERHOLM, EX-FINNISH LEADER, DIES
description: Karl-August Fagerholm, who was Prime Minister of Finland during one of the nation's major crises with the Soviet Union, died yesterday, his family reported in Helsinki. He was 82 years old.

title: DUARTE'S APPEAL SEEMS TO SWAY HOUSE ON ARMS
description: President-elect Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador told Congress today that he was putting his ''life on the line'' and won predictions that his all-day lobbying effort would gain approval for $62 million in emergency military aid for his country.

title: Suit Seeks Dallas Funds For G.O.P. Protesters
description: A group organizing protest demonstrations for the Republican National Convention in August has filed a lawsuit to force Dallas to spend as much on protesters as the city plans to spend to welcome the Republicans.

title: METS' RALLY FALLS SHORT
description: Fresh from a break-even West Coast swing, the Mets bolted in front of the San Francisco Giants last night: 35-year-old George Foster stole home for the first time in his career, the catcher Mike Fitzgerald hit his first home run of the season and Hubie Brooks extended his hitting streak to 17 games with a double.

title: SENATE VOTES GUIDES ON COMPENSATION FOR AGENT ORANGE ILLNESSES
description: The Senate unanimously approved a bill today that would require the Federal Government to establish guidelines for compensation of veterans whose illnesses were traced to Agent Orange, the toxic defoliant used in the Vietnam War.

title: EFFECTIVE HEALTH-COST CONTROL'S BUILT-IN PAIN

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the great treasures of the American table is the soft-shell crab, now coming onto the market. Soft-shell crabs can be sauteed in butter or oil and then dressed with any number of flavors - just a sprinkling of parsley, say, or capers or chopped anchovies.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
STAGE: PARABLE OF INDIA
description: AT the beginning of his parable of ancient India, ''Transposed Heads,'' Thomas Mann issued a warning. It takes, he said, ''more courage to tell such a tale than to hear it.'' Dauntless, Julie Taymor, in collaboration with Sidney Goldfarb, has tried to adapt this grotesque legend to the stage. Visually, the version at the Ark Theater Company spins a fanciful web around the audience, but, dramatically, the evening barely approaches the horror and the lyricism of the original.

title: ALBANY ASSERTS MARSH BROKE INSURANCE RULES
description: The New York State Insurance Department said yesterday that the Marsh & McLennan Companies had violated state regulations by using insurance premium funds held in fiduciary accounts to buy long-term bonds. But the department and the insurance brokerage concern said that no insurers would lose money from the trading and that no New York fiduciary funds were currently invested improperly.

title: BRITISH CHANGING ON CERAMICS
description: -ON-TRENT, England - Britain's venerable ceramics industry, chastened by the impact of recession and the loss of export markets when the pound shot up along with oil prices in 1979, is now working on several fronts to stimulate its recovery.

title: K Mart Expects Record Profits
description: K Mart, the nation's second-largest retailer, behind Sears, Roebuck & Company, expects record profits in 1984 and sales of more than $20 billion, its chairman, Bernard Fauber, said at the annual meeting. The company, which last year earned $492 million on sales of $18.6 billion, has benefited from high consumer confidence and the addition of more upscale lines of merchandise to traditional discount goods in its 2,161 North American stores, he said.

title: FORECLOSURE KILLER GIVEN LIFE
description: An 18-year-old man was sentenced today to life in prison for the ambush slaying of a rural bank president at a foreclosed farm that once belonged to his father. He also received a 10-year term for the second-degree murder of a bank loan officer.

title: RIGHTS BILL DRAWS CRITICISM FROM ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration today sharply criticized a bill designed to clarify the scope of laws banning discrimination by recipients of Federal aid.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago net income excludes debenture interest costs of $312,816, or 12 cents a share, pending the resolution of bankruptcy proceedings. There were no share earnings in the latest quarter after the reduction of net income for preferred stock dividend requirements of $46,111. The company has changed its fiscal year from Oct. 31 to Dec. 31, effective for the calendar year ending Dec. 31, 1984.

title: Britain Selling Leyland's Jaguar
description: Jaguar, a British automobile legend, is to be sold back into private hands later this year after becoming the most profitable part of the big state- owned British Leyland group, the Government said in what had been a long-expected announcement.

Bus Driver Shot In Face by Youth
description: A 33-year-old city bus driver was shot in the face yesterday by a youth who got off his bus at Buffalo Avenue and Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, fired through the closed door and fled, the police said.

description: b-Net income.

Preakness Tops $10 Million in Bets
description: Betting on the 109th running of the Preakness Stakes totaled more than $10 million at 22 sites throughout the country, including Pimlico Race Course, where the race was held, and the New York and Connecticut offtrack betting corporations.

title: Sperry's Plea Is Accepted
description: A Federal judge has accepted a guilty plea from the Sperry Corporation, for illegally billing the Government $325,000 on an MX missile contract, in the first criminal prosecution of a major military contractor for overcharging.

title: IRAQI LEADER VOWS TO KEEP BLOCKADE
description: Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, said today that Iraqi forces would continue their air and naval blockade of Iran's principal oil terminal at Kharg Island.

description: Information Displays, a computer company based in Armonk, N.Y., has filed for reorganizaion under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Defendant Who Fled Murder Trial Is Seized
description: A 35-year-old defendant in a murder trial who escaped from a holding cell in the Cattaraugus County courthouse Tuesday was captured last night in an abandoned cabin five miles away, local law enforcement officials said.

title: Maulers to Name Coach
description: Hank Bullough resigned as defensive coordinator of the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League, and said he would be named head coach of the Pittsburgh Maulers of the United States Football League.

description: ''We can say again today, with greater certainty than ever, that cigarettes are the most important individual health risk in this country, responsible for more premature deaths and disability than any other known agent.

title: BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION: GLORIA STEINEM AT 50
description: GLORIA STEINEM, who once fibbed about birthdays, celebrated a big one last night in the most public way possible - with 750 well-wishers in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, with Bette Midler camping on stage and Phil Donahue trailing a microphone and working the tables below, with Kit McClure and her all-woman band playing Steinem favorites like ''Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend,'' and with Bella Abzug and a chorus of feminists singing:

title: U.S. BUYS ISRAELI PILOTLESS PLANES

description: Lawrence J. Twill, a Wall Street executive, has been elected president and chief executive of New York Air, effective immediately.

title: Brazil Hopes to Pay Interest Due in '84
description: Brazil will be able to meet interest payments due this year on its $93 billion in foreign debt, despite the recent rise in interest rates, Affonso Celso Pastore, president of the central bank of Brazil, said in an interview yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: In the haute cuisine regions of New York now, and for the rest of May, it's fiddlehead time. Croziers, also called fiddleheads, are pushing up, coiled to spring; the fern leaf buds stay tightly bound until they quickly relax in the open air.

title: Donaldson Selling Units
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said yesterday that it would sell some of its physical commodities businesses to Cargill Inc., a Minneapolis-based commodities concern, for more than $82 million.

title: MUSIC: 'MARATHON'
description: CONCERT artists are inclined to overstatement, but Yvar Mikhashoff's Saturday afternoon ''Great American Piano Marathon'' at the Symphony Space was exactly that. Over the course of seven hours, Mr. Mikhashoff was scheduled to play some 70 American works, all written since 1914.

title: Coach's Parting Shot
description: Jim Bush, U.C.L.A.'s head track and field coach, is about to retire, and he is a bitter man. ''It's just not any fun for me anymore,'' he said.

title: Daylong Walkout By Yale Workers
description: NEW HAVEN, May 23 (AP) Hundreds of Yale University clerical and technical employees left work today in a one-day job action aimed at getting the university to negotiate a new contract.

description: b-Net loss

title: Enstar ShareholderObjects to Merger
description: Roy M. Huffington, the largest shareholder of the Enstar Corporation, said yesterday that he opposed a merger agreement reached between Enstar and the Unimar Company late Tuesday. The agreement, when completed, would have a value of about $570 million.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1984
description: International Efforts to provide Saudi Arabia with 1,200 portable Stinger antiaircraft missiles will be revived, according to State Department officials. They said the Reagan Administration had informed key members of Congress of its plan because of the possibility of Iranian air attacks. The move, they said, was taken in response to an urgent request Tuesday by King Fahd. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iraq will continue its blockade of Iran's main oil terminal at Kharg Island, President Saddam Hussein said in an address in Baghdad. (A10:1.)

title: Harold Charles Wilson Dies; Retired Aluminum Executive
description: Harold Charles Wilson, a retired aluminum company executive, died Monday at the North Broward Medical Center in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Pompano Beach and New Canaan, Conn.

description: b-Including a net gain of $1.9 million for the 16 weeks and year from the sale of real estate. c-After a charge of $4.2 million for prior period countervailing duty adjustments.

title: Unity Is Credo of Western Governors' Group
description: A new-alliance of governors from Western States concluded its first meeting here today with some internal differences but united in a belief in the growing influence of their region in Washington.

title: Bell Canada Case
description: Canada's telecommunications regulator rejected a request by Bell Canada Enterprises Inc.'s telephone operating unit to raise local rates by 6 percent and long-distance rates by 2 percent, starting Sept. 1. The increases would have provided the company with an extra $45 million this year and $140 million in 1985. The Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission said it was not convinced that Bell needed the money now, and suggested that the company could meet its profit target by "further efforts at controlling expenses."

title: MONDALE SEEKS FUNDS TO CLINCH NOMINATION
description: Arriving in his hotel suite this afternoon, Walter F. Mondale removed his jacket, loosened his tie and began dialing the phone numbers of bankers, businessmen and Democratic Party contributors.

description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $90,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $60,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months.

title: GOING BACK TO A PLAYWRIGHT'S SOURCE
description: -effects is to leave you feeling that you should, you must discover or rediscover books, paintings and other works of art maybe more rewarding than whatever it is you've just seen. A. R. Gurney's ''Golden Age'' did at least something to justify its recent brief stay on Broadway if it sent a few of its detractors back to its source, Henry James's ''Aspern Papers.'' Nor will Stephen Sondheim's ''Sunday in the Park With George'' have lived in vain if it increases the crowds around Seurat's ''Parade'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - or, indeed, packs them off to Chicago to see the great ''A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte'' itself.

description: The year-ago results were restated to exclude discontinued operations.

Cribbs Returns
description: Joe Cribbs , the star running back for the Birmingham Stallions, returned to the United States Football League team yesterday, ending a midseason walkout in a contract dispute. The Stallions' coach, Rollie Dotsch , said Cribbs would be in uniform against the New Orleans Breakers in a televised game this Sunday, but it wasn't known how much playing time he would see.

title: RATES UP ON TREASURY ISSUES
description: Interest rates for Treasury securities rose yesterday, reflecting weak investor demand for notes and bonds as well as concern among traders that short-term rates might come under upward pressure in the near future.

title: U.S. and Japan In Yen Accord
description: The United States and Japan have agreed on a basic plan to open up Japan's capital markets to foreign investors and use the yen as a principal currency in international trade, officials from both countries said today. The tentative agreement, which is subject to more discussion, was long sought by United States officials as a way of increasing the yen's value against the dollar, making Japanese products more expensive.

title: PURCHASING CITY HOMES AT AUCTION
description: frame house at 26 Harbor View Court in the New Brighton section of Staten Island and wonders when all the decorating will be completed. The plumbing works, the heating is in order and flowers are blooming in the yard, but the living room is still furnished in Early University.

title: GESTURE OF U.S. SUPPORT Washington Ready to Provide 1,200 Portable Weapons -- Earlier Move Blocked
description: The Reagan Administration told key members of Congress today that it planned to try again to send Saudi Arabia 1,200 portable Stinger antiaircraft missiles to defend against possible Iranian air attacks, State Department officials said.

title: Advances Stir Global Issues
description: THE emerging technologies of genetics, computers, telecommunications and other growth industries are straining relations among nations -- in commerce, defense. law ad culture.

title: 'A Widow for One Year'
description: Summer 1958

title: Esmark Reportedly Accepts Bid;  Beatrice Is Said to Raise Offer To $2.9 Billion
description: The Beatrice Foods Company has reached an agreement to buy Esmark Inc., the huge Chicago conglomerate, for $60 a share, or about $2.9 billion, in cash, food industry sources disclosed last night.

title: JACKSON TO GO TO MEXICO TO DISCUSS PEACE PLAN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will make a one-day trip to Mexico City to learn more about a four-nation group's peace plan for Central America, a spokesman said today.

title: SPAIN CHARGES CATALONIA'S LEADER WITH BANK EMBEZZLEMENT
description: In a move that rocked Spanish politics, the President of the Catalan regional government was charged today with misappropriating funds as chairman of a Catalan bank that collapsed in 1982.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: PKN Anstalt of Vaduz, Liechtenstein, is privately placing a 70-million-franc, 6 percent, maximum 5-year note issue on the Swiss capital Market through Credit Suisse.

title: Bank Charter Plan
description: The First Railroad and Banking Company said it had filed an application with the United States Comptroller of the Currency to charter new national banks in Aiken, S.C., Charleston, N.C., and Richmond. It said the new banks would make no commercial loans. The Comptroller has declared a moratorium on approving applications for such consumer banks but is still taking applications.

title: Plugging Seagram's Scotch Gap
description: THE mighty Seagram organization, despite its domineering role in the spirits world, is not represented in the tight and houghty clique of premium Scotches.

title: Dual Position Is Filled By Woods Petroleum
description: V. Lee Powell has been elected president and chief executive of the Woods Petroleum Corporation.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
35 Reported Killed in New India Riots
description: Officials said today that at least 35 people were killed in new rioting by Moslems and Hindus who burned factories, houses and a temple. Six of the vctims died when policmen fired on a crowd of 2,000 rioters on the outskirts of Bombay today.

title: WIN OR SEEK PEACE?
description: President Reagan said the ''U.S. must support the Salvadoran Government and the Nicaraguan people.''

title: WENDERS'S FILM, 'PARIS, TEXAS,' WINS AT CANNES
description: Wim Wenders, the West German director, won the grand prize of the 37th Cannes Film Festival tonight for ''Paris, Texas,'' a film made in the United States about a man's quest for his son's love and his search for his estranged wife.
