description: Plea for a Woman on Ticket

title: Phone Users Facing a Long-Distance Choice
description: In coming weeks, as the battle to carve up a market previously dominated by the American telephone and Telegraph Company enters a decisive phase, phone subscribers in the New York area will be asked to decide which company they want to use for long-distance calls.

title: THE PROCEDURE FOR BIDDING
description: CITY auctions are held about five times a year and brochures listing the properties are available from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The buildings are sealed and viewing times are very limited, about two hours on a single day.

title: George Zaharias, HusbandOf Babe Didrikson, Is Dead
description: George Zaharias, husband and manager of the late golfing champion Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, died at a hospital here Tuesday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: A Patrician President in Bonn; Richard von Weizsacker
description: Not long ago Richard von Weizsacker recounted how, on a visit to the United States to attend the bicentennial independence celebrations, he was struck by "the deep joy and pride" that Americans have for their country.

title: 3 Hurt in Pileup In Lincoln Tunnel
description: A seven-vehicle pileup that began when a dump truck struck the rear of an auto injured three drivers and tied up traffic in the Lincoln Tunnel for four hours yesterday morning.

title: 'CORE' SKILLS NEEDED BY WORK-BOUND PUPILS
description: A National Academy of Sciences panel of business and education leaders said today that students who start work after high school need to master ''virtually the same'' basic academic skills as college-bound students.

title: Vandals Scatter Papers In Democratic Offices
description: Someone broke into the offices of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Tuesday night, ransacking files and knocking over potted plants. The intruders created a Watergate break-in scare that the Democrats found unamusing.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,441,000 from an accounting change.

title: SANITATION URGED FOR FIELD HANDS
description: Medical authorities testified today that thousands of American farm workers, lacking access to toilets or clean water at their work sites, suffer levels of parasitic illness rarely encountered in developed societies.

title: TV Ownership in Japan
description: Color television sets are owned by 99.2 percent of Japanese households, the Economic Planning Agency said today. Its survey covered 6,000 households.

title: Brach Heiress Declared Dead as of 7 Years Ago
description: A judge today declared Helen Vorhees Brach legally dead as of Feb. 17, 1977, allowing her brother to collect more than $200,000 interest from a trust fund and freeing the estate of the candy company heiress.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South Africa Exchanges Prisoners With Angola
description: South Africa and Angola exchanged 32 prisoners today and on Tuesday under Red Cross auspices at an Angolan border town, a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross said.

title: Auerbach Calling
description: Beginning next season, Red Auerbach, the Celtics' president and general manager, will be dispensing much of that advice by telephone from his home or the office space he rents from a real-estate company in Washington.

title: ; AS FARMERS FALL VICTIM TO THEIR EFFICIENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NOWADAYS it is not surprising to see houses with two or three antennas on the roof, an unsightly arrangement that few homeowners really like, but that they mistakenly feel is necessary to insure good reception when they own more than one television set. Most think that the only alternative is using the built-in antenna for the second and third sets; the large roof-mounted antenna is then used for the family set in the living room or den.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $9 million for the 6 months and an extraordinary credit of $6 million for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $3 million for the quarter and $4 million for the 6 months and extraordinary credits of $1 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 6 months.

description: Results are for 14 and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 13 and 52 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: Aid to Salvador Stalled By Clash On Nicaraguans
description: House Democratic leaders put new pressure on the Reagan Administration today to stop trying to link $62 million in emergency military aid for El Salvador to continued aid for Nicaraguan rebel groups.

title: AUSTERE SET OF FURNITURE
description: HAVING done some architectural work for his clients Charles and Ora Ramat, David Estreich, right, an architect, was asked to design a dining room set.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Revenue figures represent bullion revenue.

title: Foster Achieves A Career First
description: After 15 years of playing experiences, most professional athletes have seen just about everything their particular sports have to offer.

title: AN 'INVITATION TO HELL'
description: LIFE in ABC's Silicon Valley turns out to resemble a watered-down version of NBC's ''V.'' In ''Invitation to Hell,'' the television movie on ABC at 8 tonight, the other-worldly creature luring innocent earthlings to their doom is an aggressive seductress who runs an exclusive country club. Prospective members are urged to play the game of social climbing, to ''step over a few bodies and rub shoulders with the right people.'' Greed, ambition and power, not to mention assorted sexual capers, are the key motivating factors.

title: JUDGE VOIDS U.S. RULES ON REPORTING OF HANDICAPPED INFANTS
description: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan yesterday struck down Reagan Administration regulations requiring doctors in hospitals to report suspected instances of neglect in treating handicapped infants.

title: HOW TO USE HOUSEHOLD PESTICIDES SAFELY
description: With garden flowers in full bloom and insects on the attack, a consumer group has published a pamphlet detailing the safe use of pesticides in and around the home.

title: Continental Says Flow Of Funds Is 'Stabilized'
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said today that its financial rescue had been "well received" by the financial community and that its funding situation had "stabilized" as a result of the multibillion-dollar financial assistance package assembled a week ago.

title: Storer Sale
description: Storer Communications Inc. said it had signed some cable television systems in Maryland and Virginia to a group of investors led by Winfield M. Kelly Jr., an executive of the cable systems. The cable systems, which are being sold for about $49 million, are in north Prince Georges County, Md., and Leesburg and Fort Belvoir, Va. The company said it had agreed to the sale to reduce corporate debt and curtail future spending needs.

title: Murderer Is Granted Stay in Final 7 Hours
description: A condemned murderer, William N. Moore, was granted a stay of execution by a Federal appeals court today, seven hours before he was scheduled to die in Georgia's electric chair.

title: 25 ARE INDICTED AS JEWISH TERRORISTS IN ISRAEL
description: Twenty- five Jews, most of them militant settlers from the West Bank and the Golan Heights, were formally charged today by Israel's State Attorney with belonging to ''a terrorist organization'' that conducted or planned at least six violent attacks on Arabs in the last four years.

title: Steel Industry Leader Supports Mondale Views
description: David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday took a position in wholehearted agreement with the United Steelworkers of America: he said that his favorite Democratic candidate was Walter F. Mondale.

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2,838,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Jane White Canfield; Author and a Sculptor
description: Jane White Canfield, an author and sculptor, died of cancer May 23 at her home in Bedford, N.Y. She was 87 years old.

title: Unionists End Boycott In Northern Ireland
description: The Official Unionist Party, the largest political party in Northern Ireland, announced today that it was ending a six-month boycott of a provincial assembly that was set up to promote power-sharing between Roman Catholics and Protestants.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a net loss of $45,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Surgery for Campbell
description: Earl Campbell underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair a minor cartilage tear in his right knee yesterday, Bob Hyde , a spokesman for the Oilers said.

title: VALENZUELA STOPS PHILS, STRIKING OUT 15
description: Fernando Valenzuela struck out 15 batters, allowed only three hits and drove in the only run of the game as the Los Angeles Dodgers snapped the Philadelphia Phillies' 10-game winning streak with a 1-0 victory tonight.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HEAVY RAINS DELAY AIR TRAFFIC AND CUT POWER TO THOUSANDS
description: On what was the hottest day of the year so far, short but severe thunderstorms yesterday delayed thousands of airline passengers, darkened hundreds of homes in the New York metropolitan area and drove the temperature down 15 degrees in five hours.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks underwent surgery for a herniated disk yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, where he is expected to remain at least a week. Brown, who had been suffering from back pains for several months, was ''resting comfortably,'' a spokesman for the team said. . . . The Rangers have traded Rob McClanahan , a left wing, to the Detroit Red Wings for future considerations. McClanahan, a member of the 1980 United States hockey team that won an Olympic gold medal, was unhappy with his playing status with the Rangers and asked for a trade.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Recipe

title: AFTER NIGHTMARE OF VIETNAM, VALEDICTORIAN AT CITY COLLEGE
description: Nearly five years ago, after a six-day journey from Vietnam as one of the ''boat people'' and five months in a refugee camp, Chi Luu arrived in Elmhurst, Queens. He was not sure what to expect, but he did know what he wanted - an education.

title: Damages Granted Black For Harassment on Job
description: A black welder who endured years of racial harassment from his white co-workers and supervisors was awarded $1.5 million in damages today by the Michigan Civil Rights Commission.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After extraordinary gain of $7,918,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $32,827,000 from termination of retirement plan for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Cuba Withdraws From Olympic
description: Cuba withdrew today from the Olympic Games, the Cuban Government press agency Prensa Latina reported from Havana.

title: TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lawmaker Hurt Fleeing Fire
description: Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, suffered a spinal fracture after leaping from a second-story window early today to escape a fire in his home in suburban Washington. The Congressman, who also suffered smoke inhalation and first-degree burns, was reported in good condition at Alexandria Hospital. He was later transferred to the Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md.

title: MONDALE IS GIVEN 14 MORE DELEGATES IN NEW YORK
description: Capitalizing on his strength among Democratic Party and public officials, Walter F. Mondale picked up at least 14 additional New York State delegates last night as the Democratic State Committee selected unpledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Topics; Shaping the Future
description: City Builder

title: Killer Who Cited Vietnam Trauma Convicted
description: A Vietnam veteran who contended that delayed stress from his war experiences had caused him to murder his fiancee was convicted today of first-degree murder.

title: TWO PERFECTIONISTS: ARCHITECT AND CLIENT
description: FOR seven years Dr. Vallo Benjamin, a New York neurosurgeon, looked for an apartment in Manhattan with a double-height ceiling. Once he had found and bought one, he spent another eight years remodeling.

title: Foes of Chicago Mayor Say He Has Forfeited His Office
description: The majority leader of the City Council asserted today that Harold Washington, Chicago's first black Mayor, had forfeited his office by failing to file required financial statements by the legal deadline.

title: Baseball Players Ratify Drug Plan
description: The tentative agreement reached three weeks ago by a joint owner- union committee on how to deal with drug dependency has received overwhelming ratification from the players in major league baseball. But continuing opposition by some team owners, several of whom think that the accord lacks sufficient disciplinary provisions, makes its future uncertain.

title: THE FINANCING: LOANS, GRANTS
description: DENISE REED bought her $8,000 house with a $2,000 down payment from her savings. She obtained a 7.5-percent 20-year city- financed mortgage for the $6,000 remaining in the purchase price. For the rehabilitation costs, however, Miss Reed put together her own financial package.

title: Rejects Bid for New Search -- Acting Chief to Be Formally Appointed Wednesday
description: The Board of Education decided yesterday to name Nathan Quinones, the Acting Chancellor, as the next Chancellor of the New York City School system.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 14, 1984 and a 7 percent stock dividend to be paid June 25.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: Everybody was invited to a birthday today, and thousands braved lowering clouds to turn out.

title: PROFESSOR'S PATH TO MAYAN DISCOVERY
description: IN 1962, a geologist who was prospecting for the Sun Oil Company came across a cluster of

title: Man Who Impersonated Professors Wins Release
description: After serving a 90-day minimum sentence, a professor convicted of using false credentials to obtain simultaneous college teaching jobs under assumed names was to be released from prison Thursday.

title: Anees Jung
description: IT was a summer of jasmines. The twilight

title: Excerpts From Report on How Reagan Camp Got Carter's Briefing Papers
description: Following are excerpts from a summary of the House Subcommittee on Human Resources' report on its investigation into how the REagon Presidential campaign obtained briefing papers prepared for President Carter in 1980. MAJORITY VIEWS

title: DRAMA ARTS ACADEMY CELEBRATES CENTENNIAL
description: THE love and learning of acting brought them to that school in the first place; it brought them together again in gratitude and nostalgia last night.

title: MUSIC: JUNKYARD BAND OF WASHINGTON
description: -off plastic buckets for drums, plus toy trumpets, a toy organ, tambourines and their own youthful voices, the Junkyard Band made propulsive, nonstop dance music Friday at the Pyramid.

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Technology; Advances Stir Global Issues
description: THE emerging technologies of genetics, computers, telecommunications and other growth industries are straining relations among nations -- in commerce, defense, law and culture.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 16 weeks to April 21
description: b-After a loss of $10,900 from discontinued operations and a gain of $925,300 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of 303,700 from discontinued operations.

title: Books: On El Salvador By Thomas P. Anderson;
description: WEAKNESS AND DECEIT: U.S. Policy

title: SPONSERS ALSO RACE AT INDY
description: Teo Fabi, the young Italian racing driver who is one of the favorites to win the Indianapolis 500 on May 27, has been traveling fast. He qualified for 14th place in the starting lineup and in recent practice sessions has been whistling around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in excess of 208 miles an hour.

title: The Whole City Comes First
description: While New York City struggles to retain jobs, some neighborhoods think primping is more important. Thus residents of Elmhurst, Queens, are rallying to keep the Quick Roll Leaf Manufacturing Company, which makes plastic labels, from installing filters and raising its chimneys to meet Federal air quality orders.

title: VETERENS IN ROCHESTER CANCELING PARADE TO BLOCK PEACE MARCHERS
description: Veterans said today that they would cancel the city's 116th annual Memorial Day parade rather than allow a women's peace group to march with them.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CITIES AND THE WEALTH OF NATIONS. Principles of Economic Life. By Jane Jacobs. 257 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Former GAF Official Back After Proxy Battle
description: In chess, a player can move sideward, even backward, and still end up with a checkmate. James T. Sherwin, an expert chess player who was New York State champion in 1951, has applied this technique in the corporate management game.

title: BARRICK RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was not publicly held at that time.

title: MUSIC: TARANASAZ SINGS OF AFGHANISTAN
description: WALI TARANASAZ, who performed Sunday at the Alternative Museum, composed songs for Radio Afghanistan for more than two decades before he came to the United States six years ago.

title: Doctor Sees No Need For Reagan Surgery
description: There is no need to remove the remainder of a small benign growth discovered in President Reagan's colon last week, and the surgery probably will not be done, the White House physician said today.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Texas Authority's Interest Rates Up
description: Interest rates were increased about a quarter of a percentage point for a $265 million offering of the Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas. The authority, which sells electricity to 41 municipalities and cooperatives near Austin, Tex., is constructing a coal-fired power plant.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ally & Gargano Prevails At Clio Awards Again
description: The annual Clio Awards, an always showy event in adland, reached new heights last night in celebrating its 25th anniversary at an expensively mounted extravaganza in Radio City Music Hall.

title: AUTOMATED MEDICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $32,000 for the latest first quarter and $25,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: HART LISTS WOMEN'S ISSUES AS PART OF 'NEW IDEAS' SERIES
description: Senator Gary Hart offered a series of proposals on women's issues today as ''the second in a series of new ideas for America's third century.''

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Language and Prehistory of the Elves
description: The author of the widely read ''Lord of the Rings'' and ''The Hobbit,'' was a man obsessed with the world he had created. J. R. R. Tolkien, who had worked from 1920 to 1922 as an assistant on the Oxford English Dictionary and passed much of his life as a professor of English at Oxford, said of his masterpieces of fantasy, ''The invention of languages is the foundation. The 'stories' were made rather to provide a world for the languages than the reverse.'' He did invent two complete languages (of Elves and Gnomes, respectively) which are used in the stories.

title: Research Group Says U.N. Worsens Conflicts
description: A conservative research group made public a book today that argues that the United Nations makes conflicts worse rather than helping resolve them. The book also charges that the United Nations has become a forum for attacks on Western interests and democratic values.

title: Merger Panel Set in London
description: Robin Leigh-Pemberton, governor of the Bank of England, has named a select committee to recommend regulatory changes to govern mergers and takeovers of financial institutions.

title: Periling Debtor Countries
description: High and rising interest rates are a terrible blow for indebted developing countries such as Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Peru and the Philippines. It is in the interests of debtors and creditors alike to act now to reduce the burden of these rising rates.

title: Walkout Disrupts Papers' Deliveries
description: Deliveries of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal were interrupted in New York City yesterday morning by a walkout of drivers employed by the Metropolitan News Company, a wholesaler.

title: Illinois Lotto Winner Giving Away 2.3 Million
description: Harold Collins is quite happy on the money he earns from his factory job. So, he said, he is giving away the $2.3 million he won in the Illinois Lottery, making good twice over on a 16-year-old promise to a friend.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Accolade

title: CITY WEIGHS PAYING WELFARE RENT STRAIGHT TO LANDLORD TO END FRAUD
description: The Koch administration, concerned about the illegal cashing of welfare rent checks, is considering paying rents for thousands of welfare recipients directly to their landlords.

title: Suns Win, Trail by 3-2
description: The Phoenix Suns shot a tremendous 60 percent from the field in the first three periods tonight and

title: COOPER UNION IS HAILED FOR EDUCATING THE POOR
description: The head of the Ford Foundation praised Cooper Union at its 125th commencement yesterday for having offered a free education since its founding and having unlocked the ''doors of learning'' to the poor.

title: LANGLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CAPITAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Walt Terrell will start for the Mets against Mike Krukow.

title: Betty Young, 58, Is Dead; Led Nikolais-Louis Group
description: Betty Young, executive director of the Nikolais-Louis Foundation for Dance, died of cancer on Monday at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 58.

title: A Deadly Weapon Against Air Attack
description: Stinger antiaircraft missiles, which the Reagan Administration is seeking to sell to Saudi Arabia, are light, portable weapons that are fired from a soldier's shoulder.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,005,000 from the restructuring of debt. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to a fiscal year ended Dec. 31, effective Aug 31, 1983.

title: Officer Indicted In Youth's Beating
description: A city police officer has been indicted on charges that he assaulted a handcuffed teen-ager after arresting him on charges of possessing a stolen car, resisting arrest and other offenses, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Marcos Is Said to Seek An Expanded Assembly
description: Spokesmen for President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that a special session of Parliament that he has called would consider adding 18 appointed members to the body. But they later retracted the statement, saying the agenda had not been set.

title: THEATER: KEVIN WADE'S 'MR. & MRS.'
description: IN his engaging first play, ''Key

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SAN JOSE BOND RATINGS CALLED INTO QUESTION
description: Bond ratings of San Jose, Calif., were called into question yesterday after the city announced a $60 million loss from investing in long-term Treasury bonds. The city's general obligation bonds carried high-grade ratings of Aa-1 from Moody's Investors Service and AA from the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Explosion Kills 6 in England
description: An explosion believed to have been caused by methane gas ripped through an underground water plant today, killing at least 6 people, injuring 33 others and reducing the structure to rubble, rescue officials said. Witnesses said a "ball of fire" tore through the plant in rural Abbeystead in Lancashire, 200 miles northwest of London, as a tour group was visiting it. There were conflicting reports on casualities, but a police spokesman in Preston, the nearest large town, said at least six died.

title: CONCERT: PREVIN LEADS NEW HARBISON WORK
description: JOHN HARBISON, who has been the house composer of the Pittsburgh Symphony since 1982, last evening brought to Avery Fisher Hall one of the fruits of that association, a 34- minute ballet score entitled ''Ulysses' Bow.'' He composed the piece for the orchestra and its music director, Andre Previn, under a Meet the Composer residency arrangement.

title: DURGAN SIGNS FOR LESS SALARY
description: One day after he and three other veteran regulars had been waived by the Cosmos in a dispute over salaries, Jeff Durgan today became the first of them to sign a new, lower-paying contract with the team. Another of the waived players, Steve Moyers, also agreed to a new contract, and his signing appeared imminent.

title: CITY MAY SEEK LAND-USE REVIEW ON MORE PROJECTS
description: The Koch administration may subject more of its land-use proposals to a review procedure involving local planning boards as the result of strong local opposition to two recent Brooklyn projects, the city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday.

title: RENOVATION OF 2 HIGH-VICTORIAN ROOMS
description: WHEN Laura and John D. Rockefeller came to New York a century ago, they moved into a mansion at 4 West 54th Street. It had been furnished in high Victorian style by the previous owner, Arabella Duval Worsham, who became Mrs. Collis P. Huntington, wife of the railroad magnate.

title: ALLCITY INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Market Place; Oil Company Bucks Trend
description: IN the midst of a despirited stock market, the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) is riding high. On Monday and Tuesday its shares did something no other equity on the New York Stock Exchange could match: they registered back-to-back, 52-week highs.

title: World Bank Testing Payments Lid
description: The World Bank, seeking ways to ease the strains of indebtedness on the third world, has designed a new lending technique that combines a ceiling on repayment installemnts with the bank's first credit guarantee.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Japan's New Ceramics Drive
description: Here in the heart of Japan's ceramics industry, the Noritake Company produces th china for which it is known throughout the world. But near the dishes in a company showroom are some newer Noritake ceramic products -- pump components, digital displays for electronic devices and parts usd in the molding of engine blades for the American F-15 fighter.

title: Writer Acquitted
description: Michael Katz, a New York Times boxing writer, was acquitted today of charges he punched an undercover police officer in the face during a scuffle that followed a World Boxing Council bout between Tim Witherspoon and Greg Page last March 9 at the Las Vegas Convention Center. Justice of the Peace James Bixler also dismissed a charge of disorderly conduct against Mr. Katz following testimony in a non-jury trial.

title: Hoffman Is Loman Till July 1
description: Dustin Hoffman yesterday agreed to extend his performance in the revival of ''Death of a Salesman'' through July 1, according to representatives of both the actor and the producer of the play. The sold-out engagement of Arthur Miller's Pulitzer Prize-winning play at the Broadhurst was to have ended June 10.

title: Beatrice Proposal Draws Warnings
description: Two major rating agencies warned yesterday that the Beatrice Foods Company's long-term bonds might be downgraded if the company proceeded with its proposed acquisition of Esmark.

title: Phone-Computer Ruling Near
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to reach a decision soon that telephone officials believe could lead to "an explosion" in the use of computer terminals in homes and businesses.

title: QUANTUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $814,000.

title: Protectionism Is Assailed
description: Americans have had to pay from $2 billion to $4 billion more a year for clothing because of an agreement that limits imports from poor countries. A.W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, said today.

title: LIFE WITH CONSTITUENTS WHO KNOW THE SCORE
description: It was 8 o'clock on a weekday morning, two hours before the House convened, and Representative Stan Parris stood before a senior class at West Springfield High School, in Virginia. In the course of his lecture he asked the students to identify Sri Lanka as either ''an island in the Indian Ocean, something you put on spaghetti or a Southeast Asian disease.''

title: MEYER DRUCKER, AN ARBITRATOR
description: Meyer Drucker, an independent arbitrator for the building service industry and other industries in the metropolitan area and former executive secretary of the State Mediation Board, died of cancer Monday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 66 years old and lived in Woodside, Queens.

title: KOCH ACTS TO BOLSTER DRIVE TO HALT ABUSE OF CHILDREN
description: Mayor Koch yesterday added a $7.5 million program to his proposed budget for next year to hire 172 child-abuse social workers and 190 clerical and instructor personnel for the city's child welfare agency.

title: RENOVATION FOR ELLIS I. IS OUTLINED
description: The Great Hall on Ellis Island, once the clearinghouse for millions of immigrants, will include museums, theaters and a computerized genealogy room under final renovation plans announced yesterday.

title: Bank Fund Yields Post Rise Again
description: Annual effective yields on money market deposit accounts posted their 17th consective weekly increase in the week ended Wednesday, exceeding the previous 16-week run that ended in September, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
LOCKS FOR PRIVACY
description: PRIVACY locks, commonly a push button in the middle of the doorknob on a bathroom or bedroom door, can be a great convenience. A more elegant knob or a lever handle with a similar locking feature can also be installed.

title: TOCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
92 More Charges Filed In Child Molesting Case
description: Prosecutors today filed 92 additional child molestation counts against the 76- year-old founder of a preschool center and her six former aides.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1984
description: Companies Beatrice raised its bid for Esmark to $2.9 billion, or $60 a share, after Kohlberg, Kravis withdrew its own offer of $2.4 billion, food industry sources said. Esmark's chairman is understood to have accepted the offer and granted Beatrice an option to buy its food operations. The two boards are to vote on the deal today. (Page D1.) Continental Illinois Bank said its situation had ''stabilized'' since a multibillion-dollar rescue package was assembled last week. Although the run on the bank had about ended, the bank added, it was still drawing on its credit line. And it said it was less interested in being taken over than officials had indicated. (D1.)

title: ACCORD ON STOLEN OBJECTS
description: The Guatemalan Foreign Minister, Fernando Andrade, said today that he and Secretary of State George P. Shultz had signed an agreement on Monday that commits the United States to the recovery and return of stolen Guatemalan cultural and archeological objects.

title: ALGONQUIN MERCANTILE reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $109,631. c-The company changed its fiscal year-end from June 30 to March 31 and did not provide year-ago results.

title: HENRY G. DAVIS
description: Henry G. Davis, a retired financier and investment banker, died Tuesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn.

title: RASMUSSEN SPARKLES IN DEBUT
description: Dennis Rasmussen, called up from the Yankees' Columbus minor league team just last Sunday, allowed only two hits tonight in an eight-inning debut, and New York went on to a 3-0 victory over the Seattle Mariners .

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a foreign currency translation loss of $576,000 for the quarter, a foreign currency translation gain of $389,000 for the 9 months and income from discontinued operations of $35,952,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,504,000 for the quarter and $13,872,000 for the 9 months and foreign currency translation gains of $225,000 for the quarter and $206,000 for the 9 months.

title: 2 East Germans Set Swim Marks
description: Two East German swimmers competing in their country's national championships shattered world records today, the state news agency ADN reported.

title: GAMMA BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ACCOUNTS
description: * Quaker Oats Co., Chicago, to Backer & Spielvogel for an unnamed cereal.

title: LED COAL OPERATORS' GROUPS
description: Joseph E. Moody, the former president of the Southern Coal Producers' Association and later of the National Bituminous Coal Operators Association, both industry trade groups, died Tuesday of Alzheimer's disease at his home on Cape Cod. He was 81 years old.

title: Ford Recalls 4,300 Chassis
description: The Ford Motor Company said Monday that it had recalled 4,300 E-350 Econoline cutaway chassis models for replacement fo fuel-tank supports. The company said the vehicles, which ranged from 1980 to early-1984 models, were built as shuttle buses and small transit buses and are used principally for airport shuttle and intra-campus transport. A spokesman said the fuel tank supports may loosen and possibly crack.

title: CBS MOVES TO HALT WESTMORELAND SUIT
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it could prove that military intelligence officers in Vietnam had conspired to falsify data on the size of enemy forces, and it asked a Federal court judge to dismiss Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit challenging a broadcast that alleged the conspiracy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UPSTAGING Next Wednesday, from 11:24 A.M. until 2:28 P.M., the biggest show in New York will be the annular eclipse, in which the moon will be directly in front of the sun and blotting out 92 percent of it as seen in our neighborhood. (It will do even better in the nation's Southeast). This celestial dark- out, the most impressive around here until 2004, has propelled the Hayden Planetarium, 81st Street and Central Park West, into a stir of preparation, starting today.

title: Out of the Race
description: Jacques Villeneuve of Canada, who suffered a concussion last week during practice, will not be allowed to drive in the Indianapolis 500 Sunday because he has not sufficiently recovered, the medical director of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway said.

title: As Tension Rises in the Gulf, Role for U.S. Becomes Issue
description: The tensions in the Persian Gulf area, caused by the extension of the Iran-Iraq war to attacks on the ships of other countries, have raised questions about the war and about possible American involvement in it. Here, in question-and-answer form, are the major factors that will influence decisions on American involvement.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELEDATA II reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Giant Potential
description: Should Bill Roberts become a starter as a rookie, achieve all-pro status in time and be elected to pro football's Hall of Fame, he would only begin to atone for the misjudgments and mistakes by the Giants with regard to his predecessors.

title: DONALD MCGANNON, A FORMER CHAIRMAN OF BROADCAST GROUP
description: Donald H. McGannon, the retired chairman of Group W, Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc., died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at a convalescent home in Chester, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: Where's the Search for Chancellor?
description: Just two weeks ago, after accepting the resignation of Schools Chancellor Anthony Alvarado, the president of New York City's Board of Education, James Regan, promised to conduct the search for a successor in a ''deliberate and responsible'' manner. Now the board, with the silent blessing of Mayor Koch, is rushing to hand the job to Nathan Quinones, who has served as Acting Chancellor for two months. Students, parents and the public have a right to ask: Where's the search?

title: A CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SPANISH ARCHITECTURE
description: The Japanese Sword, Kenzen Institute, 152 West 26th Street, 741-2281. Today through Saturday, over 100 Japanese swords, mounts and fittings will be on display. Demonstrations in sword polishing, blade carving, lacquering, handle-wrapping and making a habaki (the metal collar between the guard and the blade) will be held daily.

title: ROCKETRY PROJECT PLANNED IN ALASKA
description: The Army plans to build a rocket-launching base in the Aleutian Islands for monitonng Soviet missile tests as part of its burgeoning effort to develop weapons that can destroy enemy nuclear missiles in flight.

title: Warner meeting
description: Warner Communications Inc. expects to be profitable during the second half of the year, its chairman, Steven Ross, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting.

title: Blue Shield Wins Jersey Rate Rise
description: Rate increases have been approved that will provide New Jersey Blue Shield with an additional $29.9 million a year and affect 1.3 million subscribers of the medical insurance concern.

title: Reports of Insider Trading
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Dow Posts Drop of 2.82, to 1,113.80
description: Stock prices continued to decline yesterday in less active trading, although issues responding to actual or rumored takeover news made strong gains.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Schnellenberger Leaving
description: Howard Schnellenberger, the University of Miami football coach, met with his lawyers today and was expected

title: Toys 'R' Us Net Rises
description: Toys "R" Us Inc. yesterday reported an earnings rise of 77.8 percent for its latest quarter. The Rochelle Park, N.Y., company's net income in thethree months ended April 29 was $9.6 million, or 17 cents a share, up from $5.4 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 36.2 percent, to $247.4 million, from $181.7 million.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 23
The U.N. Today; May 24, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (MERIDIAN, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: NANCY MEEHAN AND COMPANY
description: NANCY MEEHAN'S mostly gentle, flowing dances seem to exist in a time and place of their own. But clearly where the dances are presented does add to their effect.

title: A 'DEPOSITION' FOR MUNSON
description: On the book jacket, Reggie Jackson is staring straight at you, his chin on his left hand$ as if he were studying a pitcher, a slight smile below his mustache. The title is ''Reggie,'' the subtitle is ''The Autobigraphy,'' but a better title might have been ''The Ego and I.''

title: Robert Ormes, an Executive Of a Science Magazine, Dies
description: Robert V. Ormes, associate publisher of Science, journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, died of leukemia Monday in Alexandria, Va. He was 62 years old.

title: JURY IS TOLD PISANI HAD FRAUD IN MIND
description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani was portrayed by a prosecutor yesterday as a public official who had ''fraud on his mind and larceny in his heart.''

title: BAKER IS BACKED ON CARTER PAPERS
description: In a two-volume report released today, a House subcommittee said that a "credible witness" had "corroborated" the account of James A. Baker 3d, the White House Chief of Staff, about how the 1980 Reagan campaign received some of President Carter's 1980 briefing materials.

title: A Departure From SSC&B
description: A memo distributed in the office of SSC&B yesterday announced that Malcolm D. MacDougall, president and director of creative services for the domestic company, would resign. SSC&B is one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Mets-Giants Rained Out
description: The Mets' game against the San Francisco Giants last night at Shea

title: BUSH SAYS ARMY MORALE IS AT A PEAK
description: Vice President Bush told graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy today that they would be leading a proud Army, where standards were improving and ''morale is higher than it's been in years.''

title: Bridge: Cheating Dispute Is Revived In Connecticut Tournament
description: An echo of an old controversy resounded in the middle of a tournament in Stamford, Conn., last weekend. In the eye of the storm was Steve Sion of Wallingford, Conn.

title: WESTERN ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sexual Harassment Suit Filed Against ABC-TV
description: A former ABC-TV employee has filed a $1 million lawsuit against the network and three of its officials, charging that an executive sexually harassed her and that she was unjustly dismissed after reporting the problem.

title: Income Halved At Firestone
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that its second-quarter income from continuing operations fell 50 percent, to $11 million, or 22 cents a share, from $22 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. was awarded a total of $301.6 million in two contracts by the Navy for high- speed antiradiation missiles in the fiscal years 1983 and 1984, the Defense Department said.

title: THE CRIME THAT COSTS TAXPAYERS $100 BILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: Call for Alliance Splits an Anti-Sandinista Group
description: The leaders of a Nicaraguan insurgent group here are split over demands reportedly made indirectly by the United States that they form an alliance with rebels based in Honduras.

title: Disney Stock, Volume Leap Walt Disney Productions Inc.
description: stock jumped $3.25 a share yesterday, to close at $66.25. making it the second-biggest gainer

title: HART SWEEPS NONBINDING CONTEST ON IDAHO PRESIDENTIAL PREFERENCE
description: Senator Gary Hart has swept Idaho's nonbinding Presidential preference primary, and he hopes it will provide momentum against Walter F. Mondale when convention delegates are chosen Thursday night in Democratic caucuses around the state.

title: Jersey's Crucial Primary; Intense Campaigning by Mondale and Hart Reflects Importance of Democratic Contest
description: The intense campaigning in New Jersey this week by Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart empphasized the unaccustomed importance that both candidates attach to a primary that, in other recent Democratic Presidential campaigns, has served as a postcript to the nomination battle.

title: Advice and Valium at a Walk-In Clinic in Canton
description: Every Monday and Wednesday morning, Dr. ZhaoGengyuan dons his white physician's jacket and sits in his third-floor clinic at a suburban hospital, sympathetically hearing out the compulsions, phobias, inadequacies and phychosomatic ailments of his patients.

title: HARDEE FARMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $185,000. c-The company changed its fiscal year-end from May 31 to March 31 and did not provide comparable year-ago results.

title: TIGERS EQUAL MARK AT 16-0 ON THE ROAD
description: Lance Parrish's two-run homer in the seventh inning tonight gave the Tigers a 4-2 victory over the California Angels that enabled Detroit to equal the American League record of 16 consecutive triumphs on the road.

title: Changes at Lotus
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had reorganized its sales efforts for its popular Lotus 1-2-3 business analysis programs.

title: Judge Calls Case in Slayings of 4 Chruchwomen Strong Enough for Convictions
description: The trial of five former national guardsmen charged in the killings of four United States churchwomen in 1980 opened today. The presiding judge said the evidence was strong enough to result in a guilty verdict from the five jurors.

title: Stockman on '85 Budget Cuts
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, said today that a second Reagan Administration would have only six months to push through Congress the budget cuts needed to finish the task President Reagan began in 1981.

title: Burger King Wins Military Contract
description: The Pillsbury Company's Burger King unit said it had won a competitive bid to open fast-food restaurants for the Army and Air Force Exchange Services at selected military installations worldwide.

title: House Adopts Ban On Weapon Testing For Space Warfare
description: The House voted 238 to 181 tonight to prohibit the testing of an antisatellite weapon against an object in space so long as the Soviet Union continues its voluntary moratorium against such tests.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILLIAMS-SONOMA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: CONCILIATION IN HOUSING BIAS ISN'T ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about projected electricity demand gave an incorrect unit of measurement for an Energy Department forecast and the capacity of the nuclear plant at Shoreham, L.I. The references should have been to gigawatts, or thousands of megawatts.

title: Serving for No. 4
description: Martina Navratilova was seeded first, Chris Evert Lloyd second and Hana Mandlikova third for the French Open tennis championships, which begins Monday.

title: Experiments Seem to Back U.S. on 'Yellow Rain'
description: Two Canadian experiments have cast doubt on the theory that the "yellow rain" poisons found in Southeast Asia might be a natural occurrence rather than chemical warfare agents, according to reports presented at an international conference on chemical weapons, which ended here today.

title: Details of Seabrook Rescue Bid; Exchange of Power Involved
description: The Federal Government has agreed to back a new deal that will help save the troubled Seabrook nuclear project because the revised arrangement will leave the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative with a plant no matter what the fate of Seabrook, according to the Rural Electrification Administration.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: How to Fill a Gap

title: Charter's President Resigns
description: Raymond K. Mason, Who built a near-bankrupt family lumber business into the Charter Company, a multibillion-dollar oil and insurance conglomerate, resigned yesterday as the company's president and chief executive.

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit at selected institutions on Wednesday, May 23, 1984. Some six-month C.D. yields assume reinvestment after six months.

title: FOR LIMITED VISION, IDEAS FOR THE HOME
description: EVERYTHING in Vernon Vergara's home is well organized. ''I always leave things where I will find them,'' he explained. ''I insist that my roommates inform me of any changes in the placement of things. I don't want to be frantic when I'm in a rush.''

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
First 1984 Hurricanes Named Arthur, Alma
description: Arthur will open the hurricane season on the East Coast this year, while the first such West Coast storm will be Alma, the National Weather Service announced today.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: The summer solstice is still a month away, but very soon now, within 24 hours in fact, the great lotioned army that marks the unofficial beginning of the season will abandon its winter quarters and begin to make its crowded encampment by the sea.

title: SEAGULL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TAMING OF THE NEWS CONFERENCE
description: It was a couple minutes before the start of President Reagan's news conference Tuesday night and the White House spokesman, Larry M. Speakes, had just finished his usual run-through of the ground rules.

title: JAZZ: WIDESPREAD ORCHESTRA
description: IN the six years since the Widespread Jazz Orchestra, originally known as the Widespread

title: PEOPLE;
description: Marcio M. Moreira , an executive vice president, named international creative director of McCann-Erickson Worldwide.

title: Paper's Appeal In Rapes Denied
description: The Connecticut Appellate Court today rejected an effort by a newspaper to force a judge to reveal the names of four purported victims in a rape trial.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Anchor Hocking Corp, a dinnerware company in Lancaster, Ohio, said it was considering curtailing a portion of its glass tableware manufacturing facilities and may close a plant.

title: Air Florida's Mounting Woes
description: Air Florida, the upstart airline that was going to show the established carriers how to thrive under deregulation, is now reeling from one financial crisis to another.

title: Surgeon General Links Smoking to Lung Disease in Nonsmokers
description: The Surgeon General of the United States, C. Everett Koop, said today that there was "very solid" evidence that nonsmokers had suffered lung disease from exposure to cigarette smoke.

title: A BANKRUPT POLICY
description: To those watching from outside, the torment of Andrei Sakharov and Yelena Bonner is many things. It is a human tragedy: the destruction of two great spirits. It is a brutal example of Soviet indifference to the claims of humanity. And it is telling evidence of the bankruptcy of Ronald Reagan's policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: 3 Democrats to Appear Separately on Public TV
description: Walter F. Mondale, Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson have each accepted invitations from WNET/Channel 13 to appear on one- hour call-in shows on successive nights beginning Saturday.

title: Teacher Under Fire Resigns 2d Position
description: Dr. Conway L. Lackman, a 46-year-old Rutgers University economics professor who resigned last week after accusations he had plagiarized an article, has also resigned from Rollins College, where he has been teaching for the last year, according to a Rollins official.

title: LONDON'S BLOSSOMING CHELSEA DISPLAY
description: When Robin Herbert, the new president of the Royal Horticultural Society, was in America studying for an M.B.A. at Harvard, he would escape frequently to the Arnold Arboretum in Boston to study the trees. Now a London banker, he is overseeing his first Chelsea Flower Show, the 27-acre gardening extravaganza, which opened Tuesday and which the society has sponsored since l9l3 on the grounds of the Royal Hospital in Chelsea.

title: SARDI'S RESTAURANT SOLD
description: Sardi's Restaurant, one of the theater world's best-known meeting places for six decades, has been sold. The new owner is Show Biz Restaurant Inc., and the managing director, who is said to be a principal of Show Biz Restaurant, is Robert Warshay.

title: Defense Concedes Videotape at Trial Shows DeLorean Discussing Cocaine
description: John Z. DeLorean's chief lawyer, in an impassioned statement to reporters, conceded today that his client was talking about cocaine in a videotaped conversation played at his trial today and apoligized for the defendant's judgment.

title: Athletes Campaign In Jersey for President
description: A group of professional and amateur athletes, including Roger Maris, the onetime Yankee home-run champion, and Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight boxing champion, toured New Jersey today to urge voters to suppport President Reagan.

title: OVERHEARD IN OTHER PEOPLE'S HOUSES
description: LAURIE HARROD says that she likes ''to see how people take their space and use it.'' Marilyn Cooper calls it ''a way to see beautiful objects that I ordinarily wouldn't.'' Gail Newman, who lives in Cleveland, says it's ''a way of finding that people in New York can live like anyone else.'' And another visitor said, ''Frankly, I simply love to snoop.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $150 million issue of Commonwealth of Massachusetts general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with serial bond yields ranging from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.50 percent in 1994 and 10.60 percent in 1999, while term bonds due in 2004 were offered with a yield of 10 3/4 percent.

title: Fluke fishing in Margate
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Fluke fishing in Margate Bay continues to be superb. Earlier this week, 25 people aboard the party boat Fish'n Fun IV caught 323 fluke in four hours of angling. The boat is docked at Capt. Andy's Marina and the run to the fishing grounds takes less than l0 minutes. Bluefish have been spotty, but great numbers of them are expected at any moment. Seaside Park, N.J.: A few bluefish have been taken, but the water temperature, in the low 50'searlier this week, has kept most of them away. Point Pleasant, N.J.: While awaiting the arrival of the bluefish, the party boats are concentrating on half-day ocean trips for fluke.

title: LEADERS OF COPTS PRAISES MUBARAK
description: For the last 13 years Pope Shenuda III has served as spiritual leader of Egypt's six million Coptic Christians. But for nearly three years his physical realm has been confined to a remote monastery in this stark desert.

title: N.F.L. Approves Sale of Broncos
description: The sale of 60 percent of the Denver Broncos to a group headed by Patrick Bowlen of Edmonton, Alberta, was approved today by owners attending the National Football League spring meeting, which runs through Friday.

title: Two House Panels Back Stiffer Rights Laws
description: Two House cocmmittess today brushed aside Administration objections and unanimously reported out legislation that would stiffen enforcement of existing civil rights laws.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Every Deficit Chip Counts
description: The Senate and House bills to reduce future budget deficits accomplish more than anyone expected at the start of 1984. But they still amount only to a ''down payment'' on hard fiscal choices still to be made. If nothing more is done, the deficit three years from now could still exceed $200 billion. The sooner Congress acts the better, and it could do even a little more this year.

title: Yes, Await a Request From the Gulf for Help
description: The letter that President Reagan sent this week to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia reiterated a standing American offer of military support on the condition that the United States had access to airfield, radar and other facilities near the head of the Persian Gulf, The President emphasized, and right so, that the United States would be willing to help only if publicly requested to do so by the Gulf states. Saudi Arabia has made no such request, and Washington should stand by its original position.

title: Aid Plan For School Districts
description: School districts stung by the recent collapse of two Wall Street securities firms will be given legislative authority to borrow against anticipated property taxes and state aid payments, the Senate and Assembly sponsors of the measure said today.

title: Renault '83 Loss Wider
description: France's state-owned Renault Auto Group said today that its consolidated losses widened in 1983 to the equivalent of $190 million from $156 million in 1982.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about television coverage of the Presidential campaign in New Jersey gave an incorrect date for a visit to Trenton by Walter F. Mondale. It was last week.

title: IN A REFORMATORY IN '66, AN M.D. TODAY
description: In a way, Mary Groda-Lewis says, she is glad she was arrested that day when she was 16.

title: ADDITIONS TO GARDENING REFERENCE SHELF
description: Reference books are especially valuable during the busy spring gardening season and there is a wide range of recent volumes to choose from.

title: CELTICS GAIN FINAL ROUND
description: The Boston Celtics' rebounding was so dominant tonight that not even their sloppy floor play could deter them from clinching the Eastern Conference title at Boston Garden.

title: May 11-20 Car Sales Rose 22.1%
description: he nation's major automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars in the May 11-20 period rose 22.1 percent from a year earlier, on a daily selling rate basis.

title: Delay for Vasquez
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board has postponed until June 1 a hearing at which attorneys for Jacinto Vasquez will petition for a new hearing on the jockey's one-year suspension for attempting to bribe Eddie Maple , a fellow jockey, at Saratoga in 1974. The postponement came on a request from Vasquez's attorney, Ronald Fischetti , who said he needed more time to produce key witnesses, whose identity he has not disclosed.

title: Bombings in Colombia Aimed at U.S. Targets
description: Nine bombs meant for United States and Honduran targets exploded in Bogota and in Cali, killing 2 people and wounding 11, the police said today.

title: Use of Deadly Air BombsReported in Afghanistan
description: Jane's Defense Weekly reported today that Soviet planes are dropping ''liquid fire'' bombs on Moslem guerrillas in Afghanistan and fuel-air explosives that set off shock waves that kill anyone within a quarter-mile.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pepsico Sells Unit
description: Pepsico Inc. said it had signed a contract for the sale of its Lee Way Motor Freight division to Commercial Lovelace Motor Freight Inc. for an undisclosed sum. The company had earlier announced it was negotiating to sell the division. The sale is subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Couple Strangled In 'Ritual' Slaying
description: An elderly Russian immigrant couple was found strangled with kitchen towels and lying side by side yesterday in their Manhattan apartment, the police said.

title: Whittaker Marine
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it was negotiating the sale of its marine group, with the exception of the survival systems division, to a newly formed company in a leveraged buyout. The company said the purchase price would be substantially in excess of book value and that it would buy a large minority interest in the new company, subject to the receipt of financing. Whittaker said that in the first half of its fiscal year the marine group, including survival, had sales of $59.6 million and a pretax operating profit of $4,241,000.

title: McNeilab Inc. Sues F.D.A.
description: McNeilab Inc., manufacturers of Tylenol, sued the Food and Drug Administration for approving the nonprescription sale of a pain reliever - ibuprofen - with the condition that the agency regulate its advertising to minimize use by patients for whom it is unsuitable. The suit claims that the F.D.A. does not have the authority to regulate nonprescription drug advertising; the Federal Trade Commission, it said, has that responsibility.

title: BIRDVIEW SATELLITE COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCOUTING ; NEWEST DODGERS
description: On opening day of the Pacific Coast League baseball season last month, the starting outfield of the Albuquerque Dukes consisted of Franklin Stubbs, R. J. Reynolds and Lemmie Miller. Less than two months later, the Dukes have a new outfield because those three players now play for the parent club, the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ART: WALT KUHN AND INFLUENCE OF PARIS
description: IF Walt Kuhn were alive, he

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RESTAURANTS
description: A French bistro with Polish accent.

title: DYSAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,405,000 from the sale of securities. c-Net income which includes gains from the sale of securities of $20,220,000 for the quarter and $23,505,000 for the 6 months.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income

title: ISRAELI OFFICERS CHARGED IN BOMBINGS
description: Criminal charges were brought today against two Israeli Army officers in the West Bank military Government in connection with the bombing attacks on three Arab Mayors in 1980.

title: DISPUTE HAMPERS U.S.-PERU FLIGHTS
description: Air travel between the United States and Peru continued on an improvised basis yesterday after the rupture early this week of agreements by which airlines of the two countries carried on regular direct service.

title: REAGAN, AT C.I.A., COMMENDS CASEY AS AGENCY'S HEAD
description: President Reagan today praised the performance of William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence, but offered no comment on a Congressional report charging that crimes might have been committed in the 1980 Reagan Presidential campaign, which Mr. Casey directed.

title: SOUTHLAND CHAIRMAN TESTIFIES
description: The chairman of the Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, testified in court yesterday that he ''cannot recall one way or the other'' whether so-called entertainment expenses were discussed at a 1977 meeting attended by himself and other company officials.

title: BRIEFING
description: Movement at U.S.I.A.

title: ON THE LONG AND BLISSFUL MARRIAGE OF TECHNOLOGY AND THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After $2,800,000 additional depreciation, depletion, and amortization due to a writedown of both producing and non-producing oil and gas properites.

title: CLYDE A. FARNSWORTH, 76, DIES
description: Clyde A. Farnsworth, a foreign correspondent for The Associated Press, the Scripps- Howard News Alliance, The Chicago Tribune, Time Magazine and The New York Times, died of cancer May 24 at Arlington Hospital. He was 76 years old and had been a resident of the Washington area since 1978.

title: U.N. Official Assails Research Body's Book
description: The spokesman for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations said today that the book ''A World Without the U.N.,'' which was published on Wednesday by the Heritage Foundation, reflects views that are erroneous and misguided.

title: The Cold Winter in Gorky
description: All that is ugly and much that is dangerous in Soviet behavior is in evidence in the worsening tragedy of Andrei Sakharov. Wedded to an ideology that cannot admit error, the Kremlin can only respond to a stubborn dissenter's challenge with self- destructive vindictiveness. In this pathetically unequal duel with an aging scientist and his ailing wife, his tormentors fear that any concession will mark them as weak, thus exposing only their own insecurity.

title: F.C.C. Authorizes Fiber Optic Project
description: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized eight United States companies, led by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to participate in the construction of the world's first fiber optic undersea telephone cable.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Muhammad Ali , the former heavyweight champion, will carry the Olympic torch about six-tenths of a mile Sunday in Louisville before it heads south through Kentucky. . . . Joe Sambito , a relief pitcher, is scheduled to return to the Houston Astros today, slightly more than two years after he went on the disabled list with elbow problems that required three operations. . . . Felix Quinones , a jockey at Monmouth Park, has been suspended indefinitely for allegedly accepting a $300 bribe from an undercover state police detective to throw a race in 1981, officials said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Taxing the Rev. Mr. Moon
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon may have felt persecuted and outnumbered in his battle to stay out of prison for tax fraud, but he was not without advocates and friends. His wealthy Unification Church hired superb lawyers to seek reversal of his conviction and review in the Supreme Court. Several large religious organizations filed briefs as friends of the Court warning of threats to religious liberty, even a wave of tyranny. A public relations firm worked hard to create the impression that the case had ominous significance.

title: FAMILIES OF VICTIMS IN STOUFFER INN FIRE WIN $48.5 MILLION
description: A Federal judge today announced a $48.5 million settlement of the civil suits stemming from the fire at a Stouffer's Inn that killed 26 executives.

title: ASEA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales figures represent invoiced sales.

title: ACORN DRAWS A BUMPER CROP OF FILLIES
description: She was lucky to win the Kentucky Oaks and lucky to win the Black-Eyed Susan, but Lucky Lucky Lucky will need more than good fortune to win the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park tomorrow.

title: SOLTI CANCELS BATREUTH STINT
description: Georg Solti, the conductor of the controversial production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle unveiled last summer at the Bayreuth Festival, will not lead it this year, it was announced yesterday in Bayreuth, West Germany.

title: MITTERRAND URGES NEW COMMON MARKET PACT
description: President Francois Mitterrand called today for a renegotiation of the constitution of the Common Market countries and suggested that those not interested - a clear allusion to Britain - could stay out.

title: CONTEMPORARY JEWELRY AS ART
description: Right at the entrance to the contemporary jewelry exhibition at American Craft Museum II, you know the word ''jewelry'' has been stretched to include more than rings, bracelets and necklaces. In the window are two hats made of aluminum screening by Debra Chase.

title: 'Real Thing' Honored, With 'Sunday in Park'
description: The Drama Desk, an organization of theater journalists, yesterday named Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing'' the outstanding play of the Broadway season and Stephen Sondeheim's ''Sunday in the Park with George'' the outstanding musical.

title: Pand StreetLife
description: Peter Fink, a photographer whose work was shown in several countries, died last Saturday at the St. Luke's- Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was in his 70's and lived in Manhattan and New Milford, Conn.

title: VAN PELT SKEPTICAL ON GIANTS' FUTURE
description: Pro football's minicamps usually have an air of optimism, but there was none coming today from Brad Van Pelt. Van Pelt, the veteran Giant linebacker, reiterated his desire to be traded, saying that he was weary of playing on a losing team and that he saw no particular promise for the coming season.

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS DUNN AND A.B.T.
description: DANCE lovers who are also music lovers were able to hear two fine 20th-century ballet scores on Wednesday, Stravinsky's ''Pulcinella'' and Prokofiev's ''Cinderella.''

title: Australian Output
description: Australia's major areas of production declined in April from March but were up from a year earlier, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said today. April production in 18 of 24 categories was lower than March's level, but 19 of 24 improved from a year earlier. Production of beer and bricks rose from both the previous month and a year earlier, as production of cars, trucks, iron, steel and cement fell from March but rose from a year earlier.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 17, 1983.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $7,000 for the quarter and $80,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary loss of $209,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a loss of $37,000 from discontinued operations.

title: METZENBAUM RETURNS $250,000 FEE, CITING POSSIBLE MISPERCEPTION
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the leading critic of Edwin Meese 3d's financial dealings, today returned a $250,000 finder's fee he had received from a political supporter who sold an elegant Washington hotel near the White House.

title: POLISH AND JEWISH AMERICANS' JOINT TASK
description: To the Editor: Contrary to Dr. Wisniewski, the Nazis chose Poland for the ''final solu

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $164,000 for the quarter and $552,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Lights Go On in Brooklyn
description: It's been strictly a Manhattan show

title: Bridge: Charity Funds Get $62,000 From Events in New York
description: Charity was the big winner in New York bridge circles this week. The Children's Cancer Fund collected about $14,000 from the Cavendish invitational events over the weekend, and the U.J.A.-Federation of Jewish Philanthopies profited by $48,000 from its annual Pro-Am event.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,113,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $320,000 for the quarter and $1,043,000 for the 9 months. d-After extraordinary gains of $4,874,000, $19,500,000 and $46,906,000 and an extraordinary loss of $17,200,000.

title: BILL ON INFORMATION ACT IS ASSAILED AT HEARING
description: A bill that proposes to modify the Freedom of Information Act was sharply criticized today by representatives of news organizations and public interest groups at a Congressional hearing. They said the changes would lead to withholding of valuable Government information now available to the public.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUSPECT IN ROBBERIES AND RAPES ON EAST SIDE IS ARRESTED IN SHOP
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday after police officers said they watched him try to rob an ice cream store on the Upper East Side.

title: WORKING FAMILIES IN SWEDEN AND U.S.
description: The majority of mothers of children under the age of 6 are in the labor force in both the United States and Sweden, but it is more difficult for American women to combine careers and motherhood because of a lack of support from government and business. That was the message delivered recently to a conference of the Coalition of Labor Union Women and the Swedish Information Service.

title: 20th Century Sculpture
description: An exhibition titled ''20th Century Sculpture: Selections From the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' will be on display at the Storm King Art Center, Old Pleasant Hill Road, Mountainville, N.Y., through Oct. 31.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
A BONUS FOR BURGER EFFORTS
description: IN the advertising agency business,

title: MUSIC: DAVID GILMOUR SINGS
description: TO hear just three Pink Floyd songs, fans of the now-dormant group filled the Beacon Theater Tuesday and sat through some 90 minutes of undistinguished material by David Gilmour, Pink Floyd's guitarist. Mr. Gilmour has a place in millions of record collections as the singer of Pink Floyd's ''Money,'' which he did not write. But his husky voice and slow-moving guitar solos could not enliven his own songs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transcription error, a dispatch from Bahrain Wednesday on the Persian Gulf conflict referred incorrectly to the Gulf Cooperation Council. Oman is a member; Jordan is not.

title: PHILHARMONIC: LEINSDORF AND MAHLER SYMPHONY
description: THE season now ending has been an uneven and disjointed one for the New York Philharmonic. One guest, Rafael Kubelik, suffered an arm injury and dropped out of his concerts. Then, Zubin Mehta, whose contract as music director had recently been extended into 1990, had to be operated on for an elbow inflammation, so he lost the last six weeks of his schedule. That brought in a string of hurriedly summoned guests, who did what they could on short notice.

title: 2 NEW STUDIES BOLSTER ATTACK ON BOXING
description: Citing two new studies of brain damage among boxers, the editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association said in today's issue that the sport should be abolished or else blows to the head should be made illegal.

title: SENATE ARMS UNIT APPROVES 7 1/2% RISE FOR PENTAGON, MIRRORING WEINBERGER REQUEST
description: The Senate Armed Services committee today approved a military authorization bill of $299 billion for the next fiscal year, including money for the Pentagon and military programs of the Department of Energy.

title: Rockefeller Group Floats Eurobond
description: The Rockefeller Group Inc. is raising $100 million through a five-year 13 1/4 percent Eurobond priced at 99 3/4 percent, the lead manager, Morgan Guaranty Ltd., said today.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today May 25, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: 3 Riveras at Sotheby's.
description: PAULETTE GODDARD acquired three works from Diego Rivera 40 years ago, including a major painting from his flower vendor series of the 1940's. All three of these works will be auctioned next Tuesday at 7 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arlen Realty and Development Corp. , a New York City holding company, said it had agreed in principle to sell its remaining real estate interests, consisting of stock holdings in the Broadstone Group Inc., to Prochen Holding Corp.; the price is estimated at $14 million.

title: Afro-Brazilian Program
description: A benefit for Zumbi, the Afro- Brazilian Cultural Association, will be held Sunday from 6 P.M. to midnight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street at Houston Street.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings figure was prior to the company's initial public offering.

title: GROUPS OFFERING TO SEEK MISSING CHILDREN ARE SPRINGING UP ACROSS NATION
description: Responding to growing concern over abductions of children, scores of volunteer and professional groups, private investigators and profit-seeking enterprises have been springing up around the country.

title: THE REGION ; ;  3 From L.I. Die In Crash on I-95
description: Three Long Island residents were killed and four other people were injured Wednesday afternoon when a tractor-trailer collided with a van and a car on Interstate 95 in this Westchester County community, the state police said.

title: GATT Sees Trade Up 6%
description: The value of world trade could expand as much as 6 percent this year, or well above the 2 percent advance recorded in 1983, the 90-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said today.

title: THE CASE FOR A WASHINGTON TILT TOWARD TEHERAN
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE VOTES OF TRISTATE AREA
description: Following are the House roll-call votes today by Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a measure to give $61.75 million in emergency military aid to El Salvador, which was approved by 267 to 154, and on a measure to deny more money for Nicaraguan rebels, which was approved by 241 to 177. An ''xxx'' denotes not voting.

title: Diner's Journal
description: RABBIT is showing up in the best places lately, served in terrines, stews, meat pies and as roasts. It is a versatile and healthful meat that can be prepared in as many ways as veal.

title: A.T.&T. PLANNING CHANGE IN PACT WITH CITY FOR MUSEUM AT TOWER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has decided against building a three-story communications museum that had been part of an agreement with New York City, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: OUTINGS AGENDA FOR CITY DWELLERS
description: Those pent up in cities often have

title: ADVERTISING
description: Foote, Cone Adding

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Artra Group, Northfield, Ill., a manufacturer of metal machinery and plastics products, has elected to its board William W. Crawford, senior vice president, general counsel and secretary of Dart & Kraft Inc.

title: BROADWAY;
description: 'Starlight Express' sparks a scramble by U.S. producers.

title: HAROLD KALT
description: Harold Kalt, retired partner in the Kalt Lumber and Kalt Realty Companies in Manhattan, died Tuesday at the home of a son, H. Worthington Kalt, in Montclair, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Smoke Rise, N.J.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES;
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale have been certified to receive Federal matching funds totaling more than $850,000, the Federal Election Commission said Wednesday.

title: Article 216171 -- No Title
description: The Charter Company reported yesterday that it lost $36.2 million in the first quarter in contrast to earnings of $952,000 in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HIROSHIMA BALLET COMES TO HUNTER
description: TOKYOIn 1952, on a stage in Hiroshima, a Japanese dance troupe performed a new ballet based on a blunt antinuclear theme. The message was not unusual, certainly, in the first city to have an atomic bomb dropped on it. But the dance company was hardly typical. Everyone - the dancers, the producer, the choreographer, the arranger - had survived the blast that destroyed Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945. By 1952, some were dying from the aftereffects, even if they did not know it.

title: SUNS' SHOOTING STIRS LAKERS
description: More than an hour after the game, Magic Johnson was still shaking his head and wondering how the Phoenix Suns had stolen his bag of tricks. Just when he and the other members of the Los Angeles Lakers seemed poised to make the Suns disappear, the Suns outdid the Lakers at their own flashy, running game.

title: IN A 'DYING' FOREST, THE GERMAN SOUL WITHERS TOO
description: More than just trees are dying in the Black Forest. As fir needles turn yellow and spruce branches sag limply, the industrial poisoning of West Germany's forests is assuming the dimensions of a spiritual, as well as an environmental, catastrophe.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: Kleinwort Benson Finance B.V. came to market with a $150 million floating-rate note issue through Credit Suisse First Boston. The notes have a coupon of 1/4 percentage point over the mean of the six-month London interbank offered rate.
