description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: A Walk Into the Past
description: Herman Storick's New York Walk- About will feature ''Fulton to South Street Seaport: The Past Preserved'' tomorrow at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. Walkers will meet at the corner of Fulton and Broadway in front of St. Paul's Chapel. Admission is $5. Information: (914) 834-5388.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Artist's Message

title: SCOUTING;
description: British Touch

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN IS FORCED TO LIMIT MISSILES FOR SAUDIS
description: Administration officials said today that unexpected opposition from members of Congress had forced President Reagan to limit the number of portable Stinger antiaircraft missiles that would be sent to Saudi Arabia for possible use against Iranian attack.

title: SPAIN'S KING IMPRESSIVE ON THE POLITICAL HIGH WIRE
description: Francisco Franco would have been aghast.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We may not know his name, but we know his courage. He is the heart, the spirit and the soul of America.'' - President Reagan. (9:1.)

title: THIS INDIANAPOLIS 300 TO GET FAST START, FOR HOME
description: Scott Whitfill and Ray Gentile are taking about 300 friends on a 1,000-mile trip to see a 500-mile race.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Trial Balloon?

title: BUSINESS DIGESTSATURDAY, MAY 26, 1984
description: Companies

title: CONCERT: ABBADO LEADS 'WOZZECK' IN CHICAGO
description: A starrily cast opera-in-concert has traditionally been the highlight and hottest ticket of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra season. Berg's ''Wozzeck'' Thursday was theoretically almost sold out, but the hall was dotted with the empty seats of subscription holders who, also by tradition, take a discreet tax deduction and return their tickets when contemporary music dominates the program. They missed a great performance.

title: Sports Illustrated Wins Libel Suit
description: A jury in Federal District Court found early today that Sports Illustrated magazine had not libeled Pam Parsons, former women's basketball coach at the University of South Carolina.

title: CLASS REUNION
description: Why have I promised to show up at a Saturday night country club dinner- dance in an Iowa town 1,500 miles away? To tell elderly strangers with familiar names what has happened to me in the 40 years since we graduated from high school? Embarrassed laughter will mask the shock of noting the drastic change in our appearances. I still have most of my hair and haven't put on weight - should I be apologetic? The class reunion may be one of the cruelest forms of torture yet devised by sentiment. And yet, I've sent in my reservation.

title: ;  Not-Guilty Plea In Extortion Case
description: The former Mayor of Atlantic City, Michael J. Matthews, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he extorted $11,000 from businesses in the community while in office.

title: JACKSON ASSAILS ADMINISTRATION'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today charged that the conviction of five former members of El Salvador's national guard for the slayings of four United States churchwomen had been an ''orchestrated scheme'' designed to bolster support here for the ''puppet regime'' of Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Instructor and Actor Held as Child Molesters
description: A dance instructor and an actor appeared in court today to face charges of sexually abusing students at the Minnesota Children's Theater and School, a month after the theater's director was arrested on similar charges.

title: Air Florida Seen Close to Key Loan
description: Air Florida is close to receiving a crucial $5 million loan from the General Electric Credit Corporation to help it meet urgent debts and keep flying, according to the airline and reports published today. Robin Cohn, a spokesman for Air Florida, said late today that the company expects to complete the loan Tuesday.

title: Black & Decker
description: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company said it had introduced a new line of electric motors that makes obsolete all existing standards for rating electric motors. The new M-series motors will have up to two- thirds fewer parts than older models.

title: Murdoch Buys A Magazine
description: News America Publishing Inc., the parent company for Rupert Murdoch's American newspapers and magazines, announced an agreement in principle to buy New Woman magazine. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SHALOM SPIEGAL, SCHOLAR, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Shalom Spiegel, a retired professor of Hebrew literature at the Jewish Theological Seminary, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHOIR: WESTENBURG CONDUCTS
description: Music resounding in the vastness of a great cathedral, echoing on stone and marble, takes on a kind of grandeur that it cannot have anywhere else. One hears resonant overtones that are lost in normal spaces, and the simple fact of long reverberation smooths over vocal impurities and rough orchestral edges.

title: Physical for Bowie
description: Sam Bowie , the Kentucky center, underwent a physical examination in Portland at the request of the Trail Blazers, who have the second pick in the college draft June 19.

title: SCIENTISTS MIX OPTIMISTS AND PESSIMISTS TO VIEW GLOBE'S FATE
description: Will the world be a better place to live in the next century, or will it become more crowded, more polluted and less stable than the globe we live on now?

title: Students Observe Day For Missing Children By The Associated Press
description: Iowa schoolchildren contributed $782 to the hunt for a classmate, toddlers were fingerprinted in Philadelphia, and Massachusetts officials pledged new efforts to find vanished children yesterday as the nation observed Missing Children's Day.

title: SCIENCE MEETING HEARS 2 SIDES OF TOXIC WASTE
description: The 150th meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science opened here with controversy yesterday when the results of a new study linking a hazardous-waste dump site in Massachusetts to ailments among people living nearby was immediately attacked by chemical industry officials attending the session.

title:
PATENTS;
 Jefferson Medal Winner
description: Donald W. Banner, a Washington attorney and former Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, will be presented with the Jefferson Medal by the New Jersey Patent Law Association on June 2. Thomas Jefferson, for whom the medal is named, was the first Commissioner of Patents and an avid inventor. Mr. Banner is president of Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a trade association representing owners of patents, trademarks and copyrights.

title: AT PARAMUS MALL, AMBIVALENCE OVER TRHE PRIMARY
description: At the age of 78 - and after 57 years as a Democrat - Frank Mamola is about to do something he never dreamed he would do in a lifetime - vote for a Republican.

title: FILM: DESERT 'FLESHBURN'
description: ''Fleshburn,'' which opened yesterday at the Warner Twin and other theaters, is an inert action movie about a crazed Vietnam veteran, who's also an American Indian, who kidnaps the four psychiatrists - three men and a woman - who had him committed. He takes them to the middle of the Arizona desert, where he leaves them to perish, with the help of the sun and his own spells.

title: No Headline
description: Defendant Brandishes =*according to one of the officers, Lieut. Paul Christopher.

title: India Puts Sikkim Under Central Rule
description: President Zail Singh proclaimed central rule in the northeastern state of Sikkim today and dissolved the state legislature after 15 of the 28 legislators from Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's ruling Congress Party resigned from the party, reducing it to a minority in the house.

title: Fire on Upper Broadway
description: Two men and a dog were rescued by firefighters last night in a fire in a three-story building at 2521 Broadway, at 94th Street.

title: REAGAN HONORS UNKNOWN AMERICAN KILLED IN VIETNAM WAR
description: A coffin bearing the remains of an unidentified American military casualty of the Vietnam War was placed in state at the Capitol Rotunda today as President Reagan prayed that ''this hero be America's last unknown.''

title: Buckner Sent to Red Sox
description: Bill Buckner, a former National League batting champion, was traded by the Chicago Cubs to the Boston Red Sox today for Dennis Eckersley, a former 20-game winner. The Cubs also got a minor league infielder-outfielder, Mike Brumley.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Democrats in Dispute Over Convention Delegates

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

PATENTS;
MEASURING THE FORCE OF WINDS
description: A WIND measurement instrument originally designed for use on Mars was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The instrument, capable of measuring wind velocity up to 100 miles to the second, could be used to forecast dangers to towers and other tall structures.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
LLOYD'S MORE THAN DOUBLES SHIP PREMIUMS FOR TRIPS TO IRAN PORTS
description: Lloyd's of London announced today that it had more than doubled war risk insurance premiums for ships traveling to two Iranian oil ports, following reports of increased violence in the Persian Gulf area.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
SOME POLIO SYMPTOMS MAY RECUR UP TO 40 YEARS AFTER THE DISEASE
description: Medical researchers say they think that aging may contribute to the recurrence of polio symptoms among as many as 25 percent of the 300,000 survivors of the crippling disease.

title: Australia-China Flights
description: Direct flights between Australia and China are to begin in September, the Government announced today. Aviation Minister Kim E. Beazley said there would be two flights a week, one each by the Australian national airline, Qantas, and the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

title: Caracas Said to Oppose Debt 'Cartel'
description: Venezuela has refused to join four other Latin American nations in their call last weekend for a meeting of debtor countries, according to a high- level source in the Venezuelan Government.

title: Bank Failures In '84 at 33
description: The number of banks that have failed this year in the United States has risen to 33.

title: GREEK COURT UPHOLDS JOURNALIST'S CONVICTION
description: A Greek appeals court today upheld the conviction of a Cypriot journalist for libel and defamation but commuted his sentence to a $1,200 fine and $150 damages.

title: CALM MARKETS FAIL TO RECOVER FULLY
description: Financial markets calmed yesterday after being shaken Thursday by rumors of spreading problems in the nation's banking system.

title: LUIGI POLANO
description: Luigi Polano, a founder of the Italian Communist Party, died at his home here today after a long illness, party officials announced.

title: V.A. Mortgage Rate Limit Up
description: The interest rate ceiling on basic home loans insured by the Veterans Administration will rise one-half percentage point on Tuesday, to 14 percent, the highest level since 1982, the agency announced today.

title: Small Tremor in El Salvador
description: It took three years of agitation, a denial of $19 million in American aid and a special inquiry by an American Federal judge, Harold Tyler. But a court in El Salvador has finally managed to convict five former National Guardsmen of murdering four American churchwomen in December, 1980. Now the challenge is to assure equal justice for Salvadoran victims, who remain statistics in an unremitting slaughter that has claimed the lives of more than 30,000 noncombatants.

title: PARTY'S RULES GIVE MONDALE EDGE AS 'SUPER DELEGATES' ARE CHOSEN
description: Walter F. Mondale was booed by workers as he urged the closing of the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant. Page 8.

title: DE GUSTIBUS ; COPING WITH DIFFICULT WAITERS
description: Service can make or break a meal. Even the most professional of waiters can spoil a dinner by acting unprofessionally. I don't mean in the sense that they pour scalding coffee down your back or stack plates on the table. These waiters may do everything properly in a technical sense, but by their demeanor they mar an otherwise pleasant experience.

title: HAROLD KALT
description: Harold Kalt, retired partner in the Kalt Lumber and Kalt Realty Companies in Manhattan, died Tuesday at the home of a son, H. Worthington Kalt, in Montclair, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Smoke Rise, N.J.

title: Spoleto U.S.A. Festival Opens in Charleston
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A., opened its eighth season Thursday with festival organizers, buoyed by record advance ticket sales, expecting 110,000 people at the 120 performances of opera, music, drama, dance, chamber music and jazz over 17 days.

title: CONTINENTAL PLASTICS & CHEMICALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KINGMAN SLAM TOPS YANKEES
description: Yankee baseball is not a pretty thing to watch these days.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS BILL RAISING DEBT CEILING ANOTHER $30 BILLION
description: President Reagan today signed legislation that allows the Government to borrow $30 billion more, raising the national debt ceiling to $1,520 billion.

title: TACO VILLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 18
GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
SCOUTING;
description: Positive-Pitching Helps Met Staff

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After realized losses on investments of $8,277 for the latest year and $36,234 for the previous year.

title: LAKERS GAIN FINAL
description: The Los Angeles Lakers survived a feverish fourth-period rally by Phoenix tonight and gained a 99-97 victory that eliminated the Suns, 4 games to 2, in the Western Conference finals.

title: Strikers Vote to Return At 13 Las Vegas Hotels
description: Waiters, cooks, bartenders and other workers have voted to end a 53-day strike for higher wages and other benefits at 13 Las Vegas gambling hotels, a trade union official said today.

title: DISCOVERY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PATENTS ; Enhancing the Display In X-Ray Diagnostics
description: A method of X-ray examination described as offering substantial advantages to medical diagnosticians was patented this week for Georgetown University by Robert S. Ledley, professor of physiology and biophysics.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: PATENTS ; Sewing-Stitch Guide Is Updated by Inventor
description: After spending a decade developing and perfecting a stitching guide for sewing machines, Dorothy Y. Kirby of Clermont, Fla., received an improvement patent on the device this week.

title: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 1:20 P.M. Ed Lynch, a converted middle-inning reliever who has had trouble going the distance, nonetheless gets another start for the Mets. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. (Television - SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.)

title: Baseball; Tiger Road Streak Ends at 17 SEATTLE, May 25 (UPI) - Alvin Davis homered and drove in three runs, and Bob Kearney hit a two-run homer tonight to help the Seattle Mariners snap Detroit's historic 17- game road winning streak with a 7-3 victory over the Tigers.
description: Detroit had tied the major league mark of 17 straight road victories set by the 1916 New York Giants. The decision also snapped an overall nine- game winning streak by the Tigers, now 35-6.

title: Environmentalist Wins Promise From President
description: After his first meeting with the leader of any major environmental organization, President Reagan has promised to read a book denouncing the environmental policies of his first two and a half years in the White House,

title: Judge in St. Paul Is Dismissed
description: The Minnesota Supreme Court today ordered the dismissal of a judge who admitted hiring male prostitutes, saying he had ''exploited vulnerable young persons.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Express Is Back

title: Crocker Meets Pretoria Foreign Aide
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, met with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa here today and later flew on for talks in Zambia with President Kenneth D. Kaunda.

title: Comings and Goings The World Boxing Council refused to authorize a fight between its lightweight champion,
description: Edwin Rosario of Puerto Rico, and Howard Davis of Glen Cove. L.I., the second-ranked challenger, until Rosario fights Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico, who is ranked first.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $1,492,000. c-Including a tax credit of $7,000. d-Including a tax credit of $2,877,000.

title: DENTAL WORLD CENTER INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Somalis Say Ethiopia Killed 4 in Air Raids
description: Ethiopian MIG-23 jets attacked the Somalian town of Isha Baidoa today, killing four children and raising the toll to six dead and seven wounded in two days of air raids, the Somalian radio said. A raid by MIG-21's and MIG-23's on Abduwaq in central Somalia on Thursday killed two people and wounded seven, the broadcast said, quoting Defense Ministry reports.

title: Reagan Sets Colorado Trip
description: President Reagan plans to fly to Colorado Springs next week to visit the United States Olympic training facility and give the commencement address at the Air Force Academy, the White House said Thursday.

title: PLAYING IT SAFE
description: There they go again. For the second year running, the seven members of the Board of Education have made an embarrassment of themselves in the search for a Chancellor to run the largest public-school system in the country. They have also shortchanged the 920,000 children in that system.

title: FOR REGENTS, 200 YEARS OF TRADITION AND DEBATE
description: R. Carlos Carballada, a member of the New York State Board of Regents, was hurrying toward a meeting in Syracuse not long ago when he was stopped for speeding. He explained to the state trooper that he was on official state business and asked if the trooper would write out the summons as quickly as possible so that he could continue on his way.

title: City Ends Inquiry In Alvarado Case
description: The City Department of Investigation has ended its inquiry on Anthony J. Alvarado, the former Schools Chancellor, and is writing a final report, according to an assistant commissioner.

title: Dominelli Is Indicted
description: J. David Dominelli was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on five criminal charges relating to the involuntary bankruptcy of his international money-trading firm. The grand jury charged that Mr. Dominelli, who has been jailed for a month for refusing to cooperate with the bankruptcy trustee, defrauded investors and debtors, lied to a grand jury and failed to cooperate with the trustee assigned to sort out the financial dealings of his failed J. David & Company.

title: SCIENTISTS PLEAD FOR SAKHAROV
description: The academies of science of the United States, Britain, France and Sweden have sent a message to Anatoly P. Alesksandrov, head of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, expressing ''concern and deep feelings regarding the worsening of the state of health'' of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident nuclear physicist, and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: MANVILLE, 3 INSURERS IN ACCORD
description: The Manville Corporation, which has been in bankruptcy proceedings for 21 months, announced yesterday that three of its main insurers had agreed to pay Manville a total of $315 million to settle coverage disputes regarding asbestos-related injury claims against the company.

title: 'LOVE OF PEACE' IS URGED IN SARAH LAWRENCE TALK
description: The actress Jane Alexander, saying ''we are at the dawn of a new age'' of information, today exhorted the graduating seniors of Sarah Lawrence College to go forth with ''a light heart, a love of peace and an intense curiosity.''

title: TESTAMATIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alaska Refuses to Allow Capture of Killer Whales
description: A California aquarium's proposal to capture 10 killer whales off Alaska, the first catch in American waters in more than a decade, was rejected today by Gov. Bill Sheffield of Alaska.

title: Tennessee Disaster Areas
description: President Reagan declared today that sections of Tennessee hit by severe storms and flooding in early May were major disaster areas, paving the way for use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: INCREASE IN NUMBER OF AGED CALLED THREAT TO HEALTH CARE
description: Jr.

title: Trenton Fiddles, Atlantic City
description: Burns A tenth casino hotel has just opened in Atlantic City, and New Jersey's flourishing young gambling industry expects to gross $2.1 billion this year, overtaking Las Vegas. But this bonanza has yet to help Atlantic City's redevelopment, as was promised when casinos were sanctioned.

title: No Headline
description: Defendant Brandishes Knife at Court Officers

title: SHIFTING THE BURDEN OF PROOF CAN'T REPAIR THE INSANITY DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: AT MAYAN TOMB SITES, SCIENTISTS VS. LOOTERS
description: The discovery of an intact Mayan tomb at Rio Azul, deep in the Peten jungle northeast of this capital city, is a victory snatched from the picks and shovels of organized looters.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a credit equal to 30 cents a share from the sale of surplus equipment.

title: FROM NORMANDY TO REAGAN CAMPAIGN'S D-DAY
description: As President Reagan returns home from the beaches of Normandy early next month, his re-election strategists will be approaching their own D-Day and moving key political field officers into place for the opening assault on the Democrats.

title: Bridge: A Season for Tournaments In the New York City Area
description: For tournament players in New York, this is the busy season. In the past week the Cavendish Club invitation events, pairs and teams, have been the focus of attention.

title: INDIANAPOLIS 500 GOES MORE INTERNATIONAL
description: When he was 12 years old, Roberto Guerrero started racing Go Karts in the streets of Medellin, Colombia, hoping to win a trophy. Now he is 25 and primed for his debut in the Indianapolis 500, where the prize money will total $2.5 million and where even last place earns $50,000.

title: Schnellenberger Shifts
description: Howard Schnellenberger today left his head- coaching position with the University of Miami and signed a contract with the Washington Federals of the United States Football League. Two weeks ago he labeled as ''hogwash'' reports that he was set to move.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Saudis Celebrate

title: SEES PROFIT DECLINE
description: Levi Strauss & Company, citing inefficient plant use and higher fabric and advertising costs, announced plans today to close about 10 percent of its facilities and said its second- quarter profit would drop about 85 percent from a year ago.

title: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Man Said to Kill Himself and Kin
description: A man estranged from his wife hanged their two children yesterday while seeing them on visitation rights, and then hanged himself, the police said last night.

title: TEXAS FARMERS PUT THEIR BRAND ON THE CRAWFISH
description: For two centuries or so, since the Acadian French of south Louisiana started plucking the native red swamp crawfish out of the bayous, the vest-pocket lobsters have been a regional delicacy.

title: Chicago Sets Trader Limits
description: Trading activities of brokerage house employees and those who lease seats from members will be restricted under new rules approved by the membership at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Letter: On Child Support Too Harsh on Defaulting Parents To the Editor:
description: Your editorial ''In Pursuit of Runaway Parents'' (May 18) endorses an important objective when it favors Congressional legislation regarding wage-deduction orders against parents to enforce their child-support obligations. The proposed law requires that all states automatically attach the wages of anyone liable for child support who is behind in a payment for more than 30 days. However, this nationwide proposal is unnecessary in view of present collection procedures, and its over-mechanical approach has many drawbacks.

title: NEW YORK MAKING CHANGES TO IMPROVE ITS TAXI SERVICE
description: When it comes to taxis in New York City, there is probably only one thing the industry is agreed on: If it's Friday, 5 P.M. and raining, chances are you are not going to find one.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
U.S. DEFENSE DECISION LEFT UP TO MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans to Hear Ford
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford will be at the Republican National Convention here in August, according to Ron Walker, the convention manager. ''Jerry Ford has received a phone call from the President and will be with us and will speak,'' Mr. Walker said Thursday at a meeting of the Dallas Republican Men's Club. Mr. Walker, who was once an aide to President Nixon, said Mr. Nixon had not been invited.

title: VATICAN PAYMENT REPORTED
description: Vatican Bank officials signed an agreement here today to pay $250 million to creditors of Banco Ambrosiano, which collapsed in one of Italy's biggest financial scandals since World War II, banking sources said.

title: No Headline
description: Experiment Produces Shortest Light Flashes

title: GOSSIP VS. NEWS: HOW A FALSE REPORT SPREAD
description: When The Boston Herald's gossip columnist reported that a fancy Boston restaurant had refused to seat former President Jimmy Carter because he was not wearing a coat and necktie, other news organizations found the story too amusing not to print and too innocuous to need verification.

title: ACS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GREAT AMERICAN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINDING HAPPINESS IN BUYOUT
description: He can close an automobile bumper plant without a lot of hassle. He can manage for cash flow instead of earnings. And when he calls his stockholders' meeting he faces no corporate gadflies but 50 shareholders whom he calls ''quite sophisticated,'' including representatives of the lenders - banks, insurance companies and pension funds.

title: THEFT, CASUALTY TAX DEDUCTION
description: Limits on tax deductions for unreimbursed casualty and theft losses have led many homeowners and automobile owners to review their insurance policies.

description: From remarks in Newark Thursday to a group of teachers and school administrators attending a conference on education:

description: Trimming the Real Fat

title: FREQUENCY CONTROL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHEN 5,000 SCIENTISTS MEET FOR A WEEKEND
description: No one knows exactly how long it takes for a scientist reading at lunch to dribble the soup on his tie, but casual empiricism conducted at the New York Hilton coffee shop now suggests that it could be about four minutes.

title: Staff Reduced At Visicorp
description: Visicorp, the privately held software company that marketed the first popular electronic spreadsheet, said that it had laid off 40 employees, about 20 percent of its staff, to reduce operating overhead. ''We are still growing,'' Ronald D. Fisher, vice president of marketing for the San Jose, Calif. company, said.

title: FILLIES WITH CLASS
description: Mark the Mathematician, who makes a good living playing the horses in Florida and New York, finds his edge in the most obscure subleties of numbers. At Hialeah last winter, he discovered a tiny new wrinkle in the relationship between the times of six-furlong and seven-furlong races, a shift of about one-tenth of a second. It wouldn't have made the slightest difference to most horseplayers, but to Mark it was as if the physical laws of the universe had been shattered. He adjusted his figures, and says it helped make it a winning winter.

title: BANK BUILDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $26,000 for the quarter and $91,000 for the 6 months.

title: Southern Poll Shows President Would Win
description: A poll of Southern voters shows President Reagan easily beating any of his three Democratic challengers, Walter F. Mondale, Senator Gary Hart or the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: 8 SHIPS DESTROYED OFF IRANIAN PORT, IRAQI FORCES SAY
description: President Reagan reportedly cut back the number of Stinger missiles to be sent to Saudi Arabia. Page 4.

title: THE REGION ; ;  School Chief Plans ToStayinYonkers
description: Dr. Joan M. Raymond told the Board of Education today that she would remain as Superintendent of the 20,000-student Yonkers school system because she had failed to get a superintendent's job in Florida.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a charge of $562,000 for the quarter and 9 months for the closure of a plant.

title: U.N. COUNCIL OPENS TALKS ON THE GULF
description: The Security Council opened talks today about the attacks against shipping in the Persian Gulf, with Arab countries condemning Iran for its ''aggression'' and Iran refusing to take part in the session.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chronology yesterday of developments in the 1980 case of four American churchwomen slain in El Salvador incorrectly described the route they were traveling when they were abducted. Their van was halted as they drove to the capital, San Salvador, from the airport.

title: William Ogle; Led Bomb Test
description: Dr. William E. Ogle, the scientific commander of the first thermonuclear tests off Eniwetok Atoll in 1952, died May 16, apparently of a heart attack, at a meeting of a conference at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 66 years old and lived in Anchorage, Alaska.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AT OXFORD, DISPUTE ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT REPORT
description: A female student group at Oxford University has charged that some professors sexually harass female students and that the atmosphere of the university is one of ''intellectual sexism.''

title: MURDERER TAKES THE STAND BUT REFUSES TO TESTIFY IN MARGOLIES TRIAL
description: A man convicted of killing a diamond-company worker and three CBS employees who came to her aid took the stand yesterday for the defense at the trial of the man accused of ordering the murders. But the convicted killer refused to testify because the prosecutor would not grant him immunity.

title: PIERCE, S S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including a gain of $669,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net losses.

title: SOLHENITSYN IS GIVEN DEGREE FROM MASSACHUSETTS COLLEGE
description: The exiled Soviet author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, making a rare public appearance, was hailed as ''a prophet to our times'' today as Holy Cross College awarded him an honorary degree.

title: Dole Taking Advantage Of New Fund Technique
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is taking advantage of a new fund- raising technique to enrich his political action committee, Campaign America, and to pile up political debts in Congress.

title: No Headline
description: A Reward of $75,000 Is Offered in Art Theft

title: Force-Feeding Ordered By Judge for Prisoner
description: A convicted rapist who pleaded to be allowed to starve to death rather than remain in prison will be fed against his will until the state Supreme Court decides the constitutional issues, a judge ruled today.

title: LACANA MINING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'BACK ROOM' FOR CHARGE CARDS
description: With Americans' growing use of credit cards, a company based in Omaha has been able to carve out what industry analysts describe as a ''nice little business'' handling Visa and Mastercard transactions - some 445 million last year alone.

title: Texaco Defense Against Merger
description: Shareholders of Texaco Inc., a company that joined in the recent flurry of oil industry mergers, approved two changes in the bylaws designed to fortify Texaco's defenses against hostile takeover bids.

title: TWENTIETH CENTURY INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including investment income of $3.5 million for the latest first quarter and $2.6 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ARGENTINA IS REPORTED CLOSE TO PACT ON DEBT
description: Argentina is close to an agreement with its foreign bank creditors that would avoid a major debt crisis at the end of the second quarter, banking sources said yesterday.

title: COCAINE CAPITAL
description: He was young and wealthy and college-educated. He owned a boat and a plane and was active in sports. He had everything he could ask for and even more to look forward to.

title: KENNEDY CASE IN SOUTH YIELDS A 2ND SURRENDER
description: One of two men accused of selling cocaine to David A. Kennedy surrendered voluntarily to the authorities in Florida yesterday. The suspect, David L. Dorr, of West Yarmouth, Mass., was released on $25,000 bond after he was booked at the Palm Beach County jail in West Palm Beach.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 26, 1984 International
description: The destruction of eight ships in an attack on a convoy in Iranian waters in the northeast Persian Gulf was announced by Iraq. But no distress signals were picked up in the region and there was no independent confirmation that any ships had been hit. There have been delays of 24 hours or more in the past before such claims could be verified. (Page 1, Col. 6.) A demand for a gasoline price rise of 50 percent in the Dominican Republic led to the suspension of Government negotiations with the International Monetary Fund, which has been requesting tough austerity measures in exchange for financial aid. (1:3.)

title: EASTPARK REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fuel Agency Curbs Sought
description: President Reagan sent Congress legislation today under which the quasi-governmental Synthetic Fuels Corporation - under fire from Congressional Republicans and Democrats alike - would be able to subsidize only competitively feasible projects to squeeze oil from solid substances.

title: HART WINS 10 DELEGATES IN OHIO
description: Gary Hart won 10 national convention delegates in Idaho's Democratic Presidential caucuses caucuses Thursday night and Walter F. Mondale got 6.

title:
PATENTS;
 Interferon Process
description: The Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week on a process for recovering human fibroblast beta-interferon from microorganisms, by extraction using specific alcohols.

title: METS WIN: GOODEN STRIKES OUT 14
description: Dwight Gooden says that a strikeout is ''just another out,'' but don't expect his manager, his teammates or the 27,340 fans at Shea Stadium to agree after the overpowering rookie pitcher struck out 14 Dodgers last night in a 2-1 Met victory.

title: STAGE: JERUSALEM TOUR: MUSIC BY MISS SWADOS
description: Although Elizabeth Swados has come to be identified as a composer of hard-edged musicals about urban outsiders, there is in her work a line of warmth and generosity - from the frolicsome ''Nightclub Cantata'' to her new oratorio, ''Jerusalem.'' Between those signposts were such shows as ''The Haggadah,'' a festive theatricalization of the Passover seder; the tale of ''Aladin''; and, this season on Broadway, the comic-strip musical ''Doonesbury'' (with book and lyrics by Garry Trudeau).

title: U.S. RULING FAVORS ATOM SAFETY PLAN
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission may not approve low-level testing of nuclear plants until plans for protecting residents in surrounding communities have been tested and approved, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: MOSCOW TALKS END FOR NORTH KOREAN
description: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea today ended his first visit to the Soviet Union in 20 years amid indications that he might have succeeded in obtaining enhanced Soviet military assistance.

title: Cavaliers Drop Coach
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, making their eighth head-coaching change in the last five years, dismissed Tom Nissalke yesterday after he compiled a record that, at only 28-54, still gave them their best season since 1980-81. No successor has been chosen.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
CORRECTIONS
description: A brief Reuters dispatch from Belfast on Thursday misidentified a group blamed for the slayings of three people in a Protestant church last November. The police said the Irish National Liberation Army, a splinter group of the Irish Republican Army, was responsible. The I.R.A. denounced the slayings.

title: AT 36, RODGERS HAS RACE AGAINST TIME
description: Bill Rodgers is the second oldest of the 170 to 175 men expected to run here Saturday in the United States Olympic marathon trial.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AVX Ltd., a multilayer ceramic capacitors company in Great Neck, L.I., said its presence in Northern Ireland would more than double if plans for new manufacturing plants were successful. It has manufactured multi-layer ceramic capacitors in Colerane since 1979.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a settlement of civil suits arising from the 1980 Stouffer's Inn fire erroneously described one lawyer in the case, David G. Miller. He represented some of the plaintiffs.

title: CARSON'S NAME RAISED AT TRIAL OF DELOREAN
description: A Government informer who is the key witness in the cocaine trafficking trial of John Z. DeLorean testified today that Mr. DeLorean told him in 1980 that he had once trafficked in cocaine with Johnny Carson, the entertainer.

title: CHINA PLANS TO PUT TROOPS IN HONG KONG PEKING, May 25 (AP) - China intends to station troops in Hong Kong when it regains sovereignty over the British colony in 1997, Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, said today.
description: The remarks, which were contrary to an earlier pledge by a Chinese official, had an immediate effect on the Hong Kong stock market. Within an hour the market index fell 30 points and then rose slightly.

title: CHILDREN'S PLACE IN THE NUCLEAR ARMS DEBATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Judge ShiftsOn Chicago Arrests
description: A Federal district judge who earlier ruled that up to a million arrests made by police sweeps of crime- prone neighborhoods were illegal rescinded his ruling today, saying the city deserved a chance to be heard in the case.

title: Ex-Employee Sought After Capital Break-In
description: The police are searching for a former employee of the Democratic Congressional Committee who is suspected of burglarizing the organization's Capitol Hill offices.

title: REGENTS, IN REVERSAL, PASS PLAN SOUGHT BY CUOMO
description: A disputed proposal that had pitted the State Board of Regents against Governor Cuomo was approved by the Regents today in an emotionally charged meeting.

title: Alicia Eimicke, Executive, Wed to Ferruccio Barbieri
description: The marriage of Alicia Karen Eimicke to Ferruccio Renzo Barbieri took place yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Victor W. Eimicke of Bronxville, N.Y., parents of the bride.

title: New Jersey Channels To Carry Interviews
description: Three live, hour-long phone-in programs, with separate appearances by each of three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, will be televised tonight, tomorrow and Sunday on WNET, Channel 13, and WNJM, Channel 50.

title: ; URBAN LOCOMOTION: TO FOSTER COEXISTENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVISION IN FED ON MONEY RESTRAINTS
description: Three governors of the Federal Reserve opposed the March decision of the Federal Open Market Committee to tighten restraints on growth of the money supply, a summary of the meeting shows.

title: THE OTHER DRUG ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMORIES AND EPITHETS
description: THE RETURN OF MR. HOLLYWOOD.

title: YARDNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CARB-A-DRINK INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company commenced operations on Dec. 10, 1983 and, therefore, no comparable year-ago results are presented.

title: Cosmos Clear Waivers
description: All four players dropped by the Cosmos in a salary dispute earlier this week cleared waivers yesterday. The refusal of the eight other teams in the North American Soccer League to claim any of the players under the terms of their original contracts meant that Jeff Durgan , who signed a new pact for less pay after he had been waived, was a member of the Cosmos again.

title: Dow Rises by 3.67; Losers Predominate
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in slower pre-holiday trading after plunging on Thursday because of concern over the financial condition of some large banks.

title: PATH TO JUSTICE IN EL SALVADOR IS STREWN WITH ROADBLOCKS
description: Felipe Menjivar's brother, Ernesto, a 32-year- old mathematics teacher, disappeared on March 7. Today six Civil Defense guards are in jail in connection with his murder. But many Salvadorans consider it unlikely that anyone will ever be tried in the case.

title: PETRIE CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: MARRIOTT MAY JOIN IN DISNEY BID
description: The big Marriott hotel organization is considering joining an investor group headed by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, to make a nearly $900 million bid for a 49 percent interest in Walt Disney Productions, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: 'GRAPESHOT' TACTIC IN COMBATING DRUNK DRIVING
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED STATES MUTUAL FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UP THE RIVER One of New York's most traditional cruises, the one-day round-trip up the lordly Hudson, resumes today with the sailing this morning of the Hudson River Day Line's Dayliner from Pier 81 at West 41st Street. Time was when short-run shipping fanned out from New York to Albany, ports on Long Island Sound and the New Jersey shore, with voyages by day and night inspired by the hegemony of our great port.

title: 2 GRANDSONS OF TEXAS OILMAN LOSE SUIT FOR MORE OF ESTATE
description: A probate judge today dismissed a contention that two Italian grandchildren of Hugh Roy Cullen were entitled to another $2 billion from the oilman's huge estate.

title: EQUAL-TIME EXEMPTION TO 'DONAHUE'
description: The Federal Communications Commission has ruled that the Phil Donahue television talk show is a news program and thus exempt from the equal-time provisions of the Fairness Doctrine.

title: PLAYING FOR KEEPS
description: In a departure from its usual fare of mindless froth, Broadway this season has come up with two new plays that deal with America as a real place. They are Arthur Kopit's ''End of the World'' and David Mamet's ''Glengarry Glen Ross.''

title: CASEY ASCRIBES POLITICAL MOTIVES TO REPORT LINKING HIM TO PAPERS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, today described as ''politically motivated'' a House subcommittee report that concluded that as Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign manager he was involved in the handling of briefing materials obtained from President Carter's advisers.

title: Ireland's Nuclear Foes Lose a Suit on Reagan
description: The Irish Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament lost a court action today to keep President Reagan from entering Ireland with the equipment he needs to launch American nuclear missiles.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After a charge of $125,000 for the cost of closing a store.

title: Crenshaw Leading Memorial
description: ''You have to be a fatalist to putt,'' said Ben Crenshaw, who last month won the Masters and is one of the best putters on the PGA Tour.

title: DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Daniel Sarnoff Weds Conchita Suarez
description: The marriage of Conchita Maria Suarez, the daughter of Pedro Suarez Hernandez and Conchita Priete Suarez of Asturias and Granada, Spain, to Daniel Jay Sarnoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Warren Sarnoff of Beverly Hills, Calif. took place yesterday at the New York Athletic Club in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: G.M. PLANT OUTLAY TO RISE 50%
description: The General Motors Corporation will spend $6 billion on new plants and production machinery this year, 50 percent more than it spent in 1983, Roger B. Smith, chairman, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting here today.

title: Arco Field Bid
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company is seeking Federal permission to develop Prudhoe Bay's Lisburne formation, a field Arco estimates contains 3 billion barrels of oil.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Bill Rates Fall a Bit;  Notes, Bonds Are Mixed
description: In confused and erratic trading, rates for Treasury bills declined modestly yesterday, while yields for Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed.

title: U.S. Lays Death of Dissident To Mistreatment by Moscow
description: The State Department today cited the death in a labor camp of a Ukrainian activist, Oleskiy Tykhy, as a reminder of Soviet mistreatment of dissidents.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $686,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a charge of $35,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Including a tax credit of $364,000.

title: BOARD RESTRICTS OCCUPANCY IN 9 CITY HOMELESS SHELTERS
description: The Board of Estimate approved late Thursday night a plan to renovate nine shelters for homeless New Yorkers, but only after requiring the Koch administration to provide 60 square feet for each resident and thus limit how many people could legally be housed.

title: BAND PIANIST PLAYED FOR POPULAR SINGERS
description: Graham Forbes, a pianist who played in the bands of Bunny Berigan and Charlie Barnet and was Frank Sinatra's accompanist for several years, died Tuesday after a heart attack at his home in Westbury, L.I. Mr. Forbes, who was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Thornwood, N.Y., was 66 years old.

title: OBERAMMERGAU PLAY: STILL ANTI-SEMITIC
description: The Oberammergau Passion play, which opened Monday in a special season to mark its 350th anniversary, remains a serious obstacle to building better Christian-Jewish relations. Despite outside efforts to have changes introduced, the play still is unmistakably anti-Semitic. Unless, finally, it is purged of its bias, economic pressure should be brought to bear on those who profit from sending tourists to see it.

title: AIR TRAVEL: BUMPING PASSENGERS
description: When John Muccioli checked in for an American International Airlines flight from Fort Lauderdale to Philadelphia the attendant at the boarding gate announced that the plane was overbooked and asked if any ticket holders would voluntarily take other flights. No one stepped forward.

title: Tax Ruling Backs Ford
description: A Detroit suburb and two other taxing units must return to the Ford Motor Company more than $18 million in property tax overpayments on the auto maker's Rouge plant, a Michigan Tax Tribunal judge ruled. The City of Dearborn must return $5 million in taxes collected from Ford in 1981 and 1982, plus $1 million interest, the administrative law judge, Charles P. McDonald, ordered. He ruled that Wayne County owes $3 million and the Dearborn Board of Education owes $9 million.

title: HOW BRAHMS SHAPED HIS MATERIAL
description: Walter Frisch, a member of the music faculty of Columbia University, has adapted this article from his book ''Brahms and the Principle of Developing Variation,'' which is to be published Wednesday by the University of California Press.

title: SAKHAROV'S KIN URGE WEST TO ACT FOR HIS FREEDOM
description: The stepdaughter of Andrei D. Sakharov urged today that Western countries undertake ''extraordinary measures'' to win freedom for the dissident Soviet physicist and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: VENEZUELA CHIEF FACES FIRST MAJOR TEST IN LOCAL VOTES TODAY
description: Nationwide local elections Sunday will be the first major test for the left-of-center President, Jaime Lusinchi, since his landslide victory last December. Seven million Venezuelans are expected to vote.

title: 5 MORE DIE IN CONTINUING INDIAN UNREST
description: Five more people have been killed and several wounded in new sectarian violence in India, it was reported today.

title: Of Camelot And Centerport
description: According to legend, Camelot was a place during King Arthur's reign. Centerport was real and still is. How sad if in the offing we would have to use the word ''was'' in referring to it.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN MY daughter was home from school the other day, but one of her friends was still at the dorm. ''What does my room look like when it's clean?'' I overheard my daughter ask on the telephone.

title: MCENROE LEADS U.S. TO TEAM TENNIS FINAL
description: John McEnroe coasted to a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Jose Higueras of Spain and led the United States into the final of the $531,000 Ambre Solaire World Team Tennis Cup today.

title: MISS BOYLAN WED TO J.S. CAMPBELL
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity in Westfield, N.J., yesterday, Jerilyn Mary Boylan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Boylan of Westfield, was married to Jeffrey Scott Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Campbell of Great Falls, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael J. Desmond, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Hugh Livengood, an Episcopal priest.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Dance
description: New Yorkers will have an opportunity to see what some modern-dance choreographers from San Francisco are up to when two lively dance groups from the city by the Golden Gate share a week at the Joyce Theater.

title: IF LONG-TERM U.S. BONDS HAD GOLD BACKING
description: To the Editor:

title: Week of Disarray For Soccer in U.S.
description: Professional soccer's management and financial problems in this country were typified by the release Friday of four top players for refusing to take salary cuts, and by the inability of the national team of the United States to have enough time to prepare for its game with the World Cup champion Italy.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
MELODY AND HOPE BUOY TWO MUSICAL OFFERINGS
description: While music programs - either live ''in concert'' performances or video clips - have become an accepted ingredient of the pay TV programming diet, two examples this evening, each in a very different way, constitute significant departures from the norm. On Home Box Office, the return of melody to popular music is celebrated as Linda Ronstadt and the Nelson Riddle orchestra perform the songs that have suddenly captured the fancy of the rock generation: the music of, among others, Irving Berlin and George Gershwin. And HBO's sister pay service, Cinemax, is featuring a music video program with an inspirational element: two-and-a-half years after the devastating car accident which left him paralyzed from the waist down, the soul singer Teddy Pendergrass resumes his career.

title: 'NONSENSE' ABOUT A JEFFERSON SLAVE MISTRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: MICKEY MOUSE'S APPEAL TO COLLECTORS
description: The time tunnel traveled in dreams by collectors of Mickey Mouse memorabilia ends at the toy counter of a 1930's dime store. There, the exuberant mouse appears as an untarnished image on windup toys, sandpails, shovels, Big Little Books, cast-iron banks, toothbrush holders, tea sets, clocks, watches, play money, dolls and pencil boxes, all in their original wrappers and at prices that seem like the most incredible part of this fantasy - from five cents to $1.50.

title: PRINCETON SUED IN MT. LAUREL CASE
description: An Opinion article about the Mount

title: SMENON'S LAST CASE
RISKY TREND IN BUSINESS BORROWING
description: LAST January, the Westinghouse

title: ONCE AGAIN FOR CON ED, IT'S DIG WE MUST
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York is standing tall largely because it's been standing pat. Con Edison, which provides electricity to 2.7 million customers in New York City and Westchester County, is the state's largest investor-owned utility and its most healthy financially. That's because the company got out of its last major construction project a decade ago and has managed to avoid most of the delays and mammoth cost overruns now plaguing utilities trying to complete nuclear power plants.

title: Rejecting 'Lolita'
description: To the Editor:

title: Davila Retains Title
description: Albert Davila stopped Enrique Sanchez 31 seconds into the 11th round tonight with a savage flurry of blows to retain his World Boxing Council bantamweight title. Both fighters kept up a furious pace throughout the 11 rounds, but Sanchez had the edge until the 10th round when Davila all but stopped him.

title: N.C.A.A. Title To Johns Hopkins
description: Johns Hopkins defeated Syracuse, 13-10, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse championship today before a tournament-record crowd of 17,671 at the University of Delaware.

title: Cynthia S. Welles Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Nelson Welles of Greenwich, Conn., and Northeast Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Sumner Welles to David Boyd Borie Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Borie of Greenwich and Nantucket, Mass.

title: MAILBOX
description: A Grand Slam Or Grand Sham?

title: LILCO STOCKHOLDERS: TIME OF FRUSTRATION
description: IF the Long Island Lighting Company goes bankrupt - a possibility that persists regardless of

title: Soviet Atom Blast Detected
description: The Seismological Institution of Uppsala University said today that it had recorded a Soviet underground nuclear explosion at the Semipalatinsk test site in eastern Kazakhstan. It was the fourth recorded this year at a magnitude exceeding 6.5 on the open-ended Richter scale.

title: No Headline
description: Guardsman Is Charged With Taking Weapons

title: LAKERS DOUBTFUL OF LETDOWN
description: The Lakers did not take the most direct route to Boston, but they are used to those kinds of delays.

title: NIGHT SHAD FISHING IS FOR THE STALWART
description: -old fish scales on his faded orange rubber overalls. The curly-headed man in his mid-40's pulls up the hood of his worn slicker to shed a nasty, nagging May rain.

title: TOPICS
description: Dear Mr. Como,

title: STRINDBERG IS MADE SENTIMENTAL, OTHELLO GETS AN UPDATE
description: Pity the writer in search of his second success, marooned as he is between promise and accomplishment. No doubt even the founder of tragedy was given a hard time in the Athenian papyri when he ceded the bays to Sophocles in the Dionysian Festival of 468. ''After the raw power of his smash hit, 'The Persians,' '' the critics must have grumbled, ''this latest effort by 'Baldy' Aeschylus, the thrusting new talent from Eleusis, comes as a sad letdown.'' Well, Amlin Gray and Kevin Wade would not, I'm sure, yet claim to be competing in quite the same league; yet the question that has to be asked of their new plays isn't essentially different from the one that must have rippled through that hillside orchestra two-and-a-half millennia ago. How does Mr. Gray's ''Zones of the Spirit'' at Theater for the New City compare with his acidulous account of a reporter's life in Vietnam, ''How I Got That Story?'' And does Kevin Wade's ''Mr. and Mrs.'' at WPA fulfill the expectations created by ''Key Exchange,'' a tale of love among the bicycling classes that proved pretty successful Off Broadway in 1981?

title: Mount St. Helens Rumbles
description: Mount St. Helens burst forth with a rumbling explosion today. It spouted a plume of steam and some ash 22,000 feet high and sent a small mudflow down the volcano's slopes and into Spirit Lake. A spokesman for the United States Forest Service said a strong seismic signal was recorded beneath the peak at 8:14 A.M. but that the explosion was milder than a similar one recorded there on May 14.

title: Lee Anne La Motte a Bride
description: Lee Anne La Motte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Howell La Motte 3d of Hilton Head Island, S.C., formerly of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Carl Raymond Anderson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Hilton Head Island, formerly of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Dr. William Oliver Nisbet performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church, Hilton Head Island.

title: Executive Is Wed To Miss McGrath
description: Maryann McGrath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. McGrath of Pelham Manor and Millbrook, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Joseph McNamara, a son of Kathleen McNamara of Saddle River, N.J., and New York and the late Gerald C. McNamara. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor.

title: Oakland Wins, 17-14
description: Kevin Shea kicked a 32-yard field goal on the final play of the third period tonight to break a 14-14 tie and the Oakland Invaders' defense made it stand up through a fourth-quarter downpour to defeat the Oklahoma Outlaws, 17-14, in a United States Football League game.

title: THE NEW MODERN REENTERS THE CONTEMPORARY ARENA
description: Unlike most of his curatorial colleagues at the newly reopened Museum of Modern Art, John Szarkowski doesn't have to worry about where ''modern'' begins and ends (or, indeed, whether it has ended). The director of the museum's department of photography for the last 22 years - exactly half of its 44-year existence - believes that photography is and always has been modern. It entered into the picture-making tradition as ''a profoundly radical system,'' he said recently, ''one that we are still trying to figure out how to use.''

title: V.A. CENTER STARTS COUNSELING SERVICE
description: JERSEY CITY ANEW counseling and outreach project designed to meet the specialized needs of black, female, Hispanic and handicapped Vietnam-era veterans has been started at the Veterans Administration Center here.

title: Grassland Fires in California Scorch Thousands of Acres
description: Firefighters today contained wind-whipped flames that had burned 6,000 acres of grassland in the western San Joaquin Valley near here, but another fire in the region was out of control.

title: Break-In at Jackson Office
description: The Los Angeles campaign headquarters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a Democratic Presidential contender, was broken into Thursday night, the police said Friday. A police official said campaign workers had told officers that they believed the headquarters had been broken into by thieves seeking cash campaign donations but the money had been banked.

title: LEE FAWKES WED TO MISS STAVITSKY
description: Ellen Barbara Stavitsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abram Stavitsky of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Lee Bohn Fawkes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bohn E. Fawkes of Minneapolis, were married yesterday. The Rev. Clayton Lund, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: THE WORLD;
description: The Deadly Mix Of Green And Saffron

title: POLITICALLY, THE BRIEFING BOOK STILL NAGS THE WHITE HOUSE
description: The smoking gun metaphor that became a political cliche during Watergate evolved into something exquisitely apt last week. The chairman of a 10-month Congressional inquiry into charges of political espionage during the 1980 Presidential debate summarized 2,412 pages of findings thusly: ''We have a warm barrel, but the smoke is still to be found.''

title: AWARDS GIVEN FOR AIDING CITY'S OPEN SPACES
description: Individuals and corporations that have made major contributions to preserving and improving open space in New York City have been honored by the Parks Council, a nonprofit organization devoted to the maintenance of parks and open space.

title: Wedding in Manhasset For Beatrice Brennan
description: Beatrice Brennan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Brennan of Manhasset, L.I., and Robert P. Wall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Wall Jr. of Garden City and Nassau Point, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Bennett performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in Manhassett.

title: ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN
description: Kultur 88 minutes. $59.95

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Hotel Manager Takes Beer From Hart's Son
description: John Hart, the 18-year-old son of Senator Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential contender. had his beer taken away from him at a hotel by an official who pointed out that he was under age.

title: A TINY AGENCY JUMPS INTO NUCLEAR POWER WITH BOTH FEET
description: New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear power plant was long ago written into the litany of financial disasters increasingly associated with the construction of such plants. Though the scope of the project has essentially been halved since the planning stages in the early 1970's, its estimated cost has quadrupled, rising from $1 billion to $4.1 billion, of which $2.7 billion has already been spent.

title: TRENDS SIGNAL GREATER THREAT OF CHEMICAL WAR, EXPERTS SAY
description: Experts on chemical weapons from a wide range of countries are concerned that the danger of chemical warfare breaking out somewhere in the world is increasing seriously.

title: YANKS BEAT A'S; HOMER BY BROOKS STOPS DODGERS
description: Hubie Brooks extended his hitting streak to 20 games yesterday with a seventh-inning home run that ignited a two-run rally and led to a second straight 2-1 victory for the Mets over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium.

title: BALLET THEATER MAKES ROOM FOR FORMALISM AND DRAMA
description: Just when it seemed about time to single out one dance trend over another as the wave of the future, American Ballet Theater came along with two premieres to suggest that everything still goes. Twyla Tharp's ''Bach Partita'' is a pure- dance, plotless work. Focused on formal concerns that deal with structure in music and dance, it also explores a host of movement possibilities. By contrast, Martine van Hamel's ''Amnon V'Tamar'' uses movement to build a dramatic episode. Compressing a narrative from a literary source, Miss van Hamel, in her first work for Ballet Theater, focuses on the relationships of clearly defined characters and on their primary emotions.

title: WORK FROM ARTS AND CRAFTS MOVEMMENT AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: ALTHOUGH it fostered illusions of progress, the Industrial Revolution did not go uncontested. The opposition wasn't just from Luddites, either, but came early on from various writers, the poet William Blake among them, while the Pre-Raphaelitism of the 1850's was still another reaction.

title: DR. SCOTT WOLFE WEDS MISS CALLE
description: Lynne Calle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Eric Calle Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Dr. Scott Wedgwood Wolfe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Wolfe of Riverside, Conn, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Olufson Jr. performed the Protestant ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: Phillies Top Padres On Lezcano Homer
description: Sixto Lezcano hit a three-run homer last night and Len Matuszek doubled home two runs as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the San Diego Padres by 7-2 in a game delayed 59 minutes by rain.

title: BASEBALL'S WHIFF OF SUCCESS: THE STRIKEOUT MASTERS
description: DAN QUISENBERRY, who every year gains nearly as many saves as he does strikeouts, has heard all of the jokes about his style of pitching. ''In 1980,'' he recalled, ''there was the 30-30-30 club: 30 saves, 30 strikeouts, 30 great plays.'' He even makes some at his own expense. ''I'm probably the only relief pitcher,'' he said recently, ''who has more saves thanstrikeouts. But recently I had a couple of 0-2 counts.''

title: Reagan's Talk Stresses Need to Bar Inflation
description: President Reagan, in one of his most overtly political radio speeches in recent weeks, said today he will not ''panic or be buffaloed'' by rising interest rates.

title: CRITICS'S CHOICES
description: Cable TV

title: CONNECTICUT SUMMER FARE: FROM CONCERTS TO RACES TO FAIRS
description: T HE lazy days this summer may be as energized as as sedate as anyone would want - from a punishing 62 1/2-mile bicycle race to sailing in a new ocean race on Long Island Sound, or from witnessing a more serious musical side of the comedian Victor Borge, to attending the premiere of a new Broadway-bound musical in a new theater.

title: UTILITY RATE RISE LOOMS IN WAKE OF SEABROOK
description: THE collapse of the Seabrook nuclear project in New Hampshire will begin to make itself felt in Connecticut this week.

title: L.I. MAN HEADS REAGAN CAMPAIGN
description: A LONG ISLANDER who has had no experience in running political campaigns will be the day-to-day director of Ronald Reagan's campaign for re-election in New York State.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: IN MODERN ART, SOCIETE ANONYME PLAYED AN EARLY ROLE
description: ALTHOUGH most of the fireworks these days are in New York for the reopening of the Museum of Modern Art, some pinwheels and sparklers are in order for New Haven, too, in honor of the Societe Anonyme, which was New York's first ''Museum of Modern Art.''

title: FESTIVAL FILLS THE WILLING EARS OF CALIFORNIA'S CAPITAL WITH DIXIELAND JAZZ
description: This city is paying homage to Dixieland jazz this weekend with a noisy, stomping spectacle that has drawn 101 bands from 13 countries to play and more than 150,000 spectators to listen.

title: SOME CHARITIES OPPOSE CHANGES FOR FEDERAL DRIVE
description: Scores of groups around the country are demanding that the Reagan Administration drop its proposed new rules for the Federal employees' annual charity drive, changes that the groups say would cost them millions of dollars in donations.

title: STATE REPORTS A 41% INCREASE IN PRODUCTION OF MAPLESYRUP
description: New York State's crop of maple syrup this year rose 41 percent over last year, according to figures issued here this week by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: TAPEWORMS CITED IN FATAL DISEASE
description: A young woman from Mexico complained about severe headaches, so her doctor gave her painkillers and migraine headache drugs. A year later she lapsed into a coma and died of a tapeworm infection that has killed dozens of immigrants in the past 20 years.

title: CHANGES ASSAILED
description: In a move that has angered environmentalists, the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, headed by Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of Spring Lake Heights, has approved a bill to extend from five to 10 years the length of pollution-discharge permits provided for under the Federal Clean Water Act.

title: Maloney Promoted
description: Dan Maloney , the Toronto Maple Leafs' assistant coach for the last two years, was promoted to head coach yesterday, replacing Mike Nykoluk , who was dismissed April 2.

title: TAXES WOULD RISE 7% IN SUFFOLK WITHOUT SHOREHAM, REPORT SAYS
description: If the Shoreham nuclear plant does not operate, Suffolk County property taxes would have to rise 7 percent to make up for lost revenue, and in the Suffolk's five western towns the increase would be 16 percent, according to a county study.

title: Inquiry Is Urged on Grades At Air Controllers Academy
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole has been asked to investigate a departmental report confirming a House committee's finding of ''grade manipulation'' at the Federal Aviation Administration's school for air traffic controllers.

title: SIMENON'S LAST CASE
Oldfield Sets Mark In Shot-Put
description: Brian Oldfield, who will be 39 years old on June 1, smashed his own American record in the shot-put by 6 3/4 inches today and came within an inch of the world record with a put of 72 feet 9 3/4 inches.

title: Censorship Is No One's Civil Right
description: When the Indianapolis Council met last month to consider forbidding pornography as a violation of women's rights, the Moral Majority bused spectators to the meeting. The moralists joined with feminists in a novel collaboration against smut, and the council overwhelmingly voted its agreement.

title: ELLIPSE AMONG RECTANGLES
description: An elliptical office tower - Manhattan's first, according to its architects, Philip Johnson and John Burgee - has begun to rise on the east side of Third Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets in a setting of recently erected rectangular office towers. Indeed, that unusual oval shape was chosen, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Burgee say, to distinguish the new building from the dominant form of its neighbors, including the Citicorp Center directly across the avenue.

title: DIRECTORS MADE A DIFFERENCE THIS SEASON
description: If anyone wants to feel buoyant about the just concluded

title: Sheffield of Alaska PlanningTrade Mission Aboard a Ship
description: A Cunard Lines cruise ship will be the setting in September for a floating international trade mission arranged by Gov. Bill Sheffield of Alaska.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
MAYBE THIS WILL BE THE SUMMER THAT WE'LL...
description: I KNOW that the change of season is about to occur when I slip

title: FOR NYACK, OUTWARD BEATS UPWARD D
description: NOW that the Nyack Village Board has rejected a high-rise condominium building on a rundown waterfront parcel, a developer is considering how to build outward rather than upward.

title: THE WORLD;
description: Moscow Rattles Its Missiles

title: JAPANESE FOOD, FRIENDLY SERVICE
description: HIZEN, in Levittown, looks as if it might have been cut from the same mold as most of the other Japanese restaurants on the Island. The dining room is simply done, with some decorative light wood panels and dividers, paper lanterns, boldly printed fabric hangings and functional light wood tables, chairs and booths. There is a sushi bar along one wall.

title: WHAT TENANTS CAN DO
description: To establish harassment, a tenant must show that a landlord is intentionally tormenting him to repossess the apartment. A landlord's failure to keep a repair appointment or an isolated shortage of hot water are not considered harassment unless a tenant can show that such incidents fit into a pattern of abusive behavior.

title: REDISTRIBUTING CHEAP ENERGY: STATE DEBATES WHO GAINS AND WHO LOSES
description: State legislators, Governor Cuomo and utility executives are facing a series of issues that will affect the State's distribution of energy for decades to come.

title: MUBARAK'S VENTURE IN DEMOCRACY
description: Judith Miller is chief of The Times's Cairo bureau. GYPT IS ENTERING the space age. Or so says the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram. Within the next six months, according to the paper, several Egyptian pilots will be selected for training, probably in the United States, as astronauts for some future American space shots. But in Cairo, the epicenter of the ancient strip of life along the banks of the Nile, Egyptians are absorbed by more down-to-earth concerns.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COOPER COINS IN THE SUNLIGHT
description: Copper coins have played second fiddle to gold and silver coins in recent years, but two coming events figure to give them an overdue share of the spotlight. The first will be a landmark sale of United States large cents and half cents; the second will be the publication of a major new book covering the gamut of regular-issue U.S. copper coins.

title: MRS. FERRARO CITES CHALLENGE OF '84
description: A FEMALE Vice Presidential candidate would represent a gain for the Democratic ticket, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said last week during a visit to the county. In an interview after her speech to the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York, meeting in White Plains, the Queens Democrat, who has frequently been mentioned as a potential Vice Presidential candidate, said: ''There are a lot of voters who would vote for a woman.''

title: BUSINESS VENTURES IN SPACE STUDIED
description: The first commercial products to be made in space are to go on sale later this year.

title: SERENDIPITY IN THE CINQUE PORTS
description: The Battle of Hastings, 1066, is one of the few dates that everybody knows, for when William, Duke of Normandy, assembled his 7,000 men one Saturday in October 918 years ago to defeat the usurper Harold, the course of our common history was changed.

title: ELIZZABETH ANN TOWNE WED TO GORDON STONE
description: Elizabeth Ann Towne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Towne of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Gordon Henry Stone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin A. Stone of Bloomfield, N.J. The Rev. William D. Christ, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Towne home.

ART;

title: HUNGARY'S WARTIME ANGUISH IS RELIVED THROUGH 'THE REVOLT OF JOB'
description: Forty years after they were carted off toward Auschwitz in their own horse-drawn wagons, a dozen survivors, back in their East Hungarian village, were in the carts again, waiting for an order to set off across the same muddy fields.

title: PATTERNS IN THE CERAMIC ARTS
description: BY COINCIDENCE, a cluster of exhibitions in Newark and New York City are serving as stepping stones across some major currents of American ceramics during the last century.

title: BEHIND PSYCHIC PREDICITONS
description: IT is one of the more surprising aspects of human behavior that so many people continue to believe in and accept the predictions and advice of astrologers, handwriting analysts, palm readers, biorhythmists and other alleged ''psychics'' when the predictions are either so vague as to apply to almost everyone sooner or later or turn out, when examined, to be just plain wrong.

title: CYNTHIA GREGORY: THE ALL AMERICAN
description: The word ''ballerina'' is used so often and so carelessly that it can refer to anyone from a moppet in a tutu at a dancing school recital to the star of a professional ballet company. But the designation ought to be reserved for someone who is not only a principal dancer of a company, but also an artist of international stature. One dancer who would surely qualify for such an honorific title is Cynthia Gregory of American Ballet Theater, which is now in the midst of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: GETTING UNDER WAY
description: HERE IS ALMOST NO HOLIday or celebration on earth - secular or religious - that does not bring to mind food tailored to the occasion. The most obvious associations, of course, are turkey and Thanksgiving, fruitcakes and Christmas, hoppin' John and New Year's Eve, and ham and Easter. In Italy, almost every saint has his or her day and a food to go with it. St. Martin, for example, has roast chestnuts soaked in sweet wine, and there is a sweet bread to celebrate the feast of St. Anthony.

Islan Jr. of Cos Cobb, Conn., and Mrs. John T. Robinson of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony.

Falvey of Jamestown, N.Y., and the late Anna M. Falvey. The Rev. Richard Jacobs performed the ceremony at St. Virgil's Roman Catholic Church in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Inside Trading by Outsiders; The S.E.C. strives to widen its net.  But major rulings have held it back.
description: THE court documents read like a Hollywood potboiler. An influential reporter for one of the nation's most prestigious newspapers -- The Wall Street Journal -- is accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of profiting from information ''misappropriated'' from his employer. The S.E.C. complaint filed this month weaves a tale of intrigue involving wealthy accomplices, a Swiss bank account and false invoices -- charges that have made the actions of the reporter, R. Foster Winans, a matter of scrutiny in both financial and journalistic circles. The Winans action, more stunning than routine S.E.C. filings, is the latest in a string of dramatic cases flowing from the agency's attempt to stretch the definition of illegal insider trading into new and uncharted terrain.

description: Piece by shimmering piece, one of the world's most famous restaurants is finding a new home for its classic French cuisine here in the home of Creole cookery.

title: MISS GOODMAN PLANS WEDDING
description: The engagement of Christine Carpenter Goodman to William Randall Price has been announced by her parents, Mr and Mrs. William E. Goodman 4th of New York, Bay Head, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Price Jr. of Garden City and Remsenburg, L.I. The wedding is to be in September.

title: WHY SAKHAROV STILL HITS A SOVIET NERVE
description: The disclosure that Andrei D. Sakharov had launched a hunger strike in the isolated city of Gorky brought a swift and explosive reaction from the Soviet state. An article accusing Yelena G. Bonner, his wife, of plotting with the United States Embassy was published in every Soviet newspaper of note, and a personal attack on her was prominently displayed in Izvestia, the Government newspaper. The K.G.B. security police, charged Mrs. Bonner with anti- Soviet crimes, preventing her from returning to Moscow. The Sakharovs' friends and contacts in Mosocw suddenly found themselves carefully watched and without telephone service. Dr. Sakharov was spirited away, probably to a clinic.

title: Houston Men Take N.C.A.A. Title Golf
description: Houston charged from three shots off the pace to give Coach Dave Williams his 15th national championship and North Carolina's John Inman won the individual title with a record 17- under-par 271 today in the 87th National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I golf championships.
