title: Q & A
description: I was about to sell my rights to buy an apartment in a building going co-op and reinvest the proceeds in another home when I was told that since I had never owned the apartment, I would be taxed on the proceeds as income. I was also told that if I owned the apartment even for an instant by doing a ''simultaneous'' closing - buying it and instantly selling it to my buyer - and then reinvesting the proceeds in a new principal residence, I could defer these taxes. Is this true? . . . A. M. G., Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 6 on the marriage of Jocelyn Eve Shorin to Andrew B. Lyss misidentified the bride's father, Joseph E. Shorin. He is president of Aggogle Inc., a product development company. Her stepfather, E. John Rosenwald Jr., is a senior partner in the investment banking firm of Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: SUNDAY, MAY 27, 1984 International
description: Two United States Air Force KC-135 aerial tankers will be sent to Saudi Arabia to provide the Saudi F-15 fighters with refueling capability for longer-range patrolling of the Persian Gulf to defend against further Iranian attacks on oil tankers near Saudi waters, a senior official in the Reagan Administration said. Administration officials are insisting, however, that there are no plans at the moment for American involvement in the conflict. (Page 1, Column 6.)

description: The annual Invitational Pair Championship of the Cavendish Club in New York City staged last week-end was in several ways remarkable.

description: MORE than once, Earl Williams, a New Haven lawyer, has left the courtroom shaking his head and muttering under his breath. He would have liked to give the judge a piece of his mind, he says.

title: MRS. PERON'S RETURN COULD STRENGTHEN ALFONSIN'S HAND
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron returned to Argentina last week for national unity talks with President Raul Alfonsin, but her presence quickly became more critical to unity inside her own Peronist Party. After dominating this country's political life for nearly 40 years until Mr. Alfonsin's election in October, the Peronists face the possibility of breaking up.

title: Theater Review; PRISON SATIRE WITH BITTER LAUGHS
description: TOM EYEN is popularly known as the author of the Broadway hit musical ''Dreamgirls.'' But long before his association with that project, he was one of the leaders of the Off Off Broadway avant-garde. His plays are known for emotionally grotesque material combined with sharp satire.

description: The growing use of undercover techniques by Federal law-enforcement agencies has touched off debate in Congress over controls proposed to guard against abuses and guarantee that the innocent will not be lured into committing crimes.

title: SALVADOR LEFTISTS LOOK TO TALKS WITH DUARTE
description: A spokesman for the political arm of the Salvadoran guerrilla coalition says Costa Rica has agreed to help arrange an ''open dialogue without preconditions'' between the insurgents and the President-elect of El Salvador.

title: TENNIS PLAYERS VIEW FOR OLYMPIC BERTHS
description: THE odds are stacked against them, but that doesn't faze 10 Long Island tennis players who will attempt to make the Olympic team in the qualifying tournament that starts tomorrow at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Ship Captain Guilty of Theft
description: Spirodon Magoulas, a ship captain, was convicted Friday by a Federal jury of stealing 2,636 barrels of oil from a Venezuelan shipment at a refinery of the Cities Service Oil Company.

title: Egyptian Voters Pick New Parliament Today
description: Egyptians will choose a new 448-member Parliament Sunday in elections that President Hosni Mubarak has promised will be the first free balloting since the monarchy was overthrown 32 years ago.

title: OWNERS SPLIT OVER TESTING
description: WHILE lives and careers hang in the balance, the 26 ownerships of major league baseball remain divided about how to handle the drug problem among their players. The split is honest and reasonable, but also unnecessary.

title: THE DOLLAR STILL STRETCHES
description: At the flea market out near the Porte Clignancourt in Paris, some wily furniture sellers have taken to quoting their prices in dollars to Americans. These masters of bargaining understand that the soaring dollar makes their franc prices look cheap. But the result is that at some places, especially those that cater to tourists, the prices aren't as good as they might be, because the sellers have already adjusted them upward.

title: A COURSE IN FASHION
description: WHAT'S the recipe for a successful fashion show? Four things, said Susan Dinhofer of Lynbrook: ''To know the merchandise you're working with, understanding the concepts of the designer, having good models to work with and doing a lot of reading.''

title: COMPOSERS IN HEAVEN RUMINATE ON LABEL
description: They all decided to meet at Parnassus, the new coffee house in the sky, and talk over their mutual concern: musical composition. As you can imagine, it turned into a heated session, what with Beethoven getting on everyone's nerves by pretending not to hear what they were saying and Wagner insisting on having his wife Cosima take down everything he said for use in memoirs, diaries and publicity releases. Mozart did not help much, either, by giggling uncontrollably when Brahms set his beard afire trying to light a cigar.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: A DAY ON THE AVENUE. Written and illustrated by Robert Roennfeldt. Kestrel/The Viking Press. $9.95. (All ages) A wordless picture book that captures an ordinary sort of day, some time perhaps a half-century or so ago, on a street in a provincial Australian town.

description: The New York City Department of Health cited 36 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Mary Otte, an Editor, Weds Kim G. Harper
description: Mary Maxwell Otte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laine Otte of New York, was married yesterday to Kim Geoffrey Harper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth John Harper of Melbourne, Australia. John McIntyre, a celebrant (a term used for people registered to perform marriages in Australia), performed the ceremony at the home of Lee Harper, the bridegroom's brother, in Melbourne.

title: Iona Lutey weds Eric Proshansky
description: Iona Teresa Lutey, a graduate student in business administration, and Eric Proshansky, a law student, both at New York University, were married yesterday at the home of Howard Reed in Kent, Conn. The Rev. David E. Butler, pastor of the Congregational Church of Weston, Mass., performed the nondenominational ceremony.

description: True, the baseball season is still far from the All-Star break, a point that separates the swift from the sure. But in this town sports fans celebrate when they can. And so, perhaps, Chicago Cubs fans may be forgiven for having pennant fever already.

About $42,000 of the proposed $59,000 grant is expected to go next month to their archrivals, Planned Parenthood.

description: Representative James A. Courter's position on military spending was misrepresented in the May 6 article, ''Courter's Audience Growing.'' It gave the clear impression that Mr. Courter might be some sort of closet dove, or at least very tough when it comes to approving military spending.

description: The State Senate, which is Republican-controlled, approved a measure this week that would eliminate the need for a runoff in next year's Democratic primary for mayor of New York City.

title: WEEKEND IN WHITE
description: Climate is the great equalizer: There are essential outfits for every season, especially in summer, as the ones shown here illustrate. Whether inspired by name designers or produced by mass manufacturers, whether expensive or modest in price, such weekend clothes are basic to warm-weather living. he basic silhouettes shown here - all cool and breezy - are generally available at a variety of prices. They are casual musts for protecting oneself from the steamy days ahead.

title: THE OLD-TIME HONEST AMARANTH IS A GOOD CROP FOR SUMMER;
description: Walter Masson is a freelance writer and home gardener.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ TURN UP THE HEAT IN THE GULF
description: WASHINGTON T HE three-and-a-half-year Iran-Iraq war seemed in grave danger last week of exploding into a wider conflict involving neighboring Persian Gulf countries and major external powers. Iraq was, in effect, provoking international intervention by attacking shipping in order to force Teheran to choose between a widened war and negotiations. Iraq claimed last week to have destroyed 10 ships in the Gulf.

title: PANEL, CITING STATE COCAINE PROBLEM, FINDS LACK OF HELP FOR USERS
description: Cocaine use has become New York State's No. 1 drug problem, but state officials have failed to provide adequate rehabilitation services for cocaine users, a State Senate Committee has asserted.

title: MISS OCEANA, 2-1, TAKES ACORN STAKES BY A NECK
description: Miss Oceana swept past the early leaders on the turn and then held off Life's Magic in the closing strides to win the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday and bolster her trainer's claim that she is the best 3-year- old filly in the country.

title: RECYCLING THE PAST
description: Six former lace mills on Long Island's South Shore will be transformed into a shopping mall in the mode of San Francisco's Ghirardelli Square and Boston's Quincy Market, according to owners of the property. The red brick turn-of-the- century mill buildings are on l4 acres north of the Montauk Highway at Waverly Avenue in Patchogue.

title: SETTLETRS' FAMILIES HOLD FIRST MEETING
description: ''DOCUMENT that your ancestors settled in this state or helped establish it before Dec. 31, 1685, and you can be a member of the Descendants of the Founders of New Jersey,'' Harriet Stryker-Rodda said.

title: HOMOSEXUALS SEEKING ADMISSION TO R.O.T.C.
description: Students and faculty members on California's state university campuses are pressing administrators to take action against a Government policy that excludes homosexual students from full participation in the Reserve Officer Training Corps.

title: DUBLIN PROTEST OVER REAGAN VISIT
description: About 1,000 demonstrators led by a group of nuns chanted anti-American slogans and marched in Dublin today to protest President Reagan's visit to Ireland next weekend, the police said.

description: A study of the Criminal Courts in the county has determined that such tribunals are in session only three hours and 28 minutes during an average court day, although the rules prescribe sessions of at least six hours a day.

description: Mrs. James J. Critchley of Forestville, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Cecelia Jane Critchley to Clarke Kimberly Oler Jr., the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Oler of Pasadena, Calif. The wedding is planned for July 28.

title: ANGLER'S NOSTALGIC RETURN TO MASCOMA
description: Although I first fished New Hampshire's Mascoma River more than 30 years ago, its larger trout elude me. I return to the stream two or three times a decade, hoping, as sometimes occurs with a half-understood poem revisited after a hiatus of several years, that its secrets will suddenly become revealad and at least one big trout will succumb to my blandishments. This has happened only once.

title: South Korean Cabbies Riot
description: Taxi drivers demanding higher pay vandalized their company's offices in the southern city of Taegu, destroying more than 30 cars and other property, the police said today.

title: Two Days of Food Riots Are Reported in Haiti
description: Paramilitary policemen sent from the capital have restored order after two days of rioting over food supplies in the north Haitian city of Gona"ives, diplomatic sources said today.

title: FROM ITALY'S ATTICS AND THE ORIENT
description: ANNE MARSHALL ZWACK is a writer who lives in Florence.

title: THE NATION
description: Continental Goes to the Next Window

title: CUSTOM-BUILT LUXURY ON STATEN ISLAND
description: A group of Staten Island builders is taking residential development in a South Shore area near Hylan Boulevard in a new direction with Park Place, a community of large, expensive, custom-built houses.

title: Lag by Women Seen In Quitting Smoking
description: Women who smoke have more difficulty stopping than men, who are more willing to try and are able to stay away from cigarettes longer, according to a new study.

title: No Headline

title: C.H.S.A.A. Track Won by McClancy
description: Msgr. McClancy High School, after trying for 28 years, finally won a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field title yesterday. The Queens team, scoring in 10 of the 19 events, won the association's outdoor championship with 41 points at St. John's University.

title: ROLE PLAYING
description: King of Waters

title: COLLEGE SPONSORS CONCERTS
description: SUMMERS in the county are a musical joy, thanks to the festivals at Lyndhurst and Caramoor, many outdoor park concerts and the Summerfare programs at the State University of New York at Purchase. One festival, however, stands apart from the others by dint of its timing, which neatly spans the traditionally quiet interval between the end of the regular spring season and the start of those intriguing warm-weather adventures. At the ''Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence'' - from June 9 through the college's gala ''Meet the Budget'' marathon on June 24 - one can attend three or four campus concerts each week given by outstanding chamber musicians and ensembles.

title: Ellen Barbara Kessner Marries a Law Student
description: Ellen Barbara Kessner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kessner of White Plains, was married yesterday to Frederick Michael Shortz, a son of Winifred Shortz of Dallas, Pa., and the late Robert Edwin Shortz. Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter, leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Darien (Conn.) Community Association House.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on housing discrimination on page 7 of the Real Estate section last Sunday incorrectly identified two officials of the New York City Commission on Human Rights. Joan M. Thompson is the commission's director of fair housing and Isaiah E. Robinson Jr. is its former chairman.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY YOUR SPRING BULBS DID NOT BLOOM
description: TO a gardener, having the heart of a gambler is an asset. Who else but a gambler would bury bulbs in the ground in the fall and expect them to grow and flower come spring?

title: MUSICALS FARE WELL
description: WHILE serious professional theater in the county flounders, lightweight musical entertainment evidently is flourishing, in both profit and nonprofit status. For the former, consider the five-week extension of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' ending today at Elmsford's An Evening Dinner Theater: its 62d production. (''Kismet'' begins performances Wednesday.)

title: AGORAPHOBES FIND NEW WAY TO COPE
description: CALDWELL PATRICIA STEFFENS gets frequent, frantic telephone calls from strangers late at night, and on Monday mornings her living room here is often filled with men and women she has never met before.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: NEWSLETTERS CAN PROVIDE VALUABLE ANALYSIS
description: Many travelers have special interests that demand more information than newspapers and magazines can usually provide. To meet this need, specialized newsletters have been developed in recent years. Some have grown quickly and have proved highly durable, although the mortality rate is high.

title: WHAT LANDLORDS CAN DO
description: Many harassment complaints revolve around the conversion process, according to Georgia J. Malone, counsel to the Rent Stabilization Association, the landlords' trade group. ''As soon as an owner files an application with the Attorney General to co-op a building, the tenants start making frivolous complaints to delay the conversion process.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPIINON;
SCHOOLS AS SENIOR SANCTUARIES
description: RESPONDING to the enormous population growth on Long Island between World War II and 1970, a total of 803 public schools were built. With the baby-boom period decidedly over, about 20 percent, or 157, of those schools have been closed. A problem for many school districts is what to do with those vacant buildings.

title: COCAINE INDUSTRY HAS SPREAD TO THE AMAZON BASIN
description: Coca leaf plantations and cocaine laboratories have been found for the first time in the vast jungles of the Amazon basin, according to United States and Brazilian officials here.

title: MEMORIAL DAY WEEKEND
description: With the customary observances - the hometown parades and the tributes to fallen members of the armed services - Long Islanders mark Memorial Day this weekend. But since the holiday has also come to signify the start of summer pursuits, there are some less somber traditions on tap, too.

title: FOLLOWING THE BASIC STEPS OR INSTALLING EXTRA TELEPHONES
description: SINCE the installation of one's own telephones is now legal, more and more homeowners and apartment dwellers have been buying their own phones and adding extensions themselves, knowing that buying an extra phone is now a one-time expense that does not involve any labor charge or increase in the monthly telephone bill. In other words, they could now have the convenience of additional phones wherever they wanted them simply by running wires to the new location and installing one of the new modular jacks, then plugging in the extra phone.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Law Firms Held To Anti-Bias Law

title: NEWARK BREWER IS EXPANDING
description: BY ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ NEWARK THE old Krueger brewery in this city is now a neighborhood health center. The James A. Graham brewery in Paterson is an addiction- rehabilitation center. And the onetime Betz brewery in Jersey City is about to become luxury apartments.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: '' MEMORIAL DAY,'' a 14-minute filmed tribute to East Hampton's annual parade and the tradition it upholds, can be seen in one of its rare public viewings today through Thursday at the East Hampton Cinema before each showing of ''The Natural.''

title: GARDENS IN THE WILDERNESS
description: John R. Stilgoe's most recent book is ''Metropolitan Corridor: Railroads and the American Scene.'' He teaches at the Harvard School of Design. THE LAND BEFORE HER

title: No Headline
description: Punishment of Youth For Earring Is Upheld

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Broadcast TV
description: ''My Dinner with Andre,'' which was one of the delights of the 1981 New York Film Festival and surprised everyone by becoming a theatrical hit, is coming to television, where it should look and sound even better on the small screen. The film, directed by Louis Malle, is one of those classics that, in breaking all the rules, doesn't destroy them but simply demonstrates that all rules are flexible.

title: Diane Ball Is Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Diane Marie Ball, a vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, was married to Joseph H. Brendel, a vice president and government affairs officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. The Rev. Vincent McShane performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ball of Rye and the bridegroom a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Brendel, also of Rye.

title: SUPPLY SCARCE AS DEMAND FOR INDUSTRIAL SPACE RISES
description: A resurgent economy, fueling the engine of industrial production, has

title: PRIMARY IN JERSEY IS SEEN AS CRUCIAL BY THE DEMOCRATS
description: As the Democratic Presidential race enters its final stages with crucial primaries on June 5, the three major candidates are courting New Jersey voters using limited budgets, heavy schedules of personal appearances, a blitz of broadcast ads and tailor-made campaign themes.

title: ALONG THE STREET OF SWEETS
description: Supermarkets continue to sprout throughout Jerusalem. But the Moslem Quarter of the walled Old City is, as it was in pre-Roman days, still a place of outdoor markets, with scales balanced not by electronics, but by various-sized metal weights. The most tantalizing foods in this long, stone-paved market are the sweets - cakes and candies that may be the sweetest in the world.

title: U.S. CALLED STRONG FOR OLYMPIC SAILING
description: Each afternoon for the last four weeks during the Olympic sailing trials in Long Beach, Calif., the starting line has been crowded with past Pan American and Olympic medalists, class, national and world champions; collegiate all-Americans, and members of America's Cup and Admiral's Cup teams.

title: CROSSING THE BORDER THAT DIVIDES POLICE AND THE PRESS
description: The paths of reporters and police officers often cross, but the jobs have distinctly separate goals and functions. Some recent events suggest that this boundary is being eroded.

title: BASIS FOR TAXATION CHANGING
description: Ever since condominiums first began to

title: No Headline
description: Judge Limits Prisoners At Old Navy Yard Brig

title:
GARDENING;
WHY YOUR SPRING BULBS DID NOT BLOOM
description: TO a gardener, having the heart of a gambler is an asset. Who else but a gambler would bury bulbs in the ground in the fall and expect them to grow and flower come spring?

title: Tigers Lose 2d Game in Row
description: Dave Henderson's two-run single highlighted a four-run first inning and Bob Kearney hit a two-run homer in the seventh tonight as the Seattle Mariners trounced Detroit, 9-5, and handed the high-flying Tigers a second consecutive setback for only the second time this season.

title: RELOCATION PLAN IS 7 YEARS OLD
description: WHEN the Federal Environmental Protection Agency holds its final public hearing next month on its proposal to relocate the sewage-sludge dump site, now 12 miles east of Sandy Hook, it will have been seven years since the agency first considered the idea.

title: RACE IS HELD A LEGAL FACTOR IN F.C.C. RULING
description: A Federal court has ruled that the Federal Communications Commission has the right to consider the race of an applicant for a broadcast license to help alleviate the ''extreme underrepresentation'' of minorities in the broadcasting industry.

title: PFITZINGER WINS MARATHON TRIAL
description: Pete Pfitzinger said he tossed and turned Friday night from a series of nightmares.

title: GETS REPLY
description: Senator Gary Hart, returning to California to press his drive for votes in the crucial 5 primary, made a wise crack about the state he had just left behind - New Jersey.

title: Nissalke 'Shocked'
description: Tom Nissalke , let go as coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers Friday, said yesterday that he had refused an offer to resign and that he could not accept the reasons given by the team for dismissing him after a 28-54 record in the second season of his four-year contract. ''I'm totally and absolutely shocked by the turn of events,'' Nissalke said from his Salt Lake City home.

title: Cosmos Lose, 3-2
description: Neill Roberts scored the only goal in a shootout tonight to lead Tampa Bay to a 3-2 North American Soccer League victory over the Cosmos.

title: BECK HAS 68 ON LUCKY BOUNCE
description: Charles Henry (Chip) Beck bounced an errant shot off the top of a spectator's head today, and his ball wound up close enough to the pin so that he got a birdie at the par-4 sixth hole. The 27- year-old Beck went on to shoot 4-under-par 68 and take a one-stroke lead after three rounds of Jack Nicklaus's ninth annual Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: HILARY WINTER WEDS JOHN L. THURMAN
description: Hilary Ann Winter, the daughter of Col. Ernest Howard Winter Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Winter of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to John Lochry Thurman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duard Nunn Thurman of Hopkinsville, Ky. The Rev. George Rupp, dean of the Harvard Divinity School, from which the bride and bridegroom received masters' degrees in theological studies, performed the ceremony.

title: THE REGION;
description: Drinking-Age Bill Advances

title: ; WHEN YOU COULD SEE THE UNIVERSE MOVE
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME WHO MADE IT- AND SOME WHO DIDN'T
description: The Supermanagers: Managing for Success, The Movers and The Doers, The Reasons Why, by Robert Heller. Truman Talley/E.P. Dutton, N.Y. 400 pages, $22.50.

title: Chilean President Held Immune in Fraud Case
description: President Augusto Pinochet won a court ruling Friday that upholds his immunity from prosecution on fraud charges.

title: DUTCH MISSILE STAND TROUBLING U.S.
description: Although top officials are saying the opposite in private, the Reagan Administration has adopted a public stand of insisting that the NATO alliance will suffer no damage if the Netherlands declines to allow deployment of new American medium-range missiles.

title: DANCE: HIROSHIMA STORY
description: ''No More Hiroshimas--A Lone Star Shinning,'' presented by the Hiroshima Dancers on Friday, and performed again this afternoon, at Hunter College Playhouse, tells the story in broad allegorical strokes of the effects on one family of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima in August 1945.

title: PLAYGROUND RISES IN DOBBS FERRY
description: '' DISNEYLAND, the second,'' said a tired, happy but almost disbelieving Rolf Suhren as he gazed at his work.

title: Teamsters Will Repay $4.3 Million to Fund
description: The Labor Department has announced that the Central Conference of Teamsters has agreed to repay $4.3 million to the Teamsters Central States Pension Fund, the largest single settlement ever of a pension fund violation.

title: 'HOME' IS A RARE PLEASURE
description: NEW plays, revivals, reinterpretations of classics and second looks at works that failed in the first place for the wrong reasons - discovery and re-discovery - are what we expect serious regional theater to do. We do not need retreads of successful, recent Broadway plays; one tends to approach such selections with some suspicion and much trepidation.

title: GREAT BALLOON MYSTERY HAS JAPAN GUESSING
description: For the last three weeks the Japanese police have been preoccupied with what could be called the Great Balloon Mystery.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THREE New Jerseyans were recently honored for, respectively, efforts to preserve the environment, campaigning for peace and combating disease. Paul D. (Pete) McLain of Toms River, deputy director of the state's Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, an arm of the Department of Environmental Protection, was one of 10 conservationists to receive a Gulf Oil Conservation Award in Washington.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline on an article about firewalking (Travel, May 13) incorrectly indicated that the Greek village of Lankadas is on an island. It is on the mainland of Greece.

title: PEGASUS: RIDING FOR THE DISABLED
description: made up of residents from throughout the county and Connecticut - applauded when 17-year-old Michael Murphy won a blue ribbon last Sunday for his performance in the Advanced Riding Class.

description: IN THE FREUD ARCHIVES By Janet Malcolm. 165 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: RECITAL: A VIOLINIST FROM FRANCE
description: The ground rules for the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition are changing, and to judge from the formal award recital of the 1983 winner Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, that's all to the good. The idea for the competition from its outset has been to encourage the performance of American music.

description: Morrie Goldfischer is a book- publishing consultant.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: TROOP RELIVES CIVIL WAR ACTION
description: THE 20th Connecticut Regiment was mustered into the service of the Union in September, 1862. In the following two years, it saw action at Chancellorsville and Gettysburg before moving west to join General Sherman's Army of the Cumberland on its sweep through Georgia. When the war ended on April 9, 1865, the 20th had fought its way up the East Coast as far as Raleigh, N.C. Only 430 men remained of the original 1,000.

title: FOR CALLERS, JACKSON CITES HIS POSITIONS
description: In the first of a series of phone-in question-and-answer programs in which the three Democratic Presidential aspirants will participate separately, the Rev. Jesse Jackson fielded questions tonight on his approach to human rights and United States aid, his use of an ethnic slur and his position on this country's support for Israel.

title: DIVIDING THE PENSION AFTER A DIVORCE
description: THE most valuable asset that a husband or

title: WATCHING FROM THE SIDELINES AS THE OIL INDUSTRY PLAYS OUT ITS MERGER FRENZY
description: IF the last few merger-hungry months in the oil business prove anything, it's that this is an industry in love with itself. Recent multibillion-dollar deals include Socal's takeover of Gulf and Mobil's pending acquisition of Superior. Major companies are now looking over Occidental, widely assumed to be the next target.

title: LETTERS
description: More on China

title: VAST ARRAY OF CANDIDATES VYING IN ISRAELI ELECTION
description: Today, a week before the deadline for filing nominating papers for the Israeli elections, the political scene is kaleidoscopic.

title: NEED FOR SHELTER AND JOB LEADS WOMAN TO ADMIT OF SLAYING
description: Attorneys agreed that Fayette Mount had a good chance of being acquitted of murder charges if she went to trial. But the unemployed mother of two chose prison because she wanted shelter and job training.

title: A VENERABLE MUSIC JOURNAL IS PLANNING A FACELIFT
description: The music publishing firm of G. Schirmer has decided that the Musical Quarterly, its venerable journal of musical opinion and scholarship, is in need of a discreet facelift as its 70th birthday approaches in 1985. Eric Salzman, a critic and composer, has been appointed as the magazine's new editor; his brief is to nudge the Quarterly away from what is perceived as its academic bent and staid image. ''I would like to see the burning musical issues of the day discussed in MQ,'' said Mr. Salzman recently. ''I want to have a musical journal comparable to the New York Review of Books.''

title: THE DEBATE OVER WOMEN'S STUDIES
Pilot Lands in Parking Lot
description: Lost in fog, a pilot landed his singleengine airplane in a Jones Beach parking lot early today, the park police said. The pilot - Patrick F. Harris, 30 years old, of Shrewsbury, N.J. - radioed Kennedy International Airport that he was unable to proceed, then landed in Parking Lot 4 at about 12:30 A.M., Officer Frank McDermott said.

description: Kitchen People

description: Five youngsters suffered minor injuries Friday night when a ride at a church carnival stopped suddenly, officials said today.

description: IT'S as sure a sign of spring as the first crocus pushing up through the ground, the pastel green buds forming on the trees and the return of the robin's sweet song.

title: Auto Race Canceled
description: The last event of the Formula One auto race series has been canceled, Mayor Sancho Adan Valverde of this Spanish town said today. There is not enough time to modify the urban circuit, he said. The race had been scheduled for Oct. 21.

title: MILITARY CHIEFS RESIST IMPROVING SPECIAL FORCES, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A senior Defense Department official has asserted that the military services have resisted plans to strengthen forces for guerrilla, commando and other special operations despite a high priority assigned by the Reagan Administration.

title: photo of Penn Wilcox; Penn Wilcox Has Nuptials
description: Cordelia Penn Wilcox, a daughter of Mrs. James Simpson Wilcox Jr. of Charlotte and Blowing Rock, N.C., and the late Mr. Wilcox, was married yesterday to Francis Sunfield Branin Jr., a son of Mrs. Branin of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Branin. The Rev. Dr. William Wood performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Charlotte.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Pet Foster Care
description: After the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals closed its shelter in Queens in 1982, Beatrice Cotler, a tenderhearted pensioner in the Forest Hills section, worried about what would happen to stray dogs and cats. A year ago she announced a new volunteer organization, Animal Rescue Force Inc., and a new plan: foster care for stray pets.

description: Aurelia Anna Reinhardt, a daughter of Mrs. G. Frederick Reinhardt of Porto Ercole, Italy, and the late Mr. Reinhardt, was married yesterday to Antonio Gebauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugenio Gebauer of Caracas, Venezuela. The Rev. William C. Woodhams, retired rector of St. Paul's Within the Walls Episcopal Church in Rome, performed the ceremony at Mrs. Reinhardt's home.

description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home viewing. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics. NEVER SAY NEVER AGAIN

title: 110-FT. YACHT SINKS AT FORT TOTTEN BASE AFTER HITTING OBJECT
description: A 110-foot yacht sank while moored last night at the Coast Guard station at Fort Totten in Queens, the Coast Guard said. The powerboat's seven passengers were evacuated without injury.

title: SOME FRIENDS TO FOES IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Several hundred Shiite Moslems demonstrated in West Beirut last week against the Israeli occupation of south Lebanon and they ended their protest with the vehement chant: ''Khaibar, Khaibar, ya Yahood, Jeish Mohammed sa ya'ud.'' The chant extolls the ancient battle of Khaibar, in which the Prophet Mohammed defeated the Jews of Arabia and warns that his army will be returning.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: T WO Bergen County Police Department officers have been named in a $40 million suit charging culpability in the death last year of a 28-year-old New York State corrections officer.

title: Nicole Laccetti Marries R. C. Rives Jr.
description: Nicole Janvier Laccetti, a daughter of Col. Joseph N. Laccetti, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Laccetti of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday to Robert Clement Rives Jr., a son of Mrs. Rives of Washington, Conn., and the late Mr. Rives. The Rev. Thomas Atwood, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the post chapel at Fort Myer in Arlington, Va.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Advances In Italy on a Default
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd advanced to the semifinals of the $150,000 Italian Women's Open today when the defending champion, Andrea Temesvari of Hungary, defaulted because of a back ailment.

title: WILTON FETES IS FAVORITE CARTOONIST
description: HIS work has hung in London and Munich and in galleries of major cities across the United States. But beginning tomorrow, Whitney Darrow Jr., will ''come home'' to the Wilton Library for a six-week retrospective of this most prolific cartoonist.

title: RAISING THE ANTE ON REAGAN'S DEFICIT PLAN
description: The legislative work isn't over yet, but so far the House and the Senate have defied the ''conventional wisdom'' that a deficit reduction package would go nowhere in a Presidential election year.

title: A POULAR BUT NOISY LUNCH SPOT
description: HOW you like Breakaway in Fairfield depends on how you feel about dining in crowded, noisy, smoky places. What this wildly popular eatery has going for it is reasonably good food, a menu with frequently changing specials and some imaginative creations, and outrageously vivid decor.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE HONORS A SUPERB ATHLETE
description: A new commemorative honoring Jim Thorpe has just been issued by the United States at Shawnee, Okla.. This is the town nearest the farm where he was born in 1888 in a place called Prague which was then Indian Territory. It is the latest addition to the American Sports Series.

title: HONORARY DEGREES FOR 5,000: MOTIVES AS VARIED AS SCHOOLS
description: James E. Burke, the chairman of Johnson & Johnson, bowed his head before the 9,100 graduates of Rutgers University Thursday as the university registrar and gonfalonier placed an academic hood with a scarlet lining and white trim around his shoulders.

title: FARMLAND'S VALUE DROPS FOR 3D STRAIGHT YEAR
description: For the third year in a row the value of farmland has dropped, with the biggest declines occurring in Iowa and Nebraska, the Agriculture Department has reported.

description: John Chancellor, senior commentator for NBC News, was a foreign correspondent stationed in Vienna, London, Moscow, Brussels and Berlin. He is the co-author, with Walter R. Mears, of ''The New Business,'' a primer for young journalists. THE NIGHTMARE YEARS: 1930-1940

title: Twins 7, Brewers 6
description: Robin Yount's throwing error at shortstop in the bottom of the ninth inning allowed Tim Teufel to score from second base with Minnesota's winning run.

description: The engagement of Elizabeth A. Savage to John Ripley Wright Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Savage of Pelham, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

description: The delegates of 51 nations that conduct dog shows gathered for the General Assembly session of the Federation Cynologique Internationale last Tuesday and Wednesday. Several sweeping changes that will affect the world of dogs around the world were adopted.

title: AGAIN, THE NIGHT OF IGNORANT ARMIES
description: Three score and 10 years ago, the First World War shattered a self-confident civilization at the summit of its achievement. Now we are looking at a world again divided in half and, under the guise of arming to preserve peace, preparing for another incomprehensible catastrophe.

title: Miss Sadin Weds R. H. Pershan Jr.
description: Shelley Ruth Sadin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Sadin of Bethesda, Md., and Richard Henry Pershan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pershan of New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Walter Jacob performed the ceremony at the Sheraton- Carlton Hotel in Washington.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the article entitled ''What's Doing in Santa Fe'' (Travel, May 13) ticket prices for the Santa Fe Festival Theater were incorrectly stated; tickets for each of the three plays offered this summer range from $8 to $20 a performance.

title: FOR SOVIET EMIGRES, THE 2D HURDLE IS IN ISRAEL
description: More than a decade after the Soviet Union began to permit significant emigration to Israel, many of the 165,000 Soviet Jews who have made the difficult journey are still struggling to find their places in Israeli society.

title: BASEBALL GOING TO JERSEY?
description: NEARLY 30 years after Jersey City was a stepping stone for the Dodgers on their way to Los Angeles from Brooklyn, whispers of major league baseball expansion that could include a New Jersey franchise have begun in, of all places, Jersey City.

title: SALVAGE CREWS IN GULF RISK DEATH FOR RICHES
description: Aad W. van Wijngen was painting his bedroom in Rotterdam last month when he heard that the Safina al-Arab, a giant Saudi-owned tanker, had been set afire by a missile in the Persian Gulf.

description: New versions of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto flow from record companies seemingly by the truckload. It is a commodity on which money is obviously being made.

title: GRADUATES AT BARD HEAR SPEECH WITH A TWIST
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 26 (AP) - Dress ranged from togas to formal wear, and the featured speaker talked about the insignificance of graduation speeches at the 124th commencement at Bard College today.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
COMMUNITIES NEED GUIDANCE ON HOUSING
description: MUNICIPAL governments in New Jersey are still begging for state guidance on how to comply with a nine-year-old court directive requiring developing communities to make room for housing that can be afforded by all income groups.

description: The Soviet Union has protested Japan's celebration this weekend honoring Heihachiro Togo, the hero of Japanese naval victories over czarist Russia in 1904 and 1905.

title: TEMPEST AT LIDO BEACH
description: FOR generations, housands of Long Islanders have used Lido Beach, delighting in its uninterrupted stretch of white sand, clear surf and undulating dunes. It is not an exaggeration to say that the quality of life for many South Shore residents - swimmers, boaters, surfers, surfcasters and sun worshipers - has been greatly enhanced by their proximity to and use of the beach.

title: STUDENTS PLEDGE NOT TO DRIVE AFTER DRINKING
description: Reacting to a student's death in an automobile accident, more than half the students at Hampden-Sydney College in southern Virginia have pledged to avoid driving after drinking alcoholic beverages.

description: Edward A. Perell, a partner in the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, has been elected president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies Inc., it was announced by Robert Coulson, whom Mr. Perell succeeds.

description: -- King Fahd of Saudi Arabia held talks in Jidda today with two high-ranking Syrian officials in an effort to find ways to keep the war between Iran and Iraq from spreading to other countries in the gulf.

description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and the Joint Chiefs of Staff have advised President Reagan to avoid, if at all possible, the use of American forces in the Persian Gulf region, according to Pentagon officials.

description: The marriage of Dr. Rona Spector, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Spector of New York, to Dr. Leslie Alan Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of the Bronx, took place yesterday at the Electchester Jewish Center in Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Samuel Burstein performed the ceremony.

title: SUMMER JOB OUTLOOK SHIFTS
description: This weekend, as the summer season begins, William Butler faces a problem. Each spring he has placed an advertisement for summer help and then sat back waiting to be inundated with applicants. This year he's still waiting.

description: The Army's Stinger antiaircraft weapon, which President Reagan wants to send to Saudi Arabia for defense against attacks on Persian Gulf shipping, has had a troubled development history, records show.

description: Georgia's Cindy Schreyer won a three-hole playoff on a birdie from Martha Foyer of Southern Methodist and Michele Bertiotti of Miami today to capture the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's golf championship.

title: Barbara Barrow To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Barrow of Evanston, Ill., and Bass Lake, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Louise Barrow to Jonathan P. Achenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Achenbaum of Irvington, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 14.

title: ILLEGAL DUMPING WIDESPREAD IN STATE

title: THIS TIME, COAL MINERS DON'T SEEM STEAMED UP
description: The nation's coal miners have begun their contract bargaining at a hotel in Washington. But it is out here in the coal fields, hundreds of miles away, that a contract will be rejected or ratified.

description: Philharmonic: Catching It On the Road Though the New York Philharmonic may leave America, there's no need for Americans to leave the Philharmonic.

description: Dade Countians have entered a new era with the much-delayed debut of their Metrorail train, the backbone of an ambitious overhaul of the mass-transit system aimed at linking parts of this sprawling area and stimulating economic development.

title: Jessica Hecht Engaged
description: The engagement of Jessica Ruth Hecht to Kenneth Bruce Wittcoff has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hecht of West Orange, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wittcoff of Tampa, Fla.

title: NEW HAVEN TO VOTE ON ALDERMENS' PAY
description: NEW HAVEN's aldermen do not always earn much prestige, but they may at last earn some money if the city's voters approve a referendum in November.

title: IN WAR, PEOPLE JUST DON'T CARE HOW YOU PLAYED THE GAME
description: IN 1957 the Hicksville, L.I., Little League championship was won by Levco Drugs. I was on that team. I'm told that for weeks after the day of victory I referred to it as ''the best day of my whole life,'' and in 1957 it probably was.

title: AUTOMOTIVE AUDIO IMPROVES
description: The general exuberance of spring also affects motor cars. Vehicles kept to prosaic errands in the drab season are once again taken for spins in the country and weekend outings. Freshly greased and tuned up, they are prepared for eagerly anticipated summer journeys, and drivers relying on music to shorten the miles are also checking the condition of the sound system.

title: COLOMBIAN REBELS ANNOUNCE A TRUCE
description: Two guerrilla groups, the April 19 Movement and the Popular Liberation Army, have agreed to sign a one-year truce with Government security forces, a spokesman for one of the groups says.

title: TALKING ANTS AND OTHER UNORTHODOXIES
description: ANIMAL THINKING By Donald R. Griffin. 237 pp. Cambridge, Mass. Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: Bonnie Wess to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wess of Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Bonnie Sue Wess to Steven Paul Caley, a son of Lillian Caley of Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late Robert G. Caley. Miss Wess and her fiance are associates in the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye & Warren. They plan to be married in November.

title:
DINING OUT ;
MADISON: NO LACK OF RESTAURANTS
description: THE Morris County borough of Madison has become something of a center for interesting dining of late. An eclectic cluster of engaging restaurants has opened there, including Cook Plaza Cafe (which, by the way, has just changed hands), Four Seas, Sonia Rose and, one of the most attractive of the lot, L'allegria.

title: IT'S AN ECLIPSE
description: Don't risk retina damage by looking directly up at it, but a solar eclipse around lunch time Wednesday will bathe the eastern United States in a strange orange light.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEND 2 AERIAL TANKERS TO AID SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to send two KC-135 aerial tankers with American crews to Saudi Arabia to expand the range of Saudi fighter planes in the Persian Gulf, a senior Administration official said tonight.

title: Barbecue Smoke Problem
description: Jim Overton has a problem with the State Environmental Protection Agency because of the 5,000 pounds of ribs he barbecues weekly at his restaurant, Jim's Rib Haven. The hickory smoke barbecue smell brought complaints from neighborhood residents. The environmental agency said Thursday that the restaurant needed smokestack filters or taller smokestacks.

title: Indonesian Volcano Erupts And Panicked Farmers Flee
description: The Soputan volcano in northeastern Indonesia erupted Friday night with a roar, spreading a blanket of volcanic dust over several villages and forcing 6,000 farmers to flee, a newspaper reported today.

title: MRS. SADAT ASKS GRADUATES TO HELP 'SISTERS'
description: Jihan Sadat, widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, told graduates of Wheaton College today that women from Western nations should address the ''cry for help'' of women from less- privileged countries.

title: SOUTHERN YEMEN JOINS THE OLYMPIC BOYCOTT ADEN, Southern Yemen, May 26 (Reuters) - Southern Yemen said today that it was joining the Soviet Union and other nations in withdrawing from the Olympic Games in Los Angeles. It was the first Arab nation to join the Soviet-initiated move.
description: The Olympic Committee here said in a statement it was boycotting the Games because of ''Olympic violations by the American side and the wild hostility campaign against Soviet athletes and those of socialist states and some developing nations.'' It said such actions endangered the safety of athletes.

title: LETTERS
description: Venice

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW IN ARMONK,POSTCARD CAFE
description: FILLING the need for a restaurant that serves moderately priced fresh food - from snacks to full dinners - The Postcard Cafe, a small, new arrival in Armonk, is worth knowing about even in its present fledgling state. It is full of youthful enthusiasm that begins in the dining room with barn-red walls and ceiling, bare wood tables, pressed-tin wainscoting and a mounted collection of interesting postcards and that ends in the impetuous kitchen. Full of verve and promise, this kitchen has clearly good intentions; but it needs to cultivate patience and finesse. At times, the cooking was terrific, the inventiveness impressive. Other times, however, mistakes reached the dining room - unseasoned food, poorly balanced sauces, ill-conceived dishes - that put into question whether the chef had time or inclination to taste some of the fare.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE MULITFACETED COLONIAL HOME
description: SPRING is the traditional season for heightened activity in residential real estate, and observers expect this spring's housing market to be a good one. Economists speculate that the recent years of high interest rates have created a tide of eager young househunters ready to take the plunge. So what kind of house is likely to sell best this spring?

title: REAGAN FIGHTING TO WIN AID FOR ANTI-SANDINISTAS
description: After more than three years of political controversy over United States policy in Central America, President Reagan and Democratic leaders in Congress are in a power struggle over the Administration's once-covert war against Nicaragua.

title: 'Mingles' Caveat
description: To the Editor:

title: ROLES EXPAND FOR PEG MURRAY
description: WHEN Lillian Cornwall, the leading character in the Off Broadway comedy ''Isn't It Romantic,'' had to choose among career, child and marriage, she opted for the first two, letting her husband go, knowing you can't have it all.

title: HONDURAS SEEKING CHANGES IN MILITARY TRAINING BY U.S.
description: Honduras will ask for changes in the United States-administered military training program, according to the commander of the armed forces.

title: A Closer Look At The Hart Generation
description: AS LONG AS A YEAR AGO, AS long as 12 years ago and longer, Gary Hart knew it would eventually happen - perhaps not in the early years or even last February, the month in which he would be transformed into a major Democratic Presidential contender,. But Gary Hart had analyzed the population figures, he had assessed the men who ran the Democratic Party and he knew that the time would come for what he called the politics of a ''new generation.''

title: PAVAROTTI
description: Luciano Pavarotti performing in Las Vegas U.S.A. Home Video 77 minutes. $59.95

title: Growing Up Together
description: When I showed my wife George Vecsey's article, ''Growing Up Together,'' (About Men, April 29), her immediate response was, ''Did you write this?'' Our first child is now 15 months old, and the time we spend together is the most important in my life. I take great pleasure in his wonder of discovery, and discover more than a few things about myself. ROBERT P. HERMIDA Brick, N.J.

title: A SUPPORT NETWORK FOR YOUNG WOMEN IN DENTISTRY
description: Thirty members of the 57th Street Study Club got together the other night for their regular May meeting. Are they neighborhood activists? No. Real-estate speculators? No. They are young female dentists.

title: An Irate Owner
description: His team had won only 4 of 13 games and was losing by 34 points, so Fred Bullard, the owner of the Jacksonville Bulls, decided things could not get much worse. At the two- minute warning before halftime, Bullard walked onto the playing field Friday night in Jacksonville in the game against the Houston Gamblers to give the United States Football League officials a piece of his mind.

title: RIVALS CALLED NOT FAR APART ON ENVIRONMENT AND ARMS
description: Walter F. Mondale's aggressive attacks on Senator Gary Hart have stirred uneasiness among environmental and arms control groups, who say that the Coloradan's record on these issues matches, and in some cases surpasses, the former Vice President's.

title: BEST SELLERS May 27, 1984
description: Fiction1 112 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.) A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world. 2 27 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $17.95.) One man's experience in the wars of the Holy Land. 3 1 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. Delacorte, $15.95.) The relationship of a mother and daughter changes with changing values over 40 years. 4

title: YALE CONFEREES CALL POLISH UNDERGROUND STILL VITAL
description: A three-day conference on Poland this week, which drew more than 200 experts from all over the United States and Europe, has concluded that the Polish underground culture appears to be as vital as ever.

title: OPENING THE RURAL HEARTLAND
description: IN a little more than 18 months, one of the

title: TAPES HELP A GENERAL DO JOB
description: Kent Hull, the center for the Generals, is a contemporary athlete: He has a video cassette recorder that he said he uses to tape every telecast of a United States Football League gamefor business purposes. He likes to watch the defensive line and the linebackers.

title: SPRINGSTEEN SCANS THE AMERICAN DREAM
description: ''Born in the U.S.A'' (Columbia QC 38653) finds Bruce Springsteen, the most idolized keeper of the flame of American rock and roll, imaginatively coming to grips with the new rhythms and textures of 80's popular music. ''Born in the U.S.A.'' doesn't make a radical leap from old-fashioned guitar-based rock and roll into the futuristic world of synthesizer pop. Rather, Mr. Springsteen, his E Street Band and his team of three co-producers have forged a dense, metallic sound that embraces more mechnical rhythms and textures, but without severing Mr. Springsteen's ties with with Chuck Berry, Motown, rockabilly, and other traditional rock and roll idioms.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PORTLAND
description: Portlanders like to think the yearly deluge of winter rains entitles them to a season of sun-dried days. But rain or shine, the city's residents pack the summer months with activities and celebrations, topped by the annual Rose Festival. Most of the events demonstrate that Portland, despite its growing urban core, retains an outdoor flavor.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SUTTON PLACE
description: Above the buzz of the Franklin D.

title: CITY OFFERS LEGISLATION FOR PRIVATELY RUN RESTAURANT IN BRYANT PARK
description: After months of negotiations involving park advocates and community groups, the Koch administration has proposed state legislation that would permit a private corporation to build a restaurant in Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library.

title: THE REGION;
description: Making All-Day Kindergarten Last All Day

title:
LESSONS FROM THE CONTINENTAL;
THE REGULATORY SYSTEM WORKS
description: THE system works. The United $12 States regulatory authorities have done what was required and have done it well. Confidence in the safety and soundness in the banking system has been reconfirmed. Markets have stabilized. The possibility of a crisis of confidence has been contained. Trade and commerce continue without interruption.

title: MARCOS DEFENDS HIS POWER TO RULE BY DECREE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would resist efforts by the country's revived opposition to curb his law-making powers.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY YOUR SPRING BULBS DID NOT BLOOM
description: TO a gardener, having the heart of a gambler is an asset. Who else but a gambler would bury bulbs in the ground in the fall and expect them to grow and flower come spring?

title: IMMIGRANTS DEFINE AMERICA ON SCREEN
description: ''When we come over here,'' a rueful Russian-Jewish immigrant remembers in ''Hester Street,'' ''we say, 'Goodbye Lord, I'm going to America.' '' More than by anything else, America is defined in movies by the ways in which the eventual reality - for better or worse - differs from the expectations.

title: CELTICS HOPE TO EXTEND TITLE-ROUND DOMINANCE OVER LAKERS
description: Thursday night, April 28, 1966, was eventful in Boston.

title:
OLYMPIC PROFILE: PAUL SUNDERLAND;
RESPECT, AT LAST, FOR U.S. VOLLEYBALL
description: PAUL Sunderland, the 32-year-old elder statesman of the Unitad States men's volleyball team, says he will know when his sport has ''arrived'' in this country: ''When the people who see us in airports stop asking us what basketball team we play for.''

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
CLASS OF '42
description: THE year was 1942, and Bud Mangels, a recent graduate of White Plains High School, was heading to war. Blue- eyed, square-shouldered, he boarded a train at White Plains Station. The classmate who saw him off said she would wait.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY
description: The Burn , 712 North Union Street, Natchez, Miss. 39120 (601-445-8566). This Greek Revival house built in 1832 has six rooms at $81 each. It is now the home of the Mayor of Natchez and his wife, an accomplished cook, who oversees the preparation of breakfast. Two rooms are in the main house, with four in a separate building. There is a swimming pool.

title: Navy Sets New Pilot Rules
description: The Navy has adopted new flight training standards that will require its aviators to have longer arms and shorter legs. The standards will exclude 73 percent of all college- age women and 13 percent of college- age men from flying in the Navy, according to a military spokesman. The standards were devised so that all aviation candidates could reach rudder pedals and see over their instrument panels.

title: Miss Corroon Has Nuptials
description: Suzanne Corroon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Corroon of Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Capt. Richard Boyd Harris, U.S.M.C., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Gray Harris of Clinton, Iowa. The Rev. Joseph E. MacGinnis performed the ceremony at the St. Lawrence of Canterbury Episcopal Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: Jeanne Keller Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Keller of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeanne Alice Keller to Mayor Steven R. Rothman of Englewood, N.J., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rothman of Tenafly, N.J., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

CAMERA;
BIKING AND PHOTOGRAPHY: A GOOD COMBINATION

title: AT HOME IN THE OLD SOUTH
description: Virginia ASHLAWNThis early 19th-century house, the home of James Monroe, is now owned by the College of William and Mary. It is furnished with both Monroe and period pieces. Also of note are the peacocks in the boxwood gardens, a smokehouse and an overseer's cottage. Hours : March to October, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily; November-February, 10 to 5. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. Admission : $3; children 6 to 11, $1; those under 6, free.

title: NEW ROCHELLE TO HONOR PANE
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE irrepressible, outspoken and superprolific pamphleteer of the American Revolution known as Thomas Paine spent much of his time talking to anyone who would listen or writing for anyone who could read the prose carrying his ideas.

description: Toronto

title: Manna Falls on Tenderloin
description: Joseph Ahkenbrandt, who admitted he'd had a few, tossed about $1,000 from a window onto a crowded street on a windless summer evening.

title: Lynn Stetson Marries Alan David Vertrees
description: Lynn Stetson, a daughter of John Charles Stetson, former Secretary of the Air Force, and Mrs. Stetson of Chicago, was married yesterday to Alan David Vertrees, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph William Vertrees of Austin, Tex. The Rev. Milton Winter performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago.

title: WHEN ZONING AND COVENANTS CONFLICT
description: WHEN the countryside was being divided up in New Rochelle in the 1880's, nobody worried about condominiums or parking lots. Residents did worry, however, about the possibility that someone might build smaller houses or ''manufactories'' among the gracious homes they imagined for the future and which indeed were built between 1905 and 1925.

title: THEATER: O'CAEY'S 'GUNMAN'
description: Sean O'Casey's ''Shadow of a Gunman'' is being given an Off Broadway production at the Actors' Playhouse, on Sheridan Square, after a more modest showcase presentation at the Irish Arts Center. In light of the killings in Northern Ireland that continue into the 1980's, a play about The Troubles set in the Dublin of the 1920's provides historical and theatrical perspective today.

title: MIKE NICHOLS: THE SPECIAL RISKS AND REWARDS OF THE DIRECTOR'S ART
description: IKE NICHOLS SIT ERECT, ARMS FOLDED, at a trestle table in a large-windowed, bare- floored rehearsal room, where he is directing a new play by David Rabe. Rabe sits slumped in a chair nearby, ready to leap protectively to the defense of any seeming slight to his precious words. The actors clutch their scripts - insecure, groping, desperate to please - watching Nichols for a sign of approval. Nichols, who is in a position more or less to have his pick of scripts and stars, has experienced both the joys of taking creative chances and the pitfalls of playing safe. He has been nominated for an Antoinette Perry Award for his direction of Tom Stoppard's ''The Real Thing;'' if he wins next Sunday, it will be his sixth Tony. And now - as he intermittently feels compelled to do - he has chosen to try a risky play.

title: 3 Benzene Proposals Dropped
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has withdrawn proposed standards aimed at regulating three industrial sources of benzene fumes, a cause of leukemia in humans.

title: GRIZZLIES' PLIGHT PITS U.S. AGAINST A HUNTER GUIDE
description: Federal officials are seeking to levy penalties against a hunting guide accused of killing a grizzly bear cub. The action reflects growing concern among Federal officials about the country's dwindling population of grizzlies.

title: McCarthy on Didion, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: AFGHAN DRIVE: A COSTLY GAIN FOR RUSSIANS
description: Intelligence analysts studying the often conflicting reports from Afghanistan have concluded that Soviet forces won a considerable but not decisive success in their recent offensive there, but at a higher cost in casualties than they expected. One British source put Soviet losses in the Panjshir Valley at 500 men, plus 2,000 more throughout the country since the offensive started in mid-April.

title: CARSON STERNLY DENIES ASSERTION ABOUT COCAINE
description: Angered by testimony that John Z. DeLorean once confided he was ''involved in cocaine trafficking with Johnny Carson,'' the entertainer turned serious on ''The Tonight Show'' Friday to denounce the allegation as ''totally false.''

title: RELIGION AND KINSHIP STILL CUT DEEPLY IN AFRICA
description: Last month, in the Guinean capital of Conakry, an old woman leaned across a restaurant table and whispered: ''A storm is brewing, I tell you. The Susu and the Fula are plotting against the Malinke.'' Within eight hours, a coup d'etat had overthrown a political structure that had endured for the past quarter century.

title: THE TRAGIC CASE HISTORY OF INTRAVENOUS VITAMIN E
description: From the first hint of trouble, it took more than two months to get a new vitamin E solution off the market, according to Congressional testimony. By then, 38 infants had died after receiving the product, E-Ferol Aqueous Solution, intravenously.

title: HART'S RECENT VICTORIES AID HIS PARTY STANDING
description: Victories for Gary Hart in the Nebraska and Oregon primaries apparently stopped a decline in support for the Colorado Senator in his race for the Democratic Presidential nomination and revived his strength among independent voters, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Quake in the Indian Ocean
description: There was a strong earthquake about 2,050 miles southeast of the Cape of Good Hope in the southwest Indian Ocean today, Hong Kong's Royal Observatory reported. There were no reports of damage or casualties.

title: NEW PRENATAL TEST RAISES CONCERN FOR FETUS
description: New concerns are emerging over possible risks to the fetus in using a highly promising new method of early prenatal diagnosis that has been described as a likely replacement for the widely employed technique of amniocentesis.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Historic Smithville Development Company and a coalition of environmentalists and shellfishermen are back in court, this time appealing decisions by the state's Department of Environmental Protection that have sought to restrict the company's 2,300-acre housing and commercial development in the Atlantic County community of Galloway Township.

title: VOLUNTEERS RESTORE HISTORIC CEMETARY
description: O FFICIALLY, it will be the historic ''African Cemetery.'' At least it will be once the 24-by-38-inch red white and blue aluminum marker is erected by the Westchester County Tricentennial Commission later this summer.

title: Auto Club Sets Annual Costs Of Operating a Car at $3,456
description: It costs 23 cents a mile, or $3,456 a year, to operate a 1984 American-made car, the American Automobile Association has reported.

title: Jane Hammerslough Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Hess Hammerslough, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Hammerslough of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Ezra Palmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Palmer of New York. Justice of the Peace Patrick Sheehan of Weston performed the ceremony at the Hammerslough home.

title: Constance M. Neville Weds Joseph Wetzel
description: Constance Marie Neville, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett Neville of Arlington and Cotuit, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Arthur Wetzel, a son of Ruth Bouza Wetzel of New York and the late Joseph Arthur Wetzel. The Rev. Edward O. Miller performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

description: The Long Wave Cycle, by Nikolai Kondratieff. Translated by Guy Daniels. Introduction by Julian M. Snyder. Richardson & Snyder, N.Y. 138 pages, $30.

description: Two employees of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson railroad are believed to have stolen more than $500,000 in turnstile fares over a five-year period, a Port Authority spokesman said yesterday.

title: JAMES BALDWIN-REFLECTIONS OF A MAVERICK
description: The hair is almost white now, but that is the only indication that James Baldwin will be 60 years old in August. Thirty-one years have passed since the publication of his first book, the novel ''Go Tell It on the Mountain,'' and 21 years since ''The Fire Next Time'' made him an international celebrity.

title: JAPAN WILL USE FOREIGN VESSELS TO GET GULF OIL
description: Japanese petroleum officials said today that because of self-imposed restrictions on Japanese tanker movements in the Persian Gulf, they would begin chartering foreign-manned tankers to carry crude oil to Japan from the Persian Gulf.

description: Dianne Cheryl Jonassen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Jonassen of Farmingdale, L.I., was married yesterday to William Michael Galvin Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. L. Johnson Jr. of Gibson Island, Md. The Rev. Ralph J. Morgan performed the ceremony at the Farmingdale United Methodist Church.

description: Cynthia Freeborn Chace, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick M. Supper of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., and J. description: Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, and French Carter Gamble Goodwyn, president of Corporate Travel Services and Corporate Consulting International in Washington, were married yesterday.

title: CARRIED BACK TO OLD VIRGINA
description: South of Interstate 64, which cuts across Virginia, near the more obvious historic places - Williamsburg, Jamestown, Yorktown - there are two roads that run through 400 years of social history. One is the old Indian road that is now Route 5 and runs into Route 60 East. It was once the main land route to the west. Now the Route 5 section, the John Tyler Memorial Highway, is called a Virginia Byway. So much for fame and social stability.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Peter of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Melinda-Joy Peter to Peter Harold Kern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Kern of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I. The wedding is planned for September.

title: A NEUTRAL COSTA RICA VITAL TO REGIONAL PEACEEditor:
description: Ever since Costa Rica abolished its army 36 years ago, the country has been a model democracy, immune to the violence and political instability which has characterized other Central American nations. Its governments have not been threatened by greedy and power-hungry generals, while its neighbors have not had to worry about being provoked militarily.

description: We read with great interest the article ''2 Jewish Papers Battle for L.I. Market'' (May 6). We are pleased that the issue of U.J.A.-Federation- supported organs versus independent papers is being publicly debated in general as well as Jewish media.

description: The international race to build ever- bigger atom smashers has become so expensive that countries and groups of countries are going to have to give up the habit of building nearly identical ones, according to physicists speaking at the 150th annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

description: To the delight of hundreds of spectators, the ''first annual'' Port Chester bed race rolled down Abendroth Avenue last Saturday, proving as one contestant quipped, ''It's funny to see a person pushing a bed down the street.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'TWO-BRAIN' POWER

title: Miss Peyton Is Bride Of Cpl. Steven Hahn
description: Catherine Craft Peyton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Stewart Peyton of Pennington, N.J., was married there yesterday to Cpl. Steven Dale Hahn, U.S.A., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Phillip Hahn of Chesterfield, Mo.

title: MIXED REVIEW FOR WORKFARE
description: SINCE the state's work program for certain welfare recipients started in 1981, only ''a minuscule number'' have got permanent jobs and been able to leave welfare, according to the state official who oversees the program.

title: PREP SCHOOLS IN A STRUGGLE TO CURB SPREAD OF COCAINE
description: The following article is based on reporting by Maureen Dowd and Jeffrey Schmalz and was written by Miss Dowd.

title: Scotland and England Tie in Tourney Finale
description: Scotland and England drew, 1-1, today and brought to an end the 102-year-old British Soccer Championship.

title: HEADLINERS
description: A Leading Lady for Jaycees If there was any question about how far the Massachusetts Jaycees would go in opposing their parent body on the question of admitting women, it was answered last week.

title: KARCHER TAX PLAN: A LONG W YA TO GO
description: TRENTON THE Assembly Speaker, Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, was cast in the role of ''Robin Hood'' last week when he pushed through the Assembly his bill to raise the state tax on incomes of more than $60,000 to finance higher property-tax rebates.

title: 'HORIZONS' GIVES A HEARING TO LIVING COMPOSERS
description: Horizons '84, the New York Philharmonic's second annual contemporary music festival, gets under way this Wednesday with a symposium at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts on the festival's theme, ''The New Romanticism - A Broader View.'' The first concert, devoted to the music of Hans Werner Henze and Krzysztof Penderecki, follows on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, and the series will continue through June 8 with an admirable range of styles and performing forces and even a mini-festival of computer music next Sunday and June 4.

title: JUST WHAT IS THE INFLUENCE OF AN ANCHOR'S INFLUENCE?
description: A recent survey by U. S. News & World Report finds that influential Americans regard Dan Rather of CBS as more influential than almost anyone. In fact, other than Government officials, Mr. Rather is at the top of the list. When the influential Americans rated other influential Americans, the first nine people they chose, beginning with Ronald Reagan, were elected or appointed office holders. Mr. Rather was No. 10. This was one place in front of Walter Mondale, seven ahead of Vice President Bush, and a full 19 in front of Henry Kissinger. The same survey in 1982 placed Mr. Rather 19th, while the one last year put him 12th. Apparently, he is growing in influence, or at least in the perception of having influence, and while the significance of this is uncertain, one thing is clear: Mr. Rather is not someone who just gets up and reads the news.

title: Watt Lobbies for Indians
description: James G. Watt, who angered some Indians with his comments when he was Interior Secretary, has been hired as a consultant and lobbyist by the Lummi Indian tribe. Gerald James, a member of the Whatcom County Lummi Tribal Council, said the tribe had retained Mr. Watt two months ago because of his business connections.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY FACES PROBLEMS IN RENTAL-REHABILITATION GRANTS
description: The notion of rehabilitating older rental

title: MAAZEL DEPARTURE THE CLIMAX OF DRAMA IN VIENNA
description: --With standing ovations of sold-out houses ringing in his ears, Lorin Maazel, the first American to manage the illustrious Vienna State Opera, is resigning in anger and moving to Monte Carlo. He terminated his four-year contract last month, before his second season was up.

title: SCHOOLHOUSE TO GO TO NEWSITE
description: -ROOM schoolhouse in Easton dating from 1850 is scheduled to make a seven- mile journey to a new location across town this week.

title: ; LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Whooping Crane

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Cocaine is the most powerfully reinforcing of all the drugs. These kids don't have a clue of what they're fooling around with.'' - Robert Dupont, president of the American Council for Drug Education. (1:3.)

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
COMPLAINTS AGAINST DOCTORS:RX TO HASTEN THE POLICING PROCESS
description: DO doctors protect their own? Is organized medicine muzzled by a conspiracy of self-serving silence? Last year, the Nassau County Medical Society received 172 complaints against doctors, a clear indication that people are very much aware of the fact that the medical society functions as a watchdog agency for the public interest.

title: BRINGING BUILDING INSPECTIONS UP TO CODE
description: Like all environments outside of Paradise, the fabled splendor of the hanging gardens of Babylon presented special dangers. Assaulted by termites and weakened by moisture, timbers used to support the terraced gardens collapsed with deadly frequency. To force architects and builders to take precautions, King Hammurabi decreed in the 18th century B.C. that, if a house collapsed, the houses of the architect and builder would be torn down. If the owner of a house was killed in an accident, the architect and builder were put to death. With that order, the King established recorded history's first building code.

title: Border Panel Installed By Central Americans
description: A Nicaraguan-Costa Rican border commission was installed here today to oversee the frontier after recent clashes brought the neighbors close to a break in relations.

title: PRO TRAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH AND MIGHTY
description: A demonstration by the Blue Angels, the Navy's famous stunt-flying team, will be one of the highlights of McGuire Air Force Base's Open House and Capabilities Demonstration tomorrow, Memorial Day.

title: Lois Berry Wed To Jeffrey Meyer In Darien, Conn.
description: The marriage of Lois Berry to Jeffrey Stuart Meyer took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean officiated.

title: NEW WEST BANK POLICY IF ISRAELI LABOR WINS?
description: It is widely imagined, especially abroad, that the Israeli election on July 23 will be primarily a referendum on the future of the West Bank. Since Labor is leading in the polls, many people imagine that the day after the election, some bold new Israeli foreign policy initiative will be announced. A Labor Government will, it is thought, make an offer that King Hussein of Jordan and even some more moderate groups within the Palestine Liberation Organization will not be able to refuse.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; 6 PIPE BOMBS FOUND IN A WISCONSIN TOWN
description: -A sixth trip-wire shrapnel bomb intended to ''inflict harm to people'' was found today in this western Wisconsin city. The police warned parents to watch their children closely over the holiday weekend.

title: HOW SPIRITED THE BIRTH OF THE MINT JULEP?
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT MEN
description: Hitting the Road By Keith G. McWalter Keith G. McWalter

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: MEDICARE, the Federal health plan for the elderly, pays less than 40 percent of the overall health-care expenses of the aged, according to the state's Department of Insurance.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS HART ON CONFIRMING WATT
description: Walter F. Mondale today criticized Gary Hart for voting to confirm James G. Watt as President Reagan's first Secretary of the Interior, and he accused the Reagan Administration of failing to protect environmentally sensitive coastal areas.

title: Contempt Charge for Nap
description: Lyndon Kramer, a 69-year-old retired Army colonel, has been cited for contempt of court because he napped and read while serving on a jury, leading to a mistrial in a civil lawsuit.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WARING: MIXED DOUBLES CAN BE HARMFUL TO YOUR HEALTH
description: YOU cannot play tennis with someone you love, not if you want to be in love by the end of the third set.

title: SALES TAX EXTENSION CHALLENGED
description: THE penny sales tax increase that went into effect in Nassau County two years ago to cover a shortfall in county tax revenues is due to expire at the end of this year, but sharp disagreement has broken out over whether the State Legislature should grant its approval to extend the levy.

title: Talks Fail to Settle West German Strike
description: Talks between West German employers and metalworkers who are on strike to demand a 35-hour week ended Friday night with no sign of compromise.

title: LEGISLATURES TO WEIGH AUCTION OF AIRPORT SLOTS
description: WHITE PLAINS HURRYING to meet a judicial deadline, county legisators have targeted for legislative action a proposed auction method for allocating airline takeoff and landing times at the Westchester County Airport.

title: Rumanian Leader Opens Black Sea Canal
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu today inaugurated a canal linking the Danube to the Black Sea, a huge project intended to speed traffic along one of Europe's busiest inland water routes.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE ART OF THE DECOY CARVER
description: SOUTH DENNIS HANDCRAFTED reproductions of wildfowl to attract their live counterparts as a source of food have been made for centuries.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GYPSY GOLD

title: 'GIRL SCOUT' IN A CIVIL WAR
description: MY CHINA YEARS By Helen Foster Snow. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.95.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OLD DOCUMENTS IN RIDGEFIELD
description: ONE of Connecticut's longest running outdoor antiques shows will open in Ridgefield Saturday at 10 A.M., with 200 exhibitors from throughout the Northeast offering eclectic displays of antiques and collectibles.

title: NICARAGUAN INDIANS TELL CONGRESS OF A REBEL RAID
