description: Three Miskito Indians, testifying this week at Senate hearings on violence against Nicaraguan civilians, said United States-backed rebels attacked their settlement last month, leaving 7 people dead, 39 missing and 15 wounded.

title: GROWING UP TOGETHER
SITE OF AN INDIAN FORT STUDIED
description: WHEN the Corchaug Indians looked for a protected spot to settle on the East End, they found an ideal location on the banks of a creek in what is now called Cutchogue. There they had access to Peconic Bay and yet could observe trespassers before they left their canoes to go ashore.

title: Fittipaldi Becomes Indy Rookie at 37
description: He drives a pink racing car with lavender trim. He has won two world championships. He retired three years ago because he thought that racing was getting too dangerous. And he came out of retirement two months ago to become the oldest ''rookie'' in the Indianapolis 500.

title: Conner Forms Group
description: Dennis Conner , the defending skipper in the last two America's Cup series, has announced the formation of a highly specialized design team he hopes will help the United States regain the yachting trophy from Australia in 1987. Conner said his group, called Sail America Challenge 87, had formed a design team comprised of ''some of the most creative minds in the United States in the fields of naval architecture and well as hydrodynamics and aerodynamics.''

title: SUPERFLY
description: Tent caterpillars were denuding Maine's forests in 1982 when the big Sarchophaga aldrichi swarmed in, and - pow - caterpillars began to die. That was good, forest lovers said.

title: MOTIVE AND CLUES ELUDE POLICE IN SLAYING OF 10 IN BROOKLYN
description: At 7 P.M. on April 15 the bodies of 10 people, 8 of them children, were found on the ground floor of a two-story house at 1080 Liberty Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Laos Rebels Reported To Ambush 40 Troops
description: Anti-Communist Laotian guerrillas ambushed and killed 40 Vietnamese and Government soldiers on May 14 in an attack on a military convoy in Saravane Province in southern Laos, the Thai press agency reported today.

title: HELMS IS ASSAILED BY RIVAL ON FOREIGN STANDS
description: For months, at barbecues and banquets, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina has warned his constituents that a Communist takeover in Central America would send millions of ''feet people'' marching across the southern border of the United States.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
SLOW DOWN 'KING SPEED' AT INDY
description: SPEED is King at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Every year a quarter of a million spectators turn out for qualifying to see cars circle the track one at a time. I don't think fans are coming out to see crashes. On qualifying days they come to see speed. Or hear about it. I think that it's numbers that count more than actual velocity of the machines as the spectators watch them circle the track. Most onlookers can't tell the speed of a car within 15 or 20 miles an hour, anyway.

title: Miss Johnson Marries Jesse Kornbluth
description: Katherine Ann Johnson, a daughter of Anne Cox Chambers, chairman of Atlanta Newspapers and former Ambassador to Belgium, and of the late Louis G. Johnson of Miami, was married yesterday to Jesse Kornbluth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kornbluth of Nashville. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I.

title: TEEN-AGE DRINKING IS THE TARGET OF GROUPS
description: '' ANXIETY hangs like a cloud over all high schools at this time of year,'' said Gae DelCampo, an English teacher at Mahopac High School. ''You talk to any principal and their response will be similar. They are all worried about kids drinking and driving at prom time.''

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Where There's Smoke...

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: LUNG cancer has replaced breast cancer as the leading cause of death of Connecticut women who die of cancer, according to the State Health Services Department.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Pianist, Mezzo-Soprano And a Marimba Player Among New Recitalists

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
PUT RAIL SERVICE FOR THE REGION NEAR THE PEOPLE
description: RECENTLY Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. wrote to Amtrak's president, Graham Claytor, asking that train service from New York to Boston on the ''Inland Route'' be restored. That line goes from New York to Stamford, Bridgeport, New Haven, Wallingford, Meriden, Berlin-New Britain, Hartford, Springfield and Worcester. Much has been written and said about the Inland Route, but, fundamentally it is only two miles longer than the favored Shoreline Route, going through New London and Providence, and serves a far greater population base.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Magnetic Schools
description: With student enrollment down and costs up, the Board of Education in affluent Greenwich, Conn., opened its 13 public schools to outsiders in June 1981 - at a price. It set the tuition fees slightly below what most private schools might charge.

title: Stottlemyre Revenge
description: A decision by George Steinbenner , the owner of the Yankees, to release pitcher Mel Stottlemyre in 1975 apparently cost the Yankees the chance to sign Stottlemyre's son, Todd , to a contract. ''My dad hates his guts,'' Todd said of Steinbrenner.

title: WEAKFISH, WHICH DISAPPEAR EVERY SO OFTEN, IS WITH US
description: SEA TROUT, otherwise known as weakfish, becomes abundant in spring. The season continues well into the autumn. It was not always the case.

title: IN DEFENSE OF COMMODITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: A DC-10 Mishap Impels U.S. To Order a Wiring Inspection
description: The Federal Government has ordered a fleet-wide inspection of the wiring in the warning lights in DC-10 cockpits as a result of an incident in which burning wires caused the crew of a Northwest Orient Airlines DC-10 to declare an emergency and return to their takeoff point.

title: TALENT WINNING FOR CUBS
description: CHICAGO TWO hours before Wednesday's game against the Atlanta Braves at Wrigley Field, Leon Durham, the Cubs' first baseman, sat quietly in front of his locker. He looked content. The Cubs were in first place, and Durham, who suffered through a below par, injury riddled 1983 season, was among the National League leaders in almost every offensive category.

title: Police Say They Control Riot-Torn Indian State
description: The police said today that they were in control of the southwestern state of Maharashtra, where 223 people have been killed in clashes between Hindus and Moslems in the past 11 days.

title: Anne Louise Bloom Wed
description: Anne Louise Bloom, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bloom of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Wayne Brian Graff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Graff of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Michael A. Robinson performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom graduated May 16 from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, she with an M.S. degree in occupational therapy and he with an M.D. degree.

title: Soviet Agrees to a Visit By Olympic Delegation
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, has agreed to receive a delegation from the International Olympic Committee in Moscow this week to discuss the Soviet-led boycott of the 1984 Games, officials reported today.

title: Afghan Radio Says All's Quiet in Key Valley
description: Afghanistan's Government-run radio has reported that reconstruction has begun in the Panjshir Valley, a traditional guerrilla stronghold that the Government says it now controls.

title: Democratic Leaders Said to Be in Doubt
description: Influential Democrats are having growing doubts about their party's chances of recapturing the White House in November, Newsweek reported on the basis of a poll made public Saturday.

title: JACKSON BACKERS DIVIDED IN JERSEY
description: A number of New Jersey supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination say the campaign has encountered organizational divisions in the state.

title: LEAD WIDENS FOR A FEW
description: On the first night of Comdex, the personal computer industry's premier trade show that opened here Tuesday, most of the scores of software companies showing their wares held staid receptions for their biggest customers at the major downtown hotels.

title: MOTIVATING MENTALLY ILL TO 'A LIFE'
description: AT a workshop at the Bronx Psychiatric Center some participants grasped at the hope of finding a way to get an adult son or daughter who is mentally ill out of the house and into rehabilitation, a halfway house or a job.

title: Jesse Jackson's Victory
description: What caught the eye in all the bustle of women in corsages, men in their best suits, red streamers and yellow balloons were the preschool children, filling two rows of seats in the Paterson, N.J., gym. They all wore white T-shirts bearing their own names - Terrell, April, Seth - on the back and the same man's name on the front.

title: Lucia M. Walters Becomes a Bride
description: Lucia Marie Walters, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard J. Walters of Pacific Palisades, Calif., was married yesterday to John Lester Diamond, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Thomas Diamond of Chappaqua, N.Y. and Chilmark, Mass. Judge Arthur L. Alarcon of the Federal Court of Appeals in Los Angeles, for whom the bride is a law clerk, performed the ceremony at a private home in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: BACK BAY BARRISTER TAKES PETER PAN
description: Back Bay Barrister was an easy three-length winner of the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, but the 3-year-old colt failed to show the speed of previous Peter Pan winners who have used the race as a springboard to the Belmont Stakes.

title: GULF WAR: A SHIFT FROM AIR TO LAND?
description: The consensus of intelligence sources here and at NATO military headquarters in Belgium is that the war between Iran and Iraq will be settled as it began in 1980 - in a series of costly land battles. Most analysts expect Iran to begin its long- threatened ''final offensive'' in the next two weeks. They cite as evidence the massing of Iranian forces on the Majnoon Islands in the marshes northeast of the Iraqi city of Basra and the movement of two divisions to Hamid to support ground operations.

title: Spanish Guard Captain Slain
description: A bomb killed a paramilitary civil guard captain and seriously wounded his wife today in an attack believed to have been carried out by Basque separatist guerrillas to coincide with an Armed Forces Day parade, the police said. The bomb exploded under the car of the captain.

title: HOSTILITY TOWARD THE BRITISH IS REVEALED IN EUROPEAN POLL
description: Citizens of Europe's 10 Common Market countries reflect the fractious mood of their leaders, with the French and West Germans expressing particular hostility toward Britain, according to a new poll.

title: NICKLAUS WINS IN PLAYOFF
description: Jack Nicklaus gained his 70th PGA Tour victory and one of his most satisfying triumphs today when he parred the third hole of a playoff with Andy Bean in the ninth annual Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: Pfitzinger Wary on Olympics
description: On Friday night, nightmares kept interrupting Pete Pfitzinger's sleep. On Saturday, he surprisingly won the United States Olympic marathon trial for men. On Saturday night, he still could not sleep.

title: NEESKENS PLANNING A REUNION
description: No player from the four participating teams in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup that starts here Monday is looking forward to the tournament more than Johan Neeskens of the Cosmos, who meet Barcelona of Spain after Fluminense of Brazil plays Udinese of Italy in the first game of the doubleheader.

title: Mrs. Carner Wins
description: JoAnne Carner captured her first title of the year and 40th of her career today by shooting a 70 for a four-stroke victory over Ayako Okamoto in the $150,000 Corning Classic. Mrs. Carner finished at 7 under par with rounds of 71-69-71-70 for 281.

title: TAX-EXEMPTS AND THE SOCIAL SECURITY CHECK
description: To the Editor:

title: CALLER TELLS POLICE HE STABBED 2
description: Two men were stabbed in the back yesterday in Harlem, one of them fatally, and a man later placed five calls to the police to say he was responsible, according to detectives.

title: ZAMBIA ASKS SHIFT BY U.S. ON NAMIBIA
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, who has assumed a prime mediatory role in efforts to end the guerrilla war in South-West Africa, said today that a settlement would be ''jammed'' as long as the United States insisted on linking the issue with the presence of Cuban troops in Angola.

title: LAKERS HALT CELTICS IN OPENER, 115-109
description: With the magical hands of Earvin (Magic) Johnson throwing pinpoint passes and the 37- year old Kareem Abdul-Jabbar tossing in sky hooks with the zest of his youth today, the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Celtics, 115-109, to take a 1-0 advantage in the National Basketball Association championship series.

title: Playing Sousa Softly
description: A man who once marched in the first rank of a high-school band - because he played the trombone - still remembers how the band played Sousa marches in the Memorial Day parade.

title: METS' TORREZ BEATEN
description: If the Shea Stadium fans had their way, Mike Torrez would have packed his bags yesterday and headed home with an 0-4 record and the sound of booing in his ears after the Mets' 3-2 loss to the Dodgers.

title: Stars Trounce Panthers
description: Kelvin Bryant ran for three touchdowns and the Philadelphia Stars turned the rematch of last year's championship game into a mismatch today with a 31-13 victory over the Michigan Panthers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope you will serve your country. The nation as a whole will profit from your private careers, but please give something of yourself back, something more than just tax dollars.'' - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, addressing Colgate graduates. (22:5.)

title: FEMALE CYCLIST BLAZES A TRAIL
description: Betsy King started the Bordeaux-Paris bicycle race two hours before everybody else and finished last, more than an hour after the winner. It was a great triumph and she promised to let no one forget it soon.

title: Eastern Bloc Leads in Cycling
description: Eastern European cyclists dominated the Tour of Britain today with Poland's Marek Lesniewski leading the two-mile individual time trial prologue.

title: BENIGNLY AMBIGUOUS MARBLE HILL
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hampshire Inmate Accepts Nourishment
description: A convicted rapist who had vowed to starve himself to death has accepted nourishment.

title: PROPOSED U.S. TAX REVISION WOULD BENEFIT NINE MILE 2
description: The New York Power Authority would be allowed to use tax-exempt bonds to finance the completion of an upstate nuclear plant under a proposed revision in the Federal tax code.

title: Prices Down For Gasoline
description: Gasoline prices fell

title: Susan Lynn Mayer Is Wed To Dr. Stephen S. Cowan
description: The marriage of Susan Lynn Mayer, a social worker at Mount Sinai Hospital, to Dr. Stephen Scott Cowan, who is to start a residency in pediatrics at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in July, took place yesterday. Rabbi Bernard Cohn performed the ceremony at Congregation Habonim in New York.

title: MUSIC: MARCIA BALL SINGS AT LONE STAR
description: -blues singer and songwriter who models herself after the New Orleans rhythm-and- blues queen Irma Thomas, has become a fixture in the Austin, Tex., musical scene in recent years. Miss Ball, who has released a promising album called ''Soulful Dress,'' has a clear mellow alto that she uses with exceptional restraint.

title: Sharon M. Osen Wed To Research Scientist
description: Sharon Miriam Osen, a daughter of Cantor and Mrs. David Osen of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jean-Marc Halbout, a son of Gisele Halbout of Paris and the late Paul Halbout. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: No Headline
description: Teddy Nadler Is Dead; $264,000 TV Winner

title: Senior U.S. Official At I.M.F. Switched
description: William B. Dale, an American who has served for more than 21 years at the International Monetary Fund, has retired abruptly after 10 years as the deputy managing director.

title: WHEN LILACS LAST...
description: It is the custom at university commencements to talk about commitment to the future: to stand on Mount Pisgah and point out the Promised Land. But before we can deal with the future, graduates and the rest of us in this country need to know something of the past.

title: MEXICO AWAITS JACKSON WITH POLITICAL WARINESS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will arrive here Monday for a visit that he says is intended to increase his understanding of the Latin American view of the region, the international debt problem and immigration.

title: The Economy
description: Machine tool orders rose 23 percent in April from March and were more than double those for April 1983. But industry leaders were little cheered because they said tool makers have only partly recovered from the lowest order levels in history. (Page 33.)

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres , at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Graig Nettles, the third baseman, and the reliever Goose Gossage make their first return since being shipped away by the Yankees. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels , at Anaheim. A rematch after the visit to New York by Reggie Jackson, Tommie John & Co. (Television - Channel 11, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Circus's Gift to Gardeners

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY MAY BE USED AGAINST U.S., OFFFICIAL SAYS
description: A Defense Department intelligence official yesterday said the Government was concerned that American advances in biotechnology might be ''turned against us'' by the Soviet Union and used to create exotic new germ weapons against which there might be no defense.

title: MOYNIHAN GETS A REASON WHY
description: WASHINGTON

title: Heart Ills More Likely For Women, Study Finds By The Associated Press
description: Women who have heart attacks are more likely than men to die, and those women who survive are more likely than men to have a second heart attack, according to a Government study.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from London, Ontario, on May 21 about an event in memory of Guy Lombardo incorrectly described the origin of the brand name Baby Ruth. The candy bar was named for the oldest daughter of President Grover Cleveland.

title: Bomb Explodes on Lot At Las Vegas Hotel
description: A bomb exploded in a parking lot at the strikebound Tropicana Hotel early today.

title: MUSK GAINING A NICHE IN 'UPSCALE' PERFUMES
description: Musk, a centuries-old scent revived by the youth movement of the late 1960's, is becoming a major force in the fragrance market of the 80's. After a decade of slow but steady growth, the earthy scent has outgrown its street origins to again become an important mainline fragrance category.

title: REDS WIN AFTER BRAWL
description: Wayne Krenchicki's run-scoring single in the ninth inning lifted the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-3 victory today over the Chicago Cubs in a contest protested by both teams.

title: MUSIC: DAVID FINKEL, CELLIST
description: The cellist David Finckel is best known for his participation in the celebrated Emerson String Quartet, yet his Wednesday evening concert at Symphony Space proved him an admirable soloist in his own right.

title: No Headline
description: Navy Parachutist Dies In Air-Show Accident

title: ACTORS GULID TRIBUTE SPARKS DISPUTE
description: A gala, star-studded tribute to Hollywood's Screen Actors Guild would seem to be a fairly routine and innocuous television event. But a bitter dispute is brewing just beneath the festive surface of ''The Screen Actors Guild 50th Anniversary Celebration,'' which airs tomorrow night at 9 on CBS-TV.

title: 10 DEAD AS A RECORD RAIN FLOODS TULSA
description: A record deluge from a foot of overnight rain forced waters up to six feet deep through thousands of homes here today, sending mobile homes and cars floating down streams and killing at least 10 people.

title: Amy M. Rosenbaum Marries Kevin Steklof
description: Amy M. Rosenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rosenbaum of Rochester, was married at the Rochester Plaza Hotel yesterday to Kevin J. Steklof, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin R. Steklof, also of Rochester. Rabbi Shamai Kanter performed the ceremony.

title: ; SCHOOL LIBRARIES NEED PRIVATE INITIATIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTDOORS: PLUMBING THE SUBTLE JOYS OF TROUT PONDS
description: MOST fly fishermen prefer to go after trout in moving water. A stream is music and motion: smooth glides, fast, turbulent riffles and deep pools, each posing a special challenge, and - to paraphrase Gertrude Stein - to many anglers a lake is a lake is a lake.

title: DOMINICA, ON THE MAP NOW, HOPES FOR BETTER DAYS
description: The invasion of nearby Grenada last October brought unaccustomed international exposure to this impoverished Caribbean island nation.

title: 12 in Congress Opposed By Anti-Pistol Group
description: The political action committee of the National Committee to Ban Handguns has said it will campaign to defeat 12 members of Congress who have established themselves as major foes of gun control.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ON A PRIVATE INQUIRY
description: When a Federal grand jury was investigating Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in 1982, his former business partner, Ronald A. Schiavone, started a private investigation to learn who was spreading allegations against them both.

title: Alice Scovell to Marry Stuart Coleman
description: Alice Hannah Scovell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin E. Scovell of Newton, Mass., and Stuart Hayden Coleman, a son of Donald H. Coleman and Melissa Hayden, the ballerina, of Winston-Salem, N.C., were married yesterday. Rudolph Kass, a Massachusetts Appeals Court Associate Justice, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Kaufman, the bride's brother-in-law and sister, in Wayland, Mass.

title: Genscher Said to Irk U.S.
description: The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has irked the United States by seeking last-minute changes in a NATO declaration that is to be issued after a ministerial meeting here this week, senior NATO sources said today. The sources said Secretary of State George P. Shultz had written a stiff letter to Mr. Genscher saying that the ministers should not waste time drafting the declaration at the three-day session, which is to start Tuesday. The sources said Bonn had sought to make more positive references to the achievements of detente.

title: KOHL'S D-DAY SNUB BY ALLIES ASSAILED
description: The exclusion of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany from ceremonies commemorating the 40th anniversary of D-day next month has come under criticism here.

title: Israelis Say 3 Soldiers Are Slain in Lebanon
description: Three Israeli soldiers were killed and two others were wounded today in an ambush near the cease-fire line separating Israeli and Syrian forces in southern Lebanon, the military command announced.

title: JEFFERSON'S PROSE JOINS LIBRARY OF AMERICA LIST
description: The dream of publishing a series of American classics that would cover the written heritage of the country is at last becoming a reality on home and library bookshelves. The dream is called the Library of America, and this spring, its select literary club has for the first time been joined by a President - Thomas Jefferson.

title: Senator Hart to Take Questions by Viewers
description: Senator Gary Hart will answer questions on an hourlong phone-in program tonight on two New Jersey television stations.

title: PRESIDENT ZIA VS. FOUR MILLION PAKISTANIS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLUE JAYS WIN DOUBLEHEADER
description: Tony Fernandez's sacrifice fly capped a two-run rally in the bottom of the ninth inning that gave the Toronto Blue Jays a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians, a sweep of today's double-header and a club-record seven- game winning streak.

title: U.S. BANKS SEE LURES IN EUROPE
description: Several of America's biggest banks, chastened by troubled loans to Latin America and in search of fresh fields to cultivate, are expanding their activities in Western Europe.

title: WORLD WAR LESSON STILL UNLEARNED
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq and Iran Delegates Doubt Early Cease-Fire
description: The chief delegates of Iran and Iraq to the United Nations held out little hope today of a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.

title: MONDAY, MAY 28, 1984 International
description: U.S. sales of antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia will be doubled by the Reagan Administration, Administration officials said. The Stinger missiles are intended for use against possible Iranian air attacks on oil tankers, oil fields and other installations. The decision was a response to the Saudi request for more missiles than had been designated in an emergency sale of 200 Stinger missiles and 100 shoulder-held launchers tentatively approved Friday by the Administration. (Page 1, Column 6.) Egyptians voted in the first parliamentary elections since Hosni Mubarak succeeded President Anwar el- Sadat in 1981. Four opposition parties were challenging Mr. Mubarak's National Democratic Party. Opponents said pro-Government crowds stuffed some ballot boxes, burned others, and chased voters from polling places. An opposition candidate was reportedly shot to death by her Government opponent. (1:4.)

title: Tunis Sentences 10 to Death For Killing 2 in Food Rioting
description: A Tunis court has sentenced 10 people to death for the murder of two people during rioting over food price increases in January, judicial sources said today.

title: School Bus Crash Kills 5 in Florida
description: Five people were killed when a school bus and three cars collided today on Seven Mile Bridge, which connects the Florida Keys, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS' GAINS
description: A century ago, today Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., three times wounded in the Civil War, said that we ''must find new fields for action or thought, and make for ourselves new careers. But, nevertheless, the generation that carried on the war has been set apart by its experience . . . in our youth our hearts were touched with fire.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Brooklyn's Black Churches

title: KEY DEBUT AHEAD FOR 'DUNE' MESSIAH
description: A 25- year-old actor who has the still-unknown name of Kyle MacLachlan will soon make the most prominent film debut as a pop-culture hero since Christopher Reeve donned his red cloak in 1978 to play ''Superman.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; Europe's Rusty Pump
description: The American economy's booming, wholesale prices are edging up and it's only natural to start worrying again about inflation. What's hardly natural, claims James Tobin, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, is to allow such American worries to dominate policy making in Europe.

title: MEARS WINS THE INDIANAPOLIS 500
description: Rick Mears won the Indianapolis 500 for the second time today in a record-setting ride that averaged 163.612 miles per hour and left his nearest rival two laps behind.

title: QUESTION BOX;
description: down situation on its 3-yard line, Team A decides to go for the first down. On the play, the quarterback drops back into his end zone, where he is pressured by the defense and throws the ball away to prevent being sacked or intercepted. An official rules intentional grounding by the quarterback, which in this situation normally means a safety would be called against Team A. Since it was fourth down, does Team B have the choice of declining the penalty and taking over the ball on downs at Team A's 3-yard line?

title: HELP FREE SAIGON'S VETERANS TO LEAVE
description: The United States Government is letting slip a chance to free thousands of Vietnamese political prisoners. This is at once careless and inhumane, an evasion of our obligation to a group of Vietnamese to whom we incurred a special responsibility in the war that so many Americans would prefer to forget.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Complaints and Calls

title: Bridge: 3 Teams All Close Together In Grand National Playoffs
description: The three competing teams were virtually neck and neck going into the final 20 deals of the zonal Grand National Team playoffs yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: DIVERS SEEKING RELICS HARM HISTORIC WRECKS
description: At about this time of year, thousands of scuba divers begin exploring lake bottoms and coastal shoals in the New York area in search of shipwrecks and relics, including some that have lain undisturbed for generations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: OPEN TODAY Monday is not a day when most museums receive the public, even less so when holidays fall on Mondays. However, the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street (534-1672), takes an opposite tack on such special Mondays, as it will today when it remains open to visitors.

title: A CITY UNTO ITSELF: OFFICES, STORES AND PEOPLE
description: The Talkofthe WorldTrade Center

title: Explosives Found in Ulster
description: The discovery of two huge explosives dumps may have thwarted plans for a bombing campaign by the Irish Republican Army to coincide with the visit to Ireland by President Reagan this week, police sources said. They said the explosives found in two locations in Northern Ireland last week were believed to be intended for immediate distribution to I.R.A. units.

title: DANCE: ANNABELLE GAMSON PERFORMS
description: Ananda Shankar's Dance Troupe, which made its New York debut on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is dedicated to presenting a modern interpretation of the dance forms of India. Mr. Shankar is following in the footsteps of his father, Uday Shankar, who, in his son's words, ''brought modern dance to India and Indian dance to the world.'' And if the elder Shankar - and Ruth St. Denis, for that matter - could work his way with such cultural forms, why not Ananda Shankar? The problem with Saturday's program, however, was that its greatest claim to artistic distinction was that it was a pleasant way to pass a hot spring evening.

title:
MIDWEST JOURNAL;
TRADITIONS TUMBLING ON PRAIRIE
description: The world did not shake when the announcement finally came the other day. The Cliff Dwellers, an 80-year-old downtown club that is so exclusive most Chicagoans do not know it exists, voted to admit women as members for the first time.

title: SCHOOL LIBRARIES NEED PRIVATE INITIATIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: ARVIDA'S ROLE IN DISNEY PLANS
description: Within the next few months, Walt Disney Productions and the Arvida Corporation are expected to develop plans for thousands of acres of land in Florida and other parts of the United States and Europe. Those plans could substantially change the outlook for Disney - or they could be blocked entirely by stockholders who want to provide the guidance themselves.

title: BASS PLUS WESTWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: SECRETARY REGAN, AT COLGATE, CITES 'ECONOMIC EXPANSION'
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, saying the economic future of the United States was bright, today urged Colgate University's graduates to participate in the nation's ''economic expansion.''

title: NEW EMPLOYER HEALTH PLANS GIVE CASH FOR UNUSED BENEFIT
description: Bernard Krimm, a 36-year-old Chicagoan, may receive as much as $325 in extra cash this year from an innovative health plan. The money will be added to his pay as a speechwriter if he stays away from hospitals and doctors.

title: OPPONENTS: BOXING'S FACELESS, NECESSARY LOSERS
description: THE opponent, Obie Garnett, came to Chicago to fight two weeks before Christmas. He took the bus from Cincinnati, where he worked in a mill. He arrived alone, as opponents often do, and that night he boxed in the Aragon Ballroom, a dance hall with stars painted on the ceiling. He did not know the man who taped his hands with gauze and adhesive, nor the man who served as his second. A third stranger was prevailed upon to carry Garnett's water bucket. A white towel was placed over Garnett's shoulders and the three strangers followed him to the ring.

title: BALLET: IN BOSTON, NEW STAGING OF 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: The Boston Ballet has staged an unusually handsome new production of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Its choreography by Choo San Goh moves swiftly along. Stylistically, it may even constitute a fresh creative departure for this Singapore-born choreographer, who is the assistant director of the Washington Ballet.

title: TRANSFERRING A HEADACHE
description: BOSTON THROUGH the years, the best defense, if not the only defense, against Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has been his occasional migraine headache. Two years ago, in the fifth game of the National Basketball Association championship series with the Philadelphia 76ers, the Los Angeles Lakers' center played with a migraine.

title: LEVY FACES A TEST WITH BLITZ
description: When Marv Levy was 22 years old he received a master's degree in English from Harvard and considered a career that would lead to a college professorship. His first job was at the St. Louis Country Day School as an English instructor - and as head football coach.

title: MANY TANKERS ANCHOR OUTSIDE GULF AND WAIT ABU DHABI, May 27 (Reuters) - The total of tankers of various flags anchored off ports outside the Persian Gulf has risen to about 60 from 10 since Iranian and Iraqi attacks on ships intensified in recent weeks, shipping officials said today.
description: The ports, Fujaira and Khor Fakkan, are on a stretch of the coast of the United Arab Emirates just outside the gulf. The tankers are awaiting orders to load from terminals in Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates, the sources said.

title: TRADE HELPS U.S. JOBS, STUDY FINDS
description: Despite deep import penetration of the steel, automobile and other industries in the 1970's, foreign trade produced an increase over all in manufacturing jobs in the United States, according to a new Brookings Institution study entitled ''Can America Compete?''

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: High Price of Track The highest-paid American athlete in track and field is Carl Lewis, who will attempt to win four gold medals in the sprints and long jump in this summer's Olympics. He gets $6,000 to $15,000 for each meet in the United States, sometimes more in Europe.

title: China Reports It Drove Vietnamese From 2 Hills
description: China said today that it had ejected Vietnamese troops from two hilltop positions they had held since Vietnam and China fought a border war in 1979.

title: Lazard Senior Partner To Coordinate Change
description: Michel Alexandre David-Weill, the chairman of a new partnership intended to forge closer links between Lazard's independently-run banking houses in New York, Paris and London, admits he is very excited by the new arrangement.

title: STUDIES SHOW VIETNAM WAR FAILED
description: Officials of the Central Intelligence Agency concluded in 1966 and 1967 that United States bombing in North Vietnam was not only ineffective but also left the North Vietnamese with more transport and other military assets than they had before the bombs began to fall.

title: NAZISM AND YEARNING
description: REFLECTIONS OF NAZISM: An Essay

title: RAISING NEW YORK DRINKING AGE TO 21
description: A sharply divided Legislature is scheduled to vote tomorrow on whether to raise New York State's drinking age for the second time in two years.

title: A SILICON CORRIDOR BUDS QUIETLY IN PHILADELPHIA
description: When it happened, nobody seemed to be looking. Even if searchers had looked, it would have been hard to see.

title: TURNOUT LIGHT IN VENEZUELA VOTE
description: Voters chose among candidates for 1,592 municipal offices across the nation today in an election that opposition parties tried to make a test of President Jaime Lusinchi's economic austerity policies.

title: CENTENNIAL FOR SELLERS OF BOOKS
description: Norman Hall had too much to drink the previous night, so he was in no condition to call on stores that morning to sell them books from his Farrar & Rinehart list. But while he was nursing his king-sized headache, a salesman from Little, Brown sold Mr. Hall's list for him, and later sent the orders to his home.

title: TWO GREAT RIVALRIES RESUME: BIRD-JOHNSON, CELTICS-LAKERS
description: ''HERE, look at this,'' the Los Angeles Lakers' coach, Pat Riley, said one recent afternoon as he sat in his bright and spacious office at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. He handed his visitor a large black-and-white photograph. ''Isn't it something?'' he asked.

title: WNET SERIES SURVEYS WORKS OF BALANCHINE
description: The two-part ''Balanchine'' that begins on WNET/13 tonight at 8 - the second half will be broadcast next Monday - is a biography of the choreographer Georgi Melitonovitch Balanchivadze, born in Czarist Russia in 1904. Later, of course, he would come to be known as George Balanchine, or simply Mr. B, recognized throughout the world as a major force in the history of ballet. He died last year.

title: Political Action Urged
description: Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Connecticut, addressed graduating seniors at Mount Holyoke today, urging them to exercise their political power, right away.

title: Advice Given On Latin Debt
description: Senate Banking Committee

title: New Threats to U.S. Citizens Reported by Beirut Embassy
description: A spokesman for the United States Embassy in Beirut said today that new threats of kidnapping or death had been made against United States citizens living in Beirut.

title: DANCE: ANANDA SHANKAR
description: Ananda Shankar's Dance Troupe, which made its New York debut on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is dedicated to presenting a modern interpretation of the dance forms of India. Mr. Shankar is following in the footsteps of his father, Uday Shankar, who, in his son's words, ''brought modern dance to India and Indian dance to the world.'' And if the elder Shankar - and Ruth St. Denis, for that matter - could work their way with such cultural forms, why not Ananda Shankar? The problem with Saturday's program, however, was that its greatest claim to artistic distinction was that it was a pleasant way to pass a hot spring evening.

title: Candidate Is Suing N.B.C.
description: A minor Democratic Presidential candidate, Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. filed a $1 million lawsuit against NBC, Friday, accusing the network of unfairly excluding him from a planned debate among the other contenders.

title: U.S. TO SELL SAUDIS 200 MORE MISSILES WITHIN THREE DAYS
description: Analysts expect Iran to begin its ''final offensive'' against Iraq soon. Military analysis, page 4.

title: Ruth Ann Katzka Weds Jeffrey David Zukerman
description: The marriage of Ruth Ann Katzka, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Katzka of Old Westbury, L.I., to Jeffrey David Zukerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zukerman of Bel Air, Calif., took place yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel. Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski performed the ceremony,

title: FOR BONN, A LOSS OF FOREIGN INFLUENCE
description: With Soviet-American relations worsening, officials here say the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl appears to have momentarily lost influence in Washington and Moscow, while other foreign policy initiatives have been blunted by budgetary restraints and domestic politics. A growing sense of foreign policy drift and impotence was caught this month by the shuttlings of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to Washington and Moscow. Before leaving for the American capital, Mr. Genscher had vowed to highlight Bonn's anxieties about the Reagan Administration's so-called Star Wars military initiative. But he came home with little more than vague promises of consultation over the development of antisatellite and antimissile weapons.

title: MAN HONORED FOR WARNING OF HITLER PLAN
description: Gerhart Riegner remembers the day in August 1942 when he sat in his office in Switzerland, looking out over Lake Geneva toward Mont Blanc. Several days before, he had sent a cable to the United States and Britain with news of Hitler's plan to exterminate European Jewry.

title: Japanese Plant for Ohio
description: KTH Parts Industries, a venture of four Japanese companies affiliated with Honda of America Manufacturing Inc., said Friday it would build a $30 million auto parts plant about 30 miles northeast of Dayton, Ohio.

title: LOSING A JOB: HOW WOMEN COPE WITH THE SHOCK
description: It almost always comes as a shock, even though the signals have been out for some time and the office has been full of gossip. The staff is being cut and executives in middle-level positions who have been performing well are among those whose services are no longer required. Or maybe there is only one executive being dismissed, but the reason has nothing to do with competence.

title: NEIGHBORS' DEBTS CAUSING PROBLEMS FOR COLOMBIA
description: Years of cautious financial management have so far saved Colombia from joining the long line of Latin American countries unable to keep up their foreign debt payments, but gradually Colombia is being besieged by the problems of its neighbors.

title: Pedroza Wins
description: Eusebio Pedroza of Panama retained his World Boxing Association featherweight title today with a unanimous decision over previously unbeaten Angel Levy Mayor of Venezuela. There were no knockdowns in the 15-round bout.

title: HAITIANS SAY POLICE CRUELTY TOUCHED OF 4 DAYS OF RIOTS
description: Residents in this northwestern city said today that the immediate cause of rioting last week was the beating by policemen of a pregnant woman, who later died of her injuries. They said it was the latest in a series of such incidents of brutality against civilians.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aquanautics Corp., San Francisco, a manufacturer of scuba diving equipment, has named Robert Bosler president of the Imperial Manufacturing Co., a subsidiary.

title: The Writing on the Courtroom Wall
description: Every time the Supreme Court looks back at its 1979 decision allowing a courtroom to be closed for pretrial hearings on evidence, it seems to regret it. A unanimous Court discussed Gannett Co. v. DiPasquale again last week and, without overruling it, severely refuted its reasoning.

title: THEATER: 'FIRECRACKER,' A BETH HENLEY COMEDY
description: When Beth Henley is really flying, her comic voice has the crazed yet liberating sound of a Rebel yell. In ''The Miss Firecracker Contest,'' her comedy at the Manhattan Theater Club, this Mississippi-bred playwright reaches that high pitch for the first time since her celebrated debut, ''Crimes of the Heart.'' Who but Miss Henley can describe one tragedy after another and send us home smiling? This time, we hear about midgets, orphans and deformed kittens - and they're the fortunate ones. Other characters, whether on stage or off, are afflicted by cancer, tuberculosis, venereal disease and, most of all, heartbreak. Even so, the evening's torrential downpour of humor - alternately Southern-Gothic absurdist, melancholy and broad - almost never subsides.

title: BRIEFING
description: Of Peyote and Headgear

title: MUSIC: EDMUND NIEMANN IN DEBUT
description: The pianist Edmund Niemann neatly bisected his venturesome debut recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Thursday evening, devoting half of it to recent Minimalist compositions, the other half to a retrospective of works by the late Stefan Wolpe.

title: MIGRATION OF AFFLUENT WHITES TO HARLEM FORECAST
description: Two social scientists at Columbia University have detected signs that a process of gentrification has begun on the western edges of central Harlem that could ultimately displace a large number of poor blacks with affluent whites.

title: WAGNER COLLEGE GRADUATES 504
description: Assemblywoman Elizabeth A. Connelly told the graduates of Wagner College on Staten Island yesterday to volunteer their time to civic and charitable organizations.

title: Mayor Bradley Seeks Commission Vacancies
description: Mayor Tom Bradley has asked 150 Los Angeles commissioners to resign by June 1, prompting speculation that he may be preparing for another gubernatorial race in 1986.

title: AS BRAZIL'S COURSE SEEMS SET, POLITICAL FIRES DIE
description: Pots and pans were banged, some car horns sounded and a few fireworks crackled in several Brazilian cities on Friday evening. But to many people here the simultaneous cacophony sounded more like a dirge for a buried dream than a powerful political statement.

title: No Headline
description: Gail Zeltman a Bride

title: Jonathan Rosenbloom Weds Debra F. Kenis
description: Debra F. Kenis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Kenis of Chesterfield, Mo., was married yesterday to Jonathan B. Rosenbloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram H. Rosenbloom of New York. Rabbi Bernard Lipnick performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Amoona in University City, Mo.

title: OPERA: BEL CANTO COMPANY PRESENTS MARCHETTI'S 'RUY BLAS'
description: Giuseppe Verdi dominated Italian opera from the early 1840's to the advent of Puccini around the turn of the century, but many fine composers worked in his shadow. The Bel Canto Opera's current production of ''Ruy Blas'' suggests that Filippo Marchetti was one of the finest.

title: OLD CZECH BONDS TO BE PAID IN PART
description: More than 60 years after being issued, defaulted Czechoslovak bonds with a face value of about $3 million will be honored - at least, in part.

title: TOOL ORDERS JUMPED 23% IN A MONTH
description: Orders placed last month for machine tools rose 23 percent from March and were more than double the April 1983 level. Still, the industry organization that compiles the figures saw little to cheer about.

title: HENDERSON ROMPS AS YANKEES LOSE
description: Gracefully combining the different parts of his game, Rickey Henderson bedazzled the Yankees today. The Oakland A's defeated the Yankees, 7-1, and Henderson, playing his highly stylized game, was on base in each of their four rallies.

title: UP A LAZY RIVER WITH THE PORTHOLES ARMED
description: About a month ago, emissaries from the Soviet Embassy here got in touch with two senior aides in President Reagan's re-election campaign to talk about politics, according to people involved in the campaign.

title: MARKETS ROLE AIDS GROWTH AT REUTERS
description: For millions of newspaper readers, the name Reuters has been familiar for more than a century on news stories from every corner of the globe. But to investors considering the merits of Reuters' 114 million-share stock offering that will come on the market here and in New York Thursday, the company's main attraction is its other, nonnews side.

title: MUSIC: BOBBY ROSENGARDEN OFFERS SALUTE TO RAY NOBLE
description: The Rainbow Room's current series of salutes to big bands of the past are, as a rule, given a sense of verisimilitude by the use of arrangements made famous by the bands and by the presence of singers associated with them - Jack Leonard for the Tommy Dorsey salute in mid-May, Johnny Desmond for the Glenn Miller salute that starts June 5.

title: No Headline
description: 3 Young Children Die In Fire in Bensonhurst

title: THE ISOVENTIONISTS
description: ''Nothing that is not a real crime,'' wrote Joseph Addison centuries ago, ''makes a man appear so contemptible and little in the eyes of the world as inconsistency.''

title: K Mart Executive Plans Push for New Products
description: It was, reflected Robert E. Brewer, executive vice president for finance at the K Mart Corporation, ''a curious argument.''

title: ACCORD REACHED IN TAX DISPUTE ON OFFICE TOWER
description: The builders of a midtown office tower have agreed to pay $7 million in disputed property taxes, and the city's tax incentive board, in turn, has given them a tax exemption worth at least $7 million.

title: HART SPURNS MONDALE CALL FOR APOLOGY TO NEW JERSEY
description: Senator Gary Hart today spurned advice by Walter F. Mondale that the Senator apologize to New Jersey voters for an offhand remark about the state.

title: CORPORATIONS ARE DISCOVERING FRUITFUL PARTNERSHIPS WITH HIGH SCHOOLS
description: When Fairchild Industries honored two high school students with a festive dinner in 1981, the teen-agers stunned the chairman of the aerospace conglomerate by criticizing the company for reaping ''indecent'' profits.

title: F.C.C. RULE CHANGE CREATING A SCRAMBLE OVER MICROWAVE T.V.
description: A section of the television airwaves once reserved for programming by colleges and schools has become the latest battleground in an intense struggle to exploit the commercial potential of pay television.

title: Minnesota Bomb Case Similar to 6 Others
description: A six-inch pipe bomb, similar to six found in La Crosse, Wis., went off here this morning, and the police say a note similar to those found with the Wisconsin bombs was recovered.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
description: Ward Fills Up a Wall

title: Ex-Government Leaders Call For Reagan-Chernenko Talks
description: A group of 26 former Government leaders concluded a three-day meeting today with a call for a meeting between President Reagan and Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader.

title: A DEAN OF PEDIATRICIANS LOOKS AT TODAY'S FAMILY
description: Dr. T. Berry Brazelton was concerned. ''There's something I started noticing in my practice over the last year or so and it really shook me up,'' said the Harvard University pediatrician before an utterly silent conference audience. ''It's a phenomenon I've begun to be aware of among expectant mothers who know they'll have to be going back to work up to three months after the baby is born.''

title: NEW INTEREST IN CANADA FOR OIL-SANDS PROJECTS
description: Development of Alberta's massive oil-sands resource is moving ahead rapidly, after staggering for several years because of stagnant oil prices.

title: DELEGATE GROUPS CONTINUE DESPITE MONDALE'S PLEDGE
description: Walter F. Mondale promised last month to shut down the delegate committees formed to support his candidacy and return all the money they had collected from labor union sources. But so far he has not fulfilled that promise.

title: Letter: On Housing
description: To Prevent Harassment by Landlords

title: UNKNOWNS' TOMB HAS 4 WARS' DEAD
description: The American serviceman buried today at the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery joins three other men buried at a monument intended to memorialize all Americans soldiers who died in 20th-century wars.

title: HOLOCAUST: GATHERING IN MEMORY
description: The last of the generation that faced the horror will someday be unable to bear witness.

title: MORRIS WINS 10TH, HALTING TIGER SLIDE
description: Jack Morris became the first 10- game winner in the major leagues and stopped the Detroit Tigers' three- game losing streak by defeating the Oakland A's tonight, 6-2.

title: YALE AWARDS 3,086 DEGREES IN DOWNPOUR
description: As graduates, faculty members and spectators huddled under umbrellas and wrapped themselves in makeshift coats of plastic bags, Yale University awarded 3,086 degrees here today in the midst of a teeming rainstorm.

title: POP: WILLIE NELSON SINGS
description: WILLIE NELSON and his loose association of musicians known as the Family ambled onto the stage of the Radio City Music Hall last Thursday and demonstrated that a knowing casualness and simplicity of performance can make genuinely eloquent pop music. The understated passion of Mr. Nelson's performances was significantly more powerful than the singing on some of his recent albums, which have seemed to strain for a self-consciously monumental aura.

title: The U.N. Today May 29, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Archbishop Visits Scranton
description: In his address, Archbishop O'Connor talked about his faith in the youth of this nation and was greeted by warm applause when he asked, ''How ya doin'?''

title: MUBARAK'S PARTY WINNING IN EGYPT
description: President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party appeared to be winning a commanding majority in Egypt's parliamentary elections, official returns showed today.

title: Toews Retires
description: Loren Toews , the linebacker who played 11 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers, has retired. Toews, drafted out of California on the eighth round in 1973, will accept a job with a major commercial bank, according to a team spokesman.

title: GWYNN FINDS THE CAMERA DOESN'T LIE
description: The purchase was made with the

title: WILDLIFE REFUGES: PEOPLE AND POLICIES INTRUDE
description: The national wildlife refuges, islands of natural shelter for birds and animals in a sea of human development, are coming under increasing assault.

title: 'A MAN OF THE RIGHT' IS ROUSING PASSIONS IN FRANCE
description: Almost every night last week, there was a campaign rally, and almost every night there was a fight to go with it, a scenario of sirens and blood: Jean-Marie Le Pen speaks, the crowd shouts ''Fascist! Racist!'' and politics turns into clubs and fists and the gyre of lights from tens of police cars.

title: TAXPAYER HANDOUTS FOR TOP EXECUTIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Tuesday

title: POLICE COUPLES TRYING TO MANAGE ADDED STRESSES AND FRUSTRATIONS
description: The house was quiet. The dishes were washed and the children in bed when the police radio in Detective Joseph Foushee's bedroom crackled with a report of a slaying in a housing project. The police who had responded were chasing a suspect.

title: NEW POPULAR MANDATE FOR PRESIDENT MARCOS
description: To the Editor:

title: 24 Flee Nursing Home After 2 Bomb Threats
description: Two bomb threats at a nursing home today forced the evacuation of 24 elderly residents. The incident occurred as the police investigated a rash of pipe bombs discovered in Wisconsin and Minnesota.

title: LONDON TALKS TO TEST HOPE FOR ECONOMY
description: A year ago the leaders of seven major industrial democracies met in the restored colonial village of Williamsburg, Va., for three days of cloistered discussions. At the end they arrayed themselves on the world stage, before a sea of television cameras and journalists, and issued a communique promising a stronger world economy.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Suspect Is Held on Coast In $1 Million Robbery
description: A suspect has been arrested in a daytime robbery of more than $1 million in cash from an armored car company and another man is being sought.

title: STINGER SALE: MIDEAST BALANCING ACT
description: In recent years, American Administrations pondering policy decisions have repeatedly been faced with choosing between Israeli and Saudi concerns.

title: 400 MISSILES SENT TO SAUDI ARABIA, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: The United States has sent 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia, which plans to establish a protected zone for shipping along the western coast of the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.

title: THE STAGE: 'ELIZABETH'
description: HOT on the heels of a brilliant revival of Stephen Sondheim's ''Pacific Overtures,'' the York Theater Company has handsomely mounted ''Elizabeth and Essex,'' a musicalization of Maxwell Anderson's 1930 blank verse drama ''Elizabeth the Queen.'' Though not especially innovative, the show (which had its premiere in 1980 at the South Street Theater) is decidedly high-toned. Michael Stewart's and Mark Bramble's book maintains Anderson's carefully elevated diction, and Douglas Katsaros's music aspires to the kind of semiclassical elegance we associate with Stephen Sondheim and Leonard Bernstein.

title: STAGE: 'ZONES OF SPIRIT,' EMULATING STRINDBERG
description: THE corrosive effect of art on the artist who creates it is the principal subject of ''Wormwood,'' the more consequential of the two plays that share the title ''Zones of the Spirit.'' Both plays, on stage at Theater for the New City, were written by Amlin Gray in response to, and in emulation of, August Strindberg. Where productions of actual works by the Swedish playwright frequently avert his self-excoriating spirit, Mr. Gray's inventions are themselves penned with wormwood.

title: RAPID GROWTH FOR SOME PUBLISHERS
description: A decade ago Facts on File would not have been among the exhibitors at the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association. That is because since its founding in 1940 it had been almost exclusively a news digest for libraries.

title: Letter Backs Enstar Offer
description: The Enstar Corporation said yesterday that it was sending a letter to shareholders in which it supported the offer for Enstar by the Unimar Company.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. This improved San Diego team has the look of a seasonlong contender.

title: CONCERT: VIOLIN STUDENTS OF SUZUKI METHOD
description: ONTO the stage of Carnegie Hall they stepped, 60 young musicians between the ages of 4 and 16, armed with miniature violins. Friday night's concert by the Haag-Leviton Academy of Performing Arts - under the joint direction of Julian Leviton and Betty Haag - and the Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Henry Mazer, was a celebration of Shinichi Suzuki's controversial pedagogical methods.

title: FOR STUDENTS IN GREAT NECK, TOES TAP, VOICES SOAR AND THE PLAY'S THE THING
description: It was March 20, the second day of tryouts for ''Anything Goes,'' and Alan Lehrman, the drama teacher, was narrowing the field. ''Don't read any special significance into it, if I ask you to read for a particular part,'' he said.

title: Nissalke Fights for Job
description: Tom Nissalke , dismissed as coach by the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday with two years remaining on his four- year contract, is appealing to the team's owners for reinstatement. Richard Watson , secretary on the club's board and an attorney for Gordon Gund , one of two brothers who own the club, said he had three conversations with Nissalke during the weekend.

title: RETAINING VALUED ATTORNEYS
description: Paul Koepff joined Davis, Polk & Wardwell in 1973 fresh out of Duke Law School, expecting, like most of the other first-year associates, to work hard and ultimately become a partner in the firm.

title: SOVIETS SEND SUPPLY SHIP TO SALYUT 7
description: The Soviet Union today launched an unmanned cargo ship to supply the orbiting station Salyut 7, indicating the spacecraft may still be suffering from mechanical problems.

title: 19 Are Killed in Fire In a Taiwan Hotel
description: Nineteen people were killed today in a fire in a downtown hotel.

title:
SCOUTING;
Spring Advocate
description: Don't add Howard Schnellenberger's name to the list of such people as Donald Trump who are advocating that the United States Football League switch to autumn play.

title: Police in Peru Destroy 45 Cocaine Factories
description: The Peruvian Government said today that its police destroyed 44 secret airports, dismantled 45 cocaine processing factories and captured 47 people in raids on a smuggling ring operating in the nation's northeastern jungles.

title: TEXT OF ISRAELI STATEMENT ON INQUIRY
description: Following is the text of a statement today by the Ministry of Defense on the cause of death of two of the four Arab terrorists who hijacked an Israeli bus last month, as made public in translation from the Hebrew by the Israeli Government Press Office: (1)

title: Zola Budd Wins British 1,500 Title
description: Zola Budd won the 1,500-meter final at the British track and field championships today in the world- class time of 4 minutes 4.39 seconds, breaking the championship record by 9 seconds.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: LANDMARK One of the best views, a glimpse that somehow sums up two aspects of the city, may be had on Wall Street, looking west through the long wall of concrete that frames, almost as in miniature, the church that is the spiritual anchor at the end of the street dedicated to money.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Journalists' HangoutBecomes a Gift Shop
description: Where the picture of Leo the bartender used to hang is a row of Smurf dolls. Where the Herald Tribune writers used to lean against the bar, sometimes playing the match game, always complaining about editors, is a row of shelves.

title: CONTINENTAL DEPOSITORS GET OFFER
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the troubled Chicago bank, said yesterday that it was trying to woo back individual depositors by offering to repay the penalties they had suffered when they withdrew their funds in the recent run on the bank.

title: FIGHT ON DRINKING AGE NEAR VOTE
description: Governor Cuomo has mounted the strongest lobbying campaign of his administration to try to persuade legislators to raise New York State's drinking age to 21 from 19.

title: A DC-10 Mishap Impels U.S. To Order a Wiring Inspection
description: The Federal Government has ordered a fleet-wide inspection of the wiring in the warning lights in DC-10 cockpits as a result of an incident in which burning wires caused the crew of a Northwest Orient Airlines DC-10 to declare an emergency and return to their takeoff point.

title: People
description: * Kent De Felice promoted to general manager of Geers Gross, New York.

title: BANK STOCKS: 'DON'T PANIC'
description: WHAT'S ahead for bank stocks now that the nation's banking system repeatedly has battled rumors and skirted crisis? Late last week, prices of numerous major banks sank to their lowest levels for a year or more.

title: Fighting Female Poverty
description: The phrase ''feminization of poverty'' is apt to summon the image of a young mother with no husband, several children and little hope of getting a job. But the image is incomplete: females make up 57 percent of America's poor, and nearly one-third of them are elderly. A woman over 60 is twice as likely to be impoverished as a man her age.

title: BLACKS BOYCOTT TV STATION IN MISSISSIPPI
description: From the pulpits of this city's black churches, in union gatherings and in political meetings across town, the message has been going out all spring: Turn off Channel 3. Don't watch the news on WLBT-TV.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day.

title: HART PRESSES MONDALE TO RETURN DISPUTED FUNDS
description: Gary Hart today accused his leading rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Walter F. Mondale, of ''attempting to have it both ways'' by failing to return money used by delegate selection committees to elect Mondale delegates.

title: Bonn Denies a Disagreement With U.S. Over a NATO Text
description: West Germany today denied that it had irritated the United States by trying to strengthen references to the importance of East-West relations in a NATO declaration to be issued this week.

title: BRIEFING
description: A 'Gray Eminence'

title: ; THE ROAD TO TRILLION-DOLLARENERGY SAVINGS
description: To the Editor:

title:
SCOUTING;
Hofstra Prospect
description: An outstanding prospect for the Hofstra basketball team next season will be Willie Brown, a 6-foot-8-inch forward from Macon, Ga., who averaged 25 points and 18 rebounds as a high school senior.

title: Financial CorporationAppoints an Executive
description: High and volatile interest rates make life perilous for financial institutions, particularly savings and loan associations that specialize in making long-term home mortgages.

title: Morning Bob Wins at Keystone
description: Morning Bob rallied from more than 18 lengths back to beat favored At the Threshold by a head in the $221,400 Pennsylvania Derby at Keystone Race Track today.

title: BEST OF AMERICAN FALL DESIGNS
description: The best American fashion collections for fall and winter make a strong statement about how women can dress for both comfort and charm. They are clearly focused, so each designer's message is comprehensible, and easily adapted to individual needs.

title: SPURNED VETERANS JOIN RITE AT TOMB
description: Three hundred Vietnam War veterans in combat fatigues and jeans, refused a place in the official funeral procession, marched silently in their own tribute today, far behind the coffin bearing the remains of an unknown serviceman who had been their comrade in battle.

title: Rainbow Programming
description: Rainbow Programming Services of Woodbury, L.I., has switched its account to Fearon O'Leary Kaprielian from Slater, Hanft, Martin. Rainbow, which is expected to spend almost $2 million a year for advertising, is made up of the Bravo, Sportschannel and Playboy cable TV channels and has a subscriber base of more than 1.5 million. The assignment is for both trade and consumer advertising in print, radio and TV.

title: NEW YORK AIR SPARKS BOSTON SHUTTLE RIVALRY
description: Bill Marro, a manufacturing representative for a small company in the Boston area, sat contentedly in a red seat at a New York Air gate at La Guardia Airport waiting to catch the shuttle to return to Boston.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Reuters news service in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the company's pretax earnings for 1983. They were $76.5 million.

title: NO MUD ON HIS SHOES
description: William J. Casey, the Director of the C.I.A., has dismissed as ''clearly a partisan document in a political year'' a House report linking him to the theft of Carter Administration briefing papers. But that doesn't explain why Mr. Casey's prime accuser is another high-level Reagan Republican - James A. Baker, the White House chief of staff.

title: One Killed in New Delhi In Bangladesh Protest
description: One person was killed and three were wounded today outside the Bangladesh Embassy when the police fired on a crowd protesting what its spokesman said was a takeover of Hindu properties by the Bangladesh Government.

title: CALIFORNIA PRIMARY RULE SPINS OFF 45 CAMPAIGNS
description: Democratic Party officials say that California's Presidential primary campaign this year is evolving in some ways into 45 ''minicampaigns,'' one in each Congressional district, because of new procedures for choosing delegates to the party's national convention.

title: 7 RUN IN SOUTH JERSEY PRIMARIES FOR CONGRESS SEAT
description: The new 13th Congressional District in New Jersey runs the breadth of the state's southern half, stretching from the industrial towns on the Delaware just upriver from Philadelphia to the Atlantic resorts on Long Beach Island 50 miles to the southeast.

title: Merle Nancy Witkin Weds Richard Milder
description: Merle Nancy Witkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Witkin of Edison and Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard James Milder, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Milder of the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norman Weitzner performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: ONE OF 58,012 VIETNAM DEAD JOINS THE UNKNOWN
description: His voice choking with emotion, President Reagan led the nation in a state funeral today for the only American known to have perished in the Vietnam War who is still unidentified.

title: NELLIE CASMAN
description: Nellie Casman, a longtime actress and songwriter in the Yiddish theater, died Sunday in St. Vincent Hospital.

title: COURT ASKED TO LIMIT AID FOR HANDICAPPED
description: AT least twice each school day, Amber Tatro, a second grader in Irving, Tex., leaves the classroom and spends 5 to 10 minutes with a nurse who inserts a catheter into her urethra to drain the child's bladder.

title: PIDGIN IS THE FASTEST GROWING OF CAMEROON'S 285 LANGUAGES
description: More than a thousand languages are spoken between Cairo and the Cape of Good Hope. Some 285 of them are spoken in Cameroon, including French and English, the ''official'' languages here.

title: COSMOS GET A WET VICTORY
description: Many of the 37,629 spectators who braved the continuous rainfall at Giants Stadium today came primarily to watch Diego Maradona, the heralded forward for Barcelona of Spain. Instead, they saw Steve Moyers of the Cosmos provide the best individual play and lead the Cosmos to a 5-3 victory in the first round of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup.

title: ACTORS GUILD MARKS 50TH YEAR
description: NOT too many unions get to have a birthday party on prime-time television but, perhaps understandably, the Screen Actors Guild is different. Tonight at 9 on CBS-TV, the guild can be seen having a two-hour ''50th Anniversary Celebration,'' produced for the occasion by Bob Precht for Smith- Hemion Productions. After all, how many other unions can deliver so many members with familiar faces?

title: CHOOSING THE BABY'S SEX IN ADVANCE
description: AFTER the birth of their daughter three years ago, Charles and Marilyn Cox of Mason, Mich., agreed that they wanted one more child and that it was to be a boy.

title: Torch Bearer at 99
description: Ansel Stubbs , a 99-year-old Kansas City man, has agreed to help carry the Olympic torch across that city June 8 as it heads toward Los Angeles. Mr. Stubbs, who will become the oldest bearer of the flame in the country, says that he will carry it on behalf of the Y.M.C.A., of which he has been a member since 1899.

title: Olympic Aide to Make Final Plea to Soviet
description: The International Olympic Committee said today that Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, may receive the committee's president this week to hear a plea for a reversal of the Soviet-led boycott of the Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let us, if we must, debate the lessons learned at some other time. Today we simply say with pride: Thank you, dear son, and may God cradle you in his loving arms.'' - President Reagan, honoring unknown Vietnam casualty. (A14:2.)

title: JEWISH BOOK UNIT HONORS 10
description: Roman Vishniac, author of ''A Vanished World'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), a volume of photographs that he took in Berlin and in the ghettos of Eastern Europe before the Holocaust, has been named winner in the visual- arts category of the 35th annual awards of the Jewish Book Council.

title: WRITER SEES LIFE REPLAYED FOR FILM
description: A well-dressed middle-aged man is striding purposefully down the street. Suddenly his step falters; he hesitates, wincing, then grimaces, gasps and clutches his chest. He staggers to the curb, reaching out to a parked car for support. As he slumps onto the car, clawing at his breast pocket for a vial of pills, a woman passing by stops to ask worriedly if he needs help. Shaking his head, he waves her away.

title: Zimbabwe Senator Criticizes Army Troops
description: A white Senator who is also a prominent cattle rancher in Zimbabwe's troubled Matabeleland Province criticized the army today for avoiding combat with anti-Government rebels. He said he and other white ranchers will leave of the region because of what he called a lack of protection from the army.

title: French Dairy Farmers Kidnap a Milk Official
description: Dairy farmers kidnapped the head of the French Milk Board today and held him captive for eight hours to protest curbs on milk production.

title: The Democrats: A Delegate Update
description: delegate switch in North Dakota,

title: European Steel Output
description: Orders are picking up in the European Community's steel industry, but output is still low and job losses continue unabated, according to new figures from Eurostat, the community's statistical organization.

title: MAY CHANDLER GOODAN
description: May Chandler Goodan, the oldest daughter of Harry Chandler, former publisher of The Los Angeles Times, died Saturday. Mrs. Goodan, who was 91 years old, was twice elected president of the California Division of the American Cancer Society.

title: FIT TO FIGHT WINS AT BELMONT
description: Fit to Fight drew alongside A Phenomenon rounding the stretch turn, and the two horses ran as a team to the wire, where Fit to Fight thrust his head in front for a stirring victory in the $303,500 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ECONOMISTS QUESTION EFFECT OF RATES
description: With bond prices down sharply and yields skyrocketing since the middle of January, economists are wondering how much momentum the economy is apt to lose from higher interest rates.

title: 20th Century Sculpture
description: An exhibition titled ''20th Century Sculpture: Selections From the Metropolitan Museum of Art'' is on display through Oct. 31 at the Storm King Art Center on Old Pleasant Hill Road in Mountainville, N.Y. Works by Alexander Archipenko, Henry Moore, Mark di Suvero and Isamu Noguchi are are included. Admission is free. Information (914) 534-3115.

title: HARLEM HOSPITAL IS LOSING ITS PLASTIC SURGERY PROGRAM
description: The Harlem Hospital Center, which will lose its orthopedic residency program June 30, is scheduled to lose another surgical residency program, in plastic surgery, a year from now.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1984 International
description: Washington has sent 400 missiles to Saudi Arabia, which plans to establish a protected zone for shipping along the western coast of the Persian Gulf, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the Saudis had bought the 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles and 200 missile launches. (Page A1, Column 6.) Oil exports from Kuwait have begun to be affected by the shipping war between Iran and Iraq, according to oil industry sources. Kuwait is geographically the most vulnerable country on the Persian Gulf. (A8:1-2.)

title: Geers Gross Gets All Of Bass Shoe Business
description: Geers Gross Advertising, which about a month ago got a $1 million project from G. H. Bass & Company, a shoe manufacturer in Wilton, Me., has now acquired the rest of the company advertising, which totals about $5 million.

title: THE WONDERS OF DISCOVERY ABOUND IN EVERYDAY LIFE
description: AMID all the esoterica, carefully guarded by skillfully invented jargon, there was at least one reminder at the A.A.A.S. meeting here that science is not, at its core, the exclusive experience of an academic elite armed with sophisticated tools.

title: 100 Are Reported Killed In a Landslide in China
description: About 100 people were killed and 50 injured by a landslide in southwestern China that was caused by heavy rains, a provincial radio reported today.

title: A MEASURE OF HOLIDAY STABILITY
description: IF any one factor stabilized the

title: LKP Chief Retires
description: LKP Advertising president John Walsh, 51, who suffered a heart attack last December, last week announced his retirement from the company. He was president for four years, having joined as general manager in 1966 from McCann-Erickson.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.83

title: EUROPEANS IN POLL TAKE CENTRIST LINE
description: The Europe that will elect a new European Parliament next month cleaves to the political center, is worried about unemployment and doubts the benefits of membership in the Common Market, according to a new poll in the 10 countries of the European Economic Community.

title: Most Jersey Leaders See Mondale Winning There
description: Fifteen of the 21 county Democratic chairmen in New Jersey say they believe former Vice President Walter F. Mondale will win the state primary.

title: Syrian, in Soviet, Faults U.S.
description: Vice President Rifaat al-Assad of Syria, who arrived in Moscow for a ''friendly visit,'' and Vasily V. Kuznetsov, First Vice President of the Soviet Union, issued a statement today condemning what they called the ''adventurist'' United States policies in the Middle East, the official Soviet press agency Tass said. Tass said Mr. Assad and Mr. Kuznetsov urged the Palestine Liberation Organization to restore unity to its ranks and blamed the ''aggressive actions of Israel and the interventionist policy of the United States'' for the situation in the Middle East.

title: COLOMBIA CEASE-FIRE BEGINS AND THE CAPITAL CELEBRATES
description: Thousands of people took to the streets waving white handkerchiefs today as a sign of peace to celebrate the start of a yearlong truce between the Government and Colombia's largest guerrilla force.

title: Bridge: A Westchester Team Wins Playoffs in Grand National
description: A foursome representing Westchester County emerged early yesterday as winners of the Grand National Team zonal playoffs at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Port Chester, N.Y. Slow play and other factors delayed the proceedings, which concluded at 2 A.M.

title: THE RULES OF CHAOS: DNA AND JUPITER
description: JUPITER'S giant red spot has retained its shape over hundreds of years amid the icy blasts and storms of the Jovian atmosphere. Scientists are trying to determine how it keeps its remarkable order amid chaos.

title: Battleship to Be Renovated
description: The battleship Missouri, on which the Japanese surrendered in World War II, will get a $400 million facelift after three decades in mothballs.

title: Comings and Goings The Minnesota Twins' president,
description: Cal Griffith , said he hopes to complete a deal to sell the club to the Minneapolis banker Carl Pohlad on Thursday. . . . The Chicago White Sox right-handed pitcher Salome Barojas has been sent down to the club's farm team in Denver and the right-hander Bert Roberge has been called up to replace him.

title: ROCK: SIMPLE MINDS GROUP
description: LIKE so many other new wave rock bands, Simple Minds, the Scottish quintet that appeared at the Beacon Theater on Friday, writes and performs essentially amelodic music. Typical songs like ''Up on the Catwalk,'' ''Glittering Prize'' and ''Promise Me a Miracle'' are rock dirges with few notes and thick chiming guitar and keyboard textures.

title: PENSKE'S GAMBLE PAYS OFF IN THE 500
description: Roger Penske, the race-car designer who took a gamble and won the Indianapolis 500, considered the extremes of the business today: One of his cars took first place by five miles, but another lost second place by 10 seconds.

title: TWO PADRES, SAME SERMON
description: Several months ago, Rich Gossage and Graig Nettles escaped from the Bronx Zoo, where they had been two of the most fascinating attractions: the golden Goose of the bullpen, the acrobatic Author at third base. Yesterday they arrived at Shea Stadium in the brown and gold vestments of the San Diego Padres, perched atop the National League West while the Yankees floundered. And the sermons of the two Padres were virtually the same.

title: Olympic Trials Begin in Tennis
description: Ed Ross of Gainesville, Fla. and Jill Smoller of Larchmont, N.Y., the top-seeded players in the men's and women's division of the United States Association's Olympic qualifying competition, scored easy first-round victories yesterday. Ross, a sophomore at Southern Methodist, beat Ed Coates of Houstan, 6-1, 6-2, while Miss Smoller, a sophomore at Arizona, defeated Cammy McGregor of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., 6-1, 6-2.

title: PLAN TO SELL SURPLUS PROPERTY TO LOWER DEFICIT HITS SNAGS
