description: A Reagan Administration program to sell surplus Federal property as a way to reduce the budget deficit has generated much less revenue than expected.

title: A BRITISH COMIC AND TV STAR
description: Eric Morecambe of Britain's Morecambe and Wise comedy team died early this morning of a heart attack sustained at the curtain call of a performance in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. He was 58 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Tuesday

title: BUSES IN THE MICROWORLD ARE ROADS, NOT VEHICLES
description: IN the microworld of computers,

title: GENERALS TOP BLITZ ON 14-POINT RALLY
description: Two fourth- quarter touchdowns, both ''wind- aided,'' according to Coach Walt Michaels, enabled the Generals to beat the Chicago Blitz, 21-17, tonight at Soldier Field before the United States Football League's smallest crowd of the season.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEEKS SUPPORT IN EUROPE
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa left here tonight for Western Europe on an eight-nation tour aimed at reducing the international isolation of his white minority Government.

title: John Henry Wins Hollywood
description: John Henry added another honor to his career today, winning the $300,000 Hollywood Invitational Turf Handicap for the third time. Ridden by Chris McCarron, John Henry, the 3-5 wagering favorite of a cheering crowd of 48,008, finished a half-length in front of the french-bred Galant Vert. Load The Cannons was another 2 3/4 lengths behind in the field of nine. the victort was worth $165,000 and increased John Henry's career earnings, the most of any thoroughbred even to $4,652,997.

title: Helms-Hunt Poll Finds Race Too Close to Call
description: Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican, and Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. are running even in their battle for Mr. Helms's Senate seat, according to a Gallup Poll in North Carolina.

title: Slew o' Gold Hurt in Mishap
description: Slew o' Gold was to have made his first start as a 4-year-old at Belmont Park yesterday in a seven-furlong allowance race, but instead he spent the afteroon in his stall ''looking like a kid who fell off a bicycle,'' in the words of his assistant trainer, Andy Elder. Last year's champion 3-year-old broke loose from Willie Freeman, a groom who was walking him in the morning outside barn 7.

title: MISS MALEEVA, 17, UPSETS MRS, LLOYD
description: Seventeen-year-old Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria took a nap between matches today, then went out and upset top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-3, 6-3, to capture the Italian Open women's tennis tournament. The title was Miss Maleeva's second in 15 days, following a victory in the Swiss Open.

title: No New Leads In 2 Stabbings
description: The police said yesterday that they had no new leads in the stabbings of two men Sunday in Harlem.

title: PARTNERSHIPS ELUDE WOMEN
description: THE United States Supreme Court ruled last

title: Abe Spitzer, B-29 Crewman I A o N
description: Abe Spitzer, a crewman on the plane that dropped an atomic bomb on Nagasaki during World War II, died Friday in an automobile accident in White Plains. He was 72 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Debt Issues
description: Condec Corp. , a valve and machinery company in Old Greenwich, Conn., said that on July 9 it would redeem all of its outstanding 5 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 1993 at 101.8 percent of principal plus interest accrued.

title: SMITHKLINE: ONE-DRUG IMAGE
description: ''One thing you'll see is a lot of crowding,'' Stanley Crooke said. ''I don't want people too separated. That's not the way to make good drugs.''

title:
SCOUTING;
A Late Entry Is Too Late
description: Some golfers will go to almost any lengths to make sure that their entries for the United States Open arrive before the deadline at the offices of the United States Golf Association in Far Hills, N.J.

title: DANCE: AMERICAN BALLET
description: ANTONY TUDOR is known for the psychological revelations of his characters and ballets. Those revelations are delivered to precisely set steps and gestures. But Mr. Tudor's hardy ''Jardin aux Lilas'' withstands a surprising range of subtly distinctive interpretations. Presented by the American Ballet Theater Thursday in the Metropolitan Opera House, ''Jardin aux Lilas'' offered two role debuts that made it newly vivid.

title: UNEVEN SPICE FOR A POTPOURRI
description: In the Indy 500 telecast shown by

title: NEW ATTACKS ARE MADE ON MEDICAL EDUCATION
description: NEW attacks are being made against medical education in the United States. The latest is by Derek C. Bok, the president of Harvard University, who says it is ''far too narrow,'' and that the objections raised against changing it are ''shopworn and unconvincing''

title:
PLAYS;
NICKLAUS SURVIVES A COSTLY MISTAKE
description: DUBLIN, Ohio

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Safari on Lower East Side
description: One of the sidelights of the annual

title: How to Rescue the Olympics
description: The United States Olympic Committee shows admirable initiative in trying to get the Games reorganized before they're destroyed by partisan protest. Moving quickly after Moscow's decision to boycott the Los Angeles Games, the committee has proposed new rules to discourage boycotts of all kinds, and not just by superpowers. The new rules would be coupled with a permanent and crucial agreement on where the Games are to be played.

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND IN NEW ROLE
description: IT is always newsworthy when a

title: MILITANT OF 60'S WINS HONORS
description: Twenty years after he started the student's free speech movement in Berkeley, Mario Savio graduated Phi Beta Kappa from college.

title: EDINBURGH ARTS FESTIVAL UNDER LABOR PARTY FIRE
description: Early this month, the voters of this staid Scottish city, which has an elegant and harmonious core but more than a few seamy and unsalubrious residential neighborhoods, stunned almost everyone by giving the Labor Party control of the Edinburgh District Council for the first time.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Better Off? (1934)

title: VENEZUELA'S RULING PARTY SWEEPS LOCAL VOTE
description: President Jaime Lusinchi's Democratic Action Party has assured itself of undisputed political control in Venezuela for the next four years with a resounding victory in municipal elections.

title: BILL TO CREATE AGENCY TO FINANCE CITY WATER PROJECTS GAINS SUPPORT
description: A New York City finance authority that would borrow $4.1 billion in the next decade to finish a water tunnel and repair crumbling water and sewer lines in the city would be created under legislation that has won the support of key lawmakers and Governor Cuomo.

title: JACKSON HEARS MEXICAN VIEW OF CUBA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and a dozen Mexican senators struck an expected tone of agreement today in a meeting nearly two hours long on such issues as ending increasing militarization in Central America.

title: Micronesian Art
description: An exhibition of Micronesian art is on view through June 8 in the visitor's lobby of the United Nations, First Avenue and 45th Street.

title: BIG GUARDS NEW N.B.A. PLOY
description: For a long time, change in professional basketball focused almost exclusively on the centers and the different ways Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Dave Cowens played the pivot. But with the arrival of the 6-foot-8-inch George Gervin in San Antonio and the 6-9 Earvin (Magic) Johnson in Los Angeles, the emphasis in coaching strategy appears to be switching to playing big men in the backcourt.

title: MONDALE DEFENDS HIS ACTIONS ON DELEGATE GROUPS
description: Walter F. Mondale insisted today that he had stopped his disputed delegate committees, and he brushed aside a report that he had been unable to fulfill his promise to shut down the groups formed to support his candidacy.

title: LAROUCHE'S GROUP FIELDING SLATE OF CANDIDATES IN JERSEY PRIMARY
description: In addition to the three major Democratic Party candidates on the ballot for the June 5 Presidential primary, New Jersey voters will find the name of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr.

title: Canada's Thomson Names a President
description: W. Michael Brown has been named president and chief operating officer of the International Thomson Organization Ltd., Lord Thomson of Fleet, the publishing and oil company's chairman and chief executive officer, announced in London.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: METS DEFEATED BY PADRES
description: A crick in Hubie Brooks's neck put a dent in Dave Johnson's plans yesterday.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: TWO weeks ago, every other New

title: KEY FARM LABORATORY PLANS 'OVERDUE' MOVE TO GENETICS
description: Federal agricultural scientists here are planning an ambitious and, some say, overdue shift in emphasis from conventional plant and animal breeding programs to genetic engineering and related biotechnologies.

title: The Neighbors 11, the City 0
description: Good sense in Queens took an 11-to-0 beating at the Board of Estimate last week, while public officials who know better cheered.

title: MOVING THE U.S. EMBASSY IS 'ANTI-ISRAEL'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFLICT IS FOUND IN MANILA INQUIRY
description: A Philippine Air Force sergeant's account of the slaying of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. appears to support accusations that the opposition leader was killed by soldiers, the counsel of a board of inquiry said today.

title: Protype's Inventive Leader
description: Stephen L. Kurtin, president of Protype, a new California-based high- technology company, seems to like starting new companies almost as much as he likes to invent things.

title: AUTOPSIES: TEACHING TOOL
description: THE autopsy is often thought of as a procedure to help the police investigate crime, and David A. Kennedy's is a case in point. But autopsies can be a good deal more by being important educational tools for doctors, as illustrated by the case of George Balanchine.

title: THE OLD RICH ARE DIFFERENT
description: RICHARD DOUGHERTY has seen it all at least once as newsman, press secretary and big-time flack, and before departing the Metropolitan Museum's public affairs office to write ''a harmless, innocent, innocuous and one hopes amusing detective novel,'' he paused, lit up one in a seemingly endless chain of Merit cigarettes and delivered himself of some observations concerning the big rich.

title: Full Slate of U.S. Issues Scheduled
description: The Treasury has a full schedule of auctions in this holiday-shortened week, while few corporate issues are planned.

title: Play Fellow Takes Armour
description: Play Fellow slipped through on the rail halfway through the race and easily drew clear of six rivals as he scored a seven-length victory today in the $89,625 Laurance Armour Handicap at Arlington Park.

title: Dr. Martha Yepes, a Pediatrician, Wed
description: Dr. Martha Cecilia Yepes, a senior pediatrics resident at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Alan Small, a senior medical resident at the Presbyterian-University of Pennsylvania Medical Center. The Rev. Charles Hagen, Roman Catholic chaplain of the University of Pennsylvania, and Rabbi Edward Maline of Congregation Ramat-El in Philadelphia, performed the ceremony at the Wharton Sinkler Estate in Philadelphia.

title: Massachusetts Town Searches for Safe Water
description: Officials searched today for new sources of water to replace at least 10 private wells contaminated by a suspected cancer-causing pesticide.

title: Japan Oil Combination
description: The Nippon Oil Company and the Mitsubishi Oil Company have agreed to combine some of their operations, including refining and marketing, spokesmen for both companies said. Under the agreement, the two companies will jointly import crude oil, charter tankers, use oil tanks and adjust marketing prices. The Nippon- Mitsubishi group will become Japan's leading oil distributor with a domestic market share of 25 percent, industry sources said.

title: EXPERTS PLEAD FOR A BAN ON ANTISATELLITE WEAPONS
description: REFLECTING a rising tide of opposition by scientists to the arming of space, experts who gathered here yesterday called with near unanimity for a ban on testing of antisatellite weapons and a limit to development of even more exotic technologies for so-called ''Star Wars.''

title: Grenadians Start New Party Named After Maurice Bishop
description: Former Cabinet colleagues of Maurice Bishop, the slain Grenadian Prime Minister, have founded a new political party named after him.

title: Rosenberg Associates Is Closing Its Doors
description: After 37 years in business, Anna M. Rosenberg Associates, a public relations firm, is closing its doors next Thursday, a year after the death of its founder.

title: IDEALISTIC LAWYERS, CORPORATION-BOUND
description: Despite the rising number of lawyers in the United States, access to the nation's courts is becoming more difficult than ever for all but the wealthy and incorporated.

title: THE RICH ARE NICHE OF T. AND C.
description: THESE days with more and more

title: Karen Fleischer Weds a Physician
description: Karen J. Fleischer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Fleischer of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. William R. Freeman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Freeman of Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Freelander performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PROJECT DEMOCRACY TAKES WING
description: Carl Gershman, a former aide to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, is setting up shop here these days in a difficult new job.

title: SOME SCIENTISTS PROTEST PLAN TO LEAVE UNESCO
description: A GROUP of American scientists has expressed the opinion that there will be serious scientific consequences if the United States carries out its proposal to withdraw from Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A NEED TO TESTIFY. Portraits of Lauro de Bosis, Ruth Draper, Gaetano Salvemini and Ignazio Silone. By Iris Origo. 274 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. WAR IN VAL D'ORCIA 1943-1944. A Diary. By Iris Origo. 239 pages. David R. Godine. Hard-cover $14.95, paper $8.95.

title: RESULTS OF 1983 CONFERENCE
description: Here, according to economists, is how seven major industrial democracies performed in trying to fulfill the commitments they made at their Williamsburg, Va., economic summit conference, held May 28-30, 1983:

title: KUWAIT STARTING TO FEEL IMPACT OF SHIPPING WAR
description: The shipping war between Iran and Iraq has begun to affect oil exports from Kuwait, geographically the most vulnerable of the Persian Gulf nations, according to oil industry sources.

title: Chess: Two Finish in a Tie for First In Banco di Roma Tourney
description: The eighth Banco di Roma International Tournament in Rome ended in a tie for first place between Gyula Sax, a 32-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, and Stefano Tatai, a 46-year- old Italian (formerly Hungarian) international master.

title: DENVER PROJECT CALLED NEW WAY TO FINANCE HOUSING FOR POOR
description: The Victorian-era building, with its fresh painted cream brick and chocolate trim, looks like a frosted cake.

title: HAMPTONS RITUAL: GETTING TO KNOW THE HOUSEMATES
description: It is the weekend of truth, when it becomes painfully clear who is going to hog the bathroom, who is going to leave dirty dishes and who is going to eat the crumbs off the crumb cake.

title: LET THEM GO
description: Memorial Day is for remembering acts of courage and sacrifice in defense of personal freedoms, so it is fitting on such an occasion to consider Andrei Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner.

title: TO HART, CALIFORNIA VOTE WILL BE THE REALITY TEST
description: In this state where fantasy is an industry and, for some, a way of life, Senator Gary Hart's Presidential campaign has run up against the iron realities of the 1984 Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: Jody Alyssa Mushnick Weds Dr. Jerald Rosenberg
description: Jody Alyssa Mushnick, a daughter of Lucille Mushnick of Bellmore, L.I., and the late Irwin Mushnick, was married yesterday to Dr. Jerald Neil Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Rosenberg of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi William Orentlicher performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: SHOULD USE OF LEADED GASOLINE BE ENDED OR SHARPLY CUT OVER NEXT FEW YEARS?
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is considering whether to adopt rules that would eliminate or drastically reduce the use of leaded gasoline over the next few years.

title: JAPAN SET TO LOOSEN ITS MARKETS
description: The Japanese and American Governments are to announce a broad agreement Wednesday that could bring about important changes in the Japanese financial system.

title: Maryland Donating 5 Old Railroad Cars
description: The state has offered to give away five 70- year-old, 70-ton, self-propelled passenger cars to anyone who can move them, Kathleen Kujawa, a spokesman for the Maryland Railroad Administration, says.

title:
SCOUTING;
N.H.L. Show
description: At the National Hockey League's annual meetings June 6-8 in Montreal, a novel side attraction will be N.H.L. Expo '84, the league's first trade show.

title: Dollar Gains; Gold Mixed
description: The dollar moved higher yesterday in very light trading. Markets in the United States were closed for the Memorial Day holiday.

title: McDonnell's Aid for Spain
description: - The McDonnell Douglas Corporation today announced details of a $1.8 billion package of technological assistance it agreed to provide in return for Spain's agreement last year to buy 72 F-18A Hornet fighters worth $2.5 billion. The plan includes joint production of components for the planes, the transfer of technology, help in the marketing of Spanish products in the United States and promotion of foreign investment in Spain, a company statement said.

title: Canada's Growth Slows
description: The more moderate pace of economic growth evident since the fourth quarter of last year will probably extend into the third quarter of 1984, Statistics Canada said today.

title: No-Foul-Out Test
description: Because of an experiment authorized at the state and national levels, prep basketball players in Minnesota will not have to worry next season about fouling out. Under a new rule approved only for Minnesota by the National Federation of State High School Associations, a player will be allowed to remain in the game even after committing a fifth foul.

title: Moscow Trip Called Off
description: Like any city dweller, the Museum of

title: HIGHER, THICKER KREMLIN WALLS
description: The Soviet Union's withdrawal from the Olympics in Los Angeles reflected a good more than a fear of defections or an effort to embarrass President Reagan and weaken his electoral chances. It is part of a wider policy of retrenchment and repression that could have serious long- term implications for East-West relations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carson Pirie Scott & Co., Chicago, has elected Peter S. Willmott, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman.

title: WHEN SQUARES PREVAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN WHO SETTLE DOWN TO ADDED TASKS
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET: 'G MAJOR' AND ERTE
description: BY borrowing some designs from Paris, the New York City Ballet made a stylish ballet look stylish in a new way on Friday night at the New York State Theater. The ballet was ''In G Major,'' Jerome Robbins's plotless, but playful, choreographic treatment of Ravel's Piano Concerto in G Major.

title: SEACHING FOR MAN'S CLOSEST RELATIVE
description: SUDDENLY, the orangutan is challenging the chimpanzee and the gorilla for the position as man's closest kin. But the subject has engendered a spirited debate among anthropologists.

title: ARABS WERE SLAIN BY ISRAELI GUARDS, INQUIRY CONCLUDES
description: The Defense Ministry announced today that a commission of inquiry had determined that two of the four Arab terrorists who hijacked an Israeli bus last month were captured alive and then killed by security men.

title: POLITICAL USE OF AUTO FEES IS CHALLENGED IN INDIANA
description: In Indiana, when you obtain a driver's license, register your car or buy a license plate, you contribute to the political party in power.

title: Phinney Wins Bicycle Race
description: Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., beat Steve Bauler of Canada by half a wheel today and won the main event of the 41st Kugler-Anderson Tour of Somerville bicycle race.

title: Millions in Unsecured Loans Tied to Block and Partners
description: A new financial disclosure report showed today that Agriculture Secretary John R. Block and his financially hard-hit farming partners owed as much as $2.9 million in unsecured loans at the end of last year.

title: MESTER IS NAMED PASADENA CONDUCTOR
description: Jorge Mester, chairman of conducting studies at the Juilliard School, has been named conductor of the Pasadena Symphony. His three- year contract will begin with the orchestra's fall season.

title: U.S. FINANCIAL ACCORD WITH JAPAN ANNOUNCED
description: The United States and Japan, as expected, announced a major agreement today that could substantially expand the international role of the yen and provide new business opportunities in Japan for American financiers.

title: Congress, in the Path of Taxis
description: Most cities, including New York, restrict the number of taxis on the streets and set their fares. But the fact that most cities do that doesn't make it right, or legal. The Federal Trade Commission is now charging that taxi regulation in New Orleans and Minneapolis violates Federal antitrust law. Congress should have the sense to get out of the way and let the commission make its case.

title: SALVADORAN REBEL SAYS TALKS COULD DECIDE FATE OF OFFICERS
description: A Salvadoran rebel leader said Monday night that if peace talks were started, the issue of whether officers of Government forces would be tried on criminal charges would be ''open to negotiation.''

title: MEASURE TO RAISE DRINKING AGE TO 21 LOSES IN NEW YORK
description: Roll-call vote, page B4.

title: SQUARE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gain from the sale of a parcel of land of $432,000, or 46 cents a share, for the quarter and year. The year-ago average shares adjusted for stock dividend.

title: Irvine Is Pacer Coach
description: George Irvine became the youngest head coach in the National Basketball Association when he was named to succeed Jack McKinney , dismissed earlier by the Indiana Pacers. The 36- year-old Irvine, who was a journeyman forward with the Virginia Squires and the Denver Nuggets in the American Basketball Association, served as McKinney's assistant for three seasons before moving to the Pacer front office last summer as vice president and director of basketball operations. . . . Tom Nissalke, dismissed as the Cleveland Cavalier coach last Friday, was turned down in his appeal to the owners for reinstatement.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editing error in John Wheeler's article ''Vietnam Veterans' Gains'' on Monday produced a misstatement. The following is correct: ''John Kerry is Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts, Bob Kerrey is Governor of Nebraska and Charles Robb is Governor of Virginia.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rick Robey , the Phoenix Suns' reserve center-forward, underwent surgery for the removal of a bone spur in his left heel. . . . Patrick Bedard , who suffered a concussion and a fractured right jawbone in the Indianapolis 500, has improved considerably, according to a spokesman at Methodist Hospital. . . . Jim Palmer , unable for now to find a pitching spot with another team since his release by the Baltimore Orioles, will resume his broadcasting career next Monday night as a commentator on ABC-TV's first baseball telecast of the season. According to Palmer's lawyer, Ron Shapiro, the decision does not necessarily mean that his pursuit of a further pitching career has permanently ended. A spokesman for the network said that Palmer was committed to it for the rest of the regular season.

title: WANTED: A MAGAZINE FORMAT
description: When CBS broadcasts the renovated version of ''The American Parade'' on June 27 it will represent the latest incarnation of a recurring network dream: to present a successful magazine program that isn't ''60 Minutes.''

title: A SCRAMBLE FOR OLYMPIC TENNIS BERTHS
description: Many of the young women spent the time between matches talking among themselves or sitting with blank expressions while their feet tapped to the music only they could hear on their Walkman radios. A few occasionally peeked at some matches in progress on the indoor courts below. But because her busy college season has just ended and final exams are a week away, Patty Fendick was lying on a sofa in the player's lounge, stifling a yawn and doing some required reading.

title: GLUTINOUS RICE: IT TASTES BETTER THAN IT SOUNDS
description: GLUTINOUS rice is a most misunderstood grain, particularly in the West, where it is not as well known as other varieties of rice. Many people know it as ''sweet rice,'' the label under which it is most often sold, or as ''sticky rice.''

title: BIG TOTE, WILD SOCK, ARTY BELT AND TUNES
description: 1.*Long-Weekend Tote

title: MODERN CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MONDALE ASSAILS HART'S ASBESTOS PLAN
description: Caroline Spankowski wept this morning as she spoke to Walter F. Mondale. ''The dust was on my husband's clothes,'' she said. ''It was in his lunch. The kids would hug him when he came home and they would eat the dust.''

title: Trial Opens for Judge Indicted in Illinois CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) - A jury was empaneled today in the trial of the first of four judges indicted in a three-and-half-year Federal investigation of the Cook County court system.
description: Judge John M. Murphy, accused of accepting $3,000 in bribes to fix cases, has been charged with mail fraud, extortion and conspiracy to participate in racketeering activities in a scheme involving lawyers, a police officer and an unidentified judge.

title: AMERIHEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company did not start operations until Nov. 21, 1983.

title: MANCINI CHALLENGER IS A PUZZLE
description: Livingstone Bramble, who challenges Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini for the World Boxing Association lightweight title here Friday night, is not an orthodox fighter, and not just because his manager, Lou Duva, says that ''he does everything wrong, except it works.''

title: PARENTAL LEGACIES
description: SECONDHAND SMOKE

title: Ex-Im Bank Sells 5 Laker DC-10's
description: The Export-Import Bank of the United States, which makes loans to foreigners to help them buy American goods, said it had finally sold five DC-10's that it repossessed two years ago from Sir Freddie Laker's failed airline. The bank, a Federal agency, had provided $150 million in credit when Laker Airways bought the planes from the maker, McDonnell Douglas.

title: The U.N. Today; May 30, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: WINE TALK
description: THE Long Island wine industry has come of age: It has hired a press agent and is issuing position papers, unmistakable signs of business maturity.

title: ;  Maxwell in Switch
description: John C. Maxwell Jr., who is considered the last word on Wall Street when it comes to data on the tobacco, soft- and hard-drink markets, has just switched his area of operations to A. G. Becker Paribas from Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. The new job title is managing director in the research department and senior analyst covering the food, beverage and tobacco industries.

title: Either-Handed
description: Hal Sutton, the leading money winner on the PGA Tour in 1983, was struggling with his putting during the Memorial Tournament last week, so he made a change in his grip in the middle of the second round. Instead of using the normal grip for a right- hander, with the right hand below the left, Sutton began putting cross- handed at the 10th hole and continued through the rest of the round.

title: BISHOP TO HEAD YOUTH VOLUNTEER PLAN
description: Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn will be the chairman of New York City's volunteer program for 18-year- olds, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: China Cancels Wheat Orders
description: China has canceled orders for 340,000 metric tons of wheat scheduled to be delivered in the coming crop year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 2 MASTER STORYTELLERS BEWITCH SCIENTISTS WITH STRANGE TALES
description: When Isaac Asimov and Arthur C. Clarke opened one symposium at the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting yesterday, most of the 300 people in the audience leaned forward to savor every word from two of the leading popularizers of science.

title: State's Witness Is Called a Liar
description: The lawyer for Irwin M. Margolies, a jewelry executive on trial for the murders of two employees, told a Manhattan jury yesterday to ignore the statements of the state's chief witness, a former confidant who had tied Mr. Margolies to the killings.

title: No Headline
description: Navy Reverses Its Rule On Pilot Measurement

title: Harlem Dance Theater Plans Children's Day
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will present its annual Children's Day celebration and performance June 10 at 3 P.M. at the Dance Theater of Harlem School, 466 West 152d Street.

title: RAM PETROLEUMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago figures are restated.

title: SHANNON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The loss in the latest quarter includes losses from unconsolidated affiliates of $509,551 versus losses of $117,463 in the year-earlier period.

title: ;  Advanced Genetic Chief Sounds Optimistic Note
description: Thomas M. Dyott had already been offered a job as president and chief operating officer of Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. when one of the company's major projects - involving the first outdoor testing of a genetically engineered organism - was ordered halted by Federal District Judge John J. Sirica two weeks ago. Mr. Dyott, who is 36, took the job anyway.

title: ;  Citicorp Rates Up
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly auctions of commercial paper. For $100 million of 91-day paper, the bank holding company said the average rate was 11.166 percent, up from 11.046 percent a week ago. For $50 million of 18-to-21-day paper, the average rate was 11.566 percent, up from 11.40 percent.

title: Lea Esto, Por Favor
description: ''Es su guia. IUsela con orgullo!''

title: AIM TELEPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
VIEW OF 12 PRESIDENTS BY MOYERS AND STROUT
description: HOW does the Presidency appear on television? Remote, certainly; imperial, perhaps; powerful, without a doubt. On the other hand, Presidents are individuals, separate in temperament, ability and style. We see the last 12 Presidents in ''A Walk Through the 20th Century With Bill Moyers'' on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Careers; After A Business Fails
description: JANET TWEED of Gilbert

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After LIFO charges of $1,538,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,351,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ITALY A TEST FOR U.S.
description: The coach of the American team, Alkis Panagoulias, calls Wednesday night's soccer game at Giants Stadium between the United States and Italy ''the game of the decade for the Americans.''

title: Advertising; Pepsi-Cola And RCA Team Up
description: WHEN John S. Breuer, director of marketing of Pepsi- Cola USA, came to town seeking a record company to be partners in a big consumer promotion caper, he found a particularly responsive chap at RCA Records - Michael L. Omansky - who has just been made director of marketing. No wonder, Mr. Omansky is out of package goods, an alumnus of both Nabisco Brands and General Foods.

title: Article 226744 -- No Title
description: Teledyne Inc., the electronics and manufacturing conglomerate, said yesterday that it would buy back all 8.7 million shares tendered under a $200-a-share offer for its own stock that expired last Friday.

title: Gault Loses Appeal
description: A Federal judge has denied a plea from Willie Gault , the Chicago Bears' wide receiver, that the International Olympic Committee be forced to allow him to compete as a sprinter in the Summer Games.

title: Brooks Streak a Met Blessing
description: Hubie Brooks put his elbows on one of the wooden tables in the Met clubhouse, leaned forward, and considered the question.

title: AARON K. NEELD
description: Aaron K. Neeld, a former New Jersey State Treasurer, died Sunday at the Odd Fellows Home here. He was 86 years old.

title: Bridge to Be Shut
description: The Westchester County Department of Public Works announced today that the Broad Street Bridge between Yonkers and Mount Vernon would be closed for 18 months for repairs, starting next Tuesday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cameron Iron Works Inc., Houston, has named Carl B. King senior vice president and general manager of the Oil Tool division.

title: After Six Buyout
description: After Six Inc. said it had agreed in principle with its investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., on the proposed acquisition of After Six for $15 a share by a new private company.

title: Reds-Cubs Brawl Is Under Review
description: Charles Feeney, the National League president, said today he would review films of Sunday's brawl in the Cubs- Reds game and receive a report before deciding whether to discipline the Reds' pitcher, Mario Soto. He told The Cincinnati Post he would not have a decision before the end of the week.

title: AMERICAN OFFICIALS SAY SOVIET ATTACKERS BEAT U.S. DIPLOMAT
description: United States Embassy officials disclosed today that an American diplomat based in Leningrad, Roland Harms, was beaten and thrown to the ground by unidentified Russian assailants while leaving a Leningrad restaurant with Russian friends last month.

title: 'CAGE' LYRICIST RELISHES TONY BID
description: ''There are only a couple of us who care about writing songs that people can leave the theater singing, and I'm one of them,'' Jerry Herman said last week.

title: JAZZ: HENRY (THINS) FRANCIS, STRIDE PIANO
description: HENRY (THINS) FRANCIS is a pianist who acquired his nickname because, although he plays in the style of Fats Waller, he is distinctly different from Mr. Waller physically. But Mr. Francis, who is at Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 92d Street through June 2, is as involved with the music of Duke Ellington as he is with the stride piano playing associated with Mr. Waller and James P. Johnson.

title: Kings Name Quinn
description: Pat Quinn , who took the Philadelphia Flyers to the Stanley Cup final against the Islanders in 1980, has been named the Los Angeles Kings' coach, succeeding Roger Neilson. The 41- year-old Quinn had been reported in line for the Los Angeles job for some time, but negotiations were delayed because he was nearing his final examinations at the Delaware Law School.

title: E.E.C. Wine Surplus
description: Member nations are furnishing unreliable figures on wine supplies to the European Economic Community, undermining the bloc's efforts to control its glutted wine market, the community's farm commissioner, Paul Dalsager, said today. He called for creation of a commission to recommend solutions for a 150-million-gallon wine surplus, which has driven down prices and sparked protests by wine growers.

title: JUSTICES WILL HEAR CASE INVOLVING FORD MEMOIRS
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether The Nation magazine violated Federal copyright law when it published an article based on an advance copy of former President Gerald R. Ford's memoirs.

title: OF THE ART OR SCIENCE OF NIT-PICKING
description: ''This agency,'' said William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, ''gets more ink per dollar than any other agency in town.''

title: Pisani Jury Begins Its Deliberations
description: Jury deliberations began yesterday in the Federal trial of State Senator Joseph R. Pisani, who is accused of having embezzled state funds to purchase a summer house and of having stolen money from his law firm and his campaign operation.

title: Equal Justice in Israel
description: Israel has done what decency requires in the case of the two Arabs who were taken alive from a hijacked bus and then killed by security police. Without excuse or equivocation, Defense Minister Moshe Arens confirms the deed and pledges that those responsible shall be held criminally accountable.

title: LAWYER AND EX-N.L.R.B. OFFICER
description: William J. Isaacson, a New York lawyer and a former regional commissioner of the National Labor Relations Board, died Sunday at the Danbury (Conn.) Hospital of injuries he received when he was struck by an automobile while bicycling in Redding, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and Redding.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S STUBBORN STATESMAN: PIETER WILLEM BOTHA
description: To his supporters, he is the man who will lead his country on a path to peaceable change and evolutionary progress. To his foes on the left and right, he is seen as a traitor to his people's true cause and as the herald of racial violence. Pieter Willem Botha, Prime Minister of South Africa, is a man who inspires conflicting emotions, all of them as fierce and uncompromising as his own quick temper and his single-minded drive to secure a future for the Afrikaner nation without diluting its power.

title: THE DEFECTS IN A PLAN TO RENEW TIMES SQUARE
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON SELECTIVE DRAFT PROSECUTION
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government violated the constitutional rights of vocal opponents of draft registration when it singled them out for prosecution for failure to register.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
GROMYKO REBUFFS AUSTRALIAN WHO ASKS ABOUT SAKHAROVS
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko told his Australian counterpart today that Moscow would not bow to pressure from abroad over the plight of Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 30, 1984 International
description: An additional Air Force aerial tanker and 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles have been sent to Saudi Arabia, the United States announced. The arms were sent to help the Saudis improve their air, sea and land defenses against Iran. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iran vowed to fight any American military intervention in the Persian Gulf. Meanwhile, Iraq reiterated its pledge to continue its air and sea blockade of Iran's main oil export terminal until Iran responded to appeals to end the war. (A1:4-5.)

title: SALSA: RUBEN BLADES BAND
description: RUBEN BLADES'S face showed concern as his feet danced, a combination mirrored in the songs he sang Monday at the Village Gate. Mr. Blades has long been acclaimed as salsa's finest lyricist, and in the last few years he and his group, Seis del Solar, have been stretching their music to include hints of other American and Caribbean pop.

title: The Sin in Synfuels
description: Does America need subsidized synthetic fuels? In 1980 Congress was sure it did, and created the Synthetic Fuels Corporation to hurry along production of substitutes for scarce oil and natural gas. Four years later scarcity has turned to glut, and the corporation has little to show for its efforts beyond a record of bad management and a whiff of scandal.

Moffat, after three years as president of Zenith Data Systems, a leading maker of desktop computer systems, has been named president and chief executive officer of Fujitsu Systems of America Inc. The company markets Fujitsu computer systems for the banking and retail industries.

title: A FILM MAKER'S FOCUS: MUSIC, FOOD AND PEOPLE
description: The people in Les Blank's documentaries have a high old time. They sit around playing music in back yards and living rooms; they rustle up corn bread or Polish sausages or red beans and rice; they dance all night long. They also reminisce a little and, in a low-key way, let us know how their parents and grandparents lived. Most of them are downright neighborly, although they're not the kind of people a New Yorker is likely to meet around the next corner.

Jesse Jackson, before leaving Mexico City and resuming his Presidential campaigning here, said today that he would hold a peace demonstration July 4 at the Mexican-American border and would make trips as a ''peace activist'' to other Central American countries and possibly Cuba.

Atkins, the high-living financier who persuaded a long list of notables from the world of business and Hollywood to invest $84 million in his tax-shelter partnerships, has filed for bankruptcy. On behalf of himself and five of his partnerships, Mr. Atkins asked for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

description: Japan's leading economic indicator shows growth is likely over the next few months, the Economic Planning Agency said today. The leading indicator for March, the latest reporting month, was unchanged from February at 75.

description: A student from the Choate Rosemary Hall preparatory school pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges he was carrying $300,000 worth of cocaine on his return April 23 from a vacation in Venezuela.

description: Fourteen National Football League place- kickers assembled last weekend in this southeastern river town that Radar O'Reilly of M*A*S*H, who never kicked about much himself, called home. They competed on the high school field, they fanned into the blue-collar community of 28,000, signing autographs, and they talked shop.

title: THE POPLIFE
description: ATHENS, Ga., is a quiet Southern college town, and the members of R.E.M., currently the town's most closely watched rock band, would like to keep it that way. ''Nobody in the band has a telephone,'' the group's guitarist, Peter Buck, said recently. ''We don't really need phones, because we all live in the same neighborhood. If we want to see somebody, we just walk down the street to their house. Right now, I'm standing at the pay phone outside our corner store, and I've seen the rest of the guys in the band pass by just since we've been talking.''

title: ARREST MAY BE DETERRENT IN DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, STUDY SHOWS
description: Domestic violence is twice as likely to recur in households where police try to mediate a dispute than where a suspected attacker is arrested, according to a new study.

title: DISNEY CASSETTES OF CARTOON STARS
description: For a limited period, Walt Disney Productions is making available video cassettes of some of its vintage films.

title: Talley Gets Post
description: Villanova, which returns to intercollegiate football in 1985, has selected Andy Talley , considered an excellent recruiter, as its coach. The Wildcats eliminated football in April 1981, a decision that brought protests from alumni, faculty, the student body. For the last five seasons, Talley has been the coach at St. Lawrence University.

Greenberg, general partner and chief executive officer at Bear, Stearns, said yesterday. Mr. Rubin, 47 years old, will work with Kenneth D. Malamed of the firm's Los Angeles office in supervising $900 million of assets currently under Bear, Stearns management. In conjunction with Mr. Rubin's appointment, Bear, Stearns announced that another Bernstein-Macaulay employee, Peter N. title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The meaning of Memorial Day Has changed, in a peculiar way; Memorializing's no longer its reason - It marks the beginning of the rental season. The same way with Labor Day; About its original meaning most people don't give a lentil - It marks the expiration of the summer rental.WILLIAM COLE

title: Parental Legacies; How to Frame $50,000 How to Frame $50,000 A friend whose daughter was graduated from college last Sunday spent Monday getting a frame for the diploma. Without one, she knew, it would either be lost (like hers), wrinkled or coffee-stained within a week. After pawing through the selection at her neighborhood framer and discarding black as too lugubrious and too reminiscent of a doctor's examining room, she found perfection. Silvery, discreet, possessing a kind of throwaway elegance, but with a frisky edge. (This is a woman who has overheard oenophiles in full flight.) It had, however, a flaw. The price was $9.95.
description: ''Gee,'' she said to herself, ''I don't know if I want to spend that much,'' and was about to resume pawing when she suddenly realized something.

title: Father-in-Law Of Cuomo Gains
description: Doctors upgraded the condition of Charles Raffa, the father-in-law of Governor Cuomo, to satisfactory yesterday. They said he should soon be able to talk to the police about the two muggers who beat him May 22.

title: REFUNDS SET BY CHILD FIND INC.
description: New York State's Attorney General said yesterday that Child Find Inc., a nonprofit registry of missing children, had ''misrepresented'' its services and had made ''misleading claims.''

title: I.M.F. Names Official
description: The International Monetary Fund today announced the appointment of Richard Erb as its deputy managing director. Mr. Erb, 43 years old, succeeds William Dale, who is retiring on May 31, the I.M.F. said in a statement. His five-year term at the I.M.F. will begin on June 1.

title: YANKEES CLOUT 3 STRAIGHT BUT LOSE
description: The Yankees hit three consecutive home runs tonight and still they lost, 6-5, to the Angels, mainly because Phil Niekro, their reliable 45-year-old pitcher, experienced his first bad performance, and partly because the Angels' center fielder Juan Beniquez went 5 for 5 and Beniquez's replacement, Gary Pettis made two sensational plays to save the victory.

title: NEW TIMES ON TAIWAN AS OLD GUARD EASES GRIP
description: A foreign diplomat who was first posted to Taiwan a decade ago recently remarked on the changes he noticed when he returned last year. He was struck most of all, he said, by the easing of censorship, especially of opposition magazines, which now regularly carry spirited criticism of the ruling Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party, and its leaders.

title: Soviet General Reported Killed in Afghanistan
description: Western diplomats said today that a Soviet general was killed in Afghanistan this month when his helicopter was shot down by insurgents near Panjshir valley, where Soviet forces had been pressing an offensive.

title: Bridge: Hearings Got the Attention At Grand National Playoffs
description: Lengthy delays and committee arguments overshadowed a victory by a Westchester County foursome in the Grand National Team zonal playoffs this week at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DR. DeWITT STETTEN JR. was a leading scientist at the National Institutes of Health when a progressive disease of the retina rendered him legally blind. Even with corrective lenses, he could barely see at 20 feet what people with normal vision can see at 200 feet away. Although unable to read or drive, Dr. Stetten was not told about aids to improve the quality of his life by any of the seven ophthalmologists who treated him during 15 years of increasing visual loss.

title: Stakes in Amerace

title: Talks at a Standstill In Las Vegas Strike
description: Negotiations in the 58-day strike at Las Vegas hotel-casinos were deadlocked today, but several hundred union members who earlier settled on a new contract went back to work at three of the gambling spas.

title: THE HISTORY OF FOOD GAINS A SCHOLARLY PEDIGREE
description: THE Boston Culinary Historians meet once a month to discuss the history of bread, Japanese cooking traditions, the problems that women have as chefs in Paris restaurants or the regional cuisines of the Germans in 19th-century Pennsylvania. The jolliness of the group's meetings does not belie a serious approach to a new and growing area of interest: culinary history, or the study of what people eat and why; of how we grow, prepare and consume the foods we eat, and of how culinary habits evolve and change throughout history. It is a study that is commanding the scholarly attention of academics and dedicated amateurs in England, Europe and the United States.

title: STAGE: 'BOYS FROM SYRACUSE' REVIVED
description: WITH a story borrowed from Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors,'' a mock-Greek setting, and a bubbly Rodgers & Hart score, ''The Boys From Syracuse'' is a musical- comedy burlesque that seems to hold nothing sacred. And in 1938, George Abbott's slangy, decidedly non- Shakespearean dialogue helped lend this zany bedroom farce an atmosphere of sophisticated naughtiness. The problem in staging a revival is to find a tone that's racy in contemporary terms yet faithful in spirit to a frothy score that includes ''Falling in Love With Love,'' ''This Can't Be Love'' and ''Sing for Your Supper.''

title: FORMALIZE DEBATES
description: If the acceptance of televised debates as an important part of running for the Presidency can be carried into the general election, the voters, who have benefited from the Democratic candidates' debates, will benefit yet again. But as the primary season draws to a close, televised Presidential debates are far from assured. This year, the Republican and Democratic Parties can make them possible. In future years, we need an institutional mechanism that will insure that debates are part of every Presidential campaign.

The deal ended what had become a stormy relationship between the Bengals' leadership and Johnson, whose 70 touchdowns are the most in the team's history.

description: Employment in Italian industrial companies with more than 500 employees fell 5 percent in February from a year earlier, the state statistical institute said today. description: The Federal Government sued a Camden County golf club and its superintendent today, seeking $150,000 in fines and the cost of cleaning up 15,000 pounds of illegally dumped insecticide wastes.

description: THE violinist Marina Kruglikov and the pianist Efrem Briskin often played together before emigrating from the Soviet Union. A Sunday night concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, however, marked their first New York appearance as a duo.

title: Muzzio Triumphs
description: Rob Muzzio, a 19-year-old sophomore from George Mason University, accumulated the second-highest decathlon score in collegiate history today, winning with 8,227 points at the national collegiate outdoor track and field championships. Muzzio's score was the best in N.C.A.A. decathlon competition since Tito Steiner of Brigham Young registered 8,279 points in winning the 1981 event.

title: ALL SEASONS REPORTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. The company commenced operations in January 1983.

title: SANTA CLARA FINANCES UTILITY IMPROVEMENTS
description: A two-part note and bond offering by Santa Clara, Calif., to finance improvements to its municipally owned electric utility was announced yesterday. The financing included $82 million of semiannual tender bonds offered through Morgan Stanley & Company as sole underwriter and $33 million of bonds with various maturities offered through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: The Wrong Fare
description: In six languages, the Port Authority

title: ARMED FORCES ARE EASILY FILLING THEIR MILITARY RECRUITING GOALS
description: Sometime in mid-June, the armed forces will stop taking in recruits for the rest of the fiscal year because their enlistment quotas will be full, Defense Department officials have said.

title: AN 80-BOY NEW YORK SYMPHONY MAKES A RAINY WASHINGTON DEBUT
description: Eighty members of the Allen-Stevenson School Symphony Orchestra, the only symphony orchestra at a Manhattan private school, traveled here to perform outside the White House today. And it rained.

title: MOPEDS SPUR SECESSION TALK ON BLOCK ISLAND
description: A casual visitor might mistake for comedy the talk of revolution on this tranquil little island with its sandy cliffs, fields of June grass and weathered Victorian hotels.

title: Denny's Halts Trading; Acquisition Rumored
description: Denny's Inc., which operates fast- food restaurants and coffee shops, yesterday asked the New York Stock Exchange to halt the trading in its shares pending an announcement ''of significance to its shareholders.''

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DATAPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AGENT ORANGE ISSUE
description: What will $180 million buy the Vietnam veterans and their families whose lawyers recently settled their lawsuit against the makers of Agent Orange? Is the interest-bearing fund created May 7 by the herbicide manufacturers enough? To many veterans and some of their lawyers, the questions remain unanswerable as long as the number of claimants remains unknown.

title: A PAN FOR TARTE TATIN
description: ONE of my favorite desserts, in summer or winter, is tarte tatin, which is a caramelized upside-down apple tart. It is a nice twist on the all- American apple pie and just as easy to make if you have the proper pan, such as the heavy gauge copper one pictured here.

title: URGENT CARE CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said its date of inception was Sept. 13, 1982 and all of its operating results for that year were in the fourth quarter.

title: PALOMA PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
;  AC&R Wine Account
description: AC&R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been named agency for Conseil Interprofessionel du Vin de Bordeaux, which is composed of 22,000 wine-producing chateaux in the Bordeaux region of France. To start, the agency will create a 30-second commercial for use in this area during the pre-Christmas months. The budget is $500,000.

title: C.I.A. PLANS TO STAY IN NICARAGUA
description: Despite warnings that money for the covert war against Nicaragua will run out June 1, the Central Intelligence Agency plans to keep American agents in operation until October in hopes of persuading Congress to provide more money, Administration officials said today.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GEORGE ORWELL ON WORLD SPORTS COMPETITIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Fire Investigated
description: A restaurant manager has been detained for questioning by the police in connection with a hotel fire Monday morning that killed 19 people and injured 53. A police spokesman said initial investigations indicated that the fire was probably caused by a short circuit resulting from a leaking roof in the restaurant. Yu Chang, 44, the manager of the restaurant on the second floor of the 14- story Time Hotel, told the police he had informed the hotel management about the leaks more than two weeks ago but received no response.

title: 2 747's Ordered
description: The Boeing Company said its Boeing Commercial Airplane unit had received an order from Lufthansa German Airlines for two 747-200B aircraft valued at $180 million.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets appear to be on an early-season roller coaster: winning streaks interspersed with losing streaks.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split effected in the form of a 33 percent stock dividend to shareholders of record March 30.

title: WALL TO HONOR CITY'S VETERANS OF VIETNAM
description: A plain wall of glass brick, etched with words that American soldiers wrote from the jungles and mountains of Vietnam and the news that reached them from home, is to serve as the New York City memorial to the veterans of that war.

title: 'INDIANA JONES' TOPPING 'JEDI' BOX-OFFICE RECORD
description: Earning $42,267,345 at movie theaters during its first six days, ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' has broken nearly every box-office record set by ''Return of the Jedi'' during its opening week last May.

title: NOW NORWALK GETS ITS TURN TO SHARE IN OFFICE BOOM
description: During the great rush to Connecticut's Fairfield County in the 1970's, when major corporations left New York City for greener and less hectic settings, Norwalk was virtually ignored. Greenwich and Stamford were the favored locations, and by 1977 they had become major office centers. But Norwalk, just 10 miles farther up the Connecticut Turnpike, held only 264,000 square feet of office space.

title: Looking Overseas
description: Gordon Chiesa, the basketball coach at Manhattan College, is happy that his entire starting lineup will be returning next season and is pleased with three talented recruits he found in the Bronx, New Brunswick, N.J., and Lowell, Mass.

title: THE DEFECTS IN A PLAN TO RENEW TIMES SQUARE
description: To the Editor:

title: STEINBERG PLANS DISNEY PROXY FIGHT
description: Saul P. Steinberg, the New York businessman, said yesterday that he had ''determined to seek removal'' of Walt Disney Productions' board of directors.

title: A WEEK TO REMEMBER
description: This should have been a reassuring week - a week to remember - for the foreign ministers of the NATO alliance meeting here, but somehow it wasn't.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Mubarak's Party Wins Decisively in Egypt
description: President Hosni Mubarak's party won 391 of the 448 contested seats in the parliamentary election Sunday, according to official results announced today. The opposition gained the remaining 57 seats, its best showing since the 1952 coup.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANYONE with a benign outlook on the course of American history would seem to have reason to be nervous about the publication of Gore Vidal's new novel, ''Lincoln,'' the fourth and latest book in his fictional tetralogy, of which ''Burr,'' ''1876'' and ''Washington, D.C.'' were the previous three entries.

title: THE RAGTAG AND REGIMENTAL LEGACIES OF VIETNAM
description: It never fades away. Whenever Americans gather to remember the Vietnam War, there is the gap between what is official and what is not.

title: JUDGE IS UPHELD IN SETTING ASIDE STOUFFER VERDICT
description: A state appeals court ruled unanimously today that a Westchester County judge was correct two years ago in setting aside a jury verdict finding Luis Marin guilty of arson and 26 counts of murder in the 1980 Stouffer's Inn fire.

title: SOVIET IS DENOUNCED BY REAGAN IN VISIT TO OLYMPIC CENTER
description: President Reagan today denounced the Soviet bloc's withdrawal from the Olympic Games as the ''political machinations of power brokers in countries that are less than free.''

title: MONDALE WORRIES ON WEST VIRGINIA
description: Not since 1960, when West Virginia aided in the nomination and election of John F. Kennedy, has the state seemed to hold as much importance in a Presidential election as this year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DANCE The American Ballet Theater is a company that has been open to modern dance as well as its regular run of classical ballet. Over the last several years, Twyla Tharp, a choreographer as contemporary as they come, has created many dances for this troupe and today at 8 P.M. the company responds with a program honoring her - an all-Tharp evening of dance - as part of A.B.T.'s season at Lincoln Center's Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Jersey Power
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III men's baseball championship tournament begins tomorrow in Marietta, Ohio, and for the first time since it began in 1976, three of the six contenders will be from the same conference.

title: Death Toll Below Estimate
description: The Chicago-based National Safety Council estimated that 400 to 500 people would die in highway accidents over the Memorial Day weekend, but a United Press International fatality count yesterday showed that 378 people died in traffic accidents in the period. The safety council said poor weekend weather and an increasing awareness of the dangers of drinking and driving held the death toll down.

title: WAR'S UNCERTAIN EFFECT ON OIL
description: Despite recent bombings of oil tankers in the Persian Gulf, oil prices are remaining stable on world markets because of a widespread belief that large reserves and excess oil- producing capacity outside the gulf will prevent an immediate supply crisis.

title: HARD-PRESSED AIR FLORIDA GETS $5 MILLION LOAN
description: Air Florida said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the General Electric Credit Corporation that provided a $5 million loan to the hard-pressed airline.

title: IRANIANS VOW TO 'RESIST AND FIGHT' ANY U.S. INTERVENTION IN THE GULF
description: Iran vowed today to ''resist and fight'' any American military intervention in the Persian Gulf.

title: FRENCH CRITICIZE SOVIET AS NATO MEETING BEGINS
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France accused the Soviet Union today of trying to intimidate the Western powers and of having contempt for human rights.

title: L.I. Company Wins Dun Suit
description: A jury has decided that Dun & Bradstreet should pay a Long Island company $47,711 in damages for gross negligence, based on a 1978 credit report on Metropolitan Greetings Inc.

title: Major Nuclear Test Planned
description: A major nuclear weapons test with an explosive yield of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT has been scheduled for Thursday, the Department of Energy said today.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a $138,000 tax credit for the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter net includes credit of $405,000 due to a decrease in the effective tax rate resulting from increases in capital acquisitions and research and development expenses. The results for the year-earlier quarter reflect change in fiscal year- end.

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to April 7
description: b-Including tax credits.

title: Irene Jacobi, Pianist, Dead; Performed Husband's Music
description: The pianist Irene Jacobi died Friday at her Manhattan home. She was 93 years old.

title: COMPUSHOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the company's fiscal year-end from Oct. 31 to Jan. 31.
