description: b-Net income includes $1.5 million recovery of previously recognized net unrealized losses. The figures for the latest periods include Graniteville Company's results from Aug. 7, 1983, on a consolidated basis. The share earnings for all periods were adjusted to reflect aggregate stock distributions declared through May 25, 1984. The latest quarter loss includes $200,000 from recovery of previously recognized net unrealized losses. The latest year includes $1.1 million recovery of previously recognized net unrealized losses on marketable securities and the year-earlier period includes $2.2 million of net realized gains and recovery of net realized losses on marketable securities.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PAPER BY TREASURY ON ACCORD
description: Following are excerpts from a Treasury Department background paper on the measures agreed to today by Japan and the United States that are aimed at broadening the use of the yen as an international currency and at deregulating Japan's domestic financial markets:

title: THE LINEN DUSTER RETURNS
description: EVERY year, fashion designers predict that there will be a revival of the spring coat, a statement always met with the same incredulity that might greet the announcement that white gloves are back in vogue. But this spring, due in part to unusually cool weather, the spring coat

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
UNC Litigation
description: UNC Resources Inc. said an out-of-court settlement appeared to be near in its litigation involving contracts with the General Atomic Company.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 11.

title: Article 226411 -- No Title
description: A group consisting of management, employees and outside investors reached an agreement in principle yesterday to buy the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company, the nation's largest maker of generic cigarettes, from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. for $325 million.

title: No Headline
description: E.P.A. Chief Reveals Bonus

title: JEWEL RUMORS DYING DOWN?
description: After more than a month of rumors and gyrating stock prices accompanied by heavy volume, the interest in the Jewel Companies may be evaporating.

title: Israeli Censor Ends the Ban On Pictures of 2 Slain Arabs
description: The Israeli military censor lifted a ban today on the publication of photographs showing two Arabs being led by security men from a bus they hijacked last month.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FOR LEBANESE, EVEN HOPE FOR HOPE HAS VANISHED
description: For the Lebanese, the civil war is no longer a crisis waiting for a solution. It has become a way of life.

title: RIVALS ASSAILED
description: Senator Gary Hart, in proposing an economic course for the nation, today opposed some of the key economic programs of both Democratic and Republican rivals for the Presidency.

title: DOW LOSES 5.86 AMID RATE WORRIES
description: Stock prices dropped broadly yesterday in sluggish trading as concern over rising interest rates depressed the market.

title: Food for Charity
description: Paul Newman, the actor; Tom

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in March 1984.

title: Upchurch Retires
description: Rick Upchurch, whose career punt- return yardage of 3,008 set an N.F.L. record, retired from the Denver Broncos at age 32 because of what doctors had told him was the potential for spinal-cord damage.

title: Chicago Alderman Loses Bid
description: Neil Hartigan, the Illinois Attorney General, today turned down a Chicago alderman's request to seek the ouster of Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago for failing to file a financial disclosure statement on time. Mr. Hartigan rejected the request of Alderman Edward M. Burke, who contends that Mayor Washington forfeited his office by missing an April 30 deadline set by state law for filing the statement. The Mayor filed the document last week.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RUMOR ON LOAN CURBS IS DENIED
description: Henry C. Wallich, the Federal Reserve Board's senior governor, denied today that the Fed is considering putting controls on ''nonproductive'' lending - that is, bank loans that companies use to finance takeovers of other companies.

title: NCR OFFICER TO RUN COMPUTER DIVISION
description: The NCR Corporation announced yesterday that it had established a personal computer division. It named a vice president, Vernon W. Yates, to be the new division's general manager.

title: New Woman Magazine Names New Editor
description: Pat Miller, an Englishwoman working for Hearst Magazines here, has been named editor and publisher of New Woman magazine, acquired last week by Rupert Murdoch's News America Publishing. The magazine is based in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Benvenuti a Brooklyn'

title: Paperboard Makers Are Planning Talks
description: Southwest Forest Industries said yesterday that it plans to hold ''exploratory discussions'' with the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation about ''a possible transaction.''

title: SPAIN'S TALKS ON JOINING COMMON MARKET AT A CRITICAL POINT
description: Spain's effort to join the European Economic Community has reached a critical point, and the two sides are still far apart over the marketing of Spanish produce and over Spanish fishing rights.

title: Bank Yields Extend Rise
description: Continuing the upward cycle that began 18 weeks ago, annual effective yields on money market deposit accounts rose again in the week ended yesterday, to 9.34 percent, from 9.32 the week before, The Bank Rate Monitor said.

title: Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: Security Pacific International Leasing (Europe) Inc. , a wholly owned subsidiary of Security Pacific Corp., a Los Angeles-based financial services company, offered and sold through Commerzbank A.G., 60 million West German marks of its 7 5/8 percent notes due 1988. Elizabethtown Water Co. , Elizabeth, N.J., had the rating of its debenture and secured pollution control revenue bonds raised by Moody's Investors Service to A-One from A-Three. Some $57 million of long- term debt is affected by the rating change.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Passer-By's Prize

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BECAUSE brick walls and chimneys will often last as long as 50 to 100 years with little or no maintenance, some homeowners may think of brick as a ''maintenance-free'' material. However, many others have learned otherwise. They have found that brick walls and chimneys often develop problems - sometimes because of poor construction techniques, sometimes because a poor quality brick was used originally and sometimes because of structural defects that have developed over the years.

title: Japan-Brazil Accord
description: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry has reinstated short-term export insurance guarantees to Brazil that it suspended in December, a ministry official said today. The official would not comment on reports that the ministry had also extended short-term export insurance to Rumania, Peru, Malawi and Morocco.

title: Man Killed in Mine Cave-In
description: A West Virginia man was killed today and another was injured in a cave-in at the Mettiki Coal Company mine near Oakland, about 150 miles west of Baltimore.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANISATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results have been translated at the rate of one pound equals $1.44.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUYOUT BID FOR REVLON WEIGHED
description: Revlon Inc. said yesterday that an investor group was trying to put together a leveraged buyout of the giant cosmetics company.

title: IN SNEAKING A MIDWEEK TAN, THE ONLY FEAR IS A RED FACE
description: THIS is the time of year when James McCann's suntan is so deep that people think he has just come in from the beach. There is a good chance that he has: Mr. McCann, an insurance broker, keeps a bathing suit, a bottle of suntan lotion and a folding chair in his car trunk so he can sneak away from his Lake Success, L.I., office during the business day and catch some sun.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Summonses and Surcharges

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article by the Associated Press in Metropolitan Report on May 19 about the sentencing of former Councilman Luis A. Olmedo and his co-defendant, Carlos Castellanos, erroneously reported the basis for an appeal by Mr. Castellanos. The appeal will say that a surprise decision by Mr. Olmedo to take the stand damaged Mr. Castellanos's case.

title: Convicted Extortioner Calls News Slanted
description: Frank P. Balistrieri, despite his denials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's description of him as chief of organized crime in Milwaukee, was sentenced Tuesday to 13 years in Federal prison on extortion and bookmaking charges.

title: DUARTE MAY SPLIT COMMAND IN SALVADOR
description: The President-elect of El Salvador plans to separate the command of the regular army and the country's three security forces, according to Salvdoran officials.

title: KEY AIDE WORRIES COALITION IN BONN
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher disclosed in a television interview this week that he would not lead his troubled Free Democratic Party in the 1987 elections, surprising West Germany and Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Investments From Abroad
description: Foreign investors scaled back their spending to acquire or establish businesses in the United States in 1983, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Panel Criticizes L.I. Police Test
description: The Nassau County Civil Service Commission said today that a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic people had failed a police exam after it was revised to eliminate racial or sexual bias.

title: BURROUGHS NAMES HEAD OF MEMOREX SUBSIDIARY
description: Philip S. Dauber, 43, a former executve with the International Business Machines Corporation, has been promoted by the Burroughs Corporation to president and chief operating officer of its Memorex subsidiary, which competes with companies such as I.B.M. and the Control Data Corporation in producing memory devices for medium and large computer systems.

title: McEnroe, Lendl Victors
description: John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl, the top two favorites, today swept into the second round of the $1.8 million French Open tennis championships, the first Grand Slam event of the year. McEnroe brushed aside 18-year-old Horacio de la Pena of Argentina, 6-3, 6-1, 6-3, and Lendl beat Matt Mitchell of Moraga, Calif., 6-3, 6-2, 6-0.

title: U.S. Energy Use Expected to Rise
description: Total energy use in the United States is expected to rise in 1984 for the first time in four years, the Energy Department said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I lost convincingly, it was a defeat. If governors got everything they wanted, they wouldn't need state legislatures.

title: Farm Credit Bank Gives Bond Rates
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks announced interest rates yesterday for nearly $3.4 billion of bonds that are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers and banks.

title: Marilyn Schwartz Robertson, FormerOfficialofCityAgency
description: Marilyn Schwartz Robertson, a former official of the city's Human Resources Administration, died Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mrs. Robertson, who lived in Brooklyn, would have been 48 years old today.

title: Examination for Stearns
description: John Stearns, the 32-year-old catcher who has not played regularly for almost two years because of elbow problems, may be back with the Mets by the middle of June. Stearns will have his right elbow examined today at Shea Stadium by Dr. James Parkes and Dr. Richard Eaton, the team physicians who performed two operations on the elbow last year.

title: BOND YIELDS RISE NEAR 14% LEVEL
description: Bond prices continued to plummet yesterday, sending yields on 30-year Treasury bonds perilously close to the 14 percent level not seen since late June 1982.

title: Twyla Tharp Troupe Schedules July Season
description: -22 at Broadway's Gershwin Theater. Miss Tharp's company will perform her ''Nine Sinatra Songs'' and ''Fait-Accompli,'' two hits from the company's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in February.

title: Port Authority Sets $100 Million Offerings
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is offering $100 million of bonds and $100 million of notes though underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Investment bankers said sales were modest with most of the buying by individual investors.

title: FIGHTING OLD AND NEW WARS AND SPOTS ON THE WALL
description: For the last few months, the wall above the fireplace in the office of Attorney General William French Smith has been decorated by an empty picture hook.

title: SOONER DEFENSE OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEW SHUBERT TICKET SYSTEM
description: Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman, and Bernard Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, yesterday announced the completion of what they termed a ''state of the art'' computerized ticket system. The $15 million system allows patrons to buy tickets by telephone for any of the 23 Shubert theaters in New York and across the country - and to get the best seats available.

title: Man Is Charged In Flatbush Rape
description: A man was charged yesterday with one of 12 recent rapes in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: REAGAN URGES AIR FORCE ACADEMY CLASS TO PROTECT PEACE ABOVE ALL
description: President Reagan urged the graduates of the Air Force Academy today to let their determination to preserve peace ''override all other considerations.''

title: '19 ECLIPSE UPHELD EINSTEIN
description: Scientists no longer look to solar eclipses as occasions for conducting major research in astronomy and physics. They now have ways, using dark disks to blot out the Sun in their telescopes, to create artificial eclipses so that they can observe the Sun's outer atmosphere.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Activision Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a developer of home entertainment software, has promoted Tom Oswold to vice president, finance; Ed Roffman to the new position of vice president, U.S. business operations, and Mike Gennaro to controller.

title: HART PRAISES FREEZE EFFORTS, ENDING SWING IN NEW JERSEY
description: Senator Gary Hart today ended a three- day swing through New Jersey by stressing his commitment to arms control and the environment.

title: Dayton-Hudson Units to Expand
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation said Mervyn's, its California-based department store chain, plans to add 126 stores through 1988, including 55 in the south-central part of the nation.

title: Gulf Broadcast
description: The Gulf Broadcast Company, a Houston-based operator of television and radio stations, said it had agreed to buy two Texas television stations for at least $125 million. Gulf said the two stations, KTXA-TV in Dallas- Fort Worth and KTXH-TV in Houston, would be bought from a group of investors led by Sidney Shlenker and Milton Grant. Mr. Grant, who is president and chief executive of the two stations, will continue in that capacity after the stations become a division of Gulf Broadcast.

title: LETTING THE DAYLIGHT STREAM IN: INVENTIVE WAYS WITH WINDOWS
description: IN more spacious times when single-family homes

title: A Late Rally Helps Dow Gain 1.35
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in very heavy trading after an afternoon rally erased many of its earlier sharp losses.

title: I.R.S. SETS UP GUIDELINES TO LIMIT AGENTS' USE OF PROFESSIONAL POSES
description: In new guidelines for undercover operations, the Internal Revenue Service has forbidden agents to pose as lawyers, doctors, clergymen or reporters unless they obtain specific approval from top officials.

title: BURRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Kean Signs Bill On Car Inspection
description: Governor Kean signed into law today a bill extending for two years the motor-vehicle inspection program that allows drivers to take their cars to state stations or private garages for an annual safety test.

title: O'Neill Will Not Seek
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would abandon for now any effort to raise Connecticut's drinking age to 21 because the New York State Assembly rejected such a move earlier in the day.

title: TWO WASHINGTONS WITH A CAPITAL W
description: The Washington native is considered an oddity in this city of transients. But two of this country's better known architects have grown up here, make their homes here and are a part of the city's establishment.

title: CREEDMOOR AIDE INDICTED OVER DEATH
description: A nurse's aide at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens has been indicted on charges of strangling a mentally ill patient, prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Wilkins Foundation

title: HERS
description: WHEN I think of freedom and women I am often reminded of a comment made by Vassilis Vitsaxis, an old friend who was once Greece's Ambassador to India. Each freedom, he would say, is its own cage. Perhaps too, each success. Once achieved, both have a strange way of limiting one from looking beyond. As I look back, at myself and other Indian women I know, it seems that some of the freedoms gained at particular moments have, in time, negated themselves.

title: WIDCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $247,939 from the sale of securities.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page caption in some editions yesterday incorrectly identified two winners of a competition to design a memorial in New York City for Vietnam War veterans. William Britt Fellows was at the right and Joseph Ferrandino was beside him.

title: BRIEFING
description: Lenkowsky Redux

title: The U.N. Today May 31, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: OFF BROADWAY'S SPARKLING BREVITY
description: IT is no secret that this was an extremely inhospitable season for

title: HOW MUCH WILDERNESS IS ENOUGH?
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Lewis Departs
description: After 13 years in the National Football League, the wide receiver Frank Lewis is leaving because of injuries that kept him out of five games with the Buffalo Bills last season. In announcing that the 36-year-old Lewis had failed his preseason physical and would not return to the club, Coach Kay Stephenson praised him as a ''totally dedicated'' team player who was best under pressure and came through with the big catch in critical situations.

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CITY'S SAVINGS BANKS PRESSED
description: Several major savings banks in New York are urgently seeking private investors to bolster the banks' capital accounts as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been increasing pressure to get them to resolve their problems.

title: NICARAGUA BLAST SAID TO WOUND A REBEL LEADER
description: The Nicaraguan rebel commander, Eden Pastora Gomez, was seriously wounded in a bomb attack Wednesday that killed three Costa Rican journalists and wounded 20 people, including foreign journalists, a Costa Rican radio reported.

title: Mr. Vergari's Scorn
description: Remember the withering scorn that Carl Vergari, the prosecutor of New York's Westchester County, poured all over Judge Lawrence Martin two years ago for taking such pains to deal fairly with the Stouffer's Inn fire case? He accused the judge of committing a ''gross perversion of justice'' amounting to ''judicial impropriety'' when he set aside the jury's verdicts of guilty to arson and murder against Luis Marin, a hotel coffee waiter. Now who looks perverse and improper?

title: TASS SAYS SAKHAROV IS EATING AND FEELS WELL
description: The Government press agency Tass said today that Andrei D. Sakharov, who was reported to have begun a hunger strike on May 2, was eating regularly and feeling well.

title: AN ARBITRATION PLAN GAINS IN POPULARITY
description: NICHOLAS BARONE, an upholsterer who lives in Queens, bought a 1979 Pontiac Bonneville in the fall of 1978. When the odometer read 11,000 miles the engine failed, and Mr. Barone had to pay $1,600 to have it rebuilt. Eight months later, the transmission broke. That cost him $400 to fix.

title: U.S. BACKS ARAB BID IN U.N. TO CONDEMN SHIP ATTACKS BY IRAN
description: The United States today backed efforts by a group of Arab nations for the Security Council to condemn Iran for attacks on commercial shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: ROCK BAND: THE NEVILLES
description: -style funk, there's still no better band than the Neville Brothers, who played Tuesday at a hugely overcrowded Lone Star Cafe. The band's songs mesh voices, percussion and percussively played keyboards and guitar into complex, kinetic, syncopated rhythms.

title: ALLIED NURSING CARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Batboy Is Thrown Out
description: Sam Morris seemed pretty shaken Monday night when he arrived at the Portland Beavers' locker room after being ejected from a Pacific Coast League game against Vancouver. No wonder.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COLLEGE FOOTBALL PLAYOFFS HELD FEASIBLE
description: A special committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has concluded that national championship football playoffs can be established as early as January 1986, but only if they are limited to no more than four teams chosen from among the winners of the traditional bowl games.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS WITH MUCH IN COMMON VIE IN NEW JERSEY
description: Jeffrey Laurenti and James C. Hedden have much in common, despite their political differences.

title: U.S. HOLDS ITALY TO SCORELESS SOCCER TIE
description: The United States national team held Italy, the defending World Cup champion, to a scoreless tie tonight in an international soccer match in heavy rain at Giants Stadium.

title: Einhorn Heads U.S.F.L. Team
description: Eddie Einhorn, president of the Chicago White Sox, said today he had completed the deal for a new United States Football League franchise in Chicago that he hopes will ''rise from the ashes'' of the current Blitz team, which goes out of business after this season.

title: 23 ARE HURT AS STRIKING MINERS AND POLICE CLASH AGAIN IN ENGLAND
description: Striking coal miners clashed with the police for the second day at the gates of a coke plant outside this steel and coal center in northern England today. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called the rising violence in the 12- week-old national strike ''a fight that goes to the heart of our society.''

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Gallup Reports Reagan Leads Mondale and Hart
description: President Reagan continues to lead both Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart among potential voters, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: 2-Hitter By Cubs Wins, 6-2
description: Steve Trout flirted with a no-hitter for seven and two-thirds innings, then got relief help as he and Lee Smith combined for a two-hitter tonight in leading the Chicago Cubs to a 6-2 triumph over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Minor Leaguers Invest Time Well
description: Two young men attempting to work their way through the Mets' minor league system to the parent club have another profession to fall back upon if their baseball dreams are not fulfilled.

title: JACKSON ATTACKS MCGOVERN PLEA FOR MONDALE-HART 'UNITY' TICKET
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that former Senator George McGovern, by endorsing a Democratic ticket consisting of Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart, had given up his role as the ''conscience of the party.'' Mr. Jackson said that as a result he would contribute to but not attend a fund-raising event in Los Angeles Friday for Mr. McGovern. The event, to help the former South Dakota Senator retire the debt he incurred in his Presdidential campaign before he dropped out last March, was originally planned to include all three remaining Democratic candidates and provide ''a party unity tableau'' as the 1984 Presidential primaries ended.

title: PARADE MAGAZINE PUBLISHER
description: Arthur H. Motley, a onetime Fuller brush salesman who became president and publisher of the fledgling Parade Magazine and turned it into one of the most profitable Sunday supplements in newspaper history, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif. Mr. Motley, who retired in 1978, was 83 years old and had lived in Palm Springs for several years.

title: Author Reflects
description: Graig Nettles, author and third baseman, spent an hour during the early part of a rainy afternoon yesterday at the Barnes & Noble Bookstore on Fifth Avenue, autographing about 300 copies of the book, ''Balls,'' which he wrote with Peter Golenbock. Since its publication by G. P. Putnam's Sons in late April, about 85,000 copies have been sold, and it is seventh on the New York Times bestseller list.

title: BLACK WORKER WINS $1.5 MILLION SUIT
description: For almost nine years, Ben Citchen says, he went to work dreading what the day might bring: a dead rat in his lunchpail, a noose hung over his work station. His car was vandalized and racial slurs were scribbled on the floor and walls near where he worked, he says.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page photo caption yesterday incorrectly described the vehicles ridden by Maggie Kent and Bruce Ross on Block Island, R.I. They are small motorcycles owned by their riders.

title: JOB SQUEEZE AS BROKERAGES RETRENCH
description: As markets weaken, many Wall Street firms are retrenching. And when Wall Street firms retrench, that means heavy cuts in employment.

title: AT THE SUMMIT'S FOOT
description: The costs of the last four years of recession in the countries of the developing world have reached far beyond those poor nations, taking a significant toll in the United States. Continued slow growth in the third world will be a strong drag on growth in the industrialized countries. The developed and less developed countries have a considerable interest in working together to halt and reverse these trends.

title: Educator Opposes Bill As Threat to Colleges
description: The president of Grove City College said today that proposed civil rights legislation would end the independence of private schools that had declined Federal assistance to avoid the strings that come attached to the money.

title: Success Story
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits are one of the success stories of the United States Football League this year, even without Burt Reynolds's visible help.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Results are for 53 weeks for the latest year and 52 weeks for the previous year.

title: UNICORP CANADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $4.2 million gain on issuance to public of shares by a controlled subsidiary at a price over Unicorp's carrying costs in the company.

title: CALENDAR: BOSTON CRAFTSMEN'S FURNITURE
description: Boston Influence in Furniture Design, Pritam & Eames, 29 Race

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD HAWAII'S STATUTE ON LAND REFORM
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a major land reform program in Hawaii, ruling 8 to 0 that a state may use its power of eminent domain to break up large estates and transfer land ownership to the estates' tenants.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FLORIDA WASTE COMPANY CLEARED OF U.S. CHARGES INVOLVING PCB'S
description: A Jacksonville waste disposal company and two of its past officers who were charged with defrauding the Government were found not guilty by a Federal jury Tuesday.

title: VAN DER ZEE SUIT SETTLED
description: The court battle over possession of more than 50,000 works by James Van Der Zee, the photographer who chronicled Harlem life for half a century, was ended yesterday with a settlement between the photographer's estate and the Studio Museum in Harlem.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SOFTWARE HITS MACHINE LIMITS
description: COMPUTER retailers like to say these days that ''software drives the market.'' What they mean is that many of their customers could not care less about the computer they buy, but are primarily interested in whether the programs designed for it will keep their books, churn out their letters or foresee their business problems. Although software fanatics rejoice at anything that is faster, cheaper and quicker, most learn quickly that it is impossible to divorce a program from the computer that is designed to run it.

title: Military Contracts To Boeing, Others
description: The Boeing Military Airplane Company, a unit of the Boeing Company, received a $199.7 million contract from the Air Force for re-engine modification kits, the Defense Department said.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HUNTER HONORS MISS MACLAINE WITH DOCTORATE
description: Shirley MacLaine, adding an honorary doctorate of humane letters to a new Oscar and a newly published book, thanked Hunter College at its commencement yesterday for ''recognizing that I did it the hard way: without an education.''

title: MEARS MAKES PITCH FOR HIS 'SPORT'
description: Near the end of a month in which Rick Mears achieved record speeds with his bright yellow racing car, one of his most remarkable feats occurred on a street in New York. Anyone who has stood in the rain and waited impatiently for an attendant to return a parked car can appreciate the magnitude of his accomplishment. When Mears emerged from lunch, the yellow racer was already at the curb.

title: STRONG DOLLAR CITED
description: The nation's trade deficit widened in April to $12.2 billion, more than 18 percent greater than the deficit in March, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the fourth consecutive record monthly gap between imports and exports.

title: NATO'S MINISTERS DISCUSS OPTIONS ON PERSIAN GULF
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other NATO foreign ministers discussed today what steps, if any, their nations could take individually to limit the spread of the conflict in the Persian Gulf, alliance officials said.

title: Cranston Dissatisfied With Party Arms Stand
description: Senator Alan Cranston, who withdrew from the Democratic Presidential race, says he is ''not totally satisfied'' with the nuclear arms stands of any of the remaining contenders.

title: Foot in the Door
description: Greg Wright decided one day in college he'd like to try punting ''because there was no one else on the team to do it; the other guy graduated.''

title: AROUND THE BATTING CAGE
description: ATLANTA About three weeks ago, a voice on

title: 2 Israelis Acknowledge Failure to Tell of Bomb
description: Two officers in Israel's military command in the occupied West Bank admitted Tuesday through their attorneys that they knew in 1980 of a Jewish terrorist bomb plot against an Arab Mayor and did nothing to warn anyone.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Movable Feast

title: THE 16-MILLIMETER FILM IS CELEBRATED AT FESTIVAL
description: Librarians, not movie stars, are among the judges. The winners will get blue ribbons encased in Lucite rather than statuettes called Oscar, and most of the films will have their major showings in school and college classrooms, not anywhere named Loews or RKO.

title: TOLL OF WIND ON HOMES
description: Wind causes about $4 billion in damage to American homes each year, but more than half the loss could be prevented by sturdier construction at only 5 percent additional cost, according to a wind engineering expert.

title: DRINKING AGE: CUOMO'S LOSS AND WHAT HE MAY STILL GAIN
description: In the world of Albany, Governor Cuomo suffered a considerable defeat early today when the Assembly rejected his call for an increase in New York State's drinking age. But to the voters, Mr. Cuomo may still come out a winner as he continues his crusade on this popular issue. As the Governor said, victory would have been better for him than defeat. But even in defeat - a defeat Mr. Cuomo promised was just the first skirmish in a battle to increase the drinking age - the Governor established himself in the vanguard of a national issue.

title: Philips Video Recorder
description: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, said today that it would start selling its VHS- type videotape recorder in Europe this fall. Philips jointly developed the V2000-type recorder with Grundig A.G. of West Germany.

title: UNDERFED LIBRARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Massey Profit First in 4 Years
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., which has lost more than $1 billion since 1978, today announced its first quarterly profit in four years. The company, at its annual meeting, reported profits of $2.4 million for the quarter ended April 30, compared with a loss of $17.9 million in the period a year earlier.

title: THE CLIENT CONFLICT ISSUE
description: THE year is moving toward its

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHIPPERS OFFERED DISCOUNT BY IRAN
description: Iran offered a $1.50-a-barrel discount yesterday to shippers willing to pick up oil from its war-torn Kharg Island oil export terminal. Oil analysts said Iran's action was intended to offset the higher insurance premiums that have been levied on tankers and freight because of recent attacks on shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: ; LONGER CITY KINDERGARTEN HOURS: THE BENEFITS AND THE COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLIONS IN SOUTH TREATED TO RARE VIEW OF SOLAR ECLIPSE
description: From Louisiana to North Carolina, people today were afforded a rare glimpse of a nearly total solar eclipse that turned noontime into an eerie twilight and briefly framed the black shadow of the Moon in a spectacular necklace of light.

title: GERMAN STRIKE SLOWING EUROPEAN AUTO OUTPUT
description: A strike by West German metalworkers for a 35-hour workweek is gradually crippling wide sectors of Europe's auto industry, including the subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation.

title: MAKING WEIGHT A PROBLEM FOR BUMPHUS
description: Johnny Bumphus is obviously getting too big for his World Boxing Association 140- pound championship belt. His first junior-welterweight title defense, Friday night here against Gene (Mad Dog) Hatcher, could well be his last.

title: WESTMORELAND V. CBS: LEGAL DRAMA INTENSIFIED BY 2 CONTRASTING LAWYERS
description: The legal matchup in Westmoreland v. CBS, like the military equation in Vietnam, appears at first to be something of a mismatch.

title: CALIFORNIA DRIVES SINGLE OUT HEAVILY HISPANIC AND JEWISH DISTRICTS
description: Strategists for both Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart have singled out Hispanic and Jewish voters in the Los Angeles area as critical swing constituencies in the June 5 Democratic Presidential primary, according to officials of the two campaigns.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Framed - in Poland
description: In Communist tyrannies, laws are harsh for all, but not for the state. For a bald example, consider a remarkable article in Poland's party paper, Trybuna Ludu, assailing four lawyers for taking their job too seriously. They have been accused of trying too hard to acquit political defendants, for forgetting that Polish justice serves society and its ''highest organizational formation, the state.'' To make the lesson plain, that high formation crudely framed one of the lawyers.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TO THINE OWN SELF BE TRUE
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, was asked on American television last month about allegations that two Arab terrorists had been captured and then killed by Israeli security forces. Those charges, he said, ''are not coming from people who are friends of Israel.''

title: DWIGHT HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DELOREAN LAND SALE AN ISSUE AS DRUG TRIAL IS IN 7TH WEEK
description: In a civil fight on the sidelines of John Z. DeLorean's trial on Federal charges of trafficking in cocaine, his lawyers once proposed calling the judge presiding over the criminal case as a witness in the automobile maker's behalf in the civil case, according to court documents.

title: SUBURBS FLOODED BY 3 DAYS OF RAIN
description: A continuing downpour flooded roads, caused power failures and forced scores of families out of their homes in the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

title: South African Students Rally on Behalf of Blacks
description: More than 1,000 students held a demonstration today on the campus of the University of the Witwatersrand, a major university where most of the students are white, to support black students campaigning for equal education.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The early part of the Cardinals' season has been a huge disappointment, largely because of their performance in close games. As they went into last night's game at Houston, the Cards had lost 9 of 11 games decided by one run.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JOURNEYS. By Jan Morris. 173 pages.

title: Women's Record Set in the 10,000
description: Kathy Hayes, an Oregon junior, won the women's 10,000-meter run tonight at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's track and field championships. She finished 20 meters ahead of Katie Ishmael of Wisconsin in 32 minutes 43.81 seconds, a collegiate record.

title: Ease on Abortions Proposed
description: Two Congressmen introduced a bill today that would eliminate restrictions on federally financed abortions for Medicaid recipients, Federal employees, Peace Corps volunteers and American Indians.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: G.E.-Israel Deal
description: Moshe Arens, Israel's Defense Minister, said his country will buy engines made by the General Electric Company for the 75 F-16 fighters Israel is buying from the United States, starting in 1986. He said the G.E. engines had been selected over the Pratt & Whitney engines that now power 75 F-16's already in the Israeli Air Force. No price was put on the engine deal.

title: Apple Copyright
description: The appeal bench of the federal court of Australia reversed an earlier ruling against Apple Computer Inc. that said a Taiwanese- made personal computer called Wombat did not infringe its copyright.

title: Pizza Units' Talks
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation said its Showbiz Pizza Place Inc. subsidiary is holding preliminary discussions on the possibility of combining with parts of Pizza Time Theater Inc. The companies said the discussions are very preliminary and there are significant legal issues to resolve. Pizza Time, which operates restaurant-entertainment centers, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on March 28.

title: EARLY-INFANCY LEARNING
description: ONE of the best things about ''Innovation,'' Channel 13's weekly series on health, science and technology, is its approachability. It doesn't patronize us; it doesn't intimidate us, either. The program tonight, ''The Developing Child,'' an exploration of intellectual and cognitive processes among infants, is a fine example. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock.

title: Koch Acts to End Bias in Pensions
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed adding $55 million to his executive budget for next year to cover increased payments to city pension funds.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Xerox Contract
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had agreed to sell electronic printers to the Control Data Corporation.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $343,000. c-Net loss

title: Rolling Stone Planning An Electronics Show
description: As with most youth-oriented magazines, especially those with a musical inclination, Rolling Stone's stereo and hi-fi advertising is a top category.

title: Kidney Study Hints at Gain
description: A combination of aspirin and a drug usually used as a heart medication appears to slow deterioration of the kidneys in certain diseases, doctors reported today. The drug dipyridamole taken with aspirin stabilized kidney deterioration in a rare disease called membranoproliferative glomerulonphritis, according to a Mayo Clinic study reported in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Bolivians May Delay On Debt
description: The Government and the powerful Bolivian Labor Confederation reached a preliminary agreement today to temporarily postpone payments on the $1.05 billion the country owes private Western banks while new terms are negotiated, Government officials said.

title: Knee Troubles Dawson
description: Andre Dawson, the Montreal Expos' power-hitting outfielder, is suffering from a longstanding knee ailment that may relegate him to part-time duty for the rest of the season. Dr. Bob Broderick , the team physician, said that the problem could be traced to an operation Dawson had as a teen-ager to repair a football injury. ''As a result of surgery when he was 16,'' Dr. Broderick said, ''he's got bone on bone in that knee. He's got almost no cushion in there between the bones.''

title: HOUSE APPROVES STIFF RULES TO CONTROL COST OF MILITARY SPARE PARTS
description: The House of Representatives approved strong new regulations tonight to control the cost of spare parts for military equipment as it continued debate on a bill to set ceilings on military spending for the 1985 fiscal year.

title: People
description: * Lawrence H. Spiegel elected an executive vice president of Tracy- Locke/BBDO, Dallas.

title: ARENS, OPENING TALKS IN U.S., SEES TIES 'BETTER THAN EVER'
description: The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, said today that the relationship between Israel and the United States was ''probably better than it ever has been before.''

title: COSEKA RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AVX Corp. , Great Neck, L.I., a manufacturer of multi-layer ceramic capacitors, said it had acquired Monolithic Components Corp., a San Diego-based maker of ceramic chip capacitors, for approximately 280,000 shares of AVX common stock.

title: NORTHLAND BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Rep. Gore to Run for Senate
description: United States Representative Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, announced today that he would try to follow his father's footsteps into the Senate. He hopes to succeed Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, who is not seeking re-election. Mr. Gore's father, Albert Sr., was a Senator from Tennessee from 1953 until 1971.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,735,000.

title: CHICKEN POX VACCINE FOUND EFFECTIVE IN TESTS
description: A vaccine against chicken pox has proved highly effective in protecting healthy children against the potentially dangerous disease, medical scientists reported yesterday.

title: Transco Leases
description: The Transco Energy Company, managing general partner of Transco Exploration Partners Ltd., said Transco Exploration and its partners had been awarded 22 of the 27 leases for which they submitted high bids during the Gulf of Mexico lease sale held April 24. The company said final acceptance of the other five bids was pending with the Department of Interior. Transco said it and its partners bid $98 million for all 27 leases, with Transco accounting for $29.5 milllion.

title: Admiral Asserts U. S. Ships Already Have Cruise Missiles
description: Adm. Sylvester R. Foley Jr., commander in chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, said today that the United States had started arming some of its ships in the Pacific with Tomahawk cruise missiles.

title: HART'S REMARK ON JERSEY HITS A NEW AND RAW NERVE
description: The Presidential primary in New Jersey next Tuesday has focused national attention on a place eager to show its new image, spirit and combativeness - as Senator Gary Hart has recently discovered.

title: Software Deal
description: -Computer Associates International Incorporated said it had acquired the assets of the Sorcim Corporation, which is involved in the microcomputer software market.

title: Ex-Nazi Suspect Loses Immigration Court Case
description: An immigration judge has denied political asylum for John Demjanjuk, accused of being former Nazi death camp guard, and he faces deportation, an official said Tuesday.

title: CROWN BOOKS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SEX BUSINESS IN TIMES SQUARE SAID TO DECREASE
description: The Koch administration released figures yesterday that cited a drop in the number of sex-related businesses and the number of crimes in the Times Square area.

title: Average Salesman Call Cost $205.40 Last Year
description: Since 1942, McGraw-Hill Research has been figuring on an every-other- year basis the cost of the average salesman's call.

title: QUINONES ELECTED AS SCHOOL CHIEF
description: Nathan Quinones, who has been running New York City's school system on a temporary basis for the last 10 weeks, was unanimously elected Schools Chancellor last night by the city's Board of Education.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $408,000 for the quarter and $597,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $228,000 for the quarter and $344,000 for the year.

title: ABUSE OF STUDENTS IN SCHOOL CHARGED
description: A fundamentalist Christian school was closed and its 57 students were sent home or taken into protective custody today after three school operators were jailed on charges involving the mistreatment of the students.

title: STAGE: MAMET'S LATEST
description: THE newest David Mamet play in town is ''Vermont Sketches,'' to be found on Series C in the Ensemble Studio Theater one-act-play marathon. Such is the high quality of Series C, however, that the three other plays on the bill can hold their own with Mr. Mamet's. Even by the E.S.T.'s standards, this chapter of the Marathon is densely packed with both new and seasoned talent in playwriting, acting and directing.

title: Antitakeover Law
description: A bill designed to discourage hostile takeovers of Michigan businesses has been signed by Gov. James Blanchard. A statement from the Governor's office on Tuesday said that hostile takeovers create ''the possible loss of industry and jobs.'' Proponents say the law will also protect minority shareholders in an unwanted merger by insuring a fair price for their holdings.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: In this political season, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is still listed as the associate minister of the Fellowship Missionary Baptist Church in Chicago, has turned a well-known pastorate into a Presidential campaign.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 228719 -- No Title
description: Denny's Inc. said today that it had received a $788.5 million offer from an investor group that includes its top executives to buy all of its common shares and take the restaurant chain private.

title: REPAIRING OR REPLACING FURNITURE LOCKS, KEYS
description: Any piece of furniture with a smoothly functioning lock, fitting snugly into the wood and with a working key, has usually been carefully maintained. But keys get lost, locks get damaged or the internal works corrode with rust, making replacements necessary.

title: A LITTLE JUSTICE IN SALVADOR
description: Last week, five courageous jurors in Zacatecoluca, El Salvador, convicted five former members of the Salvadoran national guard of murdering four United States churchwomen - including my sister Ita - in December 1980. The conviction brought to an end more than three long years of frustrations and delays in our efforts to help bring this case to trial. But more than an end, the verdict is a beginning, a first step toward justice in El Salvador.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
VERSATILE LADDERS
description: -step stool or full size, is one of the handiest tools for a homeowner. There are two new ladder styles available, one large, one small, that will provide support for many jobs.

title: Troops in Haiti Kill 3 To Quell Food Protests
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 30 (Reuters) - Troops killed three people in Cap-Ha"itien in renewed food rioting on Tuesday, Government officials said today.

title: CELTICS PLAN TO SLOW LAKERS
description: With a payroll of $7,250,000 that will grow to well over $8 million next season, the Los Angeles Lakers are the highest-salaried team in National Basketball Association history. They are paid to run.

title: 2 DOMINICANS DEFEND REBUFF TO I.M.F.
description: Two Government ministers said today that the Dominican Republic would have faced full- scale civil strife last week if it had agreed to demands from the International Monetary Fund to raise the price of gasoline and other oil products as a condition for new loans.

title: Zhao Presses Soviet And U.S. on Arms Talks
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to stop deploying nuclear weapons and to return to serious arms talks.

title: ON CITING POVERTY AS CAUSE OF CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'WILLIAM TELL' IN SAN ANTONIO
description: SAN ANTONIO NOW in its second year, the San Antonio Festival is like some amiable bear cub: big, voracious, appealing and a little erratic. Fathered by an enthusiastic artistic entrepreneur named Parvan Bakardjiev, this year's festival runs from May 18 to June 9, encompassing 93 events performed by some 40 groups on 11 stages.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DISTRIBUTED LOGIC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Energy-Use Forecast
description: Energy demand in the non- Communist world will rise at an average annual rate of 2 percent through the year 2000, Ralph Bailey, chief executive of Conoco Inc., said today at the 13th annual meeting of the Indonesian Petroleum Association.

title: DYLEX LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
THOMAS NELSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When to Bank on Congress
description: When there's no crisis, Congress would rather do almost anything than pass banking laws. It's much easier to look the other way because there are so many conflicting interests in play - big banks and small, savings and loan associations, insurance companies, stockbrokers.

title: THE ENDURING FASCINATION OF SECRET PLACES
description: AS a magician in a family of magicians, Dakota Jackson learned from an early age to make the type of stage furniture in which a blonde might be sawed in two. When, in the late 1960's, he decided to apply his skills to making more comfortable and conventional pieces on a commercial basis, the former magician succeeded in transferring an element of magic while eliminating the discomfort. Mr. Jackson built furniture with secret compartments that could be opened by arcane movements known only to the person for whom it was designed.

title: Sikh Terrorists Kill 12 In New Attacks in India
description: Sikh terrorists made hit-and-run attacks that killed 12 people in the northern state of Punjab, the police said today, and Sikh activists announced plans to block the flow of grain and water to neighboring states.

title: Air Florida Ticket Status
description: Air Florida said today that its emergency $5 million loan had won it readmittance to an industry ticket clearinghouse a day after being ousted for failure to pay a $2 million bill. But an officer for the clearinghouse said the reinstatement was not yet official, although Air Florida had given it notice that it intended to meet all the necessary conditions.

title: BRINK OF ARMED SPACE
description: If the United States goes ahead with planned testing and production of anti-satellite weapons (ASAT's in the jargon), this will be the command center for using them.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Year to April 30
PENTAGON BARS NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced yesterday that the Defense Logistics Agency of the Defense Department had notified the company that it had been barred as a supplier of aerospace products for the military.

title: Bid for Conrail
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Robert B. Claytor, said the company's directors had authorized submitting a bid for Conrail to the Department of Transportation.

title: MONDALE PREDICTS VICTORY AS HE BEGINS FINAL CALIFORNIA DRIVE
description: Walter F. Mondale today opened his final campaign swing in California before next Tuesday's crucial Democratic Presidential primary in the state, appealing to three key constituencies: environmentalists, the elderly and women.

title: Upper Volta Said to Foil Plot to Stage Coup
description: A plot to overthrow the Government of Upper Volta was foiled by the arrest of a dozen soldiers, Agence France-Presse reported today.

title: RESTORING HISTORIC FRATERNITY HOUSES
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Cyprus-Egypt Ties Restored
description: Cyprus and Egypt resumed diplomatic relations today after a break of six years. In February 1978 President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt broke relations after 18 Egyptian commandos were shot down by Cypriot troops when they tried to storm a hijacked Cyprus Airways airliner despite the Cyprus Government's refusal to give its permission for the operation.

title: 2 Die in Nebraska Explosion
description: An explosion and fire at a grain elevator killed two people today and prompted the evacuation of all 50 residents from this eastern Nebraska farming community, the authorities said. The Seward County Sheriff's Department said two people were killed in the explosion at the Blue Valley Co-op about 1:30 P.M.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ACCESSORIES BY ARCHITECTS
description: RECENTLY and because this venture is what they call their maiden voyage, Nan Swid, right, and Addie Powell, far right, admitted that they ''haven't been sleeping too well at night.'' Over a year and a half ago, the partners started Swid Powell, a company that is developing table-top accessories by well-known modern architects and designers.

title: PERIPATETIC ENGLISH TRYING OUT FOR JETS
description: As a high school star, he received as many honors as any quarterback now starring in the National Football League. But today, Jon English turned up at the Jets' minicamp as one of 63 free agents hoping to make the team, along with 15 draft picks.

title: No Headline
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Margate Bay fluke angling remains first-rate. The foul

title: SALES OF NEW HOUSES DECLINED 4.9% IN APRIL
description: Sales of new houses dropped 4.9 percent in April, the Government reported today, with builders blaming high interest rates.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IRISH In one of the last Fifth Avenue town houses, at No. 911, near 81st Street, the American Irish Historical Society puts a roof over the books and papers and pictures and artifacts that are the milestones in the story of the Irish both here and in Ireland.

title: CUOMO TO 'FIGHT LIKE HECK' TO REVIVE DRINKING-AGE BILL
description: Hours after the Legislature rebuffed his efforts to raise the state's legal drinking age from 19 to 21, Governor Cuomo vowed today to ''fight like heck'' across the state for the proposal.

title: HYDRO PLAN CALLED 'DEAD' FOR YEAR
description: Governor Cuomo said today that his plan to reallocate huge amounts of cheap hydroelectricity from the Niagara and St. Lawrence projects was dead for this year.

title: CITY BALLET: THE NEW AND THE FAMILIAR
description: THREE new performances and a dazzling familiar one enlivened an uneven program by the New York City Ballet Tuesday in the New York State Theater.

title: Alaska Housing Bonds Offered
description: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation is offering $100 million of housing bonds with a maximum yield of 11 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: U.S. ASSAILS SOVIET ON ENVOY ASSAULT
description: The State Department has filed a formal protest with the Soviet Union about an assault on an American diplomat in Leningrad by several young men last month, officials of the department said today.

title: BOB AND RAY AT PLAY IN CARNEGIE HALL
description: And now . . . the team that brought you Mary Backstayge, Noble Wife; the Komodo-Dragon Expert; Elmer W. Litzinger, Spy; Interviewer Wally Ballou, who makes Howard Cosell seem acutely sensitive, and Einbinder Flypaper (seldom fatal to parakeets even if they fly directly into it), is coming to Carnegie Hall.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
REVLON: COSMETICS SHOW THEIR AGE
description: The company is still known for its Charlie scent and its Flex shampoo, but the bulk of the dollars these days comes from such things as plasma derivatives and lens grinders.

title: TEXT OF ADDRESS BY PRESIDENT AT COMMENCEMENT
description: Following is the prepared text of President Reagan's commencement address here today to graduates of the United States Air Force Academy:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Delegation Demographics

title: G.O.P. ADS ACCUSE O'NEILL OF ABUSE POWER
description: Two new Republican television commercials, accusing House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of abuse of power, depict George Washington and Thomas Jefferson weeping at the sorry state of the House of Representatives.

title: WAR MAKES LEBANON AN ECOLOGICAL DISASTER ZONE
description: Lebanon is one of the few countries in the world where the stick of dynamite is the preferred means of catching fish.

title: HAWAIIANS FORESEE CHANGE IN HOMEOWNERS' STATUS
description: The Supreme Court's decision upholding the Hawaii Land Reform Act of 1967 was described in Honolulu yesterday as a landmark ruling that would bring significant long-term change to Hawaii's middle class.

MARY-KATHERINE BELL
description: -Katherine Bell, a former Manhattan lawyer whose legal career spanned 40 years, died last Thursday at her home in New Canaan, Conn.

description: b-After a charge of $110,000 incurred in connection with a terminated public offering. c-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $160,000.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the quarter and $83,000 for the 6 months.

title: ADS FOR BOGUS CURES UNDER ATTACK
description: The Food and Drug Administration and the Council of Better Business Bureaus today offered to help newspapers and magazines screen out advertising for fraudulent medical products.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EX-COACH IS SUED
description: The University of Texas-El Paso has filed a civil lawsuit against its former track coach for setting up a special bank account for athletes, college officials said today.

title: Liverpool Captures Cup
description: Liverpool, exposing nerves of British steel to the power of favored Roma and its feverishly partisan hometown soccer crowd of 69,693, won the European Cup tonight on penalty kicks, 5-3. It was the fourth time in eight years that Liverpool captured the silver trophy, and it capped a season in which the team won the English League championship for the 15th time.

title: DISPUTE OVER TONY AWARDS
description: ON the eve of the 1984 Tony Awards, the four major groups of theater artists are battling producers for a larger role in the awards.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $174,000.

title: IRAQ SAYS ITS JETS HIT ANOTHER SHIP
description: Iraq said today that its jet planes had attacked and hit another large ship in the Persian Gulf south of Iran's principal export terminal at Kharg Island.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 31, 1984
description: The Economy

title: DESIGN DIVERSITY OF ILONKA KARASZ
description: The modernist and illustrator Ilonka Karasz, who lived from 1896 to 1981, turned her talents to a wide variety of subjects - furniture, fabrics, ceramics and wallpaper, as well as the magazine illustrations for which she was best known.

title: GUIDRY REVIVES WITH A 7-HITTER
description: When the season is only two months old and a team is in next-to-last place, 17 1/2 games out of first, and when that team is the Yankees, even the easiest of victories means only so much.

title: QUEBEC STURGEON RIVER MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Singapore Oil Trade Off
description: The value of Singapore's petroleum trade declined 10 percent in 1983, reflecting a worldwide oil industry slump, the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce said today. While Singapore's total import bill fell by 1 percent last year, imports of crude oil dropped 12 percent, to $6.7 billion, the chamber said.

title: Circus Circus
description: A $100 million issue of Circus Circus Enterprises 15 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1994 is offered at a price of 98.16 to yield 16 1/8 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Proceeds of the speculative grade notes, rated B-1/B, will be used to finance new hotel facilities.

title: JURY IS TOLD JUDGE WAS IN 'BRIBE CLUB'
description: R. SHIPP

title: A BANKRUPTCY JUDGE IN U.S. DISTRICT COURT
description: John J. Galgay, a United States District Court bankruptcy judge in Manhattan, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: FOR BIKE RACERS, OLYMPICS ARE ALWAYS IN MIND
description: The blue and white sign read, ''Road Closed: Bike Race Today,'' and it glistened with beads of water as a steady rain continued to fall only minutes before the start of a 24-mile race in Central Park yesterday morning. Women cyclists - wearing the colorful shirts identifying their familiar commercial sponsors - pedaled along the deserted course during the warm-ups, mindful of puddles and slick spots, feeling generally uncomfortable. For a select few, there was more than one reason to exercise caution - a rule of the road that is not always sound strategy in a bicycle race.

title: AUSTRIAN NETWORK A DOOR OPENING WEST TO EAST
description: VIENNAWhen he looks out the window, he sees the Palace of Sch"onbrunn where Mozart played for Empress Maria Theresa and her ill-fated young daughter Marie Antoinette. It is a suitable vista for Gerd Bacher, director general of ORF - Austrian Radio and Television - who likes to give Austria's artistic heritage a proper airing.

title: Upsets Mark Tennis Trials
description: Richard Matuszewski of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., stunned top-seeded Lawson Duncan of Asheville, N.C., 6-1, 7-6, and Larry Scott of Merrick, L.I., was an 0-6, 7-5, 6-4 winner over third-seeded Michael Kures in the fourth round of the Olympic tennis trials yesterday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows. Like Matuszewski, Scott is a late developer.

title: ON A CARIB RESERVE, FRAGMENTS OF A MIGHTY PAST
description: Traces of the once powerful civilization are now primarily in the almond-shaped eyes and straight black hair. The language has been lost to the centuries, as have the rituals.

title: Housing Officer Kills a Suspect
description: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot by a Housing Authority police officer early yesterday after he pointed what turned out to be an inoperable replica of a .38-caliber revolver at the officer's partner, the housing police said.

title: Williams Hails Boston
description: There was no cap to tip, but this time it wasn't needed. Ted Williams , speaking for himself and Joe Cronin Tuesday night at a Fenway Park ceremony in which their numbers were retired by the Boston Red Sox, said everything there was to say when he told the crowd, ''Baseball is the greatest in Boston, and the fans are the greatest - and I salute you.''

title: THURSDAY, MAY 31, 1984 International
description: The Persian Gulf war was discussed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other NATO foreign ministers in an 18th-century mansion on the Maryland shore. Alliance officials said the ministers had talked about what steps, if any, NATO members could take individually to limit the spread of the conflict, but reached no decisions. (Page A1, Column 1.) Meanwhile, Iraq reported hitting another large ship near Iran's main oil terminal. (A7:1.) The American trade deficit soared in April by more than 18 percent, to $12.2 billion, the fourth successive monthly record, the Commerce Department reported. Imports, driven by the expanding economy and the continued exceptional strength of the dollar, rose 6.1 percent while exports fell 1.1 percent from March levels. (A1:2.)

description: b-Including a gain of $638,000 from discontinued operations.

Devil Decision Due
description: The Devils will announce their head-coaching plans for next season at a news conference here Thursday, and there were some indications today that Tom McVie would be replaced.

STEPHEN A. KOSHLAND
description: Stephen A. Koshland, an active member of the New York Stock Exchange for more than 50 years, died in Bellevue Hospital Saturday of injuries from a traffic accident. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ANNUALS THAT NEED A MINIMUM OF CARE
description: GARDEN centers, florists, supermarkets and discount houses are colorful now with small flats of annual seedlings on sale. Because the young plants are in bloom, selection is easy for a panorama of summer flowers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Wrenched From the Past
description: To the joy of scholars, the intact tomb of a Mayan lord has just come to light in northern Guatemala. Its treasures were rarer for having been found in context, like bits of a puzzle gathered in a single capsule. Pieced together, they form a miniature portrait of a civilization that was in flower when London was a muddy village and Rome was in decay.

title: LEBANESE LOSING IDENTITY IN A RETREAT INTO FACTIONS
description: In a sense, the Lebanese are becoming extinct. It is not that they are dying off, although they are doing that, too. It is that the number of people in Lebanon who think of themselves and identify themselves as ''Lebanese'' - as opposed to members of a religious group - is becoming smaller and smaller.

title: Soviet Goalie Retires
description: Vladislav Tretyak , the outstanding Soviet goaltender, has announced his retirement from the national hockey team, but not apparently to join the Montreal Canadiens. According to Tass, the Soviet press agency, the 32- year-old Tretyak plans to devote himself to coaching young goalies at the Central Army Sports Club, where he and more than half his national teammates train.

description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company asked state lawmakers today to loosen Illinois banking restrictions to allow its purchase by an out-of-state institution.

description: J. P. Stevens & Company said yesterday that improved textile sales helped triple its profits in the second quarter, to $4.6 million, from $1.5 million in the period a year earlier.

PROSPECTS FOR SUMMER RALLY
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average rebounding yesterday to close above 1,100, investors can expect to start hearing Wall Street predictions of the ''traditional summer rally.'' But they might be advised to look twice before leaping into equities even at current depressed prices.

title: 2-Way System Cuts False Alarms
description: False fire alarms have dropped 67 percent since alarm boxes that force callers to talk to dispatchers have been installed, Fire Department officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: The National Gallery of Art, in Washington, has just acquired a very important late painting by the 16th-century Venetian painter Paolo Veronese. ''The Martyrdom and Last Communion of St. Lucy'' was until lately in a British private collection and is well known to Veronese scholars.

title: HEALTH FRAUDS SAID TO PREY ON ELDERLY
description: Congressional investigators said today that promoters of health frauds and quack remedies were cheating elderly Americans out of more than $10 billion a year.

title: PENSION FUND TO DIVEST SOUTH AFRICAN HOLDINGS
description: A majority of the trustees of New York City's largest pension fund said yesterday that they had agreed on a plan to withdraw city investments from companies doing business with the South African Government.

title: Brazil Limits Steel for U.S.;  Brazil Limits Steel for U.S.
description: The Government has reduced its steel exports to the United States by more than 50 percent following heavy import duties levied by the United States, the federal trade bureau, Cacex, announced today.

title: A.T.&T. MARKETING SHIFT SEEN
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company scheduled a news conference for this morning to make what it called ''a major announcement for consumers'' using the company's long-distance service.
